text: At first glance, I thought this seemed like just the usual can opener.  I doubted the "Smooth Edge" claim.  But, after opening many cans now, I have to admit...these really do leave a smooth edge behind.  I also liked the ease of attaching the opener to the can.  Some openers struggle to get a good grip on the can, but this one digs right in.I will point out though that, like many can openers, the lid may not always completely release at the every end.  It may hold on by just a thread of metal.  But a little twist of the lid will finish the job.  As a result, you may find that one tiny connection point sticks out a bit even though the rest of the can is smooth.Add to this its modern look and feel, and this is a really nice can opener.  I have a few can openers in my kitchen.  This will now be my go-to opener.Reviewer's note: I received this can opener free for the purpose of testing and reviewing.

In short, the sound and Bluetooth connectivity of these headphones are great.  The fit is pretty good, even given my weird ears.Some details:Connectivity is smooth and quick.  On my Galaxy S6, there is roughly only a 1-second wait time between turning on the earphones and actually being connected to Bluetooth.Sound is very good.  For podcasts and music, the quality is quite good.  Normally, I expect to sacrifice sound quality for sports-based headphones.  Here, though, the sound is much better than I expected.  This may partially be due to the snug fit in my ears.Good sound control: Some Bluetooth headphones simply adjust your phone's actual volume.  These, on the other hand, actually have their own volume control, independent of the phone.  So, use your phone's volume to set a "max" for your headphones, and then you can use your headphone's volume control to adjust from silent up to that max.The fit is pretty good.  One of my ear openings is slightly larger than the other, and so it's nice that there are three different tip sizes included.  My only complaint is that the little "wings" that help hold these in my ears don't seem to do a bit of good.  Perhaps I am using them incorrectly?  I cannot seem to figure out any way to use these effectively.  For my workouts (mostly weight training), the earbuds stay in place well.  But for running, I wish the wings did a better job.All in all, a decent seat of Bluetooth headphones: good sound and connectivity for the price!Reviewer's note: I received these headphones free for the purpose of testing and reviewing.

This is such a handy tool, I now keep it in my backpack so that it is always handy.  The stick is solidly built, and the lanyard is a nice safety feature so that you won't lose your camera if you accidentally let go of the stick.Given that the stick has a standard tripod mount, you can mount nearly any kind of camera on the end of it.  I have a holder for my Galaxy S6 and my wife's iPhone 6.  Either of these can attach to this stick.What makes this better than one of those telescoping "selfie sticks"?  Primarily, it is very sturdy.  I have played around with selfie sticks and would not trust them with any serious action.  But this offering from Ho Stevie! is designed to endure the same kinds of bumps and jumps that the GoPro can handle.So, if you're just looking for something for taking selfies in your backyard, this probably isn't the right choice.  But if you want to run, jump, bike, or swim with your camera, this Floating GoPro Grip Stick is a great choice!Note: I received this stick free for the purpose of testing and providing an unbiased review.

I was impressed with the quality of this lock, given its low price.  Once connected to your laptop, this lock serves as a good theft deterrent.  It has a solid look and feel.  I am currently using it on my somewhat older (2011-ish) Macbook Pro with no problem.This style of lock is "universal" in that it fits a LOT of different laptops, but certainly not all.  My Asus Chromebook and Macbook Air are not designed to work with this kind of lock.  Do a little research before ordering, to be sure you are getting the right kind of lock.Regarding setup: BE CAREFUL.  Selecting and setting a combination for the lock is straightforward.  But if you make a mistake, you may never know what combination you set unless you are willing to try all 10,000 combinations.  I nearly messed up in this process, partly because my 47-year-old eyeballs could not adequately read the tiny numbers on the combination dial.  When setting it up, you need to press a little button on the lock while you turn the dials to your desired combination.  This is probably best accomplished with an extra set of hands, because pressing that button requires a fair bit of pressure.  So, while your hands are busy holding in that button, you might ask someone else to set the numbers for you (and that extra set of eyes could be useful as well).I certainly recommend this lock, despite the slightly tricky setup.  Once that combination is set, you'll have a solid theft-preventer for your laptop.Reviewer's note: I received this security cable free for the purpose of testing and providing an unbiased review.

I was skeptical that these would work, but it turns out that they live up to their claims: they do save space, and they do stay sealed.Many "space saving" bags required some kind of device to suck out the air.  These do not.  Essentially, these are like very large "ziploc" bags.  You remove air from them by mostly sealing them, then rolling them to push out as much air as possible, and then completely sealing them.And they work.  I put a pair of jeans (that's about the width of these bags...wide enough to hold a folded pair of jeans), a couple of t-shirts, and a pair of socks into a bag.  Then, I followed the mostly-seal-then-roll-then-finish-sealing procedure.  That was enough to remove nearly all the air from the bag.  Then, we got on the road for our trip.  4 hours later, the bagged clothing was still just as sealed as when we started.All in all, these are great bags for traveling!Reviewer's note: I received these bags freee for the purpose of testing and reviewing.

This is a solid turner, great for stirring and tossing in a non-stick pan (and any other pan for that matter).I like the feel of the rubber handle, and it seems to be nicely secured to the wood.  In other words, it hasn't slid or rotated on the handle.  I do have a bit of concern that water could get between the rubber and the wood, but this would only be a problem if you let it soak in water (which you shouldn't do anyway).If I could cite one minor issue, it would be this: When I use this for stirring ground beef, bits of the meat end up getting caught in the slots.  It takes a little extra effort to remove these.  So, just be diligent about cleanup.

For both my Galaxy S6 and my wife's iPhone 6, this is a sturdy and reliable car mount.I've attached it to the dashboard and to the windshield.  In both cases, it attaches very easily...almost effortlessly...and then stays put.The arm is flexible, allowing me to twist and turn my phone until it is at just the angle I need, and then it stays in place.I will say that at first I was put off by the "sticky" feel of the suction pad.  Then I realized this is the intention.  That stickiness gives the car mount a little extra stability.  Apparently the stickiness is mean to last a long time: the instructions say to wash the suction with warm water in order to refresh it.Finally, I like how easily the clip will open to accommodate a variety of phones.  It, like the rest of the mount, is very sturdy: once you put your phone in, it's not going to come out.I highly recommend this if you are looking for a reliable, quick-and-easy way to mount your phone in the car (for GPS, hands-free talking, etc.)Note: I received this mount for free for the purpose of testing and reviewing.

This is my first experience with a barcode reader, and I was instantly impressed.  It was truly Plug and Play on my Windows 10 machine.  Plug it in and start aiming at bar codes and pulling the trigger.Note that you technically don't need any special software to make this work.  It is like a keyboard except that its input comes from barcodes.  In fact, I just aimed the scanner at a barcode as I was typing this review, and it instantly put the barcode number into my review.  You can also scan directly into a spreadsheet: just point and click, and the bar code is entered into a cell (this worked flawlessly in Google Sheets and in Microsoft Excel).This scanner is lightweight but sturdy feeling, as is the connection cable.  Not that this matters much, but note that the images on Amazon's product page show a blue and white RUBAN logo on the top of the reader.  This does not have that logo.  In fact, RUBAN does not appear anywhere on the device.Note that this is specifically for reading barcodes, and not other kinds of codes (it won't handle QR codes, for example).Long story short, if you are looking for an inexpensive easy-to-use barcode reader, this offering from RUBAN is a great way to go.  As a complete beginner, I'm very happy with it!Note: I received this barcode reader free for the purpose of testing and providing an unbiased review.

So, you realize what this is NOT, right?  This looks a lot like something else, but it is not that.  Once you understand that, you can begin to appreciate this for what it is: a decent mp3 player, FM radio, photo viewer, digital recorder and more, AND it comes with a 16GB Micro SD card.  Now think about that, and look at the price.  It would be hard to beat a price like that.There are minor issues here and there:* Menu navigation takes some getting used to* It plays AMV/MTV video formats (not MP4 as far as I could figure out).  I had to spend time converting files to one of these formats before I could view them.* You will need to connect it to your computer and drag audio, video, and photo files onto itStill...audio quality is decent, it picks up FM radio stations quite well, and has a nice feel to it (the brushed metal makes it look more expensive than it is).Should you buy this?  If you are looking for an inexpensive audio/video/photo solution, and don't mind dragging and dropping files, and putting up with a quirky menu system, then absolutely.  It's worth it.  If you are looking for something that is more like an Apple device, this is definitely not what you should be considering.  But then, those Apple devices are WAY more expensive than this device.Note: I received this player free for the purpose of testing and providing an unbiased review

The strength of this recorder is that it is discreet, so it won't easily distract the person being recorded.  Too often, voice recorders are big and have multiple lights, thereby distracting people.  By contrast, this voice recorder...* is small (about the size of a flash drive)* has only one tiny button on the side, almost not noticeable* has a little LED light that turns on when you switch on the recorder, but that goes off after about 10 secondsNote that this is purely a recorder, incapable of playing back recordings on its own.  Instead, you slip it into the USB port of a Mac or Windows computer.  Then, you just double-click on the recording you want to play, or download the recordings for future listening.The recording quality is very good for close, face-to-face conversations, which is how I tend to use it.  However, it is not what I would recommend for recording in a large room where the person being recorded is 10 or more feet away.  There is a noticeable dropoff in sound when the subject is beyond that distance.All in all, I like this for its simplicity: turn it on and it records.  Turn it off and the file is saved.  I recommend it if you need to record one-on-one conversations without distracting the person being recorded.Reviewer's note: I received this recorder free for the purpose of testing and reviewing.

I've tested several wallet-type phone cases, and most have disappointed me because they can only hold two cards.  This case can easily hold all 4 of the cards I normally carry around: there are only 3 card slots, but the money compartment easily holds a fourth.So, for that reason alone, this case is worth considering.  Add to that the nice appearance (I really like the black leather with red stitching), and the magnetic clasp, and this is a really good case!Reviewer's note: I received this case for free for the purpose of testing and providing an unbiased review.

A speaker this small, and priced so low, should not have such good sound.  I'm not talking "best sound you could ever get from any speaker", but for a 2-inch speaker you can throw on a keychain?  I'm impressed.It is plenty good, even at high volumes, indoors and out.  The sound is clear and undistorted even at the highest volume setting.  Planning a picnic?  Toss this in the picnic basket, and you'll be set.  Even if it rains...I tested this under running water, and the music just kept on playing...Lyle Lovett is apparently unaffected by a little moisture.Reviewer's note: I received this speaker free for the purpose of testing and providing an unbiased review.

Have you ever found yourself searching for a bottle opener?  Here's a simple solution: get a 12-pack!  Despite their low price and bulk packaging, these are very sturdy bottle openers.  I also like that each opener was individually wrapped.These would be good as stocking stuffers, or for strategically placing around the house or patio for a party.Don't be put off by the low price.  These are good bottle openers!Reviewer's note: I received a set of these for free for the purpose of testing and reviewing

These are well constructed, sturdy whistles that sound like...well...whistles.  Put one on your keychain, and you will have a distress signal in case of an emergency.  Given the bulk packaging and the low price, I was concerned that I would be disappointed.  But I was quite pleased.I also like that each whistle was individually wrapped.  These would be good door prizes for a kids' birthday party, or for a group heading out on a hike.Reviewer's note: I received a set of these for free for the purpose of testing and reviewing

Ok, I was not brave enough to test the waterproof-claim of this cover with my Kindle.  But I did want to test it.  So, I put a piece of paper in the case, sealed it shut, and held it under a few inches of water for a minute.  And....success!  Not a drop of water in the case.Note that Incipio says the waterproof seal is good for up to 2 meters of water for 30 minutes, so my test could have been more thorough.  But it is nice to know that this will offer good protection against rain, or an accidental drop in the pool.Here are a few other details you might care about:* All of the Kindle Voyage features still work when this case is on. In particular, all of the following work: the light sensor in the upper-left corner, the power button on the back, the side buttons for moving forward and back (and I can still feel the little vibration feedback with each page turn), the touch screen, and the charging port.* The touch screen was my biggest concern, but it mostly works fine when it is in this case.  I did find that touching the right side of the screen required a bit more pressure than I normally needed.  That was a bit distracting.  It used to be that my slightest touch would advance to the next page.  Now, sometimes that touch does not register...but tap just a bit harder and it's fine.  This is my main reason for the 4-star rather than 5-star rating (though there are a couple other minor issues...read on).* The out-of-the-box experience was a bit confusing.  When I opened the box, there was the case.  But I could not figure out how to open the case.  So, I thought I should read the instructions.  I could not find any instructions.  It turns out that the instructions were INSIDE the case.  And the first step in the instruction explained how to open the case.  This seemed rather silly to me.  Then I figured out that, if I had removed the protective sticker from the screen of the case, I would have been able to read the instructions through the screen.  So, probably I'm just a bit dumb, but that never occurred to me...that the only way to find the instructions was to peel a sticker off the screen of the case.  So, I figured out on my own that it was safe to pry apart the case and just work around the perimeter of the case to separate the two pieces.  Also, the instructions referred to the included microfiber cloth, but there most definitely was no cloth included with the case.* This will add some bulk to the normally very light Kindle Voyage.  But if protection from water and dust is important to you, then the extra bulk is probably worth it.* Finally, as best as I can tell, Incipio assumes no liability for damage to your Kindle while using this case.  This is not really surprising, given that user error could cause problems.  Specifically, they say, "Incipio is not liable for any damage to your device, including data loss that occurs while using the Atlas case except as expressly outlined in the Incipio Protective Products Agreement (where applicable)."  The instructions include a LOT of detail about the steps you need to take to be sure that you get a good seal...it is clear that they want to make sure you know there are risks involved if you are not careful.All in all, this case does what matters most: protects your Kindle Voyage from water.  I can put up with some minor issues if it means knowing that my device is safe.

What surprised me most about this lamp is its size.  It is the biggest desk lamp I have ever owned.  I was not quite prepared for it.  Fully extended, this is 4 feet long (not that you would want to fully extend it).  Not to overstate it, but do consider the desk or table where you want this to go.  Roughly speaking, you want a lamp to accent your desk...not overshadow it.Having said that...this is a really nice lamp.  It is elegantly constructed, and the brushed metal is a nice touch.It is also quite sturdy.  I like that you can set the angle you want for the lamp, and it will keep that angle as you move it along its other hinged joints.All in all, I'm very impressed and very pleased with this lamp.

I have tested and liked many cases for the S6, but this OtterBox case is by far the one that I've liked the best.  It has a really solid feel to it that just makes it seem like a natural part of the phone.Some additional details:* The fit is very snug.  The product description says the case "easily slips on and off".  While it is true that I can remove it in a few seconds, I find that the fit is quite tight...so much so that you may find that the buttons on the side of the phone are being triggered as you put on or take off the case.  This may be a deal-breaker if you frequently take off the case, but if you plan to keep it on and leave it on, then this won't be an issue.* The product photo makes it look like the back of the case is textured.  It is not.  It is as smooth as can be.  If you put the phone face up on a table, you will find that it slides around easily.* The rubber edge around the front of the phone is perfect for gripping.  Because it has a rubberized texture, I recommend setting your phone face down rather than face up.  It won't slide around if it is face down.* I like the appearance.  A lot.  I am a fan of blacks and greys in general.  This case is exactly what I'm after.* It works with Qi chargers.  I love being able to set my phone on a pad to charge it, rather than needing to plug it in.  The case does not interfere with the two Qi chargers I own.It took me a month or so to find it, but I now have the perfect case for my phone.

This is, bar none, the best grill brush I have used: sturdy and highly effective.  I'm using it on stainless steel grates on my Weber and find that it gets into each crevice perfectly.  The whole thing is constructed so solidly that it should last a long time.A couple notes:1) The instructions explain how to clean your brush when you are done using it.  I recommend not cleaning your grill at the end of a cook.  Rather, the next time you cook, preheat the grill and then clean it right before it is time to cook.  By that time, old food has turned to ash and is easier to scrape clean.  Then, I see no need to clean the brush.2) The metal on this brush will rust if left out.  With that in mind, find a place to store it where it is protected from the elements.  You can certainly get years of use out of the brush if you treat it nicely.All in all, there is so much to like about this brush.  You won't be disappointed!Reviewer's note: I received this brush free for the purpose of testing and reviewing.

Though I have tested many earbuds, earphones, and headsets, this is the first time I have ever tried the neckband-style earphones.  I'm very happy with the results, but have learned a few things about how not to use them.For me, the biggest advantage of these earphones is that the controls are simpler to use.  Many earphones have just 3 buttons, with each serving multiple purposes (for example, one button switches tracks and changes the volume, depending on how long you hold it down).  With the neckband, it is very easy to locate the volume and track controls.  Each button has a unique shape, making it easy to find the right button even if you forget which is which.  Volume and phonecalls are on the right side, and playing/pausing/switching tracks are on the left.I also like the sliding switch to turn the headset on and off.  While many earphones have a button that you must press and hold (but not too long...you might go into Bluetooth pairing mode), the Q800 lets you flip a switch to turn it on and connect.Finally, I appreciate audio feedback that tells me the status of the battery.  It's easy for me to forget how long it has been since I last charged my earphones.  A voice on the Q800 lets you know how full the battery is each time you turn it on.But now, let me tell you how NOT to use these earphones:1) They did not work too well for me on my run.  They tend to bounce up and down on my neck, which I find distracting.  I tucked the neckband under my t-shirt, which helped, but eventually as my run progressed, they came out again.2) They worked well in the gym, until it was time to do my sit-ups on an inclined platform.  Then, the neckband fell off my neck.  In all other ways, these worked well in the gym.I don't fault SoundPEATS for the above problems...I suspect this is the nature of neckband-style earphones.If you plan to use these on a walk, or around the house, then I highly recommend them.  On the other hand, if you plan to use them for a run or workout, you might look at some other options (SoundPEATS has another set of earbuds, Q8, that work great when I am running).Reviewer's note: I received these earbuds free for the purpose of testing and reviewing

This is my first experience using compression sleeves.  My impressions:*  The material is flexible yet sturdy.  They fit my calves well, and seem built to last.*  They are comfortable.  On my run this morning, it was 59 degrees outside.  They felt nice at the start of the run...though I was happy to remove them at the end as I could feel my legs getting a little warm.I hope to get a lot of use out of these!Reviewer's note: I received these sleeves free for the purpose of testing and reviewing.

"Kings Mountain" by Hank Messick is an older title (1976) but a good read on what some historians believe was the turning point of the American Revolution.  The book is around 180 pages and covers topics such as:1.  Events leading up to the battle.2.  Background info on the patriot leaders, particularly: Shelby, Campbell, Cleveland, Winston, Williams, etc.3.  Description of the mountain men's march from Sycamore Shoals TN to Kings Mountain SC.4.  Background info on Patrick Ferguson (British army officer who was from Scotland and led the loyalist forces at Kings Mountain) and some of the loyalist leaders.5.  Description of the battle.6.  Results and impact the battle had on the American Revolution.7.  Post battle careers of the patriot readers.Messick uses an entertaining narrative:  Refers to the mountain men as hillbillies or rednecks as described by the British, provides appropriate details as needed, and gets to the point.  The only complaint I have is a similar one to other military-related titles I have read:  would have liked to have seen more maps.  Complaint aside, still a good read.

Tried the Sharpie Extreme Permanent Markers the other day and they seem to work well - good and dark marks, easy to handle while using, and good fine point.  As for the fade resistant feature mentioned on the marker, I'll have to wait and see how well that works.  So far, so good.

Yesterday I passed the PMP Exam on the first try, yipppeee!  Now that I have recovered and am no longer a basket case, time for some comments and a review.  First, I have never been a full-time project manager but until after taking some PMP courses and preparing for the exam, realized that I have been applying PM principles during my whole life and career.  My career has consisted of being an Air Force Officer and mainly sales and am now looking to going into a new phase.  As I completed my last PMP class and started to prepare for the exam, I started to read the PMBOK as my only study source.  After reading a chapters and seeing that I was doomed to fail, it was time to find other resources that could help me better understand Project Management and go back and read the PMBOK with a "new set of eyes".Now, my comments about Head First PMP:1.  In my humble opinion,  Head First PMP is the best resource to use for exam prep for someone like me.  The authors' philosophy of learning by visuals, examples (wedding, baking cookies, etc.), exercises, repetitively describing key concepts (although in different words), etc. really work.  I consider myself a visual learner and the Head First fits the bill.2.  Really like the exercises, crossword puzzles, and exams - the questions were somewhat challenging.  Like I said earlier, repetition works.3.  Really like the way the Head First is organized - the first 3 chapters serve as an introduction to Project Management and chapters 4 - 10 correspond with the knowledge area in the same chapter in the PMBOK Guide.4.  Good practical pointers throughout the book.  For example, the Head First mentions practical tips on preparing for the exam, red herring questions (have to say, I did not find too many in the PMP exam version I took) and so on.  Very helpful.5.  Very good layout - eye catching, logical order, etc.For what it's worth, here's the strategy I implemented for passing the PMP exam:1.  No boot camp for me - (don't do well with trying to cram in too much information too quickly, I prefer to pace myself.  Some impatient folks may disagree with me, but I believe taking your time and pacing yourself, when possible, is a better way to learn).  Instead, I took 4 courses at a local community college whenever my schedule allowed me.  Earned plenty of credits to qualify for taking the exam.2.  Studied the Head First quickly to get an idea of how the book is laid out and its content.3.  Next, I read through the book several times for more in depth knowledge of PMP principles.  DO NOT skip the exercises, puzzles, and mini exams, they really help!4.  After reading the Head First a few times, I then started to read the PMBOK - really helped me look at the PMBOK in a new way.5.  Studied the PMBOK Guide glossary after reading Head First.  One of instructors strongly recommended this and I do too.  However, I would say the glossary was easier to understand after reading the Head First.6.  While the Head First did have several math problems, I wanted to supplement learning the formulas with the McGraw-Hill PMP Certification Mathematics title.  The title is a good aid and I recommend it.  Will probably do an Amazon review on that title soon.7.  Pray like crazy and get a great night's sleep! I tried to keep things in perspective - the worst thing that could have happened to me if I failed was to take the exam again.  Compared to the difficulties that millions of people around the world are experiencing, that helped me see things in a different light.  I can say, that praise the Lord, I am relieved that I don't have to take the exam again!8.  Finally, do some online exams - Gary Lehman has a great site with several exam examples.In summary, I highly recommend the Head First PMP.  Buy the book, study, pray, and pass the exam!  Go get'em!

The "Purina Pro Plan Dog Food, Bright Mind" version so far seems to work well with our dog, a 7 year-old mix of mainly Jack Russell with blue eyes.  A great dog, he seems even more energetic and alert after having some meals.  Bailey seems to wolf the food down with no after effects.  So far so good.

My wife tried to install the Perky-Pet Feeder the other day and had great difficulty putting the lid back on after pouring the solution.  An attractive product to look at and a good concept for adding more solution.  Unfortunately, it was too difficult to use. Don't know if other folks have had similar problems.

"Take My Hand Again" is a good title for anyone wanting to assist an aging loved one.  My mother in law belongs in that category and my wife and I read through the book and offer the following comments:1.  Very practical guide for helping aging parents through the aging process.2.  Would have been great if we had access to this title about a year or so ago when my mother-in-law was (and still is) going through an especially difficult phase in her life.3.  Very biblically-based.4.  Offers good advice on various issues: looking for a long term care facility, what to expect during the transition, etc.5.  Letting go of your loved one during the final life phases.Good and helpful read.  Recommended.

"How To Enjoy Reading Your Bible" by Keith Ferrin is a good title for anyone wanting insights on how to get more out of your Bible reading time.  The book is around 150 pages, contains 10 tips for your reading, and contains such points as:1.  Expecting to learn and enjoy your devotion time before you actually start your reading time.2.  Have a planned strategy for reading your Bible.3.  Understand the high points of a book first instead of focusing first on details that may distract your learning.4.  Read aloud during your devotion time - will engage you more and help you remember verses.5.  Suggested 60 day and 4 month Bible reading plans.The narrative flows freely and is easy to follow.  I will give this title for our children to read to aid them in their devotion times.

"Seven Men" by Eric Metaxas is a great title for anyone looking for an introduction to 7 men who made a positive impact on the world in their time.  The book is around 240 pages and covers the following men and their challenge:1.  George Washington - leading the country during the American Revolution and turning down the chance to become a king.2.  William Wilberforce - his long and eventually successful struggle with abolishing the slave trade and improving common manners in England.3.  Eric Liddell - refusal to run an Olympic race on a Sunday.4.  Dietrich Bonhoeffer - resisting Hitler's dictatorship in Germany during World War 2.5.  Jackie Robinson - letting Christ rule through him as he endured racism and hatred in Major League Baseball and elsewhere (and not only in the South!).6.  Pope John Paul II - resisting communism in Europe and reaching out to common folk.7.  Charles Colson - letting God use his time in prison to minister to other prisoners and eventually starting various prison ministries when he was let out of prison.Some reviewers appeared to be a little critical of Metaxas' book because the title apparently did not  go into sufficient detail into each man's life.  I submit that the author's aim was to give a glimpse into each man's life on how God worked in and through him to advance His kingdom.  In that goal, the author succeeded admirably.  Indeed, if the author wanted to do a more comprehensive biography on each man, the book would be considerably larger!  Plenty of books are available that cover each man's life in more detail.I will give this title to my son when he is a little older and able to read such titles so he can get a grasp on how God works in our lives.  Read and enjoy.  Highly recommended.

My wife used the KitchenAid Ceramic 2.8-Quart Casserole Bakeware the other day for cooking rice as part of an orange chicken recipe.  She liked the bakeware - plenty of room, sturdy, the rice cooked evenly, and tasted good.  Would like to see the bakeware come in additional colors besides red (would match well with the black and stainless steel appliances we recently purchased.  Minor complaint aside, the bakeware worked well and we look forward to many more uses.Recommended.

Used the Scotts Liquid Turf Builder the other day and so far the product seems to be okay.  The product is easy to use - turning the on tab was easy to operate and the sprayer worked well.  I will need to wait a few more days before realizing the full impact of spraying the lawn food and have not noticed any adverse results or damage to the lawn.  Will also make another application later this year - there is ample supply in the bottle.  But so far, so good.

"Ulrich Zwingli" by William Borkenstein is a good read for anyone wanting to learn more about Zwingli, who was, along with Martin Luther, an important figure in the Protestant Reformation.  The book is around 160 pages and covers such topics as:1.  Zwingli's early life and priesthood.2.  Early struggles with Rome.3.  Zwingli's and Luther impacting the Protestant Reformation (in history, compared to Martin Luther, Zwingli is covered much less).4.  Zwingli's ongoing tension with Rome.5.  Zwingli's marytrdom and legacy.The book has a good narrative and covers many aspects of Zwingli's life - a character often overlooked in the Protestant Reformation.  Good read.

I've tried the "Calvin Klein ETERNITY for Men Eau de Toilette" and so far the product seems to be okay.  The scent is a mixture of several blends and does appear to be somewhat "woodsy" which is okay with me.  My wife seems to like it okay and gives it around an "8" out of 10.Would be good to use whether as an everyday cologne at work (don't apply too much) , going out on a special occasion, or at night.  So far, seems to be okay.

Tried the "Ortho Weed B Gon Weed Killer, RTU Trigger 1" the other day and waited a few days to see the result before reviewing.  After 2-3 days of waiting, looks like the product is working good so far.  Sprayed on several weeds and looks like they are dying off.  The product was easy to use (trigger gun was easy to press, filled quickly, and easy to aim).I saved enough for a future application.  So far, so good.  Recommended.

Just received the "Turtle Beach Large Traction Premium Textured Mouse Pad" and really like the product - about twice the size of my old mouse pad, nice tight weave, does not slip, and a good surface.  I especially like the lager area as when I'm playing PC games the mouse usually goes off the smaller pad.  With this pad, the problem is solved!Really look forward to using this more extensively and with the good quality, should last a long time.Recommended.

"What Every Christian Needs to Know About Passover" by Rabbi Evan Moffic is an enlightening read on how Christians can celebrate the Jewish Passover remembrance/celebration.  As a committed Christian, I see Jesus Christ as the sacrificial lamb whose blood was shed to spare His children from God's wrath.  While Rabbi Moffic does not appear to be a Messianic Jew (perhaps I am wrong), he shows much knowledge about Jesus' life and how Christians can tie their own beliefs into Passover.The book is around 190 pages and covers such topics as:1.  History of the Israelite exodus from Egypt.2.  How Passover was celebrated during Jesus' day.3.  Celebrating the Passover is more of a home event - makes it more intimate.4.  Preparing spiritually and otherwise for Passover.5.  Singing during the Passover observance.6.  Telling the Passover story.7.  Examples of freedom throughout history when people sought to be free of oppression.A good read and helpful future reference.

Received and tried on some of the "Calvin Klein euphoria for Men Eau de Toilette" and my wife liked the scent.  Not overwhelming nor weak, the smell was pleasant and manly.  Based on past work experiences, I've had people at work apply too much cologne or perfume and was distracting.  Will use this scent mainly at home or when going out for a night on the town with my wife.  Look forward to using the product for the next several weeks/months.So far, so good.  Recommended.

"Praying Over God's Promises" by Thomas Yeakley is a good title for anyone needing encouragement to hang in there and cling to God's promises for your life.  The book is around 110 pages, is an easy read, and covers topics such as:1.  While God does not promise a problem-free or stress-free life, He does promise to be with us.2.  Suggestions for mentioning God's promises for your life.3.  Learning to walk by faith while waiting for the promise to be fulfilled.4.  Some promises will not be fully realized during our lifetime.5.  Reasons why a promise may go unfulfilled.6.  Being careful to twist Scripture around to suit your own purpose.7. Using Abraham's life as an example of living a life of faith.The book may be read in 2-3 sittings and the narrative flows freely.  The author readily describes his own life experiences (praying for a bookshelf, leaving Indonesia, etc.) when he had to live on God's promises in the Bible.  Will be a good future reference.  Good read.

"The Complete 101 Collection" by John Maxwell is a comprehensive treatment on the subject of several leadership topics:  attitude, self-improvement, relationships, success, teamwork, equipping, and mentoring.  The book is just over 600 pages and contains sections of the above mentioned topics, each section around 80 or so pages.As with other Maxwell titles, "Complete 101" is an easy to understand read and Maxwell readily gives credit to dozens of people from all walks of life with their quotes on leadership.  Good basic information - nothing exactly earth shattering, but full of reminders that we need to apply when in a leadership position (home, work, community, etc.).  My main complaint is that there seemed to be some unnecessary repetition in some of the chapters (later chapters would repeat what earlier chapters already addressed).  Still, a good title and useful present and future reference.

I received "Social Security For Dummies" the other day and eagerly read through parts of the title.  While I still have several more years of meaningful employment left, I still want to learn more about social security, since I am paying into the system.  As with other "Dummies" titles, this one is easy to read, informative, and relatively easy to understand.  The book is around 300 pages and covers topics such as:1.  Introduction to social security.2.  How you qualify and how much you may get.3.  Deciding at what point to collect benefits (hint: the longer you wait, the larger your monthly payment will be).4.  Appealing when you disagree on social security's decision on your monthly benefit.5.  Introduction to Medicare and how to enroll.6.  Myths about social security.7.  Working while collecting social security.8.  The future of social security - while some people think there is no future in social security, the author and others believe social security will continue to exist.I will definitely hang on to this title and use as a future reference. Regardless of what you think about the author's conclusion about social security, the book is full of helpful information.  Recommended.

Being in the south and having sun in my yard most of the day, I wanted to try the "Scotts Turf Builder Grass Seed - Sunny Mix" before the weather got too hot and/or dry.  Applied the product a couple of weeks ago and seems to be doing okay - I liked how the grass was colored differently and better see how the seeds would grow.  We've had a good bit of rain since applying and the product seems to be taking root.  Will know better how really effective the product is later this summer when the heat is turned up and if we have some dry periods like past summers.So far, so good.

"Natural Balance Dry Dog Food, Limited" so far seems to be a good product. Our dog, a Jack Russell mix, is not a picky eater and this product was no exception.  The first time we gave him this, he took about 5 pieces out of the bowl to investigate (different from other food we've gotten him), eat them one by one, and then consumed the whole bowl.  Obviously, he liked it! Bailey has finished the other portions we've given him and plan to keep feeding him until he finishes the bag.  He looks forward to dinnertime!So far, so good!

Our dog, a mix of Jack Russell and something else, pretty much eats what we give him.  Needless to say, he wolfed it down a few samples we have given him.  Product seems to be okay for him, even though he is almost 6 years old, not necessarily a "senior dog" and we'll see how he continues.  So far, so good.

Along with "Killing Lincoln" and "Killing Kennedy", "Killing Patton" is an engrossing read of arguably the best fighting WWII general with the focus on his war accomplishments, relationships with various personalities (Eisenhower, Bradley, Truman, Stalin, etc.), and the events surrounding his mysterious death - was it a conspiracy or not?The authors mention some strange events after General Patton's accident - the driver of the truck that hit Patton's care never being tried, other people supposedly involved in the incident not apprehended or taken into custody for further questioning, etc.  The title is around 330 pages and is a great narrative that covers a lot of Patton's war accomplishments - tense, dramatic, etc.Great read, my only real complaints is that I would have liked to have known more about General Patton's early life and several examples of Patton's salty language.  Still, a great read.  Recommended.

"Vision Map" by Joel Malm is a great read for anyone wanting clarity for their life, specifically, their purpose for being here on earth.  Less than 100 pages, easy to read, and to the point, "Vision Map" covers such topics as:1.  Developing a brief vision statement for your life.2.  Finding people who can support you.3.  Spending much time in prayer.4.  Be awake to potential opportunities that come up, you never know when they may appear!5.  Start small and build on that.6.  Don't be afraid to ask for help.7.  Be the person God created you to be.8.  Learning to wait while God acts (hint: this does not mean being passive, but doing what you know God wants to do in and through you until you get His next assignment for you).9.  Don't be afraid to take risks.10. Sample vision maps.A good read that I will often refer to for future use.  Recommended.

"Ordinary" by Tony Merida is a good read for anyone wanting to be different from the self-absorbed, self-obsessed world we live in.  As a member of the "evangelical right" I have to admit that at times we emphasize right theology to the point of forgetting to apply what we believe into practice.  Specifically, Merida addresses the following areas where folks like me can see God work in great and mighty ways for His glory:1.  Focusing more on serving God quietly out of the spotlight and serving to be pleasing to Him instead of serving to please people.2.  Showing hospitality to others - not trying to impress people when having them over to your house, but making them feel like honored quests by serving them.3.  Caring for others unable to fend for themselves - orphans, widows/widowers, elderly, etc.A good and brief read that will encourage and challenge you to get out there and serve for God's glory and honor to a lost world.

Gave this product to my wife on Christmas (amongst other presents!) and she was pleased with receiving the cups since we have some measuring spoons, also made by OXO.  She likes the OXO quality and will use them quite often.  I especially like:1.  The clipping mechanism that keeps all the cups together.2.  Clear color coding on the sides showing the size - easy to read and differentiate what size is what color.3.  Good black coloring.4.  Sturdy plastic - won't easily break.So far, a good product and will often use for some time to come.  Recommended.

As a sales representative for several years in various industries (especially education), "Customer Experience For Dummies" was a natural title for me to check out.  Indeed, in a business where repeat sales can go a ways in achieving quotas, making sure current customers are happy and want to renew makes it easier to focus on new customers.The title is around 325 pages and covers several topics such as:1.  The financial impact (positive and negative) a customer experience can have on a company.2.  Taking care of an angry customer.3.  Getting customer feedback (I do this now with a view to securing future business and getting referrals).  Indeed, a happy customer is the most powerful kind of advertising.4.  Ways to improve customer experience (hint, good listening skills are one of the keys - have to reminder, we are born with one mouth and two ears!).5.  Working within your companys' culture for dealing with customers.  As the title mentioned some companies have a great culture to work in to positively address customer experiences, while others, well, aren't so good.  I've been on both sides of the fence!A good read, one that I will often refer to.  I have to remind myself - positive customer experiences lead to bigger and better sales - everyone wins!  Recommended.

Applied some product around our garage and patio the other day.  Don't like the dusty application but so far seems to be effective. Worked the product into the cracks and gaps in the garage and patio and will hopefully work its way down to where the insects have been before. No problem with bugs so far, but this is a cooler time of the year.  Will apply more in the spring and see what happens - will probably be able to give a more accurate report on its effectiveness.Will update as soon as possible.  Unfortunately, I had to do the review within a certain time period.  Have tried other Garden Safe products and they seem to be okay.

Good product - hooks are strong, high quality, and really like the rubber tips.  I used them the other day and they work great - have to make sure, however, that you have the right pegboard size - I have different sizes throughout our house.  Hooks are too thick for the smaller holes but fit right in with the correct hole size.Recommended.

"Life With A Capital L" is a good title for anyone wanting more out of life for God's glory.  The book is around 230 pages and focuses on being the person God created us to be.  The first 50 pages or so describes the yearning we have for a more fulfilling life and how we may access that life through God's grace.The book then goes into 10 experience of our lives where we can experience more meaning:FreedomHeartBeautyIlluminationStoryWorshipLoveTimeBrokennessHeavenRead and be encouraged to enjoy life in God instead of just going through the motions of enduring life.

Because literally nothing goes right in this story.  And I'm sure that was his point.Main character, Ryuu, witnesses a brutal massacre of his town folk including his parents, right before his eyes.  He's saved by Shigeru, a nightblade.  Raised as Shigeru's prodigy.  There's a darker story to the nightblades, but the author attempted to blur the lines of good and evil while emphasizing causality: for every action there is an opposite, equal reaction.I had three problems with the book.First, Ryuu got way too good, way too fast.  I understand there's more to him than meets the eye, and we'll learn about this in the second book, but it was like he couldn't fail.  He was killing people left and right with ridiculous ease, even those that seemed to have godly powers.  It was almost laughable.Second, Takako made no sense.  First, she's enthralled by Ryuu's conversation.  Then, Ryuu selfishly acts, and the result is bloody.  Takako ends up hating Ryuu, no real forgiveness, never gets over it, but never leaves.  Then "the end" happens, and while it's expected, it's like the author couldn't make up his mind which way he wanted to go with Ryuu's feelings.  We never got to explore Takako at all, and she never revealed anything of herself.  She became a victim of circumstance with no real substance.Third, General Nori and his son.  Without spoiling things, this goes back to my first issue.I gave it 4 stars because it was a very easy read, very well written, and it took an intriguing story that made me want to read the sequel at the end of the week when it comes out.  Just don't expect a happy ending, and don't expect resolution or absolution.

Those who criticize the game really miss the point.I played this game ages ago.  Vividly remember it.  If you're a fan of creating your own character and playing the game as if you're in it, this is the game for you.  However, if you're just into "graphics OMG!!!", don't play it.  This game focused more on telling a story.You create a character.  He has a storyline, starting from fighting in small, seedy gyms with a few people and gaining fame over time, all the way up to the main event scene.  Along the way, realistic things happen; you get injuries during training or in fights, you have to buy stuff, you'll get into a feud with another fighter, dirty fighters where the judges/refs don't call it, etc.  I remember once, my guy broke his hand, and you take damage with every punch with that hand.  Just as with the real thing.Loved the game.  The graphics were not great, and the fight controls were clunky.  But in terms of storyline, it was awesome.

.First let me be clear: Renshaw is a very good writer.  He was able to explain scenery very well.  I only detected one grammatical error so minor I don't even remember specifically what it was.  Character development was about a B+; I was able to feel personalities from most of the main cast.The problem here is the same that Terry Brooks suffered in the Genesis of Shannara series: there's just not enough to care about.  I didn't care about any of the characters except Lira, who wasn't really explored.  Part of this is because Renshaw went so many ways; this is a book that could easily be a third the length. There's that much "fluff" and it was dull.  It got to the point I speed read to the end just to get to the predictable outcome I totally expected.Main character is at first presented as just a kid with his friends.  Slavers sneak into the town; he tries to warn people but is ignored.  This was an interesting few chapters.  But then, he's in a cart being taken somewhere by his parents (this is the FIRST time we're hearing anything about parents, and we don't learn hardly anything about them except that his dad is a violent child and spousal abuser).  This felt like a forced attempt to make the reader feel something for Aedan; it didn't work on me.Then, the bulk of the book - and when I say "the bulk", if it's 639 pages long, I'd argue that the breakout is something like this:~50 pages with the first town and his friends~400 pages of just Aedan training to be a marshal and failing, while constantly being bullied by nearly everyone.  This segment was extremely DULL.The rest, random out-of-nowhere quests complete with deus ex machina event and no real resolution at the endThis is not what I expected.  I expected Aedan to be trained as a marshal, then thrown into battle fairly quickly; rough yet getting better.  I expected him to overcome his fears naturally and by confronting them - you know, like NORMAL people do - and not by some strange light.  I expected him to master his horse, which would become a loyal and trusted companion, not a terror to the town later completely forgotten.  I expected him to finally forge a sword worthy of song, one that people would later talk about.None of this happened.  It just...stopped.  And it stopped with Aedan no more a man, no more a warrior, no more a marshal, than when the book started.What also went unresolved:- Beef with Malik, never really explained or resolved- Emroy, who basically threw Aedan "under the bus" (this might be dealt with in the next book, but he was so sparingly mentioned in this one the reader doesn't have any idea what's to happen or why)- Ilona's strange "not when my friends are around" behavior (Aedan theorizes, but there's never a full 100% explanation of it)- WHY Peashot feels a need to shoot things- WHY Lorrimer freaked out in the middle of combatI give the author major credit for not writing the equivalent of a short story and for writing so well, but too long is too long.  I also would have preferred more closure, more definitive action, and more resolution than what I got.Small side note for the author: the book does not paginate properly on Kindle because the chapter headers are images, not text (KDP tells you this is a no-no).  Thus, when you want to go to a "chapter", it just lists the first sentence, not the chapter number.  If you update this book, please do at least include basic text with chapter segments appropriately, so it's easier on Kindle readers.

I'm reviewing the last book first, because it's supposed to be a culmination from the series.  I felt dissatisfied, and here's why.The first couple of books are slightly dark.  There is failure.  There's heartache.  There's stress.  There's death.The last book has a bit of stress, and nothing else.Pairings of couples, friendships, even stories told are not wrapped up in this book.  The author essentially throws away everything that came before, as if he started off telling one story but somewhere along the way decided to tell a completely different one.  It felt like he was trying to tell the reader that "everyone's got a little evil and a little good in them", but it ended up like "we're here, but yeah, we can't do what we came to do and everyone who was mad, is no longer."Irrelevant characters are brought in, for no reason.  Here, it felt like someone told the author, "hey, I read books 1-5 and uh, they don't feel like YA stories.  You need more child-relatable characters!" so then he throws in a barkeep, a mage, some farmers, and some kids, but doesn't really do much with any of them except the mage, a character that simply makes NO sense.Plot holes are all over the place - Percy walked off mad and vowed revenge, then nothing.  A wooden arm is "critical" to Sleag's Quest, but only so he can see an arm that looks like it and know what to do?  Sleag and Danagh are constantly carrying boatloads of weapons around only to leave all but one behind every time?  What about the weapons Danagh left in the tree?  Bree can talk to animals yet only does so once in the whole book - well, what's the point of her having the skill if it's not to be used after that?  And what about "Danagh's Quest"?  The ultimate cliffhanger.I don't know if Hayes was compelled to "hurry it up", but I was not pleased with this book.

Unlike others, I didn't get this stuff to fill a dog bed (IMO, that's too much money for such a use case when you could just buy a replacement dog bed for the same price, but I digress).No, on a recent trip I stayed at a hotel that had quite frankly the perfect pillows. They never got too hot, never got too soft, had perfect neck support, and my head didn't sink too far down.  I'd never had a pillow so comfortable, and believe me, I've gone through many types: down ("Poker face" anyone?), down alternative (sore neck anyone?), memory foam (breaks down when hot), water base (half of it too firm), shredded memory foam (either too hard or too soft), cervical (OUCH)...A previous patron had ripped a corner of one of the pillows (clearly, as curious as I was what the stuffing was).  Come to find out it was this stuff, though I didn't know it at the time.  Google was key here.So I bought a 5 lb bag and some zippered pillow protectors.  Didn't want to bother sewing up a pillow and have it fall apart over time.  These were King size protectors, and I would estimate that 3lbs was needed to properly stuff one of them.  Which means for two King size pillows I didn't have enough, and this concerned me.  Usually I have to sleep with two stacked pillows due to the issues above, but not here.When properly stuffed, one King pillow was the same height as two pillows which worked perfectly for my neck.  It was firm enough to support my head, but not so firm as to be painful.  My head sinks down roughly halfway and just waits for blissful sleep.  Less stuffing can be used for a softer pillow, but then you get the "down alternative" effect where your neck will suffer.  It also didn't seem possible to "overstuff" the pillow, which was nice.  It remained breathable no matter what.I know pillows are a subjective thing, but I strongly recommend trying this if you've had issues finding a good pillow out-of-the-box.  Might be that you have to just knuckle down and stuff your own.

I will make updates to this review over time.  It is difficult to know things such as quality, durability, heat retention, and flexibility of the piece without sleeping on it for a good deal of time. I purchased this to help make my Casper mattress a bit more comfortable.  While that mattress is basically a memory foam mattress, and while it touts great heat dispersion and durability, The problem is that it suffers from the same challenges that all memory foam mattresses do : when it receives a certain amount of heat, it breaks down and gets weak.  This causes you to sink into the mattress, into a dented space, which wreaks havoc on your back, sides, and legs. I've been sleeping on this topper for a couple of days now. I can say with confidence that it's a lot easier to fall asleep than it was without it.  The top layer is a down alternative, plush and comfortable.  There's a foam middle pad just beneath the down top layer, then a gel layer at the bottom.  The gel layer is rigid enough that you will not dent into the mattress beneath unless if you weigh more than the rated amount for the mattress in the first place.At first, the topper did not feel all that comfortable compared to the regular mattress, but my body adjusted quickly.I get hot at night, especially my lower body, but this never got overly warm or uncomfortable. It seemed to do a great job separating the heat from my body. Note that this is not a cooling mattress; the heat will just flow away from you which has the net effect of keeping you cooler. Time will tell whether this continues to be the case as I sleep on the topper. This does not come with any sort of fitted corners or extra fitted sheet, so you will need to add your own.  It's just the topper. Overall I'm satisfied with the purchase.
No effect in either case.  Might do something with dark circles (which I don't have) but certainly did nothing for bags (which I do have, though not large).

tl;dr: This works, despite the price shock.  But the vendor should consider different hardware options.Upfront: I am not, and have never been, a smoker.  I don't believe I suffer from COPD.  But I diagnosed with asthma as a kid, inherited from my mother, or so I was told.  I used to carry a Proventil (albuterol sulfate) inhaler around, just like she did.  And truthfully, I was wheezing and coughing, but not nearly as frequent as her.  Mine usually had to be triggered by exertion.  It was no fun being one of the fastest sprinters in high school, only to resort to a coughing fit that would last for a long time.When I hit my 20's, all of a sudden the asthma was nearly non-existent.  I had to really push myself running or lifting or climbing to get it to trigger and even then it never lasted.When I hit my 30's, the asthma came back but in the form of chest tightness, seemingly all the time.  By now I was nowhere near in the shape I used to be, being 30-40 pounds heavier and not nearly as defined.  Being in Washington State seemed to make this worse, and I don't know why, but I suspect it's the lack of sun, and the humidity at times.Robitussin Peak Cold Cough and Chest Congestion DM, 8-Ounce seemed to always help this, so I figured it had something to do with phlegm.  I started a regimen of RidgeCrest Clearlungs Extra Strength, Homeo/Herbal Decongestant , 120 Veg Capsules, which worked, but took hours to kick in and required taking them every 4 hours constantly.  Not fun.  If it was decidedly bad at night I would turn to good old Vicks Vaporub Cough Suppressant Topical Analgesic Ointment 1.76 Ounce,  (Pack of 3), which worked, but is extremely messy and has to be re-applied constantly.On a whim I decided to give this a try as it made rather large claims, but the ingredients seemed to match those you'd find in basic oils + Robitussin (expectorant) + ClearLungs (oxygenium) plus Vicks (menthol), but deployed directly into the lungs in atomized form.  You can do the same thing with an ionizing mister, but with a lot wasted.In my case it did come charged and I haven't had to charge it yet.  After application, I noticed the pressure in my chest wasn't there anymore.  I didn't cough at all as the instructions indicated.  But it did trigger me to clear my throat a couple of times, and it was the same effect as if you take Mucinex Maximum Strength 12-Hour Chest Congestion Expectorant Tablets, 42 Count - clear, thin, easy to cough or spit out.No effect with my nasal passages, at least not a noticeable effect.  And yes, I tried exhaling both via mouth and nose.I further tested this the best way I knew how: singing.  And I was able to sing songs that gave me trouble, better than before.  Louder, more powerful.  No shortness of breath after multiple tracks which would usually be the case.So, to summarize the experience, it does work and it didn't take several days.  Also, despite some of the other reviews, my version of the instructions seems to indicate that they re-engineered the tank cartridge.  It no longer needs coil replacement, with a life of approx. 6 months.  Having never used a vaporizer before, I hope that helps someone.First negative.  While they tell you how long to hold your breath, they don't give any sort of guidance as to how many times to repeat.  I would argue that if there's expectorant in the solution, it's probably not good to do this too many times per day.  I don't know for a fact.  I can say that I did feel nauseous after the first day's treatment, and I did it 5 times in a row.  This is with the mild that comes pre-loaded.  It says "half a Pyrex tank to a whole one", but there's no way to measure this against the pre-loaded solution, so I ignored it.Second negative is that you have to essentially disassemble the thing to charge it.  I'm not sure why they didn't just put the charging port on the bottom of it for easy access.  I assume it was to block use of the product while charging, but why not just implement an electronic kill switch that disables the device while charging?  This can be done.Third negative is that it requires a proprietary charging cable.  I would rather they just include the screw-on piece with a micro-USB opening, and include the cable as a detachable.  That way, it doesn't matter if the cable gets lost; I've got at least 10 micro USB cables around the house and they're cheap to buy on Amazon.  As is, if you for whatever reason lose the charger (and it's small enough that I can see this potentially happening at a hotel or something), you're screwed and have to go back to the vendor.  What if the vendor goes out of business?  Screwed.  (if you're concerned about the solution, don't be.  As I said, it's comprised of commonly available oils, and it's not a stretch to replicate if need be.  But the charger part is of greater concern.)Fourth negative.  While it is effective, considering the hardware at play here, I consider it grossly overpriced.  Let me explain.  The bottles are $40 each separately, you get three of them in the case, so technically you're already at $120, so they're charging only $20 for the vaporizer.  A deal, right? Except that as I said, the solution is comprised of widely available common oils that collectively, one could buy for much less $40.  This is where I feel it's overpriced; the bottle solutions.  $15 a bottle to me is more acceptable (which has profit in there but not gross overprofit), at which point, you're down to $45, add $20 on the vaporizer then add profit, Come to $89.99.  Or, sell the vaporizer with ONE solution bottle and do the pad I put above, come to $69.99 as an alternate option.  I find that much more tolerable.  Personal opinion.  The mild was more than effective anyway.

Let me be clear.  The stuff works.  But you need to be aware of some things.First the default pack gives you four tablets.  That's it.  Nearly $15 each.  We're talking tablets the size of Alka Seltzer here.  That's called a ripoff.  I could forgive the price of each tablet lasted a full 24 hours; they don't.  Each lasts 2.5 hours.  Means you'll need all four if you do a cross country trip.Seconds there's nothing magical in these that would help justify the cost.  They're basically multivitamins with one thing added: pycnogenol which is basically an antioxidant, readily available everywhere for under $10.In other words, if you took pycnogenol with a Starbucks Refresher, you'd get the exact same effect, flute a fraction of the cost.Now, besides cost.  I don't think it tasted all that good, either.  Think Airborne, or Kool-Aid with no sugar.Effective?  Sure, but remember, it's not a cure, it just delays the effect.  If you do one tablet for a three-hour flight, you'll feel energized and fully functional that day, but come that evening (I estimate about 12-15 hours), you will knock out.  The idea is to get you through the day, say if you're fresh off a redeye flight but have a meeting or something.  You could of course keep taking the stuff, but your body benefits from the sleep, so it isn't really recommended.Something else to more, at least from my experience, is that it appears to conflict slightly with Dramamine.  Nothing serious, but I usually take the non-drowsy version; taking 1Above and the non-drowsy seemed to result in the same effect as taking the normal Dramamine.  Woosy after an hour.  Totally unexpected.  This is after sleeping for 6 hours.Anyway, those are my thoughts on the stuff.  Effective, but way overpriced.

These were comfortable when I first bought them, but the left shoe has torn near the toe and the foam is fully exposed, about 6 inch opening.  Right shoe is still perfectly intact, which is weird.  I'm considering it a defective stitching.  The shoes are not too small or tight, they're slightly bigger than my feet with more than enough room to move.It's too bad too because the foam pad bottom is quite comfortable and the shoes could pass for Vans.

As a purveyor of fine shaving products, I decided to give the Shaving Powder a try, mostly to try and deal with ingrown hairs that show up on occasion.First the powder bears an eerie resemblance to cocaine.  It also will get all over the place no matter how cautious or careful you are.  It's not hard to clean up, but it's annoying.Second the container is not X-ray friendly, so despite the fact that it's a powder which is normally allowed through TSA, the cannister might cause them to stop you.  When they open it and see what appears to be cocaine, they may very well proceed to frisk you.  A very easy way to address this issue is for the manufacturer to consider a different container style, ideally one that is transparent and just screws on like any other cannister.Speaking of screw on, the container is difficult to open without a flat edge of some kind.  I use a multi-tool that has a small metal cutting edge, then I don't completely re-close it afterwards; it's closed enough that it keeps it fresh but not so much that I can't re-open it by hand.  Again, a different container would help this a lot.Mixing the powder and water is the worst.  Of the total time it takes to complete the process I would say that mixing is the great majority of time, even more so than the set time.  I really wish there were a way to just have a "micro blender" or something that could blend this faster.I've left it on for 10 minutes without issue.  I wipe it off with a damp, hot towel while I'm in the shower, then proceed to wash my face with a scrub.  Afterwards I go lightly over the area with a safety razor downward.  The hair that doesn't get removed via the towel (I'd say roughly 30% does not) falls off easily with this method.  I'm left with a baby smooth surface.  This additional step seems only necessary with my face.  If I use the powder on my body, the hot towel seems to get 95% of the hair off.  Longer, fine hair, best results.  Short, coarse hair, not so much.Good stuff and the value of this 12-pack was awesome.

I think some people don't really understand coffee.  By that, I mean that there is a science to brewing coffee correctly.  Of course, how the beans are harvested and roasted and whatnot matter for the flavor of it all (Starbucks, as an example, is too roasted and tastes burnt), but when you're sitting down to have a cup you really need to have the right components.Bulletproof Coffee's claim to fame is that it's organic.  That's it.  There are a lot of fancy words on the packaging and on the Bulletproof website, but at the core, the coffee is grown organic with no additional chemicals.  That means that you're getting a maximized antioxidant effect out of the coffee.  All coffee has antioxidant properties when drunk in moderation; how much depends on the chemicals, the growing, the harvesting, the roasting, etc.  So please, don't think this is some magic coffee with stuff added to it to make it superpowered; it's not.That said, there's nothing wrong with organic coffee.Tastewise I felt that the coffee fell just short of Starbucks: burnt but not overly so like theirs.  I did like that it was ground coarse rather than fine (Starbucks is ground fine and it's annoying when not using paper filters, for example), and I did appreciate the smell.  It's a Columbian roast, not too light and not too dark.  Some might feel the coffee is weak; I don't.  I use two heaping teaspoons which suits me just fine.  One teaspoon was like water, three teaspoons was...well, like Starbucks. Disgusting.One annoyance for the packaging.  It uses just a sticker to reseal the bag rather than what everyone else does with a metal bend.  Not sure who thought this was a good idea but it's a failure.Second annoyance for the packaging, the bottom is in an "X" shape rather than a box-shape.  This means there will always be coffee grounds stuck in that crevice when you start to run out that you can't get to.  A small thing, but I point it out.I usually blend this coffee with unsalted butter, half-and-half (I have to have cream in my coffee, I can't just have butter), Bulletproof Brain Octane Oil - 16 oz., and a drop of Vitamin D Drops - 2oz Liquid D3 5000 IU Per Dropper - 100IU Per Drop - Best Absorption - Natural Vit D Supplement Treats Deficiency for Baby, Kids and Adults - Boost Your Immune System, Fight Fatigue Naturally.  Seems to help with energy - it's not a magic elixir or anything.  I have to supplement this with a can of Starbucks Refreshers Variety Pack, 12 Ounce Slim Cans, 12 Pack, which is where my focus and sharpness come from.I read reviews online about people making a similar blend and having it curb hunger.  Not me.  If anything I end up quite a bit more hungry than I normally would within 2 hours, guaranteed.  It's not good to drink too much coffee, so I only have one cup of this per day.I also read about people losing weight drinking the coffee.  Again, not here.  If I lose weight it's because I'm purposely eating foods designed to do that.  This doesn't help me lose weight because, again, it doesn't curb my hunger, it makes it worse.These are my personal experiences.  Your mileage may vary.  I still order it and I still enjoy it if only for the energy and wakeup power it gives.

I purchased this adapter somewhat in a hurry as I was on business travel and had forgotten the charge cable for my work-issued iPhone.  Tim Cook and Steve Jobs with their mission to keep people using proprietary adapters isn't my thing - I have at least 6 microUSB cables, 2 of which are with me at all times.  This is because I'm an Android user; I don't like or care for mobile Apple products.  But it's what the company issues, so I'm stuck with it.The adapter is tiny, and I can see how it would easy to lose this thing.  I really wish they would have included some sort of small chain or loop so that you could attach it to keys or a lanyard.  AS is I plan to just keep it in the laptop bag and be done with it.It worked perfectly for charging the iPhone 5S.  I did not try data connection directly, but I did notice that I couldn't get USB tethering working.  I wasn't able to confirm (as I didn't fight with it for long) whether that was due to the adapter or the driver on the laptop.  It never saw it as a network device.

The fit was a little large.  Washing a few times helped here; it got them down to a more reasonable fit around the waist area.  They're comfortable and keep you warm rather nicely.  Where I had an issue is the pockets - they are WAY too shallow.  Things constantly fall out when sitting anywhere.  Also there are no rear pockets.Anyone trying to use these as just casual pants for out-and-about who actually carry wallets and keys will be annoyed by these issues.

But it didn't.See, I'm a Magic Shave Shaving Powder Gold - 4.5 oz user.I had to take a business trip and didn't want TSA groping me after assuming it was cocaine or something (the powder looks a LOT like illicit drugs, unfortunately).  The canister also was not very X-ray friendly.  I was going to buy some after I arrived at the destination, but because the powder works so well, you really only need to use it like every 2-3 days or so, which would have been a waste to sit there mixing so much for so brief a trip.  So I got the cream, figuring it'd be the same.It wasn't.First, the instructions tell you to apply it thick.  But the cream is so watery that it just didn't want to apply like that at all.  Not for nothing, because even with what it did apply, I got some removal.  Nowhere near what the powder did with the same instructions.The real issue is that it burned the living (blank) out of my neckline just below my beard line, where the bend is when you look down.  And yes, I used a pre-shave, and no, I didn't wash my face before hand.  A red, swollen line right across.  It looked like I'd been hanged - and being African American that's not a look you want to go for.For some reason, I had no redness or burning anywhere on my beard area.  I'm not sure why there was this reaction, the area in question was constantly exposed to the powder version with no ill effects.  I'm thinking it was the crease itself that the cream just overreacted to, though I'm not sure why.So on the first hand, it didn't really work that good, and on the second it burned the living (blank) out of me.  (thanks to a post shave balm, the redness did go down after 2 days or so).

And I was impressed, just not for the price (thus the one star knock off).  Don't let that deter you if all you want is a way to keep an eye on things and be alerted to (other) things.PRO: The setup was very simple.  A caveman could do it.CON: Such a small device literally requiring a cable is a turn-off.  That this does not have a Li-Ion battery and support recharging is simply a joke, I'm sorry.  Now, you might say "but then how would you charge it if it's mounted somewhere?!" Easy - I would buy 4 or so of the portable recharge packs and just swap between them every week or whatever while the others are recharging.  The value of doing this is that when mounting it somewhere that is not readily accessible to a power outlet (for example, the ceiling), I don't have to care about buying extension cables BUT I could charge the thing.  Something this size should be able to hold a charge for at least a week if not longer.  Might seem like an additional maintenance routine, but at least provide the choice for those that don't want cables everywhere.PRO: The video quality is great.CON: Why do you have to tap anything to "improve quality" when zooming in?  This doesn't make sense, the camera should automatically assume improved quality since - SHOCK - the only reason one would zoom in is to get a CLEARER LOOK at the target!  This is clunky and silly.PRO: The alerts give you enough to know when something's going on.CON: As with most other cameras it's picky about lights and shadows.  So it lets you pick a zone where you want to detect movement, the problem is if light from a window runs across that zone as the sun moves, the camera detects this as motion and sends false alerts.  It's annoying, because you can't tell the camera how to properly identify true motion even though it's pinned down to a specific region only.PRO: It's versatile enough to mount nearly anywhere.CON: The drywall anchors provided didn't accept the screws at all.  As a result mine is mounted precariously.  A better design would have included a center mount screw, no drywall mount, and drywall anchors as part of the back plate (not separate) that you just drive the screw through and into the wall, so that the screw itself creates the hole that the anchor goes into, while the center screw allows you to at least keep the thing up there while getting the mounting done.PRO: it picks up audio quite nicely.  I was able to hear sounds from downstairs, which is what I wanted.CON: Because the microphone is amplified there is a ton of white noise in the background, so it's hard to detail exactly what you're hearing unless it's a car going by on the street outside.  Would it have killed someone to implement some cleanup here?  It's called noise gate, it's not hard.PRO: You can tell the camera not to detect, dependent on the location of your phone or tablet.CON: This is GPS dependent, meaning that of course, it's not going to be fine enough detail to know if you're in one room vs. another.  It will know if you're in one building vs. another, yes.  If that isn't what you wanted, well, you're kinda SOL.  I'm not sure why this bothers me so much, but it does.PRO: You can tell the camera not to detect during certain times of the day.CON: The issue here is that it assumes such times are static OR that you would combine this with the location detection (so for example, if you're in the home, it doesn't detect but if you're not in the home, it does).  But say I'm in the office.  I don't want it detecting.  I can't use the location setting (see above), and I might be in the office any of the 24 hours in a day, so I can't use the time setting.  So ultimately I have to manually disable alerting while I'm in the office, which is annoying.Again, pros and cons.
