There is musicology behind this disc - reconstructing three different historical stages of the music setting of one of the Oracles of the Sibyl, the prophetess of ancient Greece and Rome, that apparently was much in vogue in Medieval and Renaissance Europe, as it was considered to have announced the coming of Christ: "From Heaven a God will come for centuries to come, present in the flesh to judge the world". Its original Greek version is also an acrostic, the first letter of each of the five first verses forming the Greek code word ICHTUS, "fish" but also Iesous CHristos Theou hUios Soter, Jesus Christ Son of God Saviour. Sibyls were actually very trendy in Antiquity throughout the Mediterranean area, and this one is attributed to the Sibyl Erythrea of Anatolia / Asia Minor. The Chant has been made part of the Christmas liturgy and, although it was banned from Christian liturgy by the Council of Trent in the late 16th Century, it is still in vogue in some parts of Mediterranean Europe, like Malta, Catalonia, the Balearic Islands, Sardinia, Sicily and other parts of Italy. Augustine gives a Latin translation (that he doesn't claim to be his) in City of God XVIII-23, which served as a basis to the versions current in the Medieval times. The French Wikipedia entry on Ichtus gives an earlier Latin translation by Emperor Constantine of Byzantium, from Oratio Sanctorum Coetus, side by side with what seems to be the, or "a" Greek original, but strangely, the English corresponding Wikipedia entry doesn't display the same document (see my upload). The text is incomplete but I've found another website which gives the complete Constantine poem in Latin, and Constantine's translation is interesting for extending the acrostic to form the words Jesus Christus Dei Filius Servator Crux (Augustine did the same only on the 15 first verse, which read JESUCS CHREISTOS), but when you look closely at the hard-to-decipher Greek text, it's puzzling to see that the third verse seems to fall out of sequence, with a Sigma that shouldn't be there. You can also find online (on "Mystagogy", the weblog of John Sanidopoulos, of all places...) an English translation of what seems to be the Constantine poem which restitutes the full acrostic of 31 verses, Jesus Christ Son Of God Saviour Cross: well done, Mystagogue John!Almost 30 years after this disc was recorded (1988), the Wikipedia entry on the "Sibylline Oracles" is far clearer than Savall's liner notes about the history and medieval posterity of these oracles: those in vogue in Medieval Europe had actually nothing to do with those of Ancient Greece and Rome. Let me quote: "The Sibylline Oracles (Latin: Oracula Sibyllina; sometimes called the "pseudo-Sibylline Oracles") are a collection of oracular utterances written in Greek hexameters ascribed to the Sibyls, prophetesses who uttered divine revelations in a frenzied state. Fourteen books and eight fragments of Sibylline Oracles survive. These are a collection of utterances that were composed or edited under various circumstances, probably between the 2nd and 6th centuries AD, and are not to be confused with the original Sibylline Books of ancient Roman religion which are now lost. Some apocalyptic passages scattered throughout seem to adumbrate themes of John's Book of Revelation and other Apocalyptic literature. The oracles have undergone extensive editing, re-writing, and redaction as they came to be exploited in wider circles." I've also found online an erudite article about the musical setting of this particular Oracle in the Middle Ages, more up to date than Savall's 1988 musicology, but in French only.Incidentally, speaking of the loss of the original Sibylline Books, we are all horrified to see the illiterate thugs of Da Esh destroy the remnants of pre-Islamic civilizations wherever they rule, but who refers that to the hundreds of thousands (no exaggeration) of pre-Christian documents kept in "pagan" libraries and temples that the Christians destroyed in the 4th and 6th centuries? There's a Wikipedia entry about that in French, German, Danish and even Latin... but, strangely, not in English. Mmmhh... I wonder if there are things English-speaking Christians would prefer not to remember. It starts like this: "the losses of books in Late Antiquity (between the end of the 3rd century and the end of the 6th century) represent an irretrievable damage to the cultural heritage of Classical Antiquity. Through the loss of transmission of a great part of the ancient Geeek and Latin literature, the number of works that were kept until the Modern times is extremely small. Most of the texts that were transmitted were done so through medieval copies, and the original fragments of texts from Antiquity are in very small numbers". By some estimations, only 1 out of 1000 pre- or non-Christian texts have been bequeathed to the future. The last great Library of Constantinople, when it accidentally burnt in 475, had 120 000 codexes (books); in 576, the first Christian library of Cassiodorus, the Roman councilor of King Theodoric the Ostrogoth in Ravenna, Italy, had 100 ("Cassiodorus also collaborated with Pope Agapetus I in establishing a library of Greek and Latin texts, which were intended to support a Christian school in Rome"). Yep, nothing changes, the actions and effects of illiterate and intolerant religious zealotry remain the same then and today, a brutal onslaught on historical memory. But you can say, of course, that it's not because we did it 15 centuries ago, when we knew much less, that it justifies them of doing it today, when they should know much more. Religious zealotry never learns.Anyway, Savall and his band present three different versions of, basically, the same Chant/Prophecy, the first in Latin (Augustinus' translation) from the 10th/11th century, the second in Provenal from the 13th Century, and the third from the Renaissance in Catalan (a language VERY similar to turn-of-the-millenium Provenal). It's not entirely clear from the liner notes which sources they used, apparently a combination. See what YOU make out of this:"Realizing today an historical version of the Sibyl's Chant supposes that we are in a dynamic perspective in time, as if we were trying to grasp its coming into being at one moment without interrupting the source of its essence and of its mystery. Our method consists of first cataloging in chronological order all the known versions of each chant in a way that allows us to proceed without a break for example from the first little ornamented chants of the tenth century to the more melismatic versions of the twelfth centuries without interrupting the continuity of the chant. It was clearly necessary to determine the selection of the different versions according to the character of the text for each verse."Anyway, ultimately, it's not the musicology that counts. Much of it is very speculative anyway; is this how the music really sounded in the 10th/11th century, 13th Century Provence and Renaissance Catalonia? In truth, I don't think we know for sure, but it certainly matches our fantasy of how it might have sounded. What counts are the moods elicited, the first Chant austere, bare, with only, past its introduction with bells and a call of chalumeau (medieval oboe), a cappella chorus with drone for the refrain and an accompaniment of vielle for the soloist, still meditative and dreamy with its accompaniment of oud / Arabic lute in the Provenal second, and the third still meditative and wistful but also more grandiose, with its full accompaniment of viol quartet, cornet, sackbut, and drums and polyphonic chorus.And what counts is the angelic voice of Montserrat Figueras. This is a voice to send you high (even if - or maybe even because it is on a very uniformly meditative mood throughout).Another attraction, at least for the French-speaking listener, is the Provenal and Catalan languages, so alien and yet so resemblant to modern French.TT 54 minutes. A companion disc was later recorded, in 1996, on another label, Audivis-Fontalis, El Canto De La Sibila II: Galicia Castilla, which also reissued this recording, now become volume 1, El Cant De La Sibil-La I (Catalunya). Note also that the product photo on the present entry is the one of this later Fontalis reissue, which apparently bears the same barcode as the original edition, albeit a slightly different label number, ES 8705 vs E 8705 for the original edition. See my upload for the cover photos of the original edition. Both volumes were also reissued on Alia Vox, Savall's own label, in SACD version, El Cant de la and Cant De La Sibil.La 3 (no reason why it should be titled "3", it's in fact 2, although even that indication appears nowhere on the disc's front or back cover), and, at the time of writing, this first volume sells cheaper on the Marketplace in its SACD format than this original edition or the Fontalis reissue. But it is two later budget reissues by Nave, in non-SACD format, that right now sell cheapest, El Cant de la Sibil-la I: Catalunya - Montserrat Figueras / La Capella Reial de Catalunya / Jordi Savall and El Cant De La Sibil-La (The Song Of The Sibyl).

Although Zelenka (1679-1745) is far from a neglected presence on CD, he is still not, I think, given the public recognition he deserves: quite simply, when it comes to choral/religious music (in which Zelenka very much specialized), based on what I've heard of his compositions, he is, in my opinion, one of the very greats of the first half of the 18th century, on a par with Bach, Handel, Vivaldi and Telemann.This Missa Dei Patri is a good case in point. Despite its small catalog numbering, ZWV 19, it is one of Zelenka's ultimate compositions, from 1740. It is part of a cycle which Zelenka intended to reach six such masses, but ultimately he composed only two others, the Missa Dei Fili ZWV 20 and Missa Omnium Sanctorum ZWV 21. Apparently he wrote them with no performance in mind (no parts exist, only a conductor score), and they weren't performed during his lifetime.Like its two companions, Missa Dei Patris is an incredible masterpiece, with an opulence that seems to point to the great masses of Haydn, choral numbers of explosive power and/or tear-wringing solemn beauty (the choral "ascent to heaven" at 0:30 in the Sanctus, track 15, is one of these moments) and often with surprising melodic twists, fugues that equal those of Bach, if not surpass them in their searing and sweeping passion ("Cum sancto spirito", track 9, repeated on the final chorus, Dona nobis pacem, track 20), and a melodic writing for soloists that, like those of Handel and Vivaldi, is always distinctive and invigorating. Zelenka's orchestra is reduced to strings, with two oboes that are, here, unless I've missed something, never given a solo role but always double the strings, but there is nothing austere in his accompaniment, on the contrary he uses his ensemble in a highly colorful and virtuosic manner, as exemplified by the extraordinarily florid accompaniment in the Quoniam Tu Solus Sanctus (track 8) and even more of Et resurrexit (track 13). Truly, when I'm  listening to this extraordinary and breathtaking invention that is the Et resurrexit followed by the Et vitam venture saeculi, I don't know who else composed like that around 1740. In fact, I'm not even sure Haydn or Mozart composed anything of such furious power, fifty years later. And I'm thinking that Zelenka didn't reach much success and recognition in his lifetime, because he was too daring, way too much in advance on his own time.And yet, when you have zillion of performances and recordings of Bach's Mass in B, Handel's Messiah and Vivaldi's Gloria, this is only one of the two recordings of Missa Dei Patris represented on CD (there was another one in the LP era), and the situation is the same with the Missa Dei Filii and Missa Omnium Sanctorum. It was made in 1988 and was a pionneering effort, in a time when Zelenka was still very much a Czech specialty. Frieder Bernius, who made a great recording of Missa Dei Filii in 1989 for Deutsche Harmonia Mundi (Zelenka: Missa Dei Filii / Litaniae Lauretanae), recorded the Missa Dei Patri in 2000 for Carus (Missa Dei Patris). There are also only two recordings of ZWB 21, one by Bernius again from 1997 for Sony that wasn't even distributed in the US and isn't offered at the time of writing, Musik aus der Dresdner Hofkirche: Missa Omnium Sanctorum and ditto for the French budget reissue, Zelenka: Messe Ultimarum Sexta (Missa Omnium Sanctorum), Zwv 21), and one by the Prague Baroque Soloists under Adam Viktora, Zelenka: Missa Omnium Sanctorum, Christe eleison, Barbara dira effera.Although my comparative appreciation is tentative because tainted by the fact that I've listened to Bernius not from the CD but from the YouTube upload and hence probably in inferior sonic conditions, ultimately, if you have only one, I find Gttler's version preferable. His is an approach on a grand scale, with a sizeable orchestra (Bernius' Stuttgart Baroque Ensemble sounds more astringent and typically period-instrument) further magnified by sonics with a long resonance. Compared to Bernius, Gttler also has a somewhat thick and heavy continuo and oftentimes a heaviness of motion and lack of dynamism, especially at the beginning of the work (as in the orchestral introduction, or the fugue on the opening Kyrie track 1 at 2:21, the Domine Fili track 6, the Credo track 10). Some of the more funeral passages can take that approach (as the Domine Deus, track 5), but sometimes Gttler is also entirely up to the music, as in his exhilaratingly dynamic Gloria, track 4, much better than Bernius here. He is impressively powerful in Qui sedes track 7, in Crucifixus, track 12, Et resurrexit track 13, searing in the Cum Sancto Spirito fugue (track 9), and in the Quoniam Tu Solus Sanctus trio (track 8) he is suitably dynamic and there is little to choose there between him and Bernius. But, even when Gttler occasional plods compared to Bernius (as in the Credo, track 10), the choral moments are always grand and powerful and particularly well spotlighted by the sonics, more so than with Bernius whose chorus (with the proviso that this may be an effect of hearing it on Youtube) sounds smaller-scaled and less impressive. Although I've always found Ren Jacobs sour in tone, the soloists (which include Olaf Br) are fine. I had never heard or heard of soprano Venceslava Hruba-Freiberger, but she sings exquisitely. In the Benedictus (for baritone, track 16) and Agnus Dei I (for alto, track 18), it is Bernius who is more plangent and funeral, and excessively so I find, it bogs down the music: Gttler's more animated tempi are preferable here. The Mass is a huge work, running here 70 minutes. It is, as its companion the Missa Dei Filii, one of the great masterpieces of early 18th Century sacred music. Experience shows that it is possible to survive without knowing the music of Zelenka (or Bach, or Handel), but life is way more fulfilling and fulfilled when you do.The Dresden library, where hundreds of manuscripts of Zelenka are held, has done a tremendous and admirable job at scanning them and putting them online on the International Music Scores Library Project. It's very moving to see those manuscripts. Some - and it is the case with Missa Dei Patris - are in a dangerously tattered condition, and they are occasionally difficult to read, because hastily handwritten with nearly undecipherable indications, with compositional conventions different from those of today (for instance, the rhythms on the different staves are often not aligned vertically), sometimes in faded ink and on damaged sheets of paper. But in the case of Missa Dei Patris, for the info of anyone who'd be interested, like me, in listening to the music while following with the score, I must say that whoever did the uploading job made things particularly difficult for the reader, because some of the movements are a jumble of pages out-of-sequence. So you first have to realize that something is wrong ("why am I lost?"), then try to figure out what the problem is. It took me hours - which at least were hours spent with the Missa. For instance, the Gloria, which starts page 34 on IMSLP, gos in a sequence 34, 36, 35, 38, 37, 40, 39, 42, 41, 44, 43, 46, 45, 48, 47, 49 and from there back to normal. Things are even more complicated in the Domine Fili, because there Zelenka wrote on two systems, and obviously the score is to be read upper system page left to upper system page right, then lower system page left to lower system page right. But since the pages are loaded one after the other (and out of sequence) and must be scrolled vertically, you get a sequence of 58-1, 60-1, 58-2, 60-2, 59-1, 61-1, 59-2, 61-2 etc. In order to follow the Agnus Dei Aria for alto (track 18), you need to realize that it's written on three systems, so the sequence is 184-1, 185-1, 184-2, 185-2, 184-3, 185-3 and repeat with 186-187 (but I haven't found the four bars of coda on the manuscript). The final fugue, Dona nobis pacem, track 20, past its first page (189), is also written on two systems, so the sequence is 190-1, 191-1, 190-2, 191-2, 192-1 and so forth.The one that gave me the most trouble was the beginning of the Et resurrexit. Things go smoothly when the chorus enters, but I simply couldn't reconcile what I heard and what I saw during the extrarordinary orchestral introduction, tried to see if the first page of the movement had not been put out of its sequence but just couldn't find the page that corresponded to the music I heard.... until I realized that the first page (page 134 on IMSLP) was perfectly in its sequence... but turned upside down! Well, it is certainly music to bowl you over.And a P.S. from August 7: I mustered by best German and reported the problem to the Dresden library. They acknowledged receipt, explained that the Missa manuscript was a complicated case because it is one of the rare instances in which the manuscript is in the form of loose, unbound sheets of paper, and the page numbering is sometimes faulty, with recto and verso inverted. They'll fix it. Glad I could bring a very small contribution to the posterity of this great work.At the time of writing there's a cheaper offer than this: Zelenka: Missa Dei Patris.

Although Zelenka (1679-1745) is far from a neglected presence on CD, he is still not, I think, given the public recognition he deserves: quite simply, when it comes to choral/religious music (in which Zelenka very much specialized), based on what I've heard of his compositions, he is, in my opinion, one of the very greats of the first half of the 18th century, on a par with Bach, Handel, Vivaldi and Telemann.This Missa Dei Patri is a good case in point. Despite its small catalog numbering, ZWV 19, it is one of Zelenka's ultimate compositions, from 1740. It is part of a cycle which Zelenka intended to reach six such masses, but ultimately he composed only two others, the Missa Dei Fili ZWV 20 and Missa Omnium Sanctorum ZWV 21. Apparently he wrote them with no performance in mind (no parts exist, only a conductor score), and they weren't performed during his lifetime.Like its two companions, Missa Dei Patris is an incredible masterpiece, with an opulence that seems to point to the great masses of Haydn, choral numbers of explosive power and/or tear-wringing solemn beauty (the choral "ascent to heaven" at 0:30 in the Sanctus, track 15, is one of these moments) and often with surprising melodic twists, fugues that equal those of Bach, if not surpass them in their searing and sweeping passion ("Cum sancto spirito", track 9, repeated on the final chorus, Dona nobis pacem, track 20), and a melodic writing for soloists that, like those of Handel and Vivaldi, is always distinctive and invigorating. Zelenka's orchestra is reduced to strings, with two oboes that are, here, unless I've missed something, never given a solo role but always double the strings, but there is nothing austere in his accompaniment, on the contrary he uses his ensemble in a highly colorful and virtuosic manner, as exemplified by the extraordinarily florid accompaniment in the Quoniam Tu Solus Sanctus (track 8) and even more of Et resurrexit (track 13). Truly, when I'm  listening to this extraordinary and breathtaking invention that is the Et resurrexit followed by the Et vitam venture saeculi, I don't know who else composed like that around 1740. In fact, I'm not even sure Haydn or Mozart composed anything of such furious power, fifty years later. And I'm thinking that Zelenka didn't reach much success and recognition in his lifetime, because he was too daring, way too much in advance on his own time.And yet, when you have zillion of performances and recordings of Bach's Mass in B, Handel's Messiah and Vivaldi's Gloria, this is only one of the two recordings of Missa Dei Patris represented on CD (there was another one in the LP era), and the situation is the same with the Missa Dei Filii and Missa Omnium Sanctorum. It was made in 1988 and was a pionneering effort, in a time when Zelenka was still very much a Czech specialty. Frieder Bernius, who made a great recording of Missa Dei Filii in 1989 for Deutsche Harmonia Mundi (Zelenka: Missa Dei Filii / Litaniae Lauretanae), recorded the Missa Dei Patri in 2000 for Carus (Missa Dei Patris). There are also only two recordings of ZWB 21, one by Bernius again from 1997 for Sony that wasn't even distributed in the US and isn't offered at the time of writing, Musik aus der Dresdner Hofkirche: Missa Omnium Sanctorum and ditto for the French budget reissue, Zelenka: Messe Ultimarum Sexta (Missa Omnium Sanctorum), Zwv 21), and one by the Prague Baroque Soloists under Adam Viktora, Zelenka: Missa Omnium Sanctorum, Christe eleison, Barbara dira effera.Although my comparative appreciation is tentative because tainted by the fact that I've listened to Bernius not from the CD but from the YouTube upload and hence probably in inferior sonic conditions, ultimately, if you have only one, I find Gttler's version preferable. His is an approach on a grand scale, with a sizeable orchestra (Bernius' Stuttgart Baroque Ensemble sounds more astringent and typically period-instrument) further magnified by sonics with a long resonance. Compared to Bernius, Gttler also has a somewhat thick and heavy continuo and oftentimes a heaviness of motion and lack of dynamism, especially at the beginning of the work (as in the orchestral introduction, or the fugue on the opening Kyrie track 1 at 2:21, the Domine Fili track 6, the Credo track 10). Some of the more funeral passages can take that approach (as the Domine Deus, track 5), but sometimes Gttler is also entirely up to the music, as in his exhilaratingly dynamic Gloria, track 4, much better than Bernius here. He is impressively powerful in Qui sedes track 7, in Crucifixus, track 12, Et resurrexit track 13, searing in the Cum Sancto Spirito fugue (track 9), and in the Quoniam Tu Solus Sanctus trio (track 8) he is suitably dynamic and there is little to choose there between him and Bernius. But, even when Gttler occasional plods compared to Bernius (as in the Credo, track 10), the choral moments are always grand and powerful and particularly well spotlighted by the sonics, more so than with Bernius whose chorus (with the proviso that this may be an effect of hearing it on Youtube) sounds smaller-scaled and less impressive. Although I've always found Ren Jacobs sour in tone, the soloists (which include Olaf Br) are fine. I had never heard or heard of soprano Venceslava Hruba-Freiberger, but she sings exquisitely. In the Benedictus (for baritone, track 16) and Agnus Dei I (for alto, track 18), it is Bernius who is more plangent and funeral, and excessively so I find, it bogs down the music: Gttler's more animated tempi are preferable here. But since the pages are loaded one after the other (and out of sequence) and must be scrolled vertically, you get a sequence of 58-1, 60-1, 58-2, 60-2, 59-1, 61-1, 59-2, 61-2 etc. In order to follow the Agnus Dei Aria for alto (track 18), you need to realize that it's written on three systems, so the sequence is 184-1, 185-1, 184-2, 185-2, 184-3, 185-3 and repeat with 186-187 (but I haven't found the four bars of coda on the manuscript). The Czech Jan Dismas Zelenka (1679-1745) was a near-exact contemporary of Bach (1685-1750) and he spent part of his career in Dresden, less than a hundred kilometers from Bach's Leipzig; both vied for some of the same honors, and it is known (from a later report from Bach's son Carl Philip Emmanuel) that Bach knew his colleague personally and held him in high esteem. So it is tempting to try and hear echoes of Bach in the choral music of Zelenka. But the temptation should best be resisted. Zelenka speaks very much with his own voice. Despite its small catalog numbering (ZWV 20), Missa Dei Filii belongs to Zelenka's ultimate trilogy (1740/41), together with the Missa Dei Patris ZWV 19 and Missa Omnium Sanctorum ZWV 21. It consists only of Kyrie and Gloria, without the three other parts of the ordinary, and it is not known if Zelenka intended it that way or just left his mass incomplete (but the fact that the two others are complete gives a pointer). Given that the mass as it is runs 42 minutes, one can only imagine its length had Zelenka written the rest. That Missa Dei Patris runs 70 minutes with a Kyrie and Gloria of less than 30 gives a clue. Apparently Zelenka didn't write those three masses with a performance in view, and they weren't performed during his lifetime: at least no instrumental parts have been found, only the conductor manuscript scores. Like its two companions, ZWV 20 is a work of extraordinary power and beauty, evoking less Bach than anticipating the great masses of Haydn. I can't start describing all the marvels of Zelenka's invention, the choral moments of extraordinary power and sweep (the Kyrie, the extraordinary Gloria, nine and a half minutes of lush and uniquely elaborate jubilation, for which little peers of that era come to mind, the imposing and almost funeral Qui Sedes ad dexteram patris over a nervous and panting instrumental accompaniment anticipating Gluck and Berlioz...), the beautiful melismata of the solo arias (Christe eleison, Qui tollis peccata mundi, starting with a five minute solo for soprano with florid violin accompaniment, then turning into an aria for the baritone, soon joined in duet by the tenor, for four more minutes, etc. Zelenka's ability to churn out irresistible arias seems not inferior to Handel's or Vivaldi's), the moods alternating between the grandiosely solemn, the deploratory and the jubilant. One often reads about Zelenka - and indeed in the liner notes - that he alternated, or even combined, old style and new style. But what's "old" about Zelenka's style? That he ended with a great choral fugue on the "cum sanctus spirito" verse? But Zelenka's concluding fugue doesn't sound in the least "old-style" or stern or cerebral and astringent: it develops extraordinary sweep and warmth and sounds like the greatest homage the mind of a musician can pay to his Lord, on the words "with the Holy Ghost in the glory of God the Father".I'll be shorter on the Litany of Loreto ZWV 152, only to say that, with its companion the Litany ZWV 151 it is also part of those ultimate works of Zelenka (1741/4), and that it is a masterpiece of equal stature as the Mass. For those interested, the online International Music Scores Library Project (IMSLP) offers these works (but for some reason their copy of the Litanies is limited to the first two movements) and possibly a hundred more scores of Zelenka - and all scans of the autograph manuscripts, miraculously escaped from the World War II bombings (they had been sheltered in the cellar of the Japanese embassy!) and now kept at the Dresden Library: bless these people for having taken the time to scan all these invaluable documents and made them available to all. Those manuscripts are not always easy to follow and some pages are in tattered condition, but I find it incredibly moving precisely for that: it's like having the composer's ghost right over your shoulder.Given what extraordinary masterpieces these are, it is incredible, and somewhat depressing, to think that they were so seldom recorded. So far as I could establish, with the help of the great Zelenka CD-discography featured on jdzelenka dot net and various other researches for LPs, this was the premiere recording of both pieces, and it remains to date, more than a quarter-century later, the only recording of the Litany, while only one more has been added to the catalog of Missa Dei Filii, in 1997, by the Dresden Chamber Choir and Baroque Orchestra under Hans-Christoph Rademann, on the obscure label Raumklang, Miserere-Missa Dei Filii.If you want to look at things positively, you'll say that it's because this version by Frieder Bernius was so perfect to start with that everybody felt they had nothing better to say. If you want to look at it less positively you'll say that, in view of the zillion recordings of Bach's Mass in B, Handel's Messiah and Vivaldi's Gloria, it shows how badly discographic posterity errs in the way it treats the great masterpieces of the past. The good thing about it is that you don't need to break the piggy bank to acquire all the extant recordings of these two masterpieces.Not that it's necessary to do so either. Experience shows that an interpretation can always be bettered, but here it is hard to imagine how it could. Bernius conducts with passion and boasts some of the best early music soloists of the time (1989), Nancy Argenta, Michael Chance, Christoph Prgardien, one of the best period-instrument ensembles (the Canadian Tafelmusik Baroque) and his own vocal ensemble. That said, in the absence of comparison, you can never be sure. Well, I have purchased and listened to the other version of Missa ZWV 20: see my review of the other disc for the complete details. Suffice here to say that it confirms the excellence of Bernius' version, not because it is inferior, on the contrary, because it is also excellent, almost as good as Bernius' and in some details or individual movements even a touch better, but that it is in fact so similar in interpretive approach to Bernius that it's not really a complete necessity to add it to your collection, unless you are a diehard Zelenkite.That said, this is the budget reissue of a recording whose original edition can be found under Missa Dei Filii Litaniae Lauretanae and, at the time of writing, sells much cheaper on the marketplace that the one offer of this supposedly budget reissue. So leave this one aside and go to the original, but don't miss this. On the basis of these works and others of Zelenka that I've heard, he is one of the major composer of choral/religious works of the first half of the 18th century, of equal stature with Bach, Handel, Vivaldi and Telemann, and among all these, the one who remains still today badly and unfairly under-recognized. As with Bach, a life spent without Zelenka is liveable, but not as worthwhile and fulfilling as a life spent with him.

It consists only of Kyrie and Gloria, without the three other parts of the ordinary, and it is not known if Zelenka intended it that way or just left his mass incomplete (but the fact that the two others are complete gives a pointer). Given that the mass as it is runs 42 minutes, one can only imagine its length had Zelenka written the rest. That Missa Dei Patris runs 70 minutes with a Kyrie and Gloria of less than 30 gives a clue. Apparently Zelenka didn't write those three masses with a performance in view, and they weren't performed during his lifetime: at least no instrumental parts have been found, only the conductor manuscript scores. Like its two companions, ZWV 20 is a work of extraordinary power and beauty, evoking less Bach than anticipating the great masses of Haydn. I can't start describing all the marvels of Zelenka's invention, the choral moments of extraordinary power and sweep (the Kyrie, the extraordinary Gloria, nine and a half minutes of lush and uniquely elaborate jubilation, for which little peers of that era come to mind, the imposing and almost funeral Qui Sedes ad dexteram patris over a nervous and panting instrumental accompaniment anticipating Gluck and Berlioz...), the beautiful melismata of the solo arias (Christe eleison, Qui tollis peccata mundi, starting with a five minute solo for soprano with florid violin accompaniment, then turning into an aria for the baritone, soon joined in duet by the tenor, for four more minutes, etc. Zelenka's ability to churn out irresistible arias seems not inferior to Handel's or Vivaldi's), the moods alternating between the grandiosely solemn, the deploratory and the jubilant. One often reads about Zelenka - and indeed in the liner notes - that he alternated, or even combined, old style and new style. But what's "old" about Zelenka's style? That he ended with a great choral fugue on the "cum sanctus spirito" verse? But Zelenka's concluding fugue doesn't sound in the least "old-style" or stern or cerebral and astringent: it develops extraordinary sweep and warmth and sounds like the greatest homage the mind of a musician can pay to his Lord, on the words "with the Holy Ghost in the glory of God the Father".I'll be shorter on the Litany of Loreto ZWV 152, only to say that, with its companion the Litany ZWV 151 it is also part of those ultimate works of Zelenka (1741/4), and that it is a masterpiece of equal stature as the Mass. For those interested, the online International Music Scores Library Project (IMSLP) offers these works (but for some reason their copy of the Litanies is limited to the first two movements) and possibly a hundred more scores of Zelenka - and all scans of the autograph manuscripts, miraculously escaped from the World War II bombings (they had been sheltered in the cellar of the Japanese embassy!) and now kept at the Dresden Library: bless these people for having taken the time to scan all these invaluable documents and made them available to all. Those manuscripts are not always easy to follow and some pages are in tattered condition, but I find it incredibly moving precisely for that: it's like having the composer's ghost right over your shoulder.Given what extraordinary masterpieces these are, it is incredible, and somewhat depressing, to think that they were so seldom recorded. So far as I could establish, with the help of the great Zelenka CD-discography featured on jdzelenka dot net and various other researches for LPs, this was the premiere recording of both pieces, and it remains to date, more than a quarter-century later, the only recording of the Litany, while only one more has been added to the catalog of Missa Dei Filii, in 1997, by the Dresden Chamber Choir and Baroque Orchestra under Hans-Christoph Rademann, on the obscure label Raumklang, Miserere-Missa Dei Filii.If you want to look at things positively, you'll say that it's because this version by Frieder Bernius was so perfect to start with that everybody felt they had nothing better to say. If you want to look at it less positively you'll say that, in view of the zillion recordings of Bach's Mass in B, Handel's Messiah and Vivaldi's Gloria, it shows how badly discographic posterity errs in the way it treats the great masterpieces of the past. The good thing about it is that you don't need to break the piggy bank to acquire all the extant recordings of these two masterpieces. In fact, I just bought two more copies of the Bernius recording, to offer - I can't even say that it's putting my money where my heart is, given how cheap the disc sells on the marketplace.Experience shows that an interpretation can always be bettered, but here it is hard to imagine how it could. Bernius conducts with passion and boasts some of the best early music soloists of the time (1989), Nancy Argenta, Michael Chance, Christoph Prgardien, one of the best period-instrument ensembles (the Canadian Tafelmusik Baroque) and his own vocal ensemble. That said, in the absence of comparison, you can never be sure. Well, I have purchased and listened to the other version of Missa ZWV 20: see my review of the other disc for the complete details. Suffice here to say that it confirms the excellence of Bernius' version, not because it is inferior, on the contrary, because it is also excellent, almost as good as Bernius' and in some details or individual movements even a touch better, but that it is in fact so similar in interpretive approach to Bernius that it's not really a complete necessity to add it to your collection, unless you are a diehard Zelenkite.That said and done, whether you buy this version or Rademann's or both, don't miss these extraordinary works of Zelenka. Based on these and other works of Zelenka that I've heard, he is one of the major composer of choral/religious works of the first half of the 18th century, of equal stature with Bach, Handel, Vivaldi and Telemann, and among all these, the one who remains still today badly and unfairly under-recognized. As with Bach, a life spent without Zelenka is liveable, but not as worthwhile and fulfilling as a life spent with him.

There are many different entries for the Lenovo G50 laptop and apparently many different versions, so to make things clear, i have G50-70 with 4GB RAM and 931 GB hard drive capacity, and Intel processor 1.4 GHz.This would be, I guess, as good a laptop as any other... if it wasn't for a truly infuriating glitch with the touchpad. Regularly - I mean, not just occasionally, but many times a day, repeatedly, constantly - the cursor just runs amok, it doesn't respond to the moves of the finger on the touchpad. And it's not just for a few seconds: it lasts! so of course, since you have other things to do than just sit there and wait, you are frantically trying to regain control - wrong move! While you do, the cursor just jerks around uncontrolled, and infuriating things start to happen: screen zooms in or out, you jump from your working window to any other one that was opened in the background, if you have the misfortune of sending the cursor just near one of the icons in your lower toolbar it will load some software that you want to keep closed, etc. It's infuriating. After a while - maybe a minute or two - things return to normal - but not my level of infuriated adrenalin. The mouse on the other hand works no problem, and apparently when the touchpad goes crazy, just regaining control of the cursor with the mouse will - at least temporarily - solve the problem with the touchpad; but, sorry Lenovo, I don't find practical to work with the mouse, if only because when on the sofa or on my bed there's no support at my right-hand side, and I resent that you should force me to use the mouse: I should be the one making the choices, not you. I don't know where the problem comes from, I'm supposing that it happens while the system is doing something in the background (recording?) and using so much resources that not enough are left to control the touchpad, but I've seen on various forums that I'm not the only one to complain about it, so it must be a general problem at least on this generation and model of Lenovo laptops, the G50-70, which Lenovo still hasn't solved, a year after putting this defective product on the market. Shame!Or maybe it's the spying devices implemented by Lenovo - a Chinese manufacturer, right? - in the laptops that are secretly sending all our information to the Chinese NSA...Another infuriating problem is that, while you are typing on the keyboard, and without doing anything specific, just, apparently, from the weight of your hands and palms on the computer near the touchpad, regularly the cursor will call the Windows 8 charm bar at the right of the screen - together with the big black square at the bottom left boasting hour and date and badly barring your screen, really a needless feature since you have that displayed at [right - it's just done it again! I hate it!] the right of the the bottom horizontal desk toolbar that doesn't hide your screen), and sometimes even simply jump out of your desk working window and back to the general Windows 8 welcome screen. Hateful. Since writing this review, I think I've been able to solve at least that, by disabling the *!!!!???*** Windows 8 charm bar - If needed (which probably won't happen), I can still call it, I've learned, by using the Windows key + C. I don't know if it was a Lenovo problem or a Windows 8 problem, but I suspect Lenovo: the charm bar should NOT be so sensitive that it's called even when the cursor does NOT approach the upper corners, no? And at any rate, I've that the movement of the cursor should NOT call the bottom-left clock together with the right-handside vertical charm bar.AND... another irksome feature is the battery, it's hard to slide its two curved notches into the two small pods of the housing, you really got to practice to get the sleight of hand to do it smoothly, and before you have... it's infuriating.And: I find the right-hand side shift key badly located: I'm a very good and fast typer, that's a key you strike with your right-pinky and that you constantly use for capital letters, and two times out of three I miss it, or I don't strike it dead center so it doesn't process, and then I've got to go back and re-type my capital letters. I don't know what the problem is, the key seems slightly too far right, I've never experienced that with any other laptop, so it must be Lenovo's keyboard and not me. And I've been using the computer for a number of weeks now, and it's not getting better, so whatever the problem, my right-hand pinky is NOT getting used to it. Very irksome.AND... I hate Windows 8. I was perfectly okay with Windows 7. Hey Bill, you're doing good things with your money (which, don't forget is OUR money), but WHY do you have to constantly change what WORKS and that we've finally got accustomed to? I resent it. And now you're telling me I've got to move on to Windows 10???? How do I know it's not going to be even WORSE than 8???? Because, you know, that has been the general direction you guys seem to be taking...I don't know if you're like me, but computers seem to have this unique ability, shared with your wife, to turn you berzerk with ire. At least you can scream back at your wife and hope there's an effect, not so with the computer.No more Lenovo for me, buying this was a bad choice. As long as I'm going to be spied by the NSA, I prefer that it is the US NSA.

Great book!  It brings great perspective to the area, the war, the people and their lives.  I haven't had a chance to get to Afghanistan, but I've managed to get some ideas about how these wars start and how education gets neglected - and even outlawed - from living in Jordan and paying attention to Syria.  But even with some small experience, it's difficult to make tangible without books like this.  The writing is excellent, the views rational, and the subject matter both depressing and inspiring at the same time.  It's the kind of book I wish everyone - especially Americans - would read, just so they can try to "get" that some of the rest of the world is so "far away".  Check it out...

I like this book a lot, especially because it can bring some history to life for me and help me understand some of the moods and ideas of the time.  On paper I know what happened during this era, but it's hard to put it together and really get how it all came together and over what types of time periods, etc.  Although there's plenty of depressing stuff about the book, none of it gets you down.  The tone is easy going, and it's easy to read through, even relatively quickly.The author's style is relatively unmentionable, with the occasional strange phrasing used that sort of reminds me of old movies; maybe "nostalgic" is the right word.  Anyway, it's a great book.  It'd be really great to read before a trip down to Peru...

This is a really nice tool.  I have an indexable nail puller that I really like and that has come in handy numerous times, so I figured this would inevitably come in handy at some point as well, being more suited to prying tasks.  Sure enough, it came in great handy to pull up the boards beneath some old steps recently, the tool helping me to not bang and cut my hands.It seems very strong.  Undoubtedly, the weak point must be around the indexable portion of the head, so when I'm doing seriously heavy work, I will use a normal bar when possible, but I don't see this breaking easily in any case.  This is just a caution I'll take due to the nature of the tool.  It's certainly not as weak or disappointing as when you get a straight bar that bends under stress.  Seems like a high quality product.

These classic dishtowels seem to be of good quality, having no loose stitching and coming as near-perfect squares.  While nothing over-the-top amazing, they are as thick as one can expect and will last as long as any other standard rags.

10-pack of lights, each in their own tiny box, to replace those in my kitchen vent hood.  I've yet to find LEDs that I believe will fit in that space, and I got tired of looking and finally settled on these, which fit the bill just fine.

Cheapest I could find, came in a reasonably short time, works as expected, and even has a semi-rigid protective sheath I haven't seen before on an optical *audio cable (it helps you avoid overstepping the optimal bend radius).

I also have an Alienware 17 with GTX 880M GPU.  Comparisons are somewhat unfair considering the nearly $1000 price difference, but I believe they may be helpful to a prospective buyer:You can look at specs and framerate comparisons of the GPUs all over the web, but my experience is that both deliver seamless perfection in the newest games.  If I'm dropping some frames with either, I don't notice, but I often like to play on my TV, and I know I lose something there.  I am also not obsessed with gaming like some, so I'll concentrate on some of the other factors.The displays themselves are both fantastic, and I cannot distinguish a huge difference there.The GTX970M included with this machine does make a noticeable difference in terms of power consumption, as this machine is much thinner and lighter than the AW.  At the same time, it feels slightly less robust because the entire chassis is not metal.I don't like the CD drive placement on this machine, as I keep popping the slot open from time to time.USB 3.0 is on only one side of the machine (2.0 port and card reader on the other side).  AW has two ports on each side.What I really like about the AW is that it has a second full size HDD slot for added versatility.  It's the only laptop I've ever seen with that.There are no obvious annoyances with the touchpad or keyboard as far as accidental hitting a key or something not working correctly, which I've seen with other laptops.  I am not thrilled with the placement of the delete key on this laptop, and I don't really like the fact that the arrow keys are scrunched up with the numbers and other keys, either.  By contrast, I believe AW got their layout perfect, including their four programmable keys.Lights.  The keyboard by itself may actually look cooler on the Apache because the lights are in the height of the keys.  BUT, there are only three zones, compared to AW's four, plus multiple chassis zones.  I really love the light-up touchpad on the AW.  What really annoys me about the lights on this keyboard is that despite the controller software that allows lots of per-key and per-game customization, there is no setting that allows the keyboard to turn off at the same time that the screen goes blank (or any time for that matter; you have to wait until the computer goes to sleep).  I have it rigged to change from one profile to a dark profile when I press the special command button, but that's not seamless.Windows 10.  Actually, I love that I got the AW at the time when they were still loading Win7 (Win 8.1 was out, but nobody wanted it).  I'm still not thrilled with Win10 due to their moving some settings out of control panel and into settings, getting rid of other settings altogether, still having a ridiculous start menu, and wanting to control your life as if you're some dumb tablet/phone user.  I installed Classic Shell to get my start menu back, messed with the control panel and settings for a long time, turned off everything they were "offering" me, and I have this working just about as good as a Win7 machine.  Oh yeah, and I ditched MS Edge; God, what was wrong with Explorer?  Anyway, if we're stuck with it, may as well make the best of it.Very little crapware on this machine.  On most computers, I disable even the proprietary controls since most of them do nothing.  This machine has a System Control Manager that doesn't do anything that Windows Power settings cannot do, but it confuses things and messes up my settings, so it will be turned off.  The other stuff seems harmless so far.I was telling someone that computers like this are a status symbol to some people (like cars are to some people).  And it came with a key fob, like a car...  Oh yeah, this and the AW both come in fancy packaging, including a suitcase-style box that you'll be tempted to keep, but practicality keeps me from doing so.  However, you may want it if you frequently transport your machine.  Also comes with the largest - but not softest - microfiber cloth I've ever seen (the size of the screen).In conclusion, you can see that there are a few minor things I prefer about the AW.  Are they worth an extra thousand bucks?  No.  This is an impressive machine that can handle anything I throw at it.  It should definitely be on your consideration list.

This is a pretty good book serving its purpose.  There does seem to be a bit of filler, however.I like the tech tip sidebars a lot, but it's unfortunate that they end up repeating many of them.  An exclusive for each page would be appreciated.  The first couple chapters are sort of the same thing any such study guide would say, but the tests themselves have questions that I believe to be very similar to what may be on a test (for example, I have a math minor, but find some of the math questions tricky simply because they are different or include industry knowledge).  The answer keys definitely take up a lot more pages than they need to.I am an EE who has studied enough of this stuff to put in a home HVAC system (very well).  I was hoping to gain some more knowledge from this book.  While I can gather some new information from this book, they often leave big holes wide open if you don't already know something.  This is not particularly bad for the book, as most readers are already well versed in the industry, but it would be very frustrating if you did need a good brush-up and you were lacking other resources.If you are particularly concerned about one of these certification tests and test taking is not your strongest suit, then this should be a worthwhile guide for you.

While these definitely take some getting used to and you'd probably never pick them for comfort over a pair of snorkel-type goggles, they do fit well and seem to have the correct holding mechanism and strap for their lightweight, low-drag intended purpose.  They actually look pretty good and provide sun protection.  If you've never worn these type before, you can feel them around your eyeballs, but for short sprints in the pool, they will suffice, and you'll likely get more used to them over time.  Field of vision is barely affected.

Mine still seems white after a few weeks of use.The sticker that came with it is actually thick (I guess before only the front flaked off of my sticker) and curved.  It didn't want to stay put at the top, so I used a bit of construction adhesive and held it down overnight with a  plastic-coated, spring-loaded clamp, and now I have confidence that it will last for a while.  It was inexpensive enough to feel like a win.

Even if you haven't played this game before, you probably know what it's all about from looking at the picture.  It's a bit like Scrabble, but you modify words by building over top of them.  It has plastic pieces and a retro - nay, original - look.  If you can manage to get the kids to get away from their phones for a few minutes for some old-sko0l family time, you may all derive some enjoyment out of this.

At the time of this review, there is not a regular Amazon page on this product, but it appears to conform to VESA sizing D, with both 75mm and 100mm square hole patterns.  Manual says it is rated up to 25 lbs.When mounted properly, this thing is extremely sturdy, professional looking, and versatile.  You will be able to adjust your monitor or TV in any way you can imagine, including fixed or dynamic switching from landscape to portrait.  To mount properly, you do need a stud if mounting to an interior wall.  They also supply anchors for masonry mounting.The top cover for the wall plate says Amazon Basics, which actually makes it look less generic, although I am sure some people don't want any extra color or logos on their walls.  You can leave this off, but then the hardware will show (in black).  The upper arm also has a discreet logo.  It has a medium flat black finish that looks high end (as usual, I think Amazon's stuff looks better than "basic" does justice).Both arms are approximately 10" from pivot point to pivot point, so you can get at least a 20" reach in any direction, or sit the monitor pretty much flat against the wall without any hardware showing.The lower arm has a roomy chamber for cables that can probably hold 8 RG-6 sized cables, or at least four larger cables.  Unfortunately, the upper arm has no room for cables, so you can only do as good as using the included black tie wraps to keep them in place.  If all your cables are black, it won't be much of an eyesore.

These are much nicer than towels in the way that they are much lighter weight.  They wrap up nicely and are a pleasure to have on the head in that regard.  I haven't really noticed them to be more absorbent than regular towels, but they absorb enough for their purpose.  Definitely worth having around.

I wasn't sure if these were going to be some kind of posturing candy bars, just trying to look fancy and hope it works, but I was surprised to taste just how good they are, even great!  The chocolate isn't fully formed around most of the pieces; instead you have real nuts and raisins showing through, all of which are clearly high quality.  Perhaps the almonds and hazelnuts are toasted?  Because they really shine through.  The chocolate itself is one of the European styles, reminding me of advent calendars from when I was a kid.

There are no big name certifications or brand reputations to ensure this product is completely as advertised, but it is made in the US, and without too many inactive ingredients:  just modified cellulose, vegetable stearate, silicon dioxide, and glycerine  These seem to be pretty regular in supplements.

This appears to be completely on the up & up, with a slew of certifications, organic ingredients, and very few ingredients beyond what is touted as the healing herbs.  A couple of these, like turmeric and green tea, already a part of my diet and I believe them to be effective.  You often need more turmeric than you'd get otherwise, even if you eat a lot of Indian food.  I expect the same might be true for some of the herbs on there we think of as Italian (Rosemary, Basil, and Oregano).  The other Chinese-sounding ingredients are new on my radar.

I have two other Contigo bottles that really impressed me.  Like, impressed me more than I ever expected a reusable bottle could.  And this one is the best yet, at least in terms of styling and confidence that it won't leak.The bottle actually has internal threads for a sleek look, but the entire mechanism increases my confidence in its ability to never leak.  It has a removable piece meant to allow for the addition of ice and to easily clean the bottle:  this is not as effective as another Contigo bottle that splits right in the middle at the thickest part, but again, this seems to be an even better seal (not that I ever had problems with the other one).The other thing less perfect is that it should not be used in the dishwasher (also not in the microwave, and it should not be frozen).  BUT...it is a seriously nice looking product, so the tradeoff is worth it in my opinion.  Mostly, I'll only be using this for water, so it'll mostly just need a rinsing now and then anyway.  They tell you to leave the cap off when storing, to allow for drying.

The packaging says that you're getting 77% more sheets because they've crammed in 85 sheets to a roll.  Yes, they tell you the size, but they expect you don't know that they're 25% smaller than sheets you're expecting if you're used to at home paper towels.  That kind of gimmick really annoys me, but I'm so used to it I never pay such statements any heed.  They seem like small rolls, and the absorbency is average for non-premium brand towels but, frankly, if you're buying them for the break room, they're good enough.  And the size will hopefully mean less waste.  Even if you were using them at home, the size could be a happy median between regular and half-sized sheets.  The tear down storage box may also come in handy.  I really don't know what regular paper towels go for, but if these are a good price per total length, then I'd say they're good for business.

These come in a box that seems like it wants to be - and maybe could pass as - a holiday gift box.  Not very fancy, but if you get yours without dents and bruises, it could pass as such.  Distractingly, inside, they are all individually plastic wrapped, and all the bags are banded together via rubber.  The utensils themselves have a bit of a wanna-be air about them:  the quality is just fine and they look decent, but just a touch gaudy, specifically on the handles.  On the positive side, they are longer and more substantial than a lot of similar utensils.Overall, while I like them, I don't love them, and I think it's because they're trying a bit too hard without the substance to back it up.

Wow, there is some ugly stuff in here!  Every page is offensive to the senses!  And yet the book is interesting due to its "coffee-table" format with lots of pictures, and the fact that they do manage to find the more extreme examples of "mid-century modern", rather than just the crap people are hoping to get rid of at a premium at the local "antique" store.  It's sure to entrance you and your guests whether you like the style or are appalled by it.  Well set up book and dense, not lacking content.

I really like that this can be used in the shower; that makes it not only convenient, but it hurts less when using with soap and water.  It's also a pretty nice looking unit with a rechargeable battery and pouch.  It's like a luxury shaver for women.  I can't give it five stars because it still hurts, but the end result is nice.
Seems like a good product with not a lot of excess ingredients.  Capsules are small and jar is easy to open.

I like these, but I've learned to really like the nitrile gloves better.  These are tons better than vinyl, however, which are often considered "food grade".  They're consistently sized and fit well on my large hands.
Good product, straight up astaxanthin, with no needless scary ingredients added.  Seems like a medium dose at 12mg.

These are great gloves to have around for working with chemicals for cleaning car parts, using paint thinners, etc.  They are easy to don and remove, but don't slip off like food gloves (which I think are usually vinyl).

Seems like a pretty good product with no objectional chemicals or unnecessary additives.  Can always use some help coping with stress this time of year.  It's hard to say for certain if they're working, but even trying to do something about it is helpful.

Great gloves.  I like that they are not latex.  They stretch and fit fairly tight and comfortably over my large hands.  I feel like they are protecting me from chemicals when I work on projects around my house or with my car.

A giant pack of the most ubiquitous beef jerky I have ever known, seen in every convenience store in the States.  Good stuff that pleases almost anybody, but it's nothing amazing or special.  The giant pack should hopefully leave enough to share!

I'll admit it works just fine and appears to be of good quality.  I appreciate that they use Bluetooth instead of trying to go over a third party wireless network.  I like the flexible lead.  But why did I just lock myself into needing a phone when all I wanted was to see if I had a fever?The temp tracking abilities of the smartphone part of this make a lot of sense if you're tracking your menstrual cycle, and maybe some other health situations, but for the most part, it seems gimmicky.  But that doesn't change that now I NEED to find my phone, unlock it, turn on the bluetooth, wait for it to connect, run the app (or download it again if I have a new phone), and then do all the other stuff associated with taking my temperature every time I want to see if my temperature has improved or worsened.  With a conventional device, I just stick it in my mouth and wait until it beeps.LED LCD mini-screens are cheap.  They should have just added one so I can use the phone or not.  Further, it does not support Blackberry, Windows, or any other devices besides Apple and Android, which I find extremely short-sighted.I understand that some people just love to show how they can use their phones for anything and everything, but you're not using your phone INSTEAD of something else, but rather in addition.  Even the biggest phone nuts will sooner or later regret not having a conventional thermometer around.

This is a pretty interesting book that gets you thinking about a lot of social issues and how they relate to and are effected by the Earth and the Universe.  It's a well written book that seems almost conversational at times because the author talks about some first-person experiences.  It can be a little wordy, but nothing obnoxious.  Overall, a good mind expander to take on another view of the world.

Seems like a pretty legitimate supplement, with its very few added ingredients and verified non-GMO status.  A chance to get a "super food" you may not often eat otherwise.  It instructs you not to eat more than one daily; I wonder if to much Elder berry and currants can be harmful?  Standard medium-sized capsules.

I was sort of intrigued by the fermented mushroom aspect of this, figuring it couldn't hurt (and I guess it can't).  It is a powder (it says to use a "scoop", but I was still picturing mushroom pieces) that you mix with water.I'd rather eat some good mushrooms any day.  And while I already knew that before I tried it, I am now sort of disgusted at the use of stevia and cherry extract to make this a disgustingly "fake" sweet drink.  Honestly, I can chug a few ounces of basically unflavored water to force down some powder, but I hate stevia, anything that tastes fake and artificial.  Even if the pure powder would have tasted like funky fermented mushrooms, what's wrong with that?If you are someone that doesn't care about real food, has gotten yourself used to nasty diet sodas and energy drinks, stuff like that, then this won't phase you (and since I believe that most of Americans won't mind, I'm giving this what I consider a generous 3 stars).  But for something trying to be healthy, I can't get past the unnatural taste (and that's my thought no matter where I stand on the safety of stevia controversy).

I like this thing a lot, but it could be better in a few ways.The current picture makes it look like a standard box cutter, but it is actually more like a pen knife, like it says.  I enjoy that aspect of it.It's thin at the top and wider at the bottom, which makes it larger than it has to be.  In fact, it wouldn't have to be as long as it is, either.  Seems like a pen knife should be as close in size to a pen as it can be because people are probably carrying it around in their pocket.  The tapered size does actually feel good to hold, but not as much in my jeans pocket.It makes sense to pick this over a standard box cutter depending how you carry it, but I'd venture to say that if you keep it in a large pocket, like a jeans pocket, you may be better off (just slightly safer) with a folding box cutter.  This would be the kind of thing I'd keep ...well obviously, where a pen would better fit.While I have no problem with razor blades under most circumstances, I imagine steel blades small enough to fit in here would break easily.  So in this case the ceramic cutter makes sense.  I'm not sure it is as effective for heavy duty use like for some of my DIY construction jobs simply because I don't want to pay for as many blades as I will break in that way, but I do think it will last longer for stuff like cutting boxes.  Mine, by default is probably going to stay by my mail area, as I am an Amazon junkie with plenty of packages to open.The slide button does not protrude much, but just enough to keep it from rolling off whatever surface you put it on.  Even with the large body, there is no place to store an extra blade.  Three position sliding switch = (off, halfway extended, fully extended).

This is about as small as you can get a 6-port power strip with switch.  It is for this reason that you don't get a huge surge protector, but in most instances, it is worth it for the size trade-off.  It probably wouldn't stop a lightning strike, but will take care of little surges that the power company may let through.  Recommend using a whole-house protector in your power panel and use this for the multiple outlets and added protection.The sliding covers are a nice extra; I really like how they are integrated as to not end up a nuisance.  I like having a switch in most instances so I can turn an entire section off (completely off) all at once.

This 8.5 watt bulb appears to be brighter than any of the 65 watt incandescent and (equivalent) CFL bulbs I have in my basement.  Since I have all recessed lighting in my basement, and I need quite a few bulbs for it to light up brightly, it is especially nice to use lower energy down there.  This is a very cool-running bulb and it looks good and appears to be great quality.  I also particularly like LED for recessed fixtures because you're not getting even close to the heat rating on the insulation-rated fixtures, so you can go brighter with peace of mind.
These are cute earrings that look better in real life than they do on the pictures.  They come with backs (not pictured).  Simple design, but looks good.

Great gloves.  It's nice to have a product similar to latex, but without the smell or that bad feel.  Great for nasty chores that stain or would otherwise be harmful to your skin.  The texture is great in some applications, never seems to be a hindrance.

Fantastic candies!  You get the higher end of Hershey's always great ingredients in a piece large enough for two bites or small enough to fit in your mouth whole.  It's great to have the diversity to pick from regular or dark chocolate, and the caramel is the perfect slightly chewy type.  I love them.The tin is fairly nondescript, but it looks clean and is certainly reusable.  Inside smells of wonderful chocolate, despite the candies being individually wrapped.

I like these, but just about the same as regular bleach. Since they don't always dissolve immediately, I think the best use is to put some in a rarely used toilet or urinal when away so that the water/mold rings do not appear as quickly. Seems to work great.
Great vessel for my cornbread!  I find it tastes even better in cup form than it does in cake form.  They cook without a pan and the color designs are festive if you're baking for a party.

These seem totally different than anything I expected out of a dishcloth. You can make them different levels of abrasive depending on how dry you keep them.They can be washed or dish-washed and reused. And if they last really long as I expect - and another reviewer mentioned - that will add up to a pretty unique dishcloth.

God, this is a strange book.  Pretty much just fodder for your coffee table, but I will admit, it is a lot of fun.  The portraits are very meticulous and detailed, and often offer a real human expression to match the text.  Definitely something nice to rotate around the sitting room for your guests.

Now these are what I need for some serious home improvement projects.  I don't mind at all working with chemicals, mixing compounds, etc., when I have tight fitting gloves that don't feel gross like this.  They seem to offer a good layer of protection and liquids don't soak through easily.

I had always been skeptical about this recent trend in gluten sensitivity, but some recent research talking about what has changed and why this has occurred has me interested to know if it is causing some of my symptoms. This supplement seems like the right place to start.
Works great.  The trimming head reminds me a lot of a Panasonic battery powered deal I own.  I guess it is a cross between that and a push-powered grass mower.  Neat finely crafted device.

These are great gloves.  When you find some that are too small for you, it's the closest thing you can get to true finger feel through gloves.  They're the form fitting doctor's type gloves instead of those really shabby food service gloves.  For someone like me that rarely uses gloves even when I know I should, these are great for mixing chemicals and other toxic items.Some gloves are actually unavailable in small, so the range of sizes available here may be great for smaller people.I've heard that fingerprints can eventually transverse latex gloves.  I am unsure if that is true for nitrile, but these are pretty thin.
This is good coffee.  It strikes me as very standard for what I expect out of a single-serve machine.  It's strong, but not too bitter, definitely a solid brew, particularly when using K-cups.

Awesome book.  Since this was mis-categorized, I didn't know what it was, but it reminded me of Japanese-style horror for a while, before becoming what could just be drama and intrigue.  Now I'm not sure how to categorize it, but I know it was great.  It was fairly short, but it had looking forward to reading hour each night instead of an extra TV show.The advanced copy I read was really raw, not even having page numbers and containing more grammatical errors then I've ever seen in a book, advanced copy or not.  But it was easy to overlook and the translated writing was still very good.Definitely one of my favorite fiction books I read in the last few years.  I have a feeling it will stick with me for some time.

This is an excellent shaver, with all the bells and whistles (some of which I didn't even know existed).  It is extremely nice to be able to shave with the shaver wet, and even better to be able to use it in the shower.  This makes it much more comfortable and easier to clean up than my older, more basic model shaver I replaced with this.They tell you to clean every day, but you really only need to rinse it off.  You can pull off the head and run water over the inside instead of using a little brush like with some other shavers.I like that it has a docking station, but I'm not necessarily thrilled with it because it's so big and because it's a little awkward to make the power connection, as opposed to just setting it on something with properly placed contacts.The travel case is nice to have, as well as the included beard trimmer.  Seems like the most luxurious grooming kit for men available.

I'm replacing my Sony STR-DE998 7.1 120w/ch. receiver with this (approximately 10 year newer) model from what I believe to be the same price class.  Were this my first receiver or if I were upgrading from a cheap unit, I would probably give this five stars.  But when you get a newer and/or better model of something from the same brand, you expect to get everything and more.  I found myself giving up a few things, which in some cases requires a work-around.  I'll list some of them here to give you an idea:NOTE:  I have a lot of good things to say after all these minor negatives, so don't get too pessimistic.  I love Sony products, but that just makes the minor negatives stand out to me more...1 - The biggest thing is that the extra two channels you may not use if you only have 5.1 around your TV (in my case, due to a smaller space and not wanting to be ridiculous with how many speakers I have one of the main rooms in my house) cannot be dual-zoned.  Yes, you can do the A/B/A+B front speaker thing, but now you cannot have a separate source playing out in the kitchen (zone 2), whereas I could with my previous unit.  And then, if I ONLY want to play what used to be the second zone (my kitchen), I have to switch it to a mode that doesn't use the rear speakers, lest I annoy someone in the primary zone not using this device.Worth noting is that the previous unit had a really clunky interface for zone 2, and I'll probably be able to streamline this new switching a little bit thanks to the three custom preset buttons on the remote (of course, I'll probably have to use all three, leaving none for other applications).2 - Fewer audio-based inputs.  Yes, you can change some inputs in the main menu to show up in your "watch" or "listen" categories, but if I want to LISTEN only to something on the "video" input (which is one of only three RCA inputs), then it's a crapshoot to get to it with only the remote (i.e., it was expected you'd have your TV/monitor on to get to this input.  This is because there are buttons on the remote to take you directly to some sources, but not others, and no single button to switch through them all (However, with my Sony TV remote, I can actually switch through them all).3 - Speaking of remotes, I love the remotes of all my other Sony equipment.  Why is this one so "un-commanding"?  Not only is it smaller, less attractive, and with less buttons than what I would expect, it doesn't even attempt to be the one-size-fits-all solution to your  AV needs.If you do have all your inputs going through this (which I don't, actually:  I still like to be able to watch TV or anything else without having to turn this on, so I route through my TV) and you do have a TV that can control your cable box fluidly (good luck with that), and you do have a Sony TV remote that can switch over to control your amplifier pretty easily, than you may be able to get away with one remote.  But that's a lot of "ifs".  This remote doesn't even have channel +/- on it, so it won't be helpful at all.  Luckily, I can mostly control this amp with my Sony TV remote.That's the other thing - unless you have all those other minor compatibility issues - some mentioned above - resolved, you're still not getting a seamless solution that makes you want to keep this on every time you're watching or listening to anything (I cannot stand how some channels up the volume of commercials, and I find them all to sound particularly obnoxious coming from all speakers).  I don't have cable, for example, so I always need to switch TV inputs to get back to watching TV.4 - It has network capability, including DLNA, but it does not run apps like Pandora locally.  It doesn't do any video over the network.  My first-gen Smart Sony TV doesn't play *.mkv files natively, so this would have been the perfect gap filler.  It's an AVR, so why not fully do the video?5 - No more switched power outlets.  No AM.  No 75-ohm coax for FM.  Seems like less inputs in general (I have three analog audio sources, so now there is no place to hook up my old 400-disc DVD carousel via digital coax since the digital coax can only be assigned to those otherwise analog inputs).6 - Neither unit has a wired IR input port, which matters only if you want to hide all your components or keep them in another room.  I don't really need it, but you'd think it would be included.OK, lets talk great things now:1 - Fantastic sound.  More power than you'll probably ever use if you value your hearing.  Even if I had a full-out home theater room, this would be good enough, with all its adjustable speaker configurations.2 - I love its wired network interface (it only has a 100mb connection because it knows it won't pull video over the network anyway).  Yes, it can also be used wirelessly.Here is where I note that I hate wireless except where absolutely necessary.  Beyond my opinion (moving toward fact) is that I have noticed the Bluetooth on this does not have the same distance as some other connections because I have it in a credenza.  I expect similar issues with wireless, especially since you put this with a bunch of other electronics and they all create EMI as well as clashing radio frequencies...I have no problem pulling audio from a Win7 machine, even without having purposely set up a media server on it.3 - With this, though, I do very much appreciate the Bluetooth, both Tx and Rx.  I have wanted that for a long time.4 - One of the best things is being able to set all the options on the TV menu.  That was so horrible trying to navigate the menus on the device before.  You can still do them that way with just the device and the remote, but in most cases you won't want to.  Most of the settings are set and forget.  They're also a lot easier to set up, especially since the unit will do it for you with the included mic (that it knows where my speakers are is pretty impressive).5 - The unit itself looks great with its classic 17" width and sleek design.  The LCD is only dot matrix; could be fancier, but it's okay.In conclusion, I do actually love the unit.  I take most receiver/amp features for granted, so I didn't list every little thing as a positive.  I was slightly disappointed in a few instances, but the unit still has all the important basics of functionality for audio/surround sound.  My incessant yearning for more is perhaps my own problem.If you've looked at the inputs and features on this machine and it does what you need it to, then I would definitely recommend it.  You will not be disappointed in the sound or quality.

My freezer came with the cheapest 40w A15 bulb the manufacturer could find, which subsequently burnt out in a few years of minimal use.  This seems to be just about the same brightness as that 40w bulb, and I'm assuming it will long outlast my freezer.  Hopefully it will get cheaper yet, but I don't intend to buy any more incandescent bulbs for normal applications if I can help it.Also worth noting is that incandescent bulbs in a refrigerated space are counterintuitive because of the waste heat they put off.

In this 126 page book, mostly lifted From France country guide and France Discover, 18 pages in the back are exactly the same as that of "Provence and Southeast France Road Trips" (Ok, so one line is off, pushing back the formatting a bit to hopefully fool you).  Also a few pages in front are the same stuff you get in every LP.  After an extended version of their typical itineraries section, which looks a bit like their Discover series because of the extra pictures, it just moves on to "Destinations", which is a condensed version of their regular country guide (when they were in color for a short time).Also, these few hundred km max drives don't really strike me as a road trip.  "Road Trip" has me thinking exciting 6000km loops around the top half of Argentina or most of Turkey, not a spec of France.
