If you have a friend or loved one who loves the Original Series, then GET THESE SOCKS!

I'm the host of a top-ranked iTunes health podcast called "The Livin' La Vida Low-Carb Show" and a frequent public speaker for a living. I have long been looking for a portable device that would provide podcast-quality recordings without a lot of complicated software or smartphone app gadgetry. I've finally found it at last--the Esky VR-01 USB Flash Drive Digital Audio Voice Recorder!When I first got this thing, it just looked like any other USB Flash Drive. And it certainly can function as a USB stick if you want it to. But the real magic happens when you simply slide the button to the "on" position and start talking. I couldn't believe how incredibly crystal clear the audio was and you don't even need to put it close to your mouth (in fact, if you put it too close the sound becomes distorted).All I needed to do to create a recording is sit at a table, place this device in the middle between me and my guest and slide it to the "on" position, and have a great conversation. This lightweight device picks it all up for as long as the interview lasts (up to 15 hours--but none ever last that long!). There's plenty of room to record whatever you need.When I'm finished recording, it's as easy as sliding the button to the "off" position, plugging it in to the USB port on my Macbook Pro, and opening the file up in my recording editor Audacity to make any appropriate edits to export as a WAV file. Then it's ready to upload to my producer's DropBox and it's ready to roll. At just $25, this could quite possibly be the best investment for any podcaster, student, or anyone who wants a handy dandy quality audio recorder that fits any budget.

If you hate to dust, then these Clorox Triple Action Dust Wipes are made just for you. NOTE: I was sent this product for free by the manufacturer in exchange for my honest opinions about this product. I've been on the lookout for a quality Bluetooth speaker to use with my Apple iPhone and iPad for listening to music, podcasts, and any other audio from my devices. For all the functionality these offer, the one thing that has always been severely lacking is quality sound. That's why I was happy to find the iClever speaker to amplify that sound in a very natural way. And boy does it ever do that!Within 10 seconds of taking it out of the box from Amazon, I had synced it with my iPhone and started playing Pharrell Williams' song "Happy." I placed the speaker in the center of my 1000 square foot house and could hear it loud and clear from wherever I stood. Unlike some other speakers, it really gave you a surround experience with the audio and not a muffled sound from being turned in the other direction.And because it is small enough, this speaker is discreet and not an eyesore wherever you choose to put it. But don't let the small size make you think it's not powerful--you get a nice booming sound that is appropriately balanced between treble and bass for an authentic audio experience. The fact this thing costs less than $30 makes it a no-brainer because it's easily worth at least double that! If you've been looking for a Bluetooth speaker to bring your audio to life on your devices, then look no further than the iClever portable speaker!

If you have penchant for compelling storytelling, then this it the book for you! Christopher McDougall is a skilled journalist with an eye for getting to the heart of a story to discover the meaning and purpose of events as they are unfolding. It's one thing to simply report on what happened in a very dry, stoic manner that shares the bare minimum facts of what happened. But McDougall has that special knack for taking the ordinary and looking for the extraordinary that happened in the who, what, where, why, when and how. That formula is all over NATURAL BORN HEROES.Reading through all these amazing stories, one thing is certain--all of us have what it takes to go from misfits to masters at whatever we choose to do in life. While this book specifically examines strength and endurance since the author is already very well known for this from his bestselling book BORN TO RUN, it really has application to anyone desiring to be and do whatever it is they set their minds to being and doing. I think deep down inside most of us know we are capable of so much more than what we are currently doing. We just need that gentle nudge to push us in the right direction and give us encouragement that we will succeed. This book is just the nudge you've been looking for.Since I am primarily a nutritional health blogger and podcaster, I was especially enamored by Chapters 32-36 where McDougall brought out some incredible information that is spot on about diet, exercise performance, and healthy living. Sugar and other carbohydrates aren't the great fuel for running that they have been made out to be. Shifting over to utilizing fat for fuel instead of sugar is a much more efficient way to keep your body healthy while performing at optimal levels. Even world-renowned running experts like Tim Noakes from South Africa had to change his views on carbohydrates in preparation for running a race. WOW!Noakes also noted the error in telling runners to load up on water beyond the signal for thirst and says that doesn't make any sense from the standpoint of how our ancestors survived. The brain and body doesn't lie and you should rely on the signals they are giving you about when to drink and how much. There are so many riveting nuggets of information like these within the pages of NATURAL BORN HEROES that you'll feel like you're in a movie.My favorite quote in the entire book is this: "It's an inconvenient truth, but a truth nevertheless: animal fat made us who we are." And in our modern-day, fat-phobic society, that sounds incredibly strange and foolish to the uneducated. But the story we've always believed was unassailable was all predicated on a series of lies and misinformation that people like Gary Taubes, Phil Maffetone, Tim Noakes, and others are now exposing for all the world to see. And add Christopher McDougall's name to that list now as well who lays it all out clearly in NATURAL BORN HEROES. Kudos!

It's eye cream and difficult to give much of a review until you've been able to use it a while. It rubs on fine and smells good. Give me some time to keep using it. Don't notice anything different after two weeks. Maybe slightly tighter skin.

Couldn't be more perfect for my wife as a great carry-on for her devices and such. We've been frustrated trying to find a bag for her laptop and iPad. But nothing has been quite as roomy as this one. And lots of extra room for other stuff. Great job!

One of the most misunderstood chronic health problems of our day has got to be autoimmune disease. And because it manifests itself in a variety of ways, conventional medicine chooses to examine each condition on the autoimmunity spectrum individually, including Graves' disease, Psoriasis, Fibromyalgia, Lupus, Celiac disease, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Rheumatoid arthritis, Chronic fatigue syndrome, Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis, Multiple Sclerosis, Scleroderma, and Type 1 Diabetes. But Dr. Amy Myers is a medical doctor who actually understands all the intricacies of autoimmune disease because she sees the worst of the worst day in and day out in her functional medicine clinic in Austin, Texas.Now Dr. Myers has taken all those years of experience working with real patients and put it into book form for automimmune sufferers to glean from her wisdom and help them get on the road to recovery after years of frustration working with the ineptitude of mainstream medicine. THE AUTOIMMUNE SOLUTION isn't about some quick fix, but rather identifying the methodical steps (referred to as The Myers Way) it takes to heal your body from what ails you. She has successfully used this approach with thousands of patients and seeks to share what she has learned in an easy-to-understand program that anyone suffering from this can begin implementing immediately.The Myers Way consists of four primary components:1. Eliminating toxic and inflammatory foods.2. Adding in foods and supplements to repair the damage to the gut and body.3. Identifying and eliminating culprit environmental toxins from your household products.4. Removing any infections and dispelling stress that would exacerbate the immune system.For people familiar with the Paleo diet, The Myers Way uses this way of eating as the nutritional basis to help optimize overall health. THE AUTOIMMUNE SOLUTION provides so many other elements in this process that can make a real difference in your pursuit of beating your autoimmune condition. Dr. Myers herself overcame an autoimmune condition and has seen her method work well for all kinds of people. Stop being frustrated and start getting better by reading this book!

I really didn't know what to expect from this AYL StarLight 330 camping light, but it looked cool enough. When I got it and I saw how small it was, I didn't think it would do a very good job of providing enough light to see in the pitch black that happens outside at night away from the city. But I was wrong. The brightness was surprising widespread, but not so overwhelming on the eyes that it was difficult to see. There's a fine line between visible and blinding light and this product strikes the perfect balance. I gave it a 4-star review because of one issue I had with the setup of this thing--the batteries. I spent over a half hour trying to get them in the perfect order, flipping them back and forth, desperately trying to get them to go where they needed to go. Now, perhaps they shared this info somewhere, but I couldn't find it. Thankfully I finally figured it out but it was a bit frustrating at first. It's a nice light if you decide to get it.

These Bear Naked Real Nut Chocolate Chip Peanut Butter Energy Bars sound like they could be a healthy option for people wanting a snack. The way they are marketed as 100% natural (which means absolutely NOTHING by the way) with no high-fructose corn syrup, no artificial preservatives or flavors, no hydrogenated oils (trans fats), no cholesterol (meaningless!), and "no monkey business" (okay, whatever), you'd think these would be good for you. But you'd be wrong.There are so many pro-inflammatory, blood sugar/insulin raising ingredients in this bar, including whole grains, peanut butter (a legume, not a nut), sugar, three different kinds of inferior soy, brown rice syrup (more sugar!), and crisp rice (more grains and sugar). That adds up to a whopping 31 grams of carbohydrates (aka 8 teaspoons of sugar!) in just one bar. WHOA!Come on guys, the consumer deserves better than THIS in a health bar. Ditch the grain, sugar and soy and find better truly quality ingredients if you care about making an authentic health bar. Nobody needs to be eating this crappy carbage.

Disclaimer: I was provided this unit in free in exchange for an honest review.The question you're probably asking yourself right now is: how does this compare to Apple's official charger, which costs $30 more?Well, after two weeks of thorough usage, I've only noticed two differences:1) The cables aren't quite as thick / rubbery. They're close, but they don't "bounce back" quite as much as the more rubbery official cables. That being said, this isn't necessarily a bad thing - I've always thought Apple's cables to be a bit too thick, to the point of being frustrating / impractical. But, this is mainly a matter of personal preference - not necessarily something to hold against ClawTech.2) The red "charging" light is dimmer / more difficult to see. The green "fully charged" light works as expected, but a couple of times I've had to do a double take because it looked like it wasn't charging / I couldn't see the "charging" light.Since both of the above points are fairly small, I'm happy to say that I believe the ClawTech adapter to be worth the $30 you'd save off the official adapter. That being said, it's still a matter of personal preference - if you absolutely must have the best, or if money doesn't make a difference (ie if your work will cover the purchase), then $30 isn't that much more for the peace of mind.

Full disclosure: Eklund provided me with free supplements in exchange for an honest review.The first thing I noticed about these supplements was how no-nonsense and nutrition-focused they are. They cram A LOT into single pills, which I really like (Maybe it's just me, but I don't enjoy swallowing dozens of pills at every meal).Reviewing the ingredients list, these are no-nonsense, no-fluff supplements - they just get the job done, as their professional appearance suggests.Lacking certification in nutritional education, I'm not qualified to tell you if the vitamins themselves are beneficial or not - but given the pure ingredients and polished presentation, if you do decide to supplement your Omega 3 intake, Eklund is a great choice.I hope you found this helpful!

Disclaimer: I received this unit in exchange for an honest review.After using this battery several times for my assortment of RC toys, I've found it to work exactly as expected. I know my main concern with off-brand batteries are that they won't work, or that they'll explode...neither of which has happened so far!It's possible that it has a shorter life span than brand name batteries - I'm 3 uses in and I haven't seen anything suspicious, but I'll keep this review updated as I continue to use it.I hope you found this helpful!

Full disclosure: I received a free copy of this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.My biggest skepticism from years past when it comes to 2-in-1 cables is that they just don't work / can't do everything regular cables can. In the case of phone cables, it's usually been that they can charge your phones, but not sync data.Well, I can confirm that this cable DOES work for both charging and syncing! How do they do it? Who knows, some sort of magic - but it finally works.Once I got over my initial excitement and started using the product regularly, I found one issue: the capping system is a little awkward (the connecting cable is thick and rubbery like the rest of the cable), but I can't think of a better way to do it that still makes it impossible to lose the cap.As a side note, this cable is great for travelling - half the cables! Even if you don't own an Android AND iOS device, it'll make you quite popular with your friends when they need an emergency charge). It goes especially well with my favorite USB battery: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00ITILPZ4/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B00ITILPZ4&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=AQXDV2NYIJVIQWG5

When I first considered buying this flash drive, my biggest concern was "Where's the USB 3 port?" - as it turns out, one side of the flash drive is micro USB... and the other side is USB. There's no cap, because the entire end of the flash drive fits INSIDE of a USB slot. Yes, this flash drive is THAT small. Which is a pretty big game-changer: these days, flash drives are becoming more and more optional / "in case of emergency", so size and convenience has replaced performance as my primary concern.That being said, as a USB 3 device, performance is still pretty good. I achieved 16MB/s sequential writes (vs 30MB/s for my previous, high-performance flash drive: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00KT7DXIU/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B00KT7DXIU&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=SZIXX34MIKDAXAVMIf you need fast read and write performance, the above SanDisk Extreme is a great drive, and only slightly more expensive. The biggest drawback is the size - this drive is about half as large in every dimension. Both are great options, so pick the one that best suits your priorities.I hope you found this helpful!

Having used both this flash drive and the Corsair Voyager GO, I thought I would share my views on their relative advantages (for reference, the Voyager GO: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HVT27B8/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B00HVT27B8&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=4KHI7PYLHYKXQDKZBoth of these drives are priced about the same (unless you're able to find one on sale - in which case, they're similar enough that you should just buy the one on sale!) - the fundamental difference is about size vs performance.Having been a long time power user (I'm the head developer for an advertising startup), I've always gone for as much speed as possible. But, these days, flash drives are becoming more and more optional / "in case of emergency", so size and convenience has replaced performance as my primary concern.Because of that, I decided to replace the Extreme - the GO is now my primary flash drive. It's half as large in every dimension, which means I can easily attach it to my key ring or leave it in my backpack and completely forget about it (that being said, if you tend to lose things, you may want to get the Extreme simply because it's harder to lose).If you need fast read and write performance, the above SanDisk Extreme is a great drive, and only slightly more expensive. Both are great options, so pick the one that best suits your priorities.I hope you found this helpful!

Full disclosure: I received a free set of baking mats in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.I've always thought it was silly to throw away a sheet of aluminum foil every time we put something in the oven - but before coming across these baking mats, I had no idea there was an alternative.Having used these for oven cooking three times now, I can say that these work. I was a bit skeptical that they would, especially after taking them out of the package to discover that their unusual texture (which I can only describe as "slightly sticky rubber"). But, work they do, and we've had no issue with baked goods sticking to them, even without any sort of cooking spray!So, if they work, the big question comes down to value. When I first received these for review, they were $30 for a set - at that price, it would take a /long/ time to save $30 in aluminum foil. But, now that their price has fallen to $18, the bet is much less risky. If you cook in the oven on a regular basis, you'd likely pay these off in about a year. Plus, you don't have to use oils to keep food from sticking to the aluminum foil, which is better for your health.The last point that I would like to mention, and the only real reason I'm giving it 4 stars instead of 5 at this price point, is that you /do/ still need aluminum foil in your kitchen. With these baking mats, you won't need it nearly as much - but there are still times you need it for wrapping, grilling and covering. Which makes it slightly less of the "kitchen miracle" that the marketing claims it to be - but, hey, that's marketing.I hope you found this helpful!

Full disclosure: PCNL provided me with free supplements in exchange for an honest review.The first thing I noticed about the PCNL supplements was their premium packaging, and the pure white pills. A good indication that PCNL cares about the products they make. Reviewing in the ingredients list, these are no-nonsense, no-fluff supplements - they just get the job done, as their serious appearance suggests.The supplements are quite easy to take. They are flavor-neutral and very small (which is quite handy, since they're able to fit more supplements in smaller bottles than any other brand of supplement I've tried)Lacking certification in nutritional education, I'm not qualified to tell you if the vitamins themselves are beneficial or not - but given the pure ingredients and polished presentation, if you do decide to use vitamins, PCNL is a great choice.I hope you found this helpful!

Full disclosure: I was provided a unit for free in exchange for an honest review.In this review, I'll be comparing this VinVin model to the Amazon classic True Fabrications corkscrew ($9) - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00400OL92/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B00400OL92&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=HQSW3OKK6Q7P5UALTo decide which corkscrew is right for you, you should first ask yourself: What are you looking for?If you want a corkscrew, the cheaper True Fabrications is a corkscrew. It'll open your wine, it has all the features, and it's cheap.But if you want something to impress guests and the extra few $'s doesn't phase you, the VinVin is the way to go. The handle is visually nicer, it caries a more solid heft, and the construction feels more polished. Compared to True Fabrications, it's definitely a luxury purchase - both in price, and in quality.I hope you found this helpful!

After using the cheapest baking pans we could find, the biggest issue we had was things overflowing the edges and spilling into the oven.These trays solve that quite well, with a small lip along the entire perimeter.The pans are also coated in a nice, non stick surface, though I still recommend covering them in aluminum foil to save yourself a lot of cleaning effort later.Finally, the trays also stack. This is a huge space saving feature, and enables us to keep 3 trays in the space of one (really handy for the tight space under the oven).Overall, I'm very pleased with our upgrade to these trays and would definitely buy them again. I'll keep this review updated in case anything changes!

I loved the first two Borderlands games and was excited to buy this when it came out.Is it worth $60? Probably not, if you've played the other two Borderlands games. While it contains the same fun mechanics...it contains the same fun mechanics as the last two. Yes, there's now low gravity and oxygen and a few other small tweaks, but if I were to do it again, I'd wait till the price drops. This would be a solid game for $30.The co-op is also a lot of fun (as per usual with the Borderlands series), but that's another good reason to wait to buy it. Multiple friends buying a $60 game adds up fast!

First up, a warning: without modifying the foot holders, this product is PAINFUL to use. My feet were bleeding after a single use wearing socks. I ended up 3D printing my own foot holders for it, but if you aren't prepared or able to do some modification on yours, you should consider purchasing a better designed rowing machine like this one: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003YPZWT2/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B003YPZWT2&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=ELSYURL4CCMJBHVAPROS:- small and light / convenient to store- inexpensive- compatible with a wide variety of workout needs (adjustable tension) and body sizes (big and small)CONS:- seat and foot holders are not well padded. Prepare to be uncomfortable. (no pain no gain?)- creaks a lot while in useWould I buy this rowing machine again? If I'm on a tight budget, yes. For this price, there's simply no good competition. If I was willing to spend a bit more, though, I'd prefer to get something a bit higher quality (like the above Air Rower) that doesn't need any modifications to be usable.

David provided me with an early release copy to write an honest review of the material.At just 24 pages, it is short, sweet, and to the point. In under 30 minutes, I feel like I have gained the primary knowledge necessary to get started in selling liquidated items on Amazon.Having personally been successful in a similar field, I appreciate how many tips David shares, and how many pitfalls and mistakes he shows you how to avoid.Though the writing was imperfect (grammatical and spelling errors), I found the content interesting. Even though I do not plan to enter the Amazon liquidation game, some of the tips he shares are applicable to a wide variety of businesses.Worth the read and the affordable price, especially if you're looking for a new side project / way to expand your income.

Though I've been reasonably satisfied with this charger, I would not buy it again and would instead look for a higher quality charger without the below flaws.Pros- You can charge a lot of batteries for the price- Individual charger circuits lets you charge single batteries- Display lets you see charge status of all batteries at onceCons- Display is nearly impossible to read. You'll need a direct, bright light...which means you can't have it in an out-of-the-way spot- Power supply makes a high pitched noise whenever it's plugged in (even when it's not charging any batteries)I hope you found this helpful!

I've been using this label maker for nearly a year now.Some pros:- hey, it's pretty cheap- well-built- labels look niceCons:- label tape is pretty expensive- it has a lot of options...too many. Prepare to be confused for the first month- large- depending on your environment, the white and green color scheme feels a bit childish / unprofessionalOverall not a bad choice, especially if you're looking for something from a trusted brand.However, if you're looking for the best intro model on Amazon, you may want to look to DYMO. Their model is half the price & a bit smaller, their label tape is cheaper, and they still have all the main options you need while dropping a lot of the confusing ones. Check it out: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005X9VZ70/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B005X9VZ70&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=BHL2TZQ72CENYK3BI hope you found this helpful!

I studied Business at Tepper / Carnegie Mellon University. Brainfluence is an excellent book that compresses an entire semester of bleeding-edge marketing into direct and actionable knowledge. While reading, I was able to apply the knowledge directly to my startup.If you're new to marketing, read this: you'll learn an immense amount in a single afternoon. If you're an experienced marketer... Read this! Having run startups for the past 5 years, I still found several new and useful tips and ideas.The only reason that I deducted a star is that, for a book that focuses on being science-oriented, it still has a lot of anecdotal evidence. But, there's still enough hard science in here to provide many solid improvements to your marketing and sales - especially for such a low price compared to the potential gains!

UPDATE: after seeing my negative experience, ActivFortis support was quick to send me a new unit. It looks like the previous unit was faulty after all, and the new unit is significantly brighter. I now rate the product quite highly, both for the build quality & brightness, and the speed and quality of customer service!----Since purchasing this light, I've been hailed by several drivers who told me that they could barely see me, and that I should get a brighter light.Considering this product hails itself as "ultra bright," I find its marketing to be dangerously misleading.This is my first bike light. Although many other reviewers have hailed it as being excellent for the price (and it does seem to be well-constructed) I must say...if this is good / bright for the price, then you should be prepared to spend significantly more than $24 if you value your life and safety.

After purchasing this, I found that it does not come with any way to mount it - and I had to purchase the wall mount separately from PadHoldr's website for an additional $25.If you are looking for a wall mount, I recommend this version instead, which comes with the wall mount: (and also lets you mount the tablet in landscape or portrait) http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00I00SNL0/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B00I00SNL0&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=AJN2JA5P22LWALL4Once that was resolved and the mount installed, I found the tablet holder to be stylish and durable. It is more expensive than some of the "clever" $10 holders on the market, but looking at their tiny metal clasps, I'm not sure I'd trust my $400 tablet to them.One thing I especially like about the Padholdr holders is their tablet-agnostic adjust-ability. This came with numerous different sizes of spaces, so that you can adjust your holder to fit a large range of tablets, with and without cases.I hope you found this helpful!

You may have noticed how many reviewers remark on the low quality of the T50.Having used one myself, I can confirm that they are true and accurate.After being so disappointed in this stapler, I did further research and discovered a much better option built by Tacwise: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0091CECNE/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B0091CECNE&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=GSK2JZM2LMJEI2U4Though their stapler is more expensive, after the endless hours wasted, spent trying to unjam this T50, I can assure you that buying the higher-quality is a very good investment.I hope you found this helpful - feel free to ask any questions you might have!

I've owned both versions of this wallet (v1 and v2). Many of the concerns other reviewers have had (mainly the cards falling out) have been solved in version 2, which is what you're buying here.To put it in perspective, this wallet weighs as much empty...as a single sheet of paper.At present count, I have 5 bills and 10 cards in my wallet, and it's barely thicker than my phone. If you have tiny pockets - or just don't like having a bunch of huge things in your pocket - this wallet is for you.It's also incredibly durable. I've had my current version for over a year, and there's absolutely no signs of damage (even if there was, they're only $12!)Which leads me to the only con - some people might not like the appearance. It's sleek and modern, but it lacks the "executive" feel people usually look for in leather wallets. Depending on the color you get, dirt can also be fairly visible on it. Of course, since it's just tent fabric, it's easy enough to lightly wash.So there you have it - an absurdly light, thin and practical wallet whose only drawback is that it doesn't look like you spent several hundred dollars on it... because it only cost $12.I hope you found this helpful! Feel free to ask questions in the comments

I own both this and the DJI Phantom. When I bought it, the Walkera was slightly cheaper than the DJI Phantom. Learn from my mistake, and just get the Phantom! (Actually, the Phantom 2 looks even better, especially the one that includes the gimbal: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00JD4TQ8Q/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B00JD4TQ8Q&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=BN77OD53AMBBC7CDPros of the Walkera:- With fewer safety features, it's easier to push this quads to the absolute limits. It's kinda like driving a manual car, in the sky.- Uses a slightly larger battery than the Phantom 1, and thus has ~15 min flight time instead of ~12 min (note that the Phantom 2 mentioned above has way better flight times than either of these)- Fancier looking controllerPros of the Phantom:- All the safety features make it easier to control and harder to crash- If you do crash it (as I have), spare parts and repair guides are much easier to come by- The Zenmuse gimbal you can get for the Phantom does a much better stabilization job (if you're going the filming route)Things that neither of them have:- No telemetry. The battery indicators are /on the quadcopter/ which is pretty much useless unless you plan on flying within 10 feet of yourself. You'll want to set a timer on your phone / watch so that you know when to start bringing it in.- No collision avoidance. Some research labs are prototyping collision avoidance for quads, but right now, it's still /really/ easy to accidentally hit a tree and do some serious damage to your quad. Have a friend spot you!If the Walkera were $100 cheaper than the Phantom, I'd label as a good beater quadcopter. Not a good beginner quad, because it's so much harder to fly, but one that you could throw away for crazy stunts.But, at the same price as the Phantom, the Walkera really brings nothing to the table. So what are you waiting for, go get the Phantom 2!(But good on you for doing your research first!)

Today, I'll be comparing two USB 3.0 multi-card readers, this one and one offered by Anker for $9: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006T9B6R2/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B006T9B6R2&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=S7XQZCY5ZZWSXIQSThey both have lots of meaningless marketing ("Made with high-quality chips!"), so I'm going to cut to the chase and compare what really matters!PERFORMANCEIf you're looking for a fast card reader, both of these are great. If you're still on a USB 2.0 reader, the 3.0 speed boost is well worth the small price.DESIGNWith similar designs, the winner is down to the details. This one is slightly smaller in all dimensions (it's small enough that I leave one in my camera bag), and the paint coating on it is less glossy, which means it handles scratching and normal wear & tear better.This one also include a cap to protect the USB slot. However, there's nowhere to attach the cap while it's in use (you can't stick it on the end like a marker cap), so I ended up throwing it away, as it's not really needed.PRICEAt time of writing, this one was $2 cheaper ($7 vs $9)OVERALLI'm happy to say that both products worked well - they were fast, small, and did their jobs. The slightly better design and lower price make this one the clear winner, but I still recommend checking the price on both - at the end of the day, they're so similar that I recommend buying whichever is cheaper.I hope you found this helpful! I'm happy to answer any questions you have

First off, this shaker looks amazing. It's a rocket! It goes perfectly with my Star Trek pizza cutter: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004FQDWP0/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B004FQDWP0&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=FXBQNKANI6EA4HHPPros:- IT'S A ROCKET- THAT SHAKES COCKTAILSBut, if you care about form more than function, you may want to look elsewhere. The stainless steel looks dingy quickly in a kitchen environment, and the metal cap system is difficult to work with, especially when wet.Cons:- Maintaining shiny appearance takes work- Attaching and removing the caps every time you want to make a drink isn't very easy

After 3 months, I've found this to overall be a pretty decent chair - soft, ergonomic, adjustable...but, I have found two things that annoyed me enough to knock off a star:- the arms wiggle and squeak- the bottom cushion is impossible to clean (there's a mesh layer over top that traps in particles and flakes)In summary: if you aren't perfectionist, then this is a great chair.I hope you found this helpful! Feel free to ask questions below

After looking around for a while for controller mounting options (and not finding many choices), I gave these a shot.They work. You screw them in (1 screw), adjust their tightness, bam. Controllers mounted. We screwed them into the sides of our sofa for easy access. In that specific mounting location, it's a bit hard to line the controller up with the hook - but, if you're mounting them on the wall, it's a non-issue.Cables are also a bit annoying, since you have to get them in the middle of the hooks. There's not a very good way to set up wireless controllers to charge, since there's no charging dock built in.But, hey, it's $10 for 4. I'm happy to deal with such minor gripes for such a cheap yet durable product.Hope you found this helpful, and feel free to ask questions in the comments!

I've played half a dozen games of Sentinels so far. Played it at a party, enjoyed it enough to buy a copy. It's a good party game, quick to learn and easy to adjust the difficult (you can pick different villains and heros, each with their own difficulty score).It's quite novel in that it's one of the few games where you and your friends work together, rather than fighting each other.On the down side, it's not the most replayable of games (since so much of the excitement relies on fighting new characters, and there's a fixed set of them)If you like games like Bang ( http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001RU7UNW/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B001RU7UNW&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=WMJQ4LRF62QRHIRV )or Munchin ( http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004U7JJWE/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B004U7JJWE&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=KMU6G3J46XGAKIGI )then you'll love Sentinels (and vis-versa - if you love Sentinels, you'll love those games too!)I hope you found this helpful, and feel free to ask questions below

Looking on the ingredients, Adobo is primarily salt, garlic, and pepper. No wonder it adds so much flavor to dishes!I add it to pretty much everything I cook - I used to add salt, garlic, and pepper, but this makes sure I get just the right blend every time - and, costs pretty much the same as buying them separately.On the cost note, I purchased this on Amazon because it sounded rare / hard to find. Turns out it's a very common spice, and you can find it at pretty much any grocery store for about half of Amazon's price.Hope that helps!

I've been through several tripods in the past few years. I finally came across this one after being recommended by the Strobist blog. In short, I am extremely satisfied with the diminutive size, ultralight weight, and durability of this tripod.In long, here's a bit of a comparison of the tripods I've used over the years (and why the Strobist's recommendation to just start off by buying a really good tripod holds true):When I first started with photography about four years ago, I purchased the cheapest tripod I could find, the $25 Vista Explorer: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000V7AF8E/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B000V7AF8E&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=OOAE2WZGH75GOMM3It's light, has clamp locks and a level and an adjustable center column. Features check. What it didn't have was strength. If you wanted your camera anything but level, its plastic clamps would slowly slip (shooting on an intro-level dSLR - would probably be fine with a point and shoot). It was a great tripod....until I started taking photographs for real, and needed a tripod where I could let go of my camera for more than 5 seconds. Also, no ability to pan the camera!So, I got the $70 Dolica Proline: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001DIKUYE/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=B001DIKUYE&linkCode=as2&tag=todmedblo-20&linkId=K3PYY4E3AAHTRKT4Better. This tripod lasted me for a solid year of trustworthy functioning - until, one day, it got blown over in a wind storm, and the legs bent. Did I mention this one was still made of plastic? It was also awkwardly designed, with the pan handle extending out of the carrying bag (unless you really wanted to unscrew it every time you put it away)Fast-forward to this Mefoto, whose durability has survived drops and falls, and whose portability lets me stick it in a backpack and ditch the extra carrying case. It's made of metal, so I'm expecting it to last much longer than either of my previous tripods...It might cost twice as much as my Dolica, but it's on track to easily last at least twice as long!

If you a lot of electronics, this little $8 splitter is worth every penny. Besides being cheap, it's small size makes it quite portable (I've added one to my backpack tech kit - it's saved me several times where I've needed to plug in several bulky mac chargers).I also use them regularly on film sets, where outlets are always at a premium. I've gotten in the habit of leaving these attached to my extension cords, making them 3x as useful!I hope you found this helpful. I'm happy to answer any questions in the comments.

I have been using a Trition headset for my ps4 and it works great. I tested this model from Afterglow and I must say I am disappointed.  The sound breaks up a lot, both music and chat. I've tried adjusting settings on the earpiece and in the ps4 system to no avail.It sounds great... When it's working.It plugs into the ps4 controller, so that's not where the problem is. It's just not receiving signal very well. I've tried it in other controllers and a friend's ps4 with similar results.Update: I noted that they are lumping all of the reviews together under one listing... lovely...2/5 stars: Level 5+ is the most overpriced and the one that has the feedback and static issues.4/5 stars: Level 3 is a solid mid range headset - I think this is the best version since it has less bells and whistles and is a simple, two earpiece headset.4/5 stars: Level 1 is a great budget set with one earpiece.For a wired headset, it behaves a lot like a crummy wireless set.

Basically this is a USB charging hub.  It plugs into the outlet via a cord, so it can be taken on trips or used at home or at the office.  It does not require mounting (the title makes it sound as if it 'should' be mounted).  The plus for the Belkin brand is that it charges four devices simultaneously - some devices with multiple USB charging points can only charge one at a time.It fits standard USB - so you can put aside the clunky Samsung, Apple, and Motorola chargers and just unplug the USB to (insert proper phone connecting point here - USB, lightning, micro USB, etc...)Overall I am pleased with the device and the quality.  I have yet to have a faulty Belkin device - they continue to produce high quality portable electronic accessories - good enough to sell in the Apple Store!(Works great charging my S6, Nexus 7, fiancee's S5, and Kindle all at once!)

These are very easy to put together - just a screwdriver and wrench or pliers (to hold the nuts).  One person job, but easier with two.  The only drawback is that it takes a little while to put together with just one person. Also, the little plastic feet don't stay on very well - but if you're putting the shelf on concrete or wood (storage shed, garage, etc...) it shouldn't matter.The good?The shelf is decently heavy, but not too heavy for one person to move when it's empty.The shelves are easily adjustable.It does fit through a standard door when assembled.Instructions are actually decent for IKEA style picture instructions.Overall I am satisfied and would highly recommend it.

We play a lot of Euro style board games in the style of Catan, Agricola, Kingdom Builder, and others.  This is what I would consider a VERY light Euro style game, or a mid level family style game.  It is appropriate for a wide age range.To sum the game up, you attempt to slay a dragon, but if you have help, you have to start a 60 second timer and negotiate as to the division of the spoils or nobody gets any of the treasure.  It's a neat twist on classic game play, but it is really focused on the negotiating side of things.  This is why I hit a four star rating.  It really depends on how the other players are negotiating and how much fun folks are having.  Sometimes you play with a person who is kind of a jerk and it can take some of the fun out of it...  That's the real only negative aspect.  And replay can be dull after awhile since it consists of a similar lather, rinse, repeat style of play.

Works just like Frontline Plus.  Used it a couple of times now and no fleas, no reaction from the kitty.  Great value flea treatment.Buy from Amazon directly with all flea treatments to avoid imitations

Works just like Frontline Plus.  Used it a couple of times now and no fleas, no reaction from the pup.  Great value flea treatment.Buy from Amazon directly with all flea treatments to avoid imitations.

My one problem with most Asics shoes is the giant, massively cushioned gel soles.  This shoe actually  has a much thinner, lower profile sole and has a lot more response than other Asics I've tried.  It reminds me more of many of the Brooks shoes in the mid range.The reflective spots are VERY reflective - nice for running in dim light.  The colors in the photo are pretty accurate.  The stripes do shoe up nicely.  I often wear these to work since they're very comfortable for walking around for hours.  And the green soles and accents are very cool.

I've been playing Destiny on the PS3 and figured this was too nice to pass up.  The system has a wonderful theme: polar white with gold and silver map / logo accents.  The controller is also polar white and matches nicely.What the system includes:-One DualShock4 Controller-One HDMI cord (I used a better one from AmazonBasics)-One earpiece microphone (a very basic setup)-One power cord-One controller charging usb to micro usb cord-One month free Playstation Plus-One hard disc copy of Destiny The Taken King Legendary Edition (all DLC to date)Note: You need a good Ethernet Cable if you are using a hard line for the PS4 (highly recommended).  It does have built in Wifi.UPS was a bit late in delivering so unfortunately I had to wait 6 hours for the content to download from the servers.  In the meantime, I downloaded Sword Art Online Hollow Fragment and played that while the download ran in the background.The media interface takes a bit of getting used to with the PS4, but it is more set up to be a multi media powerhouse than a 'game system'.  The light on the system is subtle and shows when the system is running or in rest mode.One BIG annoyance however: the damn light bar on the controller.  Even changing the settings to the dimmest possible it still shows a glare on the TV when playing games.  Plus, I often play with the controller laying on my chest, so the top of the controller faces my face: annoying light in my eyes if I do this.  Time for some electrical tape!The PS4 is a great step up from the PS3.  It really shines on the newest HDTVs.  And the potential for the future is huge.  Developers have barely pushed the hardware on this system.  It is probably a ten year system - and costs about half what the PS3 cost when it was new!

This is a solid, high quality electric razor produced by Philips Norelco.  I've owned many of their products in the past and have been pleased with several of their trimmers and razors I have tested and reviewed.  There are so many wonderful things about this electric shaver but I will point out the one obvious hiccup: this sucker is expensive!If price is no object however, then you will be looking at one of the best, most comfortable oscillating electric razors out there.  Some of the pros:+ Quick charging (1 - 2 hours for a full charge)+ Long battery life (holds a charge for days with regular use)+ Lightweight and sturdy+ Trimmer attachment for beards (more on this)+ Quiet - won't wake up the missus (or mister)There should be three +++ for me for the trimmer attachment since I sport a short beard year round.  Typically I have used those standard beard trimmers, which are horrible for trimming the beard around the ear (finishing my neck with a blade).  This setup does wonders around those tricky areas.  Now I can use one tool for both a close shave on my neck and a short beard trim.  I've even used it on my head and it does a pretty good job - though nothing beats a blade for those baldies like me!Bottom line: this is a great razor.  If you have a guy in your life who needs a new electric razor - this is a GREAT gift!  Or if you're a guy (or very hairy woman - equal opportunity here) who wants to treat themselves to the very best - this is one of the best.

This is a very nice throw and pillow case set. I almost thought it came with pillows because I wasn't used to seeing pillow "shells" as a descriptor for a pillow case.The purple is quite a lovely "royal" shade. The material is obviously synthetic fibers, but it is soft and has a good quality to it.My only one drawback is price: Marshall's does have good Columbia brand throws for $10 (plain colors and patterns) - and the pattern is a love or hate thing. I haven't quite decided... But I'm not exactly putting it on display on my couch right now!

Tiger makes some of the best rice cookers on the market. There are a few minor problems I personally have with the cooker, but none of the issues affects the main function of the cooker. The cord really needs a little loop on the back to wrap it around. Also, the instructions are good, but confusing at times. Often the book says to go to a different page, then that page again says to go to another page... So lots of flipping around.On the positive side, the machine is very solid. The inner receptacle is very study metal, and a lot heavier than our Aroma brand (our little cheap ish cooker). Also, the measurements for rice and water are on the inside receptacle. The cooker has a lot of functions and can be complicated to use, but I'm happier with the numerous functions sacrificing ease rather than the opposite.Bottom line though: I've never had better, fluffier rice from the cheaper cookers. I highly, highly recommend this product for anyone coming rice or other starches on a regular basis.

(Note: this is a review for the novel - I think Amazon is lumping both the manga and novel reviews to the same page)SAO Progressive 1 had a couple of short stories / novellas about the first and second floor of Aincrad.  This volume is a bit different since it contains one longer story focused on the events of floor 3. I won't reveal too much since there are spoilers galore, but the story centers around Kirito and Asuna (of course) and a mysterious NPC elf who seems to be more than just any regular NPC.  Their journey takes them through the massive forests of the 3rd floor and they meet and interact with the other 40 odd front line players who are starting to organize into guilds.  Kirito and Asuna have tough decisions to make, decisions which will impact their relationship and their future in the world of Aincrad and the game of death.Though I enjoyed having a couple of stories in SAO Progressive 1, I really did like the single story format of this light novel.  The reader really gets to know the secondary characters, so things have much more dramatic impact when some 'events' transpire.  Overall I highly recommend this for fans of SAO - even more than the manga versions.

This is an interesting and fun game for players of various skill levels.  Each play through takes 30 - 45 minutes depending on the number of players.  It plays decently well with two players, but really shines with three or four people.+ Good quality components+ Easy learning curve+ Fun theme+ Enjoyable for players at various skill levels+ Good two player variant- Repetitive- Leather dice cup (it smells a bit)So a minor quibble: The game does get repetitive.  Though you are expanding your meeples, acquiring resources, and gaining points; each turn has a similar theme: take something or do something from one of several options.  This can get repetitive, but it is also nice for those who are not very good with complex Euro style games.  Having fewer options makes it easier for those folks to stay competitive versus experts.  Also, a little common sense strategy goes a long way.  I've been beaten by first time players mainly because they've used common sense to determine the best courses of action, thereby robbing me of my next action!Though the game can get repetitive after a dozen or so plays, it is a bit fresher when introducing new players.  There is always a little bit of variation depending on what resources you are after.  Basically you acquire workers (via the love hut as I call it!), acquire resources, use resources, gain assets (huts, etc) and gain victory points.It is a classic worker placement style game with a fun prehistoric theme.  We typically have a lot of fun by making caveman noises and such.  Because it's fairly straightforward, this is a game with good opportunity to socialize - you aren't going to lose the game completely by making one or two bad decisions.Overall I highly recommend this for entry level to mid level players who want a fun, easy to learn game with lots of socializing opportunity.

Wil Wheaton called this the most 'Zen' game he's played... and I would say artistically yes - but it can get pretty cutthroat - especially in the 3 player games.  In this game, players travel the ancient Tokaido road from Kyoto to Edo (or the other direction in variant games).  Players will take in the sights and scenery, purchase goods, eat a variety of food, meet diverse people, stop and work at farms, and donate to temples.  The player with the most victory points, usually the player with the most variety of acquisitions, is the winner.  Here is the summary:+ Gorgeous artwork.  Did I say gorgeous?  I meant GORGEOUS.+ 2 - 5 players and fun with any number (though 3 is the sweet spot)+ Lots of variety of play based on your selected character+ Unique movement style where player in last spot goes next+ Some quality components (board, meeples, coins, character cards)- Steep initial learning curve- pretty unhelpful instructions- The cards are very small and hard to shuffleThe game has a STEEP initial learning curve - and the instructions do little to help.  Instead search for 'Tokaido how to play' on Youtube for some instructional videos (I have no affiliation with any of them, but 'Watch it Played' had a very helpful tutorial).  I won't get into the rules or gameplay in too much detail because it would probably serve to confuse readers more than anything.  Also, the cards are small, so you should probably shuffle them by swirling them about on the table rather than trying to shuffle normally (I tried and promptly bent several cards...)So the game. Basically (as mentioned above) you attempt to collect various items and gain points for most things instantly.  Donating coins to temples, completing panoramas, collecting a variety of merchandise, and meeting people all give points.  Many things cost money, and coin is hard to come by, so balancing is key.  You want to make sure you have some money each time you visit an inn, because food gives 6 points - but only if you have enough coins to buy your meal.Overall the replay value is moderate - having ten different characters to choose from adds a lot of replay value - but you often keep trying for the same goals.  There is a bit of cutthroat gameplay - mainly you can land on spaces you feel other players are trying for.  So if you have someone trying to gain the end game bonus for hot springs, you can try and hit more hot springs than them - especially if they are zooming ahead, giving you one or more turns to catch up.Despite a few minor quibbles, this is a terrific game and a must have for any fan of Euro board games.

Kingdom Builder has won many awards, but looking online, I noticed a lot of 'meh' reviews.  Still, we picked up a set when it was $35 during the board game Gold Box deals day.  I am happy to say that we absolutely love this game.  We'll give you a quick overview then discuss the reasons for the pros and cons of this game designed by Donald X. Vaccarino of Dominion fame.+ Amazing design and lovely art+ High quality components+ Variety of goals to accomplish+ Several map boards can be interchanged+ Very fun with high replay+ Scoring at end of game rather than as game flows- Less freedom of placement- Less head to head gameplayNow let's explain:  In Kingdom Builder (KB from here out), the goal is to settle the map and gain gold (victory points).  Players assemble a map from four of the eight included map boards.  Each quadrant has a castle or two and a location or two.  They also contain grassland, canyons, desert, forests, flower fields, mountains and water.The players will then draw three cards from the mission or goal cards.  These cards tell the players what they must accomplish in order to gain gold (VPs).  These tasks will be completed and added up at the end.  Some tasks include having the most settlements in a quadrant or having a lot of settlements on one horizontal line, or gold for settlements next to water tiles or mountain tiles: there are ten in total and three are used each game.Players will draw one card from the terrain cards.  This card tells players where they must play settlements.  Each player MUST play three settlements on their turn onto the depicted terrain (in a rare instance where all those terrains are full, they draw a new card - we've never encountered this though).  The real trick here is that settlements MUST be played adjacent to existing settlements - if this is possible!  So if you have settlements on forest only and draw a desert card, you will look to see if any of your forest settlements touch desert hexes.  If so, you have to play the new settlements starting with the desert hex touching the settled forest hex.  If you draw a card and there are no settlements in or touching that terrain type, you can play anywhere.There are two interesting things that happen when you eventually settle next to a castle or location.  If you put a settlement next to a castle, you score 3 gold at the end of the game (don't score immediately, because you CAN get a location tile to move settlements).  If you place a settlement next to a location tile, you gain the extra move associated with that location and collect one of the two tiles on that location.  You can only gain these once per city / location no matter how many settlements touch either.  It is possible to gain two different location tiles if you settle next to two different locations and they have a tile remaining - but you cannot take two from the same.These location tiles offer additional, optional moves, such as placing an additional settlement on any grass hex, placing adjacent if possible and so on.  These are optional moves and do not have to be completed.  Also, they can be done before settling your three mandatory settlements - but you must reveal your terrain card first (since several optional moves have terrain specifics depending on your card).  Once you have taken mandatory and optional moves, you end your turn by drawing a terrain card and keeping it secret.  This way you can look over and plan your next moves while the other players are placing their settlements.  If the terrain draw stack is depleted, reshuffle (this is common and we found usually we shuffle once per game).The game ends when a player places their last settlements and all other players have taken one more turn afterwards.  Therefore it is possible to end the game with a lot of settlements unplayed - though this is not a good thing!  Score is tallied by adding gold acquired for each goal.  The cards specify how much (you might get one gold for every two settlements..., or one gold for each settlement..., and so on).  Then you add 3 gold for each castle a player has at least one settlement next to (so even four players can gain gold for one castle if they each have a settlement touching it).The game is fun with any number of the players from 2 - 4.  Granted, it gets a bit more confrontational with more players since players will be vying for more limited space.  With two players, it is a more peaceful game and typically players will be going for the goals in separate parts of the map.  We found that there isn't really any best number of players since it plays differently with each number of players.The complaints I hear are that the game limits your options: and it does to a certain extent.  Often you are forced to settle in one specific area due to the 'adjacent' rule.  But then there is strategy where you might avoid placing settlements touching another terrain type, so that you can move anywhere on the map (when the adjacent rule doesn't apply, you can place settlements on any terrain matching the drawn card).  Also there is a lot of strategy once you have the location tiles.  I found often that if I had one that allowed me to play something not using the adjacent rule, I could do that before playing my mandatory actions and therefore open up a new area for settlement.  In terms of Euro games, it is a medium to light game though since your moves are restricted.  Though this also helps to level the playing field somewhat for those who are not too accustomed to these types of games.I've found the game is a lot of fun.  There is a lot of variety, especially since you can mix up the maps and each map section having different location tiles with different optional moves to acquire.  Also, having three unique missions to compete for in each game keeps things fresh.I highly, highly recommend it for both those new to Euro games and those with a moderate level of skill in Euro games (or advanced players wanting a game with a level playing field for all skill levels).

I use Avery labels for most of my shipping needs - typically the half sheet labels.  The large labels are almost too large for shipping, but they are great for other uses.  You can use the Avery template online, or just print from Word or a similar word processing software.The other thing I figured out: If you are printing shipping labels - from Amazon for example - you can print two labels on one sheet and then just cut the sheet in half after printing.  Tougher to do if you are only printing one half sheet label at a time!Good quality and the adhesive is very good, not gummy, just very secure.  Also, the labels are very opaque, so you can stick them over existing labels if you are reusing boxes or padded envelopes and the previous label won't show through.

I've only ever watched tutorials and reviews for the original Agricola, owing to the fact that my girlfriend and I typically play two player Euro board games.  It was with utter joy and delight that we discovered the two player variant of this game.  As I understand it, this is a MUCH simpler and MUCH faster version of the game - though it is NOT an easy or shallow game.  There are no crops to manage - no families to feed either.  Instead the focus is on livestock.  Also, there isn't much random chance: most everything is determined by your personal strategy alone and your selections.In this game, players compete for victory points which are earned by raising the most livestock and building the most valuable buildings.  You make decisions each turn to: collect building materials, collect livestock, expand your farm boards, build structures (stalls, stables, food troughs, buildings), lay out fences to create animal pens, move livestock, and pick up goods.  The game lasts exactly 8 rounds - when the yellow borders in the general supply are exhausted the game ends.There are a lot of decisions to make, and different strategies.  There are ways of 'cheating' your opponent but collecting items on the board before they can, since some of the items are not added unless an item exists in the space already (like the space with 1 reed having a sheep added during the refill phase if there is already a reed in the space).The rules are very well explained in the manual - and there are tons of online help tutorials - as well as terrific customer service from Z Man games.We highly recommend this game to fans of good two player Euro board games.  (Also check out Rivals for Catan - another fun 2 player variant of a major Euro game franchise).

This is a fairly easy game to get into and learn, but one that rewards strategy.  I picked up a copy of this game at Guardian Games in Portland based on an employee recommendation for an outstanding two player Euro style game.  We were not disappointed.The premise is simple: collect and cook mushrooms and gain points to win.  Each type of mushroom yields different points, but they have to be collected in amounts of at least 3 before being 'cooked'.  If you have more mushrooms of the same type and either butter or cider, you can cook them to yield more points.  You always need a pan to cook mushrooms, so this makes it interesting as well.The instructions are fairly straightforward.  The real strategy involves determining whether to wait for higher numbers of mushrooms (using baskets to increase your maximum hand size) or playing mushrooms right away.  You also have to watch out for devouring angels, which can hurt a lot if you pick one up from the decay stack.  You can also grab the moon cards which allow you to draw from the night deck (more points).  Instead of drawing a card or cooking mushrooms, you can sell mushrooms (at least 2 like type) for foraging sticks which allow you to pick up cards further up the tableau.A few pointers: I've found that sometimes grabbing a really good decay pile early on - even with a devouring angel - can be rewarding (if you have the hand limit for it).  You can't pick up the decay if it puts you over the hand limit - note this rule when picking up a decay with a devouring angel since that reduces your hand size immediately!  Also, watch for the number of certain mushrooms going into the discard or being cooked by another player - you might be trying to collect porcinis for example, only to realize that the two in your hand are the last two!Also, pay attention to the pans.  I have had some really great hands near the end of the game only to find I missed out on collecting that last pan.  Nothing really burns as much as having three Morels and not having a pan to cook them!  (18 points down the drain!)My girlfriend and I play mostly two player games and this is one of our new favorites.  We also recommend the following with good two player variations:Rivals for CatanLord of the Rings The ConfrontationSmallworldSamuraiCarcassonne (we like the Android app - MUCH easier scoring!)Ticket to RideAgricola Creatures Big and SmallAnd I'm sure there are others - comment if you have any other recommendations: we have at least 30 Euro board games, but we're also interested in others!  (By the way: Race for the Galaxy is the best ever!  But my gf HATES it!)

Do you want a burr grinder?Do you want an inexpensive yet functional model?Do you need the grinder to be portable and require no plug in?If you answered yes to these three questions then this is an ideal burr grinder for your needs.  The Tanors grinder is designed in Germany.  Customer service goes through the American importing company.While there are several manual grinders in this price range (Hario makes an excellent model), this fits the bill and I have had no issues yet.  It takes about three or four minutes to grind enough beans for a large single serving.  You can adjust the grind size manually so you can have coarse (French Press) or fine (Aeropress).  It does an excellent job, but I recommend buying a more expensive electric burr grinder if you make a lot of coffee and do not need portability.I will say that this is great for camping trips!
This is a very good tablecloth. I was surprised by the quality of the material and the stitching. It is a very nice holiday green but looks great year round.

I really enjoyed the stories contained in this wine documentary.  I especially enjoyed the information about Carlisle and Brooks, two wineries I regularly purchase.  I've been to Brooks Winery down the road from me and it is a terrific winery with a sad but determined history.The only real problem I noted was the editing.  The narrative jumps around quite a bit and there isn't often a clear reason as to why.  I think the folks who made this documentary wanted to keep Jim Brooks' death a secret until closer to the end (for a more dramatic reveal), but this isn't a TV drama and I think that was a poor choice in setting up the timeline.I did enjoy hearing about the Virginia winery (nice to get a viewpoint from outside the main growing regions of the west coast).  I would have liked either a couple more producers, maybe something in Washington or Finger Lakes New York?I would have enjoyed it better if the story had focused on each producer in more depth at a time (less skipping around) or even just stayed with each story a little longer before jumping.

The first SAO novel was intended to be a standalone novel that was submitted for a writing award program in Japan.  The novel became a huge hit and Kawahara decided to follow up with a collection of stories filling the gaps in the story.  Most of these stories were alluded to in the first novel.The Black Swordsman: this story revolves around Silica and her quest to restore life to her 'pet' dragon, Pina.Warmth of the Heart: Lisbeth the smith is tasked with making a great sword for Kirito and they join together on a quest for a rare ingot.The Girl in the Morning Dew: Kirito and Asuna discover a young girl that appears to be neither a player nor an NPC.Red-Nosed Reindeer: Set earlier than the previous three stories, Kirito joins a low level guild but keeps his identity and level secret from the group.These stories help fill in the gaps, but the newer releases of Sword Art Online Progressive (also by Kawahara) go floor by floor through the Aincrad arc.

I've viewed the anime, and loved the Aincrad arc.  The Alfheim arc just doesn't quite live up to the first bit in terms of the game or the real danger and tension.  Instead Kirito faces enemies with his same reckless abandon, but there isn't any real tension as a viewer since the only penalty for 'death' in the new game is respawn at the last town and an experience penalty.This novel follows the story started in volume 3.  Kirito is travelling to the World Tree to discover if Asuna is actually being held captive within this new game.  The reader has already discovered early on that this is the case of course.If you are enjoying Kirito and Leafa getting to know one another, then this will be an enjoyable conclusion.  In my opinion, their relationship takes awhile to go anywhere and then when they finall discover they are related in real life - things just get weird again.There are a few moments with very good 'action', but these moments are few and far between.  The reader spends more time hearing of the political lay of the land.  This is of mild interest since the end purpose of Kirito's journey is to save Asuna.  It actually doesn't make sense that he would take time from travelling to the World Tree to save envoys of two races in Alfheim from a third.  Though this actually makes things go more smoothly later on - it still doesn't suit Kirito and his single minded resolve to rescue Asuna.Still - it's a quick and easy read and I gave it four stars, the same as volume 3.  I am looking forward to the Death Gun arc - even though I am not a Sinon fan, the story (at least in the anime) was terrific.

Burt's Bees is highly preferred to lab concocted brands such as Nutrogena (which contain parabens and other iffy chemicals).  This kit includes a cleansing cream, and daily moisturizer, and cleansing towelettes.The towelettes are great for a quick cleansing wipe - after a light workout, or after a long work day.  They remove makeup pretty well.  Best thing is they work well and smell great!The moisturizer does not have any SPF - take note.  But it is clean and not sticky or oily.  Very smooth application.  The only question mark is that glycerin is rather high on the ingredient list.The daily cleanser is a bit oily on the application, but it rinses very well.  I tried the snap test - passed (washing hands with the cleanser and then snapping fingers).* No animal testing!* No parabens, Phthalates, or Petrochemicals* Containers made with partial post consumer product* Most ingredients are found in nature* Mild smell* Not greasy* Works great!

The series revolves around a character who has the distasteful job delivering 'Ikigami'.  Modern society injects random citizens with a capsule that causes death at a certain date and time.  The people who have the capsule are unaware since they are randomly distributed during mandatory vaccinations.  The end result is so that citizens 'appreciate' life and live life to it's fullest.  In reality it is a form of behavioral control since 'miscreants' and social 'outcasts' are 'corrected' by being injected with a capsule immediately.  All it takes is a formal citizen complaint of non-compliance to start a brief investigation resulting in the person's death.It's a system that is completely unrealistic - but the stories contained in the manga are what really shine.  Each person is given 24 hours notice via 'Ikigami' in order to spend the last hours with family or finishing up projects, tying up loose ends, etc...  The family is then given a stipend from the government after the victim does their duty and does not descend to criminal acts in the last day.  The first story arc is a story about such an individual seeking revenge on those who bullied him in his past.The individual stories are great - but it's the art that really pulls everything together.  Mase-san using shading VERY well.  The use of contrast works very well.  The entire series has a lot of dark areas which lend to the overall mood and theme.Overall I give the series a five star rating - it has been a very interesting read.  I highly recommend checking out this great manga.

These are decent enough treats.  However, there is no indication of source of ingredients.  I was sent these via Amazon Vine and read the ingredients in the description - which didn't list any poultry or red meat - but when I received the box: chicken liver.  My dog is on a healthy pescatarian diet (he's never been healthier) and I don't want to introduce meats his body isn't accustomed to.  So I split these up and gave them to friends with dogs who didn't mind the meat.2/3 of the dogs enjoyed them while the other didn't fare so well (loose stool, etc...).  Hence my 3/5 rating - minus one star for the dog that didn't like them and -1 star for deceptive labeling, no source of origin of ingredients.For dog treats I typically go with Fruitables - they are pretty much safe for human consumption (though I've never tried them) and most are vegetarian.  And they're cheaper and my dog has never had an issue with them.  Try the blueberry - they smell like fresh blueberry muffins!

The table runner is 72" long - so it fits most tables or buffets.  It is lightweight lace and looks very nice when in use.  The other fun uses I've tried include draping over windows and mirrors, draping over the fan blades of the ceiling fan, wrapping around the brim of a spooky hat, and draping over my shoulders.  I can't wait to use this in October!  The best part?  It's only $5.99!!!

I wasn't expecting a perfectly made wicker storage container for $50 - but I was impressed that this is a sturdy container with a pretty heavy weight and heft.  The lid is decently heavy so it does stay down securely.  The little clasp is good, but probably wouldn't stand up to a larger curious dog.  The strap is faux leather, so the pup does not want to eat it!I use this in the downstairs bathroom and keep it open most of the time so the dog can select toys at whim.  It's great for when I have company because I can stuff the toys inside and close the lid, keeping all the chewed and frayed items out of sight.For $50 the medium size is a great purchase.  Don't expect perfection of course - that would probably set you back a few simoleans more at Pottery Barn or Pier One Imports!

A decent microfiber pet dish mat.  I use it for the secondary water bowl for the cat & dog and it does the job just fine - it's decently absorbent.  Would recommend a heavier, plastic or metal tray with raised edges for the main food bowl area.  I would not test this in the washing machine, it doesn't seem like it would stand up to more than a few washes.  Dishwasher is probably better.Mine came in a large package and it was not folded or bent - luckily.

I'm a big fan of procedural mapped RPGs (or rogue-like if you will).  I have the Super Famicom game 'Fushigi no Dungeon 2: Frai no Shiren' on my phone and play it regularly. So knowing that this game was co-produced with ChunSoft (who is mainly responsible for the Fushigi no Dungeon games), I was highly anticipating this title.  It is fun, but flawed.First off is the atrocious player AI.  First - you must use a party when delving into the dungeons - or you will die quickly - likely from lack of food before anything else.  Well, the rest of the party inexplicably splits off on their own at completely random times.  You can switch to their character and try and rally them together... but often you are controlling the character in the middle of a battle or grabbing something and notice the other character just rushing off in some random direction and that they've strayed a bit too far already.  I understand the party system... but I think they should have balanced the game for two character parties.  That way you have an additional backup person.  Most of the Mystery Dungeon titles I've enjoyed have had one or two characters.The other little complaints are rather minor.  One quibble is that you level up your characters and keep your experience.  This seems like a normal thing for an Etrian game, but it isn't a regular Mystery Dungeon theme.  Typically you have a character that completely resets if you perish losing all experience, all money, and all equipment (minus what you send to your storage).  But losing all of you experience would certainly make this game unbelievably irritating since you spend a lot of time choosing skills and organizing your character.Also, the FOEs (DOEs in this game) attack the town and can shut down establishments, making it harder for the player to accomplish tasks.  The way to prevent this is to build forts - which is another part of the game I was not crazy about...The other minor quibble is only having one save file.  So if a friend or significant other wants to play - they have to use your character and risk setting you back quite a bit if they blunder badly enough.  Two files would have been good.I played the game for a few hours and had an alright time - but not enough to rush out and buy it at $39.99.  I'll wait for it to dip to $19.99 before pulling the trigger.  In the meantime I'll enjoy the rest of the Etrian titles.

I popped this amazing film on my Wish List to watch for awhile (since I was double dipping - having owned the DVD version for years).  When it hit $9.95 I bit and grabbed it.  The Blu-Ray transition is pretty amazing - it is well worth picking up the 1080p version here even if you have the DVD version.  The special features are quite nice as well - though similar to the DVD special edition.It is a great movie and it shows well despite its age.  Family friendly, adventurous, and really uplifting.  This is a must own for any fantasy film fan.  "I am the greatest swordsman that ever lived!" - Madmartigan

This tea is inspired by the Kyoto Sakura-hana matsuri (cherry blossom festival). Traditionally the sencha brewed during the festival is flavored with the addition of rose petals and often cherry blossoms. I searched for this tea locally for a long time (having it in Houston, Texas previously) but only recently was I able to find some in Portland, Oregon (Peet's Coffee of all places!).The tea is best brewed at a temperature around 160 - 170 degrees, in order to retain the freshness of the ingredients. Average steeping is about one minute for the first steep (you don't want to oversteep sencha) and about 30 seconds to a minute for a second steep. Further steeping requires longer times and results in a harsher flavor. As always - personal preference dictates the individual preparations.The flavor is sencha style green tea at the core with a floral, slightly sweet finish (impression of sweetness - not actual sugar). I STRONGLY recommend brewing this as is - no additions of cream, honey, sugar, or milk.The one thing I can't deduce: if the green tea is authentic Japanese Sencha or if it is a Brazilian imitation sencha (which is where local company Stash Tea sources their 'sencha')... maybe somebody can shed some light on this in a comment?
