This is a shameless marketing cash grab due to the popularity of the 'Minions'.  The game is simple and easy but bears almost no similarity to 'Life'.  Instead it is a watered down game, suited for kids, which is mildly fun and entertaining.  The only similarity is the spinner.  The pieces and cardboard are cheaply made and will not last.

This novel makes a great re-entry point for fans of the Shannara series who might have not returned to this series for awhile.  It also makes for a great starting point for new readers.  I've been a fan since the first book in the series (Sword of Shannara), but I really felt that the 'Scions of Shannara' series was the best.  I lost interest somewhat in college (not much time for recreational reading), but picked up a couple of the newer novels from Powell's and had some Vine offers, and I am pretty pleased with the newer stuff.Brooks has a great style and a good 'voice' for fantasy fiction.  His novels are the type that fans of full fantasy enjoy: diabolical villains, archetypal heroes, a pretty good line between good and evil (though it blurs sometimes!).  This isn't political fantasy (think Game of Thrones) but neither do the novels veer towards the overly mystical (gods and prophecies and such).The recent novels show a trend with some of the current fantasy authors: standalone novels set in a greater fantasy world.  This novel contains several recurring characters and also features the 'wishsong' which appears regularly in the Shannara novels - but newcomers won't be confused.  This is a great standalone fantasy novel for fans of the genre.  Read it and become hooked - then start at the beginning - but make sure to read the Scions right after 'Sword...', 'Elfstones...', 'Wishsong...'

Make sure to have a durable shower curtain liner since this is a purely decorative curtain.  The photo is misleading since it shows a shower liner behind the decorative curtain.  The curtain is very thin lace and has a very feminine appearance.  Great for a guest bathroom.

This is one of my favorite films, so I went ahead and double-dipped for this film when it went on special for $3.99 for the Blu-Ray.  I won't go into detail about the film - suffice to say it is a great film with humor, cheesy one-liners, and plenty of great action.If you love this film, I HIGHLY recommend getting the Blu-Ray version.  It is gorgeous and it contains a lot of fun extras and commentary.

We love Champagne and drink it regularly.  I was excited about this documentary but it fell slightly short.  The main reason is that I felt 'A Year in Burgundy' showed a wider variety of producers and different viewpoints.  This documentary does focus heavily on Bollinger and a couple of small producers (and Gosset was thrown in almost as an after thought).  I would have liked a little more time spent on some other producers, perhaps even adding this to the special features. Speaking of: they were pretty minor - though there is an e-book of sorts about Champagne but reading on the TV is hard to do and there are four deleted scenes and a brief biography of the filmmaker.In my opinion, this is a DVD geared towards those interested in but not knowledgeable about the specifics in production and style of Champagne.  Never once was there a mention of various styles such as Brut vs Demi-sec or even what really made a 'vintage' Champagne special.  Instead we have a few winemakers talking about it and mentioning that it is special, but we don't really get a picture of non-vintage vs vintage vs Tete de Cuvee.  I was happy however to see a nice segment on the disgorging and bottling of this beverage.If I hadn't seen 'A Year in Burgundy', then this would probably rate five stars.  We did watch 'A Year in Burgundy' between watching this twice.  I am really looking forward to next year's 'A Year in Port'!!!

Good price: $12.46 and free Prime shipping.  I've used this style in the past and these Asics shirts are my go to running shirts (much cheaper than Under Armour and Nike and they shrink up less).  Good fabric, breathable, good length so it doesn't end up as a belly shirt after three washes.  Sleeves are also a good length, even in the small (used the long sleeve shirts being a little short on my long arms), also doesn't chafe - unlike my New Balance shirt which sometimes feels like sandpaper rubbing off my nipples...Overall I recommend this and others from this line.  Great value.

The only three drawbacks I noted:  the price is a bit high, the card/ cash holder is not very discreet (could have used a little more material or something else to partially cover it - I feel like I have to be wary of setting it on a table or the bar, even if I'm nearby), and the kickstand - while ingenious in a way, is kind of a disappointment and not at all sturdy.I do recommend this for folks who are travelling light and don't want to carry a wallet or purse but want an ID and a couple of credit cards.  It is durable and it fits on the phone very well.  The texture is good for grip.I didn't lower the rating for the drawbacks because I felt they were minor.  I still prefer my silicone case since it is very low profile - but this is a great case to use in those instances where I don't want to take a separate wallet but need a phone.  Parties, the gym, the beach, the pool, etc...

If you aren't trying to take this book too seriously, then you'll have a blast.  Mathew Inman (aka The Oatmeal) illustrates much of this book.  It has a lot of fun infographics and charts but it is not a reference book.  For that you would want to read 'Uncommon Grounds' all 800+ pages.For a 100 page, cutely drawn, fun little 'coffee table' book this is a winner.  It's selling for under $10 and well worth it.

This is a good Bluetooth headset.  The sound is very good.  But the four star rating is due to the fact that this really is just a slight redesign of the previous generation model and doesn't offer anything dramatically improved for those who already have the HBS 730.  If you already have the 730, then this version is probably not enough of an upgrade to warrant a purchase.  If you do not have a previous generation version, then this is a very good, high quality headset that is ergonomic, comfortable, and easy to use.

Runs a little big, but not big enough to be considered a size up.  More than enough room to add a layer underneath without looking like a stuffed doll.There are a few little details which make this very nice and attractive.  There are two seams down the side which are placed very nicely to help keep the fitted shape and give an appealing, slim look.  Two seams down the front accomplish the same while providing reinforcing, especially when the jacket is unzipped.The entire jacket and hood is lined with a soft, durable felt except the sleeves which have a soft mesh-like liner.  It is perfect for colder days and evenings, probably recommended in the 20 to 50 F range.  It is water resistant as well.  The collar is high and the hood pulls nicely low creating a nice barrier from the elements including wind and rain.  There are two zippered outside pockets and two inside open pockets as well.Features an adjustable hood which has a 3 piece design and looks good when worn up.  The 2" droptail hem has a drawcord to prevent rising up.  Purchased 2/4/2015 from Amazon directly with an automatic promotion for $63.  A steal for Merrell quality.

Season 4 had some ups and downs.  Most of what bothered me was particular characters acting out of character (it happened with Tom, Granthom, Mary, and others).  This season sticks true to the characters and tones down the 'soap opera' style of storytelling from the previous season.  The only big dramatic event is the investigation into the death of Mr. Green (which gets old quickly, but it comes in spurts here and there, so it's not too disruptive).The main things we see in this season (no major spoilers) are things such as the planning and erection of a monument to the soldiers killed in the Great War, Tom's struggles with his lifestyle and views and his acceptance of his 'family' at Downton, Daisy trying to get an education (you go girl!), and Mrs. Crawly finding not one, but two interested suitors!  Mary has her usual ups and downs with the 'dating scene' but they are more entertaining in this season.  Mrs. Patmore, Carson and Mrs. Hughes all speculate on real estate investment while Molesly quiety pursues a love interest while showing he's quite the scholar (in a sense!).  Rose pursues marriage and this story dominates more of the 5th season than others.  And I for one love the 'new' Rose - much more down to earth and loyal to the family than before.I think it boils down to the writers going for what is best for the wonderful characters they created as opposed to squeezing in every little bit of history of the time that they could (such as in four).  The writing is top notch and I am happy to say this is probably my favorite season of all.  And a little something happens at the very end of this season which I have been waiting and hoping for since the very beginning!!!!!!

We purchased this due to an employee recommendation at Guardian Games in Portland, Oregon.  Big hug guys for the great recommendation!!!The very first thing one should note is the designer of this game: Reiner Knizia (Ph.D in Mathematics).  He has designed such terrific games as Lost Cities, Samurai, Tigris and Euphrates, and many more.  Every game he designed which I have played combine a wonderful mix of accessibility and long term strategy.  Much like Carcassonne, the strategy in these games is not quite obvious at first, but with time, one learns that there is much more to be learned while novices can still play an expert player and present a challenge.This is a two player game.The setup time is minimal (less than 5 minutes).The game time is between 10 and 20 minutes each round.Short learning curve, lots of additional strategies to learn.The game plays out as follows: the players choose their side - Fellowship or Mordor.  Each side has strengths and weaknesses.  The Fellowship wins if Frodo enters Mordor or if no Mordor characters remain.  Mordor wins if Frodo is defeated or if three Mordor players enter the Shire.  The Fellowship character abilities focus on defeating particular Mordor characters or fleeing battle in various ways while the Mordor characters tend to rely on overwhelming strength or additional movement bonuses.Each player takes turns moving a character.  The characters are set in plastic holders so the opponent cannot see which they are until they are engaged.  When an opposing player advances into a realm held by the other player's character a battle ensues.  Unless there is an ability resulting in automatic defeat of another or retreat, combat ensues.  Each player chooses an attack card, reveals it at the same time and players modify battle based on the text or the strength number of the revealed card.  The character with the higher strength wins the battle, though there are cards which end in other results such as Noble Sacrifice which the Fellowship can play to end in defeat for both characters.  The cards are discarded after use.  Play continues until a result ends in a win for either side.What makes this game unique are the variations in character abilities, card abilities and other little factors (such as the Fellowship characters able to use the Anduin River or the Mines of Moria to bypass certain regions).  The Fellowship characters tend to have a bit better luck if they don't press the attack on the forces of Sauron, many abilities are used when defending against attackers and others have skills which defeat certain characters which makes it a bit foolhardy to randomly attack Sauron characters until you know who they are.I typically recommend playing once as each side in a sitting.  There are also a few tweaks which can be used to make the game easier or more challenging including a variant game.  You can leave your discards facing up in a row so the opponent can see which cards you no longer have, or you can discard face down relying on their memory.  Same goes for characters defeated in battle, you can leave them exposed or turn them upside down.There is a lot of strategy and cunning - very similar to chess in a way.  I won once with only two characters left, but my opponent rushed in and attacked Frodo who escaped sideways allowing a straight shot into Mordor but no opposing characters could attack him on the way to Mordor.  Other things can be interesting and fun, such as putting a Mordor character on Caradhras and watching the Fellowship player squirm wondering if it is the Balrog or a different character who doesn't auto-kill anyone passing through Moria.It is simple on the surface, quick and easy to learn, yet complex and fun to play over time.  This isn't a game that gets old quick.  Each game is a little different due to different character placements and different strategies.  I recommend this for players 12 and up, or perhaps some younger players with adult guidance.Fun: A+Learning Curve: B+Setup: A+Replay: AIf you like fun 2 player games check out Rivals for Catan, Race for the Galaxy (incredibly complex), or Samurai (by Knizia also).

This text is a 2014 edition and is up to date through the 2014 exams.  The new 2015 codes have been updated and the exam will have these codes.  This doesn't mean the text is outdated, it just means that one would need to look up the changes from the 2014 to 2015 codes, which is not in itself difficult to do.Since the codes update every year, no text will be truly up to date for more than a few months.  Still this is one of the better Practice Exam texts for the SE Exam for Buildings.

This is a curious product in many ways to me.  It seems to be a more stripped down version of the Vega One, but the actual nutritional benefits for each are very similar.  This product has fewer calories than the Vega One (110 compared to 160), but they have equal amounts of plant based protein (20g).  The Vega One shakes have 6 servings of greens while this has 2 servings.  Vega One is also non-GMO Verified, while this one claims no GMO ingredients but is not verified through the non-GMO Project.I mix them with unsweetened vanilla almond milk (Pacific Foods or 365 Brand).  Typically I use a shaker bottle.These are all very minimal gripes, but what it comes down to is the flavor and quality of the Vega One is better for the price in my humble opinion.  This is a good product though and I do recommend it.

The mascara looks great and is actually not too difficult to apply.  The brush is rather big, so be forewarned.  The main issue is that this volumizing mascara is actually inferior to Bare Minerals volumizing mascara.All being said, it does look good.  Hence the four star review.

This seems like a book which would cover a lot of current Japanese society, and while it does somewhat, I felt the entire book was too heavy on the current political framework of the country.  Politics are important in shaping a society, but this book really spends a bit too much time on the current model including current political parties in power and recent political moves and laws.This would be beneficial to someone really studying Japan as part of a major course of study, or someone interested in international law and politics, but for someone interested in learning a bit more about Japan and the current culture, I recommend Japan: From Samurai to Sony.  It spends a bit of time on history, but with the end result of shaping the modern Japanese society very well.

This text covers sparkling wines from every major wine producing country in the world.  The bulk of the text does cover Champagne, and there are large sections devoted to Sekt, Cava, and Italian sparkling wine (Franciacorta, Asti, etc...).  The text has a broad overview of sparkling wine production, then each section has a preface with information pertaining to said region.  Within the regions, the text has individual producer entries.While this isn't something that one would necessarily need for passing WSET or CMS exams, it is a handy reference for broadening knowledge of the producers of sparkling wines.  Each entry also has a score indicating quality and potential.  Champagne houses seem to have the edge, which is natural, but the authors have given some good scores to producers outside the classic region, though with a lower overall average.  And while many folks may agree or disagree with the scores, it nonetheless makes for a good barometer for those navigating the thousands of producers in this book.Also of note, Champagne producers are listed with the type of establishment they operate: RM, NM, and so on.  This can help readers determine which producers grow their own grapes and which purchase grapes (though it is generally not a quality indicator).If you have someone who loves Champagne and gets really geeky about individual producers, then this is a great gift idea.  It can be quite technical, but the information is heavily researched and well laid out.  For those more interested in the drink but not the technical information, there are some books which discuss more of the history and have less technical information.

I have researched this brand and from what I can tell they are accurate in their claim that they do not use any additives or concentrates.  They do pasteurize the product when in can for up to 5 minutes at 120 Celsius.  There is also no guarantee that this is organic either.But compared to the mass market, secret scam brands Zico (Coca Cola), Vita-Coco (Anheuser Busch), Naked (Pepsi), O.N.E. (Pepsi), these guys seem to be at least open and honest about their product.  C2O at least seems to be a startup based out of Long Beach, California and they seem to be a local minded company, which is refreshing in a market being dominated by a few big brands with deep pockets.  Other brands like Goya, don't even make an effort to hide their production being from concentrate, inorganic, and with added sugar.The main dietary factors to note: 12g sugar and 50 calories per serving with 2 servings per can.Overall this is a bit sweeter than I would like, but it has a very pleasant taste.  I would recommend the high quality organic brands if you can find them, but if you cannot locate one of the better brands, C2O is better than the aforementioned brands.  I would also recommend Munkijo, Taste Nirvana, and Amy and Brian for national brands (these available Amazon and Whole Foods) and the 365 brand at Whole Foods as a good middle of the road option.

If End of Eternity 1 left you feeling hot for a sequel, then End of Eternity 2 is the answer to your prayer, although Im somewhat on the fence about how satisfying it really is. Because, as you may see, author Loretta Lost has this uncanny ability to craft a story that keeps you wanting for morethis second book will only want you to crave for Book 3and I mean that in the best way.In this instalment, Carmen takes the path of self-discovery, vis--vis discovering things about her husband and his motives and reasons for leaving the world so tragically. Carmens emotional unravelling is not easy to behold, especially with the twists and turns the author tosses in her path. But like a trainwreck, you cannot turn your eyes from heryou will want to walk beside Carmen as she wends her way around the minefield that is her husbands past, and how it haunts her present and puts storm clouds over her future.A sequel that must not be missed, End of Eternity 2 is one of those books that will deeply emotionally resonate with you, regardless of what kind of relationship youre in now. Its contemporary romance that is pregnant with meaningpun intendedand you will want to sink your teeth in this tale.

Three books. Three books that will compel you to stay curled up in a corner, panting like a cat in heat. Olivia Nobles Club Luxe Boxed Set is oh so satisfying!Victoria Chase is one hot vixen with brains. As a Chicago reporter (who knew reporters could be this hot?), shes following up on rumors concerning an underground billionaires club called Club Luxe, where the wealthy elite engage in the kind of affairs that can only be best described as wanton. But to get the scoop, Victoria must put everything on the line to get inside the clubthats when everything unravels as she meets Malcolm Cage. Victorias sense of journalistic integrity is put to the test as Malcom turns her knees into rubber and her journalistic mission into a wild, passionate romp.Its a dizzying rollercoaster ride, I tell you. You will not be able to peel your eyes off reading these three books, each can be enjoyed on its own, but still much more enjoyable to read in a series. The stakes are set higher, the antes upped, from the Private Room, to Secrets Exposed, to Deadly Lusteach book a well-crafted, breath-taking tale of passion pushed to its limits. But all three in a single deal? Must not be missed. Get a copy.

This latest instalment in the I, Human series is definitely a significant step up in the tension. Having read and savoured the previous book, I am very familiar with the characters and the sense of sinister danger that simmers just underneath their interactions.In the Malevolence of Evil, there is a nagging sense of suspicionfrom Scrollos the homo superior to the darkness that seems to overcoat the universeor at least, that part of the universe that the Veda explores. Because Scrollos presence is utterly suspicious, the Captain and the crew, despite their grudging tolerance for Scrollos presence, must try to work things out despite their fear of betrayal (is Scrollos a Trojan horse sent by homo superiors?). Moreover, aside from this political intrigue and the Damoclean Sword that seems to hang above the heads of Captain Magnusson and the crew, author Vito Veii even manages to slip in an intriguing sub-plot: the ship Vedas computers have growing feelings for the Captain.There is a lot of expansive exploration that any hardcore science fiction fan will love. What I like about the authors writing stylewhich others seem to disparageis his narratives preference for the slow burnthere are many areas in this and the previous book that palpably remind you of those moments in Kubricks 2001: A Space Odyssey when nothing seems to be happening and the only sound you hear is the breathing of the desperate astronauts who are trying to fix the ship. In this book, the minimalism (like a space-age version of Hemingways) can often be misunderstood, but it hits the right spot for those who actually understand it.Overall, an awesome sequel to what is perhaps destined to be a science fiction classic. I, Human: the Malevolence of Evil must be read slowly to appreciate the full spectrum of its literary power. Highly recommended.

Whenever I read a JC Ryan book, I keep thinking about the visualshow would this scene or so look in HD or even 3D. Sure, the budget would run to a hundred million dollars, but from the 10th Cycle to The Skywalkers, it would be all worth it.Having said that, the release of JC Ryans latest book, The Skywalkers, was met with a great amount of anticipation. I was not disappointed, because right at the get go, the mere mention of the Prophet got my juices flowingits not long before I lost track of time reading and stopping my heart from lurching for the sake of the Rossler Foundations team. Theres quite an intense amount of fun and the integrated verisimilitude made even the books most astounding technology feel as real as the smartphone youre holding.Moreover, the Skywalkers ending presents a cliffhanger that leaves your jaws dropped on the floor, and it could either be good or bad: it would be GOOD if the next JC Ryan book that follows this is released as soon as possible, like TODAY; bad if the sequel takes several months to arrive and the excitement created by The Skywalkers ending dissipates and deteriorates into frustration. Im not a huge fan of cliffhangers, but I dont really dislike them, either: its one of those literary devices than can add more fun in the whole reading experience.  But in the long runin the future when readers could buy a boxed set of JC Ryans Rossler Foundation books, which might include The Skywalkers and its immediate sequelthen the said ending wouldnt bother us and would even feel like just the right ingredient stirred into the pot at the exact crucial moment.The Skywalkers is an enjoyable bookit continues the Rossler Foundations uncanny ability to invite us to wonder about those mysterious unanswered questions and could-have-beens, but it also never loses its action-y and edge-of-your-seat thrill. Theres never a boring moment reading thisit took me a day to finish the book, and that was because I tried prolonging the reading experience by dwelling in certain chapterssuch as the implications mentioned in Chapter 6and when I finally finished reading, it took me a few moments to ponder the fact that Im facing what may be a few months before the next JC Ryan book. But then again, I could just reread the previous books to relive the experience. Fans of well-crafted techno-thrillers must get a copy.

A treasure trove of intellectual and philosophical musings, Yuehai Xiaos Crossing the Seas: a Diary of my Thoughts is perhaps one of the most uplifting books Ive read. Yuehai has a knack for making sense of even the most unfathomable concepts, and he fleshes it out in the simplest ways. The result is a book that will blow your mind away.Crossing the Seas may be unconventional in the sense that it is epistolary in formatthe chapters written as diary entries that span years, starting sometime in 2010. The format, of course, does the book wellit makes the book much easier to read, with Yuehais morsels of wisdom much easier to imbibe on. Yuehais vigorous intellect shines through every pagereading the book is like listening to a wise old man, and you emerge from reading it as if warm rain has gently washed over your soul.Overall, I love Yuehais Crossing the Seas to shreds. I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to take an intellectual shortcutfrom confusion to complete understandingregarding so many of the things that matter in our lives. Order a copy of the bookor better, send this as a Christmas gift to your loved ones and friendswho knows what life you may change and uplift today. A resounding five-star rating, no less.

No matter who or what you are, if youre trying to get the dating scene in LA, Dylan Thrashers book is the best guide there is. Its a brutally honest fleshing out of LAs culture, encompassing its economic and social aspects to zero in on what it takes to find a partner worth keeping and standing by with. But more importantly, the book goes to great lengths in defining its boundarieswhat exactly do you mean when you talk about Los Angeles, and is everything you know about LA truth or myth?Make no mistake, Thrashers discussion of the kinds of people looking for love and everything else in LA is spot-on, if not uncannily, refreshingly poignant. There were quiet moments when I felt bad for all the people who were doing all the wrong things in their desperation to find the right thing. There were moments when Id scratch my head or chuckle or laugh or nod in assent. There were moments when I realized there are passages in this book Id be quoting to friends long in the foreseeable future.Dating in Los Angeles is something you must read even if youre not actively looking for someone. Its an astounding eye-opener, written by someone who comes from both sides of the table. But before you end up despairing over the hopelessness of finding someone real in the vast fakeness of a Hollywood-overshadowed LA, you can take comfort and assurance from Thrashers learned discussion of everythings thats wrong about the whole gameso that the next time you meet someone, you can make better informed decisions. And hopefully less mistakes. A book worth keeping.

Its incredibly amazing how author Loretta Lost has written the Clarity trilogy. Its rare to find an author who writes something that is both beautiful and still leaves you feeling drainedas though for the few hours youre reading her book, youre uncannily in the shoes of Helen Winters, saddled by emotional trauma and her physical disabilities, unable to live a normal life.Clarity 2 immediately follows in the hot wake of the previous bookif youre like me who read it and couldnt move on from the cleverly crafted cliffhanger, then reading Clarity 2 is like finding an oasis in the middle of the desert. I was that thirsty. And hungry. And aching. And I consumed Clarity 2 with such fervour, Im still reeling from it.Make no mistakethis is both an easy and hard read. Easy because its essentially a love story blossoming amid difficultif not impossiblecircumstances, and who would not find inspiration in that? Hard because, as Ive said, its not easy to watch Helen recoil from every disappointment, quiver from her fear (real or imagined) of reconnecting with another person, even if its as honest as Liam.Clarity 2 did not disappoint. If youve read the first book, this continuation of Helens story will make the afternoon disappear. Get a copy.

This book is shaking the business world to its very core, and for good reason: it exposes the real dynamics within corporate and even governmental leadership, and shows us why despite monumental failures, nobody was severely punished in the financial disasters that have been unleashed in the world in the past decades or so. If youre like me who have been grumbling about the blessings that are being given to those who are perceived to be less talented or skilful, then read this book and finally get it. And once you understand how it all works, you can proceed to the next step: take advantage of what you learn.I absolutely love how Vandell used a semi-fictional approach in fleshing out the theory with the use of characters (Charles, Dave and Bill). I have met a lot of Dave, Charles and Bill in my life that I found myself nodding in assent as I read the book. This is one of the hallmarks of Vandells workit is never highfaluting, always striving to make everything as plain and simple, yet it never fails to astonish. Even the simple headline how to create your unfair advantage made me do a double-takethese are business principles turned on their heads, and they make sense.This book is an absolute must-readfrom students, to bankers, to managers, to rank-and-file employees. If you want to see how the world is really run, understand the principles that are used by people to create (or simulate) value and indispensability, this is the book for you. Theres no going around it. Get it now. I highly recommend.

Its hard to read My Oil of Joy for your Mourning without occasionally stopping to savor the emotion or to let some of the tears to run down. Author Traci Wooden-Carlisle is amazing at fleshing out these highly emotional moments without departing believability. She is, as she demonstrated in My Beauty for your Ashes, a master in the art of emotional build-up.I could deeply relate with the character Mason the mostlike him, I lost a loved one, and his death changed the trajectory of my life and set me out on a path I never thought Id take. But that is only one aspect of what is very likeable about this novel. The lives of the four main characters interconnect and intersect in such a way that shows you the terrifying complexity and beauty of life and relationships, especially in the context of living with God.A perfect gift for loved ones and friends, My Oil of Joy for your Mourning can be life-changing for the right person. On top of that, it is indeed an entertaining read.

My head is still spinningThe Britannia Contagion messed up with my brain like no other book canand I mean that in the most positive sense. If theres anything I love most, its historical fiction. But Peter C. Middletons sequel to the much-beloved The Britannia Conspiracy is much more than a simple historical fictionits historical fiction on steroids.Having read Middletons The Britannia Conspiracy, I expected a lot from the sequeland Im delighted to report that I was not disappointed. And morethe language in this second book is much surer, as though the author has found a comfort level with his literary power and gleefully wields it to full satisfaction. The result is a book that will keep you speechless throughout reading itI know, because my mouth was practically hanging open during the hours reading it.I love the juxtaposition of the 1664 era with the present daythe strategy fleshed out the stark differences between the two timelines, yet it also shows you that the human condition remains essentially the samethat life and love and terror strike us in equal measure, regardless of the existence of modern trappings and what-not.If you love the kind of suspense that will literally keep you on the edge of your seat, then get a copy of this book. The Britannia Contagion is a keeper. I highly recommend it to the most discriminating reader.

Ive never read a book as jarring yet so seductive as Loretta Losts End of Eternity. Seriously, try reading even the first few pageswhere Carmen Winters comes home to the gruesome sight of her husband hanging from the chandelierand see if you cant be helplessly drawn in, Especially with the authors powerful sense of juxtaposition: for example, the dead body of her beautiful husband vis--vis the crystals of the chandelier, beauty and madness, structure and insanity placed side-by-side together is just touch.Worse, Carmen is actually pregnant, which only adds to her fears: if her husband suffered from mental problems, would her child also be afflicted with the same mental illnesses? In that context does author Loretta Lost deftly sinews the story, which proves to be a rich ground for complexity when men like Brad or Owen pops up in Carmens life.Whats more, End of Eternity is only the first book of what we learn is a four-part series, so theres more where this story comes from. Highly recommended to fans of contemporary romance, End of Eternity is a deeply entertaining read that will leave you craving for more.

As a long-time fan of Pat Hatts books for children, I am always on the look-out for any new book coming from the author. Needless to say, Theres a Goat on my Boat is a must-haveit has that distinctive Pat Hatt humor that kids and their parents will get.Hatts words have that melodic quality about themit feels like some tongue-in-cheek teasing, but you cant dismiss it because the whole cadence carries meaning. Whats more, the book ends with a delightful surprise, a little lesson on friendship and social harmony that youll love to impart to young readers.The illustrations in Theres a Goat on my Boat are note-worthy, tooI loved the facial expression and the way the illustrator captured the emotion of the main charactereven the little goat drew chuckles and giggles from the kids.Overall, another great addition to your Pat Hatt collectionand a little suggestion: order the paperback version if you can, you will love lending it to as many young readers as possible. Five stars.

Months ago, I had the pleasure to read Mike Kilroys Nine Mealsan intriguing, breath-taking post-apocalyptic yarn that practically grabs you by the throat. Thats why when I found his latest book, Solo, on my book reviewing plate, my expectations are through the roof. And Im happy to report that I was not disappointed.Now a Kindle best-seller, Nine Mealsin hindsightset the stage for readers expectations of what the author can wreak. Solo is more or less in that same threadalthough this one ups the ante even further. In Solo, author Kilroy does what he does bestthrow us into a cesspool of intrigue by deftly selecting what he wants to show, one chapter at a time, until were practically dying to know more. The main characters memory and sense of self is almost non-existentthe few things Solo remembers either buries him deeper in the pit of despair or leaves him more confused. For Solo, life is divided into two places: the Before and the After, with countless snippets of memories and pseudo-memories to add to the muck that is his mind. What aggravates his condition is Tom, his supposed best friend, whose intentions are shadowy and add only to the sense of overall mystery and mischief.Solo reminds me strongly of Christopher Nolans old film, Mementobut only in a certain sense. Kilroys book does not disappointlike always, the author offers something much more beyond the surface thrill as Solo leads us to ask deeper questions about the human condition, what makes us human, and at what point we can be considered inhuman. This book is a highly recommended mind-trip.

I have been a long-time fan of this mysterious author named Holy Ghost WriterI have bought and read a good number of his books in the past, mostly around the theme of the Sultan of Monte Cristo. This book, however, is admittedly different and intriguingly creative: who would have thought about writing an actual ghost story featuring no less than the late great King of Pop himself, then succeeding in making it an enjoyable read?The Afterlife of Michael Jackson is not only for the true hardcore Michael Jackson fanespecially those who have been missing himbut this is also for anyone who likes to read something that enthralls them for a change. The books premise is a million-dollar what-if: What if Michael continues as a spirit in this world, what would he do? The possibilities, although initially might seem endless, are deftly narrowed down by author HGW into a few plausible and entertaining threads. Whats surprising about this story is the stark juxtaposition between Jacksons life and Jacksons supposed after-life: when he was alive, Michael was almost always in the middle of some nasty controversyhe was rarely beyond the glitz and glamour and, ultimately, shallowness of his stardombut now, as a spirit, his mission is to help people find their own miracle.Needless to say, this is a heartwarming and deeply touching book. The Afterlife of Michael Jackson is that kind of book you will love giving out to friends who also love the later pop star. And the great thing about it is we gather that theres a full-length novel the author is currently completinggood news for those of us who liked this book and would love to read more. Five stars, no less!

Having just finished reading Derek Swannsons latest literary offering, let me just toss this out there: if youre looking for an incredibly absorbing page-turner to read during the holidays, then get a copy of The Snowden Avalanche. And Im pretty confident that anyoneregardless of age or genderwill simply love this book.The Snowden Avalanche could not be more relevant in our day and agein the wake of the real-life leak of what the NSA has been doing, the issue was just begging to be dramatized and written. And a topic such as this could not be better handled than by a seasoned author like Swannson. In the novel, the author crafts a devilishly absorbing tale, an extrapolation of sorts, of the possible what-ifswhich is much more chilling when you realize the what-ifs are not entirely implausiblethis could be happening right now, as I write this.In the novel, Sabina has one job: to manage the public reputations of the rich and powerful in the wake of the NSA leaks, whose unsavoury secrets (apparently, the richer you are, the uglier your secrets become) have been unceremoniously spilled out into the open. Anyone who has a good sense of understanding Maslows hierarchy of needs will understand how desperately the disgraced rich will want to bring things back to normala fact that the likes of Sabina exploit to such grace and panache that it makes her very wealthy. That is, until she meets that one job that could wring her through the proper meat grinder: billionaire and walking enigma Wes Bramley. But before you toot the horns and declare this is just another formulaic romance, consider this: Wes and Sabina are not gallery cut-outs, but cleverly and intricately rendered characters whose interactionsfrom discussing philosophy to their intellectual and sexual parleyswill make your jaw drop to the floor. And thats only for starters.Moreover, what has struck me deeply and has shaken my to the core of my being (the last time I felt like this was when I first read Alvin Tofflers Future Shock many years ago) is how Swannsons novel made one thing very clear: how even something as privacy could be commoditized, and at such a high price at that, which makes it accessible only to the moneyed few.Now, I have read author Swannsons previous Crash Gordon books and Ive gotten used to the authors distinct way of spinning a good, irresistible yarn, but The Snowden Avalanche represents him upping his ante, so to speak. This is one book that will entertain you from start to finishand its a recommendation I dont give out lightly. Five stars.

Author Brian Barton knows what works in the romance departmenthe can sweep you off your feet even in the first few pages. Hes no stranger to formulahe knows very well how to take it to its most effective fulfilmentyet hes adventurous and audacious enough to pierce through the ceiling of convention. And the result is a deeply engrossing bookBrooklyn Girl Dont Cuddlethat you will love reading on the bus, on the subway, at some beach. You will talk about this book to friends and strangersand heres why.Brooklyn Girls Dont Cuddle is set in New York, a place where finding the right one can be more difficult than sifting through a haystack for that proverbial needle. Nevertheless, youll find music journalist Buzz Vreelander hoping for that very thing. Like Elton John signing in I Want Love, Buzzs desire and longings catapult him to a trajectory that allows him to touch lives and discover a deeper part of himself he didnt know existed. I love how author Brian Barton has created believable characterthese are actual people, you mutter to yourself as you read along, and these are very real problems. I love the comic relief offered by Deke, which counterpoints to a satisfying level Buzzs intentions for the impossible-to-have Radha. Or so it seemsyoull have to read through the chapters to find out. But let me spill out the beans a little more: the twist in the end is surprising, yet deeply emotionally satisfying, like a warm embrace.I dont know, but Brian Barton feels like the male version of Sophie Kinsella, or if Sophie and Nick Hornby (of the Juliet, Naked frame of mind) made love, Barton would be the offspring who guns for filling in the middle genre of this wide gappy expanse we take for granted as romance fiction. Bartons book is a laidback, easy-to-read, and oh-so-satisfying ride on a rollercoaster thats set to run on cruise mode. Let me suffice it to say that Brooklyn Girls Dont Cuddle is a deeply entertaining bookit pushes your buttons in all the right places, at the right time, leaves you hanging for more, then gives you what you want in the endand youre left sitting there feeling good and wondering what just hit you.Theres only one thing Id love to see more: a sequel. Buzz Vreelander is a likeable fellow whose romantic sensibilities emotionally resonate not only with those people living in New York, but everywhere. Brian Barton has written another classic hereI give it five stars. And, I believe, so will you.

JC Ryans new book, The Sword of Cyrus, is as deeply riveting as his previous three thrillersalthough having read (devoured is perhaps the better term) the authors previous books, I get the strong sense that the Rossler Foundation Series just keeps getting better and better. And here I speak as someone who does not make unnecessary high praise lightly. JC Ryans latest book is astonishingly well-crafted, the layers of meaning cleverly interwoven and meticulously built up so that by the time youre reading the last few chapters, it all feels as satisfying as a desperate embrace.In The Sword of Cyrus, author JC Ryan quite cleverly stabs a finger into the open wound of the old tension between the US and Iran. However, Ryan ups the anteand in quite a breath-taking literary fashion at thatby making the threat real and palpableespecially when you have a determined villain who takes his cues from Biblical prophecies. Especially when you have a villain who is in possession of the worlds most powerful, hitherto unimagined weapon: a bomb so small and portable yet so powerful that it can level multiple cities and annihilate countless millions. The target? The American heartland. Now, it is up to the men and women of the Rossler Foundation to counter the threat. If they fail, the consequence is unimaginable.It is worth noting that, like any other good book, the plot of The Sword of Cyrus is driven by an emotional gravity that anyone can relate with. Sure, Dalir Jahandar maybe someone you can easily hate or fear, given the current world events and the rampaging onslaught of a group like the ISIS. But dalir is also coming from a place of incredible loss, and his thirst for revengewhich makes him blind to everything else and sets his path on fireis utterly believable. On the other hand, the Rosslers are awesome, yet vulnerable in certain aspects. And it is this vulnerability that makes Ryans books such a joy to follow and inhabitthese novels literally leave you clutching the edge of your seat.This is the fourth book in the acclaimed Rossler Foundation Series. And these are full-length novels, not one of those novellas others keep on churning for the sake of a quick buck. The qualityand the delicious lengthof Ryans books always make any book he releases such an enjoyable literary treat. And yes, although this is the fourth book in the series, it can stand on its ownyou get a good sense of what the Rossler Foundation is, anyway, and what its agents do. But then again, as a highly recommended modus, I suggest you pick up a copy of the previous books (The Tenth Cycle, Ninth Cycle Antarctica and Genetic Bullets). In any case, youll meet familiar characters (the Rosslers, of course), and a few new intriguing additions that add a deeper dimension to the story.Most importantly, I have said this before and Im saying it again: JC Ryan is a literary alchemist: he has the knack for crafting a blend of archaeological facts and scientific knowledge and transforming them into literary gold. There is not a page wasted in The Sword of Cyrusevery moment as tight and gripping as the next one. Read even the first few pages of The Sword of Cyrus and youll see what I mean.Get a copy. Techno-thriller fans who actually love well-written suspense books that will take you on an unforgettable rideyou will love this book. Definitely a five-star novel.

Theres something about M.K. Theodoratus novel that grabs you at the get-go and compels you to read through, no matter what. Crossings is a tale that hits you where it matters most: the heart. Its a tale that reminds us all that redemption can come from even the unlikeliest of circumstances.At the heart of the story is Ebe Brown, whose burning desire to achieve self-respectsomething he had lost long ago for committing an unforgivable mistakeis beset not only by extraordinary challenges, but also by even the most mundane truths.  For instance, the town where he lives, Crossings, set in a fantasy world called Andor, seems devoted to resisting change. But everything that the locals of Crossings value is thrown in disarray when a group of dog farmers set up their business, sowing disquiet with their disruptive way of life and business, not to mention their dogs. Even at the get-go, Ebe suspects Rabler, the dog farmers main trainer, is hiding something sinisterespecially when questionable events begin happening around town. Worse, despite growing evidence that the dog farmers are up to something bad, the local enforcers could not or would not touch themfor some reason, theyd rather turn a blind eye than heed the complaints of the townsfolk.It is in this scenario that someone like Ebeelderly, unassuming, and not the type youd think to rise to the occasionactually rises to the occasion. But when his initially feeble attemptby asking the help of the herb woman Nanceends up really badly for Nance (despite her powers), Ebe finds himself compelled to throw all that he has on the line just to right this incredible wrong. And there, let me suffice it to say, is the rub: how and why Ebe does what he does in the story, with the help of the towns array of characters, will drop your jaws.Delicately crafted and written by an author who certainly has an uncanny knack for prosody and verisimilitude, Crossings is an entertaining read . if youre looking forward to a weekend curled up in a corner reading a good book, choose this one. Highly recommended!

Whenever I look at a dog, I dont see an animalI see a gentle soul just looking for love and affection and their little place in this cruel world. I have half a dozen dogs, and I know. Thats why Irvin Cannons book, For the Love of Dog Tales hit me where it matters mostat the center of my heart.I found Cannons book right after I finished reading Garth Steins The Art of Racing in the Rain, and I was in that frame of mind in which I need to read more books about dogs, written by a skilful author who has the uncanny ability to get under their skin. And if youre like me who read and loved Steins book, then perhaps its fair to say that you will love For the Love of Dog Tales even bettereven at the risk of comparing apples to oranges, Id still say Cannon has that rare power to make you cryand I mean that in the most positive senseas Cannon weaves each of these stories like they were a giant hand that sweeps you away and throws you into your emotional depths.Its not easy to review a book like this because the emotions get in the way, but let me point out a few important aspects. One, author Cannon has successfully captured the essence of being a dogyou almost see and feel each individual, from Brisk to Robbie, their personalities distinct, their respective issues fleshed out carefully, meticulously, and with more than enough emotional gravitas to leave you teary-eyed. Brisks story, for instance, is enough to compel or move you to keep reading and is simply the perfect opener for the bookit is a tragic-heroic tale that dropped my jaws and helped me recall the many times I observed a similar behaviour in my own dogs. But thats just for startersthis is a full-length book, not a hastily written thing you commonly find these days, and youll soon discover that each of the story will touch your heart in its own wayfrom German Shepherd Helenas story of struggle amid a male-dominated world to Robbie the mutts story of love and compassion.Overall, For the Love of Dog Tales is a book that is simply unforgettable and unputdownable for its depth and scope and the uncanny way the author has given our canine loved ones their voice. If you love dogs, or if you know anyone who loves dogs, read this book or send this as a gifttruly an astonishing literary treat. One caveat: if you easily get teary-eyed, better read this somewhere private. Five solid stars for this one.

Marc Sechhias Aranya is a rare fantasy treat. If youre like me who constantly scoured the virtual bookshelves of Amazon just to find that one great book that will haunt me for daysand they come so far and few betweenthen you understand why Im completely bawled over by a book like this. Fantasy fans will sink their teeth in March Secchias bookand I mean that in the most possible way. If you end up wildly recommending this book to like-minded friends after reading it, then dont say I didnt warn you.Even the first few pages are starkly beautiful and hauntingthere is something so profound about the opening scene, for example, where Aranya watches the oncoming onslaught of Dragonshipsdirigibles from another kingdom whose ruler has one goal in life: to be the boss of everyone else. Aranyas worldthe Kingdom of Immadia, for startersis so sinuously woven, so culturally authentic (its like these people actually exist!) that the suspension of disbelief happens so smoothlygive the first ten pages a chance to drop your jaws, and they will.Secchias writing bears the mark of a seasoned wordsmithhis phraseology, his prosody has none of the occasional awkward turns or the face-palm-inducing verbosity that plague so many other books by new authors. In fact, you feel like youre reading, say, the work of the offspring of Neil Gaiman and Terry Pratchett (if such a hypothetical copulation could make sense)only this ones actually better. Let me suffice it to say that Secchia has created in Aranya a bracingly sturdy character, amid an intriguing gallery of fantastic beings and incredibly nefarious villains.Aranya should be winning a literary award somewhereor optioned by Hollywood. And thank God this is only the first book in a seriesif the next one comes out, I will buy it in a heartbeat. Get a copysee the first few sample chapters and see what Im talking about. Also makes a great gift to fantasy fans. This book fully deserves all the five-star ratings it gets.

Great fantasy novels are difficult to write because even if youre writing about events or characters that never happened or existed, there is still the readers demand for believability and verisimilitude. But Michael Diack, with his Shadows in the Sand, has fulfilled those demands in a flourish: this is a book you will devour and whose sequel(s) you will watch out for. Heres why.Shadows in the Sand is a post-apocalyptic tale about the remnants of mankind who manage to thrive and survive after a devastating cataclysm. And like how human beings lived in the past, this small, vulnerable community of survivors in a city called Nimar live near a water pool, on which they depend on for their meagre nourishment. But the water pool happens to be drying upin a few weeks, the water would be gone. Desperate, the humans send out search or exploration parties everywhere to find an alternative water source, despite their fear that there might not be any. This post-apocalyptic situation sounds familiarbut in Shadows in the Sand, the humans have allies and foes that come from the fantasy genre: elves, trolls, giant insects, mermen and mysterious immortal beings called the Ovites. And if the water problem isnt enough, the humans also face a formidable problem: the murderous onslaught of the Sanghouls, beings whose main mission in life is inflict death. Fortunately for the humans, theyre not alone: an elf prince offers alliance and military helpand a chance to survive the Sanghouls: using the long lost seven stones of light as weapon. Theres only one little problem: as Ive said, the stones have been lost a long time ago, and nobody knows where they are.And thats only for startersas you may realize, this is an epic fantasy tale that shall span multiple books, as indicated by its sheer scope. But if this Book 1 is any indication, then the entire series is set to become a well-loved classic. Author Michael Diack has a way with words that compels you to keep on turning the pages and drops your jaws when you least expect it. He paints a rich, vivid, and evocative backstory that supports the tales present, giving us more than enough emotional gravitas to feel with the main characters.Overall, an exceptional fantasy tale that will delight both fans and nonfans of the genre. Get a copyor send as a gift to like-minded friends. You will love every page of it.

Mendy Hopkins Utopian Hell is provocative, gritty, and deeply entertainingthe author succeeds well in crafting an unforgettable tale around a scourge that even now remains without a clear cure: AIDS. But make no mistake: this book exquisitely written, and will keep you turning the pages for more. Here are the reasons why.As you know, people regarded AIDS in the 1980s as a disease of gay persons, what with the many high-profile deaths of gay celebrities. Nine years ago I saw Tony Kushners Angels in America and that was when I realized the scope and depth of the social implications arising from the disease, striking at the heartland of an otherwise vibrant gay lifestyle. But this book, Utopian Hell, gives the other side of the story: young women contracting the disease at such an inexplicable rate that its only a matter of time until someone clever figures it out.In this picture enters the sultry female detective Sandy Sommers, whose mission is to find out whether there is credence behind the allegation that some shadowy figure is infecting young women. Normally competent and laser-focused, Sandy somewhat struggles between maintain her lovelife with fianc Brad and finding the truthand as you read and as the story ascends toward its gripping conclusion, you cant help but ask the same questions Sandy is asking: can she solve the case without putting her love and her life on the line?Utopian Hell is a deeply satisfying read, a romance that excites us on many levels. It slakes our thirst for mystery, and also for romanceauthor Mendy Hopkins kills these many birds with one stone, so to speak. A must-read, this book will stay with you days after reading it. Get a copyhighly recommended!

I often buy a lot of books about refining ones professional outlook and personal branding, but perhaps Latrice Collins is the only one who has written something so comprehensive and complete, you wont need another book on the subject again. Her The Perfect Fit for Careers book does not only come chockfull with actionable information, its also a joy to read.With this book, you no longer have to find a job blindlyyou will know your true worth, determine what you really want career-wise, and how to go about it. In todays world, there are jobs, and there are careers, in the same way there are workers and there are personal brands. The breathtaking difference between working for a living and enjoying a deeply fulfilling career is defined and fleshed out so clearly in this book, thereby opening your mind and eyes about your real worth as a person with unique abilities, potential, and skillsyou can use this realization to finally get what your heart desires.And when I say this book is incredibly comprehensive, Im not kiddingno stone is left unturned when it comes to getting that dream job. I love the interview section, where the author writes everything you need to know to win that interview, as it contains so many tips and actionable information I have never seen in a book before: youll understand not only what to expect from an interview, but youll also know how to craft a strategy, or how to effectively negotiate to turn the table in your favour.Whats more, the author knows what she writes about: with 25 years of experience in formulating powerful corporate strategies and helping individuals in refining their career goals, Latrice has worked on both sides of the fence, so to speak, and is in possession of a unique perspective thatfortunately for uscan be gleaned from this book.Overall, The Perfect Fit for Careers is an exciting, highly useful, and indispensable book for just about everyone in the world todaydont even start looking for a job without consulting it. Get a copy todayseriously. Or give this as a gift to someone you care about. Five solid stars for this one.

I have read some of Paul Huhns past works, but Ive gotta say The Book of Meaning is the one that struck a deep cord within me. Ever since I encountered Albert Camus works 20 years ago, Ive read and combed through all his works, even the derivative discussions of them. And for a simple reason: Camus was the first writer who struck me in the head with some fascinating, yet uncomfortable, truths about human existence.I have perhaps fleshed out the myth of Sisyphus in half a dozen of my early poems. But Camus aside, Paul Huhns uncanny knack for seamlessly putting these thoughts about meaning from some of my favourite thinkersfrom Camus to Viktor Frankland transform them into a solid, life-changing discussion of where meaning arises is what makes this book a must-read.But most importantly, Paul brings down these otherwise complex philosophies to a level the layman will not only understand, but also deeply feel. In not so many words or pages, the author manages to drive home a powerful discussion of what meaning is in human life, where do we derive it, and how it propels us not only to keep on living, but to live with happiness, contentment, and purpose.A truly groundbreaking work. Seriously, get a copy.

Those who, like me, have read Patrick Hatt's previous books in the series pretty much expects more of the same excitement and thrill. In `A Not so Barren World', just when you think the story could get more interesting, the author exceeds your expectations and drops your jaws--indeed, this new book offers more of the awesome things you've grown to love in the series.It's Jack and Emily again, and this time, they're out on a new adventure, which mainly rests on their one single goal: to return home. But like in previous books, "returning home" is unthinkably so difficult--if seizing the right opportunity to get into Earth's time fraction is hard enough, then the different monsters, political intrigues, the plottings and machinations of various villains thrown into Jack's way make the effort more hellacious--but fun to read! The fascinating thing about this series is how the author deftly manages to shift in between worlds and realities, between science fiction, myths, and fantasy. If you've enjoyed reading how Jack and Emily dodge projectiles from errant knights, dragons, gods and what-have-you, then probably it's fair to say they are meeting the ultimate villain this time: no other than Lucifer himself.So far, the story has built up beautifully for this final confrontation: a battle with the Lord of Hell himself. How Jack and Emily manages to do it depends on the various friends they have earned along the way--because at this point in the tale, there are many--and how they will use all their wit and cunning and the sincerest desire to return home for their son just to defeat the ultimate enemy.Overall, `A Not So barren World' is a gripping tale that readers of all ages will enjoy. It's not only for kids--I'm in my thirties and, heck, I enjoyed this since the first book. As I said in the previous books: get a copy! Or better, read the sample chapters and see what I speak of! Another five-star home-run for author Patrick Hatt for this one.

Before Tony Hustons The big Wig, the last time I laughed so hard in reading a novel was when I first encountered Helen Fieldings Bridget Jones Diary in the late 1990s. So in many respects, Hustons hilarious novel about an overweight guy who only wants the same things we all wantlove, and the ability to eat donuts without gaining more poundsmakes his hero, the endearing Wiggy Higgins, the patron saint of the rest of us. And here Im wondering why hasnt anyone made a movie version of this already?The Big Wig is a literary achievement in many respects. Written with wit and charm, the novel s hero comes off as being utterly real and completely endearing. You root for him because who hasnt struggled with their weight and career dissatisfaction at one point in their lives? Who hasnt hated their boss? You root for Wiggy because who hasnt walked the extra mile just for the love of their life? Wiggy Higginsand here its also important to mention the whole cast of characters that revolve around Wiggy, each of whom is a marvel of character developmentthe big Wig here, is a character who stays with you even long after youve read the book.Let me suffice it to say that I LOVE this book to shredsand Im sure you will, too, if you love a good, funny, and incredibly entertaining book. Read the first few sample chapters and youll see what Im talking about. So get a copythis is such a hit that it will also be an awesome gift to friends and loved ones who can appreciate a great book. Nothing but five solid stars for this one.

If you think famous people have it easy, then youve got another think coming. Valery Satterwhites Winning the Fame Game is mind blowing not only in how it provides proactive, highly effective ways of handling and managing fame and success, but also in how it provides us a stark glimpse behind the curtain of celebrity.Winning the Fame Game is not a book to be trifled with--Valery knows what she speaks ofapparently, her years of counselling celebrities and other high-profile achievers have given her a unique perspective on how it actually works in the real world, and what one can do. This is close to my heart because I have known a lot of celebrities who eventually succumbed to the pressures of fame. But while others fail in handling their success, there are also others who seem to sail by and actually luxuriate in itand apparently, Valerys book spills the secret.Moreover, what I love most about the book is the simple fact that it focuses not on surviving celebrity, but on thriving in itthereby turning what may be a huge constant problem from some into opportunities where you can further grow and develop and stay true to yourself.Overall, this book is a highly accessible (entertaining, even!), enlightening read about the perils of celebrityand how to effectively manage them. The thing is, these days, with the pervasiveness of social media, you dont have to be a celebrity to ever need Valerys bookanyone can suddenly have their fifteen minutes of fame, and some of the luckier (or perhaps more unfortunate) ones can have their fame (or infamy, depending on which side of the fence youre on) last longer than how theyd like it. It should be read not only by celebrities, but anyone who is interested in the deeply intriguing phenomenon of modern famewhich is my way of saying you must get a copyor send this as a gift to friends. Im sure theyll be quite thrilled to read this, as I have.

Monty McClaines book for children, Touch Screen Ted, is one of the most interesting, entertaining books in its genre ever to come out in the past several months. I have often bought books for children, and read them myself, so I know when I encounter something of a keepera book that pushes all the right buttons and even inspires kids to ask intelligent questions. And Touch Screen Ted is that rarity.Touch Screen Ted is about Ted, a construction worker, who one morning on his way to work encounters an astonishing thing: shooting stars. The said shooting stars turn out to be a mysterious rectangular object which modern readers recognize as a touch-screen tablet. But in the context of this story, the said tablet is a Neurocyte, an extra-terrestrial device that has strayed from where it is supposed to be. Ted, unable to figure out the artefact, merely calls it Shinyand from then on treats it as if it were his best friend. And its only the beginningmuch of the storys emotional gravitas, its heart, is unravelled after Shiny arrives. Let me suffice it to say that author Monty McClaine has written something very clever here, crafting a story that engages readers of all ages, while staying true to the books target audience.The authors life-long background in the IT industry obviously informs the storyit reads like a mix of cyberpunk-fantasy-science fiction, resulting in a tale that is as enjoyable to read as it is fascinating. Perhaps it is safe to say that this is only the beginning of Touch Screen Teds adventures, so if the author can maintain or even exceed the excitement in writing the sequels,  I believe we have a series of childrens books worth waiting for. Highly recommended to children aged from 9 to 11 years, Touch Screen Ted deserves a place on that shelf in the family library. Five stars for this one.

A. King Bradleys unforgettable book, Savior is that book Ive been wanting to find and readsomething like Stephen Kings Carrie but in reverse, or at least, a book where the main character actually manages to turn his life aroundsuper-awesomely, at that.Savior is about Adam Reaper, a victim of constant bullying that hes barely getting by. But once he discovers he has incredible powers just lying dormant within him, the table is quickly turned. And like most superpowers, what Adam has is double-edgedsometimes, its so powerful he barely could control its desire for destruction and revenge. But fortunately, Adam can still control it, as the Beatles song goes, with a little help from his friends. But still, nothing is cut and driedI love how author Bradley fleshes out the moral dilemma concerning how Adam uses his powers and how he struggles in choosing what is right over giving in to his powers yearning for revengeand all hell sort of breaks loose when Adams brother is murdered. And thats only for starters.The strange thing about Savior and me finding it deeply engaging is the simple fact that I used to not like these booksI couldnt suspend my disbelief enough to actually buy the plot of a teenaged superhero. But author Bradley has that uncanny knack for human drama, for verisimilitude, thereby succeeding to write something fantastic that feels deeply, utterly truthfulAdam Reaper is an unforgettable character you will root for and deeply care about. You will keep on turning the pages just to find out what happens to him and if he succeeds in what he sets out to do.Let me suffice it to say that I love Savior to shreds that Ill buy the next book in the series in a heartbeat. Get a copyor send this as a gift to like-minded friends. If the author keeps up the excitement, or even ups it, then I cant wait for the rest of the books in this series. Five stars.

Daria Kacies The Calling made my hair stand on ends and actually freaked me outand the last time I felt like this was when watching Insidious or The Conjuring. Which is my way of saying I love this book to shredsand heres why.The Calling wastes no timeit throws you right into the thick of things, with Karens inexplicable experience with knocking on doors and faucets opening on their own.  But thats only for starters, as its a story about a womans path to investigating paranormal phenomena. Lizzy Sterling, because of a good deed, transcends from being a bystander to the paranormal to one who actively has a say in how it unfolds. And even before you hit the middle part of the book, the full meaning of the books titlethe callinghits you majestically, as main character Lizzy Sterling starts acknowledging her destinyto interact with spirits enough to actually help them bridge the gap.I love how author Daria Kacie has meticulously and compellingly sinewed this paranormal mystery tale with more than enough verisimilitude to make it as believable as the person sitting next to you. You feel the terror of the unknown deep in your bones; you also feel that immense relief when understanding finally dawns, as it did with Lizzy and her group.Overall, I love this book and highly recommend it not only to fans of the genre, but also to those who just love a deeply entertaining tale that will keep you on the edge of your seat. This is the book you take to the beach or on the trainit will absorb you and will not let go. Get a copy. A solid five-star rating for this one.

I bought this Kindle book in July of 2012. My first job was in a bakery many moons ago and all my cakes are done from scratch. I am a retired gent and still enjoy baking my own goodies and eating/sharing them. I decided to review the book today because I am doing the Banana Cake. Kroger had a ton of ripe bananas yesterday.I have tried all the recipes in this book but one, the Zucchini cake (just not for me). I must say, the recipes are pretty good. The Orange Cake is my favorite but it took me three times to 'get it right.' If you are comfortable baking, these recipes can be easily adapted to your preferences.If I had one itty bitty complaint, it would be that I wished the author would have listed the ingredients by weight. Also, if you have a convection oven, you should note that these recipes should be adjusted for convection. The times and temps appear to be for a standard oven.I also like to use a lot more vanilla. I love vanilla.Thanks :0)

I like this show and I want to like this show but it is confusing.The shows is done half anf half. Half the shows appear to be from the beginning and the other half appears to start at the end. That means you are watching two different time periods at once. For me, this caused a lot of confusion for the first several episodes.I like the characters but I cannot tell several of the women apart. Yes, I know there is a set of twins. However, because it wasn't clear the show was being presented from two time-points, I spent many episodes thinking there more than one set of twins or women that looked very much alike. Also, one woman (Shelby, the blonde) looks different enough at the beginning and end that you think it is a different woman when it isn't (she appears to age 20 years but it's just a short period of time). Sound confusing? Yep.I see a lot of other reviews discussing plausibility. Well, that is fairly accurate but this pretty much describes most TV today. Apparently everyone, and I mean EVERYONE, in the FBI has dirty secrets.I still have no idea what's happening but I continue to watch it anyway.

I use these with a Sparco marker board to practice cartoons.The tips are great for writing or drawing and don't flatten after a bit of use. The marker lines are neat and crisp. The caps stay on well which keeps the tips moist. The circumference is larger than a pencil but slightly smaller than a Sharpie dry erase.Very pleased with the amount of marker juice in each pen. When they say 'Low Odor' they mean it. I have never noticed an odor.5 stars

I paint, sketch and try to do cartoons. There is a lot of difference in pencil/pen sketching cartoons and using markers.I was wasting a lot of paper and marker ink with paper. The marker board saves on both and it is easy to just erase and start all over.This board is a great size, large enough for several figures but small enough I can hold it easily with one hand or in my lap.So far, the best thing about the board is that it wipes clean, I mean really clean, like brand new clean. None of that blackish gray haze. I also like that the trim around the board seems to be fairly sturdy. I bought one at Walmart and the trim loosened within a few days. As a precaution, I put some Gorilla glue in a few places to help strengthen the trim.I am deducting one star for the marker holder. It just sucks. I put a small rubber band around the outside part and it holds my marker really well now. However, I have to wiggle and push the marker into the holder.The back is just cardboard. The trim and marker holder are white plastic. The marker holder snaps on and off so it can be removed. There is sticky tape in the box but I don't use it. The tape can only be attached to the four corners on the back because the plastic corner tabs on the back are raised above the level of the cardboard.Overall, I would buy it again. I am sketching cartoons now.

I really like these templates. They are thicker than most but sill flexible. They are not flexible enough to wrap around a circular object.I am using these to practice drawing circles and ovals. My circles and ovals were the worst part of my cartooning and someone suggested these. I didn't think they would help but they have helped more than anything else. The other shapes are just handy.They are also thick enough that my cartoon marker does not stain the sides of the template when I trace.Good quality, worth the price. Nothing negative so far.

Usually, I am very critical of a movie in this genre. This movie wasn't bad. I watched it til the end. When I left the room, I paused it to make sure I didn't miss parts. So, that means it had my attention.This movie is about bringing someone (and a dog) back from death and the creepy things that follow.It is well acted, with a decent script/storyline, which makes it a bit better than most in this category. It is also well filmed with special effects that are not overdone nor underdone. Well, in this genre, there is no baseline but the lead actress bordered on over doing it.What makes this movie worth watching? The fact that it isn't bad.Is it worth renting? If you are really bored and you have the money to burn.It is available on Netflix.

I observed this powder being used in a hospital setting on a palliative care patient's left small toe by family members. The toe was gangrenous and staff expected the lower portion of the limb would need to be amputated. Oddly enough, even though the toe fell off on its own, the foot got better and no intervention was needed.I ordered some but never really used it. It has been sitting in my bathroom for almost since April of 2012. I recently got a really bad spider bite. The bite kept looking worse despite medical intervention. It was getting a little more edematous and uglier looking each day. The itching was almost unbearable. Yesterday, there were small blisters and a new spot forming adjacent to the original spot. I decided to use the powder, mixed with white vinegar on it.The itching stopped almost immediately after the clay was placed over the site. I used a lot, very thick. In the middle, I could see where the clay was pulling fluid from my arm. I removed the old clay and put a fresh batch over the site. I was shocked when I removed the first portion. The redness and swelling had considerably decreased. Four hours later, I removed the second application and the site looked even better. There was little drainage noted with the second application.The itching, the horrible, horrible itching has stopped. The site doesn't look anywhere near as ugly. It's still pink and slightly raised but nothing like eight hours ago.Removing the clay did open the small blistered areas (I knew it would). However, after the shower and heavy soap application, the areas appear so much better looking. This is the first positive direction the wound appears to be taking.At present, I am really impressed with the clay. If anything, it has given me temporary relief from the intense itching because I cannot take Benadryl nor any of the H1 antagonists.

This movie was just aired on TV because Disney is promoting a spin-off animated series for the Disney Channel. From the feel and appearance of the movie, this was originally meant for TV, not theaters. It is not a top-notch Disney release.This movie is predictable but fun. It is a teen movie with a few adults in a high school setting. Violence is minimal but the theme is 'good vs evil.' The main kids are the 'evil' kids because their parents are evil.There is a lot of music and singing almost to the point of being too much. The music is kinda soft Disney stuff except for the stadium number (which is the best).I am a 51 year-old man and enjoyed the movie. It was fun and sends a good overall message. Three stars from me is a good rating for this type of movie.

This book is 60 pages on my Kindle Paperwhite. Although it is somewhat short, the information is well presented and covers many areas. It helped me with issues which were causing my cartoons to look awkward. I do not feel the book was too short. It was just right.The info is geared toward drawing basic cartoons, not caricatures. There are areas about defining the faces and elements to make them more specific to people, gender, age, etc. The images are like the ones on the front cover of the book. There are lots of examples on one page with little tips and notes mingled between. There are no huge sections of text.
