The author gives lots of image variations on each topic.The author seems to cover just about everything from gender, faces, hands, clothes, objects, positioning of elements in relation to sex and gender ... and a whole lot more. There are also sections about inanimate objects.Except for the front cover, this book is all black and white. I can see and read everything well on both my Paperwhite and my Kindle Cloud Read. The Cloud Reader on my Chromebook allows me to see the images a bit bigger but the Paperwhite's smaller screen is still easy to view (for me). On my Paperwhite, I only had one image per screen (unlike another reviewer that had two). On my Cloud Reader, I had two images per screen. (one image is like the pic I am posting).My pages turned very quickly with all the graphics and I had no lag at all.There really are a lot of helpful tips in this book and the price is right ... only $2.99. I feel I got a much more than my money's worth.Unless Amazon removes it, I am including one screen shot from a single page on the Cloud Reader so you can get an idea of what the pages look like.

When I have tested these, and others, I found there is almost no consistency in amount nor distance. Every brand  seems to have issues.However, this model definitely has more spray strength. It goes much further than the tiny models.This is a bigger bottle than the keychain models. My jeans are very loose and the bottle isn't too obvious when I am walking but if I sit down, it is very obvious. This size is best suited for a jacket pocket.This model does not have a keyring attachment. It's really too big for a keychain.
For anyone that remembers General Hospital during the Luke and Laura days ...Got this for my elderly mother but I am keeping a copy cause it is such a nice song.

I needed a bedside basket for more than remote controls. However, I do put most of my remotes in here.If the remote is very tall and heavy, the basket can tip if it isn't balanced well. I have six remotes (TV, cable, two projectors, two Rokus) and they all fit.Nice construction, stable and can hold a lot of stuff. However, it is small (pic is a bit deceiving). Note the size: Measures 7.5" x 5.5" deep x 7.5" high at the handle. It also has a wire frame which is a plus.When you get the basket, take it outside and shake it/beat it a little to get the dust fiber bunnies free or your chair/couch/bed will be covered. A good vacuuming will also help. After the initial bunnies are eradicated, new ones don't appear too much.If you need a big basket for a lot of stuff, this is NOT a basket for you. If you need  small basket for a moderate number of items, then this may suit your needs.

They adult coloring books are great. I carefully undo the binding and copy the pages on nicer paper. The book has images printed on both sides so just beware of this if you are using inks that will bleed. I only use my copies and save the originals. You can also enlarge/redude the images.The pages also do well for sketchings. I use them as a reference or on my Huion. You can also scan the pages to a USB and use on a projector for murals.Using high quality art paper, after coloring these can be framed and look great.

I read this book as a child and multiple times since. Miss Marple books are one of the few books I can read again and again. I am a big Christie fan.No spoilers, but if you are a fan of Miss Jane, you will like the book. When I was little, I used to envision Queen Elizabeth as Miss Marple but now, it is always Joan Hickson, the Queen of the Miss Marples.Miss Marple will always get 5 stars from me.

Despite the great cast and excellent performances from each, they were limited by the storyline and writing. I was hoping for much more.The actions sequences are well done. Some of the special effects are nice. However, this movie attempted to jump the bandwagon a bit early. The script was rushed, the story suffered and it seemed too disjointed and lacked a good, cohesive story.I enjoyed it for the action and fun parts.

Yukio's video was very helpful in my decision to purchase this carrier. Locally, nice carriers had an outrageous price. A similar looking model at PetSmart was $95.The only part the video does not show is an actual pet in the carrier. I have a large cat and the size was a concern. Turns out, the size is perfect. In this type of carrier, I want ample size but enough constraint my cat isn't moving around a lot. Lexi can turn-around and reposition herself with ease but she can stand fully and walk (for that, I would use a crate).I have had this almost a year and it has held-up well. I can remove the fleece bottom and toss it is the washer or use a towel instead. A few times I have found the fleece parts in her mouth. It has many access points and plenty of viewing options for both the cat and owner. I can reach inside and hand her a treat without opening the carrier. My cat will drink from a bottle so that helps also.I have found the cat hiding inside, sound asleep, more than once. She likes it.All zippers and handles are well secured. Very sturdy. The carry strap can double as a leash (has a clip on both ends).Happy with purchase, I would buy again.

Some complaints about electrical issues resulting in screen/light stability suggest that using this power adapter may be necessary. I ordered it 'just in case' but I don't need it. My Samsung phone charger and my Kindle charger both work well with my Huion and no screen flashing/flickering occurs.The charger plug has side access in order to avoid stress and damage to the power cord which may result in a shortage. It is two-pronged (not visible in the pic). It appears well made.I

I use this micro set for painting, not nails (I'm a guy). They do great for fine detail.When an art pen is too fine and your smallest brush is too big, these are perfect. Hard to find locally.The clean easily, few strays, easy to trim. Price is right.

Got these on a Lightning Deal special. It's shampoo, body wash and shave solution all in one and it lasts a long time. It doesn't take much to get a good lather.It actually works pretty good for whatever you're washing. The smell isn't flowery so you don't smell all girly. It never bothers my skin nor stings.For the price and performance, it was a great purchase. I would buy again.

If you need a pen with a fine tip that does not bleed nor smear, this is the pen for you. The ink flows smoothly which makes writing easy. I have purchased three dozen and only had one fall apart. Easy click but doesn't click too easy in the pocket. I have never had one bleed through the fabric of my shirt when I accidentally forgot to click it.

Men's undies aren't cheap. I like to wear these while working on the farm. They fit well and remain snug. The material is comfortable. The access portal is worthless. After a dozen or so washings, they get too many snaggs, strays and fuzzies (not lint) and the elastic gets wavy. However, it doesn't affect their usage, it's just cheap looking. These allow me to keep my Sunday Drawers nice looking for special occasions.

I have multiple units of these little sprays stashed around the house and in my vehicles. I also gave units to other family members after Amazon offered them on the Lightning Deals.I tested one and in my opinion, it's a 'one-time deal.' There is a tiny bit in the canister and I would not want to count on this for a second needed use. So, if you use it, just keep spraying til it empties. At best, it went about 10 feet then dropped down to 5 feet quickly.From what I am reading in the other reviews, these canisters do not appear to have a consistent amount nor spray distance.

One of my favorite clutches. I like the chunky size. It the shaft had a textured grip, it would be perfect but I am happy with the multi-planed shaft.Holds and releases pencils well. Has a built-in sharpener. The weight and length make sketching easy.Comes in a nice tin with a kneadable eraser.

High quality sketching pencils. Nice feel and comfortable to use. The weight is a bit heavy which is just perfect for me. Releases and holds lead well. The textured metal grip prevents slippage. Built-in eraser.The pouch is a nice bonus. Definitely worth the extra dollars.

I use this for attaching sketch paper to my Huion. It works well and doesn't tear the paper nor leaves sticky residue on the glass surface. It is also good for attaching sketches on the wall when I am using them for a mural reference.This amount should last a long time.
I use this for sketching. A nice general size.It takes and releases lead well. I like the weight and how it feels in my hand. I can get a good grip and use it for a long time.

So far, the last 5 can openers have all had issues. Either they fall apart or they don't want to open the can.This opener seems sturdy and initiates a cut well but leaves that last bit of top that I must dig out and twist off. I had this same issue with the last opener. No matter what, that last little part just won't cut all the way through.It is easy to clean with a small bottle brush. The bottle opener is a nice plus. It is easy to grip. After a month, no rusted parts but I take good care of my utensils.ETA on 8/26: Where the edges met as the opener was finalizing the cut, I noticed that the initial cut was closer to the edge than the cut nearing it at the end. So, I am tilting the opener on the initial cut away from the can and it almost cutting the lid completely off now. Hope that helps anyone else having this issue.ETA: Although it was cutting much better, I continued to mess with it, using needle nosed pliers, a bastard file and a small rock hammer. I got the two edges much closer then sharpened the blades a little. It is cutting perfectly now. I can cut any lid and it comes off every time, the first time. No twisting. YEAH!
Nice song with typical Amazon quality. Plays well without any imperfections.

I keep these on hand if case I run out of her regular food (Fancy Feast Broths).My cat rarely eats the meat bits but she likes the gravy. The cans open easily. These are typical small can size. No bad smells and good portions.Racoons love it.

High quality sharpeners for my drawing pencils. I have several of these. They are tiny and travel well in my pocket.I like the quality of the cut and the shape of the cut. I feel they help keep breakages to a minimum. The blades can be removed and fined.The sides are rough which makes the bullets easy to grip.

I bought the entire series of these little practice sketches. For shading practice, they work great. I copy and copy/enlarge them for multiple practices. You get six half pencils that are decent quality. I suggest copying on quality sketch paper. Sometimes I enlarge the photo and sometimes I put two on one page.You really should consider a decent clutch, or clutch kit, for the pencils. I bought this model:  Art Alternatives Pocket Clutch Pencil Set

I bought several of these mini sketch kits for practice. I like copying them on nicer paper or using on my Huion. If you copy these, they can be enlarged easily. The pencils are nice quality and will last much longer than the one card.If you want to practice shading, these help.I suggest getting a clutch for the pencils. I believe this is the clutch I bought: Art Alternatives Pocket Clutch Pencil Set

Another great song featuring the voice of Martha Wash. Now that Martha is actually getting some money from these songs, I decided to buy the mp3s. Yes, I am a bit slow but every bit helps.Way to go Martha.
Nice little dance tune with a fast beat. I believe it won an MTV award. Downloaded easily and the mp3 has no flaws. Typical Amazon quality.

This is the best thing to happen to Oreo's in a long time. They are perfect now.For store-bought cookies, Oreos are my favorite. It is hard to beat Oreos and milk but I was always taking them apart to remove most of the middle and making a big mess. No more! Now, there's just the right amount of filling and the wafers are perfectly matched. They seem extra crispy and even tastier.The Original Oreo package is 14.3 ounces, the Thins are 10.1 ounces. However, the Thins have 40 cookies compared to 36 cookies in a normal Original package.Amazon is not providing the nutritional info found on the back of the package. Info found on the back of Original Oreos is for three Oreos but the Thins list the info for 4 Oreos. So, I used Calorie King to adjust the info 'cookie for cookie,' based upon three cookies. Divide by three to get info per single cookie.Original Oreos: (Info for 3 cookies using package info)Calories 160. Calories from fat 60.Fat 7 grams. Saturated fat 2 grams.Total Carbs 25 grams with 14 grams from sugar.Protein 1 gramSodium 135mgOreo Thins: (info for 3 cookies)Calories 106. Calories from fat 41.Fat grams 4.5. Saturated fat 1.5.Total Carbs 15.9 with 9.1 grams from sugar.Protein 0.8 grams.Sodium 72mg.For those of you that like to use Oreos for crusts and toppings, the Thins work in the food processor much better. I don't even need to remove the middle part to avoid clumping. The decreased middle provides just enough cohesion and taste to make them great for recipes.My Walmart has the 10.1 ounce package for $2.98, Walgreens is $3.99 (just bought another bag).

Nice kit. Images can be copied and enlarged. Pencils fit well in my clutch holder. Sharpen nicely with a quality sharpener. Great practice images, especially for shading. Images can be viewed through my Huion.Highly recommend a clutch set. The product I am linking contains a clutch, eraser and sharpener. The sharpener is not the highest quality but they are cheap on Amazon. However, the sharpener on the clutch works fine for this project.Art Alternatives Pocket Clutch Pencil Set
Quality is typical Amazon. No imperfections. Nice song.
Another great song featuring the voice of Martha Wash. Typical Amazon quality and no flaws.

Bryan Cranston and company have turned this series into one of the best TV has to offer. It is intriguing, compelling and at times, quite shocking. Breaking Bad has mesmerized audiences by giving us a glimpse of what a man is willing to do when he feels he has little left to lose in life. Taking the final steps in the right direction, the producers of this show have hit the "nail on the head" with the theme of "The Transformation Of Walt To Heisenberg." We have been able to watch Walter White change before our very eyes into one of TVs most captivating characters and we want to see how it's all gonna end.5 stars all the way.

My sister ordered these, and other flavors, for a kids' party and party favors. We ordered a variety of cream flavors and an extra package of the orange creamsicle.The wrappers were melted into the suckers and the kids ended up tossing them in the trash. We were afraid the kids were going to aspirate the cellophane/plastic wrappers. After the party were able to take the remaining suckers and run them under hot water and remove the wrapper, little by little, bit by bit and it took a very long time. Even then, we adults were still finding bits of plastic.Even when the plastic isn't melted into the lollipops, the wrapper is very difficult to remove. Forget about keeping the wrapper to keep the sucker clean.The 1.1 ounce lollipops are too big for most kids. I find them a bit too large for me (grown man) so I get the 0.38 ounce lollipops in the regular/cream variety bags from Walmart.Once the wrappers were off the lollipops, they tasted great. They always do. Two stars is being generous.

This is a low quality, low budget POV movie that is just painstakingly awful. Oh how I wish I had listened to the other reviewers.The writing and acting make this one of the worst movies I have seen in a while. I cannot think of one scene nor section of the movie that I found interesting. The acting is so bad it is to the point of being cheesy.1 star.

This movie was much better than I expected. It was also much different than I expected. This is a psychological thriller set in the future, on a distant mining outpost with a few Earth scenes.There isn't much spookiness. No big aliens attacking people. No big special effects. However, in my opinion, the writing and acting are well enough to keep you watching, and guessing, til the end.There are plenty of F-bombs. No nudity, no sexual content. Fist fights, guns and knives are the extent of the violence. Some gory and bloody scenes.For this genre, it deserves 4 stars.

I decided to install two mailboxes because I receive so many packages. The construction is solid and all metal. I am very pleased with the mailbox.I was able to drill holes and slice a section to create a very secure locking system.I called the company to ask a question and their customer service was horrible. The woman was a total smartass and very unhelpful. If I had a choice, I would not buy from this company again but the product itself is great.

My cat will at least lick the gravy from any wet cat food I offer her.Not with RR's cat food. She will refuse to eat it. I can remove it and try something else and she will eat it immediately. I just opened up the last container of the RR cat food and once again because she was begging and I was out. She refused to eat it. I had to go to the store.I was hoping she would like it but it was a total waste of money on my cat.

It's a decent movie but nothing special. I really like this genre and was hoping the movie would be better,My biggest issue is with Jeff Bridges (really like him as an actor). He attempted to do an odd voice during the movie and it just didn't work. It was way overdone. Totally ruined his character for me.No real spark with the Seventh Son ...  I can't even remember his name. The actor was lackluster in the role.It shouldn't be your first choice but it is ok. Save it for a rainy day when you have nothing else to watch.

This is a documentary type movie. It seems to be done it parts with occasional narration. It is highly overacted by everyone but I think it is suppose to be that way because it's a 'spoof' type movie. I have no idea if there is a plot, I don't know the characters' names.The film quality, audio, sets and makeup are fine. Most of the costumes are good but some are just silly (not a funny silly).I just finished the movie and I never cracked a smile. I have no idea how it won so many awards. I found parts interesting enough to finish the movie they weren't funny, just oddly interesting.I don't recall any cursing. The nudity scenes had blurring.So why did I give it 3 stars. Because I am a fair person. It's my fault I only relied upon a few reviews and I did not find another trailer before renting so it gets 3 stars. However, two stars are deducted because it really wasn't funny despite being a documentary spoof.

I am 50 years old. My favorite song is "SugarSugar" by the Archies. "I Want You Back" is second. Saturday morning cartoons can influence for life. I remember all the SchoolHouse Rock songs.This Jackson 5 .mp3 is a little better quality than the average Amazon .mp3s. Still not great but good. No bad spots, no static, clear.

I was anxious to watch the new series with David Tennant but it was difficult for me to get through the first episode. I tried watching it several times over several months and finally got through it yesterday. After that, it was a marathon.It takes the eight episodes of season one to solve one murder. They take their time and it is not rushed. However, a lot of season one is not as well done as I had hoped. Tennant overacts his character to the point it is very unrealistic. His partner's actions and words are also unrealistic. Many things happen throughout this series that are just too much of a stretch to believe. It's both the major events and the little things of everyday life ... how people treat each other, their reactions, simple conversations. This makes it impossible to get 'lost' in the series because you start thinking about the acting and writing too many times in each episode. Although it was a mildly interesting 'whodunit' first season, and worth watching for free on Netflix, this is far under par in both writing and acting.One example is a main character stumbling through the police station with a heart condition, falling against a wall and barely remaining conscious while people just stand and stare. In real life, people would be rushing to this person's side and trying to help.Another example, the actions and evidence associated with the father and sister of the victim would never be handled in such a manner by police. It is a joke. Cash, cocaine and whopping lies? The police never press nor fully investigate these things?Another example is the poor hygiene by Tennant throughout the entire season. You wonder, "Does he ever shower or shave?" No boss would ever tolerate such.The reason I don't cite the MAJOR unbelievable things is because they are spoilers. At the end, you will realize this murder should have been solved by the second episode.3 stars is being highly, highly generous to David Tennant. Watch for free on Netflix.
I never expected much from this show but it surprised me. The characters and storyline were fun and interesting.Four good seasons with a great ending.

I so wanted this to work. I wanted to listen to some gifted audible books while driving.Setup was super easy. Turn your radio to a non-used station, insert the plug into the DC receptacle, the 3.5mm (1/8) jack into your device , use the < and > buttons (only two buttons on the device) to go to the same station and start the sound on your device.I tried multiple, multiple stations (pretty much every station). The sound was so low and the quality was so poor, I could barely hear it. I adjust my phone settings, my radio settings, everything I could think to do. With my radio on full volume, I tried other devices, thinking it might be my Samsung Galaxy phone. I was in my Jeep Wrangler, so I tried my Dodge Ram and the same issue.A total disappointment. Returning the item and looking for something else.NOTE: This seller left a comment pretending that the item "not working" wasn't an issue. I emailed them three times and they said I had not sent any previous emails BUT they were replying to my emails. It got to the point I had to ask Amazon to request they stop emailing me because the seller refused to stop after I asked politely.All the 1 star reviews: Believe them.

This antenna worked fairly well for a few months, but now it does nothing and the hard-to-get channels that I originally purchased it for no longer come in. I don't know if it just wore out, but for this price I expected something that would work better and last longer. I'm disappointed.

I'm a huge fan of geek history, and I previously read Isaacson's biography of Steve Jobs, so I was excited when this was published. I really loved this book, with its sweeping, thoughtful history of the whole digital age. I knew a lot of the overall story before I read this, but this book put things in perspective and provided a more comprehensive context than I've ever had before for my understanding of the way the digital age has evolved.Walter Isaacson has an amazing ability to craft highly enjoyable, easy-to-read prose to tell stories that most other authors would struggle to make readable. This is a history book that was as hard to put down as a decent fiction novel. I recommend it to anyone who works in the tech industry or is even a little bit curious about how our world became this way.

This screen cleaning kit was terrible. The cloth is a tiny square of microfiber barely large enough to clean a phone screen, but my main problem with this is the fluid. The bottle comes with a tiny amount of fluid, and promises to leave no streaks. However, this fluid leaves streaks on everything, and requires cleaning with a different fluid and a larger cloth. In other words, screens end up dirtier after using this kit than they were before cleaning.I'd stay away from this kit. There are several better options right here on Amazon.

I really like this case, but I'm still kind of missing the book-cover form factor of the Amazon case that I used to have on my Paperwhite. The origami stand is nice, but it can be cumbersome to use. The magnetic attachment to the Kindle is amazing, and makes removing my Kindle from the case a breeze, although it feels so light and delicate in my hand without the case that I rarely remove it.This case has a similar high quality leather feel to the previous case, and may be even a bit better. It's got substantial weight and feels protective, and I love how awakens my Kindle and puts it to sleep upon opening and closing the cover.The only other thing that's a little bit cumbersome is the power button, which is now located on the back. The button on the back of the case is right over the top of where the button is on the back of the Kindle, and it works well  but if I leave the Kindle with the cover folded flat on the back, or in origami stand mode, long enough for it to auto-shutoff, I have to pull the cover away in order to access the power button. This is not a big deal, but it's a slight annoyance that did not exist when the power button was on the bottom.

This faucet elevates the user interface of my reverse osmosis water system to a whole new level. It's unfortunate that APEC doesn't include a faucet like this by default; the default faucet is of severely poor quality, which tarnishes the perceived value of an otherwise wonderful filtration system. It has a flimsy feel and a plastic on/off lever that feels like it might snap at any moment.But this faucet, for the reasonable price of about $50, completes the package and lends a truly deluxe look and feel to the whole system. The ceramic disc also makes it easy to control the flow. If I want just a drop of water, I can get it by turning the handle just slightly. If you've invested in the APEC RO system this faucet is designed for, it's well worth another $50 to add the faucet that the whole system really ought to come with in the first place.

I've really liked all the Booq products I've ever purchased. This sleeve is no exception. It's a quality-made item, and has a high-end look and feel. The only misgiving I have about it is that it's not very form-fitting. My Macbook Pro Retina does not fill it up. There's not a ton of extra room, but I was expecting a more streamlined fit.Also, I recommend that if you get this sleeve, be mindful when opening it with your computer inside. The zipper opens all the way around, so the sleeve can sit flat, which is a cool feature  but it also makes it easy to drop the computer if you unzip it too far. I dropped my computer at the airport, and fortunately I caught it before it made a solid impact and no damage was sustained. But if you're not used to a sleeve that unzips this completely, that's something worth keeping in mind until you get used to it.

I'd never read The Shining before, so before I read Doctor Sleep, I plowed through The Shining, and my experience of these books back-to-back was amazing. The plot consistency between the two books is incredible, especially considering that The Shining was published in 1977 and Doctor Sleep in 2013. I'm more enamored with King's fantasy/sci-fi flavored works such as The Dark Tower series, and Doctor Sleep seems to be more of that quality than The Shining, which is straight-up horror. There's more light and deeper character development in Doctor Sleep, which sets a nice counter balance to the sheer terror and overwhelming darkness of The Shining. King's maturity as an author shows through.I recommend this book to anyone who likes Stephen King's work, but especially to anyone who prefers the more fantasy-leaning stuff.

I've been a fan of the Kubrick film for years, but I've always been told it was a completely different experience from the book. I'm not a hardcore Stephen King fan, but I have really enjoyed quite a few of his works. I absolutely love the entire Dark Tower series, and I also have enjoyed a few others such as Talisman, It, and 11/2/63. Now, as a result of finally reading The Shining then its sequel, I'm likely to dive into a bit of a Stephen King binge.The Shining is an incredible novel, and I like it all the more since it was written in the 1970s. It is truly a completely different story from that told in Kubrick's film, but I don't want to issue any spoilers so I'm not going to talk about how. But I was riveted all the way through, and I would highly recommend this for anyone who reads King.

These tongs are solidly built, and being dishwasher safe, they're trouble-free. I recommend them. This model could scratch non-stick surfaces, if you're rough with them, but there's a silicone-tipped version available if you need it. I prefer these because the bare stainless tips grip much more reliably. These feel good in the hand, and have a decent amount of heft.

I bought this to replace my 5-year-old Sonicare Series 2 toothbrush, which was still serviceable but could no longer hold a charge for more than a couple of days. This new one is so much better!This model runs more quietly, it's lighter and thinner, it's compatible with a larger selection of toothbrush heads that are better designed and use less landfill-filling plastic. My old model used the screw-on type of heads.This model also has a battery indicator light, a sleek, well-crafted charger base, and a compact carrying case.The lithium-ion battery holds a charge for a very long time, and is part of why this model costs so much and is so light, slim and quiet. As long as this toothbrush lasts anywhere near as long as my old one did, I'm happy to have paid the premium price for everything this model has to offer.The carrying case is made of molded plastic, and I imagine that after a bit of use it will probably fall apart, but they can be bought on Amazon for around $10, so I'm not worried about that. The toothbrush's several modes are useless to me; I just use it to brush my teeth, at full speed with the quad-timer. But for that it works great.I've read reviews by people complaining that some Sonicare models force them to cycle through all the useless modes when turning off the device. That does not happen with this model. The switch turns it on, then turns it off, simply. The different modes are selected using a separate switch. This model also does not shut off automatically after the 2 minutes, which I appreciate because sometimes I want to brush for a little bit longer.One word of caution about the product listing: The product description says this model comes with a charger AND a travel charger. This is not exactly accurate. The travel charger is a minimalist little charger that fits inside of a larger plastic base, which otherwise is hollow. The "non-travel" charger is just the travel charger with an extra plastic covering that has a larger surface with pegs to store a couple of extra toothbrush heads and a space to wind the cord.If you're sharing this with someone and expect to have two complete chargers, you'll be disappointed. When you take the travel charger on a trip, what's left behind is a useless shell that cannot be used to charge anything. So if you leave town for a few weeks and take the travel charger with you, the person staying home with whom you've been sharing will have no way to charge her toothbrush until you return.

This is the first tactical flashlight I've owned, and the usability, brightness and build quality are awesome. I like the tail button on/off switch, which remembers the previous setting. The front button, which switches between modes, is a little bit hard to find, even with the light turned on, but it's not as critical to be able to find it in complete darkness like the on/off switch is, so I think this design approach is best. I can always grab the light and turn it on in an instant, and if I fumble around for a second adjusting the brightness or activating the strobe, it's okay. I'm not a paramilitary type who will use this for attacking bunkers; I'm just a nerd who likes camping and backpacking with reliable gear.I previously owned one of the Streamlight flashlights, which I unfortunately lost, and when I started shopping for a replacement my research led me to this one. I think it would be unfair to compare the two, since this light is in a different class than the Streamlight I owned, and costs more than twice as much. But I'm very happy so far with my purchase.

This pouch, for the price, seems pretty well built. It doesn't fit my iPhone 6 Plus like a glove, but it certainly fits, with its case on. I use this when strapped into my backpack, which renders my usual belt holster unusable. It is a bit of a hassle to whip the phone in and out, but that's the point. The phone is not going to fall out of this case on its own.I may find other uses for this little pouch. I'm the kind of person who doesn't think it's really possible to have too many modular carrying cases.

I bought the Loopy Slim directly from Loopy upon the recommendation of a friend, and it was pretty good, but did not seem as protective as I would have liked. At the time, the Loopy Vibe, which is a bit thicker and more protective, was not on the market yet. Loopy offered me the Vibe at a steep discount when it became available, since I had just purchased the Slim.I have an iPhone 6 Plus, and it's pretty huge and heavy. I got the Loopy Slim because I didn't like how huge my previous case made my phone. It seemed to double the weight and size. The Loopy Vibe is less chunky than my previous case, but it's still pretty heavy compared to the Slim. But that's the price to pay for better protection, I suppose. I might switch back at some point, but for now I do like having all four edges of my phone covered.The lip around the front edge still is not big enough to really place the phone on its face and feel safe about it, especially with the tempered glass screen protector that Loopy threw in to sweeten the deal. I might at some point remove the screen protector and go back to the Slim just to keep things light and thin, but for now I'm happy with the Vibe.The other drawback to the Vibe is that it's shiny plastic on the back, which collects fingerprints and shows scratches pretty badly. I don't beat on my phone, but the case already looks very scratched up, and I think the shiny approach is a design flaw. I'm not really that picky about how my phone case looks, but it would be silly to think that it will retain its shiny exterior for very long. The Slim has a matte finish, which is another reason I might at some point risk less protection and switch back.

I don't generally listen when people say to order a product a full sizer larger, but for these I should have. They were so ridiculously undersized that I couldn't even get them onto my body. I returned them for a size larger, and the larger ones are now my favorite bike shorts.

These tips changed my ailing, overpriced Apple in-ear phones into something wonderful. The default silicone tips that came with the phones, which I used and struggled with for several years, started to fall out of my ears even worse, and then to fall off the phones. I nearly lost them several times while bicycling, then got these and they changed everything.My phones sound a hundred times better now that they're comfortably anchored into my ears, and these never fall out of my ears. The tips also never all off the phones. I'm so grateful for these simple little wonders that have given a new lease on life to my old phones and made them even better than they were when they were new.

I like the form factor, weight and quality of this cage over all the other ones I've tried. I've had an embarrassing number of water bottles and cages over the years, but this is the one I'm finally really satisfied with, and I recommend it. It has yet to drop a bottle, even over ridiculous bumps, and it's still easy enough to pull out the bottle and put it back while cruising down the road.

This bottle is the best bicycle water bottle I've ever used. It's dishwasher safe, so when it gets nasty I can just pop it in the dishwasher and make it like new. The plastic it's made of doesn't seem to leech all sorts of nasty flavors and chemicals into my water the way other bottles do, even in the heat of the Arizona desert. And the lid actually stays closed when it's closed, and doesn't leak.I've tried dozens of bike water bottles over the years, even stainless steel ones, and this one is by far the best I've ever used. I now have two of them.

This modest little item changed the whole quality of flow from my kitchen sink faucet from a nasty, unfocused spray to a strong, clean flow. I got a cheap faucet from Lowes, and the aerator it came with was just terrible. Once I added this, the stream of water changed to something I would expect from a faucet three times more expensive.

I haven't used a lot of salad spinners, and I even thought they were pretty silly until a lengthy conversation with a farmer at the local farmer's market convinced me otherwise. This one gets the top reviews, and I agree that it's probably the best available, but it still has kind of a cheapish feel to it, and it doesn't spin very fast. Most of the water gets out if I don't pack it too full, but for all the hype and the price I kind of hoped for something better.

I purchased this after a friend gave me a Premiere RO filter system that came out of this house after he moved into an apartment, and I struggled with the installation for a few days. The Premiere system seemed cheap, and things were broken just from a year's worth of use in my friend's house. I did some research and decided to try the APEC. I installed it myself, and it wasn't difficult even though I'm just barely "handy." The water it provides is clean, delicious, and seems even better than the finest local bottled RO and distilled water.I still can't believe I don't have to purchase and haul huge bottles of water home any more. One thing I will note though is that the default faucet that comes with this system seems cheap and feels like it will likely wear out very quickly. It has a plastic handle, and is either on or off. I recommend splurging for the $45 upgrade with the ceramic valve. It's well worth it, and the upgraded APEC faucet seems more in line with the quality of the rest of the system. I think if APEC just included that faucet outright and raised the base price by $50 it would be a smart move.

I love this jersey. When the two Primal Wear jerseys I have now start to wear out, I'll buy more. The elastic pockets hold everything I need for 20-40 mile rides (and probably more, when I get conditioned enough for more), and the quality feels solid. The design and print is just awesome. I found these after an exhaustive search for skeleton bike jerseys, since I'm a sucker for skeleton print clothing. This one is just by far the finest I've ever seen.

This is the first bicycle jersey I've ever bought, and I just love it! Obviously, the design is eye-catching, and elicits some laughs and grins from passers by. But the quality is high, and I expect to get more than a year's use out of it. The colors and print are super detailed, and the elastic in the pockets feels durable and holds a surprising amount of stuff snugly to my back. I have been compared to Slim Goodbody, which is a little bit creepy, but that's okay because really it's just hilarious.

This little multi-tool has already saved my butt a handful of times while cycling with minimal baggage: When I first got clipless pedals, they needed to be adjusted on the fly, and this tool made simple work of it; my commuter rack came loose, and this tool was there to help me tighten it; I swapped out my pedals for flats on the road, and this tool made it happen. It has just the right combo of allen wrenches and other tools for most bicyclist needs, and it's light and tiny and seems to be well built.

This lightweight, quality keyboard is the favorite of all my colleagues and me. It fits in a tiny laptop bag with my 13" MacBook Pro, and the keys feel just slightly better than the keys built into the Mac. The backlight is nice, and the tactile response is surprisingly good for such a light, small keyboard. I use a Code Keyboard with old school switches in the office, but when I travel, this is the best little keyboard I've ever used. It's also handy for connecting to other devices on the fly. I highly recommend it.

I'm a power user of Mac products, and this is by far the best portable drive I've ever encountered. The 7200 rpm speed and USB 3 connection make all the difference, and this drive is of a high quality build. It's very lightweight and slim. After having all sorts of weird trouble just basically formatting several Seagate portable drives, it was a delight to finally find a drive that doesn't have bare metal incompatibility problems with the Mac OS at a hardware level, as a lot of the more generic drives seem to. I formatted this one to HFS+ without a hitch, and it's been reliably hauling around my files for months.

This simple, inexpensive little case is perfect for my G-Technology G-DRIVE mobile 1TB USB 3.0 7200 RPM External Drive. The drive fits snugly into the case, with no room to spare, and it protects the drive. There isn't really any padding, so I wouldn't want to throw the drive around, but that also means the drive in the case is slim and light. I toss it in my pannier bags on my commuter bicycle and have never had a problem.

I bought these after first buying and sending back the Momentum on-ear model, and there's a world of difference between the two.These phones are just wonderful! The build quality is far higher than that of the next model down, and they fit and sound better. The details, such as the plugs on the cables and the carrying case, also show top attention to detail in the quality.Also, these phones come with a quarter-inch adapter that works with the iPhone cable, which is important. The iPhone cable, because of the way it's wired to work with the built-in mic and controls, does not work with a standard quarter-inch adapter, and the on-ear phones didn't come with one. These phones come with a specially-crafted quarter-inch adapter that works perfectly. I need this when I'm listening via my recording studio audio interface or my headphone exension cord.These phones are definitely optimized for listening pleasure, not for studio recording. But they're not advertised as reference studio phones, so anyone is expecting them to be that maybe hasn't been paying attention. But I thought I'd toss that into my review as a reminder.I don't think you can go wrong with these phones. I've never purchased headphones for more than $300, so I have no frame of reference to compare these with some of the extremely high-priced audiophile phones out there, but that would be an unfair comparison anyway. For this price bracket, I don't think better phones can be found.

I ended up sending these back and getting the more expensive Momentum over-ear headphones instead.These on-ear phones were very nice to look at, and had a pretty solid build quality. But they pinched my head badly, and hurt my ears after less than an hour of wear. I tried genly bending the steel to make them pinch less, but if I bent it any further the phones would stop sealing against my ears and the phones would stop working. This design just doesn't fit my head. I don't have a particularly huge head, but I've been told it's a bit long, or tall, so that might be the problem.Anyway, after I got these I ran into a friend who had the over-ear model, and showed them to me. After the comparison, I decided it was worth ponying up the extra cash to get the better phones, which are just awesome. The build quality, sound quality, and fit of the more expensive phones is so much better than these that it's hard to believe. I'm so glad I didn't settle.
It does seem a bit pricey, but I've actually had other adapters like this crap out somehow over the years. I expect this one to last.

I ended up sending these back. I bought them before doing ample research, based on all the positive reviews and knowing for certain that I wanted Ortlieb panniers.But for just a little bit more money, the Ortlieb Back-roller Classic is a far better buy. Here are features that are missing from this pannier that the Classic includes:* Buckles with straps that enable closing the panniers more quickly and easily across the top for quick access when using as a commuter and when total waterproofing is not as critical (I live in the desert).* Compression straps that double as carrying handles when toting the bags around off-bike. Again, for commuters, this is pretty important. The City model does not have any straps anywhere, although a strap can be purchased as an add-on. But the price of a single strap is more than the difference between the price of the City and the Classic.* Buckles that are opposite each other so that the panniers can be attached to each other off-bike to make them into one big blog of baggage. Again, for commuting I've found this invaluable.* Inner pouches, with a large, flat pocket and a small zipper pocket. These are very handy for keeping wallet, keys, sunglasses and so forth easy at reach, especially since my cycling shorts have no pockets. The City has one big cavernous space in it.Otherwise, the two models of panniers are basically the same. But these differences are pretty important to me. I'm using the bags primarily for urban commuting, but I can imagine the same features would be just as important for long-distance cyclists. I just don't think it makes sense, when buying a top-of-the-line set of panniers like this, to save $20 or so just to compromise this much. I wouldn't be surprised if Ortlieb discontinued the City at some point because it's not really cheap enough to be worth all the missing features. Had I known more clearly about all this in the first place, I wouldn't have bought the City.I just love the Classic, but I ended up getting a better deal elsewhere, so I haven't writtten an Amazon review of that product.

The gently provocative title of this book - Sleeping Embers of an Ordinary Mind - persuaded me to choose this as my Kindle First offering as midnight struck and November began. Anne Charnocks adept weaving of the lives of three singular souls cost me most of a nights sleep but repaid those hours with glimpses of three singular souls in a tale threaded with Renaissance art, sci-fi, and the significance of family history.Antonia, Toni, and Toniah: Three young women, each with an inner core strengthened by an earlier challenge, and each with a compelling perspective on life and a slice of art  a way of seeing.The real Antonia Uccello lived and breathed in 15th-century Florence, and Charnock compellingly imagines how her father (a painter still known today) nurtured his childs gift of vision, and her understanding of perspective, color and painting.Charnocks two fictional characters seem equally real. Toni, a teen in contemporary times, invokes her vision with fabric trims and happenstance spottings of found art in everyday places.Meanwhile, Toniah hails from the year 2113, and is about a decade older than Antonia and Toni. With her freshly minted doctorate in art history and her ability to spot connections and understand context, Toniah is the most complex character of the three. Some of this is due to her age, but she also is enriched by a family heritage that unfolds during the course of the book.Charnock skillfully builds her story a vignette at a time, with chapters alternating among her three protagonists. Pacing is easy and fluid, and we are able to draw inferences and insights based on earlier elements in the book - earlier in terms of time periods as well as book chapters. You may well find yourself pausing to reflect on such notions as the stickiness of success - whether something from our lives outlasts us and takes on its own reputation thanks to a happenstance of traction.In the end, this is a beautifully imagined and carefully structured story that pays homage to the visual and the metaphysical. It is warm and genuine without being self-important (early hints of this include sidewalk sap and a nod to Dr. Who). Its closing chapters demand inference,  reflection and rereading.

Kathleen Ernst puts her young readers front and center in Catch the Wind, a choose-your-pathway story that melds events of 1812 with those of the present. The two main characters are tweens/young teens facing similar physical and emotional challenges of being without one of their parents in service to their country. This subject is resonant today with our all-volunteer branches of service, as well as frequent activations of various states National Guard troops.The narrators mom will be leaving soon on an eight-month deployment as a shipboard doctor in the U.S. Navy, and the narrator is trying to cope with a host of emotions and concerns. Similarly, her 1812 counterpart and new friend, Caroline Abbott, is dealing with the aftermath of the capture two months earlier of her father by the British.Ernst wisely chooses to use the War of 1812 in her point-counterpoint story, because it is distant enough it is not freighted with the immediacy of emotion of contemporary engagements. Additionally, as materials from the American Girl franchise are known to do, theres a strong, accurate underpinning of historical information, an added benefit for this time period, which likely is unfamiliar territory for many of Ernsts intended readers.At several locations within the book, the reader chooses between two pathways, and follows the story to one of a number of endings. At each ending, a note suggests that the reader turn to a specific page (number provided) to see how the story would play out with different choices.This structure is equally rewarding for avid and struggling/resistant readers. Students at or above grade-level reading might be given 15- or 20-minute chunks of enrichment reading time in class if they have finished other work. The clarity of Ernsts writing is such that struggling readers also will benefit from this book both to build reading skills and as an entry point for content-area reading.The situations and choices posed throughout the book are suitable for the target age group (8+) as independent reading, and a teacher or parent can provide added opportunities for learning by guiding young readers in the development of a glossary of challenging words. My only caution regarding this book in a school environment is for the teacher or librarian to be aware of possible sensitivity on the part of young readers who may have a parent serving overseas.Physically, although this is a soft-cover book, both cover and page stock are durable enough to withstand use by multiple readers in classroom and library settings.

The concept of this soy-and-fruit snack is appealing, but the actual bar is disappointing -- both in taste and content.On taste alone, this Soyjoy Blueberry bar leaves a lot to be desired. While the flavors of blueberries and raisins are identifiable, they are overwhelmed by the weirdly powdery yet sticky consistency of the bar.The fine print on the product label continues the bad news. A third of the calories come from fat -- not horrible for an occasional snack or for a portable energy boost in the midst of strenuous activity, such as a hike. However, 3 of the 6 grams of fat in each bar come from saturated fat, a big disappointment, especially in a 1-ounce snack.Further, a bar positioned as healthful ought to be drawing any necessary sweetness from whole fruit or fruit juice. Not this one. Sugar is the third item in the list of ingredients. It is followed by butter, which is another stumper, given the multitude of other available choices.I tried to like these bars -- after all, I like blueberries and raisins, and I enjoy soy in a variety of preparations. However, by my third try, all I was willing to eat were the few blueberries I could rescue. That experience was a good reminder that trail mix and fruit leather made from dried fruit and fruit juice are satisfying and more healthful choices than this processed product.

Many teen readers devour the quirky and satirical and dystopian. With such teaser phrases as dark comedy and quirky murder mystery that is intricately plotted, I hoped No One Else Can Have You would hook adolescent readers.For all I know, it may. However, the caliber of writing is such that I will not be recommending this book to any reluctant, struggling, or avid readers (the three groups for whom I continually seek quality, age-appropriate writing). The plot has promise but the pacing and story arc are insufficient to sustain any true momentum.Hales satire is blunt and at times awkward. This transparency and visibility actually can be a positive for struggling or reluctant readers, who benefit from the added context. However, the language and situations that pepper this book are such that I cannot recommend this book as a resource for independent or book-club-type reading. To be clear, I have sourced and used everything from ghost stories to murder mysteries in units for adolescents.Adults who are shopping for the adolescents in their lives should plan to read this book themselves first before deciding whether to pass it along. Quirkiness is an approach that resonates with the teens with whom I have worked; unfortunately, even leaving aside my other concerns with this book, I dont think the quirk here is sufficient to carry the book, even for an adult reader.

If you are looking at this dartboard, chances are youre either knowledgeable about the game of darts or looking to improve your game. If you know your stuff, the specs of this board speak for themselves.If youre like me, and are looking for a tool that will help you improve hand-eye coordination and have some fun along the way, a board like this will help you elevate your game.+ Its no-excuses hanging mechanism is straightforward to use, so that your board is at the ready and positioned accurately, even if you have to store it between uses.+ The board itself is made using materials and methods that reduce the disappointment that happens when your dart hits and then falls down (as well as possible damage to the tip of the dart).+ The wires that divide the scoring sections are thinner than the norm, and are shaped in such a way that your chances of hitting wire rather than board are reduced.+ The board is staple-free. This is a biggie for me; for some reason, my darts are drawn to the staples on other boards, so practicing with this board has been a pleasure.With care, this board should last for years. The face of it is designed to minimize the appearance of punctures and the overall construction is such that the board will continue to grip dart points repeatedly. If you keep it mounted, be sure to follow the guidance on repositioning the board regularly.

Imagine for a moment that you have spent 10 years in jail because you blunted the attack of a man determined to harm a childhood friend. You have spent a decade pulling kudzu and drinking coffee brewed from ground acorns, and counting the days until the next time a family member can visit  one person, 15 minutes, every other Sunday.Now imagine the childhood friend is Nat King Cole, and he is repaying your loyalty with his trust, and that he is offering you a new start working for him in Los Angeles, away from the bittersweet memories of Montgomery, Alabama. The wrinkle that drives this story? After a year in Los Angeles and a stint on television, Cole is returning to Montgomery to perform a single concert and wants you by his side. His spoken desire is to conclude an evening that was interrupted 11 years before by violence. What lies beneath is the chance for both of you to find closure for wounds that have been festering for all those years.Author Ravi Howard brings together fact and fiction, stitching them together so delicately that it is difficult to tease apart reality and imagination. Several of the larger elements of the story have roots in history  the Montgomery bus boycott, Coles weekly 15-minute telecast, and the onstage attack (although Howard changes the particulars of the latter to suit his timeline and the creation of the fictional character of Nathaniel Weary).While it seems that Howard is running through a checklist of bigger-picture items he feels he must include, his writing and storytelling are at their best in the smaller moments. He is particularly effective at creating the character of Nathaniel Weary, and fleshing him out slowly, anecdote by anecdote and recollection by recollection.Howard doesnt tell us of Wearys character; rather, he allows the unfolding of quiet moments with his family to illustrate that Weary is a man of principle. Several particularly moving passages occur early on  on the day Weary is released from Kilby, where he has been jailed for 10 years. Tears may tickle the back of your throat as Weary and his father visit the cemetery where Wearys mom is buried. They sip coffee from the familys marriage china, paid for in cash, a piece at a time.Unfortunately, while these smaller moments ring with the clarity of a fingernail on crystal, some of the larger elements impede the story. Its almost as though Howard got tongue-tied when dealing with moments of larger significance, which is especially a shame given his deftness at coaxing out vignettes that bind his readers to his characters.Is this a book worth reading? Id say yes, if only because of the way Howard brings the fictional Nathaniel Weary to life and makes him someone you care about. (If you are a Cole fan, note that he plays only a supporting role in this story.) However, structurally, there are a number of weaknesses, and these are reflected in my final rating. That said, Howard has a beautiful voice, and I look forward to his next book, and may well check out his backlist.

Ive been using this as both a splitter and extender for several months and it has performed in steady, no-nonsense fashion. At this price point, I did not expect svelte looks, and I did anticipate that it might not be engineered for all the pluggings and unpluggings such adapters undergo.Happily, my concerns were unfounded. My various power adapters easily mounted and dismounted. Even more importantly, the business end of this adapter was designed and manufactured carefully enough that I had no issues using this in several vehicles  both the ones I drive regularly, as well as a rental vehicle that had just one adapter port.The splitter easily and securely fits into the cigarette adapter in both my newish car and an older truck, and eases out without a struggle. Between-times it stays put, unlike a more expensive dealer-supplied extender that came with one of our vehicles. While testing and monitoring the unit for this review, I found that it was able to pass through enough power to charge two smallish devices, such as cellphones, as long as both were not in heavy use. While using a map app on one phone, the other device continued to top up, but the charge percentage stayed put on the phone in use. I consider this acceptable, since I have encountered similar performance with a charger that is not sharing power with another device. Thus I mention it so you are aware, but I have not docked any stars for this.I did subtract a star because the section of cable between the power port and the split is inconveniently short, especially if your vehicle has its shift control (manual or automatic) near the center console. That is a common setup, and it is just too close to this splitter's two ports. In addition, I think this situation is contributing to the wear I am beginning to see at the Y-junction, which is disappointing.

If you are considering this multivitamin, chances are you already know the immediate and longer-term benefits of providing your body with a steady supply of vitamins and minerals.If youre like me, you have tried several brands, searching for the multivitamin that provides the broadest array of your daily needs with hopefully the least taste/aftertaste and no lingering negative effects. Over the years, I have found that my body is most likely to tolerate vegetarian capsules, but not all of them are as complete as their non-vegetarian counterparts.After several months use, I can say that the Womens Multi Gold is my new gold standard. Capsules go down (and stay down) smoothly, theres no odd aftertaste, and the amount of Vitamin D3 included means I no longer have to buy a separate bottle of D3 to boost the effectiveness of my daily doses of calcium. A calm tummy also means I am faithful about taking these daily.Im not sure whether my body tolerates these capsules better than other multivitamins because they are made from fruit, vegetables, and herbs, but I do appreciate that the ingredients are organic. When you think about it, a lifelong commitment to taking a daily multivitamin means thousands of doses, and those doses ought to be both healthful and helpful.As to the latter, it is worth noting that the manufacturer has a third-party laboratory test samples of each lot it makes of these vitamins to measure their purity and potency.These vitamins are supplied in amber-colored glass bottles with child-resistant caps, and the lot number and best buy date are printed legibly on the bottom of the bottle. Standard dosage is 3 capsules a day.Note: Initial sample provided by the manufacturer for impartial review.

One of Anna Freeman's characters describes a press of people as being "both terrible and wonderful, like an animal show at which the fences were too thin." This brief simile conveys a hint of the power that awaits you between the covers of The Fair Fight: A Novel.Freeman transports us to 18th-century England, and realistically evokes the period through descriptions, characters' conversations, and even cultural norms. Her research is evident: every archaic phrase I looked up was spot on both for the period and the context.As the title and book description indicate, this is a story of two women boxers. Their stories are told from the points of view of several key characters, with each vantage point providing a different perspective on the women and on key events.Freeman invokes two countervailing methods of bringing these women to life for her readers. One woman, Ruth, appears fully formed as a teenager -- we see her challenges and choices and life's inevitabilities as being formed on bedrock to which we aren't immediately privy. By contrast, Charlotte enters from the wings, and her importance to the story builds along with the development of her personality through a series of events that unfold during the course of the story. Ruth "is," while Charlotte "becomes."The book begins with Ruth's introduction to the ring, when she "comes up to scratch," taking her station for her first fight. Thus, quite literally we see Ruth initially as a fighter, and only in ensuing chapters do other elements of her character take shape. However, we meet Charlotte in a domestic setting, and are immersed in the development of her character in response to internal and external forces. Only after we understand Charlotte do we see the role boxing will play in her life.This is an engrossing, well-crafted tale featuring two resilient women. At 480 pages, it is not a quick read, but it certainly is an engaging one.

What were you reading as a teen? Chances are, at least some of those authors and their works became touchstones in your life, or at the least markers to the teen you were. I was an Isaac Asimov, Ray Bradbury, Dick Francis and Agatha Christie kind of person, because I couldn't quite wrap my mind around short stories ... they felt too demanding.So, before we go any further, let's acknowledge the intellectual rigor embraced by the adolescent editors of this anthology. Short stories are more challenging than they appear -- both to write and to comprehend fully as a reader. It cannot have been a simple turn of events to have combed through heaps of short stories and chosen the fraction of submissions that appear in this collection. The reader's reaction to short stories often is more immediate and visceral than it is to a book, which is fitting, because of the comparative sizes of each.The two unifying components of this anthology are that the stories all were initially published within months of each other, and that they have a noticeable degree of quirkiness. Beyond that, your favorites are likely to be different than mine. To provide just one example, I found the AP story to be a standout, but I haven't seen any of my fellow reviewers mention it. And this illustrates the truism about anthologies ... everyone is sure to gravitate to something, but those "somethings" may well differ.  The fact that this anthology was curated by teens provides readers with the added insight of what this rising generation of readers considers worthwhile.

While the idea of "teaching to the test" is not something that educators at any level like to do, sometimes pragmatism trumps principle -- especially for standardized gatekeeper-type exams for advanced degree programs.When it comes to the GMAT, the multiple sections of the tests call for strategies and tactics tailored to each component -- not unlike the diverse components of the heptathlon. In both cases, effective preparation calls for studying the route, educating yourself on the possible pitfalls and distractions, building stamina and endurance, and becoming attuned to what the judges are seeking. By removing variables and preparing mentally, you provide yourself with ways to clear obstacles from your path and make your test results as competitive as possible.At 747 intensive pages, this book is a single-source preparation manual that encompasses everything from describing the philosophy of the test and how to prepare to practice problems and two full-length sample tests.The authors address how this style of test may impact your mindset, and offer advice on how avoid getting distracted or discouraged.  Particularly helpful is their advice on gauging the "discomfort zone" that is on the upper end of your confidence level in the adaptive sections of the test. They follow this up by explaining how practice and familiarity can help you nudge that upper range higher. "[H]ow well you can recognize and manage your discomfort zone will determine how high your score can go," they note.They provide ways to identify patterns and predictability within the test. In addition, they help you to understand the reasoning behind each section of the test and what measurements each section is gathering. They also address such practical matters as practicing with homemade materials resembling the ones you will be limited to during the test, and replicating test conditions as closely as you can.In addition to generalities such as time management and how scoring is calculated, they provide specific strategies and tactics for each section of the test. They dissect how to identify what is being asked, as well as understanding what sort of answer is desired. This is especially helpful for the essay (AWA) section of the test.The overview of the various sections of the test includes a description of how the adaptive sections play out, since they function differently than other standardized tests you may have taken in the past. The initial questions predict the test-taker's skill level and the testing algorithm fine-tunes that prediction by offering questions at that level, and requiring that the test-taker demonstrate content knowledge by answering several questions correctly before ramping up the difficulty of the questions.Here's an example of how the authors not only provide advice, but explain why it matters. They debunk a number of myths about the GMAT, including the one that maintains you are best off by spending relatively more time on earlier questions. Doing so doesn't necessarily mean you'd get more of them right than you would otherwise, they say, and it may cost you the time you could have used to complete as many of the questions in the section as possible.  They note that the score-calculation algorithm makes it more costly to miss answering a question than it is to answer a question incorrectly.With the publisher's retail price of this book currently at less than 10 percent of the cost of one session of the GMAT, this book is a sound investment if you are able to commit the time to process the strategies and work through the questions over the span of several weeks so that you will be able to reinforce and encode the authors' strategies and tactics. If your prep time is briefer, the book should still help you perform triage, although less effectively than if you had a longer span of time to prepare.

The Hired Man begins as a story of a handyman's life in the small town of Gost, where life is placid and unhurried -- except that it isn't, really. Handyman Duro Kolak makes a low-key entrance as the person who helps the new arrivals who've taken up summer residence in a neighboring house.At first, Kolak seems to be nothing more than an amiable neighbor, wise in the ways of doing much with little, but slowly, slowly, his role as caretaker and conscience and memory-keeper emerges ... at first as if shot through cheesecloth, but later sharpening into razor-edged sharpness.His dramatic foils are new neighbors Laura and her children, Matt and Grace. Laura is froth and superficial, innocent enthusiasm. Matt is nonchalance and disinterest. Grace, his younger sister, is impressionable, determined, and pragmatic -- traits that resonate and harmonize with aspects of Kolak's personality.An old car, a handful of small tiles, and a dinner table are among the touchstones that help tell the story of Kolak and his village. Author Aminatta Forna introduces each of these items with a whisper of foreshadowing, easy at first to blink away and dismiss. But slowly, almost imperceptibly, Forna heightens the underlying tension, tipping you ever so slowly off-balance until you turn each page with anticipatory hesitation and uncertainty, and only notice that your pulse rate is climbing if you pause in your reading.The characters, setting, and pacing of this story are so finely wrought that I refuse to identify any plot points and risk weakening their impact. This story is of such high caliber that it compels uninterrupted focus. It will repay your attention by lingering long after you think you've absorbed the events in its final pages.

When you hear the word archeologist, does the image of Indiana Jones leap to mind? Or perhaps you think of Howard Carter, the English Egyptologist who discovered the tomb of Tutankhamun almost 100 years ago?Not surprisingly, the lives of most modern-day archaeologists are more about research and precision and documentation than about headlines. But, as Marilyn Johnson shows us, modern archaeologists are passionate about documenting humankind's history, often while living and working in challenging conditions.Her profiles of these professionals are captivating and engaging, and foster added appreciation of what their skills have done for our understanding of those who came before.This book is a good choice for anyone from history buffs to armchair travelers.

My face can be a bit sensitive -- my go-to face wash is Cetaphil -- so I tested this cleansing oil by using it on one forearm and leaving it on my skin for quite a while before rinsing. The next morning, that area of my arm still felt smoother and more hydrated than the remaining skin, so I began using this product on my face.The oils are light in consistency and have a slight, muted scent. A fine gloss of oil remains on your skin after use, but there's nothing shiny or sticky. In case you're wondering about the organic fruit acids that Juice has included to help dissolve impurities, I haven't felt any unpleasant after-effects while applying this cleansing oil to my face. After rinsing and drying, my skin does not feel stretched or tight, unlike the sensations I've had with other cleansers. It also gets my face clean: it gets rid of perspiration and such after a warm afternoon's worth of yard work.Although this oil works effectively and rinses cleanly when following the standard instructions, I especially enjoy following Juice's suggested "spa-like cleanse." All you do is apply a few pumps of the product to a warm, moist washcloth, and clean your face in circular motions using the cloth. After you rinse your face and the washcloth with warm water, you cover your face with the clean, damp cloth. It's a relaxing end-of-day ritual.

There is much to appreciate about this book. It is well-plotted and well-paced, and features a strong but imperfect protagonist. At more than 400 pages, it provides the sort of meaty read that eager young readers will appreciate.I was that sort of reader as a child, as were my kids, and a series like this would have captured and retained our interest. If your kids are fans of the author's previous Septimus Heap books, this book should be a home run for them.Unfortunately, there's a mismatch with how this book is being marketed that is likely to disappoint young readers. Although this is billed as "Book One" of a new series, it really is not a standalone work. I'm very disappointed that the author and publisher did not provide a prologue to help readers immerse themselves in the book.In this digital era, it's not too late to give new readers the tools they need: I hope that those involved with this book put together a prologue and host it on the publisher's website and/or release it in PDF or e-reader format. This then could be included in future editions.Thus, my recommendation is split:->Four stars if you are shopping for a Septimus Heap fan.->Two stars if the recipient hasn't read the earlier books -- unless you are getting the backlist, too. If you are, then five shiny stars to you for nurturing your young reader!

One of the enduring ironies of the decades after World War II is how two of America's allies, Russia and China, became her foes. The USSR kept German troops occupied on a second front at great cost. Similarly, China battled Japan in isolation for four years, and still as the war drew to a close in 1945, a weakened China continued to keep more than a million Japanese troops on its soil, preventing them from battling the Allies elsewhere in the Pacific.If we want to understand the seemingly rapid shift in the U.S. government's perception and policies toward China in the watershed year of 1945, we must begin several decades beforehand. Thus, although author Richard Bernstein calls this book China 1945 it by necessity is much larger in scope.Bernstein frames this book as an exploration of how choices the United States made in its relationship with China during a single year sowed the seeds of the harvest we have been reaping ever since. However, before he teases out the events of 1945, Bernstein explores two significant precursors. The first is China's bitter struggles with Japan dating to 1895; the second is the rise of two philosophically different groups, the Kuomintang (KMT) or Nationalists, and the Communist Party of China (CCP).Because of an interest in Japan's history, even before I began reading this book, I was familiar with Japan's quest for expansion. Although I knew some of the details Bernstein covered, he placed them into a more meaningful context than I'd had previously, and one that is essential before exploring the choices during WWII, especially in 1945. I found Bernstein's chronology of Japan's engagements between 1895 and 1937 cogent and detailed, and think that readers with less familiarity will not be at sea.Bernstein provides the same thorough, arms-length approach that makes his analysis of China's relationship with Japan so informative as he explores China's domestic situation and the evolution of its political evolution following the revolution that led to the creation of the Republic of China in 1912.Only after readers have these contextual details firmly at hand does Bernstein begin teasing apart the key fissure lines and combustible events of 1945. Without a full grounding in what went before, for example, it is difficult to comprehend why China was in a "poor and fragile state" -- even before eight years of war waged by poorly outfitted, poorly fed troops, and a death toll of 20 to 30 million. Similarly, Bernstein makes it evident that one of the beneficiaries of Japan's advances on China was the Communist Party of China, led by Mao Zedong.By the middle of 1944, Bernstein posits, Mao and his rival, KMT President Chiang Kai-shek, both believed that the U.S. would defeat Japan. That realization freed them to focus on which of the two sides would win victory in the internal struggle for control of China after the war ended. In this vein, he questions how subsequent events might have enfolded had the U.S. created a cooperative relationship with Mao on par with that it had developed with Chiang.Bernstein maintains this high level of research and inquiry throughout the book, analyzing the policies and actions of a number of key players, both Chinese and American. This information reaches critical mass, so that we readers are prepared to work through the chain of events at war's end, when the CCP notified the U.S., Great Britain, and the Soviet Union that it had earned the authority to accept the surrender of its foes. Not only was the CCP explicitly claiming its right to take possession of the troops, but implicitly laying claim to their weapons and territory.What happened next has echoed for decades, and Bernstein guides us through the unfolding of a host of confusing posturings and events, both directed at the domestic population and for consumption beyond China's borders. To his credit, he provides enough dispassionate information and analysis that we readers are able to evaluate his conclusions from an informed vantage point and formulate our own opinions.

Color Song is a finely wrought story about a young woman's devotion to art.  We meet Giulia, a teenage novice who assists in the painting workshop of a convent in Padua, Italy. Giulia is passionate about the creation of art, and the day we meet her is the day that she discovers she can hear the distinctive bell-like music made by each color of paint.Giulia's story begins in the late 1480s, and author Victoria Strauss is careful to evoke the mannerisms, mores, and atmosphere of the period. In Giulia, she has created a character who is strong and self-guided, while still perceptive enough to feel the self-doubts that teens and young adults hold close to themselves, no matter what the era.At its heart, this is a coming of age story that is draped with the details of life, art and adventure. If you've read the liner notes, you know that Giulia is faced with the choice of remaining at the convent and losing her chance to paint -- or assuming a false identity to stay true to her quest to continue developing her skill as a painter.The plot is just this side of fanciful, but is likely to appeal to its primary audience. The story arc and dialog set a fine pace and atmosphere, and Giulia and most of the supporting characters are well drawn. Passages to do with art are particularly finely evoked, especially those that involve Giulia's singular abilities to hear the colors' songs. The syntax, tone, and quality of writing are excellent throughout.This book is a fine choice for secondary students for independent or classroom "book club" reading.
