The focus on art may make this a good challenge choice for art-minded students who are reluctant readers.**Note: Although this book follows Strauss's "Passion Blue," this book can be read on its own. I did not realize it was a sequel until I was partway through the book, and never felt at a loss.

On September 5, 1978, the leaders of three countries met to discuss peace. They each were coping with political pressures and dissatisfied citizens back home -- people who were more concerned about the immediacy of domestic economic problems than the unlikely prospect for peace between Egypt and Israel.Thirty-six years on, the Camp David Accords developed by Jimmy Carter, Anwar Sadat, and Menachim Begin continue to avert war, but tensions in the Middle East remain. Thus, the insights Lawrence Wright knits together in his chronology of that September not only document a key moment in history, but also have a perennial immediacy because they contribute to a fuller comprehension of the ongoing situation and historic tensions.This book succeeds on many levels -- as a day-by-day chronology of events; as a profile of Begin, Carter, and Sadat as individuals and leaders; and as a primer on the region's history. Because of its content, source materials, and approach, this book is both history and a work of journalism. Wright's interweaving of interviews, published works, and archival materials gives the book a richness and veracity from a variety of perspectives, and adds to the sense that you are immersing yourself in unfolding events as you read.Wright starts with an overview of how volatile the relationship between Israel and its neighbors was in the decades leading up to the conference, as well as biographical thumbnails of each of the three men, including their inner motivations and moments that defined their future political choices.One example of Wright's attention to context is his care in setting the stage for the low expectations of the talks' success. He provides a concise exploration of the 10 months before they began. Sadat visited Jerusalem in November 1977, the first leader of an Arab country to do so. That brief visit had the opportunity to humanize each side to the other -- the Israelis who saw Sadat and their local coverage of his visit, as well as the Egyptians who followed their leader's visit on television. Wright uses this unexpected visit to provide an overview of the historic significance of Jerusalem that is specific and detailed, and illustrative of the innate tensions at work in the region. Although that visit offered a hint of the possibility of peace, subsequent actions by Israel and retaliations by the Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO) against both Israel and Egypt.Throughout the book, Wright stays on course with a daily chronology of events. Although he takes readers on a number of side journeys, each one appears at a logical point in the unfolding story of the 13-day odyssey. Wright is careful to keep these side trips brief and focused, and to ensure that they add to readers' understanding of the character, background, and motivation of the leader it is about.Wright's narrative is clear, comprehensive, and explicit, and provides readers with enough detail for them to make thoughtful connections and inferences. If you don't have much background on the subject, he makes sure you are not adrift, and yet he the variety of resources he taps should keep the book from being a rehashing for those who are more familiar.In a book published five years after the peace talks, Jimmy Carter described feeling "a curious fatalism" on the day those talks began. As you visit that historic September along with him, Anwar Sadat and Menachim Begin, you may well feel the same way.

Six hundred years ago, a French teenager changed history. Many of us know little more of her than her name, Joan of Arc, and her contention that she obeyed the instructions of angels.Kathryn Harrison has performed yeoman's work in researching and telling the story of Joan of Arc's life. She delves into contemporary records made at the time Joan was imprisoned, as well as interviews to gather testimony from more than 100 witnesses from various stages of Joan's life that were conducted two decades after her death as part of a retrial that cleared her name 25 years after her death.These and other glimpses of Joan in her own words and those of her contemporaries are memorable in their own right. What makes this biography even richer is Harrison's attention to context, both during Joan's brief life in the early 1400s, and in the centuries since then, as authors and playwrights recast Joan's story within the mores of their own eras. If your knowledge of Joan comes largely from plays, novels and films, you are likely to be surprised at how many misconceptions about Joan exist.What I found of special interest was how specific Harrison is about details of everyday life in the 1400s, and her ability to explain the significance of some of these details from the perspective of Joan's contemporaries, and interpretations and connections they would have made. She describes expectations of the time that were based on one's place in the hierarchy of society.She also is able to put to rest a number of superficial notions using evidence gleaned from multiple sources. For example, Joan wasn't simply the daughter of a poor villager who helped her family by herding sheep. Harrison disproves this notion by providing details about the land her father owned and his duties as dean of their village. In addition, she explains the significance of Joan's mother's surname, Romee, which connoted that either Joan's mother or maternal grandmother had made the prohibitively expensive and difficult pilgrimage to Rome.  These and other elements of Joan's childhood helped to shape the person she became.In addition, Harrison addresses some of the qualities Joan possessed that propelled her life in such meteoric fashion. These include having a memory good enough to counteract her illiteracy; choosing talents worth cultivating; and attaining mastery with great speed and comprehension.All of this helps convey why this biography is fascinating and informative. The following passage from the book conveys the power of Harrison's writing. She is reflecting on Joan's reticence about divulging certain details about the  angels who spoke to her:"Perhaps she didn't so much invent details as relinquish them slowly," Harrison writes. "Perhaps she didn't invent but borrowed unconsciously. Familiar figures ... provided ready vessels in which Joan could safeguard what she didn't want to forget or deny."This book is intense and captivating. What it demands in focused concentration it repays easily tenfold.

True confession time: The only kind of cooking I really enjoy is baking, and my favorite thing to shop for is books. Thus, with my mind on the holidays just around the corner, the chance to explore this book and offer you my experiences with it was perfect timing.If you're at all familiar with Jeff Hertzberg and Zoe Francois and their blog, you'll know that they've demystified and streamlined the process of baking breads, pizza dough and other fresh-from-the-oven delights.  However, if you or folks in your family or your network of friends are sensitive to gluten, it's probably been a challenge to buy -- or make -- dependably tasty breads and pastries with an inviting texture. That's the sadness I've heard from friends who are trying to minimize or remove gluten from their diets, and why I was pleased that the authors had modified their recipes and techniques for those who need to avoid gluten.Thus, my initial thought was that if this book was as dependable and baker-friendly as Hertzberg's and Francois's earlier recipes, I could bake up a storm and surprise gluten-sensitive friends with gluten-free gifts. After working through a range of the recipes and realizing that they are indeed as streamlined and dependable as the pair's other recipes, however, I've expanded my thinking. Some folks will be receiving baked goods. Those who enjoy cooking will be getting the book, plus a reusable container or lidded food-prep tub filled with the dry ingredients for the gluten-free all-purpose flour mixture, as well as the additional ingredients they will need to make the master recipe for four free-form loaves.Here are some notes from my baking thus far:* Following these recipes is much easier if you have a scale, because some measurements call for firmly packing ingredients; thus weighing is more precise.* The dough does blend together, but it can take longer than you're used to. Since I'm new to gluten-free cooking, I'm not sure whether that's true across the board. I was grateful for my KitchenAid and its dough hook: I didn't mind the need to halve the recipe because the mixer did the hard work.* Prepping and baking are pretty foolproof, and instructions and processes are simple and clear enough for beginning bakers. Parchment paper was a help not only for baking, but for some prep work, including the process of rolling out the pizza dough.* Your biggest challenges are likely to be finding sufficient space in your refrigerator for dough storage, and acquiring some of the ingredients. Look for commercial-grade tubs that will make the best use of the depth and width of your refrigerator, especially if you have a side-by-side. (Measure now, and buy two tubs, even if you plan to keep one tub refrigerated at a time.) As for ingredients, I was successful at finding some of the more challenging ones, such as xanthan gum, ground psyllium husk, and specialty flours at health-food stores and online. The authors also offer a range of substitutions for flours and starches. I wanted to work with oat flour, for example, and found that I could use it in place of sorghum for a nice dough that baked up well.* Pithy sidebars dot the pages of the book, and are designed to anticipate your questions and answer them quickly. Examples include how changing an ingredient can affect the texture and appearance of a dough, techniques for shaping a pizza disk, and flours to choose to boost protein content.* Technique photos for items such as pretzels are helpful both for beginning bakers who need guidance as well as for more experienced bakers who would like to compare the texture and appearance of their doughs against those of the authors.

I have needed several weeks' distance from The Nazis Next Door: How America Became a Safe Haven for Hitler's Men to be able to write calmly enough to provide the following review. The reason for that is in part a reflection of the thorough, professional effort by Eric Lichtblau to detail the choices and actions of the U.S. government following World War II. I frankly do not understand how he was able to live with the process of gathering this material, conducting interviews, and writing this very necessary book.You likely are aware of at least some of the details of which Lichtblau writes, such as  the contributions of  German scientists to our country's efforts in space to meet the scientific/political goal of placing a man on the moon by the end of the 1960s; or the government's rabid fear and loathing of Communism, as evidenced in the post-WWII era by McCarthyism and the Cold War. There's also the more recent spate of identifying a handful of U.S. residents who have been brought to trial decades after their war crimes.However, what this book does is pull together a number of these threads -- with substantial detail -- and weave them into a stifling blanket of context. The resulting work is an implicit indictment of the choices some members of the U.S. government made that run counter to the tenets on which we like to think the social contract of our country exists.Certainly, most of us know at least a little about Sen. Joseph McCarthy's fear-mongering, and FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover's empire-building and actions that exceeded Bureau mandates. What may be new to you, as it was to me, is to have these and other lesser-known actions bound together and placed in context in a single volume.Be warned that this is not a simple or pleasant read. The research and writing are excellent, and complex and arcane bits of information are presented comprehensibly. The tension comes from the incomprehensibility of what took place, and for this reason you may need to give yourself permission to read this book in installments over several days' time. I found that I was able to cope with 50 to 60 pages at a time.

I've got a soft spot for pillows, and have bought contoured pillows, memory-foam pillows, U-shaped pillows, and pillows with a thin surface layer of "cooling beads." Unfortunately, this pillow has been the most uncomfortable of the bunch, for two reasons.The first reason for my discomfort is a matter of taste. This pillow is definitely on the firm/sturdy end of the spectrum. It does have a bit of "give" when you rest the weight of your head on it; however, it molds you to its contours, rather than having enough pliability to mold at least a little to your contours. There is a difference between providing enough support so that your head is in position, and being stiff enough that there is no sense of cradling/comfort.  Those who prefer a really firm pillow may not mind, but the product description should be more specific.The second reason for my discomfort is more fundamental. I followed the manufacturer's suggestion of airing out the pillow for 24 hours before using it. Even after that time had passed, the pillow had a lingering smell, although it was much less than it had been straight out of the package.  I laundered the cover twice while waiting to reassemble the pillow. The cover held up well to laundering, which removed the smell. However, it isn't thick enough to block the lingering smell from the pillow. The foam had a slight color shift, but it seemed cosmetic, and the product information sheet mentioned this was a possibility, so that doesn't affect my rating.However, the flammability of this product is so high that although we are non-smokers and our home is fitted with smoke detectors, even if this pillow was comfortable to use, I simply would not be comfortable with it as a bed pillow. I do commend the manufacturer for the specific warnings on the product insert, including the following: "Once ignited, polyurethane foam is difficult to extinguish. Foam fires that appear to be extinguished may smolder and reignite. Always have fire officials determine whether a fire has been extinguished."

With eloquence and grace, Robert Poole invites us to meet some of the many pulsing hearts that make Section 60 of Arlington National Cemetery live on.Family members and friends visit the graves of these veterans, leaving flowers, keepsakes, and mementoes, and drawing comfort in the bittersweet process of revisiting everyday memories as well as the ache of recalling how their loved ones died.Somehow, those left behind -- whether civilians or veterans, whatever the year their loved ones passed -- have built a community. Poole touches on this by showing interrelationships, such as Vietnam veterans "being there" for those mourning more recent losses.With compassion and respect, he also explores the toll of such combat-related issues as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and other challenges that active-duty servicepeople and veterans both confront. Notably, neither he nor his military and civilian sources shies from such painful subjects, including suicide.Reading stories like those shared here can be extremely emotional, but it is necessary.... Necessary for understanding fear and bravery, necessary for understanding what makes a person willing to die for a comrade or a principle, and necessary for working through grief, whether immediate or at a distance."No man is an island," philosopher John Donne wrote four centuries ago, "every man is a piece of the continent, a part of the main." Those at rest in Section 60 and those who keep their memories alive live this philosophy. Daily.As one whose relatives sleep at the National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific and other veterans' cemeteries, I admire the people who have worked to keep the memories of their loved ones so tangible and visible. I hope their grace and generosity in sharing their stories starts a groundswell of everyday remembrance that spreads nationwide.

The premise at the heart of Mark Payne's book is likely to catch the interest of an array of people; unfortunately, some readers' enthusiasm may flag in the opening pages, where marketing jargon and "positioning" are at their most evident.If you're among them, my advice is to persevere. After taking care of some must-airs, Payne gets down to the business of showing how imagination and pragmatism can coexist in the business world.Depending on your interests and trigger points -- whether for thought or for irritation -- you may find yourself skimming some sections and underscoring key points in others. Again, persevere. If one case study doesn't interest you or provide a thought prompt, the next one probably will.My approach ended up being to read the entire book and returning to some of the sections for deeper reading, annotation, and reflection. (My tolerance for jargon is quite low; I mention this process in case it proves helpful to you, too.)

In All the Truth Is Out: The Week Politics Went Tabloid, journalist Matt Bai makes a case for what he believes is a fundamental change in how reporters cover politics.  He points to an almost symbiotic relationship between a change in political reporting and the implosion of Gary Hart's 1987 campaign for president.Until the mid-1980s, Bai reminds us, there were three major television networks and several newspapers of national record. Although wire services could move news around the clock, there was no 24-hour news cycle in the way we comprehend and live it today -- no live video feeds on location, no websites, cable, no blogs, no tweets, and no cell phones (and thus no text messages).Further, until this point, Bai posits, politicians and beat reporters had a shared ethos about what was and wasn't newsworthy. To buttress this, he points to earlier occasions during which reporters and news organizations were aware of certain politicians' extramarital involvements but did not report them. By contrast, news coverage of celebrities was much more personality-driven, especially as practiced by the tabloid-style publications and television shows.Bai then explores what happened during the 1987 election cycle that changed reporters' and news organizations' behavior; candidates' interactions with reporters; audiences' preferences for the content of news reporting; and the tools and technology available to reporters and news organizations. Some of the details he has unearthed may well surprise you, and at the very least, they bear thinking about."What really happened in 1987," Bai writes, "was that the finest political journalists of a generation surrendered all at once to the idea that politics had become another form of celebrity-driven entertainment, while simultaneously disdaining the kind of reporting that such a thirst for entertainment made necessary."That passage continues to haunt me, and it may well resonate with you, especially at this point in yet another election cycle.

Chances are you've seen dedicated handheld swipe-and-go payment devices in action, but are just starting to explore whether they're right for you. What Square has done with this little device and supporting app is to put mobile credit-card transactions within reach of sole proprietors and small businesses that don't want to be tied to overhead costs, but do want the flexibility of accepting payments by credit card.I am extremely conservative when it comes to the security of personal information -- especially financial data. Thus, I only considered reviewing and using this product after checking in with a business associate who transitioned to Square several years ago. He has a limited number of these readers, and assigns them to employees who will be working at customers' sites and needing to collect payment. Payment processing efficiency, mobile receipts, and accounting data are among the features he says he finds most useful.Downloading and activating the application went without incident on my iPhone, I spent several days exploring the "back end" of the accounting/reporting before using the reader, so that I would be prepared for the data. This was time well spent, and something you may want to consider.I appreciate the mobility and security this device provides. Key benefits include:+ Convenience for customers.+ Your ability to collect payments at the point of service in exchange for a set percentage of the billed amount. That rate currently is 2.75 percent for any card type supported by Square. This is a different pricing structure than is offered by some other vendors, so you should do the math to determine whether or not this fee structure would be an improvement for you.+ Accepting a credit-card payment can provide more protection than accepting a check, because the card issuer goes after the cardholder rather than voiding the payment to the merchant. This is a benefit if you are working with a new client, or want to avoid any risks with accepting cash/checks and keeping them safe until you can get to your financial institution. Taking credit-card payments at the point of sale also helps reduce billing and accounting work.- My main nitpick is that there should be more supporting material available to new users.

I've been an intrigued bystander to the Dragon phenomenon over the years, and was glad to have the opportunity to explore the latest version of the software. Thus, this review is from the perspective of a new user.If you are new to Dragon, be aware that installing and getting up to speed with this program requires an investment of focused time. You will get the best results by reducing ambient noise as much as possible. Dragon mentions that a microphone is optional, and that you can use the mic on a laptop, but those results were spotty because of the combination of my relatively soft voice and even minimal background noise.Also, although this software comes bundled with a headset, I got better results with a headset/boom mic combination I already owned. My suggestion is to buy the physical version of the program and plan to supply your own headset.During actual use, I was happiest with the dictation feature. I tend to speak pretty slowly, and because I'm more used to typing my writing than speaking it, the software was easily able to keep pace. It also kept up when I read passages from the newspaper, so even if you are experienced at dictating, response speed probably won't be an issue. Dragon also was able to work with a microcassette recording of my speaking voice played back through my boom mic.However, I was disappointed with the navigation tools. I didn't always get a response, and some of the responses were inaccurate. At this point, I am finding the navigation tools to be a time drain. Additionally, keep in mind that the navigation function for this version focuses on Word, WordPerfect and several browsers. If you are looking for navigation for the rest of the Office suite (Excel and PowerPoint), you will need Dragon Premium 13 rather than Dragon Home 13.

After a long day at the computer or out in the yard, the muscles in my neck and down the middle of my back often feel tight, even when I remember to stretch during the day.This product is well named -- it really does wrap around your shoulders and hug the center of your back. Better yet, it stays where you place it, allowing the moist heat to reach and relax tense or tired muscles. I've bought and made other products that provide moist heat, but they all have had the drawback of not covering enough of an area, or of shifting rather than staying put.The construction of this wrap is part of the reason it's so effective. A removable, thick poly fleece cover provides some insulation and padding for the interior pouch, which contains the flax seeds that provide the moist heat. That interior pouch is channel-stitched, so that the seeds are spread in a uniform thickness throughout the pouch. The poly fleece is easy to spot clean, and it also hand-washes nicely, without any shrinking shaping issues.This product also can be used as a cold pack. It does get quite cold when frozen. The manufacturer suggests removing the fleece cover when using as a cold pack. I tested it briefly while wearing a T-shirt, and the cold did travel pretty well. If you use this for cold therapy, do keep track of your skin exposure, in terms of both time and approximate temperature.SIZE: I wear a size 6 and was very happy with the drape of the large size over my collarbones and coverage of my shoulders and upper back. If you've got broad shoulders, you might want to choose extra-large.WARMING: The product insert calls for microwaving this for 90 seconds and for additional 10-second increments if needed. I obtained even heating by placing the folded wrap on a microwave-safe plate on the turntable of the microwave, and rearranging the wrap after the first minute.

Our lab eats everything she should, and some things she shouldn't, so her happy acceptance of these dental chews did not surprise me.  What did, however, is her definite preference for these dental chews over the anti-plaque chews she normally receives.Every afternoon, she gets a treat to tide her over until dinner. A couple of times now, I've held out both treat packages and asked her to choose by touching her nose to the bag she wants. Each time, she's chosen these.For a big, adventurous dog, she has a tender tummy, so we are careful when introducing new items to her diet. I was a little concerned that she might have an issue with potato starch vs. the potato flour and rice flour that are the first two ingredients of her usual chews.However, pumpkin is the first ingredient in these chews, and our vet has suggested small servings of canned pumpkin after previous stomach upsets, so I cut one of these treats in half and watched her closely while she ate it and afterward. No apparent issues, and no sounds of gastrointestinal discomfort.Each bone-shaped treat has 80 kcal, on par with other dental-type treats; nutrition values are similar. Product packaging and website both provide detailed figures, and both note that these treats are not meal replacements.

The folks who designed this stainless-steel tumbler either enjoy hot beverages or spent time talking with people who do. Their mission was simple: Start with a hot beverage, keep it as warm as possible, and help the user avoid spills by providing an effective pushbutton seal.This travel mug performs well, keeping the last sip as warm as the first, even after the passage of an hour or more. Its shape is easy to hold, and even when full, the mug does not have a tendency to tip over.My favorite part of this mug, however, may well be the inner workings of the underside of the lid. A lever lets you swing much of the mechanics down and away, making it easier to clean the lid assembly thoroughly. This degree of access may be less of an issue for those who don't add dairy or sugar to their hot drinks, but until I started using this version of the Contigo mug, I confined my homemade cappuccinos to cups with flip-top spout covers.In assigning a rating, I acknowledge that this version of the Contigo line has a price premium. However, I factored in some less-than-happy moments with my thermal cups (such as relatively rapid cooling and spills) as well as the cost savings of preparing espresso drinks rather than buying them. Taking these factors into account, the cup construction and lid assembly do provide additional value.Note: the manufacturer provided a mug for review.

If you like preparing loose tea but are tired of keeping leaves and other particles out of your cup, you've probably tried a variety of infusers. I know I have, and they occupy a sad little section of one of my kitchen drawers.Until I learned about Contigo's lid-mounted infuser, my least-irritating method had been to use a mesh tea ball with a scissor-action handle. The tea was acceptable, but there was a lot of swirling to do during preparation, and putting the loose tea in and fishing the wet tea out was messy.The process is much simpler and tidier with this infuser. The flat-bottomed, cone-shaped infuser has plenty of room for your hot water to wash over the tea. Loading and unloading the infuser is simple. You can do this at home if you're not going to be steeping the tea immediately, because the infuser lid and base cover both mount securely, protecting the tea. (The same is true after you use it.)The resulting tea itself is excellent. If you like a particularly strong cup, there is plenty of room for a generous helping of leaves. And even with a more delicate tea like jasmine, the stainless-steel filter does not impart any taste or aftertaste.The only reason this filter does not earn a full five stars is that even with practice, I continue to have some difficulty with snapping the infuser's mounting arms into the lid. Removing the infuser can be even more challenging unless you have excellent grip strength.

I am cautiously recommending these placemats. "Recommending" because the color gradation of warm straws and golds is beautiful, especially when set against a dark wood table. "Cautiously" because of some construction issues and the fact that the maintenance of these mats is more involved than their rustic appearance and the manufacturer's labeling of "everyday" would indicate.The range of colors in the taupe placemats I received was as pretty as I had hoped after viewing the color swatch on the Amazon product page. "Taupe" means grayish-brown, and these mats are much warmer in tone than that. Strands run from a light straw through to a matte midrange gold. Strands are woven together loosely enough to provide a rustic appearance, which boosts their appeal to me.If you sometimes set a table for eight or more, you might consider getting a set of the taupe and a contrasting set of the variegated "nautical blue" or "olive green" mats, and alternating them at place settings. That way you'd have two different sets for everyday use.Even before I washed these mats, I noticed a variation in width of an inch. The narrowest mat was 19 inches wide, while the mat next to it in the package was 20 inches. This variance may not matter to you, especially if you will be using these on a larger table. More concerning, however, are the top and bottom edges of the mat. These are the margins without the knotted self-fringe. The weave there is not always as true and tight as it is in the body of the mats. In addition, several threads along the edges were broken and another was frayed, which raises concerns for longevity, especially after several washings.In addition, there were several loose strands on the reverse. These can either be taken in by untying the knot, pulling up the slack in the thread, and then retying the knot, or tacking down the loop with needle and thread. Leaving these loops as-is invites snagging, which could damage the mat.As for cleaning, the care instructions are to wash in cold water and lay flat to dry. The fibers in the strands of the mat are dense, and drying took several hours, even though I used a mesh lay-flat ring that I normally use for sweaters. (I did not want to risk having them get funky and musty without airflow beneath them.) The mats did hold their shape, but if you're laundering four or all six mats, air-drying them may be an irritation.

With her outgoing personality and her wit, Paige Rawl could have been any extroverted teen with a bevy of friends. Unfortunately, she had something her peers didn't: HIV.And from the moment word of Paige's health status spread through her middle school, she was privy to two painful lessons that all too many children are taught: People can be shallow and unthinking. And the adults entrusted with your care at school can sometimes be more ignorant and cruel than your peers.Paige was fortunate in having a caring, involved mom; in having several strong friendships; and in having several refuges that adults ensured were safe spaces. However, even these supports might not have been sufficient if she hadn't also had an amazing inner well of strength. There is no excuse for bullying anywhere, and yet the fatalistic attitude toward its existence has allowed the culture of bullying to endure and to become institutionalized at way too many schools for far too many decades.Paige's story is one of tears, certainly. But it is also one of resilience, and choice, and perseverance. I cannot begin to imagine what her life's journey has felt like thus far, or what reserves she drew upon so that she could be a very public ambassador for people with a health status that has been stigmatized for far too long.As others have noted, the behavior of some of the people in this young woman's life was irresponsible and even cruel. For this reason, I cannot recommend Positive as a "here you go" book for younger teens, even though it is very well written. Instead, this is a book that a loved one should give to a younger teen for shared reading as part of a larger, hopefully ongoing conversation.Paige Rawl was stronger than any adolescent should ever have to be, and it is to her great credit that she is brave and compassionate enough to tell her story from the vantage point of nurturing and elevating a societal dialog that is long overdue.

In Literacy and the Common Core: Recipes for Action Sarah Tantillo provides both context and action items for those involved in K-12 education. Administrators, teachers, parents, and aspiring teachers naturally will gravitate to specific -- and likely different -- sections of the book. And while that's understandable, this book is most effective for the reader who explores it in its entirety.In fact, one of the strengths of this book is its value as a shared reference for people in the above four groups, who share the goal of ensuring students have access to quality education. Thus, although the background information Tantillo provides may be a refresher for educators and administrators, it's a good opportunity for recalibration.In addition to overall context, Tantillo addresses teachers' immediate needs with pedagogical principles and strategies, as well as with reproducibles on an enclosed disc. Educators who are especially time-starved can make do with skimming portions of the book over a couple of evenings or a weekend, and will be able to identify techniques and reproducibles they can bring into the classroom rapidly.However, these items don't drift in isolation, because Tantillo anchors them to the perennial goals of rigor and meaningful assessment of progress toward mastery. Such concepts are not abstractions but are firmly internalized by most educators, but absolutely need to be examined by parents and aspiring educators.

With all the Bluetooth personal-size speakers on the market these days, it can be challenging to figure out which one will best meet your needs. Because of its portability and oversize sound, this little unit has all of the positives of the "boom boxes" some of us remember from our youth, with the added benefit of smaller dimensions and freedom from C batteries.Here's a targeted assessment of how the Bose has been performing.SOUND: This unit puts out a rich, clean, clear sound. Bass is present without being overwhelming; higher notes don't get tinny. When evaluating any speakers, I listen for how well they handle guitar and a cappella, because fuzziness and other issues will stand out. This little unit did not muddy the purity of the unaccompanied human voice. It also stood up to the subtle complexities of guitar -- in ballads, rock, and the music I love best, Hawaiian slack-key.PORTABILITY. The unit is small enough to tuck into a day pack or oversize purse. The internal battery holds a charge of up to 8 hours' playing time, which means you don't need to bring the provided power adapter (but if you do, it's in two compact parts, a USB cable and a slimline wall adapter with fold-flat prongs). The unit will simultaneously recharge and perform as a speaker. I was able to recharge a drained battery while playing music in about 70 minutes.EASE OF USE. Initial setup takes just a few minutes, and can be done while you are recharging the battery. The spoken instructions are easy to follow. Then it's a matter of getting your Bluetooth-enabled devices to recognize the speaker. Once this recognition process is complete, whenever the speaker is on, it will verbally identify any synched device that comes within range. And this is not a generic identification - the SoundLink uses the name you've assigned to each device. Toggling between devices is simple, too, just a matter of using the "pause" and "play" controls on your devices.APPEARANCE/DURABILITY: The case is smooth, with rounded corners. The one-piece top panel and two narrow vertical panels on the sides of the case are rubberized, with some flexibility. Control functions are printed on the surface of the top panel, and are pressure-sensitive, so there are no moving parts exposed. The narrow strips on the sides of the case give you a surer grip when lifting or moving the unit. The SoundLink and power supply are both well-machined. Overall, the unit seems sturdy and capable of withstanding daily use, including frequent movement and plugging and unplugging.

A small footprint, a useful touchpad, duplex scanning and wireless connectivity are the highlights of this printer. Its printing capabilities are serviceable, and the provision for two kinds of black ink makes it versatile enough to meet the needs of hobbyists and crafters who want to print both photos and documents using a single device. In addition, those of us who still need a fax will appreciate the ability to ditch a standalone fax unit.Hobbyists and those who telecommute occasionally, or whose work doesn't require high-volume printing are likely to find that this device will meet their needs for scanning, faxing, and low-volume document printing, as well as periodic printing of scrapbook-quality photos.I put this unit through its paces using my MacBook Pro and secured internet connection and am focusing on interactions and output to help you compare this unit against other multifunction and "small-in-one" printers.SETUP: Allow yourself at least 45 uninterrupted minutes for hardware and software setup. You'll need about 15 minutes to get the device going (including a 7-minute initialization sequence that sounds much louder than the printer does in action). If you're configuring for a Mac, you will need to access the install packet online, because it's not on the supplied disk. My computer has an optical drive, so I simply inserted the supplied DVD and let it do the work of accessing. While the install packet was downloading, I scanned the QR on the setup sheet with my iPhone and captured the robust app. I liked that the additional items were opt-in rather than opt-out (temporarily select an item to read Epson's description of its functionality).Install for the configuration I selected took just under 15 minutes. I had no issues with running the installation wirelessly, but you may find the process simpler if you connect the printer to your computer. Be sure to save your old printer's USB cable or borrow one; this unit doesn't ship with that cable.SCANNING: The feeder and its duplexing capability may well be what set this unit apart for you. I've scanned documents and snapshots of varying sizes, paper quality and contrast, and have been pleased with the feeder and on-glass imaging. As part of its "small in one" footprint, though, be aware that the feeder assembly may not be as rugged as those you're used to in a larger office environment. The scanning itself goes fine, but you've got to be extra-careful truing-up the guides in the paper feeder or you'll get misaligned images. That's the tradeoff for having a lid assembly folds neatly for a streamlined appearance and to keep out dust between uses.PRINTING: Printing speed and quality have been within manufacturer specs thus far. I appreciate the convenience of printing images on the spot, but would not expect to do large runs or professional-caliber printing with this machine.SUPPLIES: Be aware that this printer requires 5 ink cartridges, including two types of black ink, one for photos and an oversize tank for non-photo printing. In addition, if you're replacing an older USB printer, be sure to hang onto your USB cable; chances are it will be compatible with your printer.STABILITY/STURDINESS: The unit's connectivity with my home network has been very stable, even after being shut off and powered back up, as well as after I've shut down and powered up my router. The feeder assembly, as mentioned above, is slightly delicate but workable. However, the supply trays are a frustration. While it's great that a device as compact as this has two supply trays, the guides within the trays and the trays themselves are finicky to configure and to insert properly in the printer. This is both an ongoing issue and a concern for durability down the road. Supply capacity also is small, which is understandable given the printer size and the two-tray versatility.SUPPORT: I received a persistent error message during the first stage of setup and needed to contact Epson. The tech-support person was thorough and knowledgeable, and helped solve the problem. However, I was disappointed that the only timely option for a non-functional printer was paying for a toll call. Before calling, I checked Epson's online resources for the error code and a FAQ setup for troubleshooting without luck.RATING: Thus far, performance is as promised. I am deducting a half-star because of the finicky nature of ensuring that documents stay aligned in the feeder, and that supplies stay aligned in their trays. However, I'm deducting another half-star for setup/support issues. for a printer at this price point, Epson really should be providing a printer cable so that the unit is definitely functional right out of the box. More importantly, it should provide a no-additional-cost means of access to support for units that fail initial setup.

That stubborn glob of natural peanut butter clinging to the inside wall of the jar just below the thread for the lids -- you know, the one that you can't quite reach with a teaspoon or an offset spatula? -- has officially met its match.This Oxo jar spatula easily and efficiently squeegees off peanut butter, raw honey, tomato paste and other food items that are clingy, sticky or viscous. Its sides taper to narrow, relatively rigid wedges, while the short, leading edge is more bendable, perfect for coaxing material out of the bottoms of jars and cans, where the walls of the container meet the base. The overall curvature is equally as functional in small-diameter cans such as tomato paste as it is in larger-diameter jars. The handle is easy to grip, and the amount of flex along the length is minimal.Although I would prefer that this tool be molded from a single piece of silicone, the seam is close enough to the top of the handle that food probably won't work its way in. Cleanup is simple, whether you wash the spatula by hand or place it in your dishwasher.

Writing in an effortless voice is exceedingly hard work. Introducing multiple perspectives and storylines and motivating your readers to stick with you through convoluted passageways and high-altitude soaring adds several degrees of difficulty.And yet in this slender volume Eden Collinsworth has managed to draw together a primer on Western etiquette (complete with discourse on the etymology of the word), hiccups and triumphs of being an American abroad, and the joys and challenges of crafting a meaningful life for herself and her son.In less capable hands, these multiple story lines and perspectives would end up in a sorry, knotted mess, but Collinsworth is able to tease out interrelationships and heightened meaning, whether she's illustrating handshake protocol and personal space or detailing the faux pas of using a business card as a nail pick. (Hint: Don't do it. Ever. And when you are Asia-bound, always bring four times as many business cards as you think you will need.)I suspect that Collinsworth's seemingly breezy style may initially be off-putting for some; my advice would be to withhold judgment until you've reached at least the halfway point of this book. This should provide you with enough of a sense of her take on things that are familiar to you to evaluate how you'll perceive what she offers about the unfamiliar.For example, while I can't vouch for all of the China nuggets she shares, enough of the components matched my knowledge and experience to make me comfortable with the bedrock of her message. Incidentally, the Xian farmer she mentions? I have his autograph, too, as well as countless photos of the terra cotta warriors, both from that trip and successive visits.

Food critics praise chefs who develop dishes that are a symphony of flavors and textures in the mouth. Unfortunately, rather than being satisfying, the combination of sensations provided by these low-carb bars is unpleasant. Nuts and other dry ingredients are bound into the shape of a pressed bar by a treacly, overly sweet adhesive.  Somehow, despite these "toffee" ribbons, the combination is powdery and dry as you chew.I had hoped to tuck these in a desk drawer as a tasty, nutritious snack on marathon days, but can't get past the taste and texture. While there is some nutrition in these compact bars, I would rather make a snack out of ingredients that are closer to their natural state, such as a quarter-cup of nuts augmented by a handful of dried fruit. Even if the latter weren't quite as balanced as the bars, the snack would be tasty, filling and moderately nutritious.My personal rating would be 1 star, but you may find the flavor and texture less bothersome, so I've raised this a star.

Our kitty overcame two cancers, one involving serious surgery. Sadly, her third cancer was untreatable. Despite her continued spunk and interest in us and the world, all that remained after the last diagnosis was to make her final days happy ones.Our vet administered an antibiotic injection for secondary infections, briefed me on end-stage details, and suggested that I head to Chinatown for some Yunnan Baiyao capsules. The herbalist helped convert the dosage from capsules to powder, and instructed me to mix the powder thoroughly in with wet food. He said that people give the powder to dogs, cats, and even horses.Our cat never refused the amended food, and her bouts of bleeding stopped for more than a week. When they resumed, they were relatively mild and stopped quickly, rather than severe, rush-to-the-vet events.When we began the Yunnan, we expected that her remaining time with us would be measured in days; she ended up being comfortable and stable for two additional months. I'm grateful that we were able to ease her journey in a manner that she didn't seem to notice.~~~Packaging notes: Each glass bottle is sealed with a tamper-proof seal inside the lid and has a five-year effective period between production and expiration dates. Under the seal and resting atop the padding that keeps the powder compacted is a bead the size of a small BB that you are to give in cases of heavy bleeding; so far we have not needed them, and have been collecting them just in case. Dosage is based on the weight of the patient. (Given a choice, I would opt for the powder rather than the pills.)

Vornado is known for the ability of its whole-room air circulators to take the edge off summertime heat and humidity, and this approach translates well to warming up chilly spaces during cooler months.This compact device quietly warms smaller rooms, raising the temperature within minutes. Following the instructions, I placed the unit on the floor near an electrical outlet in my home office, turned the dial to the highest setting and toggled the three-way switch to high, as well. With the door closed, within 10 minutes, the room was noticeably warmer. Temperature gain was pretty even -- as the product literature promises, there were no noticeable hot or cold spots in the room.Once the temperature was close to the desired level, I decreased fan speed and dialed back the temperature setting. The ambient temperature remained stable, and the sounds of operation decreased even more.I also tested the unit in a larger bedroom with mixed results. While it did raise the temperature of the room somewhat, the rate of climb was slower than in the smaller room. Temperature increase also plateaued before reaching the feel of the temperature in the smaller room. The unit had little effect in our high-ceilinged open-plan living room.If you are wondering about the relatively vague characterization of temperatures, it is because this unit's multi-position thermostat does not indicate target temperatures. While the lack of measurement may well be a drawback to you, it was not an issue for me, as I was gauging relative comfort, not specific temperatures.This unit is compact enough to fit on the top shelf of a bedroom closet for storage during warmer months, and light enough to reposition or move from room to room as needed. The price point and size of this unit also make it worth considering for college students, especially if they are living in dormitories with inefficient heating and rules against small appliances that draw a lot of power.

I always thought of washlets as slightly amusing and somewhat self-indulgent - until shivering through a wintertime business trip to Japan. Without being cringingly specific, a washlet can help with cleanliness and comfort.Toto has a line of washlet seats with a variety of features. I chose this one based on the features and ease of installation -- as well as the fact that I have seen this exact model in a number of places in Japan, including upscale hotels and restaurants. Additionally, I noticed that the same washlets were in place and still fully functional on repeat visits months apart. My thought was that if a particular washlet was specified for commercial installations and actually withstood that volume of use, it would be something that would perform well in a home, and be relatively easy to clean and maintain, as well. We've had our washlets for about a year and have found them to be dependable and easy to clean.Installation was simple; all the needed hoses and fasteners were included. Installing the first seat took me about 20 minutes, only because I didn't want to rush the process. I would suggest mounting the included remote on the wall, above your toilet-paper dispenser. Your only challenge may be providing an electrical outlet. If you don't already have an outlet, please resist the instinct to run an extension cord, moreso for your safety than aesthetics. If you are adding an outlet, position it slightly off-center and below the tank of the toilet.As for the toilet, check the Toto website for a list of compatible toilets. Amazon also stocks these, but depending on your location and your level of comfort with pulling a toilet, you may prefer to engage a plumber for this portion of the project. He or she may have ordering resources for the toilet, and shifting that responsibility will spare you from dealing with delays if there are any defects in or damages to the toilet.

Bathing the Lion very nearly succeeds in defying description, especially for a literal, linear soul like me. I refuse to spoil the story for you by parsing it; instead, I'll focus on how unusual an experience reading this book can be.Its characters and story arc resist characterization and pigeonholing. Rather, reading this book is a matter of immersion, a sense that you are passing through an intangible membrane from the here and today of your life to a place that is somewhat reassuringly recognizable -- except that it isn't, really.There's the subtle sense of otherness that you get sometimes when you're on autopilot in a different city. Comfortable and recognizable ... except for the periodic, slightly unsettling jerks that remind you that this place is not home, it is other, and while you can pass the time there, it isn't your real existence. And see? The earlier part of this paragraph is just one example of the author's skill at creating subtle moments of disequilibrium. For me, this resulted in an insistent need to seek patterns and construct comprehension. Your elemental response may well be different, but I suspect one will exist, nonetheless.As I was reading, I kept thinking about a fascinating component of an interactive museum exhibit on the human brain I took in several weeks ago. This portion of the exhibit involved sitting next to a companion on a squashy sofa, donning headphones and giving yourself over to a series of video clips on a monitor. Afterward, a docent asked each of us to describe what we'd seen and what the message was. After hearing both descriptions, which were wildly divergent, he volunteered that there are no wrong answers, just different ones, and that thus far no two answers he'd heard had been alike. I suspect that this singularity of interpretation may well prove to be the case with this wonderful, perplexing, evocative, beautifully written book.

If you are upgrading your current home or building a new one, you probably recognize Arizona Tile from your visits to design showrooms and tile wholesalers. Those folks stock and recommend it because it's quality stuff -- durable, attractive, and relatively easy to work with.Thus, I was extremely happy to find several styles of this tile on Amazon, including my favorite, at a substantial savings. The professional who installed this tile in our bathroom said that even when mosaic tile is supplied on mesh backing, it can be challenging to work with. Apparently, it is not uncommon for some brands to supply sheets with mis-positioned tiles, which the person in the field must manually adjust, at the risk of causing a slight rise or bump in the installation. Ditto with mosaic pieces that have chips or other imperfections.On the recommendation of the installer, we chose Laticrete grout in a neutral color, and the finished bathroom literally sparkles. Since then, I've done a craft project using the mosaic. I found the mesh backing to be substantial enough to position without a problem, and yet simple to cut as needed. If you're tackling this as a do-it-yourself project, my major caution to you would be to make sure you smooth out the thinset mortar, because if you leave the usual ridges, those can show through behind the more translucent pieces of mosaic.A note about the product photo: The shade and tone of the mosaic pieces is pretty accurate, but the photo does not convey the warm glow of the tile or the shiny surface of the glossy tile pieces of the mosaic. This blend coordinates nicely with warm, off-white neutral field tile. If you are working with white, glossy subway tile, Amazon frequently carries a variegated blue mosaic in this line of Arizona Tile that coordinates well with a starker, brighter white.

In the afterword to this absolutely gripping book, author Michael Ross describes several of the coincidences that brought him to the largely forgotten story of the kidnapping of a New Orleans toddler in June 1870 that caught the attention of a nation, as did the subsequent manhunt and trial.Ross was reading the column-inches of New Orleans newspapers published in 1870 in search of coverage about attempts to obstruct postwar Reconstruction efforts when he was hooked by the mention of police officers arresting and questioning practitioners of voodoo.It is our good fortune that Ross is such a thorough researcher, and that he didn't simply gather some notes on what became known as the Digby case and set them aside for some indeterminate future follow-up.Instead, Ross combed contemporaneous newspapers and conducted other research, and produced what he calls a micro-history. It is that, of course, and by dint of the generous footnotes and careful delineation of the New Orleans of 1870, obviously an academically sound tracing of the events of the case, as well as the historical, economic, societal, and political factors that contributed to making these events possible only at that particular time and place."The Great New Orleans Kidnapping Case" is gripping, captivating, and evocative of a time none of us will ever know. Somehow, though, Ross has managed to stitch  ephemera and minutia onto a solid, supportive backing of context. These are real people, largely forgotten by succeeding generations, who occupied headlines around the country for a brief moment in time.Indeed, as Ross points out, fellow author William Faulkner's words about another time and place are equally fitting for New Orleans: "The past is never dead. It's not even past." This book earns my highest recommendation, and is deserving of all the superlatives it is sure to receive when it is released this fall.

Kaui Hart Hemmings has a knack for crafting characters with flaws that hamper their lives, without quite breaking them. There's no saccharine in her writing - even sympathetic characters have a bit of "bite," and the more irritating individuals have at least one redeeming quality.Being from Hawaii and having found grains of home truths in her earlier book, "The Descendants," I wondered what insights Hemmings might unearth and portray about the scenic mountain town of Breckenridge, Colorado. While the town and surroundings play a minor role, my sense was they are rendered more generically than places in Hawaii were, unless there are subtleties apparent mainly to those from the area or very familiar with it.Overall, premise and pacing are solid, and Hemmings works to illuminate her characters slowly, adding depth as the story progresses, so that readers modify their perceptions as events unfold. That said, characters are not as finely drawn as they could be, so readers are likely to be engaged in this bittersweet story, rather than immersed in it.Similarly, the final section is adequate, and parts of it are touching, but Hemmings does not capitalize on the full potential of the characters and the interlacing of their lives. Additionally, the pacing seems rushed (rather than purposefully accelerated) and the conclusion a bit abrupt, especially when compared with the relatively leisurely pace of the rest of the book.In sum, this is a book with a thought-provoking and heartbreaking premise, peopled by sympathetic, largely credible characters. However, it does not make the most of its possibilities, and thus earns 3.5 stars, which I have rounded up to 4.

Imagine being able to remember everything perfectly. Time, date, place, content. Exactly. That's the bittersweet gift Brenna Spector developed after the disappearance of her older sister. It is an ability that helps Spector in her "day job" as detective, but causes a range of emotions in her personal life, from amusing to useful to incredibly painful.Stay With Me is Alison Gaylin's third novel featuring Spector (and this unusual but factual ability). Although you could possibly read this story as a standalone book, its impact will be greatly heightened for you if you read the first two books in the series. You wouldn't be totally adrift if you started here, but you would miss the full impact of the chills and poignancy without the context of the earlier books. I found the absence of rehashing of earlier elements in the series arc to be a positive but if you start here, that positive becomes a negative.Gaylin has an understated way of heightening tension by word choice and pacing, and her mainstay characters are credible and appealing. Spector herself is someone you root for, even as you worry with her about the fate of her missing daughter, and puzzle over the heartbreaking disappearance of her sister and busy yourself trying to avoid drawing parallels.Without spoiling this book for you, Gaylin does tie together some threads and snip some loose ends, as you would hope with an ongoing series. While this is an enjoyable read, I did not find it as absolutely captivating as the first in the series. Thus, this earns a solid four stars from me, as opposed to the five I gave And She Was.

These cute, classy labels with their scalloped edges lend themselves to a variety of uses -- pantry organization, jar toppers for preserves or dried mixes you create for gifts, and application to larger circle in a contrasting color for a tag -- or even a holiday ornament.If you've got page-design software, you can build a template, but the simpler route is to go to the Avery website, provide the product number, and build your templates on the spot. Be sure to do a test-run on a sheet of paper to check that your designs will be centered vertically and horizontally on the labels, and that you like how your designs appear "in print" before using your label sheets.The labels themselves are sturdy and pleasant to the touch, and the scalloped edges are cleanly cut. Especially if you are producing a detailed design with multiple colors, consider printing those labels on a color laser printer to minimize the risk of ink bleed during printing and rub-off afterward.One workaround if you are not able to save your template as a PDF is to print it as best you can, and then scan that image and take the file and your labels to a copy shop. While I wouldn't go to this degree of effort for party tags or pantry labels, I have saved a few sheets to make a series of Christmas ornaments, which I would rather print cleanly and durably using a color laser printer than print at home and "seal up" using laminating sheets.

The philosophy behind Common Core standards can be polarizing, and even educators who support its premise may well feel challenged by ways to make the Common Core challenging and yet achievable for both their students and themselves.This slender workbook provides immediate suggestions and materials to help teachers teach critical-literacy skills across multiple content areas. The author, Katherine McKnight, touches on learning theory, but her focus is on providing tools that teachers can tailor to their students' specific needs and interests.Adolescents are savvy. They can sniff out a canned worksheet within moments of it hitting their desks. Thus, these are not photocopier-ready documents, but images with suggestion and thought bubbles -- homework for the teacher, as it were. It is evident that care and planning went into developing as streamlined a process as possible for teachers, who are perennially time-starved, and who want to save the majority of their cognitive power for planning rigorous, targeted course work, and for conducting useful assessments in the moment and in quiet hours spent reviewing students' work.While this book may be most immediately and visibly helpful to teachers who are in their first few years of teaching, seasoned educators also will find thoughts and tools to elevate their practice.In addition, at this price point, administrators should consider providing lending copies of this to their faculty, and teacher-certification programs should add this to the required-purchase list for content-area pedagogy classes.

The human brain is a wondrous organism, capable of building virtual compartments in which to store knowledge, and fashioning methods of connecting disparate specks of information and stitching them together into concrete and abstract thought.Each day, we are bombarded with many more impressions -- sights, sounds, smells, concepts, theories, and "facts" -- than we can possibly organize, store, and retrieve. And yet our brains keep amassing data and tagging it so that we can build comprehension and access details (from memories to factoids) months and years later.In this approachable and thought-provoking book, Benedict Carey prompts us to think about thinking and learning. He provides an array of data points and then takes a step back to enable us to work through the ideas at our own pace and inclination.No doubt his low-key metacognitive approach will resonate to varying degrees with different readers, and that is exactly as it should be. I am reflective and linear in my thinking, so for me this book was a series of "aha"s, "ha!"s, and "I need to think some more about that"s. You may well feel differently.Thus, my rating is five solid stars, but I recognize that those with specialized knowledge of neuroscience and/or psychology may find this relatively elementary, and other sincere readers may just not like it. Again, that's exactly as it should be with this sort of subject matter.

I am a little ambivalent about ROMEO AND JULIET.  In many ways it is a wonderful play, but to me it falls short of being a great play.  Nevertheless, it is, with good reason, firmly ensconced in our literary heritage for being, to quote Harold Bloom, "the largest and most persuasive celebration of romantic love in Western literature."ROMEO AND JULIET was written about the same time as, and perhaps simultaneous with, "A Midsummer Night's Dream".  In a way, the two plays are the opposite sides of the same coin.  In "A Midsummer Night's Dream", all four love pairings experience turbulence, but then, at play's end, everything and everyone magically end up happy and wonderful.  In ROMEO AND JULIET, the title characters fall in love with one another at first sight and are married, but then things go horribly and tragically wrong.It is a brilliantly crafted play, even for Shakespeare.  It has three marvelous, "larger-than-life" characters:  Mercutio (Romeo's friend), Juliet's Nurse, and Juliet herself, not yet fourteen but with a wit and strength of character that exceed her apparent beauty.  What, then, about Romeo?  I find him rash, petulant, and histrionic.  In a fit of pique, Juliet's father Capulet refers to her as "a wretched puling fool, a whining maumet", words that in truth fit Romeo much more aptly.  He is the one who acts like a fourteen-year-old.I have other vague dissatisfactions concerning the play.  On the level of plot, it is rather like a Gothic soap opera.  There is a surfeit, to use Capulet's phrase, of "chopped logic."  Capulet himself seems to embody a huge contradiction in character, on the one hand the open-minded, equable host who doesn't mind that the rival Montagues attend his party, and on the other the tyrannical ogre who insists that Juliet marry Paris or else be disowned.  Then there is the awkward wrapping up at the end of the play (Friar Laurence's summary in particular strikes me as unnecessary).  In other words, I suppose (presumptuously), the play could have benefited from an additional round of polishing by Shakespeare.Still, there is Juliet's love for Romeo -- and, to a slightly less sublime degree, Romeo's for Juliet.  The epitome of transcendent romantic love is expressed by Juliet:"My bounty is as boundless as the sea,My love as deep:  The more I give to theeThe more I have, for both are infinite."

A week ago I read Tom McGuane's latest book of short stories, "Crow Fair".  His first book of short stories was TO SKIN A CAT, published in 1986.  Although it has long been in my library, I never got around to reading it.  I thought it might be interesting to do so and compare McGuane as a short story writer over three decades, from TO SKIN A CAT to "Crow Fair".The two books share a strong family resemblance.  I would say that the McGuane of "Crow Fair" is a slightly better writer, with a smoother writing style.  But I prefer the stories in TO SKIN A CAT, by a whisker -- by a wider margin if you toss out the one real clunker.  Four of the stories are excellent, better than anything in "Crow Fair", in my opinion.  The clunker is the title story, which also is the longest; it was so raunchy and unpromising that I gave up on it about one quarter of the way into it.  (As was the case with using "Crow Fair" for the title of the most recent collection, I wondered why McGuane -- or his publisher -- used "To Skin a Cat" as the title story.)Seven of the thirteen stories are set in Montana, two in the South, and two in Ohio (or thereabouts).  In many of the stories, one of the main characters is on a tear, rebelling against conventionality and seemingly hell-bent on offending everyone around.  This, of course, is not at all uncommon in McGuane's fiction.  Three of the stories feature bird dogs, including the best one, "Flight".  It is one of the few stories in which the main character is not fighting the life circumstances he finds himself in; he is, however, disconcerted by the prospect of death, which he is reminded of when he learns that his close friend from youth has a terminal illness:  "We've all got to go, I thought.  It's like waiting for an alarm to go off, when it's too dark to read the dial."In TO SKIN A CAT, as usual, McGuane is entertaining.  He is especially good at exposing, ruefully and comically, some of the myths of America, particularly those of Montana and the West.  But he rarely shows much compassion for his characters, and he rarely digs very far below the surface.  When, occasionally, he does -- as in "The Millionaire" or in "Flight" -- he can be excellent.

I have been fascinated with Siena since taking a college course about the Middle Ages and the Renaissance.  Then, about twenty years ago, I was fortunate enough to spend a week in and around Siena; it was a high point of my rather limited experiences as a world traveller.  I doubt that I will return, although I would love to.  Given that background, I probably was much more predisposed to like SIENA by Jane Tylus than the average general reader.  Having read it, I doubt that it will persuade people unfamiliar with the city that it is indeed one of the more special and singular cities on earth.  However, for those who already are enamored with Siena, or are going there for an extended visit, the book should not be missed.Jane Tylus is a professor of Italian studies and comparative literature at New York University.  She spent considerable time in Siena over the years.  Her book is a learned and literate -- and loving -- survey of Siena and many of the sites, people, and cultural artifacts that make it special.  (The center of the city is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.)  She gives some attention to the contrade, or neighborhoods of Siena, and to the Palio, the famous horse race around the Piazza del Campo held twice each summer.  She also discusses some of the more famous buildings of the city -- for example, the Duomo, the Palazzo Pubblico, and the Spedale di Santa Maria della Scala (about 1,000 years old and one of the world's oldest hospitals).  But she focuses more on the past of Siena, especially its cultural past.  Among the famous Sienese who figure prominently in her account are Saint Catherine (her preserved though shriveled head can be seen in a side chapel of San Domenico; her body is interred in Rome) and Aeneas Silvia Piccolomini, better known as Pope Pius II.The book does not really serve well as a travel guide to Siena.  Nor, as a history, is it comprehensive.  (For example, relatively scant attention is given to the Black Death plague of 1348, which reduced the population of Siena by about two-thirds.)  Instead, the book seems to cover what most interests Jane Tylus.  Moreover, she is not systematic in her presentation.  Rather, her text meanders from topic to topic, returning again and again to some while leaving others mentioned only once.  In noting these points, I am not being critical; Tylus's approach is an idiosyncratic but ultimately charming one.SIENA is a handsome book.  It is quite well-written, with a flowing style that I found reminiscent of Ingrid D. Rowland (whom Tylus quotes).  Sometimes, however, the prose began to wash over me and lull me into a doze, a phenomenon, by the way, I also have experienced reading Rowland.  The book includes thirty-five illustrations, mostly Sienese works of art and most in color.  There also are three maps, but I would have appreciated more detailed maps on which one could more readily locate all sites discussed in the text.

Recently my eldest son and I had a lively discussion about what were the five most significant battles of the twentieth century -- not necessarily the biggest or bloodiest, but the ones that most influenced the course of history.  Our agreed final list, in chronological order:  Verdun, Midway, Stalingrad, the Allied invasion of Normandy (D-Day), and Dien Bien Phu.  Although written nearly fifty years ago, HELL IN A VERY SMALL PLACE remains the classic account (at least in English) of the last of those landmark battles.The French landed in force in the remote valley of Dien Bien Phu, in northwest Vietnam about thirteen miles from Laos, on November 20, 1953.  Almost immediately Viet-Minh forces began surrounding them.  The Viet-Minh began their assault of DBP with a massive artillery bombardment on March 13, 1954.  For the next fifty-six days the Viet-Minh besieged the French strongpoints, inexorably reducing them, until May 7, 1954, when the last remaining French installations were overrun.  With their defeat at DBP, the French abandoned Indochina, leaving it to the Vietnamese themselves and the Americans to stave off nationalistic communism.When I first learned about DBP, my initial question was, Why there?  What was so important about that remote village and valley?  As Bernard Fall writes, the French stationed themselves there hoping to draw the Viet-Minh into a set-piece battle, on the belief that that would be the best way in the circumstances to destroy a large part of the Viet-Minh army as rapidly as possible.  It was, as Fall puts it, "an incredible gamble."  General Vo Nguyen Giap called the French "all-in" bet and won.  And the world order of first-tier powers versus all the rest was shaken to its foundations, an earthquake that continues rumbling.Fall's account is a detailed one, replete with military information such as the Orders of Battle.  A separate sub-section of one to ten pages is dedicated to events of each of the fifty-six days of the siege.  But Fall writes so well, and intersperses his narrative with sufficient anecdotes, that by and large he avoids tedium.  In addition, he lucidly covers larger issues, both those military and strategic in nature within the French command and those international in scope, including the ambivalent involvement of the United States.  I was not looking for so much detail, and ideally I would have preferred an intelligently abridged version of the book, but looking back I don't begrudge being exposed to so much information because Fall presents it so very well.Among the points and highlights of the book:  the schism between the overall French commander in Indochina, Henri Navarre, and his immediate subordinate Ren Cogny; the gross, and fatal, underestimation by the French of Viet-Minh capabilities, especially those that were logistical in nature (the Viet-Minh were able to supply their siege by means of 20,000 coolies over 500 miles of jungle road); the gross inadequacy of French fortifications; critical French deficiencies in the air, both airborne firepower and air transport for delivering reinforcements and supplies; the immense problems of sheltering and treating the wounded; how the latter half of the battle was fought during the monsoon season and thus the French positions were waterlogged; and how many of the French kept going with the help of benzedrine.Two things relating to the Americans particularly registered.  As the French position at DBP became desperate and the Americans engaged in an internal debate about whether to intervene in force, some proposed dropping atomic bombs around DBP.  One of those was Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, who said to the French Foreign Minister Georges Bidault, "And if we gave you two atomic bombs to save Dien Bien Phu?"  More generally, Dulles is revealed, once again, to have been both thuggish and highly disingenuous in his diplomacy.But what's most impressive is the courage and tenacity displayed by both the Viet-Minh and many of the French Union forces (which, in addition to Frenchmen, included Vietnamese, Algerians, Moroccans, and Foreign Legion soldiers drawn from Germany, eastern Europe, and elsewhere).  At one point in the battle, a Viet-Minh officer gathered a bunch of dazed Algerian soldiers and directed them, as prisoners, to the rear; suddenly the Algerians stopped as they were blocked by the body of a Viet-Minh rifleman draped over barbed wire with his intestines hanging out; the Viet-Minh officer motioned the Algerians to proceed, saying, "You can step on him.  He has done his duty for the People's Army."Only one aspect of the book bothers me, based on what I otherwise know.  Fall writes as if there were a direct causal link between, on the one hand, Dien Bien Phu and the victory of the Viet-Minh, and, on the other, events in Algeria from November 1954 to March 1962.  Fall implies (a) that the Algerians would not have rebelled without the example of the Indochina war, and (b) that right-wing French military officers acted as they did in Algeria, including their formation of the OAS, due to the Maoist/Communist lessons on "mass terror" they had absorbed in Indochina.  I am skeptical about both implications.Still, HELL IN A VERY SMALL PLACE is an excellent and very instructive hybrid of journalism and history.

I can't say that Thomas McGuane produces great literature, but with CROW FAIR I now have read nine of his books over the years.  That's more than I have read of William Faulkner.  So there clearly is something to McGuane.  Here's what I think his appeal is, at least for me:  He is an excellent writer; there is plenty of dead-pan humor; his tales are always a little askew, which makes them more entertaining; there are plenty of gimlet-eyed observations about contemporary America (at least, contemporary white America); and he never demands much from the reader.  In a way, he is like Elmore Leonard.CROW FAIR is McGuane's third collection of short stories -- here, seventeen of them.  Most of the stories are set in Montana.  All feature characters who are social misfits of one stamp or another; they do not "fit in".  They might not all be "losers", but none are winners.  Some are angry about it while others are merely rueful.  For almost everyone, life has not worked out they way they planned or desired.  There are few (if any) stable, enduring marriages.Yet there is no real sense of tragedy.  (The closest is "Hubcaps", which features a mentally handicapped kid, Ben.  But "Hubcaps" is more bleak than tragic.  It also is anomalous in that it is set in Wisconsin.)  For McGuane, alienation and loneliness, failed relationships, the hollowness of the American Dream (or, the Montana Dream) -- all that is simply Life As It Is, worthy of wry or caustic wit but not tragedy.None of the stories in CROW FAIR take your breath away.  Most are quite good.  They all are told with a brisk pace.  Of the nine McGuane books that I have read, CROW FAIR slots somewhere in the upper middle of the pack.  Which means that even at age seventy-five there has been no discernible drop in McGuane's writing or storytelling abilities.
