Plus I'm hungry in the morning and usually late, so I slice that banana fast. It's more like wedges, some thick, some thin. Hardly conducive to fine dining. It's the slippery slope, those off kilter slices and next thing you know, you're shoving them in your mouth as soon as their sliced, four or five at a time, and just grabbing a fistful of Cheerios, shoving that it too, and washing it down with a swig of milk out of the carton.  Is that any way to live (actually it is; it's fun and you don't have a dish to wash). This gives you all the slices at one time, and precisely cut.  But even more important, it somehow elevates you to this whole new realm where you could be of eating out of a bowl, and with a spoon like gourmets and humans.So you decide. Do we tank civilization for an easier way to slice a banana?  Remember. Civilization is rules, getting up when the alarm clock goes off, uncomfortable underwear, commuting in traffic, standing on line at the DMV and paying bills.  Chaos on the other hand is laid back, sleeping in when it rains, no alarm clocks, putting sugar on anything, making slurping noises when you eat spaghetti and never having to contribute to the office birthday fund.Think about it.

For anyone who has tried to shove the made-for-catfood plastic lid onto the half-eaten can of olives, or who has struggled with tin foil covers for the condensed milk, this is a small but wonderful breakthrough. Cheap plastic caps and lots of sizes, so whatever you have opened and eaten half of, you can find cover it up and save it for later.Oh, sure, you could be one of those people who immediately pours the leftovers into the little right-sized Tupperware container and close it (burping the lid, of course).  But if you are just an ordinary human being struggling against a tide of technology and overcrowded cupboards, you can't find 'em. And if you find the container, you can't find the lid. These doohickeys eliminate the middle man.  Can, cover, finished. Nothing to wash later on. And even better, you can see it's a can of Kitty Stew, or sliced, pitted olives. No guessing.  It eliminates one step of labor and helps prevent the "What's that smell" refrigerator search. Something in one of those plastic containers has gone rank and you have to open all 230 to find it.  With the cap, you know it's not the canned peaches because you just put them in a week ago, but those picked beets...aren't they from last Thanksgiving?There are lids for most can sizes(not the big giant ones like coffee cans or industrial sized pickles, but all regular stuff).  They're cheap so you can buy two sets because you know you're going to lose at least a couple.Very handy, affordably priced and, until I send them down the disposal, accidentally toss them in the trash, or otherwise get rid of them, they're a nice little extra. Five stars.

Brad Pitt spends a lot of time running down streets, sneaking around in the dark, walking through crowded corridors with other survivors, and as an exciting denouement, racing up and down almost identical laboratory corridors.  It's the end of the world, Living Dead style. There are some scary moments. And they are very good, which makes you see exactly how dismal the rest of the film is.  I was moderately entertained until the laboratory sequence, when I realized that being bitten by a ghoul was a picnic in the country compared to watching more of Pitt tiptoeing past zombies in labcoats, pushing security button door openers and piling gurneys against swinging doors. We have all seen the other movies, they all did the same thing.  "28 Days" and its sequel were better and they weren't wonderful.  The book the film is 'based' on, which was written by Max Brooks, son of comic genius Mel, is an oral history of our planet's encouters with zombies and very well done.  Too bad they just used the title.If you want to see a really chilling zombie film, something original but that sticks to our essential Romero Rules, you have to keep waiting. And if anyone knows of a film that lives up to the standard set by Romero's original "Night of the Living Dead," please let me know.  I don't think I've seen it.

And even so, I was overcharged.Grant's last wife undertakes to tell us all about her brief fling and briefer wedded bliss with the acting icon. Let's simplify.  She was about 25 years younger and vapid; He was older, sophisticated and just not that interested. Not that he had other women, he was just was kind of lukewarm about the whole relationship. Maybe even women.  Whatever, it's mostly an on off-again/off again courtship. Grant doesn't seem exactly hot for this ingenue. He is unemotional. They date, nothing much happens. He disappears, he reappears. They date some more, they break up, reunite, break up, reunite, and then they get married. The marriage is rocky. Go figure.Ms. Cannon spares us not a moment of ennui, dragging us along through the entire lackluster romance. And when I say 'spares us nothing,' I'm not whistling Dixie. At the end of the story, we find her tormented, wondering where she went wrong, who failed whom, and could things have been different. So she asks God for the answer. And God responds by inspiring her to write a poem that explains it all. And she shares that poem with us. All of it.No, God did not smite her. We have a benevolent diety. And a patient one. The reader, on the other hand, wouldn't have hesitated.To sum up, there is nothing here.. Nothing to learn, no romance, no emotion, nothing to enjoy, no good gossip to savor.  This book is so bad, it makes me regret my one good eye.

I tried to walk away.  Quit. Just say goodbye.  But it's impossible. How can you turn your back on Caroline, the evil genius who poses as a caring friend and mother but, in fact, is the source of all the real drama. The woman is sublime in her badness.  And then there's Teresa Guidice, with the amazing hair and crooked husband. Her Joe is literally as wide as he is tall, tough little bugger, except he's either narcoleptic or drunk all the time. Hard to tell.Teresa is the current Villain of the piece (I don't think the world at large is onto Caroline yet, but I hope they figure it out and soon).  She is hilarious. A woman of oversized assets, Teresa crams herself into clothing that is pink, leopard-spotted, shiny, feathered or leather-ish.  No color is too bright, no style too outr.  For this woman, sequins are the new black.  But she's not evil. Just jealous.  She is not, let's say, the smartest anchovy in the bagna cauda.  A published author, Mrs. Guidice 'writes' cookbooks. Ok, actually she just poses for pictures among the recipes collected by some worker bees, but still, standing and facing the camera is, you know, work. it must take hours to get that make up on. And somebody has to round up the kids.  And oh boy, what kids.The oldest, 11 going on 45, is a world-weary cynic, a model and dancer, who seems to know way, way too much about the ins and outs of marital relations and family dysfunction, not to mention teased hair, hair extensions and weekly pedicures. All three little girls who range down to about five, are fighters and biters. They whine, they complain, they pose hands on hips and toss their manes. Just like mama. One can only hope they surprise us all and don't grow up into what we're all expecting.Anyway, Teresa isn't bad, she just envies any woman younger, prettier or slimmer. Okay, in her crowd there are not many, these women obviously like to eat and their spandex capris aren't helping things out.  Neither is the make up.  Lashes out to there, orange lipstick on gigantically inflated lips. I mean, the lips are so big, I'll bet they need ladles to eat soup.  And the eye make up? I'm not kidding. If you want faux mink lashes, black liner and Super-Extending Mascara, I'll bet you have to drive down to Delaware to get it.  So we know how Teresa must feel. Even with all the Special Effects make up, there is something simian about her face. She's not a beauty and she's not so young. Or so skinny. When she encounters someone who is, watch out.Mostly Teresa is jealous of her sister in law, the sexy and slender (by comparison) Melissa Gorga...prettier and younger and wife to Teresa's brother. Who is more successful than Teresa's husband, not cheating on his wife, and not under indictment. Who wouldn't be jealous?  The brother is also as wide as he is tall, but he does have beautiful eyes and at least stays awake.  Mrs. Gorga thought she could sing at one point, and for almost one full year we watched various producers show up to get big bucks from her husband as they tried (almost successfully)to pretend she had talent. Anyway, Teresa hates her.There are other men and women besides the core group...we have extra sisters and brothers, parents and aunts and uncles, cousins, one idiot cousin in law and one gay one, and lots of frenemies, but aside from all having world-class heavyweight keisters, they don't count for much. They change sides, gossip, wear awful clothes and have their own rococo homes.  We don't care about them.  It's Caroline, Teresa and Melissa who are the magic.Caroline is older than the others, a lot older. And fatter.  And she always looks unkempt.  No wonder she stirs up trouble.  Her children are extremely strange. The boys have no visible means of support other than some questionable 'PR' business that trades on their mother's fame. They appear to be pushing 30, both of them, and their mom just bought them a "really classy" bachelor pad in Newark -- full of leatherette furniture and what looks to be at least three faux stone fountains. One of the sons...the visionary...treasures a dream of one day owning a combination strip-club/car wash.  The daughter (after many seasons' worth of trauma and skin of her teeth graduation from manicurist college)now has her own nail salon, also courtesy of a generous mama.Okay, are you hooked yet?  Trust me, watch this show. No matter how screwed up you are, how bad your family is, you can't sit through sixty minutes of this without thinking "Whew."  But for the grace of god and some decent taste in clothes, make up and men, there go all of us.I started out with Real Housewives of New York, but the women are at least 20 years past their sell-by dates.  No fun watching Grandma carousing in her Gucci hip boots. But the Jersey Gals...just try them.  I haven't even mentioned Jaqueline yet...or Caroline's sister from the first season who will not speak to her sister or discuss the show ever, with anyone...except TV bloggers and newspaper columnists and tabloids.  And Joe Guidice? Don't get me started.  He's going to jail, probably, and maybe Teresa will spend a night or two in dire incarceration as well.  Or Caroline's dad-in-law who was NOT, don't get her dander up on this) a member of organized crime in any way, shape or form, just because he was gunned down while entering his favorite restaurant (and it wasn't a sushi bar, know what I mean.  Any resemblance between that contretemps and, oh, say, a gangland execution is purely coincidental.  Yep.Watch this show. It's just plain fun.

I've had my Kindle for quite a while and just lost the original recharger. I got a new one from Amazon (after checking in with customer service to make sure it was what I needed).  It is about as idiot-proof as you can get, which is essential for me. You get this and the power cord, put it together, attach to the Kindle and plug it in.  It is a little pricey, since I'll bet it costs 30 cents to make in some prison factory somewhere, and really, they could just throw in the power cord for free, since they are gouging you for this gizmo, but I am starting to understand Amazon policy. I think.  They are so customer-centric, they err on our side all the time, so bargain basement pricing would hurt them.  On my original phone call, I asked about a different recharger and was given incorrect information.  I complained and within about ten minutes, the Amazon 'live chat' person fixed the dilemma and gave me both pieces free of charge.  A simple "I'm sorry" would have been okay, but this gracious offer knocked me out.  I've heard other people talk about how eager Amazon can be to fix things when they are truly in the wrong.  I've dealt with expensive department stores that aren't this sensitive or customer-friendly.  I know people love to complain about Amazon, but I have to say, I have never, in about ten years of doing business, had a single unsolved problem or one situation that left me unhappy. I can't thing of another retailer who has that kind of a record with me.  Imagine coming away from a shopping trip at Rite-Aid or Wal-Mart and thinking "Boy, I'm really satisfied with the way they treated me...they knew what they were doing, went out of their way to help." Yeah.Right. And you can see the flying pigs at the same time.So five stars for a simple product that does the job, but really, the stars are for how easy Amazon makes it do buy things.  If you hate amazon, I'm sure you have your reasons...but so far, this has been one seamless decade for me.

I am modern, pragmatic, a minimalist and absolutely impatient with froufrou, nonsense, tchatchkis and other silliness. You show me your unicorn collection and chances are I'm gonna take a swing at you.  So, there is no excuse whatsoever for me having the Teapot Beyond Teapot Fair with Tea Warmer Cozy.  Except...I love it.This is just the prettiest little teapot one could find. I have a very sturdy and serviceable Brown Betty that works just fine and an ultramodern pot that is all angles and laboratory glass that someone sent me from Italy. It is very hip.  But I don't love them.  That's reserved for my Teapot Fairy.  I'm not even embarrassed about saying the words.  Teapot Fairy.  There. Make something of it.For one thing, this little pot makes three fine cups of tea, which is to be expected.  Normally I'd swig my tea out of a mug that says Shop or Die. I'm one step away from eating my dinner out of the frying pan and consider styrofoam clamshells an acoutrement of fine dining. But I found myself sipping, not glugging. Out of a cup. With a saucer. With lemon slices. And sugar cubes.  Next thing you know, I'll be wearing underwear even when I don't expect company.But this is not just empty frivolity. This is a serious teapot.  The lid fits well, and the glass handle is heat-resistant so you can pick it up without burning yourself. The pot itself is made of tempered glass so you have no worries about pouring in the boiling water.  And then it sits on a pretty little glass bowl where your tiny little votive candle sets the mood and keeps the next two cups nice and warm for you! A festive little teaparty whenever you want.  Of course if you really want to push the boat out, you have make use one of those fancy blooming teas -- a special treat when you really need one.In the interests of honesty, I want to make it clear that I received this teapot in exchange for a review. Months and months ago. I was embarrassed to admit how gooey and silly I am about it, so I kept putting off the moment of truth. But here it is...five stars for something that's pretty and feminine and considerably more than just a pretty pot. In the even greater interests of honesty, I must admit that I am only a second generation cup drinker. My grandmother used to pour her tea from the cup into the saucer, blow on it, stir it with a Stella D'Oro Anisette Cresent, and then take a gracious but noisy slug. Her pinky would be raised, of course. We were not animals. And she always let me share the cookie.  My grandfather would only drink his tea out of a glass while hold a sugar cube between his teeth.  I have never mastered this trick and if you would try it, I suggest doing it while naked or else risking tea stains on your clothes. And I'd let it cool off a little first.Whether your lifestyle is simple, decorative or as in my case, semi-feral, I think you'll get a kick out of this pretty little pot. Sometimes it's nice to treat yourself like someone special.

For $20 you get a very well designed water bottle. The size is just right for bicycling, the stainless steel body is sturdy and has so far resisted my attempts to damage it by falling off my bike and onto the bottle.The Hydracentials Slim Grip is designed with hand holds so you can get a good grip on the thing, even if your palms are sweaty from pumping that bike uphill on a hot day.  There is a built in straw, it's easy to fill and has a 'leakproof' closure. So far so good. I have had a couple of bottles with screw tops you had to be Dwayne "the Rock" Johnson to open. They even give you a little instruction card on how to clean the thing, in case use of hot water and dish soap has eluded you until now.The size is generous, holding 25 ounces, it fits in bike carrier and the beverage holder in a car.  The only negative is that $20 price tag. Pretty high, since the Hydracentials isn't insulated or double walled, so liquids don't stay really cold after a about two hours. You can't put the thing in the freezer or microwave either.  But if you are willing to spend the money, there are no obvious problems yet so I have to go with Five stars.

Once again Krud Kutter comes through with a cleaning product that works better than expected, doesn't require any heavy labor on the part of the user, and makes a dirty, disgusting job easier.  I have used their grease cleaners, household cleaners, carpet cleaners, and window cleaners and am a Big fan.  The Krud Kutter for Carpets gets rid of stains that a professional carpet cleaner swore were impossible.  The regular Krud Kutter cleaner got the EPA to back off and remove my bathroom from that list with Fukushima, Chernobyl and 3-Mile Island.  So, when I saw they had another cleaner for mold and mildew, I rejoiced and tried it on a really nasty culprit that keeps fighting me for possession of the bathtub.Normally I take straight chlorine bleach, soak paper towels in it, and place them along the discolored bathtub surround. It bleaches the caulking to a sparking white and removes all the lining in my lungs and the skin on my fingers.  I hate doing it, but I hate bathing with black gunk looking up at me too.  And a week later I do it again, because one thing you gotta say about mold and mildew around here, they are persistent.  I've been married to people who didn't hang around as long.Anyway, I gave Krud Kutter Mold and Mildew Stain a try. It works as well as the Chlorine Last Ditch Kill or Be Killed Method, but it's a lot easier to do. And the black gook has not come back as quickly...maybe it's not for gone good, but it's been a while and I'm hoping.  To make sure, I just spray a bit on a sponge when I do my regular cleaning and go over the grouting around the tub.  It just takes a minute, so even a lazy person like me is not overwhelmed.Once I overpowered the tub, I looked around for new worlds to conquer...and there it was: The Stinky Patio Chair Cushion. You could smell the mildew on this from down the block.  I wiped it down with Krud Kutter and let it sit in the sunshine for a day, and did it again, repeating the process three or four times. It got rid of the mildew and the stink.  Okay, maybe I would not bring the cushion inside, but outdoors on the patio, even My Neigbor Who Cleans did not make a face about it when she sat down, and this is a woman who practically has a coronary when she sees my kitchen.  Anyway, Krud Kutter scored another triumph and I can go to sleep at night without looking to see if Erin Brockovich is lurking around taking notes. Five clean, fresh-smelling stars.

After a certain age, our skin must come to a screeching halt when it comes to moisture. Suddenly I'm plagued with dryness, face, hands, everplace...and particularly on my legs.  I've been using various creams and lotion for the last couple of millenia, but I let those poor shins of mine go to Aitch Eee Double Hockeysticks in a handcart.  Shame on me.  This dryness leaves skin looking rough and red and flaky and makes legs itch like crazy. Usually right after I get in bed and get comfortable.  And I'm sorry, but having dry, flaky shins is such an Old Geezerette thing, it's embarrassing. I may have reached my sell-by date, but I'm not old. Not that old anyway. I shouldn't have problems my grandmother did.After I noticed how horrible my legs were getting, and after I scratched myself raw, I went out and spent a small fortune on various moisturizers but it was like locking the barn door after the horse died of old age.  My legs were still rough looking if I didn't marinate them twice a day.  I saw the Eucerin on offer from Vines and gave it a shot.  Boy howdy. One use and it was like the skin on my legs was drinking the stuff up. I didn't have to rub...it just sank it.  My skin looks the way it should, the way it used to...smooth and sleek. And it feels soft, no ugly flaking. Best of all, there is no itching.  I use it on my arms and legs now, especially elbows and knees, which can look like the joints on a camel if you aren't careful.I love Eucrin. It's certainly inexpensive, it works better than I expected. It feels clean going on, there is no greasy residue, it soaks into your skin fast, doesn't leave oily stains on clothes or bed linens, and it doesn't have that old person Ben Gay odor.  The fragrance is extremely light, almost undetectable, and not anything one would connect with old folks. If you have severely dry skin, and it itches, try this stuff.  I can't tell you about how it works on Eczema, but since it is gentle enough for babies, it might help adults without any harmful side effects.  Five soothing, hydrating, no-itch stars!

A nice pair of memo pages for your regrigerator!  They are made of a lightweight metal with magnetized backs, are erasable, and come with a magnetized marking pen. One page is lavendar, the other white, and they both have a delicate floral design.  I don't like clutter on the refrigerator, and these are nice and low key and give you a place to write BUY MILK.  As if you'll remember when you're at the store.  You can jot down dental appointments or believable alibis for your real location, doodle, whatever. When you're done, just wipe it off.  No evidence. I am not a career criminal, but I was married.  Right now mine has a doodle of a monkey eating something...maybe a hamster? Don't read too much into it. Most of what I draw looks like hamsters.  Anyway, these are functional, inexpensive and very handy. What they aren't is foolproof. I can write down a shopping list, but who's gonna make me remember to take it to the store?If you are organized, these will provide you with yet another way to lord it over your lesser brothers and sisters.  As if you needed one.  For those in the middle, maybe they'll push you into the Organized camp.  Just don't go around gloating.The Quartet ReWritables Daily Quick List Magnets with Marker deserves four big stars. Why not five? The erasable marker is not very good. It is too light, the ink doesn't show up clearly, and the magnet is not strong enough to keep it on the refrigerator door. Mine fell off and rolled underneath and no power on earth can make me go looking under there. I have not cleaned under the fridge since I got the fridge.  I think I know where they put Jimmy Hoffa.

My hair is naturally a sort of dirty blonde, and I started playing with the color when I was fifteen. That was a long time ago. Long.  Bleach, dye, streaks, highlights? You bet. Does anyone remember those wonder Sherry and Mahogany cellophane wraps from the 80s?  I like anything that revives the color and saves me an expensive trip to the salon. Right now I have a sort of dark blonde with various highlights.  Looks nice, but boy, the upkeep needs a professional.  I used the John Frieda Warm Brunette Glosser as an experiment. I was afraid it might be too dark and destroy the highlighting, but it works rather well.  I am going to be able to wait another two or three weeks between salon appointments. Right now, every six weeks or so has been my schedule, but this might help me hold out for 9 weeks, maybe more. Since I'm about to retire, saving money is important and for $6.95, this is a good option.On the downside, it's messy, drippy, and I don't know the long-term damage it might do if used regularly.  If you hate using drippy home hair colorings, you won't like this stuff any better. But if you want a cheap temporary fix, get used to it.  You have to do the coloring in the shower, in takes a little time, and it's not the most fun ever, but I'm willing to suffer for beauty. (Who am I kidding...I'm willing to suffer to save money.)  After using it, my hair is a tiny bit darker, but the blonder highlights remain, so it doesn't look like a bad one-note dye job.  And there is certainly a lot of gloss...which is I normally acquire by spending even more money at the salon.  So, for a money-saving and pretty good way to get some extra time out of your hair coloring, for a way to make your hair look shiny and sexy, Four Stars.  If it didn't drip down my neck in the shower, I'd give it five.

I don't care how many closets you have, it's not enough.  I am forever hunting for the grey shirt with the white stripe, that other silk blouse, no not that one, the one with the double buttons on the cuff.  And didn't I used to have pants in the perfect camel color, because I haven't seen them in a long time. In other words, my closets are like most peoples...overstuffed, disorganized and chock full of clothes I don't remember buying, let alone ever wearing. And why is everything so small?I tried the J.S. Hanger Natural Wood Skirt Hangers/Pant Hangers with Etc., and they work just fine. The wood is a nice weight, not too heavy but substantial. The metal clips have a nice snap to them...it doesn't feel like the spring is going to wear out soon. And they're nice and tight. I used them to hang five pairs of trousers, one of which is lined wool and quite thick, one is silk and slippery, and the rest linen and wool blends.  The thick trousers are held perfectly. The clips provide enough room so I'm not worried about them digging into the fabric and leaving marks. The slipper silk, which half the time ends up on the floor of the closet, is held tightly too.  I gave them a little tug and it looks like they are there to stay.  I notice one reviewer says the hangers are cheap and flimsy.  I don't know what kind of hangers they're used to, but these are as good as any I've seen. Maybe not the kind the haute couture comes with, but certainly as good as the kind most of us use, probably a bit better.  The quality is certainly above average, even for hangers that cost a bit more.If you have limited closet space, or are one of those weirdos who like to be organized, I don't think you can find a better set of trouser/skirt hangers. Especially not for this price.  Hangers are one of those items where you can pay a fortune for junk or find the perfect set at the 99C store.  No rhyme nor reason. These are at the top of the Hanger List.  They save space, are extremely lightweight, feel durable, and do exactly what you need them to do.  If you travel and use a garment bag, they'll come in handy as well, saving lots of space.I'm thinking of getting a couple of sets for Christmas gifts this year.  Everyone on the planet has enough scented soap, aromatherapy candles and bath salts, but nobody ever has enough hangers. Think about it.Or else I'll buy a bunch and keep them for myself...the more likely scenario. So what if I spend another Christmas Eve at Rite-Aid wondering who got the lavender bath set and who got the Orchard Body Spray Collection last year.  At least I won't be ironing my silk pants every time I want to wear them.  If I remember to hang them up in the first place. So, five stars for the hangers, zero for me for throwing stuff on the closet floor and hoping for little cleaning elves.

This little gizmo is now in my car glove compartment, along with the Emergency Perfume, mascara, hairbrush and moisturizer.  I don't know if I will ever need it, but there is a feeling of security just knowing it's there. I don't camp and I don't go places that are dangerous, but you never know. And I have a lousy sense of direction. Once while heading for a shoe sale I ended up in some quarry where there were big red signs about dynamiting and a lot of angry men in hard hats came running at me.The Friendly Swede Carabiner has a 3 inch bundle wrapped in braided paracord. The whole package is small and virtually weightless, but there is a bunch of good stuff inside.  I know because I went an unraveled the darn thing.  You should trust the Friendly Swede. Once you unwrap that paracord, you can't rebraid it. I keep mine in a tiny leather pouch now...not much bigger, but not nearly as cool.What you get for your $15 is a lot. Starting that paracord ...nine feet of it and potentially very helpful if you remember what Bear Grylis taught us about building a shelter out of sticks and  leaves, bundling our belongings, or finding dry wood and making little floats that help us when crossing a stream or lake, that sort of thing. However It  doesnt look terribly strong and I would not use drag myself up or down a mountain or anything like that. And given my fear of heights, if there are mountains in front of me, Im staying put anyway.The grenade also contains two separate fishing lines with hooks, sinkers and bobs for each.  Not fancy, but I dont think a fish would carealthough those of us who do go fishing know that those little rascals can make themselves scare when we really want them.  You get a nice hunk of tin foil, which can be used as a heat reflector, to wrap your leftover fish, turn into a solar still (Bear Grylis explained it allnot much water, but better than none...and if you didnt watch him or Les Stroud or the rather sexy Mike Hawk and wife, you should rent the tapes or stay indoors.The kit also contains an alcohol swab for cleansing stuff like wounds and a needle for those who dont have the foresight to have a sewing kit. The instructions say this can be used for suturing wounds, but if we are camping and you have foolishly torn yourself open and expect me to sew you back together, it's not gonna work.  Id pretend I was looking for water and just leave you.  And there's a chance I would have sucked the alcohol out of the pad when I discovered we were lost.  On the other hand, I would not go all Donner Party on you either so look at the bright side.There is quite a bit of wire included as wellfor making snares to trap small animals.  I dont know if I could make a snare that would fool even that one rabbit that the other rabbits point at, but at least its there.  Most important is the fire starter. Yes, you can actually make sparks with it. They even provide some tinder. Les Stroud made it very clear that the stick rubbing thing ain't gonna happen, so this is crucial. Fire keeps away big animals, makes you easier to spot, and keeps you warm.  I never remember to include matches in my first aid kit, so this is a very good thing. You also get a tiny but very sharp knife...enough for cooking purposes, I suppose, and cleaning the fish, that sort of thing. And another thing my survival materials did not have.All in all, the kit seems well thought out. I'd give one to those outdoorsy types who like to camp, or to anyone who lives or travels through underdeveloped areas.  For me, the "grenade" is going to sit in my glove compartment, forgotten, along with the reminder about my 2014 car registration (It's a smog year...who can bother?).  But if I ever find myself down at the Silver Queen Quarry instead of the Glendale Mall again, I'll feel a little bit better.  Although I have not tried the product, it certainly looks practical and provides the essentials.  Good things in a small package, so five stars.

One good reason why shopping and drinking don't mix. Anyway, it's a heavy little bugger so when you get it, figure out where to put it right away. If you plug it in, do not use the toaster oven at the same time. Or the vacuum.  And, um, keep the cats away from it. Just trust me on that one.  Three stars because I only got the minor injuries and the cat was old anyway.

I used the Durable Pet Comb by Dog Grooming Supplies on my large and independent-minded cat.  Anna Nicole is enormous, has enough fur for herself and at least one other animal, and an attitude that some might call 'entitled.'  Others might say 'rabid.'  She looks like a long-haired Siamese, white with pale gray and peach markings, and is quite beautiful, unless you cheese her off. Then all you see is Teeth and Size.  She moves fast for a big 'un.Anyway, Anna Nicole (aka AhNo) developed a sizable mat on her chest.  I wanted to cut it off, but we have this basic disagreement of philosophies when I get out the brush and scissors.  I try to be gentle, she tries to kill me.  And I'm terrified that as she wriggles and twists, I'm liable to hurt her.  To make a long story short, I used the comb as a guard.  First I got it in position under the mat, took the pet grooming scissors (they have a ball at the end of the blades, instead of a point...no accidental jabbing of critter or human) and started cutting. What surprised me is that the grooming comb was also working to gently separate the hairs, sort of dematting as it protected AhNo's skin.  She had some mats-in-the-making on her tummy, which combed out quite easily. You just sort of wriggle and glide the comb and it gets through the tangles without pulling. Scissors help where the mat is severe.Brushing does keep the mats from forming, but this cat is a mat factory.  The comb is non-invasive and takes out a lot of loose hairs when I groom her. She has not minded me combing her and kind of likes it.  Her sister, Jane Air (also known as "Please come out, I know you're around somewhere) appeared briefly to look confused and go back behind whatever it is she goes behind.  I'm afraid she is the kind of cat the other cats would whisper about. If I ever see her again, I'll try the comb on her.  She doesn't bite.  Her trick is waiting until I'm asleep in bed and then diving on my stomach from the big dresser.Still, they're mine and I love them.  The comb works well, it helps untangle beginner mats, the curved teeth make it easy, and my extremely fussy cat is not bothered by it, and I have not been lacerated or punctured while using it, so Five Stars.

This small flashlight from Rayovac provides an awful lot of light. You can dim it down for walking the dog at night, or trying to find the bathroom during a power outage, or turn it on full blast and land a small plane in your back yard.  The weight is nice, not too heavy, but with a good heft. Nice to hold.  I do wish it had a wrist strap so you didn't have to keep your hand wrapped around.  I can probably work something out and add a lanyard or something, but that's the one thing this light is missing.Besides modesty.It claims to be 'indestructible."  Now, I don't take this sort of thing as a challenge, but I'm remarkably adept at breaking stuff.  Without even trying. I don't think they want me in most Nordstrums stores anymore since an incident with a rack of raincoats and a wall display that fell over, which wasn't even my fault. Mostly.  And when I was a baby, my grandmother named me Mountain Killer.  Not in a nice way.  I have gone through cars, hammers, husbands, all sorts of things that are supposed to be durable but, in fact aren't.The folks who tested the Rayovac  dropped it from a height of 30 feet without problems. The casing is aluminum and titanium alloy. I have no idea what this is, but it sounds good. Also it has an IPX4 Water Resistance Rating.  This means you can drop it in the water. I like to sail, but to tell you the truth, anything I drop overboard, especially something that I'd use in the dark, like a flashight, is going to stay there. I don't go in after it, so this part will probably not be tested.  The description also says that the rubber cover on the lens and tail are great shock absorbers.  Maybe.  Also the LEDs last "a lifetime" and will never need to be replaced. This is another claim that confuses me. Whose lifetime? I'm not saying how old I am, but a carrot could probably be guaranteed to last a lifetime if we're getting personal. So I'm giving the flashlight five stars because it does a lot of good things. The 'indestructible' claim remains to be tested. And the 'lifetime' guarantee.If it does break, I'll come back and change the review. But chances are I'll lose it first.

You really can't. Because somebody finally figured out that the best place to keep the slicing surfaces is inside the mandoline.  The OXO Good Grips Complete Grate and Slice Set is the perfect size and has all the attachments you need. Best of all, you store the grating/slicing platforms inside the container. I must have bought a dozen of these things over the years and somehow the grating surfaces disappear...they're like socks.  One minute they're there, next...Poof. Gone.  And since they aren't expensive, I buy more, except the only blade surfaces I have never fit the machine and I try to force them together and next thing I know, there is blood everywhere and nobody wants to even taste the carrot salad.  Cowards.  Anyway, this eliminates the problem. The container even has little slots so the attachments tuck away neatly once you snap on the cover. They couldn't escape if they tried.There are four blades, one for regular grating, one for coarse, one to slice and one for julienne slicing.  This gives you those skinny little strips that are impossible to cut by hand unless you are an expert and have nothing else to live for and the bathroom cleans itself. The set also comes with a food holder, so you are not risking your finger tips or knuckles everytime you make coleslaw.  The container snaps shut to hold leftovers, if you so choose, but really, who is going to risk losing the slicing gizmos. Keep the blades inside the slicer container. For storing leftovers, dig out one of the  storage containers inside your cupboard. You know the ones I mean...without the lids.  Why is it we all have 1 million little plastic containers of every shape and size, and one million different lids, but none of them go together? What happens at night? Do the lids change places with the ones next door? Is there some alien plot where Space Invaders do the switch to make us crazy and weaken our species?The blades on this Oxo Grater/Slicer are very sharp, by the way.  I just grated some past-their-sell-by carrots with no problem, and a piece of Jicama, which after you taste it, you'll know why it's not very popular.The gizmo comes with rubber feet so it won't skid...another smart little idea.  Nothing like slicing away at the jicama and have it fall on the floor where the dog steps on it and the cats chase hunks under the refrigerator and you have to scoop 'em up and rinse them off and hope nobody saw.  Please note: If you have ever eaten at my house, this has never happened; I am theorizing. Also the dog never licked the plates before they went in the dishwasher. Of after they came out.The product description says this is 'color coded.'  Every cutting surface has its own bright primary color, but I'm kind of missing the code.  I can see that the holes on one grater are bigger than on the other. They didn't have to be different colors.  And you can see that the Julienne slicer has a second blade. No trickery, no disguises. Even if it wasn't green, I would have figured it out. Eventually.  Maybe OXO doesn't realize just how clever I am. On the other hand, they know that I keep Tupperware lids and mandolin blades, so maybe they grade on a curve.  So, except for that mysterious 'code,' I'm delighted with the OXO Good Grips Complete Grate and Slicer Set. It's small, easy to store, has the right blade type for most kitchen jobs, looks nice, is convenient to use, well-designed and so far has not caused any mutilation. Five stars.And if anyone can figure out what I'm missing with the color thing, please explain. Slowly. And without rolling your eyes.

I have never used a programmable feeder before. My cats eat the same amount, no matter how much is placed in their bowl. When going away for the weekend, I'd just pour out a huge dish of dry food and several big bowls of water and ask a friend to check on them every day.  But the Crestuff Machine was offered to me for a review, so I decided to try this higher tech option.The unit is nice looking, feels substantial, and seems to be well made.  It works quite well and has several features that make it fun.  To start with, assembly is no problem, since it is just about complete straight out of the box. But programming the autofeed features is very difficult. It took any number of attempts, the use of a lot of creative swear words and recourse to the bourbon before I finally got it to do all the stuff it's supposed to. Or at least enough to reach a happy medium.The gizmo dispenses anywhere from 1/4 cup to 2 cups of food at a time, at times you set. You program in how much and how often.  In my case these were not precisely what I wanted but I was frustrated with trying to get it to work and as soon as I figured things out enough to get food dispensed and the timer set, I said 'enough.' If the cats want things more to their liking, they can reset the thing. Programming does get easier once you do it for a while, but there is a learning curve. A big one.When I set it up, I was not 100% convinced that it would work properly and feared some mishap...that it would jam or the food not come out. None of these things happened, so to begin with, I had it dispensing a lot of food. There were no failures, so I managed to cut the amount and number of feedings to a more reasonable amount and number, which eliminated a lot of food on the floor.  With most cats, leaving food out is not a problem. They'll take what they need and leave the rest for later. A dog, on the other hand, will eat until he explodes. Portioning is essential with pups. Still, I am a pessimist. If I'm going to be away for a day or two, I prepare for the worst case scenario, where the gizmo breaks and the catsitter is kidnapped by a roving band of disgrunted dachshunds. There is always that emergency bowl of dry food and a big bowl of water on the kitchen counter just in case. I mean, cats are cats. If something goes wrong, they'll blame me.The Crestuff has another interesting feature: it lets you record a message for your animals...you can call them to eat, tell them you love them, remind them to marry for money, whatever.  This may be reassuring. Probably is for dogs, but I have a feeling the cats just nudge one another and roll their eyes.  Besides, invitations don't work on cats. If they want to eat, they eat. Mostly they just slink up to the bowl, take a bite, look bored and walk away.  Of course if their dish is ever empty, they find me and torture me. But then, they do like torturing humans and it might not be food related at all.  And I notice it's not my voice that attracts them...it's the little buzzing noise the machine makes before the food comes out.  That makes them perk up their ears. My voice? Not so much.All in all, this is a real convenience for people who work or have to leave their animals for a day or two at a time. My Anna Nicole (aka AhNo) and Jane Air (aka I Know You're Here, Please Come Out) seem perfectly happy, the machine is their good and faithful servant, and if it just scratched their heads and changed the kitty litter, I'm sure they'd consider replacing me.  You never know with cats.  So four stars for operation. The fifth star would require easier set up.

The package containing the five canvas prints arrived a couple of days ago.  The first thing I noticed was how carefully and well packed it was, each piece separately swaddled in plastic wrap, and all contained in an exceptionally sturdy box.  Whoever packages these products makes sure that arrive in good condition.The second thing I noticed was the weight. These are not flimsy little nothings.  Each piece is mounted on a solid frame, the canvas stretched to wrap around the sides. Nothing chintzy or cheap about the construction.  The way they are constructed on a frame makes mounting very easy. We just measured, hammered in the hangars and the work was done. Per the manufacturers instructions, we left a couple of inches between each space. The five pieces make a BIG display.  In this case, the stretch across the wall behind an oversized green leather sofa. The sofa is fat...overstuffed and fairly plane. It cried out for an accent, and this group of panels does the job brilliantly.If you have bought reproduction paintings in the past, you may be surprised at the quality of the product by Global Nature Crafts. Usually pre-framed or ready to hang work that is affordably priced is pretty bad in terms of quality and construction.  These aren't disappointing and, in fact, are much better than what I expected.  I bought them for my niece who chose the subject matter. In this case, it's a misty autumnal forest in very pretty greens, browns and yellows.  The separation is done with care, not matching, but organized to work together as five separate pieces that form a single unit.  The colors are lovely. Realistic and somewhat subdued. The canvas is top quality and the grouping looks like we paid much, much more than the amazingly affordable price of under $150.This is, by the way, a BIG grouping. The individuals panels measure a little over one foot wide by just under 3 feet high. When you put them together across a wall, using the guidline 2 inch separation, you have a major statement.  If the colors were not so good, if the subject matter not so likable, and the quality not so admirable, you'd see it. But this -- all 16 feet across in total -- is just about perfect.  Bold enough to be  noticed and admired, but it won't overwhelm the room.I could not be more surprised at how good this is, how high the quality, or how great it looks. My niece is thrilled.  It took us almost no time to measure the wall, figure out the spacing and hang all five pieces.  And believe me, I can make a mess out of putting a magnet on a refrigerator.Global Nature Crafts makes dozens of different styles.  If you have an empty wall and want to make it look good (and like you spent a small fortune), you cannot go wrong with this. My niece had been looking for something to put up on that wall for ages. When the manufacturer contacted me and asked if I would review this product, I took one look and eagerly accepted.  When I do say 'yes' to a review request, I tend to be harder on the product, but in this case, I'm almost afraid to say how much I like it.  I have not looked at other reviews, but I suspect they must be equally good.  It's just a fine product at a fine price.

If you are looking for an affordable knockoff of Hermes Birkin, keep looking.  People who like the style but are sane and find $18,500.00 a little steep for a purse, have made Birkin copies a cottage industry.  And good copies are worth it. The birkin and its better wannabe cousins are big. Like satchels. They can be used as overnight bags. They're durable. The leather is top quality, the sewing is sturdy and you're not afraid the handles are going to fall off.  The size makes a statement.  Okay, maybe the statement is "I have way too much money or I want you to think I do," but even so.  And  to be perfectly honest, if I had that kind of money, I couldn't spend it on a purse.  My car isn't worth that much.  Or half that much. I'm level headed. I'd throw the money away on botox, spa vacations and cute cabana boys, that kind of stuff.Anyway, getting back to the Big Handbag Shop version, if you wanted a knock off, this won't fool anyone. It's too small, the leather is mediocre, and the lining is cheap.  The real Birkin (or its better copies) is really big, weighs a ton, and can hold a small dog, portable umbrella, hair dryer, address book, curling iron, make up bag, cell phone and the other accoutrements of the stylish woman with money burning a hole in her pockabook.  I bought my good copy in Italy; the not so good one came as a gift. The good copy cost close to $300, but it's made of ostrich leather, with heavyweight hardware and a thick silk lining. This one costs half that, but for $150, I still expect a decent purse, even if it's not pretending to be somebody else.  Sure, for that price I'm not going to walk around flaunting the skin of an exotic bird, but it should not look like it's coming apart at the seams either.  After six months of minimal use, mine shows a lot of wear and tear.  One of the little metal footies has already fallen off; the hardware is lightweight and cheap looking, the handles don't have that hand sewn look, and there is nothing that makes this look special. If you know handbags, you might pay $40 for it and use it for everyday.  But you'd never convince one of Oprah's spaniels or Lindsay's little Yorkie to travel around in it. Those dogs know what's what.

What a good little pencil. The point is thin, making it easy to create those feathery little strokes that are best. The color is not too dark, not too light. If your hair is light brown to blond and you have fair skin, the shade is will probably match your natural brows.  The pencil lasts all day long, doesn't smear, the tip isn't soft so you are not constantly resharpening.  The only thing I wish is that there were a sharpener in the lid. That's a brilliant idea and all pencils should have one.Most eyebrow makeup tips have been around for a while: Don't overpluck, brush eyebrows up and out before using the pencil, make pencil strokes that resemble eyebrow hairs, don't 'draw' on the eyebrow, and use a powder or liquid to thicken and fill in. And always trim, don't pluck, those long rogue hairs.  I did find one tip that was new and really makes a difference.  After you've done your brow make up, take some flesh colored concealer a shade or two lighter than your skin below the brow, and the same with a concealer a shade or two darker above the brow (use a pencil or a thin angled brush to apply). If you do it right, it's a subtle frame for the brows that sets off the eye area. Looks very good.The Vincent Longo pencil is an excellent addition to your brow make up, it's easy to use, the color is natural.  Five stars.

Macarons are tiny, crispy and chewy, sort of meringue textured, but reinforced with ground almonds, and filled with a variety of delicious concoctions, from chocolate ganache to fruit blends.  They're tiny, just two bites and all gone, and completely addictive. After tasting one, I was so hooked, I bought a cookbook and started baking. I mean, who wants to sit in a bakery guzzling plate after plate while people snap photos and shake their heads? Nope, I decided to make 'em at home and stuff myself in private. My first batch wasn't quite right, the second okay, but as I continued to bake them, they improved. Advice from a friend, someone who actually knows what he's doing in a kitchen, helped a lot. Now I make them often, because they are impressive and look way more difficult than they are. Although I now have several books, when I saw this little item, free on Kindle and I couldn't resist.Martha Stone is a no-nonsense baker. She provides a great basic recipe, a few twists on the basic, and even adds those helpful little things that the expensive cookbooks make you figure out for yourself (or ask that generous friend about). Like wait until the batter has dried a little before baking, don't get over-eager and try to split or fill them them too soon.  Little tips, but essential. And some of her recipes are genius. She offers a variation that's made with sumac in the mix. Sumac is a somewhat lemony spice. Paired with the writer's suggested orange filling, it is the perfect balance of sweet/tart citrusy deliciousness.The fillings are so good, you'll want to grab a spoon and forget the macaron.  Some are unusual. Mango and Dulce De Leche is so good, you want to run around stuffing it in people's mouths. Some are traditional unions in a new form, like Pear and Earl Grey Tea. She even has one for ketchup filling, which I haven't tried yet. But it sounds pretty good. I have tried tomato marmalade and like it, so why not a spicy, jammy ketchup filling?Anyway, the price is right, the writer knows what she's doing, her recipes are easy to understand, you don't have to be Martha Stewart to get good results. Five stars.

When it comes to this type of grooming, the best is professional waxing. If you choose the DIY route, the Bic Soleil Shave and Trim seems like a good alternative. Other options for home hair removal include depilatories, but not for the bikini area, I hope, and that Epi-Lady contraption that grabs the hairs a few at a time and rips them out. Yeah. Right. Just as soon as I finish poking my eye with a stick.Anyway, most of us choose shaving.  The Bic is the first to combine a shaver and a trimmer. Smart stuff. You can use the razor for a clean, hairless shave in certain areas and the trimmer to groom others.  Both are both kept in that little torso container, so they stay handy. In theory. The shaver is a good one, with 3 blades for a close, smooth shave, and a pivoting head that glides over curves easily. I've used those wand-shaped trimmers before, but this removes hair more easily and moves better, probably because of the triple razors and fancy pivoting. The trimmer attachment slips onto the razor and stays in place until you take it off. It has 1/4 inch of clearance, which is a good length.  Remember, you do need something to work with; if there's not 1/2 an inch of material to shave down there, there is nothing for the trimmer to get hold of.The problems with shaving are it must be done very often, there is rough stubble, and some skin types react by going bumpy.  The Bic Soleil provides partial solutions to all of these.  The trimmer is made especially for grooming in this area. By not cutting down to the surface of the skin, the stubble situation isn't as bad, and so far so good regarding the bumps. By the way, these can be prevented with some smart shaving techniques (except for very sensitive skin). If they do happen, they are treatable.Bumps occur when hair follicles are irritated or infected. A clean, sharp razor and light touch help prevent this.  Pressing down irritates the skin. If you need to go over an area, take your second sweep in the direction of hair growth so there's less pull. Shave in the shower. Hot water steams open follicles, and washing first removes dead skin that can harbor bacteria. And good exfoliation, particularly on the legs, will eliminate ingrown hairs. Also, always use a good quality shaving lotion. It holds hair up so the razor can cut cleanly, provides 'glide' and essential moisture. And don't shave too often. Every other day at the most.Afterwards, rinse in cold water and, if you like, try an after-shave preparation with salicylic acid or glycolic acid and aloe vera. In any case, the last step should ALWAYS be a splash of witch hazel. The stuff is magic. It's anti-bacterial, a very nice toner for the face and body, and tightens the skin. It can even help tighten eye bags (a little), and it helps skin retain moisture.But back to the razor...it's not perfect, but it is the best among the similar products that I've tried, and I've tried most brands. It has the trimmer option which others don't, the trimmer works well, and it helps eliminate some of the skin issues resulting from shaving. So, Five stars...Brazilian if they have any.

This is my second good kitchen scale. Until recently, I had a dreadful Weightwatcher style metal platform-on-a-spring-type of scale, which is useless for any real kitchen work.  I then bought a very stylish and expensive kitchen scale which is flat, slender, easy-to-store, useful and accurate. Mostly expensive.  When I saw this one, I liked the bowl, which can be used or removed. Not as storage friendly as my other model, but for the price, who could resist.  This one features an oversized weight read out, you can set it for normal or metric measurements if you prefer. And there is a 60-second shut off feature so you don't waste batteries.  The bowl fits nicely on the unit, and has a little lip so it is secure and won't slide.  When not in use, you can pop the bowl on upside down and you have a protective cover. The bowl has a lip for easy pouring, is dishwasher safe, and just the right size for most kitchen tasks. I use it mostly for baking and it have not experienced any problems.Some of the things I really like about this unit are the size, which is somewhat compact, the nice styling, the attention to detail...big backlit readout, easy conversion from pounds and ounces to K/g, and the TARE feature.  This is just a fast and easy way to weigh your own bowl, if you use one, and have the gizmo do the subtraction automatically.  I am not mathematically gifted, and were it not for the extra toes, wouldn't even try. The scale goes up to 4 1/2 pounds, which is plenty for my purposes. I bake bread, mostly, but not in tremendous quantities because then I would eat it in tremendous quantities and when it came time to weight me, I'd have to head to one of those highway truck scales.You don't need to fuss around with the Smart Weigh. It's ready to use, the batteries are included, and they're those nice little AAs. For some reason, all my other scales now require the round battery that I have to schlep to the hardware store to get. If I remember, which does not happen often. With these, if you run out, there are usually two lurking in the junk drawer...or you could just ravish some flashlight or other appliance.I've read the negative reviews. These mention difficulty in getting the scale to zero out. I didn't have a problem, and I'm about as technically gifted as a rock.  I still confuse the tv remote and my phone.  Two other reviewers say they received defective models, which is a problem and I hope they used Amazon's good replacement policy or demanded their money and postage costs back.  As for me, I like this very much. I like having the bowl, so I can weigh liquid or wettish ingredients without having to remember to use the TARE feature, I like the option of just using the platform. I like the size and the stability, and I like the accuracy (tested upon receipt by weighing coins...which is kind of fun).Baking is, for me, an exact science. My grandmother's kitchen equipment consisted of some pots that were so dented, they never sat straight. She measured with her fist, any handy spoon, or a teacup without a handle that was reserved for the purpose.  She cooked on a huge woodburning stove (In Brooklyn, in the 1950s!) with no thermometer and no oven gauge. And she turned out the lightest, fluffiest pastries and cakes, she could make a spongecake that floated, an ethereal souffl, incredible bread, and just about anything else she chose.  Me, if I so much as add an unneeded chocolate chip, the roof falls in and the cat goes crazy.  I've used the scale at least twice a week for a couple of weeks and have not had a single problem. The bowl has been in and out of the dishwasher every time and is doing fine.  The scale makes life easier, makes baking easier, and helps ensure good results. For under fifteen bucks, it's worth having.

I just came back from a doctor appointment, so my weight was fresh in my mind when I found that the Smart Weight bathroom scale had arrived.  The first thing that struck me was how attractive it is, consisting of a white frame and clear center. The read out section is about three times larger than on my much more expensive digital scale. I never remember to carry my glasses so I usually can't see the damage. This makes the bad news impossible to miss. It's even backlit in case you were trying to fool yourself that those three donuts you wolfed down (on top of breakfast) were walked off when you got up to get some ice cream.With the Smart Weigh, set up is easy, and the scale comes with 4 batteries so you don't have to empty out the flashlight every time you want to know how much you weigh.  Best of all, it uses double A  which everyone usually has in their junk drawer. My old scale requires a round battery that is not sold at the supermarket, requires a separate trip to buy, and costs quite a bit more. When I even remember to buy one. And then it only tells me bad things and makes me wonder if I need one of those things that makes a beeping noise when I back up.The Smart Weight was right on the button in terms of accuracy. Unfortunately.  The larger numbers made sure I got a really good look at how much I'd gained in the last few days.  And there's a sort of holding pattern that keeps the numbers lit up for a few seconds, in case you are a complete masochist or you have a husband/wife/friend who enjoys a good laugh.  After a couple of seconds, the light goes out and the scale shuts down so you aren't wasting batteries. The scale goes up to 800 pounds, so there is some leeway for those among us who think bacon and donuts are a match made in heaven.The scale has a number of good features. There is a warning light to let you know the batteries are running down. No more skipping breakfast, stepping on the scale and finding no results.  There is also a little gizmo that lets you change weight measurement from pounds to kilograms or stone.  I like this because  a kilo is 2.2 pounds...instantly your weight is cut in half. And a stone is 14 pounds. You can weight 280 pounds and it's only 20 stone...you'd feel like you had anorexia! Plus, it doesn't scream when you step on it.A few reviewers found that this Smart Weight is inaccurate.  I have not had this problem. My other scale, which I moved to the guest bathroom, let visitors be miserable, shows me the same weight.  Some reviews say you have to hold still and balance carefully. Well, sure. But leaning or wriggling will jigger the numbers on any scale. I've even figured out how to lean exactly right so that the monster in the doctor's office, the one with the weights that slide, counts me as a good four pounds lighter. You sort of hang one hip over the side, keep your right foot foot flat but only half on the weighing platform, and pray the nurse isn't watching.The cost of the Smart Weight is just $20.  I paid over three times that much for my other scale and this one is just as good in terms of accuracy, and a better piece of equipment given the cheaper and more accessible batteries, the nicer design, the bigger and brighter read out and the kilo/pound/stone option.  After at least 3 weeks of use, not a single problem has occurred, it continues to be accurate, and I'm very pleased. Not any smaller though. It occurs to me that in a perfect world when your weight crossed some set point, the refrigerator door would automatically lock and you'd go on the No Fly List at the pizza delivery place.  Scale people, can you work on this? In the meantime, the Smart Weigh deserves five weighty stars.

I found these at the Polish Arts website at about the same price, along with some that are twice as big and twice as expensive.  This is a nice size for wearing under a coat...just right to keep the chill off your neck.  They wrap around with a nice overlap, feel soft against the skin, aren't itchy like wool, costly like cashmere, or icy cold like silk.  The Polish site has more colors and I selected white, beige, blue and red.  I occasionally wear one as a headband at the gym (viva 1985) or to give a little life to a dark sweater and trousers.The 20% polyester may turn some people off, but in fact, it just makes them easier to wash and iron. I have a few in 100% cotton that wrinkle like crazy. By the way, there's an easy way to de-wrinkle most scarves...while the scarf is still wet, smooth it flat against the shower door and leave it there until it dries.  A quick touch of the steam iron and its ready to go.If you want something colorful and different, these are a nice change. If you are Polish and remember your own babci putting on her babushka, wearing one will just feel good..a little connection with the past.

Secrets is silly.  The information may be first class, but the producers have given us something that's hard to take seriously.  First of all, the voice-over is portentious; the most minute discovery is greeted with awe.  The word 'centuries' is repeated like an incantation. Oh yeah, this series was made for American audiences and is packed with all the power and drama of Geraldo Rivera's opening Al Capone's airshaft.  They manage to make the discovery of Richard III's skeleton seem like the work of a bunch of screwballs.  And to be fair, they're probably not all that wrong.The Hunt For The Tomb was spearheaded by The Richard the III Society, an organization that is run by and composed of two extraordinarily dedicated people: Philippa Langley and Simon Farnaby.  Miss Langley is a nervous-looking blonde lady. She calls herself a screenwriter but has yet to write anything  and seems to have a lot of time on her hands.  Mr. Farnaby is a television actor who has not been over-utilized by the media, let's just say.Obviously "Secrets" must be paying for some of the uncovering because every expense is spared.  This is not a show that throws money around. In addition to plenty of stock footage, they throw caution to the winds when it comes to digging up the remains, utilizing bulldozers to gouge out this archeological rarity. It's only when the earthmover uncovers some human legs that we get the dozers out and the diggers in.Real investigators take over and carry out chores like carbon dating, DNA testing, and such.  Preliminary exams reveal that our skeleton does indeed have a spinal deformity.  This is big news because scholars who defend  Richard III say that his famous hunchback was just Tudor propaganda.  Turns out, Richard III may have been a twisted little fellow after all.  Amazingly enough, the world greeted this information with stoicism.  Philippa, however, is beside herself with grief and has an on-camera melt down.  "I'm sorry, guys," she mumbles, voice cracking. "I can't do this" and staggers away, leaning on Simon for support.Next we have some more interesting dirt. We are shown portraits of Richard and told these are probably inaccurate, the result of artistic illusions and flattery by court painters. An interview with a very pleasant and happy lady explains the science behind the reconstruction, how painstakingly it is done, even measuring the skin depth (they don't tell us how) of men of that age who lived at that time. Pegs are affixed to the skull indicating skin depth. How about that.  Anyway, we are given a lot of information.  She has done this sort of thing before and giggles at the conceit of portraits. "Oh, you can't trust royal portraits," she notes as the camera closes in on a painting of Richard, the one with the black hat with a brooch on it. Nope, she assures us, we can bet that he didn't look a thing like that. Only science gives us the Real McCoy. Or the real Plantagenet in this case.  The segment goes on and on, but we never get the payoff.  Obviously we will have to watch to the bitter end to see what Richard really truly looked like.  At this point the discerning viewer will wonder what sort of cocktails Richard might have enjoyed and, no answers being available, just hit the gin.About halfway into the show and armed with new resolve and that belt of booze, we meet historian and geneologist John Ashdown-Hill.  Mr. Ashdown-Hill labors over various records to find the missing great great great great etc.  Unfortunately this expert is missing a front tooth which not only gives him a rather dotty look, it also goes all too well with his performance. Anyway records turn up an heir, one Michael Ibsen, a Canadian who lives in London and makes wooden chairs.  Simon Farnaby interviews Ibsen at what seems to be a truck stop. There is a long, long shot of some very yummy but greasy looking eggs and bacon frying away on a cook top.  We did say this doesn't apear to be one of those shows where the producers throw money around.  Mr. Ibsen says he is overwhelmed, but really he looks more confused. And his eyes keep cutting to that bacon.  Mr. Ibsen is the key to it all.  If he has the same DNA as the skeleton, then Philippa and Simon have nailed Richard III. On which they both seem oddly keen.The results of carbon dating come in and it looks like All Systems Go...the timing is just right. This skeleton was alive and well at the same period as Richard III.  Philippa becomes animated again, clutching at Simon.  Now the news media is starting to pay attention.  Good thing, too, because things are getting interesting.  An examination of the cleaned, tested and reconstructed skeleton reveals many injuries and the probable cause/causes of death. Whoever he is, this dead guy died fighting. Lots of cleaving and stabbing of the face, sword and knife wounds to the chest and back, and something referred to as a post-mortem 'humiliation wound,' which is never expanded upon or explained.  But the producers are kind enough to give us a close up of the skeleton's rear end, so we have a pretty good idea of where that last sword ended up.The rest of the show is largely taken up with stock footage of actors wearing armor and what looks to be costumed tourists at a Renaissance Faire.  Simon and Philippa are filmed standing in the general vicinity of Bosworth Field, but there are no remnants or reminders of the great battle. Just the two of them. She wears an enormous fur cap with gigantic earflaps.  Elmer Fudd would have killed for that hat.  Anyway there's nothing much for anyone to do...t's all over but the payoff.  What did the guy look like?The fellow was King of England for just two years, which is about how long if feels like we've been watching. Plus the gin seems to have evaporated. But the end of the tunnel is at hand. Tension mounts. Philippa, eyes closed, is led into a darkened chamber. There is an altar-like construction with turntable, upon which resides the scientifically accurate head and authentic artist-proof face.  One light illuminates it.  Philippa stumbles, her eyes still shut tight. She is savoring the moment. We can see she is breathing heavily. Even Simon the actor  assumes a facial expression, laboring to show us both anticipation and his good side.  Philippa squares her shoulders.  Her eyes open, her expression goes from surprise to a beatific joy. It is The Big Reveal. And now it's our turn. The camera pans from Philippa's tear-streaked face and to the altar...and sure enough, he looks exactly like the portrait.The show ends by assuring us that Richard's skeleton doesn't tell us whether he was a bad or good.  Maybe not, but if you ask me, that hat with the brooch said plenty.

This is a diet plan for people who don't like food, have iron discipline, and never feel hungry. For people like me...after one day, I'd be as hungy (and picky) as a vulture. If a tired cowboy came riding into town, I'd circle him and hope he fell from the saddle.There are only three things to consider about a diet-replacment liquid. Does it taste good? Does it fill you up? Is it easier than preparing your own food.  Okay, some grown up types are concerned about nutrition, but if they're so smart they probably eat well all the time, awful stuff like vegetables without the cheese sauce. They don't need to be on diets like those of us who think a bacon is a vitamin and the heck with them.  The rest of us know who we are and not just by the fried chicken grease on our polo shirts.  SlimFast passes the taste test. It's really good, just the right amount sweet, with a light but velvety texture and delicious flavor. And it's easy. I mean, how tough is it to take the lid off a bottle and glug it?  But does it fill you up?  I suspect if you gave this to a hummingbird long enough, it would wrassle that vulture for dibs on Pecos Pete.You are supposed to follow their 3.2.1. program which consists of 1 bottle of SlimFast or the SlimFast protein bar (200 calories for either) as your complete breakfast, then the same for lunch, followed by a 500 calorie dinner. You also get some 'snacks' -- three 100-calorie treats per day. This translates to one decent sized orange, 8 dry roasted almonds, or four of those little pretzel twists. Yeah, you'd slim down some. Another good diet plan is visiting Moscow, insulting the Politburo, and getting sent to the Gulag.So why would anyone mess around with 3.2.1?  First of all, for a real snack that won't leave you pretending it's the dog making those noises, you could put together a bowl of lettuce, cucumbers, radishes, green peppers, jalapenos and even a few sunflower seeds for crunch and indulge in a luscious tablespoon of the richest dressing imaginable and not go over the 100 calorie count. The fiber will certainly cure the empty tummy.  You could boil yourself  four shrimp and 5 asparagus in some Old Bay seasoning, squeeze on some lemon and really go to town.  But then you'd be working for your calories and the whole SlimFast 3.2.1. deal is the convenience.By the way, you think all that deprivation during the day ends with a big blowout dinner feast, think again. You have 500 calories, so you'd be chowing down on something like 1/2 cup (cooked) pasta topped with sauteed zucchini, maybe six little chunks, all followed by a big, delicious slice of...nothing. A half cup is usually what I wind around the fork to taste to make sure it's cooked enough.  But that's your dinner and not another bite. No butter, no oil, no sliced chicken. Nada.  Of course you'd still have another 100 calorie snack...maybe ten of those little green Thompson grapes, yippie-yi-yo-kai-yay.  And if you want something to drink and get the taste of the zucchini out of your mouth, don't even look at the wine or the juice or the beer.  You can wash it all down with water.For me, 3.2.1 doesn't work. If I'm in a hurry and watching weight, I might grab a container of the stuff as a meal replacement. Say for breakfast when I oversleep, or fun times like waiting on line at the DMV. Or the lam from the cops. Otherwise, why bother? With a tiny bit of effort, you can have real food and not exceed that 1200 total daily calorie count. I'd rather spend fifteen minutes throwing some honest-to-gosh edibles together any day. I know it's what the poor cowboy would want me to do.

This exceptional BBC series ran for just four episodes in its debut season...barely enough to satisfy, but sufficient to show us how good a television show can be.  The series is based on Mikhail Bulgakov's short story collection of the same name, and is almost alarmingly true to the book's character and content. Americans probably know Bulgakov best for his masterpiece, "The Master and Marguerita."  This short story collection, however, is more personal to the author, being based on his own early life, and presents readers with some of the best Russian writing of the post-revolution era, along with an excellent and always entertaining ethnography of Russian village life...and a Stalin era history lesson. The stories outline the experiences of a young doctor who practiced in Smolesnk, a Russian backwater, from 1916 to 1920.John Hamm, known to U.S. audiences from his Emmy Award winning role in "Mad Men" and Daniel Radcliff of the "Harry Potter" franchise, share star billing and a single role. Both play the same doctor, Radcliffe taking on the fresh-out-of medical school lad with no practical experience, and Hamm playing him as a cynical adult.  The series uses the gimmick of having the older Doctor interact with his younger self, advising, criticizing, provoking. It's a conceit we've seen before, but rarely done this well.  Both Radcliffe and Hamm are excellent, and the material gives them plenty to work with.The young doctor is sent to replace the late and imposing Leopold Leopoldovitch, a physician of imposing whiskers and reputation (and an extensive library of Turkish erotica, illustrated and in color.  When Leopold Leopoldovitch (always referred to by both names and in the most reverent terms) shuffles off the mortal coil, the young man must step into his shoes, not to mention oversized surgical gown.  And the poor kid only shaves every week or so.  But the lad is redeemed by two things:  The appearance of his older-self when his nerve fails, and his skill, albeit untried.  He graduated at the top of his class. "Five in all 15," he brags. "It was unprecedented!"  Not that this does any good when he has to saw both legs off of a dreadfully maimed 8 year old.The series is dark, the humor bitter, it's not always funny, people die, even young ones and nice ones. The first episode shows us the fear and optimism of the nave young practitioner; the fourth gives us the same young man already succumbing to depression and burn out.  The writers have captured that special bleakness that inhabits the Russian soul. The most mundane of things can have a saturnine twist; behind the loudest laughter there's awareness of death. It's a Russian thing. Maybe Eastern European, because the Scandinavians have it too. And the Poles. But if the humor reflects this spiritual black hole, it still manages to be funny.  And the parts that are meant to be serious? Well, it's fair to say they are sobering and unforgettable.  We deal with the doctor's own devils as he deals with his sick and injured.  And things can get bloody. Those operations don't pull any punches when it comes to showing us what it was like back in the day. Even the yanking of a rotten tooth can result in the accidental removal of a hunk of a jawbone and some truly impressive hemorrhaging.  The injuries may be gruesome, but they're just about right, given they way most peasants lived and worked.  And no staff of hotty interns to help the good doctor out. Would Doctor House have gotten as far with only the burned out hulk of his former self to advise him? Probably not, but the good doctors do have at least one thing in common, as we see in the enfolding episodes. You'll have to watch. I'm not going to spoil things if I can help it.(Just an aside: Do Americans know that Hugh Laurie, our haunted Dr. House, is one of England's best known comics and a skilled musician and singer?  "A Bit of Fry and Laurie" was a hilarious sketch show. His partner, Stephen Fry, also took a dark turn, going on to star in "Kingdom." Fry played the somewhat troubled Peter Kingdom, a not-terribly successful solicitor who juggled family secrets and the legal problems of some eccentric villagers in his small Norwich town.  The sketch show and Fry's series are both worth seeing. And so is "Jeeves and Wooster," the pair's other TV series. Fry is the sensible butler, but Laurie steals the show as the nave Bertie. Whenever he was deep in his Dr. House miseries, I kept waiting for him to break into a rousing rendition of "47 Ginger Headed Sailors.")"A Young Doctor's Notebook" originally aired in the UK last year and pulled in tremendous ratings. Ovation picked it up here in the U.S.  For those who aren't familiar with it, Ovation is a U.S. cable network that's devoted to 'artistic' content.  Mostly good stuff.  Season 1 is now available on Amazon and Netflix.  The producers have promised us Season 2.  The problem, of course, is pulling the stars away from their lucrative day jobs.You want to see this.
