I have compiled a detailed song listing (with album & singles label & number, chart position, debut date, plus personal comments)(BB R&B=Billboard Rhythm & Blues Chart):LP MISS ETTA JAMES (Crown CLP-5209)(1961):01 Dance With Me, Henry02 Do Something Crazy03 W-O-M-A-N (Modern 45X972)(uncharted a-side, November 1955)04 Number One (My One And Only)(Modern 45X984)(uncharted a-side, March 1956)05 I Hope Youre Satisfied (Betty & Dupree)(Kent 45X318)(uncharted a-side, 1959)06 Good Rockin Daddy (Modern 45X962)(a-side)(BB R&B 6/1955)(August 1955)07 Hey! Henry (Modern 45X957)(uncharted a-side, May 1955)08 Strange Things*listed in booklet as Strange Things Happening09 Thats All (Modern 45X972)(b-side, November 1955)10 How Big A Fool (Kent 45X352)(uncharted a-side, 1961)LP TWIST WITH ETTA JAMES (Crown CLP-5250)(1962)*4 tracks appeared on Miss Etta James, thus not included below (Good Rockin Daddy,Thats All,Hey! Henry and Strange Things Happening (according to the booklet):11 Twist With Me, Henry*correct title on the album; same as Roll With Me, Henry (The Wallflower) as in the CD song listing (Modern 45X947)(a-side)(BB R&B 1(4)/1955)(January 1955)12 Im A Fool (Etta The Peaches James)(Modern 45X984)(b-side, March 1956)13 If It Aint One Thing (Betty & Dupree)(Kent 45X318)(b-side, 1959)*not listed in the original album.14 Be My Love*listed in booklet as Be My Lovey Dovey15 Hickory Dickory DockBONUS SINGLES TRACKS:16 Tough Lover (Etta The Peaches James)(Modern 45X998)(uncharted a-side, September 1956)17 The Pick-Up (Modern 45X1016)(uncharted a-side, March 1957)18 Then Ill Care (Etta The Peaches James)(Modern 45X1007)(b-side, January 1957)19 Sunshine of Love (Kent 45X304)(uncharted a-side, July 1958)20 Baby, Baby Every Night (Kent 45X304)(b-side, July 1958)21 Come What May (Modern 45X1022)(uncharted a-side, June 1957)22 Fools We Mortals Be (Etta The Peaches James)(Modern 45X998)(b-side, September 1956)23 Be Mine (Modern 45X957)(b-side, May 1955)24 Good Lookin (Etta The Peaches James)(Modern 45X1007)(uncharted a-side, January 1957)25 Shortnin Bread Rock (as Etta The Peaches James)(Modern 45X988)(uncharted a-side, May 1956)Please note the above listing was what appeared in the CD. In my research, from the original album cover of Twist with Etta James there is a slightly different song listing:01 Twist With Me, Henry02 Good Rockin Daddy03 Im A Fool04 One Thing*new05 Thats All06 Doin Fine, Henry*new07 Be My Love08 Hickory Dickory Dock09 Feel So Good*new10 Strange ThingsPOSITIVE POINTS:1 Most of the early Etta James albums are on either Argo or Cadet label. These two albums on Crown label are the rare gems. The icing on the cake is the generous 10 bonus singles tracks.2 The sound is very well remastered, using 24-bit.3 There is a fantastic 16-page booklet, with an informative essay by Santi Comelles. Labels and numbers are included. There are also numerous beautiful coloured pictures of labels, front and back album covers, picture sleeves and posters. A first-class job!NEGATIVE POINTS:1 As noted above, there is some mix-up about the correct song titles, plus the some album tracks on Twist with Etta James in this CD are incorrect with some tracks still missing.2 No chart positions were provided.FINAL THOUGHTS:Etta James was born Jamesetta Hawkins on January 25, 1938 in Los Angeles, California. She was nicknamed Miss Peaches. She has a long illustrious career.  Her singing style spanned a variety of music genres including blues, R&B, soul, rock and roll, jazz and gospel. She has frequent bouts of heroin addiction, but finally cured in the late 1970s. In 1996, her album Mystery Lady: Songs of Billie Holiday won Best Jazz Vocal Performance Grammy. She was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease in 2008. She died of leukemia on January 20, 2012 (age 74). Her mighty, moving voice is sorely missed.After collecting all her 123 songs (as singles, except one song Bring It on Home to Me her duet with Tony Orlando), I am in the process of collecting all her domestic albums. Miss Etta James and Twist with Etta James are her second and fourth domestic albums on CD for the first time. The entire set is totally enjoyable with great sound, and will be treasured.

(ABC-Paramount 45-9997)(b-side, February 1959)*a-side Where Were You (On Our Wedding Day) disc 2, track 19.15 NO LIMIT TO LOVE (KRC 5000)(b-side, May 1958)*a-side Such A Mess disc 1, track 16.16 THATS WHY TEARS COME AND GO (ABC-Paramount 45-10162)(b-side, October 1960)(RW Pop 110/1960)*double sided hit; a-side (You Better) Know What Youre Doin disc 1, track 20.17 NO IFS  NO ANDS (ABC-Paramount 45-10102)(a-side)(BB Pop 40/1960; BB R&B 16/1960; CB Pop 38/1960; RW Pop 36/1960)(April 1960)*b-side For Love disc 1, track 5.18 HAPPY BIRTHDAY, MAMA (ABC-Paramount 45-10372)(b-side, October 1962)*rare gem; CD debut; a-side Under Your Spell Again disc 1, track 15.19 BE A LEADER (ABC-Paramount 45-10288)(a-side)(RW Pop 111/1962)(January 1962)*rare gem; CD debut; b-side Nother Fairy Tale disc 2, track 9.20 STRING OF PEARLS (instrumental)(ABC-Paramount 45-10206)(b-side, April 1961)*rare gem; CD debut; a-side Chantilly Lace disc 2, track 4.POSITIVE POINTS:1 This 3-CD set represents the most complete and comprehensive coverage of his early singles from 1952 to 1962. His biggest hit singles are included. There are many rare gems, making their CD debut, as noted above.2 The sound is very well remastered.3 The set comes in a sturdy cardboard gatefold cases like before. There is a short essay by Paul Humphries. Label & number are included.NEGATIVE POINTS:1 Time: disc 1: 49 minutes; disc 2: 46 minutes; disc 3: 47 minutes. Surely, Not Now Music could have made this compilation much more special by filling up the remaining empty spaces (98 minutes) with more songs. Even if Not Now Music chose to end in 1962, there are still 23 more songs missing from 1952 to 1962.2 The songs are not sequenced chronologically. It seems that the producer just hapharzardly and randomly created the song listing. In the song listing, I identified the names of the a or b-sides with their location in this set.3 While I appreciate the efforts of putting pictures of labels, they are put on the inner sleeves behind the transparent CD cases.COMPLETE SINGLES DISCOGRAPHY:Although Lloyd Price has 24 charted singles on Billboard Hot 100, I have just compiled a Complete Singles Discography and found that he actually has 71 singles from 1952  1985 (charted and uncharted, a and b-sides, only 139 songs not 142 songs because 3 were repeated releases). His labels are (1) Specialty (1952  1957), (2) KRC (1957  1958), (3) Artone (1959), (4) ABC-Paramount (1957  1963), (5) Double-L (1963  1966), (6) Monument (1965), (7) Hurd (1966), (8) Reprise (1966), (9) Ludix Production (1967), (10) JAD (1968), (11) Turntable (1969  1970), (12) Scepter (1971), (13) Paramount (1972), (14) GSF (1973), (15) L.P.G. (1976) and (16) Specialty (1985).FINAL THOUGHTS:Lloyd Price was born on March 9, 1933 in Kenner, Louisiana, but grew up in New Orleans. He has a long illustrious singing career with many memorable hit singles. He was known as Mr. Personality and was inducted into the Rock N Roll Hall of Fame in 1998. He currently manages Icon Food Brands, which makes a line of primarily Southern-style foods, including Lawdy Miss Clawdy food products and a line of Lloyd Price foods, such as Lloyd Price's Soulful 'n' Smooth Grits and Lloyd Price's Energy-2-Eat Bar (with the brand slogan "Good taste  Great Personality"), plus Lawdy Miss Clawdy clothing and collectibles.If you are looking for his Greatest Hits, this current set has the most complete coverage of his most popular singles with good sound. To fill in the gaps missing from this set, you can get those missing songs in Restless Heart (Jasmine, 2CDs, 57 songs). If you are looking for his early albums, I would recommend Classic 7 Albums Plus (Real Gone Music, 4CDs, 2014). His output from 1963 to 1985 on CDs is sorely missing. This current set is recommended to all Lloyd Price fans.

VIDEO (2D):Through Pixar/Disney, Inside Out (2D) arrives on blu-ray with MPEG-4 AVC 1080p 1.78:1 encode. The transfer is simply pristine, with razor-sharp details and bold, vibrant colours that pop: Joys sparkling gold, Sadness' depressed blue, Anger's fiery red, Fears gorgeous purple, and Disgust's vomit green. A fine mist encircles every emotion that is almost akin to the Pixie Dust found in the Tinker Bell films. Every strand of computer-generated hair on the heads of Sadness and Joy looks and acts realistic. When Joy reluctantly visits the Memory Dump, black levels are deep and inky. This is simply a state-of-the-art animated feature. Oscar, anyone? (5/5)VIDEO (3D)Inside Out (3D) arrives on blu-ray with MPEG-4 MVC 1080p 1.85:1 encode. Besides all the positive attributes above, the presentation adds a tremendous level of depth to practically every scene. Both colours and details remain the same. Brightness does not suffer. This is an enjoyable 3D presentation. (5/5).AUDIO:Inside Out comes with DTS-HD 7.1 Master Audio soundtrack is precisely defined throughout, whether light and airy piano notes or more aggressively styled music. Surround sound fills the room with full immersion. Bass is deep. Dialogue is clear and prioritized. This is an excellent soundtrack. (5/5)MOVIE:It's true that the basis of Inside Out isn't necessarily original. An early '90s sitcom from Fox entitled Herman's Head first introduced the idea of personified emotions controlling the main character. However, Inside Out most definitely expounds and improves upon the formula. The core emotions are done by: Joy (Amy Poehler), Sadness (Phyllis Smith), Anger (Lewis Black), Disgust (Mindy Kaling) and Fear (Bill Hader). It is beautiful, poignant, and richly animated, and a return to form for Pixar. Great movie. (5/5)TRIVIA:1 Inside Out has an estimated budget of $175 million, but has a worldwide gross of $850 million, second only to Minions with $1,156 million for animated feature.2 According to director Pete Docter, each emotion is based on a shape: Joy is based on a star, Sadness is a teardrop, Anger is a fire brick, Fear is a raw nerve, and Disgust is broccoli.3 The writers considered up to 27 different emotions, but settled on five to make it less complicated. Some of the major emotions that ended up being cut included Surprise, Pride, and Trust.PACKAGING:Inside Out 3D comes with 4 discs, each having its own flipcase: blu-ray 3D, blu-ray 2D, blu-ray bonus (very nice gesture) and DVD feature film. There is no booklet.FINAL THOUGHTS:Inside Out brazenly explores an alien world with startlingly astute observations. The interactions between the emotions are synchronously hilarious and poignant. It is pure joy to watch this movie. Both the video (3D and 2D) and audio are top-notched. I personally feel that this picture will be a strong contender for Oscar in Best Animated Feature in 2016. A great picture for both parents and children, and is very highly recommended.

VIDEO:My Fair Lady (50th Anniversary Edition) arrives on blu-ray with MPEG-4 AVC at 26.19 Mbps 1080p 2.20:1 encode. Brand new 4k restoration from an 8K scan of the original negative, and other surviving 65mm elements, was painstakingly restored by acclaimed film historian and preservationist Robert A. Harris, whose recent work on Spartacus was nothing short of a treasure. This magnificently restored transfer is a revelation. The 2.20:1-framed image (as opposed to the 2011 release's 2.39:1 framing) reveals the movie like never before, yielding a picture so pristine that watching is practically like seeing the movie for the first time. It retains the original grain structure. There are tremendous details, showing off every stitch in Cecil Beaton's Oscar-winning costumes. Colours pop with deep blacks. Many thanks to Mr. Harris to bring My Fair Lady to its former glory, well deserved for such an iconic film. (5/5).AUDIO:My Fair Lady (50th Anniversary Edition) also features a new soundtrack: the 96k Dolby TrueHD 7.1 lossless soundtrack sourced from the original full resolution presentation, heard for the first time here since the film's 1964 premiere. The track pops from the first note forward, exploding into the stage with beautiful, full-range clarity that is not only a precision representation of the orchestral score but capable of singling out the finest points to each section and instrument. Lyrics are just as impressive, with strong vocal clarity throughout the range. With all the popular songs in this film, the restored soundtrack is pure music to die for. Glorious! (5/5).TRIVIA:My Fair Lady won 8 Oscars, including:(1)  Best Picture: Jack L Warner(2)  Best Director: George Cukor(3)  Best Leading Actor: Rex Harrison(4)  Best Cinematography (Color): Harry Stradling, Jr.(5)  Best Art Direction  Set Decoration, Color: Gene Allen, Cecil Beaton & George James Hopkins(6)  Best Costume Design, Color: Cecil Beaton(7)  Best Sound: George Groves (Warner Bros SSD)(8)  Best Music Score: Andre PrevinIn 1965, the Best Actress Oscar went to Julie Andrews (Mary Poppins). Audrey Hepburn, for some unknown reasons, was not even nominated. Her singing voice was dubbed by Marni Nixon, who was then married to Exodus composer, Ernest Gold. Their son is Andrew Gold, singer in 1970s.PACKAGING:This 50th Anniversary Edition comes with an elegant polish-steel-like gatefold cases. There are 3 discs: blu-ray featured film, blu-ray special features and DVD for featured film. It is simply beautiful just to hold. Unfortunately, there is no booklet.FINAL THOUGHTS:My Fair Lady was first released on blu-ray in 2011 without much fanfare. At that time, I thought that this was a disrespectful treatment of such an important film. I am so glad that Mr. Harris has done such a magnificent restoration, bringing back the glory that this movie deserves. This is the definitive edition of My Fair Lady and I am glad to double-dip. This restored edition is very highly recommended and will be treasured.

BB R&B 8/1961; CB Pop 35/1961; RW Pop 57/1961)(July 1961)*from album Aware of Love (Vee-Jay LP-1038)(1961)08 I STAND ACCUSED (Vee-Jay VJ-598)(a-side)(BB Pop 61/1964; BB R&B 3(3)/1964; CB Pop 58/1964; RW Pop 44/1964)(May 1964)09 LET IT BE ME (with Betty Everett)(Vee-Jay VJ-613)(a-side)(BB Pop 5/1964; BB R&B 1(3)/1964; CB Pop 9/1964; RW Pop 3(1)/1964)(August 1964)*from album Deliciously Together (Vee-Jay VJLP-1099)(1964)10 A LONELY SOLDIER (Abner 1035)(a-side)(BB R&B 25/1960; CB Pop 100/1960)(March 1960)*from album He Will Break Your Heart (Vee-Jay LP-1029)(1960)11 MOTHERLESS CHILD*from album Folk Songs (Vee-Jay LP-1057)(1963)12 JUST A LITTLE BIT (Vee-Jay VJ-556)(a-side)(RW Pop 132/1963)(August 1963)13 NEED TO BELONG (Vee-Jay VJ-567)(a-side)(BB Pop 31/1963; BB R&B 2(1)/1963; CB Pop 28/1963; RW Pop 30/1963)(October 1963)*from album Need To Belong (Vee-Jay VJLP-1076)(1963)14 MAKE IT EASY ON YOURSELF (Vee-Jay VJ-451)(a-side)(BB Pop 20/1962; BB R&B 18/1962; CB Pop 24/1962; RW Pop 31/1962)(June 1962)*from album Need to Belong (Vee-Jay VJLP-1076)(1963); original version; later remake by Scott Walker and the Walker Brothers (BB Pop 16/1965)15 STRAWBERRIES (Vee-Jay VJ-526)(b-side, June 1963)*from album Need To Belong (Vee-Jay LP-1076)(1963)16 AINT THAT LOVIN YOU BABY (with Betty Everett)(Vee-Jay VJ-613)(b-side, August 1964)(BB Pop 108/1964; BB R&B 24/1964; CB Pop 91/1964)*double sided hit; from album Deliciously Together (Vee-Jay VJLP-1099)(1964)POSITIVE POINTS:1 Even though this set was released in 1989, the songs have stood the test of time with many gems not readily found, especially the duet with Betty Everett.2 The sound is very good and clean.3 There is a 4-page booklet, with an informative essay by Michael Ochs.NEGATIVE POINTS:1 Only 16 songs. I guess 16 songs were considered good by 1989 standards.2 There were no label & number and no chart positions.FINAL THOUGHTS:Jerry Butler was born on December 8, 1939 in Sunflower, Mississippi and raised in Chicago. He and his childhood buddy Curtis Mayfield first joined the Roosters, and the name was later changed to the Impressions. He went solo in 1958. He was dubbed "The Ice Man. In 1991, he was inducted into the Rock N Roll Hall of Fame as a member of the Impressions. I feel that he certainly deserved a second separate induction as a solo artist.Iif you are looking for Jerrys singles output, I would highly recommend Singles (Charly UK, 2011, 2CDs, 56 songs, 1959  1966) and The Soul of Jerry Butler (Not Now Music, 2CDs, 38 songs). Beyond 1966, you can get his songs through twofers, but they are usually very expensive. The soul music of Jerry Butler is both an explosion of raw, passionate energy, an artist reflection of its time, plus exploring, learning, revealing and relating. His soulful voice is oh so moving. The entire set, although released so long ago and with only 16 songs, is still totally enjoyable and is recommended.

CONTENT:The Best Of Jerry Butler as part of the Millennium Collection series, released by Mercury Records in 2000, contains 11 songs. I have compiled a detailed song listing (including singles label & number, chart position, debut date, plus personal comments)(BB Pop=Billboard Hot 100; BB R&B=Billboard Rhythm & Blues Chart; BB AC=Billboard Adult Contemporary Chart; CB Pop=Cash Box Singles Chart; RW Pop=Record World Singles Chart):01 ONLY THE STRONG SURVIVE (Mercury 72898)(a-side)(BB Pop 4/1969; BB R&B 1(2)/1969; CB Pop 5/1969; RW Pop 6/1969)(February 1969)*from album Ice Man Cometh02 MOODY WOMAN (Mercury 72929)(a-side)(BB Pop 24/1969; BB R&B 3(2)/1969; CB Pop 22/1969; RW Pop 19/1969)(May 1969)*from album Ice On Ice03 I DIG YOU BABY (Mercury 72648)(a-side)(BB Pop 60/1966; BB R&B 8/1966; CB Pop 60/1967; RW Pop 81/1967)(December 1966)*from album Soul Artistry04 NEVER GIVE YOU UP (Mercury 72798)(a-side)(BB Pop 20/1968; BB R&B 4/1968; CB Pop 18/1968; RW Pop 17/1968)(April 1968)*from album Soul Goes On05 MR. DREAM MERCHANT (Mercury 72721)(a-side)(BB Pop 38/1967; BB R&B 23/1967; CB Pop 46/1967; RW Pop 39/1967)(September 1967)*from album Mr. Dream Merchant06 LOST (Mercury 72764)(a-side)(BB pop 62/1967; BB R&B 15/1968; CB Pop 52/1968; RW Pop 53/1968)(December 1967)*different tune from 1959 version; from album Mr. Dream Merchant07 HEY, WESTERN UNION MAN (Mercury 72850)(a-side)(BB Pop 16/1968; BB R&B 1(1)/1968; CB Pop 24/1968; RW Pop 25/1968)(August 1968)*from album Ice Man Cometh08 AINT UNDERSTANDING MELLOW (with Brenda Lee Eager)(Mercury 73255)(a-side)(BB Pop 21/1971; BB R&B 3(1)/1971; CB Pop 24/1971; RW Pop 29/1971)(November 1971)*gold record; from album Sagittarius Movement09 ONE NIGHT AFFAIR (Mercury 73335)(a-side)(BB Pop 52/1972; BB R&B 6/1972; CB Pop 57/1972; RW Pop 57/1972)(October 1972)*from album Spice Of Life10 WHATS THE USE OF BREAKING UP (Mercury 72960)(a-side)(BB Pop 20/1969; BB R&B 4/1969; CB Pop 23/1969; RW Pop 21/1969)(August 1969)*from album Ice On Ice11 A BRAND NEW ME (Mercury 72960)(b-side, August 1969)(RW Pop 74/1969)*double sided hit; from album Ice On IcePOSITIVE POINTS:1 Because of the scarcity of his songs on CDs from 1966 onwards, this set, with only 11 songs, is still an excellent compilation because all the songs from 1967  1971 are rare gems making their CD debut.2 The sound is very well remastered.3 There is an 8-page fold-out booklet, containing an informative essay by Stu Hackel.NEGATIVE POINTS:1 Only 11 songs. But this was the norm for the Millennium Collection series.2 No label & number and no chart position are included.FINAL THOUGHTS:Jerry Butler was born on December 8, 1939 in Sunflower, Mississippi and raised in Chicago. He and his childhood buddy Curtis Mayfield first joined the Roosters, and the name was later changed to the Impressions. He went solo in 1958. He was dubbed "The Ice Man. In 1991, he was inducted into the Rock N Roll Hall of Fame as a member of the Impressions. I feel that he certainly deserved a second separate induction as a solo artist.Beside the current set, if you are looking for Jerrys singles output, I would highly recommend Singles (Charly UK, 2011, 2CDs, 56 songs, 1959  1966) and The Soul of Jerry Butler (Not Now Music, 2CDs, 38 songs). Beyond 1966, you can get his songs through twofers, but they are usually very expensive. The soul music of Jerry Butler is both an explosion of raw, passionate energy, an artist reflection of its time, plus exploring, learning, revealing and relating. His soulful voice is oh so moving. The entire set, with so many rare gems, is totally enjoyable, with great sound, and is highly recommended.

CONTENT:The 2-CD set The Soul of Jerry Butler, released by reputable reissue label Not Now Music from UK in 2015, contains 38 songs, covering his output from 1958 to 1962. I have compiled a detailed song listing (including album and singles label & number, chart position, debut date, plus personal comments)(BB Pop=Billboard Hot 100; BB R&B=Billboard Rhythm & Blues Chart; BB AC=Billboard Adult Contemporary Chart; CB Pop=Cash Box Singles Chart; RW Pop=Record World Singles Chart):DISC 1:01 HE WILL BREAK YOUR HEART (Vee-Jay VJ-354)(a-side)(BB Pop 7/1960; BB R&B 1(7)/1960; CB Pop 100/1960)(March 1960)*from album He Will Break Your Heart (Vee-Jay LP-1029)(1960)15 LOVE ME (The Impressions, featuring Jerry Butler)(Abner 59-1017)(b-side, October 1958)*from album Aware of Love (Vee-Jay LP-1038)(1961)16 THEME FROM TARAS BULBA (THE WISHING STAR)(Vee-Jay VJ-475)(a-side)(CB Pop 107/1962)(November 1962)17 O HOLY NIGHT (Vee-Jay VJ-371)(b-side, November 1960)18 SILENT NIGHT (Vee-Jay VJ-371)(uncharted a-side, November 1960)POSITIVE POINTS:1 This 2-CD set provides very comprehensive coverage of the early output by Jerry Butler from 1955 to 1962. Many singles and album tracks are included. This current set is much better than a similar set No End of Time: The Early Years (Jasmine, 2011, 29 songs).2 The sound is very well remastered.3 Instead of the usual gatefold hard cardboard cases in the past, Not Now Music has now switched to the usual plastic CD cases, which is not a bad thing. There is a short informative essay by Brian Parks.4 The price is cheap.NEGATIVE POINTS:1 Time: disc 1: 51 minutes; disc 2: 46 minutes. This is the trend of Not Now Music with their The Soul of series of not filling up the discs. Surely, there are so many missing tracks that can fill up the remaining empty spaces (63 minutes):From LP Jerry Butler, Esq:(01) Come Back My Love (Abner 59-1017)(a-side)(BB R&B 29/1958; CB Pop 94/1958)(October 1958)(02) If You Let Me(03) The Challenge(04) Chi Town (Vee-Jay VJ-426)(b-side, February 1962)(05) Rainbow Valley (Abner 59-1028)(uncharted a-side, June 1959)(06) No End of TimeSingle:(07) Isle of Sirens (Vee-Jay VJ-426)(a-side)(CB Pop 130/1962; RW Pop 89/1962)(February 1962)And I am only speaking of songs up to 1962.2 As per usual practice with UK reissue labels, the compilation would stop at 1962, because of local Public Domain laws. This is really unfortunate because Jerry Butler has a long charting career.3 No label & number and no chart position were provided.4 The songs are NOT sequenced chronologically. It seems like the producer just haphazardly arranged the song listing.COMPLETE SINGLES DISCOGRAPHY:Jerry Butler has a lengthy charting career. On Billboard R&B Chart, he has 59 singles. I have just finished a Complete Singles Discography, and found that he actually has 85 singles (charted and charted, a and b-sides, from 1958  1993; but only 158 songs, not 170 songs because 12 were repeated releases). His labels are (1) Falcon (1958), (2) Vee-Jay (1958), (3) Abner (1958  1960), (4) Vee-Jay (1960  1966), (5) Mercury (1966  1974), (6) Motown (1976  1977), (7) Philadelphia International (1978  1980), (8) Fountain (1982), (9) CTI (1983), and (10) Ichiban (1992  1993).FINAL THOUGHTS:Jerry Butler was born on December 8, 1939 in Sunflower, Mississippi and raised in Chicago. He and his childhood buddy Curtis Mayfield first joined the Roosters, and the name was later changed to the Impressions. He went solo in 1958. He was dubbed "The Ice Man. In 1991, he was inducted into the Rock N Roll Hall of Fame as a member of the Impressions. I feel that he certainly deserved a second separate induction as a solo artist.Beside the current set, if you are looking for Jerrys singles output, I would highly recommend Singles (Charly UK, 2011, 2CDs, 56 songs, 1959  1966). After that, you can get his songs through twofers, but they are usually very expensive. The soul music of Jerry Butler is both an explosion of raw, passionate energy, an artist reflection of its time, plus exploring, learning, revealing and relating. His soulful voice is oh so moving. The entire set is totally enjoyable, with great sound, and is highly recommended.

VIDEO (2D):San Andreas (2D) blasts onto blu-ray with MPEG-4 AVC 1080p 2.40:1 encode. This transfer is a stunner. Definition is beyond excellent. Details are consistently razor-sharp and natural in appearance. Unlike the 3D version, the colour here is beautifully saturated and natural. Blacks are inky. The many sweeping destruction scenes are simply spectacular on my 12 foot wide screen with anamorphic lens. The pictures are simply awesome. (5/5)VIDEO (3D):San Andreas (3D) rocks onto blu-ray with MPEG-4 MVC 1080p 2.40:1 encode. This film was not originally filmed in 3D, which was a post-conversion job. But the 3D effects are fairly impressive. General depth is always evident, whether considering wide-open spaces, like vast city or land overheads, or more intimate, confined spaces like the helicopter interior. The main criticism of this 3D version is that the colours are washed out, with the dimming of brightness. Watching 3D makes for a fun ride, but the 2D has more solid colour and definition. (4.5/5)AUDIO:San Andreas rattles onto blu-ray with Dolby Atmos/Dolby True-HD 5.1 soundtrack. The following description refers to Dolby True-HD since I do not have Atmos. This completely immersive and powerfully robust soundtrack is a true star of the film. Dialogue is clear no matter the on-screen chaos. It is in the various scenes of absolute earthquake destruction where the track really shines. It's heavy and rumbly, with deep bass that simply rocks the whole room. The musical score by Andrew Lockington is also outstanding. This soundtrack is considered one of the top soundtracks, like Fury and Mad Max: Fury Road. This is a totally immersive experience. Turn up the volume and get ready to rumble. (5+/5)MOVIE:The plot and storyline are simply unbelievable. To enjoy this movie to the fullest, you must leave your intellect behind, and simply enjoy all the fantastic, spectacular eye-candy CGI effects. Dwayne Johnson makes a good leading man, and is as solid as The Rock. I am sure you do smell what he is cooking. One minor surprise is the addition of my favourite singer Kylie Minogue as Susan Riddick, but unfortunately only for about 5 minutes. Still, now I simply cant get her out of my head. (4/5)TRIVIA:1 San Andreas has an estimated budget of $110 million, but it has a worldwide gross of $470 million, mainly from overseas.2 Riddick's headquarters building in San Francisco, where Blake, Ben and Ollie meet, is the Bank of America Building at 555 California Street. It was the same building, albeit with special effects, used in the disaster classic The Towering Inferno (1974).3 The first scene wherein the girl was playing "Style" by Taylor Swift actually foreshadows the events later on. The song includes the lyric "And when we go crashing down, we come back every time", which was what they did in the end.4 Did you notice that when Ray (Dwayne Johnson) steals the truck, he has to hot-wire it to start, but when he gets to the crack, he turns off the engine using the key.PACKAGING:This 3D set comes with separate 3D BD50 disc, 2D BD50 disc and DVD disc. Instead of using flipcase to house each disc separately, the DVD was stacked on top of the 2D blu-ray disc. Warner, dont be so cheap. However, it does have a fancy 3D lenticular cover.FINAL THOUGHTS:I personally like disaster movies. I still remember the experience of Sensurround system when I was watching Earthquake in local theatre in 1974.  San Andreas is big, loud, and stupid  but it never tries to be anything different. It's the perfect definition of a 'popcorn' flick, and often ignores logic and realism just to be entertainingwhich isn't necessarily a bad thing. I personally enjoyed the 2D version better because the colour was more solid with better definition, with outstanding CGI effects. It is an enjoyable movie, and is highly recommended.

VIDEO:Aladdin finally arrives on blu-ray with MPEG-4 AVC 1080p 1.85:1 encode. The transfer was stunning with vivid and vibrant colours that pop. Black levels are deep and inky. There is tremendous crisp details, from the crisp line art to every last tiny texture or touch in the background, the patterns on the flying carpet, the riches of the Cave of Wonders, or the splendor of the palace. There are minor hints of banding, but not distracting. (4.5/5)VIDEO:Aladdin arrives in North America with DTS-HD 7.1 Master Audio, which was an improvement to the Holland import with only 5.1 mix in 2013. The added channels create an engulfing feeling, especially during the musical numbers. Genie's "Friend Like Me" booms from every channel as the camera pans and rolls around the scene. Dialogue is clean, intelligible and smartly prioritized. Dynamics are excellent. This is an exciting and immersive soundtrack. (5/5)MOVIE:Referring to Disney's North American blu-ray release of Aladdin as "highly anticipated" or "long awaited" would be a gross understatement. It was fun in watching Robin Williams bringing the Genie to life with the kind of madcap flare that only he can provide. Also, the choice of voices is outstanding: Scott Weinger (Aladdin), Linda Larkin (Jasmine) and Jonathan Freeman (Jafar). There are also many memorable songs, like A Whole New World (which won Oscar for Best Original Song by Alan Menken (music) and Tim Rice (lyrics) plus Oscar for Best Original Score for Alan Menken. There are two versions of A Whole New World: within the movie sung by Lea Salonga and Brad Kane, plus the pop version during the end credits by Regina Belle and Peabo Bryson (Billboard Hot 100 #1(1)/1992). Great movie. (5/5)FINAL THOUGHTS:Aladdin is simply magical on high definition. It will make your heart race and your spirit soar. Both the video and especially the audio are outstanding with many great songs and lovely music. There are also new extras about Robin Williams as the Genie, a true tribute to the enchanting talent of Robin Williams, the Genius behind the Genie. This set is highly recommended to all.

RW Pop 24/1954)*double sided hit19 I DONT THINK YOU LOVE ME ANYMORE (Jack Pleis & His Orchestra)(Decca 9-29037)(b-side, April 1954)20 IN THE CHAPEL OF MOONLIGHT (Jack Pleis & His Orchestra)(Decca 9-29130)(a-side)(US 4/1954; CB Pop 5/1954; RW Pop 7/1954)(July 1954)21 POLLY PIGTAILS (Brunswick 05402)(UK b-side, April 1955)*ultra-rare gem; CD debut.22 I'M A LITTLE LONELY PETUNIA (IN AN ONION PATCH)(Brunswick 05402)(uncharted UK a-side, April 1955)*ultra-rare gem; CD debut.23 I WANT YOU ALL TO MYSELF (JUST YOU)(Jack Pleis & His Orchestra)(Decca 9-29268)(a-side)(US 30/1954; CB Pop 24/1954; RW Pop 22/1954)(November 1954)24 LITTLE THINGS MEAN A LOT (Jack Pleis & His Orchestra)(Decca 9-29037)(a-side)(US 1(9)/1954; CB Pop 1(7)/1954; RW Pop 12/1954; UK 1(1)/1954)(April 1954)*her biggest hit.POSITIVE POINTS:1 This set simply represents the most comprehensive coverage of the early career of Kitty Kallen, from 1940 to 1955, especially her band singer era. There are many rare gems making their CD debut.2 The sound is wonderfully remastered, as per usual high standards at Jasmine Records.3 The songs are sequence, more or less, chronologically.4 There is a 8-page booklet, with an informative essay by Geoff Milne. Names of orchestra are included.NEGATIVE POINTS:1 No label & number are included. While I appreciate the inclusion of session code number, that really does not help me to find the label & number. No chart position was included.2 Disc 1: time 73 minutes; disc 2: time 68 minutes. Surely, Jasmine Records could have filled up the empty spaces (19 minutes) with more songs. For example, there are 9 songs that Kitty sang when she was with Jack Teagarden in 1939 that could have been included.COMPLETE SINGLES DISCOGRAPHY:Kitty Kallen has 15 charted singles from 1949 to 1963. I have just painstakingly compiled a detailed Complete Singles Discography, including all her singles as band singer, plus her solo efforts, I found that she actually has 98 singles from 1939 to 1967 (178 songs not 196 songs because 18 b-sides belonged to other artists). Her labels are (1) Columbia (1939), (2) Varsity (1940), (3) Capitol (1942), (4) Decca (1943  1944), (5) V-Disc (1944 - 1945), (6) Columbia (1944  1945), (7) Musicraft (1946), (8) Mercury (1949  1951), (9) Columbia (1952), (10) Decca (1953  1957), (11) Columbia (1958  1961), (12) RCA Victor (1962  1963), (13) 20th Century-Fox (1964), (14) United Artists (1965), (15) Philips (1966), and (16) Bell (1967).FINAL THOUGHTS:Kitty Kallen was born Katherine Kalinsky on May 25, 1922 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She started as band singer for Jack Teagarden (1939-41), Bob Sherwood (1942), Jimmy Dorsey (1943  1944) and Harry James (1944  1945), Sonny Burke (1946), and Artie Shaw (1946). There are many memorable hits both as band singer and her solo career. She has an illustrious singing career, but has to cut short due to scarring of the lungs from apparent embolus to her lungs from estrogen replacement therapy.If you like her solo singles, I would recommend Our Lady Kitty Kallen (Sepia, 1CD, 2003, 25 songs, covering 1946  1952) plus Warm and Sincere (Sepia, 1CD, 2008, 27 songs, covering 1949  1957) and Little Things Mean A Lot (RPM, 2008, 28 songs). The best overall coverage is Kitty Kallen Collection 39-62 (Acrobat Music, 2CDs, 2015, 51 songs, already released in UK, which I have, but my review cannot be published until the US release date on December 11, 2015). Of course, the twofer If I Give My Heart To You/Honky Tonk Angel on Collectables is also recommended covering 1958  1961. Her output from 1963  1967 is sorely inadequate. I hope someday Bear Family will come out with a Complete Kitty Kallen box set.If you are interested in her band singer era, this current set with good coverage and many rare gems making CD debut, plus good sound, is highly recommended.

BB AC 12/1966; CB Pop 71/1966; RW Pop 67/1966)(August 1966)14 MORE THAN THE EYES CAN SEE (Peter DeAngelis & His Orchestra)(Capitol 5989)(a-side)(BB Pop 54/1967; BB AC 1(2)/1967; CB Pop 47/1967; RW Pop 41/1967)(August 1967)*not present in Collectors Series CD.15 LOVE IS BLUE (L'AMOUR EST BLEU)(Peter King & His Orchestra)(Capitol 2102)(a-side)(BB Pop 57/1968; BB AC 3(3)/1968; CB Pop 60/1968; RW Pop 54/1968)(January 1968)16 SAUSALITO (Al de Lory & His Orchestra)(Capitol 2468)(a-side)(BB Pop 99/1969; BB AC 13/1969; CB Pop 62/1969; RW Pop 59/1969)(April 1969)*not present in Collectors Series CD.17 CAN'T HELP FALLING IN LOVE (Michael Columbia & His Orchestra)(Capitol 2746)(a-side)(BB Pop 51/1970; BB AC 5/1970; CB Pop 57/1970; RW Pop 55/1970)(February 1970)18 SPEAK SOFTLY LOVE (Peter DeAngelis & His Orchestra)(Capitol 3313)(a-side)(BB Pop 80/1972; BB AC 24/1972; CB Pop 81/1972; RW Pop 77/1972)(April 1972)*from film "The Godfather"19 TO THE DOOR OF THE SUN (ALLE PORTE DEL SOLE)(Peter DeAngelis & His Orchestra)(Capitol 3987)(a-side)(BB Pop 17/1974; BB AC 7/1974; CB Pop 21/1974; RW Pop 29/1975)(November 1974)20 VOLARE (arranged by Al Capps)(Capitol 4134)(a-side)(BB Pop 33/1975; BB AC 9/1975; CB Pop 41/1975; RW Pop 69/1975)(August 1975)POSITIVE POINTS:1 There are many so-called Greatest Hits out there, which I have a few. I feel that this current set is the BEST Greatest Hits to date. The closest competitor is Capitol Collectors Series CD, with more songs but more inferior sound.2 The sound is very well remastered, much better than the Capitol Collectors Series CD.3 The songs are sequenced chronologically.4 There is a 10-page booklet, containing an informative essay by Will Friedwald. Label & number, name of orchestra, and chart positions are all included.NEGATIVE POINT:1 Time: 55 minutes. This practice may have been acceptable by 1999 standards. But by todays (2015) standards, surely, Razie & Tie could have filled up the remaining 25 minutes with more songs. The most glaring omissions include Mary in the Morning (BB 27/1967), plus earlier hits like Take My Heart (US 12/1952), Now (US 25/1952), Rachel (US 30/1953), When Youre Mine (US 27/1953), Wanted (UK 4/1954), Here In My Heart 1959 version with different orchestra (BB 86/1961) and Daddys Little Girl (BB 42/1967).COMPLETE SINGLES DISCOGRAPHY:Although Al Martino has 44 singles on the US chart, I have just painstakingly compiled a Complete Singles Discography, and found that he actually has 97 singles from 1952 - 1993 (a and b-sides, charted and uncharted, US, UK, Australian & Belgium, but only 181 songs, not 194 songs, because 13 songs were repeated releases). His labels are (1) Capitol (1952  1957), (2) Cub (1958), (3) 20th Fox (1959  1961), (4) Capitol (1961  1981) and Hansa (1993). His last single was Spanish Ballerina in 1993.FINAL THOUGHTS:Al Martino was born Alfred Cini on October 7, 1927 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvannia. He had his greatest success as a singer between the early 1950s and mid-1970s, being described as "one of the great Italian American pop crooners", and also became well known as an actor, particularly for his role as singer Johnny Fontane in The Godfather. As noted above, he has a long illustrious singles charting career with many memorable singles, like I Love You Because, Here in My Heart, Painted Tainted Rose, I Love You More And More Every Day, Mary in the Morning and Speak Softly Love. He also has numerous memorable albums, unfortunately, still not released on CDs. Al has such a smooth, charming voice, that simply soothes the heart. He died on October 13, 2009 (age 82).There is really no decent singles collection on Al Martino. If you like his pre-1962 materials, I would also recommend Take My Heart (Jasmine, 2CDs, 58 songs) and The Smooth Voice of Al Martino (Not Now Music, 2CDs, 50 songs, 2015). Although his singles after 1962 are sparsely available, I am glad to report that most of them are available online. Out of 181 songs, I am only missing 18 songs.If you are just looking for a Greatest Hits of Al Martino, this set with good coverage and great sound is highly recommended.

CONTENT:This 2-CD set Take My Heart, released by reputable reissue label Jasmine Records from UK in 2013, contain 58 songs, a combination of singles and album tracks from 1952  1962. I have compiled a detailed song listing (including name of orchestra, album and singles label & number, chart position, debut date, plus personal comments)(BB200=Billboard Album Chart; US=US Singles Chart prior to 1955; BB Pop=Billboard Hot 100; CB Pop=Cash Box Singles Chart; RW Pop=Record World Singles Chart; UK=UK Singles Chart):DISC 1:SINGLES:01 HERE IN MY HEART (Monty Kelly & His Orchestra)(Capitol CL.13779)(a-side)(US 1(3)/1952; CD debut.06 TIME AFTER TIME*from album Al Martino (Top Rank 030)(1959)07 AND I HAVE YOU, MY LOVE (Michael Goldin & His Orchestra)(20th Fox 45-180)(b-side, 1960)*rare gem; CD debut.08 THEY DIDNT BELIEVE ME*1959 version; rare gem; CD debut.09 MY ONE AND ONLY LOVE10 HOW SHOULD I TELL YOU11 CON AMORE12 THE MEMORY OF YOU (Aldo Provenzano & His Orchestra)(20th Fox 45-153)(b-side, July 1959)13 I CAN'T GET YOU OUT OF MY HEART (TI AMO, TI VOGLIO, AMOR)(Aldo Provenzano & His Orchestra)(20th Fox 45-132)(a-side)(BB Pop 44/1959; CB Pop 43/1959; RW Pop 25/1959)(March 1959)14 DARLING I LOVE YOU (Aldo Provenzano & His Orchestra)(20th Fox 45-153)(a-side)(BB Pop 63/1959; BB R&B 27/1959; CB Pop 52/1959; RW Pop 79/1959)(July 1959)15 I SOLD MY HEART (Stanley Applebaum & His Orchestra)(20th Fox 45-173)(b-side, December 1959)LP SWING ALONG WITH AL MARTINO (20th Fox 3032)(1959):16 BABY, WONT YOU PLEASE COME HOME17 ALL OF ME18 IT HAD TO BE YOU19 WHY DO I LOVE YOU? (Top Rank JAR-418)(UK b-side, July 1960)20 THREE LITTLE WORDS21 IVE GOT YOU UNDER MY SKIN22 WHEN YOUR LOVER HAS GONE23 ALL OR NOTHING AT ALL24 WITHOUT A WORD OF WARNING25 MAKIN WHOOPEE!26 SUNDAY (Top Rank JAR-418)(uncharted a-side, July 1960)27 THAT OLD FEELING28 SUMMERTIME (Stanley Applebaum & His Orchestra)(20th Fox 45-173)(a-side)(RW Pop 113/1960; UK 49/1960)(December 1959)SINGLE:29 OUR CONCERTO (IL NOSTRO CONCERTO)(Hugo Montenegro & His Orchestra)(20th Fox 45-213)(uncharted a-side, July 1960)*rare gem; CD debut.POSITIVE POINTS:1 This is a great collection of 50 songs, consisting of Als singles and 3 rare albums prior to 1962. As noted above, there are many rare gems making their CD debut. This set represents the most comprehensive coverage of Al Martinos output prior to 1962 to date.2 The sound is very well remastered, as per usual high standards at Jasmine Records.3 There is a 6-page booklet, with an informative essay by Ossie Dales.NEGATIVE POINTS:1 No labels & numbers, chart position, names of source albums, names of orchestra, are included.2 The songs are not arranged chronologically, sometimes with a-side on disc 1 and b-side on disc 2.3 As per usual tradition with UK reissue label, the compilation would stop at 1962 because of local Public Domain laws. Therefore, if you are looking for his biggest hits, like I Love You Because, etc., please look elsewhere.COMPLETE SINGLES DISCOGRAPHY:Although Al Martino has 44 singles on the US chart, I have just painstakingly compiled a Complete Singles Discography, and found that he actually has 97 singles from 1952 - 1993 (a and b-sides, charted and uncharted, US, UK, Australian & Belgium, but only 181 songs, not 194 songs, because 13 songs were repeated releases). His labels are (1) Capitol (1952  1957), (2) Cub (1958), (3) 20th Fox (1959  1961), (4) Capitol (1961  1981) and Hansa (1993). His last single was Spanish Ballerina in 1993.FINAL THOUGHTS:Al Martino was born Alfred Cini on October 7, 1927 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvannia. He had his greatest success as a singer between the early 1950s and mid-1970s, being described as "one of the great Italian American pop crooners", and also became well known as an actor, particularly for his role as singer Johnny Fontane in The Godfather. As noted above, he has a long illustrious singles charting career with many memorable singles, like I Love You Because, Here in My Heart, Painted Tainted Rose, I Love You More And More Every Day, Mary in the Morning and Speak Softly Love. He also has numerous memorable albums, unfortunately, still not released on CDs. Al has such a smooth, charming voice, that simply soothes the heart. He died on October 13, 2009 (age 82).There is really no decent singles collection on Al Martino. The best Greatest Hits CD that I would recommend is The Al Martino Collection (Razer & Tie, 1999, 20 songs, covering his entire career). If you like his pre-1962 materials, besides the current set, I would also recommend The Smooth Voice of Al Martino (Not Now Music, 2CDs, 50 songs, 2015). Although his singles after 1962 are sparsely available, I am glad to report that most of them are available online. Out of 181 songs, I am only missing 18 songs. Remember again that this set does not have his more modern big hits as stated above. But, this set, with good sound and many singles and rare gems, is still highly recommended to all Al Martino fans.

There are many rare gems, making their CD debut. The three rare albums are The Exciting Voice of Al Martino, Al Martino and Swing Along with Al Martino."2 The sound is very well remastered.3 The price is very cheap.NEGATIVE POINTS:1 The songs are not arranged chronologically, sometimes with a-side on disc 1 and b-side on disc 2. This is the usual practice with Not Now Music, a budget label that haphazardly and arbitrary creates its own song listing.2 As per usual tradition with UK reissue label, the compilation would stop at 1962 because of local Public Domain laws. Therefore, if you are looking for his biggest hits, like I Love You Because, etc., please look elsewhere.3 No label & number, no chart position and no name or source album were listed. It took me quite awhile to track the source of the songs down, either singles with label & number, chart position or name of source album.4 There is no detailed essay. In the past, the package includes gatefold cardboard cases. Now the packaging is replaced by the usual 2-CD plastic case. The 4-page booklet is quite forgettable.COMPLETE SINGLES DISCOGRAPHY:Although Al Martino has 44 singles on the US chart, I have just painstakingly compiled a Complete Singles Discography, and found that he actually has 97 singles from 1952 - 1993 (a and b-sides, charted and uncharted, US, UK, Australian & Belgium, but only 181 songs, not 194 songs, because 13 songs were repeated releases). His labels are (1) Capitol (1952  1957), (2) Cub (1958), (3) 20th Fox (1959  1961), (4) Capitol (1961  1981) and Hansa (1993). His last single was Spanish Ballerina in 1993.FINAL THOUGHTS:Al Martino was born Alfred Cini on October 7, 1927 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvannia. He had his greatest success as a singer between the early 1950s and mid-1970s, being described as "one of the great Italian American pop crooners", and also became well known as an actor, particularly for his role as singer Johnny Fontane in The Godfather. As noted above, he has a long illustrious singles charting career with many memorable singles, like I Love You Because, Here in My Heart, Painted Tainted Rose, I Love You More And More Every Day, Mary in the Morning and Speak Softly Love. He also has numerous memorable albums, unfortunately, still not released on CDs. Al has such a smooth, charming voice, that simply soothes the heart. He died on October 13, 2009 (age 82).There is really no decent singles collection on Al Martino. The best Greatest Hits CD that I would recommend is The Al Martino Collection (Razer & Tie, 1999, 20 songs, covering his entire career). If you like his pre-1962 materials, besides the current set, I would also recommend Take My Heart (Jasmine, 2CDs, 58 songs, 2013). Although his singles after 1962 are sparsely available, I am glad to report that most of them are available online. Out of 181 songs, I am only missing 18 songs. This set, with good sound and cheap price, is highly recommended to all Al Martino fans.

VIDEO:The Return of Count Yorga creeps onto blu-ray with MPEG-4 AVC 1080p 1.85:1 encode, just in time for Halloween. As a youngster, there were 3 movies that really scared me: House of Wax (with Vincent Price), Horror of Dracula (with Christopher Lee) and The Return of Count Yorga (with Richard Quarry). This movie was available as a twofer on DVD, but very expensive. I am glad that it has finally risen from the high definition grave. Considering this movie was from 1971, the video was quite acceptable, with some details. Original grain was retained. Colours were vibrant, especially bloody red. Skin tone was natural. Black levels were good. (3.5/5)AUDO:With a very strong English DTS-HD MA 1.0 track, The Return of Count Yorga sounds wonderful. Dialogue is crisp and clear and easily heard throughout. The amazing haunting violin-dominated score by Bill Marx has plenty of separation from the dialogue and sound effects elements and comes through to creepy effect. Like the scene when Yorga suddenly appeared at the end of a long corridor, gnashing his teeth, running at an intended victim with outstretched hands, the sound effect maximizes the horrified helpless feelings of the victim. As a senior now, I still hate long, dark corridor. (Another such creepy long corridor scene is from The Shining). (4/5)MOVIE:Yorga and his servant Brudda, who were supposedly killed in the original Count Yorga, Vampire, were brought back to life by those notoriously supernatural Santa Ana winds. Robert Quarry was stellar of course. This was also the final film for George Macready (as Professor Rightstat), father to Michael Macready, who produced both Count Yorga films. This film also marked the debut of Craig T. Nelson (as Sgt. OConnor). If you listen carefully to the dialogue, there is tremendous humour in it. Count Yorga also currently holds the record to the vampire who has the most mistresses (9I think). This movie still holds a special place in my heart. (5/5).FINAL THOUGHTS:The original Count Yorga, Vampire was also available on blu-ray on October 13, 2015, but unfortunately, it turned out to be a limited edition (3000 copies) by Twilight Time, and not readily available.Finally, The Return of Count Yorga is available on high definition with pretty good video and audio. Thank you, Scream Factory. I am happy with my purchase, and this set is highly recommended.

CONTENT:This twofer If I Give My Heart to You/Honky Tonk Angel by Kitty Kallen, released by Collectables from US in 2000, contains 24 songs. I have compiled a detailed song listing (including album and singles label & number, chart position, debut date, plus personal comments)(BB Pop=Billboard Hot 100; CB Pop=Cash Box Singles Chart; RW Pop=Record World Singles Chart):LP IF I GIVE MY HEART TO YOU (Columbia CL 1409)(1959):01 Need Me (Columbia 4-41546)(b-side, January 1960)(RW Pop 91/1960)*double sided hit.02 Driftwood On The River03 Always In My Heart (Columbia 4-41622)(b-side, March 1960)*rare gem; CD debut.04 Never in a Million Years05 Because Youre Mine06 Got A Date With An Angel (Columbia 4-41622)(a-side)(RW Pop 111/1960)(March 1960)07 If I Give My Heart to You (Columbia 4-41473)(a-side)(BB Pop 34/1959; CB Pop 25/1959; RW Pop 27/1959)(September 1959)08 Blues in My Heart09 That Old Feeling (Columbia 4-41546)(a-side)(BB Pop 55/1960; CB Pop 100/1960; RW Pop 87/1960)(February 1960)10 Vaya Con Dios11 Blue Doll12 Love Is A Sacred Thing (Columbia 4-41236)(a-side)(RW Pop 82/1958)(September 1958)LP HONKY TONK ANGEL (COUNTRY SONGS WITH A CITY FLAVOR) (Columbia CL 1652)(1961):13 Ill Never Stand In Your Way14 Your Cheatin Heart15 Be My Lifes Companion16 It Wasnt God Who Made Honky Tonk Angels (Columbia 4-42247)(a-side)(BB Pop 101/1962; CB Pop 137/1962)(December 1961)17 Raining In My Heart (Columbia 4-41934)(b-side, January 1961)*rare gem; CD debut.18 A Poor Mans Roses (Or A Rich Mans Gold)19 You Are My Sunshine (Columbia 4-42247)(b-side, December 1961)*rare gem; CD debut.20 Careless Hands21 I Love You Because22 Someday (Youll Want Me To Want You)23 Ill Walk Alone Last Night24 Hey, Good Lookin (Columbia 4-41934)(a-side)(RW Pop 111/1961)(January 1961)POSITIVE POINTS:1 These are two popular Kitty Kallen albums, now finally making their CD debut. She gave her own interpretation of popular hits by other artists. In Honky Tonk Angel, she smoothed out every hard core country influence and replaced them with easy-listening croon.2 The sound is surprisingly good (by usual low Collectables standards).NEGATIVE POINT:1 There are no bonus tracks.FINAL THOUGHTS:Kitty Kallen was born Katherine Kalinsky on May 25, 1922 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She started as band singer for Jack Teagarden (1939-41), Bob Sherwood (1942), Jimmy Dorsey (1943  1944) and Harry James (1944  1945), Sonny Burke (1946), and Artie Shaw (1946). There are many memorable hits both as band singer and her solo career. She has an illustrious singing career, but has to cut short due to scarring of the lungs from apparent embolus to her lungs from estrogen replacement therapy.If you are interested in her band singer era, I would recommend Little Things Mean A Lot (Jasmine, 2CDs, 2005, 47 songs). As to her solo career, I would recommend Our Lady Kitty Kallen (Sepia, 1CD, 2003, 25 songs, covering 1946  1952), Warm and Sincere (Sepia, 1CD, 2008, 27 songs covering 1949  1955) and Little Things Mean A Lot (RPM, 2008, 28 songs). The best overall coverage, with fantastic sound, is Kitty Kallen Collection 39-62 (Acrobat Music, 2CDs, 2015, 51 songs, already released in UK, but to be released in US on December 11, 2015). Her output from 1963  1967 is sorely inadequate. I hope someday Bear Family will come out with a Complete Kitty Kallen box set. Since most of her albums were released prior to 1962, perhaps, Real Gone Music (UK) can release Classic Album Collection on Kitty Kallen. There are still 6 albums from 1954  1962 that have yet to make their debut on CDs.If you like Kitty Kallen, this set is highly recommended.

There are 17 rare gems making their CD debut. The producer has done an excellent job in the song selection because there are songs that are not found in her singles discography. This is simply a collectors dream come true. Thank you, Sepia Records.2 The sound is simply wonderfully remastered: clean, vibrant and warm, as per high standards at Sepia Records using 24 bit Cedar Remastering System.3 The songs are arranged chronologically.4 There is a wonderful 12-page booklet, with an informative essay by Tony Middleton. Names of orchestra and dates of recordings are included. There are five autographed pictures of Kitty Kallen, two addressed directly to Sepia Records. With the good work of releasing her many songs, Sepia Records, you certainly deserved those beautiful autographed pictures.NEGATIVE POINT:1 There are some rare b-sides as noted above that are not included.2 No label & number, chart position were included.COMPLETE SINGLES DISCOGRAPHY:Kitty Kallen has 15 charted singles from 1949 to 1963. I have just painstakingly compiled a detailed Complete Singles Discography, including all her singles as band singer, plus her solo efforts, I found that she actually has 98 singles from 1939 to 1967 (178 songs not 196 songs because 18 b-sides belonged to other artists). Her labels are (1) Columbia (1939), (2) Varsity (1940), (3) Capitol (1942), (4) Decca (1943  1944), (5) V-Disc (1944 - 1945), (6) Columbia (1944  1945), (7) Musicraft (1946), (8) Mercury (1949  1951), (9) Columbia (1952), (10) Decca (1953  1957), (11) Columbia (1958  1961), (12) RCA Victor (1962  1963), (13) 20th Century-Fox (1964), (14) United Artists (1965), (15) Philips (1966), and (16) Bell (1967).FINAL THOUGHTS:Kitty Kallen was born Katherine Kalinsky on May 25, 1922 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She started as band singer for Jack Teagarden (1939-41), Bob Sherwood (1942), Jimmy Dorsey (1943  1944) and Harry James (1944  1945), Sonny Burke (1946), and Artie Shaw (1946). There are many memorable hits both as band singer and her solo career. She has an illustrious singing career, but has to cut short due to scarring of the lungs from apparent embolus to her lungs from estrogen replacement therapy.If you are interested in her band singer era, I would recommend Little Things Mean A Lot (Jasmine, 2CDs, 2005, 48 songs). As to her solo career, I would recommend the current set, plus Our Lady Kitty Kallen (Sepia, 1CD, 2003, 25 songs, covering 1946  1952) and Little Things Mean A Lot (RPM, 2008, 28 songs). The best overall coverage is Kitty Kallen Collection 39-62 (Acrobat Music, 2CDs, 2015, 51 songs, already released in UK, which I have already but my review cannot be published until the US release date of December 11, 2015). Of course, the twofer If I Give My Heart To You/Honky Tonk Angel on Collectables is also recommended covering 1958  1961. Her output from 1963  1967 is sorely inadequate. I hope someday Bear Family will come out with a Complete Kitty Kallen box set.If you are collecting Kitty Kallen, this set, with many rare gems making their CD debut, together with top-rated sound, is simply a Must-Own.

As to her solo career, I would recommend Our Lady Kitty Kallen (Sepia, 1CD, 2008, 25 songs, covering 1946  1952), Warm and Sincere (Sepia, 1CD, 2008, 27 songs, covering 1949  1957). The best overall coverage is Kitty Kallen Collection 39-62 (Acrobat Music, 2CDs, 2015, 51 songs) released in UK already, and on December 11 2015 in US. Of course, the twofer If I Give My Heart To You/Honky Tonk Angel on Collectables is also recommended covering 1958  1961. Her output from 1963  1967 is sorely inadequate. I hope some day Bear Family will come out with a Complete Kitty Kallen box set.This set, with only 24 songs and average sound, but a few rare gems is recommended more for collectors.

CONTENT:I have compiled a detailed song listing (with singles label & number, chart position, source of albums, with personal comments)(BB=Billboard Hot 100; AC=Billboard Adult Contemporary Chart; CB=Cash Box; RW=Record World; UK=British Singles Chart):01 ALL OVER THE WORLD (MCA 41289)(a-side)(BB 13/1980; AC 46/1980; CB 14/1980; RW 8/1980; UK 11/1980)*from album Xanadu02 EVIL WOMAN (Jet 729)(a-side)(BB 10/1975; CB 9/1975; RW 9/1975; UK 10/1976)*from album Face the Music03 MA-MA-MA BELLE (United Artists 405)(UK b-side)(UK 22/1974)*double sided hit; a-side: Daybreaker; from album On The Third Day04 SHOWDOWN (Jet 842)(a-side)(BB 59/1976; CB 75/1976; RW 80/1976)*charted twice! From album Ole ELO05 LIVIN THING (Jet 888)(a-side)(BB 13/1976; AC 36/1976; CB 10/1976; RW 10/1976; UK 4/1976)*from album A New World Record06 STRANGE MAGIC (Jet 770)(a-side)(BB 14/1976; AC 24/1976; CB 14/1976; RW 20/1976; UK 38/1976)*from album Face the Music07 10538 OVERTURE (United Artists 50914)(a-side)(UK 9/1972)*from album Electric Light Orchestra08 CANT GET IT OUT OF MY HEAD (United Artists 573)(a-side)(BB 9/1974; CB 14/1974; RW 23/1974)*from album Eldorado09 SWEET TALKIN WOMAN (Jet 1145)(a-side)(BB 17/1978; CB 18/1978; RW 23/1978; UK 6/1978)*from album Out of the Blue10 TURN TO STONE (Jet 1099)(a-side)(BB 13/1977; CB 11/1977; RW 9/1977; UK 18/1977)*from album Out of the Blue11 STEPPIN OUT*from album Out of the Blue12 HANDLE WITH CARE (Wilbury 27732)(a-side)(BB 45/1988; AC 30/1988; CB 39/1988; UK 21/1988)*from album Volume One by the Traveling Wilburys13 DONT BRING ME DOWN (Jet 5060)(a-side)(BB 4/1979; CB 4/1979; RW 3(3)/1979; UK 3/1979)*from album Discovery14 ROCK N ROLL IS KING (Jet 03964)(a-side)(BB 19/1983; AC 36/1983; CB 22/193; UK 13/1983)*from album Secret Messages15 TELEPHONE LINE (Jet 1000)(a-side)(BB 7/1977; CB 4/1977; RW 7/1977; UK 8/1977)*from album A New World Record16 MR. BLUE SKY (Jet 5050)(a-side)(BB 35/1978; CB 27/1978; RW 33/1978; UK 6/1978)*from album Out of the BlueVIDEO:This Live in Hyde Park by Jeff Lynnes ELO arrives on blu-ray with MPEG-4 AVC 1080i 1.78:1 encode. Compared with recent Out of the Blue blu-ray filmed in the 70s, this video, shot in September 2014, give us the modern presentation with widescreen and very sharp video. The colours are vibrant, especially those pictures on the half-moon shaped video screen, like those of the colourful spaceship and spectacular light show. The images are sharp. Blacks are inky. This is ELOs at their modern best. (5/5)AUDIO:This concert comes with LPCM Stereo. The sound is really excellent, with Jeff Lynnes voice fully displayed. All the different instruments are clearly defined. Richard Tandy (original member) was fantastic on piano. The backing BBC Concert Orchestra was in top form and did not miss a note. I must mention the outstanding violin solos by pretty blonde, Chereene Allan, in hot pants, especially in Livin Thing and Sweet Talkin Woman. After you have watched her play, you will agree that her violin play was purely Strange Magic. The entire backing group was very tight. Jeff Lynne was able to reproduce the studio sound onto live concert. Too bad there was no DTS HD 5.1 Master Audio. (5/5)CONCERT & BONUS FEATURES:This concert reflects ELO at their best, playing all their greatest hits. In the last Out of the Blue blu-ray, the more modern songs were left out because it was filmed in 1979 before those songs were released. Here, we have all those missing big hits, like All Over The World, and Rock and Roll Is King. The very special bonus is the inclusion of Handle with Care, a big hit by the Traveling Wilburys. Concert (5+/5)You must also watch Mr. Blue Sky: The Story of Jeff Lynne & ELO, detailing from the very beginning of Jeffs career with group like Idle Race and Move, eventually creating ELO with Richard Tandy. You also see how Jeff Lynne re-energized the career of George Harrison and Roy Orbison. There is a segment of the Traveling Wilburys. It was really poignant to watch the late George Harrison and Roy Orbison in action. We also have interviews from Paul McCartney, George Harrisons wife, Olivia, and their son, Dhani, who looked exactly like George. Jeff Lynne as a producer for the two hits by the Beatles Free As A Bird and Real Love was well documented. After you finished watching this rather lengthy but totally enjoyable documentary, I simply marvel at the musical genius of Jeff Lynne. (5/5)FINAL THOUGHTS:This is simply the best blu-ray concert released in 2015. Although only two original members of ELO were there, the sound was pure ELO. Both the video and audio are better than the Out of the Blue concert in 1979, a benefit from modern technology in both video and audio. The entire concert was totally enjoyable, and you cant help singing along with those wonderful tunes. This set is very highly recommended.

RW C&W 35/1961)*double sided hit.20 SOFT RAIN (Columbia 4-42132)(a-side)(BB Pop 115/1961; BB C&W 3(1)/1961; RW C&W 4/1961)(November 1961)21 IVE JUST DESTROYED THE WORLD (Columbia 4-42310)(a-side)(BB C&W 12/1962; RW C&W 26/1962)(June 1962)22 BIG SHOES (Columbia 4-42310)(b-side, June 1962)(BB C&W 22/1962; RW C&W 11/1962)*double sided hit.23 IM WALKIN SLOW (AND THINKING BOUT HER)(Columbia 4-42518)(b-side, September 1962)24 PRIDE (Columbia 4-42518)(a-side)(BB C&W 5/1962; RW C&W 10/1962)(September 1962)25 WALK ME TO THE DOOR (Columbia 4-42658)(a-side)(BB C&W 7/1963; RW C&W 6/1963)(March 1963)26 YOU TOOK HER OFF MY HANDS (NOW PLEASE TAKE HER OFF MY MIND)(Columbia 4-42658)(b-side, March 1963)(BB C&W 11/1963; RW C&W 11/1963)POSITIVE POINTS:1 This collection represents the most complete and comprehensive coverage of his singles (a and b-sides, charted and uncharted) from 1950  1962 at reasonable price. You can get this complete coverage and more on the Bear Family box set Honky Tonk Years 1950 -66 (10 CDs, 2002), but very expensive (nearly $290).2 The songs are sequenced chronologically.3 The sound is very well remastered, almost perfect. Besides critical listening, I now rip the songs onto wav files in my computer. Being a remasterer, I can tell how much efforts the producers have put in from the wav files. In this case, the sound is excellent.4 There is an excellent 24-page booklet with an informative essay by Paul Watts. Label & number plus chart positions are included. Recording session details are also included, just like those with Bear Family. Excellent job!!!NEGATIVE POINT:1 As per usual practice with reissue labels in UK, their compilation would stop at 1962 because of local Public Domain laws. This is a pity. There are 76 more charted singles (152 songs) from 1963 to 1989, including Make The World Go Away (BB C&W 2/1963), For The Good Times (BB C&W 1(1)/1970), I Wont Mention It Again (BB C&W 1(3)/1971), Shes Got To Be A Saint (BB C&W 1(3)/1962) and his last No. 1 single Youre The Best Thing That Ever Happened To Me (BB C&W 1(1)/1973). His singles coverage on CDs after 1962 is poor. I guess we need another couple box sets from Bear Family to complete his lengthy career.FINAL THOUGHTS:Ray Price was born on January 12, 1926 in Perryville, Texas, and raised in Dallas. He was known as The Cherokee Cowboy. His most famous song Crazy Arms currently is ranked #5 on the country chart for No. 1 songs with 20 weeks. (The current champion is Cruise by Florida Georgia Line with 24 weeks at No. 1). If you like the early Ray Price, this set is simply the best collection out there with great sound and reasonable price. This set is highly recommended to all the fans of Ray Price and country music.Lastly, if you like this type of comprehensive coverage of country artists, I would also recommend similar Complete Country Hits by Eddy Arnold, Hank Snow, Kitty Wells, Webb Pierce and Marty Robbins by Acrobat Music.

CONTENT:Golden Classics by the Three Chuckles, released by Collectables from US in 1997, contains 18 songs. I have compiled a detailed song listing (including singles label & number, chart position, debut date, plus personal comments)(US=US Singles Chart prior to 1955; BB Pop=Billboard Hot 100; CB Pop=Cash Box Singles Chart; RW Pop=Record World Singles Chart):01 AT LAST YOU UNDERSTAND ("X" 0066)(b-side, October 1954)02 RUNAROUND ("X" 0066)(a-side)(US 20/1954; CB Pop 28/1954; RW Pop 25/1954)(October 1954)*first released on Boulevard 100 in 1954; #23 hit for The Fleetwoods in 1960.03 FOOLISHLY ("X" 0095)(a-side)(CB Pop 45/1955; RW Pop 70/1955)(March 1955)04 IF YOU SHOULD LOVE AGAIN ("X" 0095)(b-side, March 1955)*rare gem; not available online.05 SO LONG ("X" 0134)(uncharted a-side, May 1955)06 YOU SHOULD HAVE TOLD ME ("X" 0134)(b-side, May 1955)07 BLUE LOVER ("X" 0150)(b-side, July 1955)*rare gem; not available online.08 REALIZE ("X" 0150)(uncharted a-side, July 1955)*rare gem; not available online.09 TIMES TWO, I LOVE YOU ("X" 0162)(a-side)(BB Pop 67/1955; RW Pop 61/1955)(November 1955)10 STILL THINKING OF YOU ("X" 0162)(b-side, November 1955)(RW Pop 57/1955)*double sided hit11 ANYWAY ("X" 0186)(b-side, December 1956)12 THE FUNNY LITTLE THING WE USED TO DO ("X" 0186)(uncharted a-side, December 1956)*rare gem; not available online.13 TELL ME (THAT YOUR LOVE IS FOR ME)(Vik 4X-0194)(b-side, March 1956)14 AND THE ANGELS SING (Vik 4X-0194)(a-side)(BB Pop 70/1956)(March 1956)15 GYPSY IN MY SOUL (Vik 4X-0216)(uncharted a-side, June 1956)16 WERE STILL HOLDING HANDS (Vik 4X-0216)(b-side, June 1956)*rare gem; not available online.17 MIDNIGHT TIL DAWN (Vik 4X-0232)(b-side, 1956)*rare gem; not available online; a-side Falling Out of Love is missing here.18 WERE GONNA ROCK TONIGHT (Vik 4X- 0244)(uncharted a-side, December 1956)POSITIVE POINTS:1 This is currently the only CD collection on the Three Chuckles, released by Collectables. Initially, I have reservation about this set because Collectables in the past was known to produce only 6-8 songs with bad sound. I am glad to say that this current set is an exception. There are 18 songs, with many making their CD debut, and some of them not even available online.2 The sound is surprisingly acceptable.3 The songs are arranged chronologically.4 There is a 6-page booklet with an informative essay by Mark Marymont on the group.NEGATIVE POINTS:1 Time: 44 minutes. There are still a few songs (singles) missing and Collectables could have filled up the remaining space with those missing songs to make this a truly complete singles collection:(1)  FALLING OUT OF LOVE (Vik 4X-0232)(uncharted a-side, 1956)(2)  WONT YOU GIVE ME A CHANCE (Vik 4X- 0244)(b-side, December 1956)*available online.(3)  NEXT STOP PARADISE (Teddy Randazzo & the Three Chuckles)(Vik 4X-0277)(a-side)(CB Pop 59/1957; RW Pop 47/1957)(May 1957)*available on Teddy Randazzo CD.(4)  HOW COULD YOU KNOW (Teddy Randazzo & the Three Chuckles)(Vik 4X-0277)(b-side, May 1957)*available online.2 Label & number and chart position were not included.FINAL THOUGHTS:I bought this CD mainly to complete my Teddy Randazzo Collection. The original members of the Three Chuckles were Tommy Romano, Tommy (Russ) Gilberto and Phil Benti. They got their name from a candy bar. In 1953, Phil quit and Teddy Randazzo joined the group. The rest, I guess, was history. If you like Teddy Randazzo, this set is highly recommended.

CONTENT:This 4-CD box set, Live in Las Vegas, originally released in 2001 and now re-released in September 2015 by RCA, contain exactly the same song listing, but the discs are housed in a smaller long box. I have compiled a detailed song listing (containing original dates of the performance):DISC 1:FROM INTERNATIONAL HOTEL, DINNER SHOW, AUGUST 24, 1969:Program One:01 Blue Suede Shoes02 I Got A Woman03 All Shook Up04 Elvis Welcomes The Audience05 Love Me Tender06 Jailhouse Rock/Dont Be Cruel07 Heartbreak Hotel08 Hound Dog09 I Cant Stop Loving You10 Johnny B. Goode11 Baby What You Want Me To Do12 RunawayProgram Two:13 Are You Lonesome Tonight14 Yesterday/Hey Jude15 Introductions16 In The Ghetto17 Suspicious Minds18 Whatd I Say19 Cant Help Falling In Love20 Elvis Talks About His CareerPositive Points:1 This is the complete concert from August 24, 1969. The rare gems in this concert are Baby What You Want Me To Do, Runaway, I Cant Stop Loving You and Johnny B. Goode. If you want his August 21 concert, you can find it in CD Viva Las Vegas (make sure get the 2 CD set). If you want the August 26 concert, you can find it in single CD Live in Vegas. Songs from those few dates are also found in disc 3 Collectors Gold (1991).2 The sound is perfect and excellently remastered. Ricky Nelsons guitarist, James Burton, is outstanding. The backing group, the Sweet Inspirations, gives a good support.Negative Points:1 For some unknown reasons, producers Ernst Michael Jorgensen and Dennis Ferrante decided to edit the piano tracks by Larry Muhoberac out. In some tracks, you can barely hear the piano, leaked from other microphones. This is totally bizarre, and the 2015 edition has not corrected this injustice.2 Another bizarre fact is that Jorgensen decided to move Elviss monologue about his career from after track 10 to the end. His explanation was playing convenience. This unilateral unnecessary edit really undermines the historic value of this box.DISC 2:FROM INTERNATIONAL HOTEL, AUGUST 11, 1970:Program One:01 Thats All Right02 I Got A Woman03 Hound Dog04 Love Me Tender05 There Goes My Everything06 Just Pretend07 I Just Cant Help Believin08 Something09 Men with Broken Hearts10 Walk A Mile In My Shoes11 Youve Lost That Loving FeelingProgram Two:12 Polk Salad Annie13 One Night14 Dont be Cruel15 Love Me16 Instrumental Vamp17 Heartbreak Hotel18 Introductions19 Bridge Over Troubled Water20 Suspicious Minds21 Cant Help Falling In Love22 When The Snow Is On the RosesPositive Points:1 The sound is again excellent, perfectly remastered. In this concert, all the different instruments are clearly defined, especially the piano of Glen D. Hardin. Of course, James Burton was outstanding as usual. Simply a fabulous great sounding concert.2 The rare gems include recitation of Hank Williams Men With Broken Hearts, Something and When the Snow Is On The Roses.NEGATIVE POINT:1 This concert was previously found in Thats The Way It Is Special Edition, disc 2, and also Essential 70s Masters disc 5.DISC 3:FROM INTERNATIONAL HOTEL, FEBRUARY 1970:Program One:01 See See Rider*from February 18, 197002 Release Me*from February 18, 197003 Sweet Caroline*from February 16, 197004 The Wonder of You*from February 18, 197005 Polk Salad Annie*from February 18, 197006 Proud Mary*from February 16, 197007 Walk A Mile In My Shoes*from February 19, 197008 In The Ghetto*from February 19, 197009 Let It Be Me*from February 17, 197010 Dont Cry Daddy*from February 17, 197011 Kentucky Rain*from February 17, 1970Program Two:12 Long Tall Sally*from February 18, 197013 I Cant Stop Loving You*from February 19, 197014 Suspicious Minds*from February 19, 197015 Never Been To Spain*from February 16, 197216 You Gave Me A Mountain*from February 16, 197217 Its Impossible*from February 16, 197218 Its Over*from February 17, 197219 Hound Dog*from February 14, 197220 Little Sister/Get Back*from February 14, 197221 A Big Hunk of Love*from February 16, 197222 The Impossible Dream*from February 16, 197223 An American Triology*from February 16, 1972Positive Points:1 The sound is again excellently remastered. Elviss voice was centralized in full display, with the backing instruments, like James Burtons guitar and backing vocals by the Sweet Inspirations clearly defined. It should be noted that J.D. Sumner appeared on tracks 15-23.2 There are just too many great live rare gems.Negative Point:1 The above songs are previously released on Elvis On Stage (1999) and Burning Love (1999).DISC 4:FROM FRONTIER HOTEL, LAS VEGAS, 1956:Program One:01 Heartbreak Hotel*from May 6, 195602 Long Tall Sally*from May 6, 195603 Blue Suede Shoes*from May 6, 195604 Money Honey*from May 6, 195605 Promised Land*from May 6, 1956FROM INTERNATIONAL HOTEL, LAS VEGAS, 1974:06 Its Midnight*from August 21, 197507 If You Talk In Your Sleep*from August 21, 197508 Im Leavin*from August 21, 197509 Why Me Lord*from August 21, 197510 Help Me*from August 22, 197511 Softly As I Leave You*from August 21, 197512 My Baby Left Me*from August 19, 1975Program Two:13 Its Now or Never*from August 27, 197514 Hawaiian Wedding Song*from August 21, 197515 Trying to Get to You*from August 20, 197516 Green, Green Grass of Home*from March 197517 Youre The Reason Im Living*from March 197518 Big Boss Man*from March 30, 197519 Burning Love*from March 30, 197520 My Boy*from March 30, 197521 And I Love You So*from December 6, 197522 Just Pretend*from December 6, 197523 How Great Thou Art*from December 6, 197524 America The Beautiful*from December 6, 1975Positive Points:1 The sound is good for the 50s material, but excellent for the 70s materials.2 There are many live rare gems.Negative Point:1 All the above songs were previously released on The Essential 50s Masters and Elvis Aron Presley silver box set.PACKAGING:This box set comes with a smaller vertical box. There is a 32-page booklet, with many rare pictures and informative essay. The unusual design of the CD holder makes one difficult to take out and put back without putting finger prints on the CDs. Poor design.FINAL THOUGHTS:This is a re-release of the original Live in Las Vegas except in smaller size vertical box, at a lower price too. I would have preferred the bigger size box hopefully with bigger size letters, making it easier for older folks like myself to read, but the price is much more expensive. After listening to the whole set, one will appreciate why Elvis is still our KING. This set is highly recommended

VIDEO (3D):Avengers: Age of Ultron - 3D arrives on blu-ray with MPEG-4 MVC 1080p 2.40:1 encode. Ultron offers fantastic 3D with a remarkable sense of pop-out and window-into-another-world effects. There is tremendous depth separation, making the action more realistic. There is no loss of brightness when compared to 2D. All the positive attributes for 2D also apply to 3D. This is simply a remarkable 3D experience. (5+/5).VIDEO (2D):Avengers: Age of Ultron - 2D arrives on blu-ray with MPEG-4 AVC 1080p 2.40: 1 encode. There are tremendous details. Images are razor-sharp. Colours simply sparkle, especially with those CGI effects. Blacks are inky. Skin tone is natural. When compared to 3D, this 2D looks flatter and less grand, but still is a fantastic transfer. (5/5)AUDIO (3D/2D):Avengers: Age of Ultron blasts onto blu-ray with DTS-HD 7.1 Master Audio soundtrack, which has tremendous dynamic range. While those explosions will rock your home theatre, there are quiet scenes with clear surround effects, like birds chirping. Dialogue was clearly heard. To appreciate the true power of this soundtrack, you really owe it to yourself to turn up the volume. This is a total immersive experience. (5/5).TRIVIA:1 Avengers: Age of Ultron has an estimated budget of $250 million, and it has a worldwide gross of $1,403 million. Currently it is #5 on the All-Time list, behind Avatar ($2,788 million), Titanic ($2,167 million), Jurassic World ($1,662 million), Marvels The Avengers ($1,520 million) and Furious 7 ($1,512 million). However, for 2015, its domestic gross in North America ($458 million) is only second to this years champion Jurassic World ($651 million). This highly profitable gross receipts really cemented Marvel's status as a brand with a singular vision, ushering in a new era of Studios With Their Own Cinematic Universes.2 Because Ultron was 8-9 feet (2.4 - 2.7 meters) tall, the 5-foot 10-inch (1.77 meter) James Spader had to wear an antennae-like contraption made out of a thick piece of wire with two red balls attached to the top that went up his entire back and 3 feet above his head. This was done so that the actors that shared scenes with him would be able to have a reference point for where his eyes would be; the two red balls represented the placement of Ultron's eyes. Elizabeth Olsen (Wanda Maximoff/Scarlet Witch) stated that this was actually distracting because Spader would be giving an intense performance and out of instinct she would look at him rather than the balls representing his eyes. Much to everyone's amusement, whenever this happened, Aaron Taylor-Johnson (Pietro Maximoff/Quicksilver) would yell, "Red balls! Look at his balls, Lizzie!" at her in order to get her to look in the right direction.3 Scarlett Johansson was pregnant during filming of this movie so many of her scenes were scheduled early in filming before she began to show. To help hide her pregnancy later in filming, three stunt doubles were hired. This caused a lot of confusion among the other actors since, according to them, all of the stunt women looked very similar to Johansson. Chris Evans stated that it got to the point where he would say hello and start a conversation with one of them, only to realize mid-way that the person he was talking to wasn't Johansson. Ultimately, some scenes used CGI to hide Johansson's belly.PACKAGING:Avengers: Age of Ultron - 3D arrives on Blu-ray courtesy of Buena Vista Home Entertainment as part of a two-disc Blu-ray 3D + Blu-ray + Digital HD Collector's Edition in an special red case. The Blu-ray 3D houses the feature film only; a 3D Main Menu pops up after the Marvel Studios logo. The Blu-ray contains the feature film as well as all bonus materials. Skippable Trailers on the 2D Blu-ray include ''Ant-Man, Agents of S.H.E.I.L.D., and Agent Carter.FINAL THOUGHTS:Marvel's Avengers: Age of Ultron is a bombastic, globe-trotting action movie stuffed with some big ideas about global security, friendship, and fears. Because there are very little bonus features, I guess eventually there will be an Ultimate Collection Edition in the future. Here, both video and audio are top-rated. Although a single 2D blu ray set is available separately, if you have a 3D set, I would strongly recommend this 3D Collectors Edition. The 3D experience is simply out of this world.

RW Pop=Record World Singles Chart; UK=British Singles Chart):DISC 1:01 TIGER (Chancellor C-1037)(a-side)(BB Pop 3/1959; CB Pop 6/1959; RW Pop 8/1959)(May 1959)02 STEADY DATE (Chancellor C-1024)(uncharted a-side, September 1959)03 HOUND DOG MAN (Chancellor C-1044)(a-side)(BB Pop 9/1959;
