(Chancellor C-1033)(b-side, March 1959)10 TAKE ME*from album The Fabian Faade: Young and Wonderful (Chancellor CHL 69802)(1960)*rare gem; CD debut.11 KANSAS CITY (Chancellor C-1086)(b-side, October 1961)12 GOTTA TELL SOMEBODY*from album The Fabulous Fabian (Chancellor CHLXS 5005)(BB200 3(2)/1959)13 MEMORIES ARE MADE OF THIS*from album Good Old Summertime (Chancellor CHLS 5012)(1960)14 SHES STAYING INSIDE WITH ME (Dot 16413)(b-side, October 1962)*ultra-rare gem; CD debut.15 GONNA GET YOU*from album Hold That Tiger (Chancellor CHLS 5003)(BB200 5/1959)16 IM GONNA SIT RIGHT DOWN AND RIGHT MYSELF A LETTER (Chancellor C-1051)(uncharted a-side, May 1960)17 TONGUE TIED (Chancellor C-1086)(uncharted a-side, October 1961)18 YOU EXCITE ME*from album The Fabulous Fabian (Chancellor CHLXS 5005)(BB200 3(2)/1959)19 BY THE LIGHT OF THE SILVERY MOON*from album Good Old Summertime (Chancellor CHLS 5012)(1960)20 LITTLE MEANIE JEANIE*from album Rockin Hot (Chancellor CHL-5019)(1961)21 IVE GOT NOBODY*from album The Fabian Faade: Young and Wonderful (Chancellor CHL 69802)(1960)*rare gem; CD debut.22 KISSIN AND TWISTIN (Chancellor C-1061)(a-side)(BB Pop 91/1960)(October 1960)23 EVERYTHING IS JUST RIGHT*from album The Fabulous Fabian (Chancellor CHLXS 5005)(BB200 3(2)/1959)24 STRING ALONG (Chancellor C-1047)(b-side, January 1960)(BB Pop 39/1960)*doubled sided hit.25 TIGER RAG*from album Hold That Tiger (Chancellor CHLS 5003)(BB200 5/1959)POSITIVE POINTS:1 This is the latest Greatest Hits collection on Fabian, and I notice great care has been taken to release rare gems, previously not available on CDs, singles like Youre Only Young Once, Made You, Break Down And Cry and Shes Staying Inside With Me. The 6 album tracks listed above, from the still unreleased Fabian Faade: Young and Wonderful, are also making their CD debut.2 The sound is very well remastered.3 This set comes with a sturdy gatefold cardboard cases, with 2 beautiful colour picture of Fabian. There is an informative sleeve note by Brian Parks.NEGATIVE POINTS:1 There is no booklet, as per usual practice at One Day Music. There are no chart position, label & number.2 The songs are not arranged chronologically.3 There are still a few singles missing:(1)  DAVID AND GOLIATH  (Chancellor C-1072)(b-side, March 1961)*available online.(2)  DREAM FACTORY (Chancellor C-1084)(b-side, July 1961)*not available anywhere.(3)  AVE MARIA IN ST. DENISE (Philips 6003 146)(uncharted a-side, 1971)*not available anywhere.(4)  EMILY (Philips 6003 146)(b-side, 1971)*not available anywhere.(5)  EASE ON IN (INTO MY LIFE)(Cream 7717)(uncharted a-side, 1977)*not available anywhere.(6)  THE AMERICAN EAST (Cream 7717)(b-side, 1977)COMPLETE SINGLES DISCOGRAPHY:Although Fabian has only 10 charted singles on Billboard Hot 100, I have done a detailed Complete Singles Discography, and found that he had released 20 singles (40 songs, charted and uncharted, 1958 to 1971). His labels are: (1) Chancellor (1958  1961, 17 singles), (2) Dot (1962, 1 single), (3) Philips (1971, 1 single) and Cream (1977, 1 single). His singles on Philips and Cream label are still not available anywhere.FINAL THOUGHTS:Fabian was born Fabiano Anthony Forte on February 6, 1943 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He was discovered at age 14 (because of his good looks and intriguing name) by a chance meeting with Bob Marucci, owner of Chancellor Records. He began his acting career in 1959 with Hound Dog Man. He belonged to the teenage idol, often compared to Frankie Avalon, Bobby Rydell, Bobby Vee and Ricky Nelson.There is still no Complete Singles Collection on Fabian. But his biggest hits are included here with many rare gems and good sound. If you are looking for his albums, I would recommend Im A Man (Jasmine, 2014, 2 CDs, 54 songs). If you are just looking for his Greatest Hits, this set, plus This IsFabian (Ace, 1991, 26 songs), is definitely highly recommended.

CONTENT:This 2 CD set, The Platinum Collection by Katherine Jenkins, released by Decca from UK in 2015, contain 40 songs while she was with Decca. I have compiled a detailed song listing (including album & singles label & number, chart position, name of source album, plus personal comments)(UK=British Singles Chart):DISC 1:01 TIME TO SAY GOODBYE*from album Second Nature (2004)02 THE FLOWER DUET (featuring Kiri Te Tanawa)*from album Serenade (2006)03 O MIO BABBINO CARO*from album Serenade (2006)04 BIZET: HABANERA*from album Premiere (2004)*her first album.05 PIE JESU*from album Sacred Arias (2008)06 AIR ON A G STRING/SWEETEST LOVE*from album Premiere (2004)07 NESSUN DORMA*from album Living A Dream (2005)08 PANIS ANGELICUS*from album Sacred Arias (2008)09 LASCIA CHIO PIANGA*from album Premiere (2004)10 RUTTER: THE LORD IS MY SHEPHERD*from album Sacred Arias (2008)11 UN BEL DI/ONE FINE DAY*from album Living A Dream (2005)12 FAURE: IN PARADISUM*from album Sacred Arias (2008)13 DVORAK: SONG TO THE MOON*from album Second Nature (2004)14 DEAR LORD AND FATHER OF MANKIND*from album Serenade (2006)15 BACH/GOUNOD: AVE MARIA*from album Serenade (2006)16 O SOLE MIO*from album Second Nature (2004)17 OFFENBACH: BARCAROLLE*from album Second Nature (2004)18 PACHELBELS CANON*from album Serenade (2006)19 MAY THE GOOD LORD BLESS AND KEEP YOU*from album Sacred Arias (2008)20 SATIE: GYMNOPEDIE NO.1/ABSENCE*from album Premiere (2004)21 BARBER: AGNUS DEI*from album Sacred Arias (2008)DISC 2:01 NELLA FANTASIA*from album Serenade (2006)02 LAMORE SEI TU (I WILL ALWAYS LOVE YOU)*from album Living A Dream (2005)03 QUELLO CHE FARO (SARA PER TE)(EVERYTHING I DO) I DO IT FOR YOU*from album Serenade (2006)04 HALLELUJAH*from album Sacred Arias (2008)05 GREEN GREEN GRASS OF HOME (UCJ 1717438)(a-side)(UK 62/2006)(December 2006)*from album Serenade (2006); not found in Ultimate Collection06 LISA LAN*from album Serenade (2007)07 AMAZING GRACE*from album Living A Dream (2005)08 CARUSO*from album Second Nature (2004)09 BE MY LOVE*from album Serenade (2006)10 GRANADA*from album Serenade (2006)11 YOULL NEVER WALK ALONE*from album Second Nature (2004)12 DOWN IN THE RIVER TO PRAY*from album Sacred Arias (2008)13 BE STILL MY SOUL*from album Rejoice (2007)14 VIDE COR MEUM*from album From The Heart (2007)15 KISS FROM A ROSE*from album Rejoice (2007)16 DONT CRY FOR ME ARGENTINA*from album Ultimate Collection (2009)17 THE PRAYER*from album Serenade (2006)18 I VOW TO THEE MY COUNTRY*from album Ultimate Collection (2009)19 WELL MEET AGAIN*from album Living A Dream (2005)POSITIVE POINTS:1 This is a decent collection of Katherine Jenkins popular songs while she was on Decca (2004-2008). There are 40 songs, which is much better than the last Greatest Hits The Ultimate Collection with only 17 songs. There are 4 songs in that collection that are not present here.2 The sound is good, but not exceptional. Nowadays, beside critical listening, I also rip the song onto my wav file in the computer. Being a remasterer, I can tell how much remastering efforts the producer has put into that song. In this case, not much, but the overall result is quite acceptable.3 Time: disc 1: 78 minutes; disc 2: 77 minutes. Good value.NEGATIVE POINTS:1 In the 8-page booklet, there is no essay. But three pretty pictures of Katherine Jenkins though.2 There is no material from Warner, when she released Believe and Daydream. This set is pure Decca.FINAL THOUGHTS:Katherine Jenkins is a Welsh mezzo-soprano, born on June 29 1980. She is a classical-popular crossover singer, successfully crossing over to the pop market. All her albums hit #1 on the UK Classical Chart. In 2009, she changed label to Warner, and was paid a handsome $10 million, the highest classical recording deal in UK history. People in North America got to know her much more when she finished second on the 2012 Dancing with the Stars. One could not help to notice the transformation from a shy young girl into a mature, sexy and beautiful young lady. You will appreciate her talent even more after you have watched her Believe concert on blu-ray  simply fantastic. If you dont know her, this set is a great introduction to the talents and pure voice of Katherine Jenkins, and is highly recommended.

CONTENT:Hank Marvin: The Collection, released by Demon Music from UK in 2015, is a 2 CD set with 36 songs, taken from Hanks five solo albums during the period 1982  95. The songs are cleverly divided into two categories: (1) instrumental only, and (2) vocal. I have compiled a detailed song listing (including album source and singles label & number, chart position, debut date, plus personal comments)(UK=British Singles Chart):DISC 1 (INSTRUMENTAL):01 PIPELINE (featuring Duane Eddy)*from album Into The Light (Polydor 517148)(1992)02 OXYGENE (PART IV)*from album Heartbeat (Polydor 5212522)(1993)03 WONDERLAND LAND (featuring Mark Knopfler)(Polygram TV PO 297)(uncharted a-side, 1993)*from album Heartbeat (Polydor 5212522)(1993)04 WE ARE THE CHAMPIONS (featuring Brian May)(Polydor PO 229)(a-side)(UK 66/1992)(October 1992)*from album Into The Light (Polydor 517148)(1992)05 JESSICA*from album Into The Light (Polydor 517148)(1992)06 STEEL WHEEL*from album Into The Light (Polydor 517148)(1992)07 ALL ALONE WITH FRIENDS (Polydor POSP 618)(b-side, June 1983)*from album All Alone With Friends (Polydor 514)(1983)08 RIKKI DONT LOSE THAT NUMBER*from album Into The Light (Polydor 517148)(1992)09 INTO THE LIGHT*from album Into The Light (Polydor 517148)(1992)10 WICHITA LINEMAN*from album Heartbeat (Polydor 5212522)(1993)11 LIVE AND LET DIE*from album Heartbeat (Polydor 5212522)(1993)12 LIVING DOLL*from album Hank Plays Cliff (Polydor 5294262)(1995)13 WIRED FOR SOUND*from album Hank Plays Cliff (Polydor 5294262)(1995)14 THE YOUNG ONES*from album Hank Plays Cliff (Polydor 5294262)(1995)15 THE DAY I MET MARIE*from album Hank Plays Cliff (Polydor 5294262)(1995)16 DEVIL WOMAN*from album Hank Plays Cliff (Polydor 5294262)(1995)17 WE DONT TALK ANYMORE*from album Hank Plays Cliff (Polydor 5294262)(1995)18 SUMMER HOLIDAY*from album Hank Plays Cliff (Polydor 5294262)(1995)DISC 2 (VOCAL):01 DONT TALK (Polydor POSP 420)(a-side)(UK 49/1952)(February 1982)*from album Words & Music (Polydor POLD 5054)(1982)02 THE TROUBLE WITH ME IS YOU (Polydor POSP 479)(uncharted a-side, February 1983)*from album Words & Music (Polydor POLD 5054)(1982)03 THE HAWK AND THE DOVE (Polydor POSP 581)(uncharted a-side, April 1983)*from album All Alone With Friends (Polydor 514)(1983)04 BAD COP*from album Words & Music (Polydor POLD 5054)(1982)05 NIGHT NURSE*from album Words & Music (Polydor POLD 5054)(1982)06 THEN I FOUND LOVE*from album Words & Music (Polydor POLD 5054)(1982)07 LIFE LINE*from album Words & Music (Polydor POLD 5054)(1982)08 JUST ANOTHER HEARTBREAK*from album All Alone With Friends (Polydor 514)(1983)09 TAHLIA TAKE YOUR TIME*from album Words & Music (Polydor POLD 5054)(1982)10 INVISIBLE MAN (Polydor POSP 618)(uncharted a-side, June 1983)*from album All Alone With Friends (Polydor 514)(1983)11 DONT ANSWER*from album All Alone With Friends (Polydor 514)(1983)12 STARDOM*from album All Alone With Friends (Polydor 514)(1983)13 99 DAYS*from album All Alone With Friends (Polydor 514)(1983)14 HEARTBEAT (vocal: Cliff Richard)*from album Heartbeat (Polydor 5212522)(1993)15 MRS. ROBINSON (vocal: Cliff Richard)*from album Heartbeat (Polydor 5212522)(1993)16 I WILL ALWAYS LOVE YOU (vocal: Cliff Richard)*from album Heartbeat (Polydor 5212522)(1993)17 CARRIE (vocal: Cliff Richard)*from album Hank Plays Cliff (Polydor 5294262)(1995)18 MOVE IT (vocal: Cliff Richard)*from album Hank Plays Cliff (Polydor 5294262)(1995)POSITIVE POINTS:1 This is a nice little collection of Hank Marvins solo hits, cleverly grouped into 2 sections: instrumental and vocal. Hank Marvin first demonstrated his vocal talents in Throw Down A Line, a duet with Cliff Richard. His solo vocals Dont Talk and The Trouble With Me Is You both charted. As noted above, all the songs are extracted from five albums from 1982-1995: Words and Music (1982), All Alone With Friends (1983), Into The Light (1992), Heartbeat (1993) and Hank Plays Cliff (1995). There are no new songs here.2 The sound is very well remastered. Nowadays, beside critical listening, I also ripped the songs into wav files on the computer. From those files, I can also tell how much efforts have been put into remastering those songs. In this case, it is not perfect, but very good. Some songs, like We Are The Champions did not get the remastering efforts that it deserved.3 There is an 8-page booklet with an informative essay. The names of vocalists are included.NEGATIVE POINTS:1 As a Hank Marvin Collection, I am disappointed that two of his charted singles are omitted:(1)  LIVING DOLL (with The Young Ones and Hank Marvin)(WEA YZ 65P)(a-side)(UK 1(3)/1986)(March 1986)(2)  LONDON KID (Jean-Michel Jarre, featuring Hank Marvin)(Polydor 32)(a-side)(UK 52/1989)(January 1989)2 Disc 1: 74 minutes; disc 2: 65 minutes. Surely Demon Music could have filled up the remaining empty space (21 minutes) with more songs. I know this is not a Singles Collection, but a lot of the b-sides could have been included.3 Hank Marvin has 14 solo albums with the latest Hank in 2014. Therefore there are lots of materials to choose from.4 His solo materials from Columbia were not included.5 No label & number, chart position, names of source albums were identified.6 The songs were randomly sequenced, not grouped under individual albums.FINAL THOUGHTS:Hank Marvin (also known as Hank B. Marvin) was born Brian Robson Rankin on October 28, 1941 in Newcastle upon Tyne, England. He chose the name Hank Marvin while launching his career. The name is an amalgamation of his childhood nickname, Hank, which he used to differentiate himself from friends also named Brian, and Marvin Rainwater, a country and western singer. He is currently living in Perth, Australia, with his wife Carole, and had 2 children: Tahlia: remember the song Tahlia Take Your Time and Ben, whom Hank taught guitar and he played with dad during the concert in 1994. If you like Hank and the Shadows, I would highly recommend The Shadows: The Final Tour (2004) on blu-ray. This current set is a great collection of Hanks solo efforts with good sound, and is highly recommended.

These are very comfortable jeans and pretty well made, however they have changed these jeans since the last time I bought them: the denim is lighter weight and (on my last order at least) there was virtually no distressing.  Previously I've had 361's come with anything from very little (dime sized) to a lot of distressing (up to torn knees).  Compared to past purchases of 361 Lucky Jeans I found the quality to be more consistent, which is good, but I wish they hadn't switched to the thinner, cheaper quality denim.The fit is good and the stitching is well done.  These are a step above what you would buy at someplace like Old Navy, but just barely.  I would not pay more than $50 for them.

Under no circumstances could I see myself giving this to one of my kids.  Why?  Well let's start with ingredient #2: Hydrogenated vegetable oil (corn, canola, palm olein).  Wait, that's trans fat right?  How can they get away with listing "zero" trans fats?  Easy, they make the serving size really small (40g of powder) so they can get the trans fats down to under 0.5 grams and they can legally claim "zero".  Which is to say they're lying and you won't know unless you read the small print and know about the legal loopholes.  But there are 20 servings in this can, so that's potentially around 10 grams of trans fats.  Safe amount for children?  Zero.  Actual zero, not the "pretend" zero on this label.But let's go on.  The third and fourth ingredients are corn syrup and sugar.  So sugar, and sugar.  How much?  18 grams of sugar per serving!  18?  That's desert! (Compare to a serving of Hagen Daz vanilla ice cream which has 19 grams of sugar).  The "prebiotics" is just your basic fiber (chicory root and oligofructose) and you only get 1 gram of that.  That's not really going to do you much good.  A decent fiber gummy will give you 3x as much per serving.  An apple will give you 4-5x.  And they toss in some vitamins so you think it's healthy.So don't be fooled by this garbage: your best bet is regular milk, but if you need powdered milk, buy real powdered milk (which generally has one ingredient: milk).  I can't conclude this product is anything but a scam.  I realize Nestle primarily sells this in third world countries where people may not have the means to know any better, but it's hard to imagine they thought they could get away with this here.  Of course it's targeted at poor immigrants from those third world countries, so perhaps Nestle is betting that their cheap, unhealthy, sugary drink (with vitamins!) can continue to sucker them in here.

I bought this for my 7 year old niece, who really enjoys it, but the humor is just a tad above her level (but it's good stuff for encouraging discussion).  However it has quickly become a favorite of her brother (age 10) and my 9 and 8 year old sons (so much so that they'll stay up late reading it together with a flashlight - laughing the whole time).  They've moved on to the second book and can't wait for the third one to come out.  I've read a bit of it as well and it's absolutely brilliant.Like all really good "kid books" some of the writing is above the targeted level.  In my experience kids thrive on that and it encourages them to stretch.  It certainly helps that it's really, really funny.  I would absolutely encourage you to buy this for any girl or boy in your life who is reading at or above the 4th grade level.  Even teens would enjoy this - it's just that good.

We have four kids and have been through our share of diapers.  My wife and I are both engineers and cant help but deconstruct and analyze things just for fun.  This includes diapersAfter trying lots of brands weve generally defaulted to Huggies and Pampers, which do seem to perform slightly better than the competition.  Though if you are on a budget even cheap store-brand diapers work pretty well (except Babies-R-Us and Walmart which are both terrible).  Over time we have seen diapers improve quite a bit, and frankly its gotten to the point where its hard to recommend one brand over the other.  In our experience the best diaper varies from kid-to-kid.  We generally found Pampers fit our older kids better and Huggies fit our younger kids better.Feature wise both Huggies and Pampers are pretty equal: umbilical cord cutouts in the newborn diapers, wetness indicators, and better leak protection around the edges.  Weve noticed that Pampers tend to be much thinner (Proctor and Gambles SAPs [super absorbent polymers] are industry leading and it seems that they are doing more with less) but we found Huggies seemed to minimize diaper rash in babies with sensitive skin (a lot of the extra bulk in a diaper is cellulose and Huggies seem to have more of it  perhaps that extra bulk is keeping SAPs from drying out skin?).Weve used these diapers on our kids with no complaints or problems.  They fit well, rarely leak, and are easy to get on, and off.  They are not as absorbent as Pampers, but in our experience its not just how much can it absorb, but can it keep it away from skin?  For newborns we had better luck avoiding rashes with Huggies (along with regular diaper changes).  As kids got older and more mobile Pampers seem to work better.  Though as weve said, every kid is different, and you should be prepared to change brands as kids grow and their bodies change.One tip though: this is a GIANT box of diapers.  Start with a few small packs from various brands and try them out first.  Then shop for the mega-sized box.

There are so many tablet choices out there it can be hard to sort through them all.  At the high-end there are the iPads and Surface and at the low end a lot of Android tablets youve never heard of.  In this price point I would consider two options: name brand Android vs. Kindle Fire.  For kids I buy Kindle Fires, which have excellent parental controls.  For adults I suggest name-brand Android tablets which provide better performance and more flexibility than a Kindle Fire.Asus isnt the only choice but its a good one.  They have a long term reputation for quality but tend to be a better value than the bigger name brands like Samsung.  I consider their quality on par with Samsung, well above Amazon, and step below Apple.  The quad-core Intel CPU far out performs anything you will find in a Kindle Fire and compares well against higher end Samsung ARM based tablets.  It does this at very low (~1.3GHz) clock speeds keeping leakage power loss to a minimum.  This uses a Moorfield platform SOC which includes the excellent Silvermont cores.  Its a quad-core single threaded design. For graphics it has a PowerVR G6430 clocked around 450Mhz (same basic graphics found on the Apple A7 but a higher clock).  I would rate this as a mid-tier graphics core that will handle anything Android will throw at it, but it would be underpowered if this was a Windows tablet.  It fits with the price point but you will find better cores in higher-end Apple and Samsung products.I personally found the IPS screen to be excellent.  Its not quite on par with the Apple Retina display but it puts my Kindle Fire HDX to shame.  I gave it to my kids and let them run a couple of their games and they had no issues with performance.  I think for the price you are getting a pretty good tablet from a well know manufacturer.  Minus catching a higher end Samsung on sale, I dont think youll find a much better deal out there.  If you are shopping around for an Android tablet I would not hesitate to buy this one.

Starting with a Le Creuset enameled cast-iron Dutch oven several years ago I've slowly migrate most of my cooking over from stainless steel.  Along the way we've picked up Staub (on par with Le Creuset), Martha Stewart (junk), Kirkland (awesome value), and now this Gorham Dutch oven.I can't comment on durability yet but it seems solid enough.  I can say that it seems to cook fairly evenly.  The lid fits well and has mimicked the "dots" found on Staub cookware that allow condensation to wick together and drop more evenly onto your food.  I'm not sure this really helps anything, but I don't suppose it hurts.  This is faller and narrower than I might prefer, since I tend to cook dishes that involve browning beef or chicken (so a wider base works best for me), but it's the perfect shape for stews.Cleanup so far has been easy.  My Kirkland still wins for easiest cleanup, but this has been nearly as easy.  I generally throw everything in the dishwasher, but for enameled cast iron a short soak and scrub with a scotch pad is often in order.  I intentionally overcooked a little frond in the pan and discovered that (just like my other cookware) a quick scrub with a SOS pad cleans it up nicely.Overall a decent Dutch oven at a very good price.  If you are on a budget and have the option I would try out Kirkland first, but this seems to be a good option.  If money isn't an object then go ahead and splurge on the Staub or Le Creuset, but understand that while you are getting a better product it's not the best value for your money.

Arendelle's Winter Festival is a fun interactive math game aimed at kids pre-k to 2nd grade.  It covers that range pretty well with five games where you can earn crystals which you can use to buy prizes.  The mathematics is pretty lightweight, but if you are going to have the kids play a video game, it had might as well be one that offered a little learning to go with it.  The quality of these LeapTV games are improving and this is probably the best of the bunch.  The important thing for me is (like Kinnect) that it has games that will the kids up and moving, which is great for cold, wet, winter days.I have two three year olds and a seven year old in the house along with some older kids.  The younger kids were able to play all the games with vary degrees of success.  They need a little adult (or older kid) direction to get going but they picked it up pretty well.  They definitely dont get much of the math involved, but its not a barrier.  The seven year old is beyond most of the math, but Im all for anything that associates math with fun so for her its still a win in my book.  Its attracted some interest from the older kids who will play occasionally.  Overall for the price I think you get a good video game system that offers some physical and learning benefits.  I still treat it as screen time entertainment, but its definitely preferred to just having them sit and watch TV during their allotted screen time.

One of our sons is a deep sleeper/sleep walker who still occasionally has accidents.  We had been using a regular Goodnights but some degree of leaking was common (roughly 25% of the time it leaks).  As a result we put absorbent sheets under him at night.  We decided to give these a try to see if they work any better.  What you get is an underwear shell that accepts an absorbent insert.  The shell is washable and the insert it thrown away.In our experience these leak as much or worse than regular Goodnights.  I think thats because they are prone to improper placement of the insert, or the insert is dislodged during normal sleep movement.  Either way it leaks.  Like regular Goodnights even when it leaks it catches most of the accident, which certainly helps.Most importantly my son likes that they look like regular underwear.  He the only kid in our family prone to bedwetting and he naturally feels a bit awkward about it.  So while its not a perfect product I think its a good option to have, especially if there are other kids in the house.  If youre talking about an only child and looking for the most effective solution Id stick with regular Goodnights (Underjams work well too).

If youre talking about an only child and looking for the most effective solution Id stick with regular Goodnights (Underjams work well too).

This is a very powerful little hand-vac and it's great for cleaning up small areas that are hard to get to with a regular vacuum.  I really like that it has  a motorized brush for pet hair clean up.  The cord is a blessing and a curse.  Ideally we'd all like to have a cordless vac but that means compromising on power and battery life.  Having a cord means more power for less price, and it's a reasonably long cord (for a hand vac) which is great for things like stairs.  On the downside you've got a 15' cord to drag around.It's bagless, relatively light weight, and has a decent set of tools.  This is perfect for things like chairs, sofas, stairs, high-chairs, curtains, and cars.  If you are willing to spend about $500 you can get a cordless Dyson almost as powerful that will run for 15 minutes.  Depending on what you need it for and your budget, that might make sense.  I think for most people this makes more practical sense.  Yes you have to deal with a cord, but you save a ton of money and there are no batteries to replace.

This is a great looking cable and the quality seems really first rate.  It ought to for the price!  Why would you spend so much on a cable?  Frankly for most people, this probably doesn't make sense.  I gave it a Five star rating for the quality, but for value it's a Three Star.  For much less you can get a decent cable, and for most people that's the best use of your money (if your cable stays pretty much in one place for example).  However if you travel a lot, or otherwise abuse your cable,  this might make sense.  This is going to stand up where other cables fail.  Or if $30 (the current price) just isn't a lot of money to you, you'd might as well by the best quality cable.  For most people a much cheaper cable makes more sense.

I was a little nervous trying this out because I see a lot of negative reviews.  That tells me the quality is probably spotty.  However in my (short) experience with this cable I don't have any complaints.  The cable seems durable.  I've only had it a few days but I haven't treated it gently and it's going strong.  It's charging my iPhone 6 and my wife's 6 plus like a champ.  The length is good for a larger car or mini-van.  For a smaller car it might be a bit long.  I've also swapped the Lightening cable with my Kindle (micro usb) cable and it charged my Kindle without any trouble.  For the price it seem like a reasonable deal.  Because Belkin is a well known brand, watch out for counterfeits - that may account for the people getting faulty products.  I stick to big reputable vendors when buying Belkin which seems to help.

I see a lot of complaints here about crappy cables.  Let me tell you, be careful ordering a cable, even a name-brand, from some no-name seller.  There are just too many counterfeits out there.  If you want to save some money look for Amazon branded cables.  This Belkin cable (assuming you order from a reputable vendor and got the real deal) is a solid, well made cable.  I'm an engineer and I've made my fair share of cables (granted far easier stuff like RS-422) and the quality of this cable is really good.  I've tried it out on a couple of iPhones without any problem.  Overall a great cable.  It's a bit pricey and if you shop around carefully you can find something cheaper and still well made.  However if you want to make sure you get a good cable it's worth the price.  Just make sure you order it from Amazon or another reputable vendor.  Otherwise you'd might as well order a cheap $5 no-name brand.

I have four kids aged 3-9 and probably the one game that all ages can play together is store/restaurant.  We have a small Step2 Kids Kitchen and we put this register on a stand next to that.  They were already working up fake menus and pretend money, and now they have this to put it all in.  It was an instant hit.The register itself has an okay build quality.  I think the quality is fair for the price.  So far its handled a fair share of abuse with no problems.  My kids have had a great time integrating it into their pretend play.  Aside from being just fun I think theres a lot of learning value to having it.  This sort of thing really helps kids grasp how stores and money works.  Its the sort of thing thats tricky to explain but really sinks in when the role play it.  The scanner is a bit hokey, but we put some of the scan sticker on some old cereal and pasta boxes and the kids have just run with it.  The important thing is that they get a satisfying beep when they scan stuff.  That sort of thing is important to kids.  I dont know if the scan comes up correctly and it doesnt really matter, their imaginations fill in the rest.So Im not sure its the sturdiest toy in the world, but I think there is real value in having it, especially if you have a small group of siblings/cousins/friends who can play together.  A much better investment than say a video game.

I'm a big fan of the Kind Fruit and Nut bars, and I think their granola bars are okay.  This bar however was very disappointing.  It wasn't terrible, but it was very plain.  Even when you get a bit with some chocolate, it's just not enough flavor to make much of an impression.  So unless you are looking for something very bland I would pass this up and go for something else.

This is the second Luly Jr. product I've tried.  I don't have my result back yet on this one, but I have gotten it back on our hardcover.  It's pretty straight forward.  You get a little kit with book pages and pens.  Each page has a box for art and lines for the words.  The art get's copied as is.  The words get typeset.  You get to submit up to 14 pages for the book, but they give you a few extra in case of mistakes.My kids absolutely love these things.  For the price is one of the best gifts you can give a kid.  Seriously.  They make their own book.  My boys each took half the pages and make their own "mini-story" for their little sisters.  It went so well I've ordered more for nieces and nephews.  What a great way to give kids a tangible expression of their creativity.I can't comment directly on the quality of the paper back since we haven't got it back yet, but the hardcopy we previously did had pretty nice binding.

Our house has it's fair share of Kindles and iPhones and we have a collection of cables for the lot of them.  I wish they could establish a single cable standard, but since that seems to be beyond them, I'll settle for more cables like this that support both.  I've used this cable for both my iPhones and Kindles and for this somewhat random HP tablet we got from somewhere.  It did the job for all of them without any trouble.  We've now moved this out to the car where we mostly need it as a phone charger but occasionally we have a kindle in need of charging.  The cable is a tad over 6 inches, so don't order this is your charger isn't close to what you need to charge.  Personally I hate having long calbes when I don't need them, so I like having short cables to reduce the clutter.

This is a decent water bottle but it's a tad overpriced.  It's a squeeze bottle, which means it has a spout but no internal straw.  Toddlers would have trouble with it but most kids first grade and up should be able to use it thought I'd say it's best for 3rd and up.  So while there nothing wrong with it, it just doesn't feel like it should cost the $8 it does as I write this.  If the price drops down to $3-5 I'd say it was a better value.

This is a nice set of medium-sized bags.  The fabric is heavy-weight canvas and the stitching is solid.  The patterns and colors in this set (Danmask) aren't that interesting, but who really cares?  They're just shopping bags.  For the price you are getting bags that are a lot more rugged than the cheap thin bags you local supermarket is probably selling.  Overall a very nice set of multi-use bags.

A friend first turned me on to Rocket 3 vocalist Ramune Nagisetty's debut album "Truth and Beauty" after he heard one of cuts on the radio and thought it was something I'd like.  It had an honest, raw vibe that I really enjoyed, and it stayed on my regular playlist for a while.  When I didn't see any follow on I kind of gave up and her CD eventually slid off my radar for a while until word she was fronting a new band came my way.This CD does not disappoint.  As much as I liked her solo work, I think this has a stronger energy.  It has that honest "just out of the garage" sound that harkens back to a great tradition in Northwest rock (and I'm not just talking Grunge - think Kingsmen).  While a little more polished than her solo album, it's still "honest rock-and-roll" that spares you any tricks and just delivers the goods.Try out "Never Again" and "Catch Me" - I think those are good examples of their range and pretty accessible to first time listeners.  And if you like this CD try out Truth and Beauty.

I got this Linksys WRT AC1200 Dual-Band and Wi-Fi Wireless Router to replace an older Linksys AC1900 router that I wasnt happy with.  Im not looking for the highest performing router, just something reliable that doesnt choke when Im streaming a movie while somebody is online.  The setup seemed pretty similar to what I recall doing for my AC1900.  Thats mostly a good thing as I had no real complaints about the setup.  Honestly most of the routers Ive tried lately (Asus and Netgear) seem to have pretty decent setup wizards.Whats different is my initial experience with this router has been really good.  No drops, no reboots, no hassles (after 2-3 weeks of use).  Compare that to my AC1900 that had to be rebooted daily for the first few months and problems came and went with different BIOS revs.  I dont use the phone apps so I cant comment on that, but I have used the Web based remoter interface and the direct router interface and both are fine.  If you are even remotely comfortable with tweaking settings youll have no trouble at all.  If you hate that sort of thing you might need to borrow your local tech geek (everybody knows one), but its really fairly intuitive.If you review the specs youll see there are better routers out there in terms of speed and multi-frequency support.  If youve got a house full of 4+ heavy tech users you may want to consider some of the expensive multi-band routers from Linksys, Asus, and Netgear.  However I think 90% of the people out there will be happy with this router, and in my experience staying away from leading edge tech is a good way to avoid technical headaches.  I wouldnt go much below this router, just because the feature set really drops off.  However cost is a really big factor Ive had good experiences setting up some of the lower-end Asus routers for people.  Otherwise I think this is a great choice for the average user.

For the past 10 years my go-to vacuum has been a Dyson DC28 Animal.  Its been the best vacuum Ive ever owned.  Technically its not as powerful as a previous Hoover Wind Tunnel, but unlike all the Hoover and Bissels Ive owed, its lasted longer than the warranty.  This Samsung costs less than pretty much any Dyson you can buy, so the question is how does it compare?I did some objective testing on hardwood and carpet by spreading out some rice and some sandbox sand.  I weighed out two equal amounts of both, spread them around, vacuumed, and then emptied and weighed the results.  The difference between them was minor and in repeat tests the winner varied.  That told me that how I vacuumed was probably a bigger variable than raw suction.For usability I found that the old Dyson was heavier and harder to maneuver.  This was an advantage in one case: when you are using the tools on the Samsung and stretch out the hose its easy to knock it over.  The Dyson can be pulled over but its much harder.  The lift-off feature was nice, though with the Dysons long hose I can achieve the same effect.The Dyson feels and looks sturdier.  The Samsung is lighter, but the plastic seems more fragile.  I also found the Dyson much easier to empty, though both are a pain to clean out if it gets too full of dirt and dust.  I also managed to jam up the Samsung roller with hair once.  It was easy to clear, but its something I have to do to the Dyson once a year.  Having it happen after a week of use with the Samsung was not inspiring.In the end the Samsung is a much better value.  For easily  the price you get pretty much all the performance (granted the test was against a 10 year old Dyson and from what Ive read the newer Dysons are more powerful than mine).  Time will tell, but I dont expect to get the same reliability.  Ultimately I think thats what you are buying with Dyson.  If money is tight this Samsung is the smart buy.  If your budget can handle it Id certainly consider the Dyson and whether the brand reliability is worth the increased price.

I have two king sized memory foam mattresses in my house.  One is a $2,000 iComfort Genius by Serta.  The other is from $1000 Parklane mattress (a great local mattress company).  I like both, though the Serta is perhaps slightly nicer than the Parklane.  Its not been $1000 better.  Ive checked out some of the cheap memory foam mattresses sold at places like Costco and just found them to be way too firm.  I like a firm mattress, but Im not interested in sleeping on a rock.So my hopes were not too high for this mattress.  I seemed unlikely that a mattress that sold for half the price of my cheapest memory foam mattress was going to compare.  Surprisingly it does quite well.  This mattress is firm, but with just enough give to be comfortable.  Definitely not rock-hard like some cheap memory foams Ive encountered.  The fabric covering it looks nice.  The stitching  seems to be well done.  I really cant find anything wrong with it.  And the price really cant be beat.  Time will tell if there are any other issues, but my first impression is really positive.If you were looking to get a good deal on a mattress and gently firm appeals to you, I think this mattress is a great value.

It took me a while to decide to try out Kind bars.  Ive seen them in the store, and they look really good, but Ive always been a bit turned off by the high fat and sugar content.  Now I recognize that most of the fat is coming from nuts, and thats mostly good fat, but Kind does add oils like sunflower and palm kernel oil to their products.  Depending on the product the sugar comes from dried fruit, honey and good old plain sugar.  About 14G of fat and 9G of sugar seems to be pretty typical from my quick survey.I finally decided to try them out, and I cant say Im sorry.  They taste great, and theyve rapidly become my go-to snack food.  I dont kid myself: its a health-ish dessert but eating this is way better than hitting a bag of chips or having a donut.Staring with a variety pack is the way to go.  There are a lot of bars, and Ive loved some and thought others were just okay.  Ive yet to find one I didnt like.  In this pack my favorite flavor is the Chocolate Cherry Cashew.  My one complaint is that it is a Kind Plus Antioxidants which means theyve added Vitamin A, C and E.  If you are eating a healthy diet or taking a multivitamin, you dont need any of those things, so Id rather not have them added to a bar.  For example people who get too much vitamin E have an increased chance of getting cancer (for reasons not well understood and possibly not directly related to the vitamin E).  Id rather just let the ingredients stand for themselves.  Fortunately this is true of most Kind bars.The bottom line is that they have some great tasting bars, and once you dial in which ones you like, youll have a pretty decent snack option.  Their expensive, but if you use the Amazon subscribe and save service you can get the price down to a reasonable range.  Definitely buying these one at a time in a store display is not a good value, but if you can get them for $1 or so per bar, I think its a reasonable price for what you are getting.

I've used the Simple Human and Oxo shower caddies.  Those are both decent, but neither is perfect.  Our SimpleHuman is starting to rust (we've had it about two years), and we weren't able to get the Oxo to be as stable as the SimpleHuman.  The Oxo hasn't rusted (yet) after a year of use.My initial impressions of this Zenna shower caddy are positive.  Using aluminum is a great idea - it won't rust and if it does build up a little oxide corrosion you aren't likely to notice.  Aluminum is light weight, and a little flimsy.  To some people this may seem "cheap" but the aluminum cost more than the cheap metal and plastic used by other brands.  You aren't going to want to try and bend this, because it will bend.  But since non of these shower caddies are meant to be hand holds, that shouldn't be an issue.Assembly isn't hard but it did take a little longer than I recall the other caddies.  Maybe fifteen minutes if the others took ten.  Depending on the height of your bathroom you may have extension pieces left over.I found all of the caddies to be pretty handy.  Each has some clever points.  The SimpleHuman has a nice hanging spot for washcloths and scub mits.  The Oxo has nice size plastic shelves.  This Zenna has lots of hooks for hanging things off of.  Like all of the caddies the shelves are that deep, so very large items could tip out.Overall these are all great ways to create more space in a small shower.  I would probably avoid the SimpleHuman just because I now know it will rust.  I was able to get the Zenna in tighter than the Oxo, but I think the Oxo otherwise a better design.  In the end I would focus on which one has the better price, but take a look at both and pick the one that seems to have the features you want.  They are both good designs.

Our primary use for these is for the iPhone.  My wife and I end up in a lot of phone meetings in the morning in order to sync with international co-workers.  Doing that and getting the family out the door can be a real challenge.  We also end up in a lot of Lync meetings at work that require some kind of headset.The sound on these is excellent for meetings.  We've tried it a couple of times and peoples voices are nice and clear.  More importantly our voice sounds very clear, and background noises seem to be filtered out.  One thing that happens is that as we carpool to work, one of us drives while the other calls into a meeting.  We found that these did an amazing job of filtering out road noise.  We even turned the radio on low and there was only the occasional leakage into the phone conversation.  We were genuinely impressed.It comes with a variety of ear buds and we did find that they were almost too good.  They completely block out outside noise.  That can be good or bad depending on where you are using them.  We also found that they were good, but not "great" for music.  Of course we compared them to a set of high-end studio headphones, so the comparison wasn't exactly fair.  I would certainly have no qualms about using them for music, just don't expect perfect quality, especially on the low end.Overall they are a nice set of earphones for the price - definitely great for business users.

This is a very handy tacker, and much easier than using a conventional stapler.  My first impression was that it seemed solidly built.  I took out to our community garden where we had quite a bit of trellis netting to put up for peas and beans.  This went through things much faster than a stapler though with netting at least you need to take a little more care.  Next it went to the kids school to help out on some sets for a play.  Once again we whipped through attaching fabric to a frame.  It's so much faster than a stapler you wonder why you've been doing it wrong your whole life.  Using it it's clearly more of a pro-tool than a home tool, but if you have projects at home, school, or in the community that usually involve a lot of stapling, this is a much better way to get the job done.  The one exception would be projects that require a lot of accuracy: it's swung like a hammer and just like a hammer  unless you use it a lot, your aim isn't probably all that great.  For example while I didn't try it on any upholstery work, I don't think it would be my first choice.

After years of sticking with SanDisk and Lexas Ive started branching out a bit.  This is my second Centon card.  They arent as well known but theyve been around for years making a lot of industrial memory products and I noticed they were showing up on the GoPro site as one its few certified products.  On paper their specs often exceed SanDisk and Lexar at the same price point, but in some (subjective) usage tests I havent noticed any difference.  When I can find professional reviews, usually the SanDisk wins, but if I cant detect a difference in real-world usage, why should I care?My bigger concern is reliability, and thats what kept me with SanDisk and Lexar.  Ive only had this a few days, so all I can say it that it passed the Not DOA test.  However I have another Centon card thats seen heavy usage for a few months with no problems at all.  This card comes as a MicroSD card but it includes an adapter to use it the larger SDHC readers.  I dont need that adapter, but I did try it out with a few quick reads and writes and it worked just fine.  Ive also started using Samsung cards, but I did encounter a DOA card.  It was probably bad luck (ever vendors has them) but having been bitten Ive been reluctant to go back.  Ultimately the price is what is driving my purchasing now, so once you work out what level of speed you need, I wouldnt hesitate to purchase whatever brand happens to be on sale the day that you are ready to buy.

This is the second one of these products I've tried.  I have a side yard where people let their dogs use the bathroom.  You basically do all the normal over-seeding prep (dethatch a little, loosen the soil) and apply this.  It comes with some mulch to help keep the grass in place.  Scott's doesn't disclose the details, but it has additives to help mitigate the salt, nitrogen, and acidity issues associated with dog urine.  The only ingredient I could pick out for this was the gypsum, which should help balance the ph.  Mine spouted happily in the wet, cool, spring weather typical of the Pacific NW.  If there was a down side it's that you don't get much product.  Much of the container is filled with mulch.  So while this is good for a few small spots, if you have a big issue you are either going to need a larger bag (they sell them) or you are going to want to just buy you own seed and mulch separately.

I was a little reluctant to buy this after reading the inconsistent reviews, but it was cheap enough that I was willing to give it a shot.  It turns out it worked perfectly for my Motorola MBP36.  It came with a built-in connect for the monitor and an adapter for the camera.  I plugged it into the monitor and it fit without any problems.  Based on the complaints regarding it's "fickle" connection I tried moving it around and it didn't have any problem with that.  It does have a small blue LED, but it doesn't really bother me.  It's nothing a piece of black electrical tape couldn't take care of.  Based on the reviews I'm guessing there must be a production quality issue, or some people are getting a different brand or model.  All I can say is that mine seems to work just fine.

Im an engineer working in high tech.  Because I know too much about whats going on inside these laptops, I tend to get more power than I really need.  Thats started to change and I find myself gravitating to whats replacing the old style of Netbooks.  Netbooks as you recall were the hot thing a while back.  The problem is they were cheap, but not usually in a good way.  They made laptops cheap by putting cheap stuff in them.  Inevitably they broke, and all of a sudden they $200 you saved by going with a Netbook didnt look like quite as good of a deal.  However now that the market has matured, you are seeing newer technologies come online enabling inexpensive Netbooks that actually last.  CPUs, frames, LCD screens and keyboards are being designed bottom up to go in these Netbooks.  These things are finally worth buying.This Asus is a great Netbook class 2-in-1 laptop (the 2-in-1 of course refers to the fact that you can undock the keyboard and voila, youve got a tablet).  Its well made, has great battery life, and is powerful enough for the sorts of things you want to do on a Netbook: surf the web, email, watching funny cat videos, and letting your kids play Minecraft type games.  Its *NOT* powerful enough for most 3D games, and not meant to handle compute intensive applications.  Its based on the Intel Bay Trail SOC.  This is a single chip that contains the CPUs, graphics, power management and I/O circuitry.  Depending on the exact speed, power consumption and number of cores this may be sold as an Atom, Celeron or Pentium SOC.  In general the Atom parts are little slower but less power hungry.  Which is perfect for a tablet.The Atom Z3775 in this laptop has four CPU cores (Silvermont if you care) running between 1.46-2.39MHz and using 2 watts.  Yes, 2.  Thats pretty powerful for a tablet, but on the low-end of a laptop in terms of performance.  On the other hand its off the charts in terms of battery life.  Asus claims around 10 hours.  Ive beaten that by setting more aggressive power saving targets.  On average though I get an alert after about 8-9 hours of use.Its has the same basic graphic engine as any 3rd Generation Core i3/i5/i7, just with fewer graphics cores: 4 vs. 6-16 in the Core CPUS.  It also has less aggressive graphics and frequency targets.  What does this mean to you?  Well you can play something like World Of Warcraft or Minecraft but you wont want to try running any newer high end games like Dragon Age or Far Cry.  Its just not that laptop.  Instead look at the games you find on the Microsoft App Center.Functionally its mostly great.  The keyboard is really responsive.  Its small, but unless youve got really big hands its really quite useable.  The touchpad is easy to use.  Its a giant improvement for Asus, which had previously deployed some really sub-standard track pads.  Note that the USB and HDMI ports (1 each) are micro-USB and micro-HDMI.  Buy any cables on Amazon.  Most big-box stores charge a big mark up on those cables.  The screen quality is really good and the capacitive touch screen is really responsive.  Windows 8 is, well imperfect, but its much better as a tablet operating system than it is as a desktop operating system.  The 32GB SSD is too small for storing videos, but there are plenty of cloud storage options from Asus to Amazon (or even better, get  a backup hard drive).Overall this is a great little laptop for traveling, school, or kids.  I almost didnt go back to Asus after buying a TERRIBLE Ultrabook they sold a few years back (very disappointing to a long-time fan of their motherboards).  But this 2 in 1 laptop has won me back over.  Asus is offering you something vastly more useful than an iPad for much less money (for something of comparable size, features, and battery life.  If you on the market for something small and already have a main desktop or laptop for more demanding activities, this is a great choice.

We've gone through a lot of gates over the years.  We've noticed that the overall quality and usefulness of gates has gone up quite a bit since we had our first child (we're up to four).  Previously there just weren't very many good choices  when it came to putting up gates in wide spaces.  Our home office has double doors and we'd been getting by with a tension gate(Evenflo Soft N Wide Gate).  It was really just a blockage with no opening.  To get past you step over it.  While it was helping me stay limber it was starting to look a bit ragged after many years of abuse.We decided to try out this sliding gate.  The installation is pretty typical of most of the hardware mounted gates: they provide a template to guide you on where to drill holes and mount the hardware.  It goes best with two people.  One person will have a lot of trouble getting even and level, and that will mess up the sliding mechanism.Once in place it works reasonably well.  You can open it with one hand.  Not the easiest opening, but by far not the hardest.  Considering you don't want kids to work out how to open it, it achieves the goal of being "useable, but fairly kid proof."  The build quality is decent.  Considering the wide gap being covered it's pretty sturdy, but I wouldn't say it's the best constructed gate ever.  Overall a good gate for a wide area.  I think the price is fair for the functionality and the quality.

After four kids weve gone through several strollers and jogging strollers.  Prior to this our go to jogging stroller was a Bob Revolution.  Thats a great mixed-use stroller that can operate as a day-to-day stroller and its a decent jogging stroller.  It does both well but doesnt quite excel at either.  This Thule stroller doesnt really function as a day-to-day stroller but it excels as a sport stroller.  If you are on a budget and looking for one multi-role stroller, there are better options.  However if your budget has room for both, this is an outstanding jogging stroller and it would complement a smaller day-to-day stroller really well.Setup is super easy.  It comes well packed and its easy to get the few parts out for assembly.  All you need to do is unfold the frame and put the three tires on.  The front tire has a bike-like quick release and the rear tires have a button which makes it easy to pop them on and off.  They are big tires (air filled and inflatable with a bike pump) so if you have a small trunk you may need to do that.  That would be a pain for a daily stroller but as a jogging stroller, not such a big deal.  Folding is easy  theres a little flap below the seat you lift up to access the handle that will collapse the stroller.  It does require you to move from behind the stroller to being in front of the stroller.  Little things like that matter if you are herding around several children.  Despite the minor hassle (compared to a rear-collapse system) I did like how much more rugged it felt than other collapse systems Ive used.Jogging with it?  A dream.  It roles easy, the shocks are superb, and the big tires deliver a smooth easy ride for your passenger.  The rear brake handle works well for large and small hands.  Its super light (~22lbs).  Ive had my hands on a lot of jogging strollers and so far this is the hands down best.It has the standard baby features: View flaps, adjustable seat recline, under carriage storage, and a sun visor.  The sun/rain visor does a very good job of actually blocking the sun (too many strollers seem to miss on this point): it can come really far forward, so if youre jogging on a hot sunny day or a misty rainy day you can provide you child with a decent amount of cover.  The seat padding is nice, and seems pretty rugged.  There is a nice amount of mesh venting on the top and rear of the seat for hot days.  The foot rest is basic but it gets the job done well enough.So not what you want as your only stroller, but if you are serious about jogging, I dont know of a better jogger, especially at this price.

I used this to do some over-seeding of some bare spots in my lawn.  I had already dethatched the lawn.  My soil is fairly compacted, so I was curious to see how it did.  I put some new top soil down on most of the lawn but I picked one good sized spot and left it bare to see how important that was (though I did loosen it a bit).  So far it's pretty early.  I've just started to get some sprouts.  The bare areas are definitely seeing less new grass but they growth I'm seeing is acceptable enough.  I'd definitely recommend combine this with soil amendments if you've got hard ground, but it's not a "must do."I can't comment too much on watering because it's been fairly rainy here mixed in with just enough sun to keep the ground warm but not dry it out.  Pretty much perfect seeding weather.  Compared to previous years this seems to be performing better than other seeds I've tried, but the weather is really lending a hand here so I'm not sure exactly how much credit I can give to the Scott's grass seeds.  I think it is safe to say if you follow the instructions and provide adequate water you are going to get good results.

This is the second one of these I've tried (I tried the nearly identical Nature Valley Salted Caramel Peanut Crisp Bars Box, 5.34 Ounce 6 bars.  Replace the dark chocolate with salted caramel and otherwise it's the same.Previously I have avoided "Nature Valley" products, because as a company it's pretty much a scam: packed full of sugar and refined canola and soybean oils.  I have noticed they have been updating their product line and improving their ingredients.  I'd still put them on the bottom of the ladder in terms of the healthfulness of their products, but if you think of them as "slightly better than candy or cookies" and incorporate them into your diet accordingly then I think they have a place.This "Nut Crisp" bar was very popular with my kids, even more so than the salted caramel bar.  Personally I thought they were both "okay".  When packing a lunch for school I like to include a "treat".  Rather than send something like a packet of Oreos, I can send some kind of bar like this.  Now, my preference would be something like 18 Rabbits Jr. Organic Granola Bar, Chocolate Cherry, which has similar nutritional profile but taste better and has a much better ingredient list.  And if you shop around in your local "organic" grocery store odds are you'll find more like it.  If not, I think these Nature Valley bars are a reasonable alternative.
