I get that he didn't want to ruin their friendship but I don't think he realized that her being with someone else would possibly ruin it anyway.Smart and sassy, it was easy to like Sky but I also wondered how she could be so clueless that Matt's attention and his insistence on making sure she was always safe was just out of friendship. It was easy to see her confusion throughout this book especially after their first night together as more than friends.I genuinely liked this story, but I also felt like Sky and Matt got cheated out of the romance of the relationship. They spent so much time talking about Caleb, dealing with Matt's elderly grandmother and feeling awkward after being together physically that they really didn't have time to enjoy each other as a couple in love instead of best friends who slept together "accidentally" twice. I'm also going to admit that I found it odd that Sky's friend Kat was so focused on the fact she thought Matt would be kinky in the bedroom and the way it was discussed throughout this book because in honesty Matt wasn't all that kinky and it just seemed unnecessary and strange the way it was brought up and continued throughout this book.While not my favorite book in this series His Best Friend's Girl was still an enjoyable story and getting to see many of the couple's from previous books just added to the enjoyment.Review copy provided for an honest review.

I have to hand it to Elle Boon. She has one hell of an imagination.  Besides her characters being extremely hot and interesting, she pens a story that has you wanting more and wishing that the next book would release the next day.  Honestly, I couldnt believe how quick this story moved.  I felt like I just started it and I was reading the HEA.  Damn, I really wanted more of Rowan and Lyric and the rest of the Iron Wolves MC.  This looks like it is going to be a fun and interesting series and I can only hope that Syns story comes out soon.Rowan and Lyric were wonderful together.  She has sass and he has a heart of gold.  Ex-military and alpha as all get out, Rowan just grabs you from his first appearance in the story and has you falling hard for him in not time  Fearless, doesnt back down from anyone or anything.  Compassionate, caring and oh so dominant in bed, he is definitely a match made in heaven for the Iron Wolves MC and Lyric.Lyric doesnt take anything from anybody either.  Her brother is very protective but there isnt much he could do about Rowan or the accidental turning of him.  He can push around his weight and be immediately told off by Lyric and Syn. Lyric is fearless and just as caring as Rowan.  She really felt bad about turning Rowan about not being able to get him through his first shift without any pain, about not giving him any choices.  But, she wanted him and was not about to walk away from that.Together, they face the threats, her brother Xan, Kellen and the rest of the MC to be together.  Together they explode in bed.  Together they will make a life for themselves, acclimate Rowan to being a wolf and in the MC.Lyrics Accidental Mate was actually fun to read.  Elle interspersed the fun with the serious, the sexy with the erotic.  All the characters were interesting and have me looking forward to more of the Iron Wolves MC.  Syn is next and I cannot wait to see who she ends up mating.  Elle left a lot of room as to who it will be.  Now, I know who I would love to see her with but Im not sure if she will take the easy way out and put her there.  And, thats the other thing that I adore about Ms. Boons writing  she writes what we least expect.  She makes sure that you have to wonder where she is taking the story and the characters.  Nope, didnt expect Rowan to just accept the supernatural being he became  see, logically, he should have fought it, asked more questions  thats what I was expecting and didnt get that at all.  I got a fun story with two characters that were totally hot and adorable.  Thank you, Elle for keeping us on our toes, keeping us guessing and giving us wonderful stories.Review copy provided for an honest review.

4.5 starsPrevious books in Pamela Clares I-Team romantic suspense series are fast-moving, full of action with unexpected twists and turns, and her latest release, Seduction Game, is no different. It was everything we know and love, and over the years have come to expect from this gifted storyteller. This is a story of deceit, regained trust, ultimate sacrifice, and of course, love.I love when an author takes a character and completely changes everything you thought you knew about them. Holly is that character. Although shes a great friend, loyal and always there when you need her, she also comes across as shallow, materialistic, and tries to live up to her Horny Holly nickname.However, things are not always as they seem. On the surface, she is fun and care-free, but once we delve into this seemingly artificial bombshell we find a complicated and multilayered woman. There are secrets about her I did not see coming. She is my favorite type of heroine, a fearless kick-ass woman with lots of spunk, confidence, sex appeal, and intelligence.Nick is someone the fans have not met until this book. Hes not exactly in a good place, driven by revenge after his girlfriend and fellow agent was killed in a CIA mission gone badly. Now Nick is on his own mission with an agenda to kill the man responsible for her death. Nick is a conflicted guy and even as the story intensifies he cant decide if Holly is who his agency says she is. The fact that she turns him on and inside out with her wit and beauty isnt helping matters either.Hold on for a wild ride while Nick and Holly butt heads, heat up the sheets, and do everything in their power to stay one step ahead of the bad guys who just so happen to be on both sides of the law. Its a keep you on the edge of your seat kind of read, a real page turner. Not only do I highly recommend this book, I recommend the entire series.I can honestly and without hesitation say, Ive never read a Pamela Clare book that I didnt like. She is a hardworking, true professional, and Im thrilled to have her well and writing again. I cant wait to see what she has in store for us next.Review copy provided for an honest review.

This series is killing me! I can't take it every time I read one of the books I fall for the Billionaire, then the next book comes out and Darn you Jessica Clare I find myself loving the newest Billionaire more.  I was so ready to HATE Chelsea.  I mean a hot girl who does Roller Derby is not worhty of my time, I mean the billionaires time.  But she was written so perfectly I fell in love with her too.  Darn you again Jessica Clare.Sebastian was written so perfectly and he truly had the ego to match his bank account, but had the humble shy quiet loving nature that made me want to jump into my kindle and cuddle.  Chelsea had the beautiful heart, the truly heart breaking broken girl issues, but she smiled and she laughed and she loved loyally.  It was impossible not to close your eyes and wish for the happy ending at the end.  I am sure I'll eat my words but I dont see how the next couple can compete with these two.  Together they were by far the most enjoyable couple to read about this year!Review copy provided for an honest.

Annnnnd, Kristin Daniels did Leave Me Breathless, sexually frustrated and oh, so happy that I read this compilation of books by a new-to-me author. She really is making me want to go and get her other books.Three very different stories with one main theme . Three hot men and the women that they will do anything for  will do anything to win their love  will love and protect for the rest of their lives. Throw in the hot, kinky sex and you have three stories that will fill your heart with love and wishing for more of these three awesome couples.Brynn and Ryan were a match made in heaven, until he ruined it all. Now, blindsiding her as her leading man in her new movie and trying to win her back, he has to prove to her that he has changed and will love her the way she deserves to be loved, forever.Eden and Shane. The hot rocker and the graphic artist that has had nothing but wet dreams about him for as long as she could remember. But, when the past is revealed and their tryst is captured by the paparazzi, will she let go of her control for long enough to grab the brass ring in front of her and jump on the roller coaster ride that is waiting for her with Shane? She just may enjoy her bonus for a job well done on his album cover.Mia and Logan  two like minds who are vying for the same position. But, with a little help from her grandmother and a little magic, they find themselves in positions that Mia never thought were possible. Finding love at first sight was just a little something extra to the off the chart sex that they fell into within the first five minutes of meeting each other.Now, none of these woman had a submissive bone in their bodies. Each of them stood on their own two feet, were strong and strong-willed. But, the dominance that each of these men showed when they took control of their bodies was hotter than hot. Yes, each of the characters fell into sex rather quickly but these are three short stories so it was kind of expected. And, kudos to Ms. Daniels for giving us off the chart sexual encounters with three happily-ever-afters that really made me smile.Hot men, the women that bring them to their knees, love and lust all combined in the three stories to bring us an exciting read that will definitely leave you breathless.Review copy provided for an honest review.

I love it!  I have the Kindle Keyboard, the Paperwhite, a Galaxy tablet, an iPad and now this one.  This on is by far my favorite size, it's easy to hold and perfect size to carry in a purse.  My absolute perfect dream Kindle would be a Paperwhite in this length and width.  The glare isn't too bad on this one, but I do prefer the weight of the Paperwhite and the e-ink technology.

I'm kinda in love with MK Meredith after reading Seducing Seven because she wrote a book about a romance writer who loves her job, knows what she needs to do to be successful, is grateful for her fans and will defend romance books until her last breath.  I know you'll are wondering why this is such a big deal, well I'll tell you; lately I've read a few books that featured romance writers as a main character and they either thought they were wasting their time, didn't respect their readers or decided that it was in their best interest to stop writing romance and write a "real" book and for a lover of this genre that doesn't set well with me!In Las Vegas for a big book convention romance author Seven Michaels is trying to escape and overzealous male fan who thinks he's going to get lucky with her over the weekend when she enlists the help of Blake Turner, a random man in the elevator.  From that moment, it was game on for these two and when Blake finds out what Seven does for a living she makes him a bet she can make him have feelings for her by the end of the convention.Seven was a spitfire heroine and I loved that Blake made her act out of character a bit; made her go for it and put herself out there.  She never backed down on her profession, she was proud of what she does and her accomplishments as she should be and while a couple of times Blake made her feel bad and had her feeling off balance and a little insecure she held her ground.  I liked Blake for the most part and honestly I believe he was a good guy but things moved really fast for him and left him feeling out of control which made him act out and say some really hateful things.  I'll admit there were a couple of times I wanted to bop him upside the head, but thankfully he figured things out and made amends.So many of their interactions were playful, fun and very, very sexy and it was easy to feel their connection from their first kiss to their last. While they were both hoping to win the bet it became obvious pretty quickly they both were feeling way more than either of them wanted to admit.Sensual, smart and supremely satisfying don't miss MK Meredith's Seducing Seven.Review copy provided for an honest review.

4.5 starsI wasn't sure what to expect from A Lover's Lament, I have never read KL Grayson before and while I've followed BT Urruela's fitness and modeling career I wasn't aware he was an author, but after reading this book I look forward to reading more from both authors. This was not a pretty romance; this book deals with heart break, death, anger, war, forgiveness, anger, sadness and a forever kind of love we all hope to find. I loved this story and it was brilliantly written; told in first person from two points of view we were given a window into the lives, thoughts and emotional trauma each of these characters experienced throughout this book.A short prologue sets up this book and then it really begins 10 years after with Katie waking up after a car accident. She is not in a good place and for several chapters we see her struggling with life and her "new" normal. When her therapist suggests she should engage with a military pen pal she finds a familiar name on the list and decides to lay it all out on the line and unleash all of her pain. She never expects to feel so much as she writes the first letter or how much Devin's response affects her.I loved reading their letters to each other which progressed into emails and eventually into phone calls. Ten years after Devin left; it is easy to tell from the correspondence that they both were unable to erase the other one completely from their memory and the feelings pour through their words to one another.Watching Katie go from a very angry and closed off woman to one who wants more out of life, one that is actually living again and one that will even admit she is happy was pretty amazing to watch. I'll admit reading Devin's war accounts and the toll it was taking on him and his fellow soldiers was hard, but I felt very realistic. As they both being to realize that the feelings they once had were still there; they fell hard and fast and came to rely on the communication they both so desperately needed to stay connected so far away from one another.They faced some very hard times both apart and together and through it all their love remained strong, they both believed they had some divine intervention and they never lost hope that they would finally get their chance to have the life they both wanted together.A Lover's Lament will touch your soul and you will feel every emotion as you read this couple's intense and beautiful journey and it is absolutely a book you do not want to miss.

This was an interesting little novella, with a quirky plot, some sizzling sex scenes and likable characters.Hannah Roberts runs the Tavern she inherited from her grandfather in Loving, Kansas. She has a crush on two of the men who play poker each week in her establishment, but knows the two gay men aren't for her. Brody Markham andDrew Pate are in a BDSM relationship, but they aren't gay, they are bisexual. Both are drawn to Hannah, but neither has acted on the attraction until circumstances throw them all together. Can Hannah become the submissive the two men are seeking? Can she handle that her lovers have each other as well as her? And can they all stay safe when her abusive ex-husband arrives to try and claim half the Tavern-even though he and Hannah were divorced when she inherited it.Hannah is portrayed as a strong woman who is willing to turn some of her decision making over to the two men who love her. What's not to love about Brody-strong, protective and dominant. Mainly because Drew is a sub to Brody, is it harder to see him as a dominant for Hannah-although he does prove to be equal to the task.Overall, a sexy little read.Review copy provided for an honest review.

4.5 starsStunned...that's what I am as Crosswinds ended. I shouldn't be, because well teenage girls can be mean and ruthless, but I am. In Elisabeth Naughton's episode of this epic small town tale, we are drawn more into the lives of the younger members of Storm, Texas. We see one girl desperately trying to hang on to the boy that has come to mean so much to her, we see that girl's best friend break her trust, we see a confused young man, and that young man's best friend wondering not only what in the hell is wrong with him but trying to console the girl he obviously has feelings for who was wronged. So much happens in this story and while the high school set is front and center there are several other developments that just add to the drama, the intrigue and the overall intensity of this series.I am so drawn to these characters and their crazy, screwed up lives and with this younger crowd how they don't think about how their actions will affect so many people in so many different ways. In addition we see Ginny Moreno whose pregnancy has rocked this small town drawn to a man she once had a crush on as he returns from his time in the service. Given the secrets she carries with her I'm very curious as to where this will lead.With each installment the story becomes more complex, more intertwined and definitely more twisted and there is no doubt a storm is brewing and the aftermath will most likely blow everyone away. While Ms. Naughton's episode dealt with different characters in this saga, the story flowed seamlessly from the last one and I am in awe of the way these authors are blending their voices and their styles to create this amazing and startling tale.Review copy provided for an honest review.

Christmas in Mustang County looked cute and sweet when I read the blurb and it definitely lived up to my expectations even though I am nowhere near ready for the Christmas season to begin.The story is centered around Charlotte and Jax  his quest to win her back and her quest to try to convince herself that Mustang Creek is not the place for her. Theres nothing exciting, nothing high-powered and certainly not a place for her to apply her advertising degree. But it does have certain charms to it. The friends she grew up with, cozy little stories and, now, Jaxon.Jaxon tolerated the big city but, when he got the call to go back to Idaho, he was concerned for his father but excited to return to the wide open spaces, blue skies and the animals that he loved. His biggest regret was leaving Charlie. He tried to convince her that she should give it a chance, give him a chance but she wouldnt. Stalking her FB page, he finds out that shes going back to Mustang Creek. He doesnt know if she is there to stay but it is worth moving there and taking the job offer from his friend to help out at his Veterinary Clinic.A little bit of magic, a lot of meddling from the adorable Mrs. Klozz, the love of animals, a secluded cabin and a sleigh ride were all working against Charlotte and definitely in favor of Jax. Then throw in good meaning friends and planting a little idea into the right minds and Charlotte falls harder than the snow during a blizzard.So, yes, the story was adorable but  it really moved a little too quickly for me. Charlotte was in love with Jax when they were in New York and their chemistry was off the charts. I love how fate kept throwing them together from the moment they both set foot in Mustang Creek. But, she just kept giving me whiplash. No, she wasnt falling into his arms or bed; yes, she was; well, maybe she will; aw, what the hell, she cant fight it. I was happy that she was giving into the magic that was being woven around them but I was also stunned. But, Jax didnt surprise me at all  he was determined to make her see her place in Mustang Creek, in his bed and in his life, forever.Linda Lael Miller actually brought the sweetness factor up a notch with this story filling it with every known decadent desert you could possibly imagine. Mrs. Klozz and Aunt Geneva, Mutley, Can-Can and Felix lit up this story and brought the fun factor into the book. She made sure that we understood what Charlie and Jax were thinking and how they got where they were by weaving their pasts into the present  made sure that we are still wondering just who Mrs. Klozz really was  she made sure that we smiled throughout the whole story. These are all characteristics that I truly love in an author.

3.5 starsA vacation from home turns into a TRUE Fairytale. This story has insta-love,hot times, fun friends and an "international incident". I really enjoyed this book. I truly am such a sucker for fairytales and being swept away in them. To imagine yourself to be seen by a prince who is can we say HAWT! Kristos is hot and a rebellious Prince with flaws. Oh you read that right Flaws. And Emmaline is a broken girl who had to give up her dreams. I know you see where this is going. But trust me when I saw Jennfier Chance takes you there in the most enjoyable way. As with most fairytales I've read the plot seems predictable I loved the current times spin on this tale. I found myself enjoying the characters of the book and did find that Emmaline and Kristos were definitely the stars of the book, all the supporting characters faded to the background until the end.I'm excited and can't wait for the next in the series just to come back to my fairytale land of Garronia.Review copy provided for an honest review.

Erin Nicholas is known for writing fun, flirty and sexy stories of life and love; in her latest release, Illegal Motion, she offers up an intense, deep and extremely emotional story and proves she can not only stretch her writing muscle but excel at it as well. Two people with a connection are reunited 6 months after the death of his best friend and her fianc, and must not only deal with the fallout from a memorable night they all three shared, but revelations from that night and regrets of time wasted. This was not a pretty or fun romance; it was a little dark, poignant and their journey took time, patience and the wisdom of friends to help them find the happiness they both so richly deserve.There was no doubt Carter Shaw was in a deep, dark place and being at the wedding of friends isnt helping. Carter doesnt believe in romance, in love or marriage and babies; hes seen what loves does to people up close as his Dad changes wives like he changes his underwear. Plus the one woman hes had feelings for is someone he would never want to hurt and he knows hell end up hurting with his inherited possessiveness.Lacey Andrews wanted to surprise Carter but getting the wrong house and then having to deal with not only an angry couple but Carter in full out police mode wasnt quite the surprise she had in mind. I admired Lacey for taking a chance and going after what she wants, but most of all for sticking to her guns and not letting Carter hide from her or his feelings.While this was a journey of two people trying to find a way to be together as a couple, there was a third person with them if only in their memories. I hurt for them both as they struggled to not only preserve their memories of Garrett, but as they realized how much they both needed one another. While Lacey was engaged to Garrett they had talked about Carter a lot and she had really taken time since his death to not only come to terms with it but to also realize that the other half of her heart belonged to Carter. Carter had not taken time to grieve or even really come to terms with the type of relationship Garrett and Lacey had wanted with him or for the time they lost because of him. To be honest Carter was kind of a mess and in many pieces but Lacey was the glue that was able to put him together. I appreciated the fact that Carter thought he needed help to make Lacey happy and was willing to do anything to keep her, but seriously he really went off the deep end a couple of times trying to find someone to step in an help him. I have to give Nolan a lot of credit for not only being a good friend to both Carter and Lacey but for trying to show Carter how way off base he was with his thinking. I also have to say that the scene in the bar with Oakley (from Mari Carrs Red Zone) was flat out hilarious and gave them both some much needed perspective.Hot, intense and emotional Illegal Motion shows a different side of author Erin Nicholas writing and an amazing addition to the Boys of Fall series.Review copy provided for an honest review.

4.5 starsI do so love when author Mari Carr serves up a sexy as hell mnage and Red Zone, her latest offering in the Boys of Fall series, is pretty much perfection. Two men; best friends for a long time and ranch hands at the same ranch decide they are tired of chasing after the woman of their dreams and offer her a night shell never forget. A secret relationship, an unconventional love, family drama, guilt, passion, and a love they cant deny all made Red Zone a page turner from start to finish and a book I know Ill want to read again and again.I loved the offbeat, snarky, and strong Sadie Milligan. Working in her fathers bad and being raised only by her Dad for most of her life Sadie isnt the typical girl next door in small Quinn, Texas. Shes outspoken, shes tattooed, she cusses, and she loves colorful hair. Sadie really is a breath of fresh air, but Sadie doesnt date much, but she finds it impossible to resist Joel and his best friend, Oakley.Three people; two very open in their sexuality and another one struggling due to his very religious upbringing made this a very intricate relationship. It was pretty fascinating watching these three people work through so many different and conflicting issues as they pursue being together in all ways.Sadie being abandoned by her mother at a young age worries shell never be able to have a committed relationship and that shell be a bad mother and while shes all good with some great sex she struggles with feelings and everything that comes with a relationship. Joel has the reputation of being cool, calm, collected, steady and a stand-up guy; hes got a good reputation and has lived his life in Quinn being raised by his dedicated but strict Catholic mother. As their relationship progresses and Joel must face the fact that he has feelings for not only Sadie but Oakley as well. And Oakleyman, I love this guy! Theres no doubt Oakley lucked out by NOT having family in town, but then he also claims his parents are pretty open about things. I loved that he pushed Joel but backed off when it became evident Joel was conflicted and that he was upfront with Sadie about what he wanted for the three of them even when he knew it might scare her. Together these three were so amazingly sexy but there was also an unbelievable closeness that went beyond sexual; it was quite beautiful watching these three not only learn so much about themselves but each other as well.Im just going to say it, I loved these three and their journey so much and I would very much love a follow up story to see not only how their relationship has progressed, but how the tiny Texas town of Quinn reacts to their unconventional lifestyle. Explosive, entertaining and amazingly sexy you dont want to miss Mari Carrs Red Zone!Review copy provided for an honest review.

I'm an avid griller and so I was excited to try the Maverick remote monitoring temperature probe. I have a high-end FireMagic grill that has a built-in temperature probe, and while it's accurate and easy to use, you need to stay within a few feet of the grill to really use it, and this just isn't convenient when smoking or roasting larger meats that take a long time. Plus, a few times I've run out of fuel while grilling...I usually don't notice until I go check the grill, and by then it's gone cold. Having temperature monitoring capabilities that could work from a distance sounded like a great idea.The probes are easy to use - pretty much what you'd expect: insert, turn it on and your done. Of course, the trick is knowing where to place the probe, and the optimum location differs for every type of meat. Still, with a little experience, you can get perfect and repeatable results every time. With some practice, you'll be pulling stuff off the grill confident that you're really getting the rare/medium/well temperatures your friends and family ask for.As promised, the monitor works from at least a few hundred feet. With my grill outside, I found I got perfect connection up to about 200 feet, and some signal out to about 300 feet, and that's with the thick stainless steel cover on my grill closed. I could also go just about anywhere in my home, and even with up to four exterior and interior walls between me and my grill, I had no trouble staying connected. I've also used these in my indoor oven with the same great results.About the only concern I have is the upper temperature limit on the probes. The manufacturer says they are safe up to 572 degrees, but I know from experience that my 140,000 BTU grill can reach almost 1000 degrees. I seldom use it at those kinds of temperatures, but I do wonder what happens when that 572 degree value is exceeded.Otherwise, these are well made products at a fair price. If you're the type who holds your breath when you make that first cut into your meat, fearing that it might be underdone or overdone, this is for you - definitely worth a look if you grill a lot and struggle to hit the right doneness every time.

I'm a bit fanatic about my toast, and the Dash does a good job at a fair price.The unique see-through sides help you get exactly the result you want without lifting your toast out to check on it. In a conventional toaster, it seems like every time you raise your toast, it cools off a bit and tends to make the final product a bit on the soggy side. With the Dash, you don't have this problem...your toast keeps right on cooking until you're sure it's the doneness you want - never seen this sort of feature before, but it's great.Otherwise, it's reasonably well made and performs as well as most of the other toasters I've tried. The overall look is sort of retro, the red color is bold and it certainly makes a statement. The red parts and knobs are mostly a plastic material...it's not as rugged as some of the high end toasters you might see, but it's definitely more than adequate to meet the demands of most kitchens. On mine, the fit and finish is okay but not perfect...there are a few scratches and rough spots here and there, and the controls feel a bit loose. An added plus is that it's pretty simple to clean.The heating elements appear to be some type of ceramic. They seem to heat quickly and evenly, and the outside of the toaster doesn't get particularly hot unless you toast item after item in quick succession. It's not as fast as some others I've tried, but it certainly puts out enough heat to toast whatever you put into it. I did notice that there was a tendency to concentrate heat towards the center of the toaster, but with a few uses, you sort of figure this part out.If you're after a cool looking toaster and like the bold red, then this is definitely worth a look.

I've owned many Epson printers over the years, and most have been reliable, competent performers. The PictureMate is what I use for quick prints from my phone or point-and-shoot camera when I just want a small print to share with a minimum of fuss.For me, setup was really easy and I was printing from my iPhone 6P in under five minutes from taking the printer out of the box. This printer is made for wireless, no matter what type of device or computer you have. Apple AirPrint support is very good, and it also works with Windows and Android. If you have WiFi, you can probably print to this device. You can also plug your memory card directly into the printer, review images on the built-in screen and print whatever photos you like. This is handy for cameras and devices lacking WiFi - no cables to attach. And yes, if you really want, you can even USB connect this printer to a computer.Overall, the print quality is quite good for this type of device. I'm a photographer and I have one of Epson's high-end Stylus Pro 4900 series printers that is simply the best image quality I've ever seen. For my review, I printed the same image on the PictureMate and on the 4900...I won't say that I couldn't tell the difference - but I was pleasantly surprised by just how good the PictureMate looked in a side-by-side comparison. Although I haven't done a scientific comparison by any means, I prefer the Epson look to that I've seen from similar Canon or HP products. A lot of printers can be tweaked to perform a certain way, but I like that with minimal adjustment, the Epson puts out prints that look good and last a long time.The Achilles heel to the PictureMate is probably the cost per page, which can be up to about 40 cents per 4x6 print. Still, the image quality, fast speed and overall performance probably warrant the premium price.If you're looking for a convenient, high-quality 4x6/5x7 photo printer, the Epson PictureMate might just be what you've been searching for.

I've been impressed by a few Lee products recently, and this shirt is no exception. It's inexpensive, but well-made - and best of all, it's comfortable and good-looking on me. The fabric is somewhat on the thin side (compared to say, a Ralph Lauren polo), but thanks to a bit of stretchiness, it always looks smooth without that crumpled some low-cost shirts have.The 5-button style is nice, the collar is well proportioned, and the sleeves are just the right length for me. I'm on the tall side, so I might like another inch of length or so, but it's by no means too short.Although I've only washed it a few times, it seems to hold up well without fading or shrinking.Overall, this is a great shirt at a fair price - congrats to Lee for another great product.

These are some great inexpensive jeans that fit and look terrific.The fabric is indeed "ultra soft" and a medium weight, and it has a bit of stretch to it. I found the fit "skinniest" at the cuffs, less so through the waist and hips...depending on your shape, you might find them a bit loose up top.They also seem well made for jeans in this price range. The front pockets are a bit shallow. The color is a little on the indigo - almost purple - side, but it fades nicely after a few washings. As the sticker on the jeans says, they are subject to a lot of dye transfer, so definitely be careful where you sit until they've been washed several times - and of course, be careful what you wash them with.It's nice to see a great pair of jeans that you don't have to spend a fortune on...great job Lee!

I purchased four of these for my business to wall mount in our conference rooms, and so far we are very happy with them.There are lots of input options that make this a great monitor for business use. We generally connect using a mix of the built-in wireless client and Apple TV, although sometimes visitors will opt for a direct HDMI connection. All of them look wonderful, even the Apple TV (which is limited to 1080p). A recent model computer putting out a 4K signal over HDMI looks amazing on this monitor - best we've seen, certainly at this price point.For business use, the need is a little different than home theater, and the Samsung does a great job with text and graphics. Colors are bright and saturated, contrast is good enough to make reading text easy from across the room, and even in a brightly lit room, the monitor is easy to see. I would be more critical if this were going in my home theater: blacks and grays aren't terrific, and there's definitely a bit of visible light blooming across the bottom of the screen. These aren't issues for business presentations, but I'd definitely find them distracting in a home theater setup.The built-in sound quality is fine for our business needs. Again, if I were thinking of this for my home theater, I'd probably have some sort of multi-channel sound system, so audio quality might not be too important. But if you're thinking of just using the built-in sound, you'll be disappointed - you'll at least want to opt for a sound bar and maybe a subwoofer.The remote control is okay for what it is...all the functions are there, and Samsung thoughtfully publishes the IR command codes on their web site so you can control the monitor from most automation systems. Like most smaller remotes, it's no joy entering lots of text, like you might find yourself doing when setting up your WiFi or when entering information into some of the built-in apps. The built-in WiFi is a nice feature and it seems more than fast enough to keep up with the content...as a test, we played some native 4K content from both Amazon and Netflix and the network seemed to have no trouble keeping up.I'm not a huge fan of most of the apps that come on this (or any other) TV...many are poor quality, and most seem rendered in fuzzy, low-resolution ways. Again, this isn't an issue for us in our business setting, but for home theater use, I'm hoping the latest Apple TV catches on and that we eventually end up with millions of high quality apps that can take advantage of our 4K monitors. Still seems like a distant goal though.Being fairly light for this screen size (65" weighs about 52 pounds), they're relatively painless to wall mount. We chose an articulating mount that can come 18" off the wall and pivot about 60 degrees right or left. Our office walls are backed by thin steel studs that aren't hugely strong, but we felt confident to use snap toggles to handle the weight. Last monitor we had was nearly 150 pounds, and our walls needed all sorts of reinforcement to carry the load. One issue we had was that the VESA mounting holes are set unusually deep into the TV. The 1.5" bolts that came with our mount weren't long enough to reach the deeply set nuts.

The last ViewSonic product I purchased was a large 17" CRT monitor many years ago...it was great for it's day (still have it, actually!), so we felt comfortable turning to them again. We needed a bunch of monitors for our offices so that visiting workers could have a place to dock, and the ViewSonic VA2465 was the model we selected.For the price, they are actually very nice monitors - way better than similar units we tried from Acer and a few other brands. Our workers have a mix of different computers, Macs to Windows, and portables through small form factor Intel NUC computers running Linux. There are both VGA and HDMI inputs, and the good news is that whatever we connect to the ViewSonic monitors just works first time with no hassles at all - and they all produce a clean, crisp display.The monitor itself is small, lightweight and unobtrusive in our environment. The image is bright and high contrast, and it renders text quite well. The viewing angle is good, and you don't need to sit directly in front of the monitor to get a reasonable image. The built-in speakers are fine for office use. We don't use them for gaming, but they seem "fast" compared to others we've used. Power use is low, as an added benefit.We have a total of six of these, and exactly zero have bad or bright pixels. They are all calibrated equally out of the box, and this also speaks well to the quality ViewSonic is delivering.Can't really say enough good things about these monitors - for the price, they're a steal in this size and resolution. Definitely recommended!

Well made, fits comfortably and maybe helps sore joints and muscles by being snug and supportive. Hard to say that there's any therapeutic value...my shoulder aches are pretty much unchanged, but I like the look overall, and it's definitely good quality for the price...worth a try if you like the style, but I wouldn't expect a miracle.

These are terrific and very small memory sticks that I use in all sorts of places.On the USB 3 port on my network router, I get a quick way to share 64GB of data with the devices in my network. On my multi-function printer, I get a quick way to scan documents to a memory stick without needing to install software or drivers on my computers. Even in my car, I can keep my digital music collection on one of these without tethering my phone. And of course, I always carry a few in the backpack should I need to share files with anyone.The construction quality is good, but these are really tiny devices - about the size of a penny. Although the small size makes it convenient to carry a bunch of these in your pocket, I'm finding that the small size is sometimes a curse - they can be difficult to insert or to grasp when removing them from certain PCs. Otherwise, performance is quite good - especially on USB 3 devices...certainly faster than moving big files over a network.At the price, they're a bargain, and if you like the really small form factor, they are definitely worth a try.

I use this on a Quartet Infinity Glass board. The erasing part is fine - fits comfortably in your hand, cleans well and without too much effort, and lasts a long while without "loading up". Only complaint is that the magnetic part could be stronger...the eraser frequently falls from the board - it's just not strong enough. Otherwise, this is a great eraser at a reasonable price.

I was having a problem at my vacation home where my cable modem would hang about once a week, causing me to lose contact with my monitoring and automation systems. More than once I needed to make the 700 mile trip, just to reset the cable modem.I figured a relatively low-tech timer like the Intermatic DT620 could be used to power off/on the cable modem once a day, and this is exactly what it does. I programmed it to be on for about 23 hours and 50 minutes a day - it switches off at 1:01AM for ten minutes, then back on...this seems to work great and it's saved me from several outages.The device itself is well made and seems to have way more than enough capacity for my use (the equipment I have plugged into it consume less than 100 watts). It's physically larger than I wished is was - you definitely can't use two of them in a single outlet.Programming is a bit complex, but once you get the hang of it, it's not terrible - and of course, it's not like you're doing the programming every day. Still, I'd say if you want complex programming, you're probably better off with the z-Wave version of this unit and relying on a home automation controller to send the ON/OFF commands.Overall, the DT620 is a solid product and seems to be doing just what I want.

I have a two year old bulldog with a fairly sensitive digestive system. He's been issue free eating Wellness CORE dry food, so I figured these treats might also be something he enjoys and tolerates well. So far, so good - he comes running (well, as much as a bulldog can) when he hears me handling the bag, and zero digestion issues for him.As Hambone says, "woof woof, woof woof woof!", and I think this translates to "love 'em - get me more!".

This is a really nice bra, although I don't think I'd exactly call it "Padded" - the cups are more like "molded" in other brands. It's very comfortable and supportive, and the overall look is really pretty. Seems like it's also made well and will hold up a long time - definitely see myself buying more of these.

This is my first Simone Perele bra and I'm mostly happy with it so far. It's pretty, well made, comfortable and the fit is good, although the band is perhaps just a little bit on the small side. As another reviewer says, the cups are also just a bit too thin. Still, happy with it overall and I'll give S-P another try next time I'm shopping for a high quality bra.

I studied every available machine for a long time before buying the Profitec. If you're a coffee fanatic, this is a great choice for making excellent espresso - now, and for a very long time.The unit itself is impeccably made and quite study. Unlike some of the super-automatics that seem to be more plastic than metal, this puppy is stainless steel all around, from the drip tray to the brew group to the cup warmer. Out of the box, it's over 70 pounds of metal. Under the pretty exterior is a serious set of coffee-making bona fides: dual stainless steel boilers, quiet rotary vane pump, sophisticated PID system with precise temperature control, shot timer, plumbed or tank operation - pretty much everything you could want in a high-end espresso machine.It's also designed for longevity and easy service. I'm always impressed when a product looks like it's built with care on the inside, where most people might not ever look - and the Profitec has this in spades. Everything comes apart easily, and it's no big deal to isolate a part for replacement without packing the whole thing up to send back to the manufacturer. There's a great video (search YouTube) revealing the internal construction...by all means have a look if you're so inclined.I also like that the brewer accommodates rather large mugs...if you don't mind buying an extra bottomless portafilter, you can generally fit a four to five inch mug under the brewer - many machines are limited to shot-glass sized cups. I also like that even though it's a dual boiler design, it runs fine on a standard 15 AMP residential circuit. A few other machines I auditioned required more...and while I could have a 20A circuit installed, this would have been an added cost and inconvenience.One additional feature I'd like to see is a built in timer. Machines like this tend to take a while to heat up - like twenty minutes - and so it would be nice to have it pop on at a preset time each day. Of course, you can use an external appliance timer for this...just feels like it would be a good built-in feature. Still, I do like that this is pretty much a "minimalist" machine with no frills beyond what it takes to make excellent espresso.But of course the proof is in the taste of what pours into your cup, and here is where the Profitec excels. With high quality beans (I like Kona and JBM), this machine produces some of the finest espresso I've ever tasted, and unlike other machines I've used, once I have it all dialed in, I'm able to reproduce the same exact taste shot after shot. I use a Baratza Forte grinder and a calibrated tamper to give me the same tamping pressure on every shot. Couple this with bottled water in the Profitec and a careful eye on the shot timer, and I get very repeatable results, shot after shot.The steam boiler is also impressive on the Profitec. With my old single-boiler system, I used to make milk drinks by heating the milk in my microwave while the coffee was brewing - there just wasn't a big difference between doing it this way and using the steamer on the espresso machine. Nothing could be further from the truth with the Profitec...the steamed milk and gentle foam it makes is a delight in any cappuccino - I'm even pouring artful looking drinks because the consistency is so perfect...something I never even tried before on lesser machines.One final complaint is that I don't like the placement of the internal tank at the back of the machine. To fill it, you really need to get to the right rear of the unit. If you have it even partially tucked under cabinetry, this means you'll be lifting a 75 pound machine every time it needs filling. To me, a better design would be a fill port at the front of the machine. Of course, you can plumb the Profitec and never have to worry about filling it - perhaps this is what they really intend, except I like the consistency I get from using the same brand of bottled water over and over, rather than putting my city water supply through it.Of course, the Profitec is expensive. so it's probably not for everyone. You really need a good quality grinder to get the best from it, and by the time you've got tampers, a few extra portafilters and all the other accessories, you're spending something around four thousand dollars to get a nice cup of expresso. With practice, you can make amazing espresso on the stovetop in a $25 espresso pot, and the Profitec costs as much as about 150 of these. Still, if you and your significant other are paying Starbucks $10/day for a few latte's, the Profitec will pay for itself in a year or two.Anyway, on the journey to the perfect cup of coffee, the Profitec 700 is definitely a worthwhile companion. Definitely recommended!

I had last year's LG 34 UM95 monitor which was generally very good, but unfortunately, not very good with text...I always found fine detail on small point sizes looked too fuzzy and were often surrounded by fringes of red or purple, making the monitor difficult to read. I had a chance to swap the UM95 for this new UM97, and the differences are fairly substantial - in a positive direction.The monitor itself isn't exactly built like a tank - it's compact, lightweight and easy to move around. To me, these are all positives. Some of the controls are a bit frustrating...it falls into power save mode way too fast for me, and it takes a deft hand to swap between sources quickly. Still, no compatibility issues with the variety of devices I've connected, including Windows, Mac and Linux PCs, Apple TV, tablets through HDMI and so forth.Otherwise, the image quality is where this guy really shines. Bright and punchy, vivid colors, sharp - very much the perfect display for medium to dim rooms...in bright light, it's okay - but I might look closer at one of the Samsung products instead. For the price, this is a great product - only hard choice is whether 31" is big enough, or to go larger. Definitely worth a look.

I have a beach home in North Carolina, and even though we have nuclear strength dehumidification and air filtering, we're constantly fighting mold.One area that's proven especially difficult to keep mold-free is the ducting connected to our bathroom exhaust fans, and this is one of the areas where the Fogmaster really helps. We turn the fan on and use the Fogmaster to get a good plume of mold killer flowing through the fan and up the ducts...the inside of the ducts have been clean as a whistle since we started doing this.Of course, it's good for all the more conventional uses as well - definitely one of the better purchases we've made in our ongoing battle against the microbes.

My shoulders tend to bother me when I get busy working out, so I thought I'd try a Tommie Copper top to see if it helped. The fit is snug everywhere, and although the stretchy material hugs you closely, it doesn't really constrict or bind you in an uncomfortable way. As a few other reviews point out, the fabric doesn't breathe, so it tends to be hot, and I found myself sweating a lot when I wear it doing anything active. Otherwise, the look is generally flattering and the material and construction are good quality. Hard to say that I'm any less sore as a result of having this top, but I'm willing to give it more time.

This is a no-frills, larger-than-typical UPS that can keep a small server going for a considerable amount of time during a power outage. I like the it's true sine wave and that it's almost completely silent. We have four Intel NUC computers connected to it, and in our tests, we get about an hour of backup power from a full charge.As some other reviewers point out, there's no Ethernet/Coax surge suppression, and it won't work with a lot of sophisticated UPS software. Still, it does the job and seems to be built well for the price.Worth a look if you need good capacity and not too much else.

I read a lot of political books from writers across the spectrum, but Mark is unique. While others point out seemingly insolvable problems or lament this or that, Mark goes further, offering insightful, common-sense solutions to our problems in the American tradition, and this makes him unique in my book.The book itself is obviously well-researched, with more facts than anyone with an open mind would need to understand the serious shape we have left our country in for the next generation. Still, although it's an intellectually serious work, it's not dry or dull, and you never feel like you're reading a textbook or someone's Masters thesis. I've read all Mark's books, and I find this to be his most compelling work to date.You have to feel that if enough people would only read and understand this book, the USA would be a very different country, indeed.

I have a serious immersion blender from one of the big name brands (Viking), and I was curious how this Oster would stack up. Honestly, at literally one-tenth the price, I didn't have high expectations for the Oster - but in nearly every case, I've been surprised at just how good the Oster is.Okay, in terms of construction quality and the feel in operation, the Viking is clearly the champ. It should be, given the price difference. But otherwise, the differences are fairly subtle. The motors are both more than powerful enough for any task I tried, and both are about the same in terms of cleanup, storage and so forth.I notice the size of the actual blades on the Oster is a bit small, and it is substantially louder and more vibration-prone in your hand. As other reviewers point out, it could also benefit from a slower speed. The Oster doesn't seem quite as durable as my Viking (which is five years old and still like new), but I doubt it's ten times less...you could almost treat the Oster as a disposable, given the cost difference. Otherwise, I'm hard pressed to find any significant differences. For the price, this little Oster blender is definitely a steal.

I'm lucky enough to have one of the world's best grills (FireMaster), but sometimes I just want a quick and easy alternative that can be cooked right in the kitchen without heading outdoors, and this is where the George Foreman comes in handy.Putting it together was a snap - maybe five minutes, at most. From there, it's simple to use - heats quickly and evenly, cooks well without a lot of smoke, and when you're all done, cleans up without a fuss.Make no mistake: it doesn't get as hot as a proper charcoal or gas grill, so there's not quite as much grill flavor as you'd get on a higher power grill, but for a quick burger or such, it does the job. It's also hard to char food beyond recognition...in a sense, the less powerful George Foreman grill is more forgiving that way. Keep in mind the lower power and smaller surface area makes it best suited for small groups - it would take a long time to do, say, a dozen burgers on this guy.Does it make food rivaling my $8,000 Firemaster? No, not really - but it's definitely better than stovetop grilling, and for the price, it's definitely worth a try, especially if you don't have the space, budget or inclination for a larger conventional grill.

I wanted an attractive and smart thermostat for my vacation home that could integrate with my HomeSeer home automation system. After trying a few z-wave products that I wasn't happy with, I eventually settled on this Honeywell WiFi thermostat.My home automation system knows all the details about what goes on in my home...whether I'm there, outside weather conditions, etc etc etc. I didn't see much value in trying to also have these smarts in a thermostat...if I want sophisticated energy management, I'll do it from my home automation system - I don't need something like a Nest or Ecobee trying to replicate these functions. Thus, I only needed a pretty basic thermostat that provides for manual operation while tying into my home automation system for the rest. If the Honeywell didn't work out, my other plan was to just implement a relay to switch the HVAC components on and off directly from my HomeSeer unit, and hang a small tabled on the wall where the thermostats would normally be.The Honeywell unit is attractive and easily customized with a variety of themes and colors. It might be possible, but I haven't found a way to change themes programmatically - I'd like to do things like load different colors depending on weather conditions or whether we're running heat or cooling. Over time, this might be easier to do with a small tablet computer running custom home automation software. Still, there are plenty of attractive themes built in, and I'm sure most people will find something they are happy with.Being WiFi, it's mostly independent from my HomeSeer, but at the same time, I've been able to integrate to it through plug-ins on the HS3 software. I can use the Honeywell mobile app or web site to remotely control the thermostat, and I can also send commands to it from my HomeSeer. This dual approach gives me an extra layer of redundancy, should some sort of error occur with the HomeSeer while I'm a thousand miles away.I use the HomeSeer part for more complex automation...changing temperature in response to weather conditions, home occupancy and other events that the thermostat generally wouldn't know about. Honestly, it was more difficult to get this part working than it should have been, but now that I have it setup, it seems to work flawlessly.The unit itself was relatively straightforward to install on my three zone heat pump systems. It replaced a 2006-era Honeywell thermostat, so most of the wiring was pretty straightforward, and with one small exception, it worked fine on the first try. In my case, I have a lot of wires to connect and the most challenging part of the install was finding a way to hide the wires in the wall behind the thermostat. Otherwise, install was a snap - even the mounting holes lined up exactly as on the old unit, so I was able to do the installation in just a few minutes.Temperature control using just the thermostat works quite well, and the home never varies more than a small amount from the set point. I have several temperature and humidity sensors throughout the home, and I find that the humidity sensor in the thermostat isn't particularly accurate - most of the other sensors in my home vary from one another by just a few percent...the one in the thermostat seems to be off by 10-15 percent.The remote access works well also. To boost reliability, I setup a network router (Asus - check here on Amazon) that has the ability to fail over to a 4G cellular modem should my main broadband connection fail. So long as I have a network connection between the Honeywell and the HomeSeer console, or between the Honeywell and the outside world, I can see what's going on and control the settings.So while the Honeywell isn't perfect, it is a good looking and reliable thermostat that can be coerced into working with home automation systems, and the price isn't terrible for what you get.

I generally love Fekkai products, and this is a great shampoo that I use on a regular basis. It's thick and cleans well, protects my hair, and has a nice fragrance. My dry hair always comes out clean, shiny and healthy looking. Expensive, but a little goes a long way, and Amazon tends to have a way better price than my local stores.

This is a very nice yoga mat. It's not too heavy to carry around, just the right size, and thick enough to provide good padding and protection. Rolls up and stores easily without a lot of fuss. Definitely a great option and worth a look!

With it's large size and unusual dark color, this is an unusual piece that has almost a "retro" look to it. For the price, it's well made, and while you won't mistake it for a priceless Tiffany gem, it's definitely a nice addition to the wardrobe.If you like the style, it's worth a look and definitely fairly priced.

I'm generally a fan of AHAVA products, and despite being pricey, this is no exception. It goes on smooth and light without feeling greasy or too "thick"...a little goes a long way. It hydrates well and the effects seem to last a long time compared to my old standby (Clinique). Only thing I don't love is that the fragrance is a bit more than I like. Otherwise, a fine moisturizer and worth a try.

Like a lot of people, I think that wearable technology holds huge promise, and some of these gadgets will prove to be amazingly beneficial. Just not sure that the Lumo Lift hits this threshold.Right off the bat, I was not at all impressed with the product packaging. It was way too difficult to get out of the package, even armed with my trusty pocket knife. I don't necessarily deduct points for a frustrating out of box experiences, but hopefully this is an area that will be improved as the product matures.I found the Lumo somewhat awkward and uncomfortable to wear. It needs to be snug against your skin, and perhaps because I tend to wear loose tops, I struggle to find an ideal way to wear it. It's held in place using a magnet, meaning you will generally see the magnet outside your clothes unless you clip it to an undergarment. Under tighter clothes it does work better, but it also gives an unsightly bulge that can be hard to conceal (I actually had a coworker think I had a pacemaker!).The mobile app is okay - I have the iOS version - but there isn't all that much data beyond what a simple pedometer would give you. The posture tracking is a relative thing...you calibrate it when you first put it on, and it vibrates (and counts) when you deviate from the calibrated position. I found that I never really hit the right mix of calibration - it would either never go off, or it seemed to go off constantly.The Lumo also tracks your activity (steps), much as FitBit and others. I happen to have a few of these devices - as well as a few iPhoone apps that monitor steps taken. The Lumo claims to be more accurate, but I'm not sure that's the case...wearing a few different pedometers at the same time, all of them came to different counts, but the results were generally within 1-2%, and it wasn't clear that any one was more accurate than the others. I'd rather just drop something like the FitBit in a pocket and not think about it than use the Lumo's clamp-on device.I'm generally enthusiastic on wearables, but I think the Lumo Lift needs a few more releases before it would be worth a look.

Who wouldn't love the idea of spending a few minutes pulsing a little light on your face, and getting better skin as a result? That's what this product promises, and although I haven't used it long enough yet to know for sure, there do seem to be signs that it's working (barely).The device itself is well made and seems like it will hold up to frequent use. This is a good thing as my chief complaint is how long it takes to use. If you value your time, you might find it more cost efficient to head for the doctors office and be done with it. On the other hand, if you don't mind committing an hour or two per week, the Silk'n might be for you.It needs to be plugged in to work properly. Not a huge inconvenience as the cord is long enough to reach without problem.As for the results, I'd say after a month, there are some very, very subtle changes. I took a few close-up photos before starting...fine wrinkles seem a little more fine, and pores seem maybe a little tighter overall. Very subtle overall, but I'm only a month into it. I intend to give it several more months, and that will help me decide whether it's truly worthwhile or just a scam.

We have this connected to a small Intel NUC device that's been hardened for use in a demanding automotive environment. It gives us a display over an HDMI connection without requiring (say) a tablet that would need Internet access.So far, we're generally happy with it - was fairly straightforward to install, doesn't consume a lot of power and displays images that are clear and crisp enough to be useful, even though the display itself is fairly compact. We seldom use the touch screen feature, but it's a reasonable alternative to a conventional keyboard if your data entry needs are modest.Two missing features we wish we could find:1. A more secure hold-down for the HDMI cable. We're concerned that in a moving vehicle, the cable will eventually work its way loose.2. A built-in way to blank the display when the vehicle is in motion. We programmed this into our app, but it would have been nice for the display to handle this natively.Otherwise, for the price, this does exactly what we expect.

My daughters both have boots similar to these and I always thought that they looked so cute in them so I thought I'de see if I could find some for myself. When I stumbled on them and saw that they were pink I just fell in love with them and ordered them right away. I normally wear a size 7.5 but after reading other peoples reviews I went up to a size 8 and I'm glad that I did since they fit me perfectly. I've had them on for 8 hours straight and they are so comfortable and keep my feet nice and warm.I do like that you can change the look of them too by unsnapping the fold over part and you can wear them as more of an ankle boot and there's enough of the laces to lace them up higher. The slot of the inside is kind of fun to keep things in but I doubt that I will personally use it as I'm not really the type to go anywhere without my purse or a backpack.The sole of these are nice and thick and have a great tread on them so when I'm in the snow and ice I shouldn't slip around as much as I would in tennis shoes. I still need to spray them with a waterproof sealant to protect them but these are beyond cute and I'm just in love with them. Just get a half size bigger than you normally wear and you'll be fine.I hope you find this review helpful.

I love to have the most amount of lights on our house at Christmas time but I always push our electrical outlets to the limit and I'm not too happy with the bills we get in January either so I'm trying to go solar as much as I can this year. These lights will be perfect for the shrubs in our yard and since they are solar, I don't need to worry about plugging them in or turning them off at night either.They came with a partial charge to them so in my photos, they're running off the power that they came with. The one thing I really like and is unlike any other solar lights that I have in our backyard is that they even supply a house mount if you don't want to put the stake in the ground. That means you can put these up higher and even put them on your house if you'd like.The solar panel has not only the on/off switch but also the mode switch so you can choose to a flashing light or constant on. I also like the fact that I won't have that mess of electrical cords in the middle of my yard and worrying about them getting wet and blowing all the lights out. I've been trying to get as much as our outdoor lighting to be all solar and except for Christmas lights, I'm pretty much done in our backyard. These light last about 8 hours after a full charge so the only thing I suggest is look throughout the day what areas get enough sun for the solar panel so you know the best place to put it. You don't want to spend a lot of time placing all 39' of lights only to discover that the solar panel is only getting an hour of sun a day. I'm only mentioning this because I made that mistake once.I'm looking forward to putting these up in a couple of weeks and I highly recommend them. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

I have quite a few diffusers in my home and now that my mother has moved in with us, I wanted one for her room since she suffers from allergies and get's stuffed up pretty easily.I'm going to start with the one negative on this and that's the fact that the instruction guide doesn't say a single thing on how to use it and I didn't even realize that the top piece as shown in their photo was the top piece since it didn't show how to put it together and I thought it was a funnel! lol I had to play with this a bit to figure it all out but the user guide is pretty useless.This has become my favorite of the ones that we have for a couple of reasons. The first is the amount of water it holds since you can  put 1.3 liters of water in it. When you fill it up it can run for over 6 hours on max or 7-8 hours on low until the water runs out. You actually fill up the top part, not the bottom like you do with other diffusers. I did notice that the top got quite a bit of moisture on it but that's because I didn't have the top piece on so now that I ran it again with the top on it didn't happen.For the LED light you just press it and it will go to the color changing mode. If you press it again then it will stay on that color and you can continue to press it to select the color you want to have and then stop there or keep pressing until it goes off. When it changes color it's very slow and suttle but the colors are very pretty and not bright so if you have it in a bedroom then the light is soft enough not to interrupt your sleep. This would even be great in a kids room as a night light too or you can just keep the light off.The dial allows you to select the flow of the vapor so you can go from fine to pretty heavy duty. This has a built in filter of some sort but again, it doesn't say what it is in the instruction guide. I like to put lavender in ours since I love the scent while we sleep. I have allergies as well and dry skin so sleeping with the humidifier on is great for not only my skin but it also helps me breath better at night. This is also so quite that you don't hear a thing and if you turn the light off, you'd never know it was on except for the mist coming out the top.Again, this is my new favorite diffuser so my mom now has the one we had in our room and we have this one. I highly recommend it and it would make a great gift as well. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

I have 3 dogs who all shed to some degree but it's an on going battle with our biggest dog, Buddy,  who will have clumps of fur coming off of him during the shedding seasons. Our furniture is covered with his fur and we have to vacuum every other day because it's everywhere. In the past I've always used our FURminator and taken him to the side of our house as I remove what seems to be the amount of fur that looks like a small dog.So I was really hoping that this would not only make brushing him out easier but I throught the other side would help get the pet hair off of our furniture too instead of using the hand held vac all the time. But I'm afraid it just didn't work. The idea behind this is great to have a dual mitt where you can brush them on one side and then clean up with the other. The mitt has velcro to make it secure around your wrist and inside there are 2 white straps to hold on to.But the problem I had is that neither the red side worked very well on our furniture or on the dogs. I first tried it with our smallest dog, Izzy to see how it would preform on long hair and as you'll see in her photo, there wasn't much hair and I brushed her 10 times. Then I moved on to buddy and I brushed him 3 times with this mitt and then 3 times with the FURminator and you'll see in my photos how much more hair the FURminator got because it can get down to the undercoat. The rubber nubs on this just don't get down to his undercoat where all the fur is so it's just not getting it and is only catching the loose fur that already on top of his fur. The FURminator is also only about a 1/3 of the width of the mitt so in reality, not got much more hair while covering less of his body.Like I said, I really wanted this to work but unfortunately, it's not better than what I'm currently using. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

I've reviewed a few different dash cam's and this has been my favorite so far. To be honest, when I saw the price I wasn't expecting it to be that good so I was pleased to find out that it was so good and came with a 32G memory card as well.This camera is nice and small so if you mount if between your windshield and rear view mirror it won't be as noticable. They also supply you with clips to run the cable to you can run it across your windshield and down along the dash board so the cable is out of view as well. You really don't want people seeing it so they won't break into your car to steal it so they've designed it to be less noticeable.There's a 2.4" window to view the road but you really can't and won't be watching it while you drive. It's more to be able to see during the set up and make sure that you have it aimed properly as the display is both too small and at the wrong angle to see it properly while you drive. They also put the important buttons like the power and menu buttons on the drivers side of the camera so they are easy to reach. What I do like is that the camera will power off when you turn your car off and then power itself on when you turn your car on. That way it won't drain your car battery and the camera on it's own will only hold about 15 mnutes of battery time before it needs to be charge so you will need to use the provided cable and plug it into your cigarette lighter but they do supply a dual charger for you so you can still charge another device while this is working. There is an option to change the on/off feature so that you can choose to have the camera stay on for either 1, 3, 5 or 10 minutes after you turn your car off. There's also an option to turn the auto on/off off but again, not a good idea if you don't want it to drain your car battery. I would only use this feature if you know that you'll be starting your car every day. Another option is instead of plugging this into your cigarette lighter is to use an external power bank. That way the power bank will get used up instead of your car battery.This camera is equipped with a G sensor so if it detects any impact, such as someone hitting your parked car, it will turn itself on and start recording. Keep in mind that it takes a bit to turn itself on so it won't capture the impact itself and if the impact is outside of the view of screen it won't show anything at all. But, if someone pulls into a spot and hits you're front bumper then it will show them afterwards. This can be set for sensitivity levels of low, medium and high. The G sensor also locks any video it's recorded during an impact so you don't have to worry about it being recorded over.The audio can be turned on or off so if you don't mind that the world will hear you singing along to the radio then it's a good idea to keep that on as well to pick up any sounds.The G sensor is different from the Parking Monitor Mode as that detects vibration instead of an impact. There's also motion detection so the camera only records if there's movement. This means the camera will not record if you're sitting in traffic and not moving for 10 minutes but once you start moving, then it starts again or if there's any motion happening in front of the camera. There is an emergency button on the camera that looks like a Yield sign and if you press that, it will lock the video so again, it can't be recorded over. You can also take a still photo at any time by pressing the Mode button.You can playback the video on the camera itself and you can also us the USB cable to move and store the video and photos over to your computer if you don't have a card reader. That way you have the files saved if you need them or want to watch them on a larger screen.When you turn your car on and it starts recording, it only records small clips at a time and you choose if it's 1, 3, 5 or 10 minutes. That way your not trying to go look through 2 hours of video to find what your looking for but the video can all be viewed together for a seemless look.There isn't a "nighttime" recording mode and if it had it, it wouldn't even work as IR lights don't work that good for distance and your headlights will shine enough light to view the road as is. Any IR lights would just reflect off the windshield and you wouldn't see the road if they had them so don't worry about not seeing that as a feature.What I really appreciate is that they include the memory card and you can go up to a 32G card if you'd like as long as it's a class 6 or higher card. The mounting backet is very sturdy and the suction cup stays in place without falling off or moving.I'm very impressed with this camera and all that they packed into it so I highly recommend it. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

I have reviewed a lot of different speakers and sound quality is always the most important factor to me and I have to say, this one sounds really good. This came with a bit of a charge to it so I was able to pair it and listen for a few minutes before I had to give it a full charge.This does have a few nice additional features such as the color changing lights that you change by tapping the top of the mushroom. The lights shine down from underneath the mushroom and you can choose to stay on one color or cycle through it and have it change colors and you can have it set to the beat of the music.There is not an instruction guide to this so it did take a lot of playing around with it to figure it all out. Along the bottom of the speaker there is a sliding button that you use to both change the volume or play the previous or next song. You either quickly slide the button to play the previous/next song and hold it for the volume. The next port is the AUX/headset port, then there's the on/off switch and the charging port. They do supply the micro USB charger for you. Next is an USB port so you can charge other devices from this, the mircophone and then there's a slot for a memory card so you can insert that and play music off the card.The lights cycle between 7 colors which again, you change by tapping the top. If you keep your hand on the top, you can adjust how bright it is. It will also speak to you so you know when its in bluetooth mode or connected. There are only 2 negatives that I can say about it and that is the lack of the user manual and that for some reason it freaks my dog out and she's scared of it to the point that she runs and hides when I get it out. That's not such a big deal as I'm sure she'll get over it and I just thought it was weird and I wonder if it makes one of those sounds that only dogs can hear. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

I have been converting over to all LED bulbs in our home as well as all rechargable batteries so this flashlight also allows me to do both of those. This is a heavy duty son of a gun that can take a lot of abuse and compared to my old plastic flashlights, you know that this one will last forever and can pretty much take on any enviornments.The LED bulb has a life span of 100,000 hours so even if you ran it for 24 hours a day, this means it would last for over 4 years before the bulb would go out. I'm guessing this flashlight will outlast me so perhaps I should put it in my will. lolIt comes with 1 batteries, the charger for it, a spare insert to use 3 AAA batteries if needed and a plastic diffuser for the end. This allows you to not only dim the light but also provide an overall "glow" type of light so instead of needing to have the flashlight shine at something, it makes if more like a lamp where the light is within the plastic cap instead. The power button on the end also can be lightly pressed to change how bright the light is so press it once and it's at it's brightest but if you keep tapping it, it gets dimmer and dimmer plus there's a strobe and then will also do an S.O.S. signal so there's a total of 5 levels. There's also a removable strap at the end so you can wear it on your wrist or hang it up.The end of the flashlight expands so you can zoom the light to a closer or further distance and either condense the light or widen it. You'll see how it looks in my photos and I was aiming it about 20" from the wall in all my shots.
