With the plastic cap on I show it with the light at different levels of brightness.The charger will only charge one battery at a time but they send the battery to you already charged which is great. This uses 18650 batteries so they are much bigger than the standare AA battery and do require this type of charging base so I appreciate that they include that. Actually for the price of this whole set it's hard to even find a battery and the charger for that price so this is a great deal. It does take a little over 5 hours to charge the battery and the charger will turn from red to green to let you know that it's fully charged.I highly recommend this flashlight set to anyone and it would also make a great gift. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

Actually for the price of this whole set it's hard to even find 2 batteries and the charger for that price so this is a great deal. It does take a little over 5 hours to charge the battery and the charger will turn from red to green to let you know that it's fully charged.I highly recommend this flashlight set to anyone and it would also make a great gift. I'm a purse-a-holic so I love to have them in different shapes, colors, sizes and style depending on what I'm doing and wearing. This is my 2nd bottle of Mask Spray which is great since we have 2 bathrooms. I was very sceptical when I got the first bottle but it definately made me a believer after I used it the first time so having this new scent is awesome.This is so easy to use, you simply spray it about 5-6 pumps so that you have enough to make a film on top of the water in the toilet bowl. Then you simply do your business and the smell is then trapped under the layer of the Mask. The only scent you smell is the Mask scent (which is amazing!!) and when you flush, you'd never ever know that anyone had even pooped. Both my husband and I got a stomach flu a couple of weeks ago and this was a life saver for us to keep all the horrible smells away.This is one of those products that you just have to try for yourself to see what I mean. Since we got this there hasn't even been a hint of a poop smell and the bathroom is safe for the next person to go right in. I have a note in our guest bathroom next to the bottle that says "When you gotta go, you gotta go but spray this first, and no one will ever know". At first it was a joke for our friends and family members but now we've had several of them end up getting it as well after trying it. If you entertain a lot like we do, this is a must in your home.The scent is hard to describe but it's really a fresh smell. I highly recommend this to anyone and it would make a great stocking stuffer too. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.
8:17 Mins

This is my 2nd SportShot  camera and once again, they have impressed me with the quality of camera and all the features they include. I also have a GoPro Hero and I honestly prefer the SportShot cameras over my GoPro.The main reason why I prefer them is simply the cost. If I damage or lose my GoPro there's hundreds of dollars down the drain for basically the same camera. Therefore, I'm way more nervous to use my GoPro and so there it sits, in it's case. I have no worries about the using my SportShot and for me and the conditions that I use it in, this is perfect. I love to snorkel when we go on trips so that will be my main reason for using it but I've taken this on bike rides (it's amazing what you see when you watch the video later) and my husband has worn it when he plays racquetball to try and improve his performance. I also have a harness for our dog which I like to use with her when we go on walks just for fun. When you get down on their level you see why your dog wants to stop and check things out more often as well.When I reviewed my other SportShot I compared the features between it and my GoPro and I feel that it's worth sharing again with you so here that is:1080p camera -............................. SportShot - Yes......GoPro - Yes12MP camera -.............................. SportShot - Yes......GoPro - NO, it's only 8MPWifi - ...............................................SportShot - Yes ....GoPro - YesWaterproof Housing - .....................SportShot - Yes.....GoPro - Yes170 viewing angle...........................SportShot - Yes.....GoPro - YesComes with 20 accessories - .........SportShot - Yes.....GoPro - NORecharable/replaceable battery - ...SportShot - Yes.....GoPro - YesCan connect to app - ......................SportShot - Yes.....GoPro - YesBurst Shots - ...................................SportShot - Yes.....GoPro - YesLoop recording - ..............................SportShot - Yes.....GoPro - YesTouch screen - ................................SportShot - No.......GoPro - YesUnder $75 - .....................................SportShot - Yes.....GoPro - No, It's currently $280Obviously the quality of the photos and videos is the biggest thing you'd want out of this and the SportShot wins that handsdown with their 12MP 1080p camera. The GoPro is only 8MP so you don't get the same level of detail with it. Yes, the color of the photos is the same but the SportShot is a much clearer and cleaner looking image. As you'll see in my photos the picture quaility is just amazing.The ease of use with the SportShot is another big plus with me. You only need to deal with 3 buttons and one of those is the wifi connection so you don't even use that one that much. The front and top buttons are a combination of the power, feature, scrolling and photo/video start and stop so it's so easy to learn.They also start you out with a nice selection of accessories where as my GoPro didn't. Yes, the accessories aren't all that much but at least the SportShot gives you enough to actually use it right out of the box while a GoPro will require that you go shopping first. Now neither one comes with a memory card so you will want to have that ready when you purchase this as well. The other item I purchased were additional batteries since they are so easy to change out with the SportShot. The camera come out of the housing very easily and on the bottom is the battery compartment. You want to keep the plastic tab on the battery since that's what allows you to pull it out but if you keep a couple of extra batteries charged then you don't have to wait to charge your SportShot and can just put a new battery in. I also keep a spare power bank in my case just incase I need to also charge the SportShot I can do it on the run.I highly recommend this camera to anyone and with the holidays arriving, this would make a great gift too. Why buy 1 GoPro for one person when you can buy 4 of these and give them to 4 people? (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

Unlike most people who are purchasing this for a baby monitor, I have this because my mother now lives with us. She has Alzheimer's and has fallen twice this year breaking each hip so I really need to be able to keep an eye on her when I can't be in the room with her. For the most part she's in the family room so that's where I set up the camera.I like that this was truely a plug and play system. The camera is already paired to the receiver when you take it out of the box so the only time you would need to deal with the pairing is if you choose to add a 2nd camera or if you have to reset it for any reason. From the receiver you can both speak as well as listen to the camera and adjust the volume plus you can adjust the screen brighteness which is nice because depending on the amount of light coming in the room it may need to be adjusted.Then you can also move the camera to look all around the room both side to side as well as up and down. I can't say that the picture quality is as clear as an IP camera but for a remote device you can definately see what's going on. The receiver does need to be charged every few days depending on how much you have it on but they supply a charger for that. There's also a hook on the top so if you want to clip the receiver to anything you can do that. There's a kickstand on it too so you can either lay it down flat or have it upright.The range of motion on the camera is great because you really can scan the whole room remotely. And since there's no need to pair the camera and receiver it's very easy to unplug the camera and move it to another room anytime you need to as it all goes back online as soon as you plug it in.This really gives me peace of mind when I have to go and shower to anything else that takes me out of the room that my mom is in. She is supposed to use her walker but when I'm out of the room she seems to think she can get away with not using it so when I catch her without it I can go get her and the walker back together. She has never figured out what the camera is andhas no idea that I keep an eye on her. She just seems to think I'm really smart and know when she's doing something she isn't supposed to be doing. I remember her telling me as a child that she had eyes in the back of her head but little does she know, I have eyes in the room with her with this Foscam camera.I highly recommend this to anyone that needs to watch a child, pet, parent or anything else when you're at home but not in the room. Just know that this is not a wifi system so you can't take the receiver with you. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

I write a lot of reviews on Amazon and I always post photos for them. I'm in no way shape a professional photographer or even close to it but I wanted to be able to take better looking photos instead of doing them on my dining room table. I had another smaller box and that just wasn't big enough for some of the things I need to take pictures of so when I saw this one I thought it would work.Now there are a lot more things that I like about this compared to what I don't like so I'll start with the pro's:- 24 x 24 gives me more room- the optional cover over the front has a slit in it if I want to remove the natural light of the room. This is great when I want to have lower light and just rely on my 2 lamps.- It's very sturdy and easy to fold up when not in useCon's:- the curved bottom doesn't allow me to place light weight items towards the back or sides of the box. They just won't sit flat because of that.- the colored backgrounds don't attach very well and stay in place. It seems like I'm always trying to adjust and fix them compared to my old one.- the backgrounds are also easy to spot in my photos as they don't quite fit to the top and sides so I'm have to crop a lot more of my photos to try and get them out of the shot.- one of the velcro strips wan't sewn down properly so I can't use that spot until I sew it down.I'm not sure if this will be the right desktop kit for me and I just may need to have a square one instead of a rounded one since I need to take advantege of every square inch inside of it. That and the poor quality of construction that I shouldn't have to mess with. I can't say that I can recommend it for those reasons.I hope you find this review helpful.

I love to wear over sized shirts during the fall and winter and pair a long shirt like this with leggings and boots and then add a scarf around my neck. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

Both my husband and I like to collect watches and I've had to rely on my father in law to help me with sizing my watch bands so I wanted to get a good set to be able to do it myself.While this kit has a lot of tools in it, there's no instructions telling you what any of them do so  spent some time looking them up so I'd know not only what each one does but thought I'd share that information just incase you don't know too. This really has way more items than I think I'll ever use but for the price, I thought it was a great deal and I now have the carrying case as well. Every tool is great quaity and very durable and this kit should last me for many years.I hope you find this review helpful.

We entertain at our house a lot and I always decorate our table when we have people over, even if it's just to watch football. I don't know why I didn't buy these for my mom's walker instead of buying tennis ball after tennis ball and having them wear out in a month on the bottom. This walllet has had a lot of thought go into the details. This may be a bit hard to describe how this wallet works but I'll do my best. At first glance it looks like any other wallet and even when you open it the first time it still looks like a normal wallet with one plastic window slot for your ID and then 3 slots on the other side for credit/debit cards. In the center you'll see a zipper that actually goes on both sides so you can tuck all kinds of change in there. Your bills go in the top but they've added a divider in there so you can seperate them out and have bills or reciepts in there. Then there's a snap on the left side you'll see a flap with a snap on the top that if you open that, there is another flap that has 2 more plastic ID slots and on the other side are 6 more slots for credit/debit cards. That's a total of 9 regular slots and 3 clear plastic slots so you can see through them.This wallet looks so unassuming at first but then you see how much you can really fit in it and what's hidden away and out of view then this is a great wallet. No one would guess that you have all those other cards tucked away so if a theif was checking out your wallet, from first glance they'd never know what all you have in it unless you open it all the way and they see that.I highly recommend this wallet and it would make a wonderful gift. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

I find using backpacks great when I'm either out shopping and want to have my hands free and not worry about a purse or for when we travel. I like that this one is not a stiff backpack so it fits into my suitcase very easily and doesn't take up as much space.The canvas is very durable and the bag is very well made. The leather is very soft and the snap that keeps the flap in place is very unique and unlike any snaps I've seen before. The bag closes on top with a drawstring and there is one main zippered pocket on the front of the bag as well as 2 on the sides. Inside is another zippered pocket as well as a pouch and there's also a handle on top to carry it by. 5:54 Mins Wow, has technology ever come a long way! When the seller asked me to review this and share my honest and unbiased review I was prepared to say that there's no way that it would work. But much to my surprise, they prove me wrong.This is a handheld thermometer that allows you to get a temperature by not even touching the person. You simply hold it 1.2 - 2.0 inches from the surface of the sking and press the button and in one second, you have the reading not only on the large, backlit display but if you have the voice turned on, it will also say it.You can read not only the body temperature but also a surface and air temperature as well. I wish I had this 20 years ago when my kids were little and you'd go in at midnight to take their temerature. I'd have to turn the light on, shake the thermometer (they didn't have digital ones yet) and then place it under their tongue or arm pit. Of course that would wake them up and I'd have to get them back to sleep when their feeling yucky. Now, all you'd need to do is sneak in with a flashlight of the hall light on, make sure the voice it turned off (you don't want to wake them), be within range and press the button. You'll see in the display right away what the temperature is and let them get their rest.It also has a memory so it will display on the screen the last 32 temperatures that have been taken so if you can't remember what it was at 3am when the doctor asks you, you can now give it to them. This runs off of 2 AA batteries which they provide and there's not even an on/off switch since it powers on when you press a button and turns itself off. You can choose between celsius and fahrenheit for the reading and with the voice on, it will read it aloud to you.The device also has a very comfortable grip on it as they've molded the finger grips into the handle and all the buttons can be accessed with your thumb. There is an instruction booklet but this is so easy to use that you don't even need it. I also really like the storage case as it's not only easy to open and close but it's made of a thick plastic for durability and and the inside is molded to the shape of the thermometer.This is not only a must have for all households but would make a wonderful baby shower gift or just a great Christmas gift too with the holidays approaching. I highly recommend this to anyone and again, where was this 20 years ago??I will apologize that I typed the name wrong in my video so please make sure that you get the AccuMed, not AcuMed thermometer!I hope you find this review helpful.

3:54 Mins I have reviewed a lot of bluetooth of all sizes and ones that light up and some that are even built into lightbulbs. I highly recommend this and for the price you really can't pass this up. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

I love using solar lights in our yard since we have a lack of electrical outlets and a lot of yard to light up. Last summer I started a memorial garden for my grandson so when the seller asked me to try this out in exchange of my honest review, I knew that I had the perfect spot for them.The first thing that struck me when I took them out of the box was that they were already partially charged so in my photos, I was able to show off the light without having to even put them in the sun. Now they say that there are 7 different colors but there really are more since there are many shades of each color as they go from soft to bright and then start to transition into the next color. 'The plasic used on these is very durable and no worries about them breaking. If you are installing them in hard dirt you may want to loosen up that dirt a bit first since the plasic part that goes into the ground is pretty wide. The top does come off when you need to change the rechargable batteries but that's the only maintainance that you'll have to do on them. Since the lights are LED they say that they'll last for 100,000 so if we average 10 hours  a night that means the bulbs will last for over 27 years! That means I can pass these lights onto my great grandkids..*sigh*And speaking of grandkids, kids will love these as well. The bright, vivid colors are just fun to watch and anyone who has a fairy garden will find these perfect as well to have.I hope you find this review helpful.

The world looks wonderful when I'm with you. What a great way to symbolize your love for someone then when both of you wear these words around your neck along with "eternal love". I'm so proud of  my husband and the success he has had with his weight loss but that has left his wedding ring way too big for him and now he can't wear it. Since it was made of a hammered gold we couldn't even get it resized so finding a ring he would like and feel comfortable in was a bit of a challange and he's pretty picky. He didn't want anything expensive but he wanted something.So when the seller asked me to try this out in exchange of my honest review, I asked if he felt this was a ring that he would like and he really liked it in the photos but wanted to see it in person to decide for sure.Since we're going to renew our vows in March for our anniversary, we also got the women's rings so I could have one that would match when we do that.I have to say, the photos just don't do these rings justice. They are elegant and simple and since they both have the words "real" and "love along with the swirl of either black (the mens ring) or gold (womens) on them, they match without being an exact match.The one thing we both like is how the rings don't cut into our skin since the band is rounded a bit and they are very comfortable. My husband is really enjoying his ring and I look forward to wearing mind in March when we say our "I do's" again. You would never know by the look of these rings that they didn't cost a whole lot more than they do.I hope you find this review helpful.

I have been using another lip exfoliator for almost a year now which is actually the one by E.L.F. and I have been very happy with that. So when the seller asked me to try this out in exchange of my honest review, I was anixous to try it out.I knew from using E.L.F. that you have to use it a few times to get that top layer of balm off and then get to the "scrubbing" part so I used it a few time throughout the day and it did leave my lips soft but I still didn't feel any thing that was exfoliating yet. The next day I used it twice and still the same so I decided to scrub it against the back of my hand for a bit to see if I could help it along and finally I was able to start to feel a slight roughness to it.Now the E.L.F. one is very corse and has large chunks that take the layer of dead skin off fairly quickly without hurting and it also left a sugary taste behind. Prior to using E.L.F. I made my own by taking sugar and mixing it with coconut oil which also worked really well but I just hate sticking my finger into pots to apply products which is why I made the change.I can't tell if it's because my lips were so use to a rougher product or if I just got a bad tube or if that's just the way it is but as much as I used it over a 5 day period of time, I never felt like my lips were doing anything other than apply the balm part of it. Sure, my lips were soft but the dry part that always happens was building up and I just had to go back to my E.L.F. and once I did that, the dead dry skin came right off.There is quite a bit of product in the tube and it is much thinner than what I'm used to. You will find that little pieces will come off but the E.L.F. does that too.To me, the Alexis Vogel seemed waxy and didn't leave any flavor behind. I just can't tell if it's because my lips were so used to another brand that I just had a hard time geting much out of it but I have a strong feeling that was the problem. If you've never used a lip exfoliator before or have had a different experience then I would totally understand why you ma have had more sucess than I did as I'm very aware that with cosmetics and any skin/lip care what works for one person may not work for another and vice versa.I hope you find this review helpful.

I had been looking for the perfect cross since I lost my favorite one a few years ago but none of the ones I've looked  at seemed very unique to me until now. I originally got these thinking that  they would be perfect for all of my sunglasses but then when my husband saw them he reminded me that between our kids and spouses, there are 7 of them so they would make great stocking stuffers and that we could also put goodies inside of them too. Well that's fine but now I need to order another set for my sunglasses! Since the seller offered these to me at no charge to try out in exchange for my honest review, I'll tell you my thoughts on them.For starters, you get 7 cases at just over $2 a case which that alone if amazing but what's even better, these are really awesome cases. I have 5 other cases that I use (not including the ones that came with my Oakley's and Michael Kor's glasses) and I had thought that they were all great cases but these are really so much better.For starters, the hard case is covered with what feels like neoprene and they're molded to hold the bridge of the glasses in place. Each case has a bright colored zipper, except for the black which is, well, just black. The zippers are all great quality and they each have the hook on them so you can clip them on to something if you'd like. I tend to use those a lot because when we travel I use a smaller purse and like to clip my sunglass case onto my purse. The inside of them is the same as the outside so they are well protected from any scratching or getting broken if dropped.So when I get MY set of them I like that I can use one color for each pair so that way I'll know what glasses are inside and just be able to grab them without opening the case to find the pair I want. I highly recommend these cases and perhaps you too will want to order 2 sets so you can give them as Christmas gifts too.I hope you find this review helpful.

There are a lot of GoPro accessorie kits out there so how do you decide which one to get? Well, what stood out the most to me with this kit was the size of the case. I have a few cases already but they're all to small to hold anything more than the camera and perhaps a few of the  accessories. This one hold A LOT of accessories and speaking of accessories, this one actually has something other than half of them be clips or mounts or 2 sided sticky pads. Most of the other kits I've reviewed have more than I'll ever need so to me it's a waste. Instead they added cool things like the tripod or the floating wrist strap or even the cleaning kit. I've never had any of those accessories before and they actually come in quite handy.These are all well made and on the chest harness, the buckle is very durable and easy to click in and out. Even the helmet mount has rubberized texture on the under side to keep it from sliding so it's the little things like that that show the attention to details. I was on the fence about the foam insert since you could customize it and for me, it just depends on what I want to have in there at any given time so I ended up leaving a space for my GoPro and then took all but the frame surrounding it out so I could put anything in there. Sure, they don't have a "place" to go but since the case is nice and ridged and the foam keeps anything from getting beat up that's ok with me and I keep alot of the things in their plastic bags anyways.This kit has by far won me over and is now my favorite. I highly recommend this to anyone, especially if you're just starting out with accessories. (Sample provided for my honest and unbiased review).I hope you find this review helpful.

These gloves at the same time are thick enough to prevent getting burned (certainly the most important thing about them) but also cumbersome and very stiff, so much so that I find myself using other mitts and potholders. They certainly fit my rather large hands comfortably, however. I see from the other many glowing reviews that I am in the minority. For whatever it is worth, my cat, who shuns any bought toy as much as his carrier, simply loves them. It appears to be the knobby texture that he cannot resist.I received a pair of gloves for a review.

The scale is sleek, attractive, light weight, and more importantly, appears to weigh quickly and accurately. The four AAA batteries were included and easy to install. The scale must be placed on a solid level floor to get an accurate reading. According to the information included with the scale, there is a two year warranty and the scale will weigh up to 330 pounds.I give this scale five stars with caution. I received another scale from the same company about  a year ago. (I see that I reviewed it on June 14, 2014.)  When I recently installed new batteries when needed, I have been unable to make the scale work. There is a remote possibility I suppose that the brand new batteries are defective; however, I have my doubts.At least this scale has one obvious advantage: it does not use the two round, flat batteries that are more difficult to find than the ones provided with this one.This scale was provided free to me for a review.

Format: PaperbackWritten in 1913-1914 E. M. Forster's MAURICE, at his direction, was not published until after his death in 1970 although in the "terminal note" at the end of the novel he says that he changed little of the story over the years. Unless you were a gay man living in 1971 and had been bombarded all your life with how awful homosexuality was, a crime, a sin and a mental illness, you cannot imagine the joy that reading this novel brought since the only person who dies in this novel is Maurice's grandfather. Of course Maurice is beset with self-loathing, fears, depression and loneliness as Edwardian society expected young men who went to Cambridge to marry and repopulate the earth. For instance, when Maurice attempts to discuss his inspeakable problem "of the Oscar Wilde sort," with a family friend Dr. Barry, the physician responded: "'Rubbish, rubbish!'" He further said that the worst thing he could do for Maurice was "discuss it." Maurice is able to rise above or work his way around this non-diagnosis, as well as a trip to a hypnotist to be cured, and have a life with another man.Some critics say that MAURICE is significant only in a historical context. Let them tell that to the gay teenager who finds this novel in his high school library and reads the beautiful ending, much more possible now than when Forster wrote it particularly if that teenager lives in Ireland or the U. S., after the events that have taken places in these two countries in the past few days.  This novel has universal appeal in that Clive, Maurice's first love, takes the easy way out by marrying and having a respectable career (we all know a couple of Clive's), and Maurice, for all his snobbery, grows to understand that love between men can cross class lines. (Forster's biographers note that he had a lover in 1919 who was an Egyptian tram conducter and fell in love with a London policeman in 1930.)In his fine memoir MISSISSIPPI SISSY Kevin Sessums recalls a conversation with the writer Eudora Welty who made him promise to read Forster's PASSAGE TO INDIA: "'MAURICE is not first-rate Forster, even though I understand the reasons why it would be the only work of his you've read.'" Being in the same boat with Sessums, I cannot disagree or agree with Ms. Welty. I can only say that this is a fine novel indeed. Forster, himself, said in ASPECTS OF THE NOVEL: "The final test for a novel will be our affection for it, as it is the test of friends and of anything else which we cannot define."By Forster's own definition, he has written a great novel. Even in the wake of the U. S. Supreme Court's recent ruling on same-sex marriage, this novel remains a treasure.

Format: PaperbackI found Holding the Man in a little bookshop in Melbourne several years ago. I had read many "AIDS" memoirs-- including Paul Monette's Borrowed Time: An AIDS Memoir and the very fine Heaven's Coast" A Memoir by Mark Doty and thought there was nothing else to be said on the subject. I was wrong. I cannot say enough good things about this book. It is so well written. In addition to being a poignant account of a beautiful love affair and sad, sad, death in the time of AIDS, it is a quite wonderful account of what it is like to be a gay teen as well. When I finished the book-- and yes, it will make you cry-- I felt an overwhelming sadness that this young man will never write again and that both these young men's lives were snuffed out at such an early age. And I wanted to see John's beautiful eyelashes.This is one of those books that, upon finishing, you call up everyone you love and ask him/her to read it although you are afraid to lend your copy in case you don't get it back.

This is one of those novels that gets off to a great start but then gets a little wobbly at times, at least for me. It all has to do with the land of make believe that the soon-to-be-eight heroine Elsa wanders in and out of. Im willing to admit that the fault lies within me and not the author, however, since fantasy stories are not my favorite form of reading. That being said, the book does have its charm. The most cynical of us cannot argue with the Land-of-Almost-Awake where magical things happen, where, for instance, if you ever get separated from your grandmother or she gets lost, she will send a lion to tell you where she is.More about the relationship between Elsa and her whacky grandmother.  They are best, best friends. (Grandmothers to a person are always special in and out of literature and Grannie is no exception.)  This one, while in the hospital for cancer takes off all her clothes when she sits on the toilet and leaves the bathroom door open, throws turds at a policeman, rolls her own cigarettes and is described by one of her physicians as someone who could start a fight in an empty room. We do learn, as we get into the story, that she has her own set of minuses and that is where the title comes from: MY GRANDMOTHER ASKED ME TO TELL YOU SHES SORRY. Elsa in her own way is just as interesting as Grannie: precocious for seven, she uses Wikipedia, loves everything associated with Harry Potter, and writes political letters to Santa.I particularly like the aphorisms that Grannie strews along the path of her beloved granddaughter.  When Elsa says she is different, Grannies reply: Only different people change the world.  And being special is the best way of being different. Dont kick the st, itll go all over the place (one of my favorites). Grannie reminds Elsa that every child of a divorce can be eccentric.  And finally when Elsa asks hard questions about why people die and after Grannie is unsuccessful in trying to distract her with ice cream and changing the subject, she tells her that something always had to give up its own space so that something else could take its place. When I asked my own precious mother a similar question when I was four or five, she in a manner that still amazes me so many years later explained that we all get frail and sick and broken and we would all be miserable if we could not die.In one of the most touching scenes (for me) Elsa asks her father if he plans to have more children with his second wife Lisette. (Elsas mom is very pregnant throughout most of this novel with a second child by her second husband.) He responds that he has all the children he and Lisette need. Elsa asks the obvious question: is it because of her and because she is different. He whispers: Because you turned out to be perfect.A word about the assorted motley characters who live in Elsas apartment: the author finally pulls them all together in his little story that ultimately makes profound statements and childhood, parents, grandparents, love, death, mothers and daughters, children of divorce, and being different.  Quite an accomplishment to finally make sense of it all.

I am a big fan of granola bars and have bought and eaten many different kinds. I can say with no reservations that I have never tasted one better. The nuts and chocolate chips are nestled on a slab of dark chocolate. Then there is just that whiff of cayenne pepper to add to this assortment of tasty delights.A word about some of the nutrition facts: for each bar, 160 calories; total fat, 7 grams; trans fat, zero grams; no cholesterol; 150 milligrams of sodium; 21 grams of carbs.Highly recommended.

The product hype pretty much gets it right about this paper. It's lighter and therefore easier to store and you get more sheets in a ream. And I quote from the wrapper: "Suitable for printing everyday internal documents, drafts and copies." That about says it all. You would not want to use this paper to send out important documents, however, where you were interested in impressing the recipient. It is just too thin. I would never use this paper, for instance, to print out a resume. The paper cannot be used for printing on both sides as the ink bleeds through as well.

I owe Grady Harp big time for recommending BLIND TRIANGLE to me.  I would have missed the three hours or so I spent with these three characters who make up the doomed love triangle: Ray Styles, a genius with red hair that he wears in an Elvis pompadour to distinguish himself from the hippy culture of 1967; Tom Laurel, a beautiful young artist two years younger than Ray; and Soledad Paz, a black-haired prostitute but oh so much more than that (she only sleeps with wealthy women).  Mr. Deveny has created three completely empathetic characters who consumed me totally in the time it took me to finish this short novel of a little over 200 pages.As always, one fine novel reminds you of another.  I immediately thought of what Toni Morrison says in her latest novel GOD HELP THE CHILD about the harm that parents inflict on their children as these star-crossed characters are saddled with the sins of their parents, each in his or her own way. The novels of Tom Spanbauer also came to mind, particularly his latest I LOVED YOU MORE, another fantastic book about another triangle.As you read this novel, you know that these characters will not live happily ever after. The sense of danger and tragedy is everywhere although you hope again hope that all will be well with these three characters who find themselves in an impossible situation. Since anyone who reads the book blurb knows, at the center of this novel is Tommy's love for Ray. (Perhaps he would have fared better if the novel had been set in the present; but that would have been another story.) He is in a word obsessed with Ray.Mr. Deveny in beautifully-written prose shows tremendous insight into human beings with all their frailties as he speaks so eloquently about love, loss, longing, and sadness. Here is Tommy after he experiences Ray having a petit mal seizure: "We both smiled, but from that moment on he was made of glass. That's the problem with loving people. Once they become precious to you, they're no longer just flesh and blood."  And Tom on what he has gained from Ray: "My father had started out life with no family and remained lost, trying hopelessly to free himself in the only ways known to the abandoned. My mother, for all her precious affection for me, could only present to him a love more dangerous than his own desperation. The two of them were crushed in an embrace from which nothing could survive. All of this understanding had come from Ray. Without his love I would have never seen my mother and father like this." And one more out of so many. Here is Soledad in a conversation with Tom about Ray: "'He made me laugh so that I forgot I was ever sad,' she said. `That as good. But also he knows sadness. I feel it in his body. That is better. Even though he is rich he knows sadness. That makes him wonderful.'"BLIND TRIANGLE is Mr. Deveny's debut novel. We can only hope that there are many more to follow.

In HOW I SHED MY SKIN Jim Grimsley gives a brutally honest and sensitive account of growing up dirt poor in Eastern North Carolina, being eleven and  in the sixth grade when his elementary school became integrated in that state in 1966  and confronting his own bigotry. On the first day of class or shortly thereafter, he approached one of the three young Afro-American girls as they were back then called with the greeting: "'You black bitch.'" Violet, the new student--Mr. Grimsley says he has used pseudonyms for any name that was not used in a media account--gave as good or better as she got: She quickly responded with  "'You white cracker bitch.'" In the words of Mr. Grimsley:  "I sat dumbfounded. There had been no likelihood, in my fantasy, that she could speak back." He describes himself as a "good little racist."Mr. Grimsley is so spot on in what he says about the South and in particular white Southerners: "The Southern dream of place is choked with longing. For the white Southerner, the past was a better time than the present, even though it was tragic and painful." And while no one ever said to him exactly as Mr. Grimsley states, he was raised to believe in the United States as a white nation, the South "as a white paradise, and in the superiority of my European-descended race over all the other races of the earth."Combining this honesty with fine writing makes for a fantastic memoir, as good as any I can remember reading.  His story resonates with me so much because I grew up in similar circumstances, that is, gay and very poor-- although my father was neither an alcoholic or wife abuser--  in a small town in East Tennessee a few years ahead of Mr.  Grimsley in North Carolina. I still shudder when I remember my dad sending my twin brother--we must have been six or seven--into a country store to ask for a bag of "N----r Toes candy because he thought that would be a good joke to play on a black customer, as I recall, a kind and gentle man whom we knew as someone who lived not that far from us.The good news is that Mr.  Grimsley confronted his own racism and obviously has worked hard to eradicate it, as much as we white Southerners ever can since we learned racism--sadly--at our mothers' and grandmothers' knees. Something that helped him overcome his racism was figuring out early on that he too like the Afro-American students was different but in another way besides skin color since he was attracted to other boys. Would that that were the case with a lot of other Caucasians in the gay community. Members of the African American gay community in Atlanta, for instance, even in 2015 have their own gay pride events, a sad commentary on the racism that still exists among many white gay men. And since Mr.  Grimsley was in an integrated school, other students were confronting and dealing with the two races sharing the same school and paying less attention to the fact that he was gay.Mr. Grimsley closes this simply wonderful book with a chapter entitled "Reunion" and tells of going to his high school forty-year class reunion in 2013. Among the usual events, he attends a memorial service at a church for classmates who have died. He and a woman friend are the only white people in attendance.  "At first I am aware of the absence of so many others; then, after a few minutes, I am simply in the room with people who mattered to me very much, whether I understood it then or not, once upon a time."HOW I SHED MY SKIN just may be the best thing I've read by this writer and I have read practically all of his fiction. Besides being a first-class writer, he is obviously a good human being as well. That face is evident  on every page.

This sale is accurate, easy to read and small enough to store easily. The bowl holds up to 2 liters, certainly large enough for my baking needs. It comes ready to use with two AA batteries already installed. And most importantly it is a lot less expensive than the one I already own.I was sent a scale for a review.

I would second everything the other three reviewers have said about these socks. They are just terrific. They fit ever so snugly, absorb moisture and are very comfortable.  It is almost as if you are not wearing them. Obviously all socks are not the same. They are not inexpensive, but you get what you pay for.I received a pair for a review.

One reviewer described Tom Spanbauer's latest novel I LOVED YOU MORE as having "messy beauty." I'm not sure I can say it better. I have read and liked immensely three of his previous four novels. I never got into IN THE CITY OF SHY HUNTERS and suspect it probably was me and not the book. John Irving has a wonderful quotation in one of his novels about how the state of mind we are in plays a tremendous part in how we react to fiction at any given time so I'm willing to give that novel another try since everyone else I know who read it was much taken with it.I LOVED YOU MORE surely is Mr. Spanbauer's most ambitious novel to date. It is long and sprawling at 464 pages and covers many years in the lives of the three main characters: the narrator Ben Grunewald, his friends Hank Christian and Ruth Dearden. (I am well aware that good fiction does not have to be autobiographical although I believe Salman Rushdie has said that all fiction is but that it doesn't matter.) I so wanted this one to be a page from the author's life. Surely there are elements of Mr. Spanbauer's own experience in the narrator since just as the author is, Ben is gay, grows up in Pocatello, Idaho, studies writing in New York, works as both a waiter and super in apartment buildings while a student there, is diagnosed with AIDS and moves to Portland, Oregon and teaches writing. Of course Hank and Ruth could be figments of Mr. Spanbauer's fertile imagination, but I really wanted them to be people in his own life, particularly Hank. At one point in this sometimes painful novel, Ruth says in the presence of both Ben and Hank that she and Ben are both in love with Hank. But aren't we all in love with Hank, straight Hank, the man whose eyes the narrator describes over and over that should have been blue but are dark, almost black, who many years into their friendship tells Ben, "'You're the one who's in my heart'"?Mr. Spanbauer is a master is creating characters who literally walk out of the novel into your living room and, if you are not careful, into your heart. You know dozens of things about them that he tells you over and over: how they look (I can see Ruth`s mane of red hair), how they smell (Ben`s wet feet), how they walk. And he is just as good at fleshing out characters whom we see for only a few pages. I'm thinking now of Andy Gronik, another wounded soul, just one example among many. The plot of the novel is certainly not linear. Mr. Spanbauer tells us early on how this story is going to end and then reminds us again and again. (The only other writer I can think of who does this so well is Toni Morrison.) And he throws everything into this novel-- love, AIDS, homophobia, guilt, sex, friendship, relationships, loneliness (those awful passages about the loneliness of the narrator's mother and sister), anger, racism, grief, illness, death, regrets (Ben never told Hank he loved him)-- and somehow makes it all fit together, no easy task.Of course there are passages that are good because of their beauty or because they hit you in your gut or because they ring true or maybe all three: "If I don't eat by ten the world gets f----d up Francis Bacon on me." "No wonder everybody hates Christmas. F-----g memories, man." "Hank Christian. . . Nobody makes me laugh like him." Then there is this evocative highly sexually-charged passage--that no writer other than possibly Reynolds Price does so well-- when the narrator describes Hank dancing: "Slow, more like a man swimming than a man dancing, how a body moves, against the water. That way straight guys won't move their hips, Hank is moving. My a-- is beautiful, the way his hips are moving. The candlelight on the muscles of his back, his chest, his arms, that full, bright face framed in cornflower. His closed eyes, his nipples, his hairy underarms, the hair in the middle of his chest, light, dark, light dark, light and dark." Finally there is the line from W. H. Auden that Mr. Spanbauer weaves into the narrative and title: "If equal affection cannot be, let the more loving one be me."Although I LOVED YOU MORE may wring you out, it is not a novel you want to miss.

Anyone familiar with the Dummy series knows what to expect with this volume: a myriad of information about every aspect of learning to play the banjo: the design of the instrument, its history, the different kinds of banjos, strings, picks, a list of bluegrass festivals, tuning the banjo,  the importance of Earl Scruggs to bluegrass musicits all here and then some. Of course there are the usual icons too: play this, remember, technical stuff, tip and warning. And there is a link to video demonstrations at Dummies-dot-com. When I tried that venue, I found an ad for a three disc set of instructions for $77.00 by Jon Maclennan, who says he has played with Julian Lennon, John Lennons son. In the tens section we have a list of ten or so (there are actually 12 listed)  groundbreaking bluegrass banjo players, beginning with the legendary Ear Scruggs of course. (Will anyone who has ever heard it forget that Dueling Banjos from the movie Deliverance I ask.  Some of Scruggs most important recordings are listed including one of my all-time favorites that I would put in a time capsule Will the Circle Be Unbroken with Maybelle CarterGod  bless herthe Nitty Gritty Dirty Band, Roy Acuff et al.What keeps me from giving this book five stars is this: some of the diagrams showing the various bluegrass  banjo fingering is so small that I cant figure out how anyone could hold a banjo in his lap and get the music close enough to read.

When my reading friends saw that I was reading this book, to a person they lit up with comments like, Shes a great writer or I read The Lottery in high school and loved it. Unfortunately I have never read Ms. Jackson; had I done so, I suspect I could have seen the seeds that flourished into her well-known works in this new book of uncollected short fiction, essays, lectures and drawings by her in much the same way that we can see Herman Melvilles masterpiece MOBY DICK in his dreary earlier novels. (At least knowing his novel OMOO is good for crossword puzzles.)  There are certainly some interesting things happening in some of the short stories and essays, but I would be less than honest if I didnt say that I found much of this book too much of a task and not enough pleasure to read. And I wondered if Ms. Jackson would have wanted some of the material published. Some of the short fiction, for instance, seems unfinished. (The editors say so about the title story Let Me Tell You.)The first short story Paranoia was quite good. The suspense that Ms. Jackson builds up is palpable as in The Man in the Woods. In these two storiesand othersMs. Jackson made a believer out of me. She can write a horror story.  I particularly liked some of her essays. The one entitled A Garland of Garlands about book reviewersshe was married to one it seems-- using the tired language over and over was amusing: I realize now thinking back over the events of the last few years, that people marry book reviewers with the expectation that it is a temporary thing, that sooner or later the poor dear is going to find himself a better niche in life, such as selling vacuum cleaners. Book reviewing is just nothing for a healthy young woman to be married to. Her essay on fan mail (On Fans and Fan Mail) was a hoot.  I also enjoyed her review of  the novelist Samuel  Richardson. And she certainly knows all the perils and frustrations involved with raising four children. Many critics I suspect would agree with her that metaphors should be like garlic, used sparingly.This book then will probably be best appreciated by Ms. Jacksons already fans.

I so wanted this one to be a page from the author's life. Surely there are elements of Mr. Spanbauer's own experience in the narrator since just as the author is, Ben is gay, grows up in Pocatello, Idaho, studies writing in New York, works as both a waiter and super in apartment buildings while a student there, is diagnosed with AIDS and moves to Portland, Oregon and teaches writing. Of course Hank and Ruth could be figments of Mr. Spanbauer's fertile imagination, but I really wanted them to be people in his own life, particularly Hank. At one point in this sometimes painful novel, Ruth says in the presence of both Ben and Hank that she and Ben are both in love with Hank. But aren't we all in love with Hank, straight Hank, the man whose eyes the narrator describes over and over that should have been blue but are dark, almost black, who many years into their friendship tells Ben, "'You're the one who's in my heart'"?Mr. Spanbauer is a master is creating characters who literally walk out of the novel into your living room and, if you are not careful, into your heart. You know dozens of things about them that he tells you over and over: how they look (I can see Ruth`s mane of red hair), how they smell (Ben`s wet feet), how they walk. And he is just as good at fleshing out characters whom we see for only a few pages. I'm thinking now of Andy Gronik, another wounded soul, just one example among many. The plot of the novel is certainly not linear. Mr. Spanbauer tells us early on how this story is going to end and then reminds us again and again. (The only other writer I can think of who does this so well is Toni Morrison.) And he throws everything into this novel-- love, AIDS, homophobia, guilt, sex, friendship, relationships, loneliness (those awful passages about the loneliness of the narrator's mother and sister), anger, racism, grief, illness, death, regrets (Ben never told Hank he loved him)-- and somehow makes it all fit together, no easy task.Of course there are passages that are good because of their beauty or because they hit you in your gut or because they ring true or maybe all three: "If I don't eat by ten the world gets f----d up Francis Bacon on me." "No wonder everybody hates Christmas. F-----g memories, man." "Hank Christian. . . Nobody makes me laugh like him." Then there is this evocative highly sexually-charged passage--that no writer other than possibly Reynolds Price does so well-- when the narrator describes Hank dancing: "Slow, more like a man swimming than a man dancing, how a body moves, against the water. That way straight guys won't move their hips, Hank is moving. My a-- is beautiful, the way his hips are moving. The candlelight on the muscles of his back, his chest, his arms, that full, bright face framed in cornflower. His closed eyes, his nipples, his hairy underarms, the hair in the middle of his chest, light, dark, light dark, light and dark." Finally there is the line from W. H. Auden that Mr. Spanbauer weaves into the narrative and title: "If equal affection cannot be, let the more loving one be me."Although I LOVED YOU MORE may wring you out, it is not a novel you want to miss.

Toni Morrison always grabs you by the collar immediately with her novels (in this instance a 178 page novella) and never turns you loose.  That is certainly the case with GOD HELP THE CHILD that I read straight through.  It begins this way: Its not my fault. So you cant blame me. I didnt do it and have no idea how it happened. It didnt take more than an hour after they pulled her out from between my legs to realize something was wrong. Really wrong. She was so black she scared me. Midnight black, Sudanese black. Ms. Morrison certainly has lost none of her passion as she writes about racism, racism, racism and here color, color, color. The main character Bride, who is born Lula Ann Bridewell,  is despised by her very light-skinned mother (for an instant her mother contemplates smothering her) because she came into this world tar black. As an adult, she flees to California, changes her name to Bride, accentuates her blackness by wearing only white, a panther in snow, becomes an exotic beauty, finds a lucrative career (she now drives a Jaguar), and willing men to fall for her. But she is haunted by demons and certainly one very large one.Ms. Morrison tells her story that takes place in contemporary America in part with a third-person narrator and also with some of the characters, all of whom happen to be female, speaking directly to the reader.  In addition to Bride, her mother Sweetness speaks, as do Brooklyn, her best friend who is white, her mother Sweetness, Sofia, and Rain.This novella with not a wasted word will ultimately break your heart. It is dark, as dark as I remember BELOVED, although I read that one long ago when it was first published. I would be tempted to say the book is too dark except for two reasons: I have never walked in this brilliant writers shoes. (I remember her telling Charlie Rose in an interview years ago of helping an Italian kid in her class in elementary school in Ohio who was new in school and deficient in English. When the boys mother learned that he was being tutored by a young black girl, she complained to the instructor.)  And I can watch the news daily where young black men are being shot by white police officers far and wide.Ms. Morrison has created unforgettable characters here: Bride of course but Booker, Sweetness and Sofia; and who can forget Rain, the little girl with alabaster skin and the greenest eyes Bride had ever seen, and the lovable red-headed Queen who has made many mistakes in her knock-about life but has attained the wisdom we all seek in old age?This book makes  a profound statement about what parents do to children. (Ms. Morrisons quotation from Luke, Suffer  little children to come unto me, and forbid them not at the beginning of the novella is a harbinger of what is to come. And Sweetness, in a moment of self-awareness says: What you do to children matters. And finally GOD HELP THE CHILD is about love, our ultimate quest for it in all its varieties and how bereft we are in we do not find it. It surely is no coincidence that Ms. Morrison entitled another recent book simply LOVE.

In these more than forty  fascinating little essays about Tokyo, Michael Pronko, the transplanted American from Kansas City, offers  kaleidoscopic views into his adopted city that he obviously finds simultaneously intriguing, beautiful and sometimes frustrating. He says that perhaps he settled in Tokyo to write them when he muses on why he came to Tokyo rather than Paris or Beijing.  His only qualifications for writing these essays, he says, are passion and curiosity.  (I would add at least two more:  an impeccable talent for writing  and a near-clinical attention to the most miniscule of details.) He neither attempts to bash the city nor put it on a pedestal, but rather to look right at it and write directly.Mr. Pronko gives us vignettes of areas and customs of Tokyo that I suspect a Tokyoite probably doesnt notice or takes for granted: the abundance of escalators, stairs, signs, banners, hanging menus, city maps that include cherry trees, the art of chopsticks (eating with chopsticks is eating with the eyes first, and then with the mouth), the dominance of the color pink among Tokyos women, etc., etc.  I particularly liked his essays on omnipresent T-shirts with English slogans the Tokyoites wear (MICROSHIT, PEARLY GATES, BOUNTY, NOT SPONSORED, SHOOT THE SUITS, JUST DID IT,),  the dividing gaps between buildings, the ritual of making small change, Don Quixotethe store with more than all the junk youll never need. (It sounds like a similar store in Japan Town in San Francisco where everything cheap and useless seems to be available.) But then there is Mr. Pronkos little praise song to eating a bowl of ramen (Ramen has touched the heartand stomachof this one non-Japanese deeply). And every essay in the section entitled A Maze of the Mind intrigued me. One essay in this section, A-maze-ing Tokyo, is Mr. Pronkos play on wordsTokyo is a city of mazeswith few if any straight lines getting you from A to B but in the end an amazing city. I would say the same about these essays. They too are amazing.Finally the greatest compliment I can give Mr. Pronko: should I ever be so fortunate as to visit Tokyo, I would certainly take his book with me.

These tea towels are soft, light-weight and really dry glassware the way even those of us who aren't particularly good at washing and drying dishes can appreciate. And, yes, they leave your glasses-- as the commercial says-- without streaks.  The towels are 18 by 28 inches and are 100% cotton. Although the ones in the photo appear to be blue and white striped, the ones I received were red and white striped. The price is reasonable as well.

I have known Bob Van Keuren since 1983, have spent many hours with him in the past thirty or so years and thought I knew him. When I finished this so-very-well written memoir, I was taken aback at all the things I never knew about him. Unlike me and many of my friends, Bob has that rarest of qualities: he is modest about his considerable accomplishments. A real class act. I never knew that he was permitted to stand, compliments of the Doorkeeper of the House of Representatives, at the front of the House Chambers where the president of the U. S. stands when he addresses a joint session of Congress in the State of the Union address; or that when he served in the U. S. Navy, that he visited all those exotic foreign countries (although I knew he had served in the Navy); or that he had a masters degree in journalism from the University of South Carolina; or that he had worked in all those political campaigns of progressive Democrats; or that he met Hubert Humphrey, or that he had dressed up as George Washington complete with a wig (Bob in drag?) for a festive event in Boston when he was president of a professional organization to which he belonged.  The list is long.While Bob is so totally honest about practically every aspect of his life, he also exhibits another quality long out of style-- when the most uninteresting sad-sacks on earth tell the most tawdry details of their sordid lives before the likes of Dr. Phil and Jerry Springer and the assembled TV multitudesrestraint. And one more rare quality of all too few writers: Bob does not trash individuals with whom he disagrees vehemently. For example, when he discusses the late Senator Strom Thurmond from South Carolina who spewed out [my words; not Bobs] his poisonous venom in favor of segregation, Bob does not remind the reader (I would have) that the Senator was big on affirmative action in his bedroom and surely guilty of statutory rape as well. There were times that Bobs narrative made my eyes burn: for instance, when he surprised his father one Christmas with the book WALL he had edited that his father had written (I felt cheated that I never met his parents) and Bobs chapter on the assassination of President Kennedy. His chapter entitled I Had a Sweetheart about his nine-year relationship with Montie that ended only in his death is beautiful and moving too.Bob begins each chapter with a quotation, sometimes by someone famous but just as often from an anonymous source. My three favorites, beginning with the second runner-up first is that glorious line from the Paul Simon song: And every strangers face I see reminds me that I long to be homeward bound. The next quotation is from President Kennedy: Our most basic common link is that we all inhabit this planet. We all breathe the same air. We all cherish our childrens future. And we are all mortal. And finally from Shirley Temple: I stopped believing in Santa Claus when I was six. Mother took me to see him in a department store and he asked for my autograph.Bob suggests that, although he is neither famous or celebrated, he is a man of his time and that perhaps that is reason enough for people to read his book.  I think he is right. He is the child of parents who started a home and family when his dad returned from World War II, he remembers the significance of radio, television and the advent of the world of computers, the civil rights era, andsadly-- the onslaught of AIDS:It would be a shame if only those of us who love himhis beloved sister Jeanie, his friends and his family at St. Bartholomews Episcopal Church in Atlanta (Bobs ashes he says will end up in the memorial garden there)--  are the only ones who read this gentle,  ever-engaging memoir.

I have been experimenting with creating a green tea cheesecake for sometime. When this sample arrived in the mail from Tokyo, the amount-- equal to about a tablespoon-- seemed just about the right amount. The resulting color and subtle flavor were perfect. Too much of the  tea powder (double that amount)  before had left a very unattractive shade of green. I took the cheesecake to friends who are my taste-testers. They loved the cheesecake.

Henning Mankell in THE CAT WHO LIKED RAIN has written a near-perfect childrens book. He is quoted as saying about this story:  This might even be my most important book. While I have not read everything this fine writer has written, this certainly is as good a childrens novel as I can remember having read and as good as the 8 or 10 books of his of all kinds that I  have read. Would this story appeal to a youngster? I do not know, but I would certainly like to put it in the hands of a child and find out. Until I can do that, Im pressing it into a middle-aged child friend of mine for his reaction right away.Lukas gets a completely black cat except for a white marking on his tail for his seventh birthday. It is love at first sight, at least for Lukas. He names his new friend Night. He wants to understand everything about Night: It seemed to Lukas that it wasnt easy to understand what went on in a cats head. Lukas knew how he behaved when he was angry or upset or happy. But he wasnt at all sure how Night reacted in such circumstances. Lukas knew that Nights tail would be upright when he was pleased and contented, and that he would rush up against Lukas legs, and that he would purr. But what would Night do when he was upset?  Lukas sets about to take care of and understand Night. Then problems begin when Night comes up missing. And that is all I can say about the plot without revealing too much.It is obvious that Mr. Mankell is no stranger to cats or to seven-year-old and fourteen-year-old boys (Lukas has an older brother Markus whose nickname is Whirlwind). The author gets all the shenanigans of Night just right. He hides in places in the home making it difficult for Lukas to find him,  he likes to jump up and lie on the highest shelf in the kitchen,  he awakens Lukas at four in the morning  when he is ready to play,  he is not interested in being put on a leash.  But Mr. Mankell  flips one characteristic of most cats: Night apparently likes to prowl in the rain.  And Lukas tiffs and run-ins with Whirlwind are so very typical of two brothers this far apart in age growing up together. The parents Axel and Beatrice who round out this family are good and loving parents. They are both attentive and sensitive to Lukas every need and feeling. That is not to say, however, that they are story-book parents. They behave the way most decent parents do. This of course does not happen by accident. As he always does--and one of the reasons he is one of my favorite authors-- Mr. Mankell shows tremendous empathy for these characters.THE CAT WHO LIKED RAIN is first about a young boys love for a pet: At that moment, Lukas knew he was in love with this cat. Hed often wondered what it would be like, being in love with something. Now he knew.  It is also a moving account of parents love  for their children and vice-versa, and probably most importantly as good a story as I can remember that gently teaches a youngster the lesson of loss. There is a magic about it as well that should appeal to everyone.  There are so many gentle touches in the story: on the first day of school Lukas knows he will tell his classmates about Night, he loves the smells he associated with his father whom he adores, Beatrice helps Lukas put up notices about his missing cat.  Additionally the illustrations are, as the Brits say so much better than AmericansI dont know about the Swedeslovely.This is a little book that, upon finishing, you want to give to cat-lovers as well as practically every other reader you know.

Lets talk about the negatives first. Bill Yosses, the former pastry chef at the White Househe was hired by Laura Bush and baked for the Obamasobviously should have had a better proofreader for what would have otherwise been a perfect cookbook. He has printed here the corrections to the errors on the recipes. I made all the corrections and lamented that I had to dirty up this beautiful cookbook with ink markings. But Ill live. Im just glad I looked at some of the other reviews and found out about the mistakes.Now for the accolades: the color photographs by Marcus Nilsson are out of this world. The recipes are for the most part straight forward and easy to follow and beautiful examples that less is more. Mr. Yosses also includes a Chefs Note for some of the recipes, thereby adding a hint of how to make the recipe better. Just when I who collect dessert cookbooks though there were no more outrageous dessert recipes left on the planet, a friend gave me THE PERFECT FINISH for Christmas. I finally today baked the blackberry buttermilk bundt cake with orange glaze (pp. 126-128). I have baked dozens of bundt cakes over the years. This one-- hands down-- might be the best one yet. I do not recall a cake so moist and was afraid that it might not come out of the intricately designed bundt pan. But it popped right out.  It seemed only appropriate to share the cake with the gift-giver.  She was quite taken with it and declared it a keeper. Mr. Yosses in his acknowledgments quotes from the chef Philippe Conticini who said that he wanted to create emotions in the mouththis bundt cake does just that comments that he loves that phrase and thinks that is the dessert makers highest calling. Amen and amen.There are at least a half dozen more recipes I plan to try. (It has usually been my experience that if one recipe in a cookbook of all of one kind of recipes, desserts, breads, soups, etc., that there isnt a bad recipe in the bunch.) The lemon pound cake supreme looks divine, Mamie Eisenhowers cheesecake is inviting, apple conversation beckons as does soft almond cake with fresh raspberries. But I think Ill try the yogurt cake next. And I went outside this cookbook to locate Mr. Yosses apple pie recipe that is a favorite of President Obama. I want to bake that one too.I would certainly purchase another cookbook by this chef.

When you get past the namethere must have been a better title for this series of booksSOCIAL SECURITY FOR DUMMIES, like every other book I have read with Dummies in the title, is a first rate book with important information about everything connected with Social Security. You name it: the author Jonathan Peterson, AARP Executive Communications Director, covers it and in language the average reader should understand. When is the best time to apply for Social Security, how to get a new Social Security card if you lose yours, how much a surviving spouse can draw, how to apply for Medicare, the pros and cons of buying long-term health insurance: these are just a few items that jumped out at me. There is fact after fact that I didnt know. How about this one? You can get three replacement Social Security cards in a year and a total of ten in a lifetime.  And your birthday determines which Wednesday in the month you get your Social Security check, which almost always no longer is a check but is deposited in your banking account; hence the saying, the checks in the mail is no longer accurate.The second edition of the book is completely up-to-date. Two items I noticed: The book incorporates the new health law with the information that seniors will only pay 25% for prescription drugs if they find themselves in the gap known as the doughnut hole by the year 2020. (This is information I have tried on more than one occasion to rely to seniors who remain steadfast in their belief that they are going to lose their SS benefits under the new health law.) The book also includes information on the new definition of spouses (p. 156). The SSA now offers benefits to spouses in same-sex marriages who live in states that recognize these unions.Since I am helping someone apply for the Social Security, I found that section of the book very helpful. Mr. Peterson gives good advice for the applicant. You should be honest in your answers. You should not exaggerate your disability; on the other hand, you should not shy away from telling what you are unable to do either.I particularly liked chapter 15: the ten myths about Social Security. Myth number fourId Be Better Off Investing in Stocks I found particularly informative.  One of the facts that Mr. Peterson puts forthamong several-- to counter this myth: Social Security benefits can be paid at an early age, should an individual experience a tragedy, and would certainly have not built up a nest egg on the stock market or other savings plan.Finally a word about the layout of this informative book: pages numbers both black and large as are the different sections of the book. The author also includes charts and what he labels Tips and Remember to better help you navigate this really easily laid-out book so you can just pick and choose the topics that apply to you.
