Her son built a Liar's Bench from the remnant of the gallows where it sits, its dubious history perhaps contaminating everyone who sits upon it.Like Mudas Summers.  She has just turned 17.  Her mother, now is a relationship with a man who probably beats her and is the father of Muddy's baby sister, is found hanging in her house, and it's being ruled a suicide, which seems unlikely to Muddy.  Muddy lives with her father, the town attorney, who is a philanderer and definitely hiding something.  And before her mother's death, Muddy overheard some angry exchanges between her mother and one of her bosses.  Also, Muddy is in an interracial relationship.  In Kentucky.  In 1972.Against the backdrop of the terrifyingly present Klan, the last brutal years of the Vietnam War, and the town's racism, trusting basically no one, Muddy sets out to solve the mystery and uncover the secrets herself.Writer Kim Michele Richardson perhaps tries to cover too much.  LIAR'S BENCH is simultaneously a mystery, a coming-of-age story, a history lesson, a love story in a difficult and dangerous situation, a story of grief, a deeply troubling portrait of a rural southern town that almost feels like a foreign country, and a story of unraveling lies to find the truth.  And while it accomplishes all of these to a certain extent, the book loses its way deciding what it wants to be.Richardson writes stunning descriptions and portrays the angst and anguish of youth terrifyingly well.  But I had to wonder which book she was trying to write.

In the third of Julia Heaberlins books, BLACK-EYED SUSANS, Heaberlin continues to write a tale of a twisted past, not fully remembered, but always fully affecting the heroine.  Tessa Cartwright was a teenager when she was snatched by a psycho and left for dead in a pit with another dead girl (or two) and some bones, covered with black-eyed susans (which is a flower for the botanically non-inclined).  She was dubbed one of the Black-Eyed Susans.Tessa was returned to her home, traumatized, broken, scarred emotionally and physically, but to a loving (if eccentric) family.  Throughout her best (and also eccentric) friend Lydia stood by her.  Tessa went to therapy with a questionable doctor and was prepared to testify at the trial of the suspect.  He was found guilty and sentenced to death.It is Texas, after all.But Tessa is not convinced he is the killer, feels guilty that her testimony helped convict him, has spent the intervening years with little reminders, creepy gifts, and all kinds of nasty innuendo, and is struggling to do what is right while simultaneously being terrified.I couldnt put it down.This being said here are the top ten things that are great about BLACK-EYED SUSANS: A NOVEL OF SUSPENSE.10.  Heaberlin captures slices of Texas in each of her books -- the terrain, the people, the food, the families, the houses, the feel that you're someplace else.9.  Though Heaberlin writes female characters that have been traumatized, victimized, and terrorized, she captures their strength, which gives strength to others.  There's always the unspoken message that, despite everything, we have strength within us.8.  She has a sense of humor.  Sure, horrible things have happened.  But life, in so many ways, is funny.  There are amusing things to observe.  Without laughter, we have darkness.7.  Character, character, character. Heaberlin write great characters.  There's the eccentric grandfather, building a house filled with surprises to delight and entertain and pose mystery.  There's the aging neighbor lady, slowly losing it, good of heart, in pursuit of her lost diggers.  There's Tessa's teenaged daughter, simultaneously belligerent and loving, filled with bravery and frightened like a small child.  And of course, there's Tessa, facing her demons.6.  Tessa's best friend Lydia, who vanished once the trial was over, never to surface again, is a fabulous portrait of the teen obsessed with the dark and morbid, collecting bits of horrifying daa, cataloguing Jack the Ripper's conquests, a font of information about skeletal remains and a collector of everything creepy.  She's a mystery within the mystery.  Our own little Wednesday Addams.5.  Building an emotional arc.  The characters grow, engage, have epiphanies, and evolve from there.4.  A realistic mother-daughter relationship.  If you've been there, you know.  It's not all love and harmony.  It's not all "I hate you" and slammed doors.  There's a lot in between and Heaberlin has captured that masterfully.3.  Suspense.  Holy cow.  Fasten your seatbelts.  Heaberlin builds and builds suspense, gives you a small break to get your heart rate back to normal, and goes right back to building suspense.2.  I love a story with a totally twisted back-story.  This one has it.1.  Heaberlin can write.  She turns a beautiful phrase, writes dialogue that rings true, mixes just the right amount of description in with the action, and takes you on a roller coaster read.I can't wait for her next book.

KILL AGAIN is the second of the Dr. Claire Waters books, written by the Neal Baer and Jonathan Greene, former executive producers of NBCs Law & Order.  It suffers from screenplay-itis.Claire has just returned to work after her traumas in the first book  (KILL SWITCH).  She has a new apartment, is back at work, is helping teach while she pursues her forensic psychiatric fellowship , and seeing patients, who include Rosa Sanchez, a young mother who has had a spectacular string of bad luck which is about to get worse.  After their session Claire sees Rosa walking down the street, where she is arrested by a uniformed member of the NYPD.  Claire makes frantic calls to all her contacts in the police department and the probation department (all of whom take her call with nary a quibble), but no one knows what happened to Rosa.  So she enlists the aid of deskbound homicide detective Nick Lawler, who is suffering from increasing blindness due to retinitis pigmentosa and is no longer allowed to carry a gun or drive or participate in active investigations.The two of them, of course, jump right in, investigating, playing with guns, driving, and doing just about everything they were forbidden to do.  And, with zero attention to protocol or safety, they manage to make some grisly discoveries.  Meanwhile, the entire police department is falling all over itself with adoration for Clairea.  Sound unrealistic?Fasten your seatbelts.  Because from there, with every chapter, it grows exponentially unrealistic, complete with faux psychology, bizarre ritualistic killings, car chases, kidnapping, and a spectacularly unrealistic love story.  In addition, there are numerous references to all the traumas of the past, over and over and over... as if this were a TV show and the viewers, who had perhaps missed the first 20 episodes, needed to be told again.  Unfortunately, a reader is far better tuned in to this and being told the same bits and pieces repeatedly grows old.The only area where the book does not suffer is in terms of pacing, which is clearly a skill the writers learned in their years of television.You won't need to read the first book because most of it is revealed here.  And if you're like me, you won't want to read the next book because that will contain numerous explanations of everything that happened in this one.The best parts were little cool nuggets of science.  The worst?  See above.

I gave these to my husband to try out, and here's what he had to say:I'm a weekend bass player who plays a long scale Fender Jazz Bass.  I've been playing flat wound strings for a number of years to reduce string noise.  The Elixir Nano Web strings are round wound, but the coating keeps string squeak to a minimum.  As one would expect, these round wounds have a brighter tone than the flats I've been playing.  The Elixirs also have great sustain and stay in tune well.  The long scale strings are plenty long for my 24 fret bass and have a nice feel.  Haven't had them long enough to comment on their corrosion resistance, but in all other respects I'm happy with these bass strings.

Because of cats and squirrels, I hang my bird feeders two stories up, away from branches suitable for mammalian leaping.  And for that reason, and my abundant supply of bird seed, I have a robust population of birds visiting (and emptying) my hanging squirrel-proof bird feeder on a daily basis and my nyger-filled feeder during goldfinch season.I fill the first feeder with no-mess wild bird seed, which they adore, and which contains a minimal amount of sunflower seeds.  So I was happy to add this to the birdie buffet.  Filling it is simple.  The top unscrews easily, and re-seats easily.  I poured sunflower seeds up to the top, closed it, and hung it by the other feeders.  Then I watched and waited.  And watched and waited.  And watched and waited.During this waiting period, I did note that the lack of little perches makes it a bit challenging for feeding purposes, and the mushroom top roof makes access a little tougher.  Then I watched and waited some more.  The birds were decidedly uninterested.On the other hand, they weren't exactly desperate.  The other feeders hung nearby, enticingly easy to access, making them a house finch buffet.  And maybe they were suspicious of this new thing which (I'm guessing) does not look like an enticing mushroom to them.  Or maybe they were waiting for a garden gnome to show up.Finally, when the main feeder was down to a few morsels, they started analyzing the Mushroom feeder.  You know the look.  Head cocked, one-eyeing it, making birdie calculations.  And eventually, when they saw I was not running out to work the pulley and refill their beloved feeder, they gave it a try.  And they liked it.  Plus the roof was a nice place to sit.  And poop.  But hey, that's what birds do.  (No pun intended.)I would recommend this as a good supplemental feeder.  Because of the size of the mesh, about the only thing you can put in it is sunflower seeds are shelled peanuts.  But it works well for those.I'll let you know if it starts attracting garden gnomes.

My prior experience with Hill's dog food was with various forms of Hill's Prescription Diet, which is dog food that looks pretty much the same going in as coming out.  And Prescription Diet was the kind of food the dog needed to be coaxed to eat.  (Option 1: Grate fresh Parmesan on top and say "Oh, look!  Tonight we're having Italian!"; Option #2: put it in cat food cans and say "Oh, look!  Tonight we're having a small plate dinner!).So I was thrilled when I opened the can and discovered food that looked like food.  I was further thrilled that, instead of having to coax the food out of the can with forks, knives, spoons, a rubber spatula, and blasting caps, it virtually glided out of the can and into the dish.  And I was especially thrilled when Esmeralda, all 70 pounds of her, did her excited up-on-her-hind-legs doggie dance as soon as she got a whiff of it.  She adored all the flavors: braised salmon, shredded beef, and simmered chicken.I was less thrilled when I started investigating the ingredients, which I should have done before I fed it to the dog.For example, the first ingredient is chicken broth, which isn't particularly nutritious though it is probably the ingredient that makes the food slide out of the can.  Second ingredient is chicken.  Points for that.  Third ingredient is pork liver - an organ meat that should be rich in protein.  (Good thing Esmeralda doesn't keep kosher.)These are followed by carrots (good nutrients), potatoes (Carb-y and not high in nutrients), green peas (good source of fiber/bad source of protein), rice starch (thickening, no real nutritional value), rice (what kind?  brown? white?  need more info), spinach (good nutrients), powdered cellulose...Wait.  Powdered cellulose?  According to Dog Food Adviser, powdered cellulose is "a non-digestible plant fiber usually made from the by-products of vegetable processing. Except for the usual benefits of fiber, powdered cellulose provides no nutritional value to a dog."  And if it's non-digestible, what is it doing in dog food?Further calculations, according to Dog Food Adviser, indicate an average protein content of 23% and a mean fat level of 18%, giving it a carbohydrate content of 51% and a fat-to-protein ratio of about 81%.Which adds up to below-average protein, below-average fat, and above-average carbs despite broadcasting that it is gluten-free.So, although Esmeralda adored this food, I  will continue my quest for the perfect canned food (and my weekly ritual of making her special gluten-free high-in-protein dog soup).

From the description, we thought it was a piece of hardware.  It is, in fact, a piece of software in a bulky box.  It looks to recreate something similar to the IOS Suite in that it tries to put all your music, all your videos, all your photos in one catch-all program.  But at a price point of $100, you could easily do this all, for free, with a little bit of footwork and the appropriate programs.It claims to have a remote control feature you can download on your phone or tablet but the website isn't really phone-friendly and we were unable to get this feature to work.  If you're looking for something to carry across multiple devices and use their cloud feature, which is pay-by-the-month option, it's nifty.  But at that price there are other ways to do it.The playbacks are smooth, as advertised.It is excellent for pulling up sub titles for videos in multiple languages, but for the life of us, we can't figure out how to turn them off.

Forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan is at it again.  Kathy Reich's latest book starts off in its usual intriguing opening - a recording of a girl imprisoned, frightened, in danger.  It's brought to her by "Lucky" Strike, a self-appointed cyber-sleuth on the trail of a girl who no one ever declared as missing.  Lucky wants Tempe's help to find the remains of young Cora Teague, daughter of religious fanatics, who has not been seen or heard from for 3-1/2 years.  How can Tempe resist?  She wades right in.Meanwhile, her on-again-off-again relationship with Montreal Police Detective Andrew Ryan is on again... or is it.  In earlier books in the now-18 book series, Ryan went hermit after the death of his daughter, re-emerged to help Tempe solve a case, and finally proposed... only now Tempe is having second (and third) thoughts about the wisdom of such as move.Meanwhile daughter Katy is still off in Afghanistan, Mama is still in her high-end asylum refusing chemo, and cat Birdie is still sharing Tempe's meals.If you've never read the series, you could start here and, if you like it, go back to the beginning because there are major character arcs for everyone.  But for the main part, I suspect this is a book for the fans and followers of Dr. Temperance Brennan.Why have I read all 18?  Top ten reasons:10.  Tempe has a sense of humor.  No matter how dark the subject matter, she brings wit, whimsy and insight to any situation.  I used to read all the Patricia Cornwall books, too, but at a certain point I had to stop because medical examiner Kay Scarpetta was always angry, humorless, and no fun to read.  Tempe, even at her worst, is a burst of sunshine in the midst of forensics.9.  The Ryan-Tempe relationship.  On again, off again, hot pants, cold feet... Come on, you two!  Let's get this party started!8.  Lots of cool cool science.  Kathy Reichs infuses each book with lots and lots of intriguing forensics.  And, while I doubt I'll ever use it, I like knowing stuff, and there's lots here to know.7.  An always astounding collection of nuts jobs, psychotics, religious fanatics...  Your crazy neighbor won't look so crazy any more.6.  Cliffhanger, cliffhanger, cliffhanger... Pretty much each chapter ends with a cliffhanger and, while it's really just Reich's writing device and doesn't always pay off, it makes for a fast-paced read.5.  Tempe always has a snappy retort for anything.  Usually she keeps thm to herself and we simply enjoy her inner dialog.  Other times she'll hit someone with a well-deserved zinger.4.  Location, location, location.  This one takes place in North Carolina.  Some take place in Montreal and across Canada.  You'll always get lots of local description and a feel for the locale.3.  A new handsome character.  To solve this puzzle, Tempe works with handsome down-to-earth Deputy Zeb Ramsey.  Where might this be going?2.  Impeccable medical research.  You can learn about all sorts of disorders you'll never want to have.1.  A smart female character who can take care of herself (despite her occasional tendency toward hot-dogging).So what happened to Cora Teague?  What's up with these web-sleuthers?  Who can be trusted?  And what's going on with Ryan?I, obviously, needed to know in the worst possible way.  Which accounts for my lack of sleep this last week.

I don't usually read short stories.  I get involved with the characters and then it's over.  But when I saw that BLACK GLASS was a work from Karen Joy Fowler, I put my short story prejudices on the shelf and dived in.  Why?  Because Fowler is an amazing, witty, insightful, cynical, diverse writer.  I have never read subject matter she has written that didn't suck me in.  Her stories here span centuries, continents, diverse people, and more.What makes this book a must-read?  Here are the Top Ten Things That Are Great About BLACK GLASS.10.  Fowler is crazy smart.  She attacks a multitude of subject matters: the Lone Ranger from Tonto's point of view, a DEA Agent who may have licked one toad too many, Einstein's letters from Mileva, Berkeley days in the early 70s... And to each situation she brings insights and understanding.9.  Impeccable research.  If Fowler writes about unicorn horn, you know she's read everything she can find on the subject.  Carry Nation?  Researched every moment of the woman's life.  Hara Castle?  Prepare to be enlightened.8.  Descriptions.  Fowler can create a picture in your mind with a minimum of words. "'Have some of mine,' Ruiz said.  He was drinking a margarita. He handed the glass to Harris.  Harris tuned the glass to a virginal part of the salt rim and sipped.  He rotated the glass and sipped again."7.  Diversity of subject matter.  In her novels, Fowler has written about Jane Austen, growing up as the human sister of a chimp, a Chinese railway worker, women's baseball...  Now we see through Fowler's window to Einstein's early love, an abducted cartographer in the Amazon, Vietnam war protests... It's a time travel, world travel adventure.6.  She writes with humor, with tragedy, with longing...  There is much emotion to be experienced reading the pages.5.  She has captured Berkeley at the time of the Cambodian invasion perfectly.  How?  She was there.  How do I know?  I was there, too. I read "Letters from Home" and was struck with the same sense of tragedy I felt then.  In fact, I'm pretty sure I could smell the tear gas.4.  Kids breaking into a mysterious neighbor's basement to find his secret stash?  Tonto at 40?  A note in a bottle, read 20 years later?  What's not to like?!3.  You'll have to think.  Not every story will make sense right away.  Ponder and find Fowler's meaning... or your meaning.2.  Fowler is clearly a student/devotee of myth and mythology.  She weaves it beautifully through her stories.1.  Sentences like this: "She regretted every tree she had never climbed."Go climb a tree and read the book.

I should preface this review by pointing out that Esmeralda is the world's shyest least aggressive dog.  She is 55 pounds of quivering insecurities.  But she loves her toys.  She loves her toys so much, in fact, that she still has every single stuffed squeakie toy she has ever owned.  She never rips the stuffing out.  She never tears them apart in quest of the squeakie.  She carries them around and offers them to visitors... as long as they don't try to rip them apart.So I figured the CHUCKIT CHUCKIT! ULTRA SQUEAKER BALL LARGE should be a fine addition to her drool-speckled fuzzy toys.I didn't calculate her fear factor.  When the ball arrived, I opened the package and offered it to her.  She eyed it suspiciously.  I gave it a squeeze, making it squeak.  She backed up.  I rolled it across the floor.  She backed up some more.  I offered it to her up close and her eyes grew wide.  She retreated to her safe corner for a nap.I figured she would get used to it.  It's a toy!  It squeaks!  It bounces!  It's a great ball!  What's not to like?!The ball sat where I had placed it.  Esmeralda took detours through the living room to avoid it.  Every time I tried to entice her, she went to her safe corner.Finally I gave up.  I decided I would give it to my friend's dog.  The one who inherited the frisbee terrorized Esmeralda.Only I couldn't find it, because she had hidden the ball someplace where she would never have to encounter it again.

I ordered this for my DLC-8S Pro when the little plastic thingie broke, rendering the machine inoperable.  (And as long as we're on the subject of cheaply manufactured Cuisinart parts, I had previously replaced the pusher mechanism),  It did not fit, and I returned it, thinking must have foolishly ordered the wrong part and maybe I should just pick up the phone and ask next time.I then contacted Cuisinart to find out what the correct part would be.  I gave them the serial number, model number, number etched in the bowl, and any other number I could find.  I spent a LONG time on the phone with them.They sent me the "correct" cover for my model.  Yep.  The same as this one.  And, big surprise, it did not fit.So I hunkered in for another half hour call and called them again, giving them the serial number, model number, number etched in the bowl, and any other number I could find.Turns out they sent the correct part.  But since my machine was "old" (as in more than a year old), the bowl had changed, and I would now need to order a new bowl.  For $75.  They did waive the shipping fee since the first agent had not actually mentioned this to me.It finally arrived, and my Cuisinart is functional once again.  Cost of replacement parts?  $124.25.Cost of Cuisinart new?  $139.00.Time spent on the phone?  One hour and 17 minutes.I think I should be billing them.

I like that the wine pourer fits snugly in the mouth of the bottle.I like that it is easier to insert than a used cork when there is leftover wine.I like that it has a little valve to keep air from entering the bottle.But when I turned the bottle upside down, I got a tiny drip, drip, drip from that very same valve that was supposed to be sealing it shut.  Which means air was getting in.And so, alas, only three stars for what I thought would be an extremely cool product.

Eileen exists in a dark dark ugly world.  She lives with her father, an ex-cop, who not only has alcoholic dementia and the accompanying paranoia, but a mean streak the size of Massachusetts.  He hates her.  She hates him, and fantasizes about killing him, or having an icicle split him in two, or, at the very least, coming home and finding him dead.  Her mother, who was possibly equally despicable, died and Eileen takes care of her father... if taking care of him means driving to the store in her exhaust-fume-filled-car to buy him liquor, or eating peanuts or a dried up sandwich in the kitchen with him or locking his shoes in the trunk of her car so he can't go out in the snow and shoot at people.She is in her early twenties and works at the local boy's prison/juvenile detention facility, as an admin who hates both women she works with.  In fact, Eileen hates just about everybody, including herself.  It appears she has never had a friend.She is obsessed with bodily functions, noxious smells, and stalking one of the prison guards.  She also likes to steal.Then one day a new employee comes to the prison, a beautiful well-dressed woman, a Harvard grad named Rebecca.  Eileen is ready to hate Rebecca, too but Rebecca befriends Eileen, makes her a confidante, a drinking buddy, a girlfriend, a BFF.  And Eileen falls for it.  Which leads, ultimately, to the day that changes everything... which is why the story can be told from the perspective of older wiser happier loved Eileen.  Which is fortunate, because is she was going to live her whole life the ways she lives it for the first 222 pages, Otessa Moshfegh would be responsible for hundreds of readers opening a vein.While it is a compelling story, with a twist I never saw coming, it is probably not good reading material for someone in danger of slipping into a depression.Moshfegh is an excellent writer, and so here are the Top Ten Things That Are Great About EILEEN.10.  It's very difficult to write descriptions of smells.  Moshfegh does it brilliantly.  You'll be opening your windows and gasping for fresh air.9.  Ever fear alcoholic dementia?  Watch Eileen's father and be afraid.  Be very afraid.8.  Sometimes a writer captures cold weather so well, you need to bundle up.7.  Moshfegh describes dirt and grunge so well you'll want to scrub your kitchen and feel good about it.6.  Look in Wikipedia under dysfunctional and you might find a picture of Eileen and her family.  Moshfegh has created a family so dysfunctional it might make your own encounters looks pleasant.5.  It is reassuring to believe that someone with such horrible beginnings can end up happy.  Yes, I know it's fiction.  But I'd like to believe that.4.  A good lesson: Beware of beautiful strangers who suddenly want to become your best friend for no apparent reason.3.  One of the best/worst testimonies/explanations of a mother who stood by while her child was abused.2.  You can walk away and say THIS IS NOT MY LIFE.1.  The twist.  Ah, what a twist.Come for the dark descriptions.  Stay for the twist.  And then go stand in the sunshine.

This nifty tool - the ARKON MAGNETIC PHONE MOUNT - came at a perfect time in my life.  You see, I have no sense of direction and my car's GPS, a mere 10 years old - suffers from GPS Alzheimer's.  In the old days she would merely give slightly cockeyed directions, like turning onto a street that was a flight of stairs.  But now she is confused all the time.  "Turn right.  Please make a legal U turn.  Please make a legal U turn. Turn right.  Please make a legal U turn. Please make a legal U turn."  When there are tall buildings, she is completely disoriented.Then I tried out the Google Maps App.  It was wonderful, and I retired my GPS to hospice care.  But it burned through a battery faster than my old GPS could say "Please make a legal U turn."  Plus it was sitting in the cup holder of my car, which kind of muffled Ms. Google Map's voice.Enter the ARKON MAGNETIC PHONE MOUNT.  At first I worried that it would stick on my pebbly dash, but it sent on perfectly, proudly displaying my iPhone 4S, with the car charger dangling from her dainty posterior into the cigarette lighter.  Then I lost my iPhone 4S (the GPS isn't the only forgetful thing in my car) and I became the proud owner of the iPhone 6 Plus... which is a big honkin' phone.  Could the phone mount hold it?  Indeed it could.  I stuck the smaller round magnetic disk on the back of the case (yeah, I know, but I couldn't get the Otter Box off), and stuck it right on the phone mount.And away we drove, monitoring traffic, finding new exciting ways that actually worked.Google Maps with the Arkon Magnetic Phone Mount are my new best friends.

I have long been a fan of Nutro cat food and, while I don't feed it to all my cats every day (because I have too many cats and it's too expensive), I have used it to help heal a cat who was wasting away, and to tempt non-eaters.  Nutro seems to have its finger (or paw) on the pulse of feline taste, because I have never found a Nutro cat food that the cats didn't like, and I have pretty much tried them all (to keep myself amused).I think Breakfast Scrambles are a fun idea, despite the fact that my cats eat one meal in the morning.  You can call it breakfast if you like.  It's their protein-packed repast for the day.  And Breakfast Scrambles are protein-packed, with real egg and chicken and salmon.  The cats gave it a look -- it was something different -- but they all ate their portions with kitty delight.There's just one problem.  It's sticky.  Really, really sticky.If you do the canned cat food ritual, you know how you pull the lid off and then try to scrap the lid against the edge of the can to get all the food off the lid.  This one doesn't scrape off well at all.Next, with your utensil of choice, you scoop as much cat food as you possibly can out of the can and into the dish.  There is no utensil that works with this  A lot remains stuck to the inside of the can.  You can scrape and fork and spoon and pick at it but it's pretty much stuck.Usually the dog is my back-up with the cans.  When I've scaped them out into the cat dishes, the dog help lick out the cans so they can go into the recycling without a layer of kitty pt.  Only the dog couldn't get it all out either.  She licked and turned and chased those cans all over the deck and still couldn't get all the food out.Five stars?  The cats loved it.  But the food had what you might call... a sticking point.

Layla Beck is the spoiled daughter of a senator, living in luxury as the Great Depression drags on.  When she refuses to marry a wealthy suitor, her father cuts her off and gets her a job with the WPA, which Layla sees as the ultimate humiliation.  Worse, she must go to very rural Macedonia, West Virginia, where she is to write the town's history.  She has no desire to be in West Virginia, much less to be living among people she feels are beneath her, and writing their history.  But she must.She ends up as a boarder at the home of the Romeyns, who were once a great family in Macedonia.  Jottie and Felix's father ran the mill and was regarded with great respect.  Now Jottie runs the house and raises Felix's two daughters, Willa and Bird.  Assorted aunts live there on and off, and sometimes Felix lives there as well.  And so do secrets.  A whole lot of secrets.Twelve-year old Willa is determined to snoop and learn the long-hidden truth.  Layla is determined to prove herself and live happily ever after with Felix.  And Jottie keeps on keepin' on, happiness having eluded her years ago when the secrets were carefully hidden.What a tangled web of secrets it is.  Annie Barrows, who first captured my interest with THE GUERNSEY LITERARY AND POTATO PEEL PIE SOCIETY has written another book full of history and character and tragedy and love and loss.  Once I started reading, I desperately needed to know all the hidden secrets, too.That being said, here are the Top Ten Things That Are Great About THE TRUTH ACCORDING TO US.10.  Annie Barrows can really write.  GUERNSEY LITERARY AND POTATO PEEL PIE SOCIETY was done in the form of letters -- the epistolary style that created some of the first novels.  In THE TRUTH ACCORDING TO US, she uses letters, as well, though they are inter-woven with Willa's narrative and other points of view.  The voices work well with each other, creating a complex layering that is beautifully done.9.  History.  As Layla write her history of the 150-year old town, she discovers that history has many faces.  And woven in with that is history in the mid 30s, the Depression trudging on, the labor unions working for fair wages, Prohibition, and many of its facets.8.  The book transports you to another time and place.  You feel the pace of Southern life, the conversations on the porch drinking sweating glasses of sweet tea, trying to get through the heat of summer.  You experience the things kids were able to do then, running loose, throwing fruit at each other.  It's literary time travel.7.  The library.  When I was a kid, the library was the best place ever.  You could hide out among the shelves and lose yourself in other worlds, and then haul a stack of books home, reading all the way, and escape whatever you needed to escape.  That's what the library is in the book.6.  Character, character, character.  There's daring dashing sneaky Felix, wise-for-her-years Willa, ever-patient, ever-longing Jottie, ever-evolving Layla.  Barrows writes great characters.5.  Not only does Barrows write great characters; when they speak it sounds natural, and it sounds like they would sound.4.  The characters grow and learn and evolve and become better or reap just desserts for their deeds.  There are epiphanies.  No one remains stagnant.3.  The book is full of little side stories, like life.  As Layla interviews various townspeople or Jottie tells her stories, we hear all sorts of intriguing little tales that don't move the story forward, but give us context and enrichment and a great deal of vicarious amusement.2.  It's a Coming of Age story that's actually interesting.1.  What really happened in the mill that night?  I absolutely had to know.

One fine evening, on the UC Santa Cruz campus, back in 1993, roommates Anna Fury and Kate Smirnoff are stumbling home from a party when they find a woman passed out by a willow tree: George Leoni.  Kate thinks she recognizes her from her Biology class, so they try to shake her awake.  George turns out to be a lot heavier than she looks.  They load her in a shopping cart and take her home.Thus begins a lifelong friendship... with requisite hiccups, bumps, disasters, tragedies, camping trips, children, and all that a lifelong friendship of women entails.The story is told from various perspectives.There's Kate Smirnoff ("like the vodka"), raised by her grandfather, ready to take over his diner when the time comes, never plans to leave Santa Cruz... or her apartment.Anna Fury is the rich kid with the wildly dysfunctional mother.  She's brilliant, she's angry, and she has an addictive personality that triggers events for the three women.And tree-hugger George, always up for a camping trip under the stars, who can start a fire faster than anyone, gives it all up for a succession of dreadful husbands.The story hops around, from character to character, from year to year, from place to place.  Santa Cruz 1993.  Lincoln Nebraska 2005.  Boston 2002. St. Louis 1999. It's a bit like assembling a puzzle, piecing it all together to find the inciting incidents that hold the women together and drive them apart and back together.Lisa Lutz writes with a natural ear for dialog, a finely tuned sense of the absurd, and an acute understanding of the unique personalities she portrays in the three friends.  And while, during the book, you may find yourself confusing which is Kate and which is Anna and which is George, eventually you'll see an artistic uniqueness to each.A fascinating involving book filled with humor and compassion and quirky moments.

Those who follow my reviews know that I like a little (okay, a lot) of rit in my reading material.  Add to that the fact that this books was tucked into the category of Christian Books and Bibles.  I never would have found it except that I saw that Sharyn McCrumb is the author.  I have enjoyed many McCrumb mysteries, with her finely woven its of history and folklore of Tennessee.  And so I chose the book, and I am so happy I did.NORA BONESTEEL'S CHRISTMAS PAST brings back a beloved character, Nora Bonesteel, who has the sight.  It also brings back good-guy Sheriff Spencer Atwood and his cynical deputy Joe LeDonne, who have been in excellent McCrumb stories of their own.Miss Bonesteel's story brings her back to the old Honeycutt house, filled with memories of her childhood, and now inhabited by a retiring Florida couple who realize, when their fake Christmas tree is smashed to pieces, that their house is haunted.The Sheriff and his deputy, meanwhile, are driving down the backroads to arrest someone who dented a Senator's Mercedes.  The snow is coming in, darkness is about to fall, and it's Christmas Eve.Both stories have sweetness and humor, history and tradition, woven through them.The book is a feel-good Christmas tale right up there with Truman Capote's A CHRISTMAS MEMORY or O'Henry's GIFT OF THE MAGI - stories about humans and their foibles at a certain time of year.To list it under Christian Books and Bibles does the book a disservice. It's a gentle book for everyone and anyone who needs a sentimental smile.

Meet the Burroughs clan.  They are meaner than snakes.  They have run Bull Mountain for generations, destroying anything that blocked their path.  First they ran moonshine, then marijuana, and ultimately crystal meth.  If they don't like you, if they think you've taken advantage of them, if you cross them, they will beat you or burn you up or kill you in equally unappetizing ways.The clan has come down to three brothers, then two.  One is the King of the Mountain, so to speak.  The other is a lawman, a Burroughs gone straight.  The question is: which one will survive?Brian Panowich's BULL MOUNTAIN is a dark action-packed deeply twisted tale, fast paced, unrelenting in emotion, violence, meanness, and one of the most dysfunctional family dynamics imaginable.Panowich tells the story in scenes from time, from the point of view of different characters.  And while this definitely builds tension and understanding of all that went before without reading through a long Bull Mountain history, it can be confusing.Chapter 1: Rye Burroughs, father of the brothers, with brother Cooper in 1949Chapter 2 & 3: Clayton Burroughs, the lawman brother, in 2015Chapter 4: Katie Burroughs, Clayton's wife, 2015Chapter 5: Halford (dead brother) and Clayton Burroughs in 1985Chapter 6: Simon Holly, Federal Agent with a twisted plan in 2015Chapter 7: Cooper Burroughs (Rye's brother) in 1950Chapter 8: Gareth Burroughs (Cooper's son) in 1958Chapter 9: Annette Henson Burroughs, who marries Rye, in 1961Chapter 10: Gareth again, in 1973You get my drift.  It's all over the place and you might want to make an Excel spreadsheet to keep it all straight before it gets REALLY complicated.Because it does.Panowich, amazingly, miraculously, pulls it all together, weaves all the threads, adds knots and tangles and twists and turns and, like a magician, makes it all make sense at the end... in a twisted kind of way.Not for the faint of heart, but a relentlessly action-packed page-turner.And in case you were wondering what a sage grouse is, I've attached a photo.

Here's a cool set: 4 games in one.Game 1: Bananagrams... without words.Game 2: Scrabble... without words.Game 3:  Scramble... without words.Game 4: SETPROS:Works well as a solitary game and as a group gameThe dice are substantial and relatively easy to see.Coherent instructions. And they fold up!There are LOTS of die.Bag of dice works as a weapon.A good price for 4 games... plus you can glue other faces on the jumbo dice for other games.Nice cubey design.The box is nicely laid outCONS:Hard to tell the symbols apart in low light.Because the dice are so substantial, it's hard to hold a multiple amount to throw them.Doesn't fold flat for travel.The crossword version of the game can be confusing.Works better as a quiet-significant-other game than a party game.It is not a rousing romp.

Sometimes in life, when everything is going fine, suddenly an anvil falls from the sky and changes everything.  That's what happened to the Dupont Family.  Enroute to parent teacher conferences, the kids safely belted into the car, the signal green, Robert and Sylvie drive their car across the covered bridge and have a head-on collision.  The car goes into the water.  Seven year old Jess dies.  Robert is physically crippled, confined to a wheelchair.  Sylvie is emotionally crippled, unable to leave the house or function.  And 9-year old Ruby gets to be the adult, the one who copes and tries to keep everyone else on track.The story flashes forward 2 years.  Robert has moved in with his brother, and Ruby stays with them because Sylvie is no longer capable of caring for herself, much less her daughter.  A storm is coming in, Robert and his brother need to leave the state to assist another brother, and Ruby must stay with her mother.Add to the mix a penniless mute pregnant teenager with mysterious roots to the town, stumbling back "home," ready to deliver her baby, and Ruby's best friend who suddenly abandons her just before they are to complete a vastly important bridge project that they are to research and design.Let's just say Ruby, who already thought she'd had the worst day of her life, is having days that rival it.All that being said, here are the top ten things that are great about T. Greenwood's THE FOREVER BRIDGE.10.  It is beautifully written.  Greenwood delivers sumptuous descriptions, hair-raising tension, and complex characters.  She ties all the book's threads together seamlessly... and there are many to tie together.9.  Character, character, character.  Each character is unique, shaped by the tragic events in different ways, coping in different ways.  The snotty friend is drawn to a T, the pregnant teenager struggling to survive reveals convincing panic, the mother's fears are almost visible.8.  Bridges.  Did you ever want to learn about bridges?  No?  Well, you'll learn a lot about them hear and share some of Ruby's wonder and obsession with them.7.  Tender memories of the brother who died.  Because little brother can be a pain, and Ruby's was, but she is able to summon little moments that hold his image together in her mind.6.  There's a family of baby raccoons living on the porch.  This is clearly not a family of animal-lovers, but the raccoons capture the fragility of life and Ruby, while struggling to cope with everything else, manages to take time to deal with that.5.  The kindness of strangers.  Here's a family who once was a vital part of the community, and now is a shattered version of themselves.  Yet there are old friends and passing acquaintances who still take the time to try to help.4.  The power of the river.  It swept away Jess years before.  The storm comes and we are reminded of what a formidable foe a river can be.3.  Have you ever read a book and found is so layered with perceptions and emotions and thought that you wonder how the writer could possibly have any thoughts left for another book?  This one is like that, and T. Greenwood has 8 previous novels.2.  Where does one go from the moment the anvil drops?  Here is one scenario and it reminds of of the fragility of life and survival.1.  Mysterious threads that will keep you wondering until the end.I loved the book and book and am thrilled to have found an author who has 8 previous novels, and clearly has more in her.

Ah, the shaving products women use in a lifetime... I've done men's shaving razors, Nair, sanding pads, an electric razor (gradation gift in high school!), letting it all grow (yes, UC Berkeley in the 60s/70s), epilation, waxing, new improved epilation, disposable razors, and finally the REMINGTON PRODUCTS WOMEN'S RADIANT AND SMOOTH SIX-BLADE SYSTEM.In order of use these products have been:  bloody, stinky, time consuming, loud and ineffectual, time to move on, ow, expensive and time consuming, slightly less ow, haphazard, and HEY, THIS THING REALLY WORKS!Unlike more traditional razors, the six-blade system does not leave you covered in nicks and scratches, and is effective in the more-difficult-to-shave bony regions.  I use it in the shower blindly yet when I emerge I appear to have neatly and painlessly removed any hair that needed removing.My legs recommend it highly.

We have one of those MIRACLE-GRO AERO GARDENS, and we've been experimenting with which herbs we can grow in abundance in the kitchen.  The 12 Pack CERTIFIED ORGANIC HERB SEEDS offer a wonderful selection of possibilities.  These created a beautifully trailing thyme and a robust basil.  The real Jack-and-the-Beanstalk-Winner is the dill, which (in Southern California) doesn't do well at all.  But with these seeds and the Aero Garden, we've made abundant supplies of it.  In fact, the dill gets too big for the Aero Garden and then goes outside, where it promptly withers.  But we just plant another kitchen crop and the dill keeps on growing.Love the variety and the options of this great seed selection.

I wanted to love this dog food. I really wanted to love it.I love that is is sourced in the US.I love that The Honest Kitchen actually sought (and obtained) FDA approval as human-grade foods for dogs.I love the fact that the beef is hormone-free meat.I love the fact that it contains "no red flag pet food ingredients like corn, soy, rice, beet pulp or wheat."I love the fact that it is easy to increase or decrease the amount fed, with no stinking half-can sitting in the refrigerator.So why did VERVE lose a star?Sigh...I have always raised large-breed dogs, and have never had a problem with them being finicky eaters.  I have always assumed this was because big dogs will eat anything (even if it's not food).The first day I served Esmeralda her big bowl of Verve.  She did her morning doggie dance, tucked in, and ate it all up... except for one lone cranberry.  I thought she somehow just missed it.The second day, she also did her joyful doggie dance, tucked in and ate it up... with the exception of two cranberries.The third day she did her dance but it was more to see what was in the bowl.  I set it down.  She sat and looked at it.  I told her about the hormone-free beef and the soy-free nature of this awesome food.  She looked at it some more.  I finally got her to eat it by scooping it into cat food cans.I hoped Day 3 was a fluke.It wasn't.Day 4 rolled around.  No doggie dance.  And she wouldn't touch it until I again slopped it into cat food cans.And there's my sad tale of the perfect food.  It's perfect except Esmeralda won't eat it. (She pointed out that it would be rather pricey if she did like it, but I think she was just trying to make me feel better.)

I find it interesting that all the negative reviews about PURINA PRO PLAN DRY CAT FOOD have logged unhelpfuls.  And looking at them, all the reviews state useful information.  So who is finding them unhelpful?  Purina elves?  I'm just saying...I like the fact that PURINA PRO PLAN DRY CAT FOOD's formula is 45% protein.  I have yet to see a cat stalking broccoli in the wild.  Cats are carnivores.  So I like that the fact that the first ingredient listed is turkey.  I like the fact PRO PLAN is formulated without corn or wheat.What I don't like is that the third and fifth ingredients are soy protein isolate and soy protein concentrate.  According to Dr. Karen Becker, a proactive and integrative wellness veterinarian:"Soy is a plant protein used by pet food companies to boost protein content and add bulk. Because plant proteins are less expensive than meat proteins, pet food manufacturers use them to increase profit margins...The majority of experts on pet nutrition agree soy isn't good nutrition for cats or dogs. It is considered a low-quality, incomplete protein well known to create food allergies in pets......The carbohydrate action of soy can cause a rise in blood sugar in many cats. Soy is also linked to thyroid damage, and since hyperthyroidism is common in kitties, this is yet another reason it should not be part of a feline's diet.The ingestion of soybean products is also linked to seizures in both dogs and cats."Not good.And the last thing I'm not liking is that Purina is not assuring me that all the ingredients are sourced in the US.  It says it is manufactured at Purina-Owned US Facilities.  But given all of the pet food disasters with China-sourced ingredients, I need an assurance of sourcing before I can trust them.Still searching for a cat food I trust.

Giovanni Bernini has a unique talent... or character flaw.  He watches a person and then perfectly mimics them.  This gets him into no end of trouble, in school, in life, in love, in entertainment, in politics...  Jacob Rubin has created a character the likes of which I have not encountered in literature before.It's been described by a number of readers as hilarious.  It's more funny than hilarious, and not funny in the ha-ha way.The pacing is a bit slow but the insights offer perfect payoffs when they occur... which is often.It's well-written, it's thoughtful,it's unique, it has spectacular descriptions of various people Giovanni meets... but it has a tendency to drag, and for that I deduct one star.

In the first sentence of Chapter 1, one of the characters describes the heroine, Maxine, of being a "tenacious b*&^#."Author Allison Brennan spends the next 372 pages proving it.Maxine Revere is a noted writer and high-powered investigative reporter who specializes in missing persons cases, using any and all techniques possible.  That means that, with her assistant and bodyguard an producer and ex-lovers and current lovers and people to whom she has "brought closure" in the past, she will determinedly undermine the district attorney's case against a murderer, steal information from a medical facility, lie and cheat to find out what she wants to find out.  She gets away with it because she is the sexiest, hottest, smartest, saintliest, most instinctive, mind-reading brilliant student of the human mind who ever walked the earth.In COMPULSION, Adam Bachman is on trial for murder.  He was caught with a drugged and bound woman in the trunk of his car, the modus operandi matching that of a number of unsolved murders.  Right before his trial, Max is allowed to interview him.  Max is convinced that Adam did not act alone, that he had a partner, and that they were responsible for the murder/disappearance of an older couple whose case remains unsolved.  All Adam says is "You'll never find them."So off Max goes, to prove her theory and find the missing couple.Anything she does, she justifies with her maxim that those left behind need truth and closure.This goes on for 171 pages, during which enough of Max's back-story and former liaisons are revealed that you'll never have to read any of the Max Revere books that preceded this one.Finally, on page 171, something happens so you don't have to watch the b*&^#-on-wheels act for a while.I, for one, was relieved.A thoroughly unlikeable character in an implausible story-line that throws in a new character whenever the plot stalls.If you're behind on your reading, you might want to give this one a pass.

The MIRACLE-GRO CHERRY TOMATO SEES POD makes a perfect teaching moment.  Often, when you plant with children (or planting-phobes), gently guiding them as they plant a seed, gently water, and watch a sprout emerge... that pesky sprout doesn't emerge.  Or it does, only to be lovingly fondled and accidentally crushed.  Or it grows and is then devoured by a giant tomato worm that looks like something out of an alien film.I can't guarantee what happens after the seed pod tomato sprouts, but the sprouting odds are greatly enhanced with the fertilizer and little peat pot.If you're planting your all-organic compost enhanced vegetable plot, this isn't your scene.  But if you want to plant your little plant and watch a seedling emerge, this makes a very teachable moment.

The dress is diaphanous and fairy-like and wispy and wonderful in terms of color.  It floats and enchants.The problem is the bust.  It is so low cut that there is no place to hide a bra.  And it is lined with a lumpy material (which is sewn in with itty bitty stitches), so that you can't remove it and it looks oddly seamed when you wear it.  If you can come up with a way to overcome the creased bosom problem, it's a winner.

Using Joseph Kennedy and his legacy as an example, Lady, Vee, and Delph Alter's mother tells them, in one of her famous pronouncements, that the sins of the father are visited down on four generations.  Lady, Vee, and Delph are the fourth generation of one massive sinner: Lens Alter.Lens Alter was a Jew converted to Lutheran, a scientist (fictional) modeled after a real scientist (Fritz Haber) who not only weaponized chlorine gas and promoted it to the Germans for use as a weapon in Word War I, but went on to develop Zyklon B, which the Nazis used to exterminate Jews during World War II.  (In addition to that, he was a thoroughly unlikeable character).Ever since, descendants of Lens Alter have met their ends by suicide in many forms - hanging, throwing oneself out a window, drowning... You name it; the Alters have thought of it.Beyond that, it is a tale of four generations of dysfunctional family members doing dysfunctional things, in darkly amusing ways.  And while all this sounds terribly grim, it's a extremely funny, insightful, quirky, touching story.Here, then, is my list of The Top Ten Things That Are Great About A REUNION OF GHOSTS10.  Judith Claire Mitchell can turn a phrase with the best of them.  Her sentences are beautiful constructions.9.  The weaving of the storylines.  Mitchell bounces between generations, telling little vignette gems from each, until all the vignettes form a complete story.  It makes it difficult to follow, at times, but eventually it all makes sense and the complexities form a whole picture.8.  It's funny.  I know.  From the description it sounds dark beyond belief, but these are real people she's created, and real people do funny things and think irreverent funny thoughts.  In addition, the sisters are irrepressible punsters.  They can't stop themselves.  And so they rarely do.7.  History.  I was a bad student of history, as served up in school.  In works of fiction, where it is woven in to make us understand times and places we have never been, I am a voracious student of history.  And there is much in the pages of this book.6.  Cameo appearances.  Meet Albert Einstein and his first wife Mileva, the Curies, Frank Zappa, Janis Joplin.  Or have a chat with Dr. Freud.5.  Location, location, location.  There is much for those who love New York, walking the streets and byways with the sisters.4.  Character, character, character.  Each of the sisters in uniquely intriguingly bizarre and endearing in strange ways.  They feel so real, so scarred, so frightened, so brave, and, as mentioned before, very funny.3.  Observations and insights.  Have you read books where the author reveals so many juicy thoughts that the pages swim with them, and you wonder how said author could ever write another book because so much of the author's soul and brain are in the one you are reading?  This is one of those books.2.  Making such a dark tale such a pleasure to read.  Sure, I recoiled.  I was horrified.  I also laughed.1.  Judith Claire Mitchell can REALLY write.  I would include a perfect paragraph, but there were far too many from which to choose.Go ahead.  You try.

You know that squeaky clean feel your teeth get right after the dentist cleans your teeth, and how good it feels?You know how you try to keep your teeth that squeaky clean, and no matter how carefully and often you brush, you don't get that feel back until he next time you visit the dentist for a cleaning?With the PHILIPS SONICARE TOOTHBRUSH, you can keep that squeaky clean feel.I am obsessive about my dental hygiene.  I floss.  I water-pik twice a day.  I use anti-plaque mouthwash.  I brush.  I go for cleanings four times a year,  And yet my mouth is apparently a bacteria-generating farm where the little buggers grow and reproduce.So I was thrilled to gives the PHILIPS SONICARE a try, and I am thrilled with the results.So here are the Top Ten Things That Are Great About the PHILLIPS SONICARE TOOTHBRUSH:10.  It holds a charge for a long time.  You don't need to constantly keep it on the charger.9.  It doesn't take up a lot of counter space.8.  It comes with a nifty travel case so you don't end up with vile-tasting sunscreen on your toothbrush. (Don't ask me how I know this)7.  Sleek design makes it easy to clean; there are few hidden nooks and crannies.6.  It times your brushing experience for you.5.  It's fairly quiet.  Some electric toothbrushes sound like buzz saws.  With this, you can brush while your partner slumbers in the adjacent bedroom.4.  It's gentle.  It doesn't feel like it's vibrating your teeth into the next county.3.  The color matches my water pik.2.  It doesn't blast the enamel off your teeth.1.  IT WORKS!  My teeth feel squeaky clean!The only design flaw I have encountered is that the on/off button is where you hold the toothbrush, so you can accidentally turn it off while you're brushing.  This is certainly not the end of the world; it's easy to turn it back on.  But it does interfere with the timing.But I love it, and can learn to live with the button.  Why?  Because my teeth feel squeaky clean!

This is my first BRUNO, CHIEF OF POLICE novel, but I immediately felt welcome in his circle -- enough so that I will be dipping back to Martin Walker's earlier works to spend more time with Bruno in St. Denis.The stories revolve around the small French town of St. Denis, where Bruno Courreges is the Chief of Police.  The town is tiny enough that everyone knows everyone's business, for better or for worse.In the book, two "children" return.  One is Sami, an autistic boy who was taken in by his uncle and aunt when he was very young.  After a number of years, they took him to a special school at the local mosquq.  But somewhere along the way, Sami's unique skills made him attractive to the jihadists, who put him to work. He has somehow escaped and wants to return to France.The other "child" is an old Jewish woman who, as a child, along with her brother, were sheltered from the Nazis.  Her brother, who was quite wealthy, recently died, and wanted to make a large bequest to the town as a token of their gratitude.But there are terrorists on the loose in the peaceful village.  As the story opens, Bruno is dealing with the corpse of a tortured undercover police officer who was investigating activities at the local mosque.  Following the assassins' trail, Bruno discovers them at the school, armed and dangerous, no doubt looking for Sami's uncle.Life in peaceful St. Denis is about to get a lot less peaceful, perhaps forever.That being said, here is my Top Ten List of Things That Are Great About THE CHILDREN RETURN.10.  Bruno's character.  He's everything  charming Frenchman should be.  A great cook, a lover of good food, a lover of wine and women.9.  Really scary stuff mixed in with beautiful touching stuff.  The contrast shows off both extremes to the maximum. The ending sequence will have you chewing your nails and flying through the pages (or chewing the pages and flying through your nails).8.  Lovely recipes and cool info about growing wine grapes and making wine.  While Martin Walker's wife is apparently putting together a cookbook of bruno's recipes, the beauty of them here, I think, is the "cooking without recipe" approach: adding fresh vegetables from the garden, some dry white wine, a drizzle of olive oil...7.  Glimpses and lessons in history, woven into the story.  We read about the French Resistance, the Partisans, the Algerian War, the Nazis' effects on secluded Southern France, and more.  Walker describes the July 1942 roundup at the Velodrome Hiver, the heroic efforts of the Jewish Scouts to save the children, the Protestant communities of Southern France who played a heroic role is the rescue of so many Jewish children, the Battles of Mouleydier in June of '44, and much more.6.  Research, research, research.  Martin has done a diligent job researching not only the history but autism, life in Afghanistan, Islam in Europe, the Taliban, and more. The subject matter around the mosques, the jihadists, and the peaceable Muslims is extremely timely.5.  Martin Walker can turn a phrase beautifully.  The words flow.  The characters' dialog is natural and believable.4.  Walker develops excellent characters.  They are portrayed with sensitivity, each unique and separate from the other characters.3. An interesting glimpse into the ways French politics (and international politics) work, with relationships, past history, protocol, and more.2.  How can you not love a book where it's time for the wine harvest festival?1. There are six more Bruno books, just waiting to be read.

I got these for my niece who was born earlier this month so she is only a few weeks old.These are definitely on the Large side but I still got them so she can grow into them.Newborns grow pretty fast anyway and I expected them to be a little big.These are made of 100% soft cotton and have a elastic bad to keep the mitten on yohr little ones hands.They manage to work but tend to fall off on occasion.She should be able to fit these really soon since she ks growing in size.They definitely help protect her face from any scratches.Newborn stages are when they scratch the most so glad these came in handy.If you want a more snug size for a newborn I suggest a small.So far I ampretty happy with the quality of these.I also received a 3 pack instead of 2pack which the listing says 2 so I am glad we got an extra pair.One con of these mittens is that when they ship them they do not guarantee the color pattern you want.We ended up getting boy colors which is fine since my sister is not picky.Besides my niece is home for the first weeks anyways.So I would keep that in mind when shopping.They washed pretty good and did not fade so I am pretty happy about that.Sample was provided to me by company in exchange for my honest unbiased review.

I am very pleased with this Portable Solar Charger from SunLabz.I have tried a few of their products and was excited to give this a try since I have never used this type of portable charger powered by the sun.This panel is very sleek and thin.Perfect to take on traveling trips I gave this to my Mother to borrow on her trip to Samoa and she had so many compliments about how neat this is.It is very sunny and hot out there so this worked absolutely well for her.She was able to charge it up quickly and efficiently and charge her IPad2 as well as her 6Plus.I tried this here as well before giving her this to try out there on our trip to Arizona and here in California and it worked great!I was a bit skeptic if it would actualy work and it did.This comes with the panel itself which is wrapped with a nylon like material around the whole frame and in the back as well.It has 4 holes total around the corners to hold the suction cups that you receive in your purchase as well as the hooks.The hooks are perfect to use while camping, hiking, etc. You can hook on the back of your backpack, bag, or tent to get a 45 degree angle to charge up the panel.That is the angle that is suggested when charging this device.What is neat about this panel is that in the back there is a net pouch to store your phone cord tablet cord or the hooks/suction cups that come with it.In the back they have a black little port for the usb to go into to charge your device.You cannot charge this with your power cord it is only charged through the sun.Overall since having this over a month we really like  it.My Family members borrow this when they are going to be outside doing recreational activities or traveling where it is hot like back in the islands.Sample was provided to me from SunLabz in exchange for my honest unbiased review.

I got this for my Mother to use since she had symptoms of candida and wanted to try it myself before giving it to her to see what it tastes like.It really is POTENT!IYou have to shake this bottle very well before using.You can smell the strong oil as soon as you open it.It tastes really bad!I could not stomach it.My Mother could not either so I got capsules to put them in for her to take.So far it seems to be helping her, she does not seem to be feeling terrible like she use to.So I am sure this is helping.I would definitely use capsules if you cannot stomach the taste or smell.It comes with a glass dropper.The directions are simple and to take daily under the tongue.Working your way up to a full syringe which is a lot!I would definitely take it slow if you plan on using this and keep in mind that it is very strong and potent and not for everyone.Sample was provided to me complimentary in exchange for my honest unbiased review.

I was excited to try this product out and wanted to give it a try.My Sister was expecting a baby when I ordered it and wanted to make one for her.I love that they include everything you need except the scissors and sharpie is what you will need from home.The kit comes with the string for the ornaments to hang from, 1 template for the markings of where the string goes,2 different size wooden beads, pink pre cut felt, off white thick durable cardstock, & 3 various sized metal rings, as well as one glue.I was a little skeptic if we got enough string or glue but after cutting all the strings to the required length I had some left over.The glue was just enough and I ended up squeezing out the last drops toward the end of getting my cardstock glued together.I was very pleased with the quality of the products they are definitely 5 star.I had to dock off one star because this did not come with any printed instructions.The only thing you get regarding instructions is a sheet of paper with a colored picture of the project printed on it and a link to a video to show you how to do it. I ended up going to this link and found the video and followed the instructions.I really wished the video would show how to actually hang the ornaments on.I think with the price of 44$ it is selling at they should have printed instructions and a better video tutorial in my opinion.I had trouble getting the string tied correctly because of the view and ended up messing up my cardstock and damaging it because I did not put the glue on the correct side & ended up placing the glue on the wrong side.The seller was kind enough to offer to send me replacements which I thought was a very nice thing to do.So just keep in mind they don't really show you step by step breakdown in the video of putting it all together, it is more like briefly going over what goes where in my opinion.I was expecting a step by step guide.I am a very detailed person so hopefully you will have a better experience than I did.Here is the link for the youtube tutorial: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=m1cUugVH2v4 Overall besides the cons for me it is a great quality product.Hopefully in the future they can include better instructions.You also can have an opportunity to make money from this.They include information on how to make these kits your own and selling them etc. which I thought was pretty neat.Sample was provided to me by Apostrophe S in exchange for my honest unbiased review.

2:46 Mins This piece of jewelry is beautiful.I love the pendant it is very attractive and adds a nice touch to my outfit.It has a nice durable thick chain, this is not your usual silver chain links where it can break easily.This one is thicker with the way it was made and even looks nice.You can adjust the lobster clasp to different lengths if you want to.The Pendant itself is very beautiful with its detailing and little crystals.You also have a turquoise stone like piece in the middle of the pendant which makes it look so elegant. I really like this pendant it has so much detail.The little part that holds the pendant from the chain keeps the pendant from turning around on you while you are wearing it which is nice.The back is plain so this feature is great to keep the front facing forward and you do not have to worry about it flipping around on you while you wear it. It is the perfect size and length.You can check out my video to see the details on this necklace.The pendant is made very well I have not had any of the crystals or turquoise stone fall out or chain break on me.It is a great piece to dress up your outfit.*Sample was provided to me at discount in exchange for my honest unbiased review.

This iPhone 6 4.7" case works well with my Moms new iPhone 6.Right out of the box it feels very sturdy and durable.It has cutouts for the volume up and down, muting ringer button, camera, power button, headphones & charging port.So far they worked great for her and I was able to test this out for her since she is new to the iPhone.I was able to use all functions just fine, It definitely comes in handy when you are out and about and forget you are running low on battery power.She is getting ready to leave back home to the islands and this will definitely help keep her prepared while at the airports since she has a stop or 2 before arriving to her destination. To operate and turn on you have to charge it up takes about 5 hours to charge there are 4 blue indicator lights that let you know how much 'juice' you got left on the battery case which is nice.You simply press the power button on the bottome left corner to turn the case on to charge your phone when low.To install your phone you would have to remove the top part of the case that slides out and then when sliding your phone in, you can simply close it back up. Another good thing about this case is that it has a kickstand located on the back.This will come in handy and when not in use simply fold it back into its storage slot.I have 1 con about this case it does not include an adapter for the headphone port, usually the battery cases include this for the 6 or 6plus.That is why I give it a 4 star, it would be nice if they included that.Overall it is definitely very useful and the quality seems good, and would definitely add some protection to your phone.It is going to add some weight to your phone so keep that in mind.It also does not include any charging cable, you would have to use your cord that came with your  phone. I would not suggest using any other cord anyway personally unless you want one as a backup.I always use the manufacturer cord unless it has to be replaced.My Mother definitely appreciates a case like this and really likes it.*Complimentary Sample was provided in exchange for my honest unbiased evaluation.

I love chickpeas but never had it in a flour form, so I was eager to try this out.My toddler loves chickpeas as well so I wanted to make something out of this for us to try.I ended up making zuchinni flour bread off a recipe I found on the internet and it was super easy.I am definitely a beginner when cooking with these kind of flours and this recipe I found on youtube was so simple and easy, they come out looking like a pancake and taste yummy!!Definitely a great healthier alternative to eat bread since this is gluten free. The bag has its organic seal which is always great, I love when companies that claim to be organic actually have that on the product itself.So if you are wondering if it has that seal it definitely does and is also a product of India in case you are wondering. I know I like to know things like this when looking for organic. This definitely has some great flavor and my family loves it!I can't wait to explore more recipes cooking with the rest of this flour.If you have never tried chickpea flour I would definitely recommend giving it a try.*Complimentary sample was provided in exchange for my honest unbaised evaluation.

My Husband and I have been missing out!Wow this definitely makes a nice Vegetable Dalia!I have never tried Indian food, like ever.I definitely had an interest in trying their foods but never imagined to try and make it myself.I attempted to make vegetable dalia from this and oh my goodness this was soo delish!!!My Husband loved it!!!It is so easy to prepare I suggest looking up some Youtube Videos for a recipe, specifically Vegetable Dalia by Nisha Madhulika.This bag comes in a decent size and was plenty for my small family of 3.It is also USDA Organic with the seal on the actual product.Sometimes companies claim they are 'organic' but when the product arrives, it definitely does not have anything indicating it is indeed certified.Overall I am very pleased with this product and definitely thnking of buying more since it makes a nice veggie dalia.I am very new to cooking with this wheat dalia and so glad I gave it a try.Very good quality!*Complimentary Sample provided in exchange for my honest unbaised evaluation.

I never use flour anymore to cook with so I was pretty excited to try out this organic Wheat flour or Wheat CHakki Atta.I have never ever used this type of flour to cook with and I finally tried making my daughter and I some flour pancakes.We usually use a banana and eggs to make pancakes, so this was totally new.I liked the way they turned out, they tasted really good and my daughter loves them.This bag is a 2lb bag and I was happy to see the USDA Organic seal on the actual packaging.I also was happy to see this was a product of India, I have tried their other organic stuff they offer and so far I am loving their brand.I am definitely excited to venture off into making other exciting things than just pancakes with this flour.So far I love the quality of this wheat flour and the taste.I am also excited to try some Indian Recipes with this as well.*Complimentary Sample provided in exchange for my honest unbiased evaluation.

3:26 Mins I really like this gypsy boho maxi full length skirt.The white is perfect for the summer if I want to wear something like a skirt, it went great with my black tank top.The material is all cotton as well as the lining inside, I did notice that you can still see a little bit through but not the type of see through that a leggings has if that makes sense.That cotton lining inside provides you some coverage.I am 5'4 and had to pull this skirt up past my waistline because it would have dragged up some dirt since it rested right on the tops of my feet.I wore sandals with it, so I would definitely recommend getting a size up to make sure you have room to pull up on the waistline if you are short like me. The waistline is not stretchable and can get uncomfortable if you do not get the right sizing.I got a size 10 and it fit great, so I would definitely recommend checking your size accurately and picking maybe a size up depending on your body type.The tiered layers that run all the way down the skirt is nice and gives the skirt some texture and design instead of a simple plain white maxi skirt.The zipper on this skirt is nicely hidden, so when you wear a top that is waistline length you do not have to worry about it showing.I would definitely hang dry this skirt as well because of the material and possible shrinking.Overall I am very happy with quality and fit.*Complimentary Sample was provided to me during a promotional offer in exchange for my honest unbiased evaluation.

2:50 Mins What a cute little plastic ladybug toothbrush holder.I thought this was really cute and fun for my daughter to use for her toothbrush.It definitely makes that part of the day more fun for her and special since she has her own special holder.It comes with 3 suctions cups to put on in the back which holds well to glass.I would recommend being careful when repositioning since the suction cups may come off.You have to kind of screw them in but they don't come off easily which is a good thing, but also it may come out when removing.The suction cups are removable so if it were to come off during removal you can easily put them back into place.This is also versatile you can keep your kids little chalk markers or crayons in if you wanted to.Or maybe keep your pens in there and use it as a holder in the kitchen for quick access.The plastic is strong enough to hold her toothbrush and toothpaste.The opening to slide things in is not that big or small it is the perfect size for a toddlers toothbrush.Check out my video for more information.*Sample was provided at a discount in exchange for my honest unbiased evaluation.

4:17 Mins I have tried URPOWER's single pocket running belt and liked that one so far.This one is even better in my opinon because of the dual pockets this one has.It allows me extra space for anything I would like to take with me while out and about or enjoying some recreation activities.The thickness of the elastic band is very durable and no different in quality than their single pocket one I have tried.The material for the pockets is made of neoprene which is very durable, waterproof, and tear resistant.It is nice to know that I can depend on using this for a long time, especialy with a toddler you do not know what kind of shenanigans my daughter and I will get into lol. If you are a mother of a toddler you know accidents happen, water is spilled, juice tumbles over, food thrown, etc. so this handy little travel waist pouch will definitely be handy to keep my phone and other things protected when out and about.I was very impressed at how this 1 1/2" width can extend bigger than I had anticipated it would.The 2 pockets are both different sizes the big one is about 11" at the opening, the smaller one is 6".That is a pretty decent size for essential things I would definitely use and need, like my ID,Credit Card, Keys, money, & iphone 6Plus.The bigger pocket fits my 6Plus nicely with some extra room for keys.The other running belt they have which is single can only hold my cell phone.So I am really liking this one much better due to the fact they have one big pocket and a smaller pocket for other various things.This is comfortable to wear and the waist belt can be adjusted to fit me or my Husband perfectly.It can fit wasit lines of 31.5 to 55.This will definitely will come in handy this summer.So far I really like this one better than the single pocket one.*Complimentary Sample was provided to me in exchange for my honest unbiased evaluation.

2:17 Mins This running belt from URPOWER  is pretty neat.I have to be honest, I have seen these floating around on my Facebook Page but never really paid any attention.I thought this belt was way too thin for my liking, and how in the world is this going to fit my valuables in while I am out and about? This running belt is very compact, thin, and very lightweight.It measures about 1 1/2" wide and can extend to fit various waist sizes from 23.5 to 47.What is really neat about this belt that I underestimated how big the single pocket is.The pocket in the front is covered by reflective strips so when you are out at night you can be visible to those driving, walking, etc. It is very well made and very durable, the material it is made of is neoprene.Making this wawterproof and tear resistant, so I can definitely be confident that this will last me a long time.It will also keep your things dry from rain, water rides, etc. I think this wait pack not only works as a running belt for outdoor recreations but also as a travel belt for theme parks and such.This will definitely keep your things in one safe accessible spot, but also keep it dry from the water rides, or any other moisture.I live in Cali. and they have theme parks with water etc. so this definitely will be handy during those type of trips.The pocket in the front measures out to be 9" long and fits my iphone 6Plus perfectly snug as well as some money,ID,Credit Card,if I needed to carry such things with me. The elastic band is very nice and thick and has to extension clips on both sides to adjust to various waist sizes.The plastic belt clip makes it easy for you to take it off and put it on quickly.I like the whole design because it is not bulky or something overpowering when you travel,excercise, etc. It is nice and sleek.I would definitely recommend this if you are looking for a good waterproof running belt or waist pack.They also have one with 2 pockets for those of us who like to carry a lot more things with us.Overall I am very pleased with this belt so far great quality.*Complimentary sample provided in exchange for my honest unbiased evaluation.

2:45 Mins How adorable are these ribbons?
