Panasonic is the master of home health products!  I own this in addition to their nano hair dryer and skin care steamer.  They are all well-built and top in their class!  They aren't cheap but are well worth the money!This scalp massager is no exception.  It is supposed to increase blood profusion to the scalp and encourage healthy hair growth, and perhaps even more hair growth (after all, rogaine with minoxidil works by increasing blood flow too!)  Now I don't know if these claims are scientifically proven but what I can tell you is this just makes your head feel good!  And for that reason alone it's worth owning and using!Thankfully this charger is safe to use in the U.S. as the specification is 100-240v.  So no need for a special transformer!5 stars!  Make your scalp happy!

Perfect for my Oxygen sensor (Denso 234-9005) on my 2004 Honda CRV EX.  Worked just as I expected!  Yes you can do the job with an open wrench but if you want to use a torque wrench, there is no other option!5 stars, a great tool!

A beautiful look and fit for my 2001 Gibson ES-335.  It came with 2 sets of screw lengths.  I didn't have to drill anything!  (Thank god!)  I completely trust Schaller with my $3000 investment, this thing feel solid!  As a bonus, the strap locks are also compatible with my Fender branded strap buttons that came with my 1995 American Standard Stratocaster.  (they are likely also Schaller but say Fender on them.)5 stars!  Meets my expectations perfectly!

I use it to mic my amp.  It is well-built, study and folds compactly (26").  It may be a bit short for most singers, as the max height with boom is effectively 60-65"  (depending how you position the boom).  Totally fine if you're sitting to play (guitar, keyboards).5 stars.  Terrific value, just make sure it fits you.

Works just as described!  I'm using the on a Dell laptop that uses the Apple display port. (Apple licenses it for free!). I use both the VGA and HDMI which worked perfectly!  This is much cheaper than the Dell or Apple versions of the same thing!  Go with this one!

This is a fantastic mattress!  I got the queen size to use for guests and wow, I was impressed.  It's very firm and supportive.  Soft enough but not springy.  Lightweight but keeps its shape incredibly well.  Some have posted that it doesn't even need a box spring on bed with slats such as metal bunk beds.  I haven't tried that myself but it is plenty thick.  The package is pretty amazing it come vacuum stuffed into a bag.  I was able to work it out of the draw string bag without ripping the bag (I was hoping to reuse it). But after I let the air in, it expanded to impressive proportions, so there is no humanly possible way to get it back in. (I guess I just need another purpose for the bag.).  I will probably get a mattress bag for it from the sleep shop when I move next.  Until then, my guests and I are enjoying this mattress!5 Stars!

I own a 1995 Fender American Standard Stratocaster that I bought new.  Until recently I never wore a strap because I only played sitting down.  However I've since started standing to play and decided I needed some secure straps.  I bought this set based on the great reviews.  I was preparing to replace the original strap buttons on my stratocaster when I noticed a curious thing.  The strap locks were IDENTICAL to my original buttons!  I had never heard that strats come built in with strap locks and being the original owner, and never having taking the guitar in for servicing, I was 100% sure they weren't replaced.  So I tested it with the Schaller strap locks I have on my Gibson ES-355, and found it's a Schaller style for sure.  Wonderfully secure feeling!  Amazing quality!

I own 2 Gibsons guitars: a 2013 Les Paul Standard and a 2001 ES-335.  Both of these guitars are coated in nitrocellulose, a beautiful but somewhat temperamental finish (reacts with many chemicals). Nitrocellulose is only found on vintage and the most expensive guitars, and requires special treatment.  Many have said that Pledge furniture polish works wonders but this is a silicone containing product which is an absolute no-no for these guitars.  Many in the guitar community and professional luthiers swear by a product called virtuoso.  I agree it's a good product but ridiculously expensive.  Gibson sells a "Pump Polish" but really it's not a polish at all, but more of a cleaner only.I noticed that Zymol recently released a special guitar polish formula, and I went back to the boards to read about it and I discovered that many people have been using the car polish version with excellent results.  It is an all natural formula WITHOUT silicone. I tried it on a small area of my ES-335 and I was really impressed.  I ended up striping all the hardware and giving it a full polish up.  The guitar looks brand new!  It took some elbow grease but that's exactly what you want, something gentle to prevent you from overdoing it.  I believe this fits the bill perfectly. The best part is its relatively cheap compared with Virtuoso and Zymols dedicated guitar polish, which is most likely just a similar formula to his one.5 stars!  Great on guitars!

I have a Gibson Les Paul Standard from 2013 with burstbucker pros.  Supposedly the burstbucker pro is wound to sound like the original PAF (how they actually sounded), while the Classic 57 is wound to the original design specification of PAFs (how they were supposed to be made). I just picked up a gorgeous Gibson ES-335 from 2001 with the Classic 57, and man, I like this way better than the burstbucker pro!  Both are great pickups, but these have such great bite in the lead and smooth in neck I can stop listening to it.  Every note rings so nicely.  Between the 2 pickups I can find great jazzy/bluesy tones and some to just rock out!  I can't say enough about it, except I'm really neglecting my chores with all the time I'm spending now enjoying these!5 stars!  Don't expect anything less than awesome!

I have been a long time Slingbox user, thru multiple generations of products.  My wife and I use this on a daily basis to watch live and recorded TV from Japan at our home in California.  The technology is wonderful, but has unfortunately been plagued by the recent addition of forced advertisements.  Slingbox is still the leader in Place-shifting but has made some regrettable choices in an effort to improve their revenue stream at the expense of customer user experience.What is "Place-shifting"?I have long been a fan and strong advocate for the technology of "place-shifting" which allows the ability to watch and control your personal media (cable boxes, Tivo, other DVR systems) remotely from outside your home.  Slingbox practically invented this market segment and although there have been several competitors over the years (Sony, Hava, Belkin to name a few), Slingbox still remains the leader in this segment.Ad-supported SlingPlayer (Read on for hints how to block)Since winning a technology lawsuit that forced several competitors to drop out of the market, combined with the increasing pressure from expanding On-demand services (Netflix, Amazon, HBO Go, etc) Slingbox has found themselves in a position to attempt to grow their revenue from ad-supported players, introduced March 2015.  Since that time, Slingbox has undergone a revolt from customers who found ads intrusive and severely impacting a previously pleasant viewing experience (screen viewing area decreased as a result of creating ad space).  It should be pointed out that the SlingPlayers for Mobile Devices, (a $14.99 app) was and still is devoid of ads.  The desktop/web-based SlingPlayer requires watching a pre-roll video ad that lasts about 15secs.  In addition there are banner ads below the viewing screen and above the guide.  In full screen mode, the ads fortunately disappear.  There are some clever ways of blanking the ad banner boxes by changing your hosts file and redirecting known ad-servers to bogus IP addresses (usually the loopback address 127.0.01).  There are special hosts files you can download on the web.  However even these maneuvers which help reduce the "screen clutter" of ads, do not fix the fact that part of the viewing screen size was sacrificed to make room for the banner boxes.So, what's new with the M2?Sorry to disappoint here, but the short answer is NOTHING really.  It's just a bundling change.  That was confirmed in an inquiry I made to the SlingMedia Marketing Department.  Indeed, in my tests, there has been no change in operation or performance from that of the M1. The M2 bundle is basically the M1 hardware plus the unlimited mobile ad-supported SlingPlayers for your tablet or smartphone.  That's it!  See below under price for a discussion about which may make more sense you.  (That's all that matters in a bundling change.)Watching on real TV?Since the SlingCatcher was discontinued several years ago, there hasn't been a good solution for watching Slingbox on an actual TV.  Several 3rd party boxes have come and gone but none provided a stable and clean connection (Boxee, Netgear, Sony).  Recently ChromeCast and Roku added a channel for SlingBox but it requires a SlingPlayer on your mobile to work which doesn't make sense that you need 2 devices to make this work (room for more problems).  SlingPlayer on an ipad can be transmitted to an AppleTV device thru airplay but again, you need 2 devices (and only the person with an ipad in hand can use it).  To date the best way I have found to accomplish this is making an HTPC and installing the desktop application or using the web-based player.  In full screen, there are no ads, and the experience is actually quite good.  However, creating an HTPC requires alot of technical know-how that most consumers don't really have.  Thus overall, this is a disappointing area for SlingBox.Watching on the go!  (Your Smartphone!)Attention!  There are now FREE apps for both iPad and iPhone!  These were released July 16, 2015.  The catch?  Everytime you connect, you have to watch a 30sec commercial to get things started.  Sometimes when you switch apps (say to respond to a text message) and go back, you may have to reconnect an watch the 30sec commercial again.  It gets a little old, and when I don't pause my show beforehand and I finally connect again, I find I've missed several minutes of the show and need to go back.  But hey, its free right?  For $14.99 a pop, you can get an ad-free version.  Although I'm not thrilled about shelling out more money, at least there is a choice!  The app itself (outside of ads) is actually very well designed.  You get access to your actual full-featured remote, in a perfect graphical replica to control your TV that appears and disappears at the touch of a screen.  The settings are easy to understand and change.  There is an excellent guide to shows (based on your location and provider that you select during inital setup).  I'm personally not a huge mobile TV viewer but overall, I'd have to say they've done a good job with the apps here.  What's more, the free apps also work with legacy Slingboxs!  I can watch both my M1 and my Slingbox Pro-HDs with the new free app.Setup?Easy.  No playing around with port setups on your firewall.  Just plug in everything (LAN cable too) and go to the setup website (you must be on the same local network for setup).  After answering a few questions about what cablebox (or other device) you are controlling and running a few operational tests, you are done!  Much easier than the past versions.  The only issue is the port number can no longer be customized, only a problem for network geeks (but even I can live with it).How is the picture quality?Overall, its great.  But keep in mind, this all depends on THREE factors:1. Upload speed at the source (where your Slingbox is located)2. Download speed at the viewing location (where your computer, tablet or phone is)3. The internet backbone latency.  These are all the interconnects between your source ISP and your destination ISP.  This is especially important for overseas connections that may rely on limited network connectionsI stream from Japan(Fiberoptic connection about 50Mbps up) to California(TWC about 30Mbps down), crossing the Pacific Ocean (where ever that line runs).  I can usually get HD quality with 2-4K link.  It is actually quite impressive!  When I watch on my home 37" screen, it's almost like I'm watching local TV!  There are some issues with fast moving things (sports especially) that take extra processing and get locally pixelated but its really not that terrible.  (I watched the 2015 Women's World Cup from my M1, and it was decent quality).  A word about network: I would strongly recommend using an Ethernet connection if possible.  There are really no problems with a WiFi connection, but a hardwire connection in general will provide more reliability (after all, you won't be around to troubleshoot any issue as that is kinda the point of the slingbox).Price (and your options)I'm not entirely sure I understand the price structure at this point in time.  The current Slingbox product lineup includes the M1, M2, 350 and 500.  The M1 currently sells for $120 which other than the name itself, is the same hardware as the M2 (this was confirmed by Slingbox PR office in an inquiry by me).  Indeed, I notice absolutely no performance difference between the M1 & M2.  The M2 sells for $199.  The $70 premium bundles the unlimited free SlingPlayer app (with ads) that are not included with other packages.  If you consider that $70 would purchase 4 SlingPlayer apps (without ads), this likely isn't the choice for you at this pricepoint.  You would probably be much better off purchasing an M1 plus 1 or 2 ad-free SlingPlayers separately ($150 total).  The Slingbox 350 is $95, has excellent quality (HD quality like M1/M2), but lacks WiFi (I suspect the 350 will be discontinued very shortly, but an OK choice if you don't need the WiFi and want to save a few bucks).  The supposed "flagship" Slingbox 500 currently costs $235, has no improvement in quality and features an HDMI input that has serious technical concerns given that Slingbox does not allow HDCP protected content.  I cannot recommend the 500.  Thus, the M1 seems to provide the highest value of the entire lineup.Overall, I still have to give the product 2 stars.  I continue use the Slingbox on a daily basis but I really feel this product could be so much better if the ads could just disappear all together (especially on the PC desktop/webplayer versions of the player).  It is a hard pill to swallow especially for those of us who have been long time users.  I also feel that the value of the M2 (at $199 with ad-supported unlimited mobile player downloads) is not as good as the M1 (at $120 with exact same hardware and option to buy ad-free mobile players at $15 a piece)2 stars.  I wish I could give more...Slingbox it's in your hands!

The clip that shipped with my so called "professional" mic stand had a plastic base to screw into the metal boom.  It doesn't take a genius to realize that situation wasn't going to last long.  Sure enough the clip wore out.  This Shure clip has a metal base, and can take a lot of abuse!  The swivel is also well damped to maintain mic angle, and still be easy to adjust.  It fits a large variety of mic brands as well, not just 57 & 58s.5 stars!  Rock on!

Wow.  Honestly, I was a bit skeptical about whether there would be any difference between this hairdryer and the $20 ones I have been using my whole life.  I couldn't be more wrong!  This dryer is truly head and shoulders above anything I've tried before.  Please read on to hear about the technology, results and how to properly use this should you be convinced to take the plunge!The TechnologyRather amazing technology here from the engineers at Panasonic.  Using a high electric potential they create negative ions which trap water molecules from the air and combine them with the hot air jet of a conventional dryer.  By doing this, they buffer the air jet with moisture which in turn prevents damage to hair.  Panasonic has been leaders in this area of technology which is why Japan enjoys the best selection of such hair dryers.The ResultsAs other reviewers have pointed out, hair is dried quicker and with softer, shinier results!  My hair is short, but for most women with longer hair, the results should be even better!  It is designed to run cooler to protect hair from heat, so if you dry your hair everyday you would significantly reduce cumulative damage to hair.Before you use:You must be aware of the electrical requirements for using this fine hair dryer.  Since it was designed for the Japanese domestic market, it is made for their electrical system, not the U.S.  Although the plugs in Japan and the U.S. look the same, the electricity supply is very different.  I am an electrical engineer and I have lived in Japan, continue to use many Japanese products in the U.S. so I understand the differences well and how to work around them.  In Japan they use 100 volts, however in the U.S. we use 120 volts.  That means by plugging in a Japanese product directly into the U.S. system, you would overload the product by 20%.  For a high wattage device like a hair dryer that is a considerable amount over the intended design!  Indeed some other reviewers have posted pictures of melted dryers and claimed they were defective.  However, if properly used this should not happen.  In fact, I noticed that when I use mine, the hair dryer itself stays quite cool.See my pictures below which show the electric sticker saying 100v (if it were ok for U.S. it would have a range that included 120v).  I have also posted 2 pictures of my dryer plugged in to a transformer.  Note the first one with the power off, my voltage reader measures 105volts (this is close enough to 100v).  The second one has the power on, and it is consuming 1148 watts.  (That is more than many microwaves, so you can imagine with 20% overload why people were experiencing bad smells, melting and early failure!)I warn that a proper stepdown transformer (capable of at least 1200 watts minimum for this dryer) will be expensive.  But used within its capacity will last forever.  I personally recommend Japanese made transformers from companies such as Sanyo, Nissyo or Toyozumi.  I have heard poor quality control on Chinese made ones, so given the high cost of the dryer (or any other Japanese product you would consider, i.e. Panasonic Nanocare steamer) I would invest in the best transformer.  Furthermore, I would not hesitate to purchase a Japanese transformer used on eBay as these are very durable items and you can often get a great deal (they come up from time-to-time.)5 stars!  When used properly will provide incredibly healthy looking hair!

I previous purchased one of the many assorted snipits of shrink tube on Amazon for my random electrical projects and repairs. I found that this size was one of 2 I used most, and rather than repurchase another assortment, I decided to get a big strip. It works great! It has terrific shrinking capacity and so in a pinch can be used on smaller cords, however just be aware that it will make the diameter of the cable larger if you are considering passing it thru a hole or plug end.I received one continuous piece of tubing, between 19-20 feet long, as advertised. Please note shipping will take about 3 weeks as it comes from China.5 stars!  Shrinks and highly durable!

I previous purchased one of the many assorted snipits of shrink tube on Amazon for my random electrical projects and repairs.  I found that this size was one of 2 I used most, and rather than repurchase another assortment, I decided to get a big strip.  It works great!  It has terrific shrinking capacity and so in a pinch can be used on smaller cords, however just be aware that it will make the diameter of the cable larger if you are considering passing it thru a hole or plug end.I received one continuous piece of tubing, just slightly greater than 10 feet(as advertised).  Please note shipping will take about 3 weeks as it comes from China.5 stars!

Admittedly I agree with many of the comments of the other reviews here.  Oil pans of today are no longer just buckets anymore.  They have splash guards and easy pour spouts for recycling.  On first inspection, it is obvious that this oil pan has none of those features.  It is a simple plastic bucket.  Therefore it is no surprise that people have the complaints they do.  I'm really surprised people expected otherwise!What this pan does do well is general small capacity fluids, that is, scooters, motorcycles and things of that nature.  I would never think of using this on a car!  It is small, lightweight and cleans easily without costing a bundle.5 stars, but know its limitations!

I bought this for a small electric 4-cycle Honda generator for emergency electrical backup.  Because the generator is something that I use VERY infrequently it is essential that I remove the fluids (oil/gas) with each use.  I needed something small(for convenience of space) and reliable, as I don't want flammable liquids falling in the wrong place on an electric generator.  (Bad combination).  I also use this for my 4-cycle 150cc scooter for regular oil changes.After its field test, I was very happy with the performance of this funnel.  The long neck is especially useful for keeping some separation from the fill hole and pouring location.  That is essential for ensuring a safe fill.  I used it for both gas and oil, wiping it down between one and the other.  I will say that it is a bit tough to wipe inside the long neck, but nothing a twisted paper towel couldn't handle.  I store it with a paper towel crunched in both ends to keep dirt out.  When ready for use I pull them out, wipe the outside and I'm ready to go!5 stars!

I'm a huge fan of prime lens and 50mm is one of those sweet spot focal lengths that should be in every camera bag, if not on the camera itself!  Canon produced a massive hit with the affordable f1.8 50mm, dubbed the nifty-fifty.  It was succeeded by the II, which sadly saw some corners cut in build quality with the transition to a plastic base.  (While I have commented in prior reviews that I challenge the "need" for metal mounts in smaller, lighter lenses, I can't help but admit that I prefer a metal mount.). This latest iteration of the venerable "nifty-fifty" sees the return of the metal mount and upgrades the focus mechanism to the silently speedy STM stepping motor!OpticsWhat's not to love about a f1.8 lens?  The optics are excellent as you would expect from the reputation of its prior versions.  Talk about a fast lens, you can take some pretty incredible shots in poor light conditions with this.  Beautiful bokeh!  It provides excellent separation of your subject from the background, as if they jump out of the picture.  I was very pleased with my results on a recent flower viewing trip.  Terrific color representation, minimal chromatic aberration and distortion.  It will not disappoint!Focus mechanismIf you haven't tried STM yet, prepare to be amazed.  Fast and quiet!  Great for video work too.  I'm very happy with the Canon STM lineup.Build QualityAs mentioned previously, the metal mount has returned. (I can hear the cheering!). The barrel feels a little less sturdy than the 24mm and 40mm pancakes, but all in all, it's an improvement over the prior version.  Considering its price, it is quite an impressive piece of work.PriceCheap, it would be hard to imagine anyone not happy with the priceMy recommendation is to run outside right now and buy this lens.  You won't be disappointed.5 stars.  Thank you Canon!
This is such a smart product:Saves water (lots!)Saves time (I hardly have to water anymore!)Protection/stability for tree!5 stars

I'm very impressed by the quality of this cable!  I use this to plug XLR dynamic cardioid mic (Shure SM58) into my effects processor to add compression, chorus, delay and reverb to voice and instruments.  Sounds terrific!  This feels like a very durable cable built to last!5 stars

I owned a Fender Deville 212 prior to getting the 410 version III.  The basic amp design and sound is nearly identical and has gone thru very little change in the near 20 years since Fender released this best seller.  This amp is quite a familiar sight in many studios and on stages of both professional and superstar musicians.  It embodies a classic sound that fender is well known for.Improvements over prior versionWhy should you consider an upgrade?  By far an away the most important change is the volume pot redesign.  As anyone who has ever played on the older version can tell you, there was hardly any control for the volume of this beast.  The slightest movement in the knob would cause all hell to break loose.  Now the new knob has a more linear and therefore more manageable control.  Thank god!  Actually there are some good 3rd party mod kits to change the old ones, but who wants to go thru that trouble or risk damaging their amp.  The version III finally gets the knob correct!The silver panel for knobs has become more user friendly by becoming black.  I used to have to put masking tape labels on to see in dark rooms. Not with this one.  Very easy to read, even in low light.The power tubes now have a protective cage.  I never had much of a problem with prior versions but I definitely feel a lot safer storing and pulling things out from the back cabinet (I keep some heavy duty speaker cables back there).ProsMagnificent cleans!  Although it takes pedals extremely well, lately I find myself just plugging straight in!Linear volume knob (See above)Loud enough for larger venues.  Need more?  Mic it!8 ohms (versus 212 that is 4 ohms) plugs into many more speaker cabinetsGreat cover!Incredibly popular with 20 years of production means easy to find servicing and partsConsHeavy!  A cart is an absolute must, as is a strong back and able hands.Would prefer a leather strap rather than the rubber as it is scary to think what would happen if it brokeToo loud for home practice (unless you have an attenuator, I have a Weber Mass)Circuit made on PCB (lacks the durability of hand soldered boutique amps)A little pricy, but worth it!5 stars!

Perfect fit as you would expect for your PW100T.  Has room for cables and a microphone too.  Store, transport and protects!  It's a bit expensive considering how inexpensive the speakers are, but it is definitely a nice addition!  If only they had something to help with their subwoofer.5 stars!

Fantastic for a medium sized venue!The first time I heard it I was impressed, when I found out the price, I was in disbelief!  Beautiful amplification, and flat frequency response (just makes your sound louder, no tint to sound).  Can take keyboards, synthesizer directly or any line in from other instruments (I have DI inputs from Guitar and bass too).  Totally scalable with "PowerLink" (via XLR cables) as you can daisy-chain as many of these as you want to fit your venue or number of inputs.  Each additional unit adds 2 more inputs to your mix.  I personally use this directly from my Nord Piano 2 in combination with a Powerwerks Subwoofer PW 112S which together make an awesome tower pair (the subwoofer takes a speaker pole and acts as a mount for the tower).  There is an optional carrying case which makes a very nice set  Powerwerks Carrybag5 stars

Wow, I can't stop looking for things around the house to tidy up with these fine velcro wraps!  Each is a touch on the long side, and  probably could stand to be a little shorter (as I find myself making alot of turns around the cord.)  I suppose I could cut it.  I find these great for the rats nest of cords behind the TV, my office desk, and all my instrument cables/audio gear.A tip: When wrapping, try to keep the softer, plush side on the outside to avoid unwanted gripping of rugs, speaker grille, etc.5 stars!

If you make your own instrument cables or custom pedal board cables, you should look no further than Mogami.  Very easy to work with and solder.  The cable itself is very flexible and comparing the cross sectional core and shield to other cable brands, there is no doubt the Mogami is superior.  It performs just as beautifully as it looks!5 stars.

I have come to trust Amazon cables for their quality and value.  These cables are no exception.  I like that they come in two colors which helps identify them in a cable tangle.  I would definitely buy again!5 stars.

Awesome!  Enough juice to charge my iPad mini.  Cheap enough to get a bunch and stow them all over the house and office so I never need to go far to find a charging station.  It will also reliable power my Raspberry Pi and include a nice cable for it.

A perfect replacement plug!  Easy to install.  A tip, before cutting off the old plug, mark the wire side that goes to the fatter prong. That way you can make sure you wire it the same way on the new one.5 stars

Great! With this baby, I find myself turning on my main computer less and less.  Now I can type real emails and not be bogged down with correcting all my fat-fingered screen typed mistakes. Thanks you!  Occasionally will drop a connection, but after waiting a second it comes back.  I have a strong suspicion the problem is with the iPad connection algorithm rather than the keyboard.5 stars.

This has no grip on my dash.  It slides around with every turn.  On the plus side, Amazon was very kind about allowing me to return it.  I switched to back to the window mount.  It is now legal in Calofornia to place your car navigation system on the window if you use the LEFT lower corner.  Yes, Left.1 stars.  Didn't work.
So many reasons to make this your pick!Feels good in the handDecent gripWarm soundDoesn't break5 stars!

Perfect.  I've bought a lot of Neutrik connectors and plugs and I've never been failed by their quality.  This one is no exception.  Solid feeling connection and very useful for extending instrument and speaker cables in a pinch!5 stars.  Does not disappoint!

It's great having different sizes for different jobs.  They are a bit on the lightweight side (compared to my old one) but that appears not to affect their function (they feel quite sturdy) and look good.  My only complaint is the worse than expected drainage (I used to have a net type in the past).  It's especially problematic with pasta to get the water completely out.  I find that I'm changing my technique from an up-down motion to more of a swirl.  That improves the drainage to a satisfactory level.  (It's just that I was taught up-down, so at first it feels a bit off, but it works!)4 stars.  Work well and look good in kitchen.

You use this soldering flux pen like a highlighter.  It's a little hard to use but not as messy as the flux that used to come in the shoe polish containers.  Basic idea is paint the connection areas with the felt tip before applying heat.  All my joints appear very solid so far.  This is an improvement, I just wish there were an even cleaner way to apply flux.4 stars

Genuine Gibson truss rod cover, comes in shrink wrap cardboard packaging.  Includes 2 screws.  Identical to my 2013 Les Paul standard.  Not sure if the PRTR-030 matches other years in addition to 2013.  I am very happy with it.5 stars

Either I have not been taking this long enough to notice any difference or its effects are more cumulative than immediate.  We just came back from a week vacation in Utah that involved a LOT of hiking.  I have a host of aches and sore joints ready for some relief. I began taking this product the night we returned home.  Honestly, my knees are recovering from the trip at the same pace I'd normally expect.  I might be sleeping a little better but that could just be from the sheer joy of being home in my own bed.  I think this product can have a great PLACEBO effect.  If you believe it's going to help, you will probably perceive some results.  If you are skeptical, you likely won't.

Not much to say here you don't already know.  Hefty bags are an industry leader and can always be counted on for quality.  These gallon sized bags are large enough for a variety of uses, heavy enough for long term freezer storage and the slider makes them easy to close and get a secure seal.  The price is fair, considering they are delivered to your door.  My only problem was with the way they were packaged.  They shipped in an envelope rather than a box so the container was mashed on arrival.  It didn't effect the bags themselves but it does effect how they store in my pantry.

My doctor says I'm supposed to take vitamin D supplements.  I don't feel any different when I take them, but supposedly its better for me.  He has all those years of medical school so he probably knows what he's talking about.  These are about double the dose he recommended so I take one every other day.  The ingredients are similar to what I usually buy at Costco.  If you or your doctor think you don't get enough Vitamin D from natural sunlight, these would be a good choice.

Mmmmm.  Milk chocolate is my favorite guilty pleasure.  Add in some caramel and I'm in heaven.  Of course, some miss-guided folks prefer dark chocolate.  This giant tin will provide their chocolate fix too, since it has both milk and dark chocolates.  Each is individually wrapped, a generous couple of bites- rich enough so that you might even be able to hold it to one rather than a handful.  The decorative, reusable tin serves it up in style making it suitable for a gift.  I took this in to the office and now we are all happily hopped up on chocolate and productivity has never been higher!

Based on some other reviews, I chose these over the boot cut version.  They certainly are comfortable though they look considerably more "frumpy" than in the picture.  But hey, I don't think the wildlife on the trail will mind.  Love the fabric, love the drawstring to cinch the waste exactly to fit.  I have these in the capri length too.  Zion National Park, here I come!

Lots of conflicting reviews here regarding sizing on this particular boot.  Based on what others had said, I ordered up a half size.  I really don't think that was necessary.  I wound up adding a pretty thick insole and wearing heavy socks to tighten up the fit so that worked out OK.  I haven't had them long enough to comment on long term wear, but dang they were cute and comfortable the first day!

Due to a glitch in the ordering system (which has since been fixed) I was sent a half size smaller than what I ordered.  They actually fit fine though so I'd say they tend to run large.  The style is adorable, the heel is not to high- and actually looks higher than it really is from being a "kitten heel".  They give you replacement heel tips so you can swap them out when they get worn.  Yes, these are "Pleather fashion boots" but the quality and styling is pretty good for the price.  They are dressy enough to wear with a skirt but will work great with leggings too.

These are even cuter in person than in the picture.  They fit true to size.  If you are worried that the Velcro will make them look too sporty to wear with a dress, don't be.  I bought these at the end of summer so I haven't gotten the chance to wear them for a full day yet but they were comfortable walking around the house.

For me, these were too wide.  One strap is adjustable, but if I set the buckle at the last hole, the other straps are loose enough to have "gap-osis" and the buckle digs into my foot.  If you have wide feet, these might work fine for you though.  The platform sole seemed quite cushy too.  You'd think that would be a good thing, but to me, it felt like it wouldn't give very good support.  Other than the fit, they were cute.  I exchanged mine for the Clarks Women's Hayla Theme Wedge Sandal which fit my foot better and were equally cute.

Vaseline products set the standard for over-all body lotions.  This particular variety provides instant relief for dry skin and lasting moisture to repair problem dryness.  I love that they left out the overwhelming perfume-y smell that so many lotions have.  For me, it absorbed well, moisturized well and felt great on my skin.  On top of that, you get a giant bottle for less than a tiny tube of something that wouldn't work any better.  Highly recommended.  One note: It did leave my hands feeling greasy.  I was OK with it on the back of my hands, but had to go rinse it off my palms.

These were cute boots and the quality seemed in line with the price point.  Unfortunately, they did not fit my feet.  I thought I'd be OK having chosen a rounded toe boot and ordered a half size up from what I normally wear.  Not only were they too short in the length but my toes felt cramped on the sides too.  Since these are "pleather" there was little hope of them stretching out to fit.If you can find a pair that fit, they wouldn't be a bad boot, provided you remember they are a "fashion" boot, not something designed for hiking or harsh weather.  Note: the top of the boot flares out which is great if you want to tuck some skinny jeans in but not so great if you want to wear a straight leg pant over the boot.  I had to return mine so I cannot comment on how well they might wear.

What's not to like here?  These have a cute design that didn't fade when heated, are thick enough to do the job, peel off the muffin easily and are affordably priced.  The little plastic packaging keeps their form pristine through shipping and storage in my pantry.  As others have mentioned, these are sized for old-school standard size muffin pans not the giant tins popular today.  If you have a thick muffin batter, you can often fill a standard size muffin more than recommended and bake an oversized muffin in a cup this size.  Don't try that with a runny batter though- it will just be a hot mess.Pan spray works fine for muffins and cupcakes too but sometimes it is just nice to have them baked in a paper to make them more festive and portable.  These met and exceeded my every expectation.

As you might guess from the small jar size, this product is intended for spot hydration, more than as an all-over body lotion.  When applied to large areas, it takes quite a while to rub in.  If I wanted to moisturize my legs, for example, I'd pick something else.  This cream is best dabbed on sparingly  for targeted moisturizing of specific areas, neck, elbows, knees.  The scent is light and though it takes a while to absorb, it must really get deep into the skin because the moisturizing effect is still noticeable the next morning.  One thing, I don't recommend it as a hand lotion.  It left my hands a strange mix of greasy and powdery and sent me running for the sink and a bar of soap.

Once I finally got this installed, it works wonderfully. Installation was a day long event, though that was entirely because of Comcast- not of any fault in the TP-Link device.  It took me 3 phone calls to finally get it activated and provisioned with Comcast.  If you are going to try self-activation, let me caution you to use your Comcast account number and phone number to log in.  DO NOT use your e-mail and saved password to log into that activation page.  For whatever reason, that was a stumbling block for me.  Even after we cleared that, Their agent still had to preform a "hard reset" on the TP LInk to get it working.  The old jam the paperclip into the hole in the back trick...  I also think you are better off if you can activate it using a hardwired connection first and then set up the wireless connections, if you have a PC with an Ethernet port.Anyway, once it was activated, I had no trouble getting my wireless devices to recognize it.  Kudos to TP Link for giving a simple 8 digit numerical PIN rather than some 16 character alpha-numeric code that is a nightmare to key in on a printer, phone or TV.  You can also use the push button WPS to link up your devices if they have that option.  Router works fine with Yoga laptop, Samsung phone, LG Smart TV and Amazon Fire TV Stick.My wireless range throughout the house is definitely better than before.  I get good signal strength in  the far corners of the upstairs where it used to drop out with my Motorola modem/router.  I'm not sure my connectivity and speed problems are fixed though.  I still get buffering issues with my Amazon Fire Stick.  Again, this is likely not the fault of the TP Link.  It can only work as well as your cable signal input.  If you have poor speeds from your ISP or your house has crappy wiring, this is not going to be a magic bullet for those issues.  {You can make Comcast come out to check your signal strength and tune things up.  Just make sure they add on the line protection coverage to your account first so you don't have to pay for the service call.  They added a small device to one of my cable outlets to boost the cable signal strength and it made a huge difference.}Back to the TP Link----  The most intriguing feature of this device for me is the 2 USB ports.  I have an external  Hard drive plugged into one.  Now I can back up both my PC and my laptop to the same hard drive- wirelessly- without having to be some sort of networking wizard.  The laptop can get at the PC's backed up files even if the PC isn't turned on, since it all runs through the router.  {Suggestion, do your initial backup hardwired and then do subsequent incremental backups wireless.  The wireless back up of my music and photo files took more than a full day.}  I plugged a printer into the other USB.  The printer was already wireless but would sometimes loose connectivity for no reason.  This gives me a back up option for when that happens, but I assume it would also enable you to share a non-wireless printer across your home network, again without requiring network administrator skills.For me, the only thing that would make this device even better is if it included telephony services so I could ditch all of Comcast's modem/gateway equipment.  As it is, I still have to pay the monthly fee for their modem just for the telephone.  If you don't have Comcast phone service the TP-LINK Archer CR700 is hands down a slam dunk choice.  Even if you do have Comcast phone, it is still worth it for the dual band and two USB port functionality.

Columbia sizing runs small (and I do NOT) so I ordered up one size.  These are simply wonderful hiking pants.  Comfort is the most important thing but if you can be stylish in the process, that's a plus.  These pants nailed it in both categories.  They are spendy but worth every penny.  So much better than zip-off pants with that cumbersome zipper.  I found these light enough for a pretty warm day yet surprisingly warm for the chilly start of the hike.  I purchased them in Long even though I'm 5' 6" because I hate pants that are too short.  They are perfect length with my hiking shoes though they'd drag if I wore them with sandals.  The only caveat is that I think that makes them longer when rolled up too.  I wish all the additional length was in the lower portion only instead of distributed throughout the whole leg.
My daughter is an elementary school music teacher.  Everybody dresses up for "Blue Friday" to show their support for the Hawks.  This cape was a big hit with the kids!

I tested both the Bloody Mary mix and the Margarita mix.  It won't let me post a separate review for each so the two are combined below.BLOODY MARY:  I've never had a Bloody Mary before so I can't say how authentic this mix is, but I found it tasty.  It has a good tomato taste, slight kick and made a decent drink using some pretty generic vodka.MARGARITA: Margaritas are in my top 3 of adult beverages.  I don't bother with making them from scratch so I have tried a variety of mixers and consider myself well qualified to pass judgement on this offering by Mr & Mrs T.  Sorry to say, I didn't really care for it.  Granted, I didn't start out with top shelf hooch but I'd say it was comparable to a "well" liquor at a bar.  This mix is a single serve can.  One can plus 1.5 ounces of tequila makes one drink.  The taste was vaguely chemical and not remotely similar to an authentic margarita.  Furthermore, there are THIRTY grams of sugar in each of these tiny cans.  That is a 130 empty calories for something that tastes nasty.  Instead I recommend Baja Bob's Sugar Free mixer.  It makes a tasty drink with any mid-level tequila and contains ZERO grams of sugar.In my opinion, convenience is all these have going for them.  Baja Bob makes single serve packets and  though I haven't tried those, I'd certainly suggest you give those a try instead of this brand. Zero calories and about half the price per serving.

These are my go-to sport bra.  They have enough support for fitness walking, hiking or occasional jogging.  The spaghetti straps do cut into your shoulders more than a wide strap, but it's worth it to be able to wear them with a narrow strap tank top or any low-cut T shirt and not have big, ole' wide straps showing.

I wish I didn't have to take fish oil supplements.  The pills are huge and can be accompanied with those nasty "fish burps".  But the doctor says its good for me and who am I to say he's wrong?  I've been taking the Kirkland Brand you get at Costco.  This Vitamin World brand is virtually identical to the Kirkland, when comparing the label ingredients.  The only difference I noticed is that the Vitamin World product  says it is purified to remove mercury.  That seems like a good thing to me!I used to take the coated Costco fish oil capsules since they didn't give me any fishy aftertaste but I switched to the un-coated to save some money.  After a while I stopped getting the fish burps with the un-coated version too.  Maybe my body got used to it, I don't know.  Anyway, the Vitamin World brand  hasn't given me any issues in that department.  If your doctor wants you taking fish oil, this would be a fine choice.

My husband has been wearing Levis 517 for his entire adult life so it's pretty hard to get him to try anything new.  He's pretty happy with these, though they have a more relaxed fit in the thigh area than he's used to.  Surprisingly, the waistband is kind of snug in relation to the rest of the pants.  Fortunately, they did not shrink when washed in cold water and tumble dried low.  The denim is pretty heavy but not too stiff.  At the current sale price on Amazon these Wranglers are about half the going price of a pair of Levis.  Pretty decent value for a pretty decent pair of jeans.

Works OK for a dual monitor set up except for the fact that it will sporadically STOP WORKING!  Either the display will go black or one of the two displays will cease to be recognized.  Very frustrating until we figured out the fix:  pull both the Star Tech adapters out from the PC at the USB connection, and them plug the both back in.  For whatever reason, this has worked every time.  *fingers crossed*

The 14-14.5 Evercase is the perfect case for my Lenovo Yoga 2 (13.3").  The smaller size would probably have fit, but I'm happy I went with this one so there is enough room for small peripherals/cords and a spiral notebook.  Looks very professional and provides a nice level of protection for traveling with my Yoga without being the least bit bulky or stiff.I did not like the strap it came with, for the reason that it cannot be shortened to the length that would work for my height, because of the way the shoulder pad is designed.  I swapped it out for the strap from my old, huge laptop bag so now this is basically perfect for my needs.

Looking at the price, I figured these must be poor quality cases made of some sticky silicone.  All the positive reviews encouraged me to give them a try anyway and I am sure glad I did.  They are the perfect combination of grippy in your hand but sleek enough to slide into a pocket.  They are soft and pliable on their own, but once they're on your phone, they feel more like a hard case. They require a bit of work to get them on, which is a testament to their precision fit.  They give better edge protection than the previous hard cases I've used and have a slightly raised lip which protects the screen if laid face down.  They are transparent so the actual color of back of your phone along with any writing on it will show through to some extent but from any distance, you just notice the bright rainbow color de jour.I have no trouble removing the case to switch colors or swap out my battery with a spare (Hey Samsung- why don't your new phones have replaceable batteries anymore???)  and all the buttons, ports, microphone and camera cut outs are perfectly aligned so as to not interfere with access.  The folks at the Friendly Swede did a great job of answering my pre-sale questions.  These cases are an absurdly good value on top of being a great product.

This does tend to slide a bit on a thick, shag carpet.  It also does not seem as thick as I expected.  I'll be keeping my warranty handy because it would surprise the heck out of me if this doesn't crack after a year or two.  Also, I wish I'd gotten a tape measure out because this mat is significantly smaller that the one it replaced.Chair mats are essential for using any rolling desk chair on carpet but you can't help buy wonder why they have to cost so much!!!  It's just plastic, folks!

I've got a couple different types of "Mystery Weeds" in my yard that seem to be unfazed by most normal weed killers.  They grow between the cracks of my patio pavers and in the gravel of my driveway- both areas where weeds are impossible to pull and are very noticeable and unsightly.  I thought I'd give this a try since any product that is designed to kill blackberries should be able to take out a mere weed with ease.  In fact, it did just that.  The effects began to be visible almost immediately and within a day or two, the weeds had totally shriveled up and died.  The sprayer was easy to use and completely emptied the bottle with no waste.  As with any total vegetation killer, caution should be used during application.  This product does not discriminate and will kill your prize shrubbery as easily as your troublesome weeds given the chance.  As long as you use common sense- like not spraying on a windy day- you should have no problems though.

These are a very attractive towel and would be suitable for hosting a fancy dinner party or staging a house for sale.  They would fit well with a French Provincial decor or might even work for New Orleans Saint fans since they use the same Fleur de Lis design.  I found the choice of fabric to make them more of a designer item than a functional one, however.  The material would seem more suited for curtains or a dinner napkin than a towel.  They'll work OK for drying your fingertips but will not perform near as well as a standard terry towel for sopping up spills.  Furthermore, they come out of the dryer rather wrinkled.  Life is too short to iron towels.  I'll be saving these for "company".

First thing to note for fans of the Bones TV show: The books bear little resemblance to the show.  Temperance Brennan is still a forensic specialist but that is were any similarity ends. The two may have the same education but are in a completely divergent life.  Not just the setting and surrounding cast of characters are different, but the Tempe in the book is much less of a pedantic, out of touch "squint" than the TV Tempe.  I am a huge Bones fan but I actually like the book character more.  She is much more believable and accessible.  It cracks me up that the book actually makes pop culture references to the show several times in the same breath with "CSI".Anyway, I thoroughly enjoyed this book.  You can read the publisher's summary for the basic plot points.  The science, though authentic is not overwhelming, the backstory of Temperance's family and love life will be of interest to faithful readers of the series but doesn't lose those who've picked up the book as a stand alone.  The author has a habit of ending chapters with an ominous cliff hanger sentence which gets a bit annoying  but other than that, I enjoy her writing style.  This isn't the kind of book I'll read multiple times, but it filled the bill well for a summertime lawn chair book.

This cable seems very sturdy and well made.  We had no problem whatsoever using it with an I-Phone 5S.  Provided your situation lends itself to a really short cord, you will be happy with this purchase.  I know I am happy because now that my boss can charge his phone at work he has one less thing to b1t# about...

Don't let yourself be fooled by the friendly green bottle here.  This is some powerful bug killer here, despite being derived from a natural source rather than a chemical one.  The same caution and care needs to be exercised with this product  as with any pesticide on the market.  Don't apply when there is wind to drift the spray; avoid contact with skin and wash up well afterwards; don't over-wet leaves and allow product to drip to avoid groundwater contamination.  While considered "low toxicity" to mammals, pyrethrins are still toxic to birds and fish and can pose hazards to mammals if misused.  Take care to NOT use this product when bees are active in your garden as it is lethal to them too and the last thing you want is to kill off your main pollinator.Provide you follow the directions and use common sense, this is a great product for control of those pests who's damage simply cannot be tolerated.  Side note- if you buy this with Amazon's "frustration free packaging" the pump sprayer is wrapped in  brown paper on the side of the box.  I accidentally threw mine out with the packaging.  Fortunately I figured it out before my recycling got picked up.

This shower gel has a fresh, clean scent that I think would appeal to either men or women.  It left my skin feeling practically squeaky clean but soft, neither dried out nor oily.  Pump dispensers can make it easy to overuse a product.  I found I could get my entire body clean with about two partial pumps worth which makes this product both effective and affordable.  Highly recommended.

I am a big fan of books with strong female characters: Rizolli & Isles, The Womens Murder Club to name a few.  I really thought this book was going to fall right in my wheelhouse.  There are 3 strong female leads, each with their own strengths, baggage and intersecting story lines.  But somehow I didnt find myself empathizing with any of them enough to really care that much about their motivation or what might happen to them.  The idea behind the story (spoiler alert), that of a radio host who fakes a threatening caller to boost ratings, is solid but ultimately fell short of its potential.

I'm really happy with the look of this necklace.  Somehow it takes a traditional, classic emblem and makes it look modern and fresh.  The design really "pops" from the hint of shadow around each detail. It has a quality look and feel in every respect.  I normally prefer a 20" chain and I was afraid I'd need to add an extender, but the drop of the pendant is about an inch and a half so it hits me just about where I'd want it.  I would prefer a slightly heavier chain over the delicate one it came with but the slide on the pendant is ample enough to easily swap it out for a different one from my jewelry box if I'm so inclined.As with all items from the Amazon Collection, this comes in a pretty, fancy box.  This will make a stunning gift that will look like you spent a whole lot more than you really did!

McCormick is the brand I always buy at my local grocery store.  I go through a lot of Almond extract in my homemade granola so recently I've been getting the Rodelle brand from Amazon because it comes in a big bottle.  I was surprised to see that (as of today's pricing) the McCormick 8 oz bottle is actually less per ounce than the Rodelle in the 16 oz bottle!  Both contain the same ingredients: Water, Alcohol and Oil of Bitter Almond and either will be a wonderful ingredient for any recipe calling for almond flavor.  I don't recommend trying to save a few pennies by buying the imitation stuff.  The real, pure extract makes a noticeable taste difference and the extra cost is well worth it!

This cleaner is similar to 30 Seconds Outdoor Cleaner.  Spray on, let it sit, scrub any stubborn spots and hose off with clean water.  The liquid is not toxic to plants nor does it stain clothes the way bleach does.  It took off the light coat of grunge on my patio chairs easily but did not help the etched in spots that have defied several other cleaning products on previous attempts. My problem is that the hose-end spray feature of the container is about the worst designed thing EVER.  Here is the best case scenario: After you screw it on to your hose, turn on the water before you do anything with the spray nozzle. Then push the little tab (that is so stiff it actually hurts your thumb) and turn the dial to begin spraying.  If you do this out of sequence, ie push the tab, turn the dial and then turn on the water, it will start spraying all over the place before you walk back from the faucet to the sprayer.The real issue comes when you are done spraying soap and want to rinse off with plain water.  It is a two handed struggle to push the tab (ouch) and turn the dial, (as you waste soap the whole time). Then walk back to the faucet and turn the water off- but, you still have pressure in your hose!  You either have to push the tab (ouch again) and turn the dial to release the pressure (and waste soap) or unscrew the bottle from the hose that still has water pressure and get water all over yourself.  Stupidest thing ever.To redesign the sprayer, put a 3 position slider on the bottle: Off, Water Only and On .  That way,  I can control how and when I dispense soap, rinse off my item without having to detach the bottle and easily release the water pressure when I want to disconnect from the hose.  This isn't rocket science.  In fact I have another spray lawn product ALSO MADE BY SCOTT'S that has a perfectly designed dispenser with that exact design.

Crescent is a go-to brand in tools and this socket set lives up to the name.  The set comes packaged in a compact carry case.  The individual pieces are held in place by a foam pad rather than having a tight, snap in/snap out fit you have to struggle with.  The ratchet action is smooth, the handles and sockets both have a quality feel to them.  I can't find a single thing wrong with this tool set.  Anyone who's ever used a socket set knows how much easier it makes any assembly job as compared to a simple open ended wrench.  You can buy this set with confidence.

I also own the Swingline Optima 45 which sells at a similar point, so I will make my review a comparison of these two comparable staplers.  Both can handle up to 45 sheets though the Speed Pro also accommodates staples with a longer length which better cope with big stacks of paper.  I appreciate that this model has a smaller footprint than the Optima 45 but it lacks several features of the Optima.1.  No on board staple storage for spare staple strips2.  Staple position is a fixed distance from paper edge.  The Optima can adjust to staple right near the paper's edge or have a set-back of up to an inchThe biggest consideration is noise.  The Optima makes a gentle whirring noise when it staples.  The Speed Pro makes a sharp, fast LOUD sound like a nail gun.  Scared the heck out of me the first time!  I would get complaints from co-workers if I used this in a quiet office setting.  It's powerful, fast & sturdy but really, really loud.  If you're running the parts counter at a garage or somewhere that is already noisy, go ahead and buy with confidence.  Otherwise, check out the Optima 45.

This is a charming little necklace.  The chains are quite thin and delicate.  The two chains, one slightly longer than the other, are independent of one another and each connect right to the clasp, which has an extender to accommodate various necklines-and neck sizes.  As with most dual chain necklaces, the two do tend to twist together at the back as the day goes on but not as bad as some others I've worn.  The garnet and butterfly, being in a fixed position rather than a sliding pendant, do occasionally go off center as you move, but they have enough weight to stay basically in the right position.  And the clasp always stays where it belongs too.I was afraid this would be too "little girly" for a grown woman but the quality exceeded my expectations.  I do think a young girl would just love this but be mindful of those delicate chains if choosing this for a child.  The garnet is the January  birthstone, but anyone can enjoy this piece and find items in their wardrobe it will compliment.  As with other items from the Amazon Curated Collection, this arrived in a fancy box that would make for an impressive gift.

This clever pot holder is designed to slid onto the handle of a frypan, if you have pans with non-insulated handles. It's a great idea, since it will stay put so you don't forget, grab the handle and burn yourself.  It's compact size should also keep it from posing any fire hazard by getting too close to the burner.  It is thick enough to give good protection and the silicone stripes give excellent grip. Personally, I'll be using it as a hot pad with a toaster oven so I really like the compact size, approx 10" x 6".  While it is a tad small to use for handling large cookie sheets or casserole dishes in a full size oven, it is perfect for a toaster oven or maybe for use in an RV kitchenette.One thing to note, the hanging loop is sewn so it lays flat, facing the pad instead of sticking out from the edge.  This gives it a nice clean silhouette but does make hanging it on a hook a two handed operation.

I was almost afraid to use this after I read all the warnings on the label.  Causes birth defects, hazardous to humans, domestic animals and aquatic organisms...  I felt like I should have a haz-mat suit on!  They say not to apply by hand or with a hand held spreader so you minimize how much you breathe in.  I just put it out today so I can't say yet how effective it is, but even if it works great I don't think I'll buy it again.  I think I'd rather put up with a flawed lawn than expose myself to something that toxic.

These are great gloves for most any situation where you want to protect your hands from whatever it is that you're handling.  Whether it's garden chemicals, paints or stains, cleaners or solvents, craft glue or the car wash water - your hands will stay clean and dry in these heavy duty gloves.  I wouldn't recommend them for stuff that is super sharp or pokey.  Even though they're puncture resistant,  you wouldn't choose them for pruning roses or stacking firewood.  But they are ideal for anything liquid or granular.  Personally, I'm really looking forward to having my hands not smell like iron after the next time I put moss out on my lawn!Size-wise, they fit my husband's hands snugly enough that he has sufficient dexterity for intricate work.  On me, they are a bit loose but I can still use them for basic tasks.  They seem quite durable.  I spread out half a bag of fertilizer by hand and the gloves were still in such good shape I saved them for the second half of the bag.  At that rate, a box of 30 will last quite a while and be a much better value in the long run than bargain gloves.

For $8.43, this seems to be an expensive option for carrying spare batteries. I've used these in the military, and was wondering if the "civilian" version was worth the price. Well, it's pretty good.The product I ordered is the Clear color, AA holder that holds twelve batteries. It's 3-7/8" long, 2-1/8" tall, and 1-1/2" thick. The batteries are kept side-by-side, not staggered. All of the AA batteries I've found - alkaline, lithium, NiMH, lithium ion (10440), and nickel cadmium - all fit just fine without tearing the battery wrapper. The retention of the batteries is nice: they do rattle a little bit, bit they're in tight enough to not fall out even when shaking the battery holder. This is true whether the batteries are inserted positive side up or down. A small tab keeps the batteries inside until you push them out. The plastic itself is a tiny bit flexible, but not bendable, if that makes sense. I wanted to use a hacksaw to divide the holder into multiple smaller holders, but the plastic is too thin to do this without sacrificing some of the battery spots. The batteries can be inserted either way - button side up or down - and still not have either end touch anything else. Good polarity protection.There's not a lot more to say about these. Yeah, you can hold some batteries positive side up or down to tell which are used, but almost any battery holder will allow you to do that. These aren't waterproof, but you can easily just slide one into a zip-lock bag. For the cost, I'm satisfied with this battery holder. Oh yeah, insertion or withdrawal of a battery is very easy and relatively silent.

For $7.11, this seems to be an expensive option for carrying spare batteries. I've used these in the military, and was wondering if the "civilian" version was worth the price. Well, it's pretty good.The product I ordered is the Clear color, AAA holder that holds six batteries. It's 3-1/8" long, 2" tall, and 5/8" thick. All of the AAA batteries I've found - alkaline, lithium, NiMH, lithium ion (10440), and nickel cadmium - all fit just fine without tearing the battery wrapper. The retention of the batteries is nice: they do rattle a little bit, bit they're in tight enough to not fall out even when shaking the battery holder. This is true whether the batteries are inserted positive side up or down. A small tab keeps the batteries inside until you push them out. The plastic itself is a tiny bit flexible, but not bendable, if that makes sense. I wanted to use a hacksaw to divide the holder into two holders of three, but the plastic is too thin to do this without sacrificing one of the battery spots. The batteries can be inserted either way - button side up or down - and still not have either end touch anything else. Good polarity protection.There's not a lot more to say about these. Yeah, you can hold some batteries positive side up or down to tell which are used, but almost any battery holder will allow you to do that. These aren't waterproof, but you can easily just slide one into a zip-lock bag. For the cost, I'm satisfied with this battery holder. Oh yeah, insertion or withdrawal of a battery is very easy and relatively silent.

This is the updated version of the Inova X1. It was updated in June of 2011, and again from 55 lumens to 80 in February of 2014, so if you bought one since then, you can disregard. At just 2.1 ounces and 4" long, it's quite compact. For the $18.90 cost, it's a good light. The price keeps it from being a "great" light, as there are many other lights that use one AA battery and have comparable output. Inova is owned by Nite Ize now. That means production is in China, but the quality is still good.The X1 I got is black. The anodization is nicely done, with no splotches or uneven coloring. It's not quite glossy and not quite matte; it's a good compromise. The light is 4" long and 3/4" thick, and weighs 2.1 ounces with an alkaline battery. The light is made out of aluminum and is thick for such an inexpensive light. You can run it over with a car without denting it. The bezel (the shiny part towards the front) is stainless steel, and is a nice contrast to the body of the light. The lens is plastic, not glass, but it's pretty thick. The reflector is aluminum as well, and has a light orange peel texture. There are no artifacts (halos, dark spots, or an uneven beam) but the beam is still quite "throwy". It's nice and tight. Not as tight as say, a Streamlight ProTac AAA, but still good. The beam can't be adjusted or focused, but that's okay with me. The LED is a Cree XP-E.The tailcap screws on (the head is pressed on and not designed to be removed) and is how you operate the light. It has a hole machined through it for a lanyard, and there's some knurling at the end to help in turning the switch. Tighten the tailcap for high mode, and loosen it then tighten it again for low mode. High mode is advertised as 80 lumens and low mode is 11 lumens. You can also loosen the tailcap just a little bit and you'll be able to press and hold the tailcap down for momentary mode: hold for high mode, then let go and press it in again within two seconds for low mode. Let go at any time to turn off. The tip of the tailcap has a rubber cover to be a bit soft on your finger when using this mode. I tested the output numbers, and the high peaked at 83 lumens while the low mode peaked at 12 lumens, each on a fresh Duracell alkaline. I also tested runtime: In high mode with a Duracell alkaline battery, the light will run for 3 hours and 39 minutes minutes. In low mode, it will run for 69 hours, 41 minutes.So, how is it? It's good. Not perfect, but very fair for the price. Its beam is tight and smooth, and I like it. The white light is actually white, not ugly blue or yellow like most "cheap" flashlights. The fit and finish are great, and it feels like a very tough  piece of equipment (which it is). Would I buy another one if I lost this one? Yes, I would. Pick one up if you need a simple, durable,  inexpensive flashlight.

The Coast HP1 runs on one AA battery. You can use a lithium ion (14500) for more output as well. For ten dollars, this is a great light. Why not five stars then? Well...The light is made of aluminum, which is anodized black. The anodization is Type II, and the black scratches off very easily. I mean, I used a soft metal (non-marring) caliper arm to attach an O-ring for more grip, and that scratched it. The LED is an R2 (I'm pretty sure) which is good for throw, but there's no reflector in this light. Since it's a zoomie (adjustable flood-to-throw using an optical lens which slides forward or backward) the "throw" isn't as good as it could have been with a reflector. The tailcap is also a little bit "mushy" in that there's some, well, mush in it until it clicks on. The lanyard hole is too small for any split ring I have, and I have some small split rings for flashlights. That's the bad. Now, the review...The light is 4" long and 1" wide at the head. At the body and tailcap, it's about 0.8" (4/5") in diameter. It weighs 3.8 ounces with an alkaline battery. It can use any AA size: alkaline, lithium, carbon zinc, NiMH, or lithium ion (14500). I tested mine with alkaline and lithium ion, and I used ANSI standards; the results are below.Runtime to 10%, Duracell Coppertop alkaline (2200 MaH): 3 hours, 39 minutes.Runtime to 10%, UltraFire 14500, 900MaH: 58 minutes, but it got very hot. I thought it might melt the plastic lens.Runtime to 10%, Rayovac NiMH 1400 MAH: 2 hours, 11 minutes.The output was as follows, starting after 30 seconds of being on:Duracell Coppertop alkaline: 96 lumens.UltraFire 14500 lithium ion: 193 lumens.Rayovac NiMH: 66 lumens.So, the 220 lumen claim is a little optimistic, but that may have been taken right when the light was turn on, or right when the 14500 battery was taken off the charger. Still, at 193 lumens, it's bright for its size.At no point did the light get too hot to hold, and there was no damage from running it for almost an hour on the 14500: no melted lens, no melted tailcap parts, no dying switch, no nothing.The head can slide back-and-forth to zoom in or out: slide the head out to get a farther beam, but not as much flood. Pull the head into the body, or at any point in between, to get a smoother beam that's not as focused. It works well, but I found it to be too slick; the zoom is too loose. I had to put some O-rings on the body to prevent the head from sliding back too easily, and it's not much better. Also, when zoomed all the way in, a lot of lights will project a square in the center, being the zoomed-in LED itself. The HP1 doesn't do that. It's not perfectly round, but it's a lot better than the other ones.The tailcap screws on easily, and has the appropriate O-ring. The switch is plastic and screws in. The switch is just one mode, on or off. It's a forward clicky, meaning you can press it softly for momentary light, or just press it until it clicks for constant light. A tiny lanyard hole is drilled in, but it's too small to be of any use to me.The body is a nice size and texture, with aggressive gunstock checkering machined in. The pocket clip attaches via two Torx (T-6) screws, and allows for a bezel-down carry. It can be removed, but not moved to any other position. It's just fine as far as tightness and placement: about 3/4" of the light sticks out of the pocket when inside.The overall quality is good on this one: O-rings where they should be, no splotched or chipped anodizing, no gouges in the knurling, no machining marks, the metal is thick enough to not dent on the first few drops, nothing loose that's not supposed to be, none of the stuff you find on the cheap China lights you get at the dollar store.For ten bucks, buy a few. Stash one in your backpack, one in your car, one in your gym bag, etc.These are some of the best flashlights you can get for the price.

After having many problems with the Streamlight Nano (ugly beam, low battery life, the light unscrewing itself) I tried the UST Pico Lite 1.0. Despite using the same batteries, costing around the same, and having the same listed output, the Pico is way better. It's essentially a rebranded and redesigned eGear Pico Lite, the differences being:-The UST has smoother, deeper, and farther-spaced machining in the head to turn on and off. The eGear felt more like knurling, while the UST is just a few grooves. Both work just fine.-Likewise, the back of the light has changed the machining from knurling to smooth grooves.-The UST has a slightly smaller battery cage.The light uses four LR41 (also called AG3) batteries, and they're housed in a neat little plastic carrier. The batteries are too tiny to really put in the light without them flipping around, so eGear made this thing and UST slimmed it down a tiny bit. Way to go! I haven't ran one all the way down yet, so I can't comment on battery life. The battery cages are interchangeable between the eGear and the UST. I'll say that side-by-side with the Nano, the Nano is much dimmer and the Pico is still very bright. Output is 10 lumens, which is enough to do a lot of tasks in a dark room. The beam is white with a hot spot and smaller spill beam; it's very useful. The LED itself is exposed, but for a 5mm LED that's not uncommon.The construction of the Pico is great, even better than the Nano. The head is easy to use one-handed. A small gate clip is attached for keyring use, and it's the same one used on the Nano. Meaning, it's pretty good.I like the Pico a lot; it's the keyring light that the Nano should have been. I have several for keychains, zipper pulls, and small kits. The one I bought - the blue one - was six dollars. Yeah, I'll be getting more.

This knife costed $33.35 including shipping, and was from BladeShop. That's the lowest price I've seen anywhere for it. So, how is it? It's an Emerson, built by Kershaw. how do you think it is!?-The knife is 4-1/2" closed and just under 1/2" thick. It weighs 4.8 ounces. The handles are made with 410 stainless steel liners, both bead-blasted. The locking side is a frame lock with no handle scale. The lock is very secure, engaging at about the 50% point. There's no blade play in any direction. The lock release has some light jimping, but I wish it were a little deeper. The entire knife is held together with #1 Phillips screws, except the blade pivot pin screw, which is a small flathead screw. There's jimping on the blade spine and the thumb rest of the handle, as well as the area your pinky finger sits on, but again, I wish it were deeper.-The other side has another liner, not drilled out. Over it is a slab of black G-10. It feels about where the Spyderco Tenacious does, in terms of roughness and thickness. The pocket clip is for tip-up carry only, as the "wave" feature won't work well in tip-down carry. Although the advertising says it's for left or right hand carry, it will only attach to the right hand (locking) side of the knife. This is because the G-10 handle scale makes it too long for the screws to thread into. There is also a lanyard hole, and it's fine: where it should be, not in the way, and will accommodate two strands of gutted 550 cord.The blade is made of 8Cr13MoV stainless steel, and is heat treated to 57-59 on the Rockwell scale. It's 1/8" thick and has a nice finish to it: the grind is stonewashed, and the flats are satin finished. The grind is fine on mine: a typical hollow grind (both sides of the blade are ground) at about a 23 degree angle. The grinds were even and smooth. The cutting edge is 3-1/4" long. It was very sharp right out of the box, and stropped up to razor sharpness very quickly. A blackened thumb disc is screwed to the top to facilitate normal thumb opening. I've found that the ball detent used to keep the blade closed is a little too strong, and a normal thumb push is difficult. Instead, I have to "pop" it out with my thumb nail, making a loud "click" sound as the blade flies open and locks. Neat, but some people may not like it.-The last feature of the knife is the "wave" feature itself. If you don't know already, it's simply a small unsharpened hook that protrudes from the spine of the blade. While the knife is in your pocket, the wave sits against the seam of your pocket. If you pull back, it will snag on the seam and "pop" open. This is normally done to have the knife end up edge out / blade up in your hand. If you keep the pocket clip on the right side and put the knife in your left pocket, you now have a knife that opens up edge out / blade down.In general, this is an excellent knife. I don't like the bead blast, but that's easily fixed with five minutes using a steel wool pad and some polish. For a $35 knife made in China, this thing is great. Kershaw and Emerson really outdid themselves with the CQC line.

The venerable Farmer is up to $30 now. That's a bit high, but the quality is still there. The Farmer is 3-5/8" long when closed and is 7/16" thick. It weighs 3.7 ounces. The liners are aluminum, as are the ribbed Alox (aluminum oxide) handle scales. The ribbed texture gives a better grip than the smooth Alox, and it hides scratches and wear better. On the back is a small (3/4" by 1/4") smooth rectangle so you can engrave something on it. The standard Victorinox split ring is attached, which is just a 3/8" diameter steel split ring. The Farmer is basic, but very capable. None of the blades or tools lock, just so you know. Here's the tool layout, sorted by the layers:-The knife blade. It's a little larger than a standard Swiss Army Knife blade, at 2-3/4" long with a 2-5/8" cutting edge. It's 56 on the Rockwell scale, and is pretty easy to sharpen. It's your basic Victorinox blade: easy to take an edge, very stain-resistant, and low to medium edge retention. In truth, if you dull the blade before you can touch it up, you probably should have brought a more appropriate tool. The blade opens via nail nick.-The reamer. It's 1-1/2" long and sharpened to poke holes in things. The arm of the reamer is sharpened on one side as well, enabling you to use it as a fire steel striker. A small lip allows you to open it. I wish this were the standard reamer on all Swiss Army Knives and not just the Alox models, but I see why the flat awl makes more sense on the others.-The middle layer houses the wood saw.
