It's 2-7/8" long with some very aggressive teeth. They're kerfed, meaning the teeth are thicker than the spine so the saw doesn't get stuck in wood. They will cut on both the push and pull stroke. The saw is a little flexible, which you want in a saw. The spine is sharp, giving you one more option to strike a ferrocium rod if you have to. A few people don't like the keyring attachment's placement since it digs into the hand while using the saw, so they file it off. I've never experienced this problem, but if it bugs you, that's a quick fix.-The last (or first, if you're looking at the Victorinox shield on the handle) layer has the bottle opener / wire stripper / large screwdriver. It's 1-1/4" long and just over 1/16" thick. The bottle opener works just fine. The large flathead screwdriver is 1/4" wide, so you can get some torque in larger screws. This tool also has a detent in the halfway position, allowing for even more torque. You can use this tool for light prying, although Victorinox doesn't warranty that.-The other tool on this last layer is the small screwdriver / can opener. It's 1-1/4" long and will open cans of food quickly. The proper technique is to cut forward, but either way will work. That flathead screwdriver tip is just under 1/8" wide, and it will work with most #2 or #3 Phillips screws as well.Overall, the Farmer is a great tool. I think the price is getting a bit high, but it's still worth the cost. There are other colors available from time to time: red, blue, and even black. Those will cost a little more money, but the quality is just as good as the plain-Jane aluminum.

The Fenix E01 is a simple, one-mode twisty flashlight. It costs around $14. What should you expect?Expect a good, basic flashlight. The E01 is made of durable aluminum, and has been described as "bomb proof" by flashlight aficionados. The body tube is one fixed piece with the tail, and has some nice knurling on it. Be advised that the anodization wears off quite quickly if it's rubbing against things like keys or pocket change. A simple split ring is included so you can attach the light to something, and it goes in the one open lug on the tail. This also allows the light to stand on its end while in use, in effect giving you a "candle". The E01 is quite compact at 2-3/4" long and 1/2" in diameter.The LED is a white 5mm Nichia, and all of the E01s I've seen tend to have a blue-ish, blobby tint to them. Output is 13 lumens, but this isn't a pocket rocket. It's made for long runtime. I've gotten 30 hours out of a fresh AAA alkaline battery. A no-name heavy duty (read: cheap!) battery is provided. This light will also run for a while on your almost-dead batteries, so that's good. The head twists to turn the light on. Tighten the head to turn on, loosen it a 1/4 turn to turn off. One-handed use is easy. The reflector is a dulled matte aluminum finish, regardless of the color you choose. There is no lens on the E01.If you want the beam to be better, just get some fine steel wool and rub the LED bulb itself. Then the reflector. Blow out the debris and use a flattened Q-tip to get in the crevices.The E01 has been a staple of the flashlight community for a while, and it's easy to see why. Again, this isn't the light if you need output or throw, but it does very well as an everyday-use item that will run a long, long time on one AAA battery.

The DooHicKey is $7 for polished stainless steel, or $8 for blackened stainless steel. Either price is fair. The items are identical except for the color, so I'll discuss that now...The polished steel tool is marked with a dark brown laser mark, while the black one has white lasering. The stainless one is all stainless, including the carabiner gate. The black one is all black, including the gate. The black one is painted, not anodized or black oxide coated. When it rubs against your keys or coins in your pocket, the paint will flake off. The lasering will remain. The rest of the features are identical...The tool is 2-1/2" long and 11/16" wide, and 3/16" thick not counting the carabiner gate. It weighs only half an ounce. The carabiner gate is wire, and has adequate "snap" and stiffness. Once in a while a key will get tangled in it since it's open, sometimes opening the carabiner or twisting it, damaging it. An easy fix is to put a small piece of heat shrink tubing over it and heat it up.-The rulers are lasered on, with 2" on one side, in 1/16" increments. The other side has 40mm marked, in 1mm increments. Yeah, I measured both against a real ruler, and they're both accurate.-The wrenches are also lasered on, and are 1/4", 5/16", and 3/8" slots. I've found that they're a little soft, but they do grip the nut / bolt/ whatever tight and secure. I like that a 1/4" slot is included; that way you can use standard 1/4" hex bits.-The end serves as a 7/16" wide flathead screwdriver. It works just fine, and also works as a scraper. It's beveled on one side, allowing it to slip under things for light prying. The tool is advertised as having a prybar function, and as long as it's a low-torque applications, that's true.-The bottle opener works as advertised. I don't have a lot of use for this tool, but it does work.-The last feature is a box cutter. This is the corner of the flathead screwdriver (the corner near the bottle opener) ground at an angle. It will open a box or cut tape, but don't expect it to open blister packaging or slice paper.The DooHicKey is a great keychain tool: inexpensive, compact, effective, and lightweight. Yeah, it has some faults, but it's perfectly acceptable for this price and size.

For $8, this is an acceptable tool. As with all keychain tools, it's a compromise of size and functionality. This tool is 2.2 ounces in weight, which is too heavy for most keyrings. It's fine for pocket carry, or in a sheath with a knife or multi-tool. It's made in China, if you care about that.The tool is 3-1/8" long, 1-1/8" wide at its widest point, and 1/2" thick. Those measurements are when the tool is snapped closed. When closed, the only tools you can use are the knife blade, flathead screwdriver, and key attachment.-The knife blade is the same as used on the UtiliKey. It's 2" long and sheepsfoot shape; the first half is serrated and the half towards the tip is plain edged. The serrations are scalloped, which work fine. The knife is chisel ground, meaning it's only ground on one side. The steel seems pretty soft, and it behaves like 440A. This is never my only blade, so it's fine. The blade doesn't lock, but it does stop halfway with a deep detent. It also has a nice detent while open, so it's no likely to collapse when in use.-The flathead screwdriver is on the side with the hinge. It's described as a #2 flat screwdriver, but it's more like a #3. It works well for most screws, and can be used as a light pry bar or scraper. It only protrudes 3/8" from the tool, so it's pretty limited in where it can reach.-The keychain attachment is really just the empty space between the Phillips screwdriver, the frame, and the micro screwdriver. It works, but there's a small gap between the Phillips driver and the micro driver, allowing it to slip off your keyring if you're using a small one. If your keys jingle or are heavy, they can pull on the frame and open the tool, detaching it from your keys. So my advice is to forget about the "keychain attachment" feature.Open the tool for the rest of the tools. On the frame side, there are the following:-The nail file is good, but not as good as on a Swiss Army knife. It's machined into the metal like a Swiss Army knife, but not as deep or aggressive. It works fine, and is 3/8" wide by 1-1/2" long.-The bottle opener is machines into the side of the frame, and is integral to it. It works fine as a bottle opener, but tends to jab my hand when I'm using the wrenches in the open position.-The micro screwdriver is on the end of the tool. It's a #0 flathead, which is just a tad too big for eyeglass screws. It works fine for the screws it's sized for, but it's only for light duty. Too much torque and you'll snap the driver blade off.The other side of the tool is attached with a hinge, like a door. It snaps closed and is held open by the hinge, but it will be necessary to use the wrenches with the frame on top so it doesn't collapse when in use. This side is 1/4" thick, which is great for the wrenches.-On the tip, there's the Phillips screwdriver. It's a #1, and is relatively soft. It works fine for screws of the right size, but it tends to slip out unless you're pressing in hard.-The wrenches are the last tool. They're machined into the inside of the hinged piece, and are relatively soft for wrenches. I know they're stainless and not hard tool steel, but they're still pretty soft. The sizes are...English: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, 1/4", 5/16", 3/8", and 7/16"Metric: 1mm, 2mm, 3mm, 4mm, 5mm, 6mm, 7mm, 8mm, and 10mm.The wrenches do have a tiny bit of "slip" in them, so they're not as tight as a dedicated wrench. I like that a 1/4" slot is included, so you can use standard 1/4" hex driver bits. After only about 8 or 9 low-torque uses, that 1/4" wrench slot is getting rounded a bit. I'm not sure how many times it can be used, but I'm a little disappointed.Overall, this tool is worth the cost. It's not for hard use, and it's not really for frequent use either. The snap that you get when closing the tool has began to loosen on mine already, and it will soon have no "snap" left. I'd like to see a tool that's just the wrenches in one solid piece of metal, but this is okay.

Yes, you get five of these. I chose the masks with the blue pouch because it was the cheapest, but the masks themselves are the same no matter what color pouch you choose. In the review I describe one mask, but all five are exactly the same.Each mask comes in a nylon pouch, which comes in a 3" by 4-1/2" zipper-close bag, which also contains basic instructions on a bi-fold sheet of paper. The first side tells how to put the CPR mask on the patient, while the second side gives basic CPR instructions (chest compressions and ventilations). These are in English. The third and fourth sections are the same thing, but in Spanish.The pouch itself is nylon, blue in my case. It has a slightly looser weave than a military-issue pistol belt. On the front is a sewn-on Ambu logo, which can be easily removed if you wish. The pouch measures 2" wide by 1-7/8" tall and 5/8" thick with the mask inserted and the flap closed. There is a small section of nylon on the left side, which has a standard 1" split ring attached. The flap closes with a Velcro rectangle. There's no attachment point for a belt or anything else, but the split ring should be sufficient enough to attach it to almost anything.Inside the pouch is the mask itself. It's enclosed in a wax paper sleeve, which is there to protect the thin plastic from tears when not in use. I just snipped the taped edge off so the mask can be accessed easily in an emergency. The mask is folded to a size of 1" by 1", which is just larger than the size of a U.S. quarter. The mask is just under 1/2" thick when folded. Unfolded, it's 9-1/2" long with the ear loops unstretched. A one-way valve is located in the center, and it goes right over the patient's mouth. Since it only allows air in one way, it has to be put on one way. If you can read the Ambu logo, it's on the patient right. Also, there's a small drawing of a mouth over the valve; this is where your mouth goes when doing the ventilations. Elastic strings go around the patient's ears, and they stretch pretty far. If they don't fit, then just use the mask without the ear attachments.In use, the mask is okay. It's designed for one use only, and clearly says so. The valve works fine. However, the plastic is too thin to be 100% trustworthy. When ventilations are being administered, it's common for the rescuer to grind their teeth a little, especially under stress. The patient will almost always bite when breathing is restored. Either one will tear the plastic, rendering the mask useless since you can now introduce bodily fluids through the mouth. If a patient bites a little harder, the valve can come off and fall down their throat, creating a new choking hazard. Yes, this has happened.So, should you buy these? Absolutely. They are valuable, and they are pretty reliable. At $11 for five, they're cheap enough to include in any First Aid Kit or glovebox.

I need six extra shells on my tactical shotgun. So do you. Get $25 together and you can have this great add-on. I bought the 870 model for my H&R Pardner Pump Protector, which is an 870 clone. In short, the SideSaddle fit with a few minor modifications.The kit comes with a mounting plate, the saddle itself (a plastic screw-on shell holder), six small screws for mounting the saddle to the plate, a large bolt, a small bolt, two washers, three hex keys (one for the large bolt, one for the small bolt, and one for the six small screws), and instructions.Installation is very easy:1. Put the larger washer on the large bolt and the smaller washer on the small screw. Tap out the two pins holding the trigger assembly (large in the rear, small in the front).2. Push the large bolt through the rear hole and the small bolt through the forward hole.3. Apply a drop of blue LocTite to the end of the threads on each, and tighten them to the mounting plate. The mounting plate only goes on one way. Don't overtighten, or you'll cause the action to bind when you rack the shotgun. If you do, just loosen it up. I got mine pretty tight - so tight I thought I would bend the small hex key - but it didn't bind.4. Remove one of the small screws that holds the saddle to the plate, apply LocTite, and screw tightly. Repeat until they're all done.The SideSaddle is now installed. Try to rack the shotgun and you'll find that you can't because the forearm bangs into the saddle. Here, you have four options.1. Remove the SideSaddle. I want to keep it on, that's why I ordered it, so we'll move ahead...2. Order a smaller forearm, like the MagPul. I don't want to, so we move on...3. Send this back and order the SideSaddle that holds four shells instead of six. I already got this, so let's use it...4. Trim the forearm. Your manual will tell you how to get the forearm off. From there, use a set of pliers to remove the retaining ring that holds the action bars to the forearm. Pull the action bars off. Using a saw, cut off that rear 5/8" or so. You'll know you're there when the forearm is even at the rear. Clean it up with a file, Dremel, or sandpaper pad. Replace the action bars, retaining ring, and put it back on the shotgun. Ta-da!The SideSaddle went on easily and stayed in place during recoil, not shifting. The plastic saddle held every 12 gauge shell I tried: the little 1-1/2" all the way up to 3-1/2" magnum shells. I know the Pardner Pump won't take 3-1/2" shells, but the saddle will hold them. The shells didn't fall out or wiggle, but they were a bit hard to pull out unless I made a very deliberate pulling action. This is fine.Since the mounting bolts are both in the rear, the front has a little "air" showing in the front between the receiver and the mounting plate. This is purely cosmetic. If it bothers you, I guess you could remove the SideSaddle and stick some foam or tape on it to fill the gap.I like this thing, and I believe it should be a standard add-on for a shotgun, whether it's tactical, hunting, or sport.

I bought this for my Ruger SR9C. It fits, only after some effort and modifications. (The SR9C had the backstrap in the "flat" position.)The price is right for this grip; ten bucks is good for what you get. It's rubber and doesn't feel tacky, so it won't snag on pockets or holsters. The light cobblestone texture feels okay, but it doesn't do anything to keep the gun in your hand. The grip has one finger swell to make two finger grooves, as opposed to the photos, which shows two finger swells. I think the back of the grip is the weak point: it's molded there, and the molding is a very thin line. The sides taper towards the bottom, adding about 1/8" of thickness to each side. I like that.Getting the grip on required more effort than I thought. First, it was just way too tight, even after using a spoon as a lever. I heated up the grip with a heat gun, and it finally went on after some effort (and being careful not to tear it). It didn't cover up the magazine release buttons, but it did cover the magazine well. A few seconds with a razor blade and that was fixed. The grip didn't budge when it was installed. Even under recoil, it wasn't move.This is a good grip, but a better one for the SR9C is the Butler Creek Slip On Pistol Grip, in Medium, for $7 here on Amazon.

I ordered this for my Ruger SR9C; the size I ordered was Medium. The bottom of the grip is labelled Uncle Mike's, who makes some good stuff. I also tried it on my German Makarov right over the stock rubber grip; it fit great.It took a little elbow grease to get the grip on; use a spoon to make it easier. Once it was in place, it was great. No shifting or twisting, even under recoil. The grip feels a bit tacky, and it may pull lint out of your pocket or holster. On the SR9C, a little bit had to be trimmed with a razor blade to get the magazine in. It didn't cover up the magazine release buttons at all.In general, this is a great slip-on grip. It's inexpensive, it fits, and it is very comfortable. It doesn't make the recoil any less, but it does make it more comfortable.P.S. It also fits great on the Smith ?& Wesson Sigma / SD9VE.

I bought this to use on my H&R Pardner Pump (a Remington 870 clone) so I could mount a light on the forearm. For seven dollars, this is a very handy item to have for any gun. It can be used with wood or polymer stocks and frames. You get:1. The rail itself. It's hard polymer (plastic) and black. It has five grooves for centering your rail adapter / scope mount. It measures 2.55" long and 0.6" wide at the base, 0.835" wide at the widest part of the rail. It's 3/8" thick. The holes are spaced 1.2" apart, center-to-center.2. Two bolts. They're black metal and use a 1/8" Allen (hex) key for adjustment. I got two of these rails, and no Allen tool was provided with either. They have enough LockTite already on them for one installation.3. Two oval-shaped nuts. They're a grey steel and have a nipple coming from one end. This is the bottom; the nipple is supposed to sit in whatever hole you're using it in.4. Brief instructions are printed on the enclosed card.Everything is very high-quality. If you have a gun that doesn't have a Picatinny rail, this is an easy add-on. Even if there's no holes for it, you can just drill them. The accessories I tried - lasers, light, slings, even vertical forearm grips for a shotgun - mounted on and stayed there. Since the rail is plastic, you can cut it down to suit your needs. As far as my review goes, that's it. This is a great add-on for any gun at a great price.However, if you plan to use this on a shotgun forearm...The pre-drilled holes (on the rails you're ordering here) won't work on the Mossberg 500-series or Remington 870 forearm without some modifications:1. First, you have to remove the forearm from the forearm rails (your manual might call them action rails, etc.). This is done by unscrewing a circular retaining ring from the front of the forearm, then pulling the forearm rails out the back.2. Then, since the part of the rail that sits with the gun is flat and the bottom of the forearm is round, you'll have to trim some of the forearm to make a flat spot for the rail to not wobble on.3. Line the rail where you want it, and drill the front hole.4. The retaining ring for the forearm rails won't screw back on with the oval-shaped "nuts" so you have to trim (with a file or Dremel) one almost all the way to the nipple.5. The forearm rails and retaining nut go on now. Get it as tight as you can without stripping the threads. It goes on now because the retaining ring WON'T go over the nut.6. Screw that screw in and through the nut. Don't tighten yet.7. The screw in the rear won't be able to go into a nut since it's right under the forearm rail and there's no space for the nut. So, drill a smaller hole. Once the rail is lined up where you want it, put some additional LockTite on the threads of the screw.8. Using straight, positive pressure, screw the rear screw in. Get it tight, but be very careful not to strip it since you're screwing it into the plastic forearm and once you've stripped the plastic, it can't be used in that spot any more.9. Tighten the front screw. No additional LockTite is needed here, but can be handy.If you have large hands, you may want to trim off the rear portion of the rail, right behind the rear hole, so it doesn't jam your hand when racking the shotgun. This is easy with a saw; just sand off the end after you've cut.

Well, there's not a lot to say about some utility knife blades, is there?In terms of construction, these are basic carbon steel blades. They're not titanium-coated and they're not bi-metal. A Rockwell test showed they're at 57 for hardness.These blades are the same size and shape of a normal utility knife blade, except these are fully serrated. The blade is ground and sharpened on both sides, and the serrations are very purposeful. It glides through rubber, carpet, nylon webbing (like seatbelts or backpack strap), linoleum, and rope / cord with ease. However, if you use it on something like drywall or particleboard, it will gum up quickly. The blade held its edge well: about as long as a normal utility knife blade, plus another half.Being the standard size, it was able to fit in any utility knife I have. The SuperKnife brand uses a contractor blade, which is thicker: if you're going to use this in a SuperKnife or the Gerber EAB Lite, then the blade will snap in but it will wiggle a little bit side-to-side.The very tip of the blade isn't as needle-like as I'm used to in utility blades, but it's still able to pierce if you need it to.If you need a blade that retains its edge through fibrous materials, this is a great choice. It makes a good all-around blade as well, but you don't get the precision you get from a straight-edge blade.

Rapala is a Scandanavian brand, made in Finland, and then Sweden. This knife, however, is made in China. For the price, it's a decent fixed blade.The handle is 5" long and made of hard white plastic. A lanyard hole is provided, and it's highly recommended that you use it if this knife will be used over water. The handle is basic, but comfortable. It's not soft or rubbery; it's hard plastic with a very light cobblestone texture. A small guard is there, but it won't prevent your hand from sliding onto the blade if you stab something hard.The blade is 4" long and actually Scandi ground. T%his makes the knife very easy to resharpen. The blade steel is 420J2 at 54-56 Rockwell. This is a good balance of rust resistance (since this is a bait knife) and edge retention. Mine came very sharp, and could shave paper with only a light stropping. The blade is 1/8" thick, so it's not flexible for filleting. It's only 1/2"  wide. The back of the blade has scalloped serrations for removing fish scales, but I find they're too sharp. They're as sharp as a knife's serrations, and tend to cut into the meat. They take up the first 2-3/4" of the blade's spine.The provided sheath is okay. It's made of the same white plastic as the handle, but it's thinner. The sides are like lattice, allowing the water to drain from the blade while in the sheath. The tip of the sheath allows for another lanyard. The knife snaps in via a small plastic lip, which can snap off over time. For the cost, I can deal with it, as almost any other fixed blade sheath will work with this knife.For the money, this is a good bait knife. It's not a fillet knife, but ti does a great job at cutting up bait. Replace the sheath with a better one, and this would be a good hunting knife: skinning, caping, and sawing through small bone or tendon is easy with this.

A lengthy review for an industrial box cutter that every grocery store in the country gives away to its stock employees? Well, okay...These box cutters (called tap knives here) are simple. A pressed metal sleeve holds a blade holder. The sleeve acts as the handle, and measures 3" long by 7/8" wide and 1/8" thick. Whether the knife is fully opened or fully closed, it's 4" long including the blade holder. The holder is pressed metal as well, and is fully removable for blade changing. Simply pull it out the back. Removal from the front isn't possible since the back of the blade holder has two rectangular spots pressed outward; one on each side of the blade holder. This is a good safety feature, since some materials will "grab" the blade and pull it, possibly pulling the blade and its holder straight off the sleeve. A bad cut is usually the result if that happens, but that's not possible with this design.The "tap knife" wording comes from the act of holding the sleeve and just tapping the back on something sturdy to expose the blade. Then tap the flat part of the blade holder to close the knife (the front has a flat piece of metal so you don't cut your box while tapping the knife shut). Retention is pretty good; the knife doesn't open or close without me wanting it to. If the sleeve loosens up, you can always flip it over and try that side, or just crimp it a little tighter with pliers.Replacing the blade is easy. Pull the blade holder off the sleeve from the back, pull the blade up (pull straight up on the crimped side) and just slide the new blade down. Slide the blade holder back onto the sleeve. The sleeve is void of markings, and the blade holder isn't notched at the back or anything to let you know what side is sharp when the knife is closed. A simple remedy is to put a piece of electrical tape over the sleeve on the side where the blade's edge is, indicating the sharp side by glance or feel. The knife takes a standard single-edged razor blade. When in the "open" position, 7/16" of the razor blade's edge is exposed.These are sold as a 12-pack, and mine came boxed and labeled, with instructions on how to change the blade. The knives each had a blade already installed, and everything was clean and rust-free. I couldn't be happier with these simple, but effective cutters.

I use this Condor EMT Pouch for emergency medical supplies (as it's intended) but you can use it for all sorts of things. The one I got is olive drab, and the color fits perfect with all of the other OD military gear I've acquired. The pouch measures 7" tall by 5" long and can expand up to 2-1/2" thick. The overall construction is great for the price.The nylon feels tough, and I'm guessing it's around 1000 Denier, as it feels just like my Maxpedition bags. In terms of stiffness and weave, it's right where Maxpedition is. For me, that's about perfect. The outside features three MOLLE strips on the front, sewn to have three slots in each. The back has two MOLLE straps, and they're sewn to give you two wider slots each. The back also has two MOLLE straps that snap to the bottom for attachment to your gear. The sewing is all (inside and outside) single-stitch, and there were a few places where the stitching was stray. All I had to do to fix this was singe the strays with a lighter. The MOLLE straps are nice and tight, as they should be. The snaps are nice and tight; they snap on with a "click" and pop off with a quick tug. The bottom of the bag has a grommeted drainage hole, and it's about 1/8" in diameter.There are two zippers on the pouch, and they go from the bottom all the way around. The zippers aren't YKK, but they're decent. Simple paracord zipper pulls with a plastic end are used to open and close the bag.Inside, there are many places to put things. The bag opens to an L shape since there's an elastic section of 1" wide webbing on each side; this is to prevent your contents from spilling out. I couldn't get easy access to the items in the very bottom, so I clipped one of the sides off. Now the contents don't fall out, but I can still get to the bottom.The side without the attachments (I called it the front earlier) features the following:A loop of nylon webbing, not elastic, that is about 1-1/2" long. I use this to hold my gloves.Two verticalal strips of elastic 1" wide webbing, each one sewn in the middle to make four slots. Each strip has another strip sewn right over it, so you can add even more things. These are sewn onto the pocket.The pocket is about 3-1/2" deep. When the pouch is full, you might have to turn it inside-out to get to the contents of the pocket.Under the pocket is another run of 1" wide elastic webbing, sewn down the center, with another run of elastic webbing sewn over it.The other side of the pouch (the back) has a small loop of 550 cord sewn to the top. It's small; I don't think a dime will fit through it. I use it with a small run of 550 cord to keep my tape in easy reach.The only other things on the inside are two elastic webbing straps, which are sewn horizontally and are about 1-3/4" wide. These aren't sewn down the middle, so your large items can go here.When all of the slots are filled up, there's still plenty of room in the middle for things such as a notebook and pen, some gauze, and a headlamp. A headlight is almost essential for a medical kit: A flashlight can be clipped to the outside MOLLE straps, but you're going to need both hands free in a medical emergency, and that's not the time to hold your flashlight in your mouth while your hands are busy.Overall, this is a great pouch. It's very inexpensive, yet well-made, holds a lot, and has enough "sections" for easy customization. If you don't need a medical bag, it can function in lots of other roles.

I bought a few of these at WalMart for $3.88 each. They're well-made, but not bright. Their claim is runtime, not output.The light is anodized aluminum in either blue, bronze, or red. No matter what color you get, the rubber grip is black with the Rayovac logo molded in. The light is 3-1/2" long, not counting the keychain. The entire light, except for the grip, feels like an old record, in that it's highly machined with fine lines. The body and tailcap are 9/16" in diameter, while the head tapers to 11/16" in diameter. The tailcap unscrews for battery replacement; a Rayovac is included. The tailcap is nicely knurled and the threads are fine for a $4 light. An O-ring at the back keeps water out. The tailcap has a keychain attached, with a lobster claw clasp. This protrudes 1-3/4" from the rest of the light, and is removable. If you remove the keychain, the light can tail-stand. The rubber grip is 1-1/8" long and is removable as well.The head tightens to turn the light on and loosens a bit to turn it off. An O-ring is inside to keep moisture out of the light. A white 5mm LED is the light source, and it's shielded behind both a focusing reflector and a thick lens. The package says output is 5 lumens, and this seems to be right. In twisting the light on and off, I found that it was too sloppy, so I put a few turns of plumber's tape around the threads. It's much better now; no losing the head due to loose threads.The included AAA battery is just a cheap dollar store one with the Rayovac name. You'll get about 4 hours of usable light out of it, but if you stick an alkaline in the light, that goes up to around 6.5 hours.The keyring is okay. It's a circular ring (not a split ring, which is designed to be removed and replaced) attached to a swivel piece, attached to another circular ring, then finally the lobster clasp. The whole thing screams "CHEAP!" to me, but this is a $4 light. The lobster clasp works some of the time, but any sideways pressure will cause it to "jump" and snap to the side. I've found that replacing the entire unit with a small split ring attached to a quick link or snap link is much more dependable.For $4, it's hard to beat this light. It's compact and very reliable. Maybe it's too big for your keychain, but it's not too big for your toolbox or glove compartment.

This is a simple, but effective light. It's available in several LED colors, but this one is red.A simple snapping wire (I guess it could be called a micro carabiner) enables you to clip it to anything less than 3/8" thick. Zipper pulls, keyrings, backpack sliders, D-rings,  and buckles are all ideal uses. The light's functions are simple: squeeze the flat sides once for steady on, a second time within two seconds for blinking. A third squeeze, or squeezing after two seconds, turns the light off. Actually, you only have to press the side with the sticker (the sticker is on the inside, but visible) on it, as that's the side with the switch.To change the battery, you pop off the side with the sticker. A small screwdriver or butter knife works well. Then, you pull out the light. Pry it out carefully, as you can bend the thin metal walls easily. You'll see the 5mm LED on the other side. Inside are two CR2016 batteries. Push them out with your screwdriver, knife, carabiner, etc. They can be replaced with CR2016s, or one CR2032 for longer tuntime, but a less-bright light. Before you replace the light, click it to make sure you put the batteries in right. Then it just pops in (the LED goes into the divot) and the cover you removed just snaps back on.I've found that with two CR2016s, runtime is about 20 hours on high and 27 hours on flashing. Output is around 6-8 lumens.With one CR2032, runtime is 34 hours on high and 43 hours on flashing. Output will be 3-5 lumens.This is a good light. It's too big for my keys, but clipping one to a backpack strap or zipper pull will allow you to be seen by cars at night. I use them as blinkers. I would love these at around $3 or $4 each, but right now, the cost is too high for more.NOTE: The batteries, both the two CR2016s that come with the light, and the CR2032s I mentioned, can be bought at your local dollar store or Radio Shack.

I ordered two of these lights, both with the red LED. I was concerned about getting a fake from some other reviews, but mine came in the factory packaging (the seller was Amazon). All of the accessories listed - the clip-on necklace and the clip-on clamp - were included in each package. A split ring is also attached to the light. The red Freedoms use one CR2032 battery, but you can swap it out for two CR2016 batteries. Doing so will give you a brighter light, but will shorten the battery life. You still have all of the modes, no matter which battery you use. The batteries supplied are Energizers. I'm familiar with the various functions of the Freedom, but an instruction sheet is included. The light doesn't remember what mode you used last, so it will always come on in high. For a "crash course" on the Freedom, a great link can be found here... [...]Keep in mind that I'm talking specifically about the red Freedom, but the modes are the same for all of the lights in the Freedom line.The Freedom can be used at any brightness between minimum power (just enough to look at a map at night) to full power (enough to use as a beacon so cars don't hit you) and can even be set to come on in that brightness whenever you want. You can also choose to have the light in a squeeze-only mode (to signal, or to save the battery) or constant on. There's even three flashing modes (different flashing speeds) and SOS. A "hidden" mode features a three-minute auto-shutoff.The clip-on necklace is a good idea, and it works just fine. It's just a plastic tray that flexes to hold the Freedom light. A small cord is attached to hang off your neck, and magnets on the back allow you to stick it on almost any metal surface for hands-free lighting. The light points down when installed. You can also install the Freedom on the tray backwards to prevent accidental turn-on. To remove the Freedom, just give it a yank.The clip-on clamp is fine, I just never use it. It's the same tray as the necklace, except it's attached to a ball joint, which is attached to a small clamp. The ball joint rotates to any direction you want, and it stays there without fuss. The clamp can go on your hat to make a headlamp, on your shirt collar, or anywhere else you can fit it. I have one clipped to the sun visor in my car.In general, the Photon Freedom is nice. I agree that it's a little expensive for a 5mm LED, but you also get the accessories, multiple modes, and LRI's lifetime warranty. Try one.

The Gerber Shard comes in at 3" long and 1-1/4" wide, and it weighs 0.6 ounce. How does it do as a keychain-sized prybar?The entire tool is coated with a black titanium nitride finish and it holds up fine to daily tasks. If you put the Shard on your keyring, your keys will chip away at the finish.The features are listed as a Phillips driver, two flathead drivers, pry bar, lanyard hole, bottle opener, and wire stripper. One-by-one, here's how they perform:The Phillips screwdriver is very pointy, and is a little too pointy to be used on screws. Mine had to be sanded down to get a better "bite" on the screws.The small flathead screwdriver is next to useless. It's a small stub. It required substantial grinding (thinning out the metal) to fit any screw that would require a driver of this slot size.The medium flathead screwdriver is okay. It's very limited in its reach, and again, it had to be ground down to work on anything.The wire stripper is the area between the flathead screwdrivers. It doesn't work; it's simply not sharp enough to strip the sheathing of the wire.The lanyard hole is there, sure, and it's 1/2" in diameter. It's a hole; not much to get wrong.The bottle opener works as advertised, and is a nice feature. I don't drink, but it comes in handy.The pry bar also works as advertised. It's nice for, well, prying things. You're not going to open an elevator door with it, bit it comes in handy for a lot of things.There are two areas that have very shallow grooves for greater control, but they're almost useless. A Dremel or file will allow you to make them deeper.Overall, the Shard is a nice tool. After all of the problems I had with the tools on it, why? Because they're all fixable, and this is such an inexpensive tool. With a Dremel, I can fix all of the problems listed in under 20 minutes, giving me a perfectly serviceable tool for my keychain.

This thing is thirty bucks? Umm, wow. Put the SureFire name on it, and this would cost almost twice as much.The ProTac 2AAA is essentially an upgrade from the Stylus Pro, but it's an entirely different light series (there are other Protac lights). Included in the package are the light itself and two Energizer alkalines. In my testing, alkalines gave the following runtimes: 1 hour 49 minutes on high, 5 hours 32 minutes on strobe, and 37 hours on low. The light will also run on lithium primaries (NOT the 10440 cells), NiMH, and even NiCad in a pinch.The ProTac is nicely constructed. It's anodized with a black finish, which is a bit glossier than that on the Stylus Pro. I've found that the anodizing is easy to scratch with just a little contact with a key. The light itself is 5-5/8" long - just a hair under 1/2" longer than the Stylus Pro. It's the same thickness as the Stylus Pro, but the head is more bulbous. The head has cooling fins machined in, and they have flats to give you an anti-roll feature. The lens is clear plastic, and the reflector is smooth. The LED is an XP-C, and mine has no blue tint. The beam throws very nicely. In case you're a light tinkerer, the head unscrews from the body.The tailcap is almost identical to that of the MicroStream and Stylus Pro. The tailcaps of all three lights are 100% interchangeable, the difference being that the ProTac has one more revolution of threads added. This isn't noticeable unless you're looking for it. The top of the tailcap unscrews for replacement of the switch cover, but I didn't find an extra one in the package. It's the same switch cover as the Stylus Pro or MicroStream. The pocket clip is positioned low for me, but it easily pops off so you can put it high on the tailcap, like on the Stylus Pro. The pocket clip is the same as the Stylus Pro, so it's good enough for me.In function, the ProTac is nice. The first press turns the light on in high, which is 80 lumens. Another press within half a second goes to strobe, which is an 80-lumen flash at 9Hz. Press again within half a second for low at 10 lumens. At any time, press the switch until it clicks for constant on. There is no memory; the light will always come on in high, and the modes will always be high, strobe, then low. The beam is nice and white, with no artifacts or halos. I like it a lot; it's more throw than flood.Because the circuitry is in the head, you can swap the bodies and / or tailcap between the ProTac 2AAA, Stylus Pro, and MicroStream and whatever has the ProTac's head will have three modes (See NOTE 1 below). Thus, if you want a multi-mode MicroStream, you can have it, but you lose some output as you decrease from two AAAs to one.Summary? It's a great pen light for $30. If you already have a Stylus Pro, you might want to check this out anyway.NOTE 1: This is assuming you have the older (pre-C4) version of the MicroStream or Stylus Pro, with the removable head. The C4 version of these lights have a permanently-attached head. The tailcaps and clips are interchangeable regardless of which version you have.

Since Schrade has closed their doors and was bought out by Taylor, they've seemed to be on a downward spiral towards obscurity. If this knife is any indication, they might be getting better quality knives. Please note that the measurements provided in my review are from a ruler, not a website description. It seems that Amazon has posted the wrong item description.The Handle: The Schrade 304 is a heavy knife, weighing in at 9.7 ounces. Over half a pound. Everything on it is metal, except the two bushings. The knife is 4-3/4" long when closed, and just a hair under 1/2" thick (not counting the pocket clip). The handle is 1-1/8" wide. The handles are stainless steel, just over 1/8" thick each, and are titanium-nitride coated to give them a nice grey color. The non-locking side has five grooves machined in, and they help a little bit with grip. This side also has the Schrade name machined in. A nice groove is there so you can unlock the knife easily. The back of the knife is open, using two hourglass-shaped spacers (also called stand-offs). Each side of the handle slabs uses two Torx (T-8) screws to hold the knife together.The locking side has no markings. It's a frame lock, and has an external cut-out for the lock. Some of the Schrade frame locks that look like this have a Hinderer-type overtravel disk; this one doesn't. The pocket clip is held on the locking side, and while it's removable (two T-6 screws hold it on) it's not able to be put in any of the other corners. So, it's right-hand tip-down only. The clip itself is good. It's a loop-over deep carry clip, coated the same as the knife. It's a bit long for me (2-3/4" from the tip to the bend) but it works fine after some tightening. As it came, it was loose and would rotate to where it was on top of the lock, pressng it in further, making opening the knife hard because the ball detent would sink further into its hole.The lock-up is great. Much better than other China-made Schrades I've had. There was a little bit of blade play, but it was fixed by tightening the pivot pin screw (a T-10). The blade stop pin is of a larger size than I'm used to seeing in "cheap" knives, but I like that. When it comes to a 9.7 ounce knife being thumb-popped open, I'd rather have a thick pin to absorb the energy than a smaller one, waiting to snap or crack. A lanyard hole is also provided.The Blade: The blade is given the same grey titanium-nitride coating as the rest of the knife. It's made of 9Cr13MoV, and is 3-3/4" long. If you're only counting the cutting edge, it's 3-5/8" long. The blade is 3/16" thick and has a hollow grind, starting at the mid-way point. Mine came very sharp, and needed only a light stropping to shave hair. Each side of the blade has a white nylon washer for smooth opening, and the blade flies open easily after the pocket clip is tightened down (see above). There's a thumb stud on each side of the blade, and opening is easy to do with a "flick" of your thumb. It seems that opening the knife in the traditional manner of rotating your thumb along the thumb stud makes the blade "pop" out due to the detent ball. If you want to, you can take the knife apart and round the ball down a little bit.The blade has no jimping, but a small section on top of the thumb studs is machined out for some traction.In use, the knife feels good. It's heavy enough that you know it's there, even in the pocket. The corners of the handle are all smooth, and there are no real hot spots unless you're applying a lot of force. Things like carving hard wood, for example, make the lock dig into your index finger because the other side of the handle is cut away. The blade steel seems adequate, and from what Taylor says, it's around 57-59 on the Rockwell scale. I'll say that it holds an edge a little worse than AUS-8. It's very easy to resharpen. Rust resistance is good, especially with the coating. Speaking of that, the coating seems to be pretty tough. Everyday chores shouldn't be a problem, but if you drop the knife on concrete or keep it in your pocket with your keys, it will get chips in it.Buy the knife? Yeah. Buy it is you want a decent, heavy, China-made frame lock for twenty bucks.

Here are my thoughts on the Direkt, Chad Los Banos biggest folding knife to date...The Handle: The Direkt has a very nice, straight handle. It's a tad over 4" long. Black, nicely-textured G-10 handle scales are bolted over full stainless steel liners. Four Torx T-6 screws (two on each side) and the blade pivot pin (T-8) hold the knife together, and it's very easy to disassemble. The G-10 is textured like all of Chad's other designs, and proves rough enough to get a good grip on without tearing up your pockets (or your hands). A lanyard hole is provided, but it's not very useful. I couldn't get a lanyard made of gutted 550 cord through it, and I struggled to get even one strand through.The handle is straight as mentioned, and it has a sub-hilt. This sub-hilt doesn't get in the way when the knife is closed, and it really helps when the knife is open. It serves as a nice flipper. Locking is positive and solid thanks to a liner lock. The lock is jimped. The back of the handle is open to allow debris to be blown out. It also has jimping for finger placement while working. You get a pocket clip, too. It's reversible for left or right hand carry, tip up or down. It's titanium-coated, and is held on with three T-6 screws. A few people have reported problems in switching the clip from tip down to tip up, but I had no problems switching mine.The Blade: All of this would be irrelevant without a blade, right? It's a nice one, and it's a 3-5/8" long piece of 440C. Mine is 1/8" thick. It's a clip point with an unsharpened swedge. The hollow-ground edge came out of the box very sharp. The blade is titanium-coated and has a blackish-grey color to it. The left side of the blade has the Boker Plus logo along with Chad's CLB logo. The right side of the blade has 440C Stainless above Steel CHINA above 0590. I believe 0590 is the serial number, as each knife has their own.You get a thumb stud on each side of the blade, but you probably won't use them much because the flipper makes the knife more fun to use. The flipper sticks out about 1/2" from the back of the handle when closed, and required very little effort to use. The detent keeps the blade in the handle, but the flipper can easily fly open one-handed with finger pressure. "Flicking" the blade open is easy. There's a hump above the thumb studs, and they're jimped as well. This gives you a good place to work with, pretty much guaranteeing your finger won't slip forward.Speaking of slipping forward; there's almost NO WAY you're going to get your fingers slid onto the blade of this knife. The flipper gives you a nice stop, but the sub-hilt gives you even more of a stop. You've got two half-inch pieces of steel to keep you from slicing your fingers during a thrust.Buy a Direkt. Heck, for $45, buy two. You'll be very impressed, as I was, with the quality and innovation that went into this design.

Here's another great Chad Los Banos design; the M-type. Boker says that this is Chad's entrance into the larger folding world. This one is a bit heavier than I'd like at 4.6 ounces, but it's forgivable because of the nice design. This knife is made in China. It's model number 560. Here are the details...Handle Details: The M-Type has a very nice handle, which is 4-3/8" long. The handle consists of two liners, one locking, and a black G-10 scale. The frame lock is jimped, although it's a bit stiff. The scale is a nice piece of black G-10, textured much like earlier CLB designs like the Subcom and Trance. The frame is titanium coated and has a grayish color. There are two finger grooves in the handle, one of which rests on the lock. There's a lanyard hole if you want to put something in there. The back of the handle is open so you can blow out debris, and the handle is held together with six (three on each side) Torx (T-6) screws. They're titanium coated, too. A Torx (T-8) screw is for the blade pivot, and it's adjustable for tension. The pocket clip is right hand only, but it's reversible for tip up or tip down carry, and is held in place with two Torx (T-6) screws. The right (locking) side of the frame has three oval cut-outs, probably for weight reduction.A complaint here... the ball detent in the frame lock makes the knife very hard to open. I disassembled the knife and smoothed the blade pivot area and sanded it down, lubed it, and reassembled. It still required two hands to open. I eventually got it where I wanted it by disassembling the knife and running a coarse stone over the ball detent until it was good enough to open the knife one-handed, but still hold the blade shut.Blade Details: The M-Type's blade is 3-5/8" long and made of 440C, and is hollow ground. It's 1/8" thick and has the same titanium coating as the frame. The left side of the blade is marked with the Boker Plus logo, and the CLB logo on the tang. The right side of the blade has "1329" on one side of the thumb stud and "440 C" on the other. The right side tang has "China" lasered on. It has dual tumb studs, but unfortunately, no flipper. A flipper would've really helped on this knife, especially with the opening problem. The back of the blade has jimping so your finger doesn't slip forward when using it. There's a slight recurve shape to the blade, but it's not enough to make sharpening or cutting difficult. The left (non-locking) side of the blade has two washers - a bronze one on top of a nylon one - between it and the frame. The right side has just one bronze bushing. An unsharpened swedge is on the back half of the blade. The blade locks open solidly, and cuts very nicely. It takes a razor edge quickly, and holds it for a reasonable amount of time. Each M-Type is individually serial numbered, which is lasered on the blade.Need a frame lock for under fifty bucks? The M-Type is quite a nice knife, and is worth the money.

I bought this for my sister, who has no formal training with a kubotan / yawara stick / koppo / whatever you want to call it. It's made of aluminum, and has a Type II anodizing. This one is listed as crimson red, but with the way light hits it (at any angle) it looks like a metallic dark pink. If you want to change the color, this responds very well to spray paint. The Fury logo is lasered on the top portion, as shown in the Product photo. This stick is 5-3/4" long and just under 3/4" in diameter, and it weighs 2.1 ounces. A simple 1" split ring is included.The anodizing from the factory holds up okay, but any metal objects will quickly put scratches in the finish. The stick has some really good finger grooves machined in, and they work very well for my sister's small hand, as well as my size XL glove hand. Apart from the grooves, there's nothing to keep the stick in your hand. It's smooth, and I wish there were a little texture. A piece of heat shrink tubing over the stick is an easy fix for this. The end terminates in a semi-pointed tip, which has been rounded. Using the stick like an icepick, it would be easy to damage a person. I prefer a thumb-reinforced hold with the tip down, and the split ring has to come off for this (again, I have large hands). Using the stick on a tree, it held up very well. There was no damage to the stick, but there were some missing spots of the anodizing.This is a good force multiplier. Period. That's it for my review, but below are my thoughts on using a stick like this as a self-defense item.-A split ring is included, and it's advocated for use with your keys. Don't do this. Sure, it makes the stick handy and makes your keys harder to lose, but using the stick on an attacker with your keys attached is an easy way to hurt yourself. Put your keys on it, hit a board or tree with it a few times with a few different strikes, and you'll see what I mean.-This is a good non-lethal device. Yes. However, an attack to the head or neck can be fatal. Be sure you know what you're hitting.-Familiarize yourself with how to use a kubotan. It's not hard. Mostly, you need to get the feel of "holding on" so it doesn't slip out of your hand when your strike makes contact. Foregoing any training, this would be an effective weapon with a basic icepick attack, going berzerk on the collarbone or sternum until the attacker stopped.

When you buy a six-dollar pepper spray, you're typically buying a no-name keychain unit from Harbor Freight or a vendor outside the ballpark. Sabre is a well-known brand, and even for a unit this size, six bucks is a screaming good deal.The canister featured here measures 3-7/8" long and 7/8" in diameter. Everything is clearly marked, and the expiration date is reasonable (the two I ordered both say 08/2017). A handy pocket clip is already installed, which keeps the unit at the top of your pocket or purse. The clip is shown on the Product page as metal; it's plastic. It slides off if you don't want to use it. There's no keyring attachment, but it wouldn't be hard to duct tape some 550 cord to the bottom if you wanted to. The unit has 22 grams in it; that's a little over 3/4 of an ounce. The main ingredients are OC (oleoresin capsicum) and CS tear gas, with a ultraviolet dye so the police can identify your attacker later. The addition of the CS tear gas is why this can't be shipped to AK, HI, MA, MI, or NY.I tested mine out in the back yard, and got 27 one-second bursts. This was without shaking the canister, taking ten seconds between each burst. There was no wind. Effective range seems to be around 8 or so feet. The spray comes out in a stream, which I prefer to a fog. A fog or gel can be wiped off the attacker's face and used against you; that's a bit harder with a spray. Also, the spray doesn't deflect as much in the wind (I used a fan to replicate a windy day). So, how does it work? Well, spray some in the far corner of your backyard and just walk around the area. It's a pain in the rear, but it's not debilitating. (Yes, I realize that walking on top of some pepper spray on the ground isn't the same as getting sprayed in the face with it.) Taking a face full of this might deter an attacker enough to run away. I prefer to use pepper spray for dogs, but I think it would be enough to get away from a human.I like the Sabre spray featured here. Nothing fancy, yet inexpensive and effective. I think it really shines when used against dogs, but I'm never eager to get sprayed with it myself.

I didn't buy these off Amazon for $7 for the two-pack. My local WalMart sells the same two-pack for around $4.Dimensionally, the F-301 bold is the same size as the regular F-301 Ballpoint pen. It measures 5-1/4" long and 3/8" in diameter. The body of the pen and the tip are stainless steel; the clicker is plastic with metallic accents. The grip is textured black plastic, 1-1/8" long. A clip is installed and can't be removed unless you break it off. It doesn't rotate. When inserted in a pocket, 1/2" of the pen sticks out. The pen unscrews right below the grip to refill. A drop of lubricant will keep the threads clean and squeak-free. If you decide you don't like the F-301 in Bold, it can accept a normal Zebra F-series ballpoint refill. The opposite is also true: the F-301 ballpoint can use the Bold refill with no problems.In use, the F-301 Bold works very well. It writes as smoothly as any other Zebra, and the bold line resembles a gel pen's line. The pen writes fluidly on most materials as long as they're not greasy or glossy (photographs, for example). I did notice a few gobs of ink coming out when the pen wasn't being used for long periods, but that's to be expected from a tip of this size. There's not a lot more to say. It's just a good pen. It looks like it should cost twice as much as it does.

Andrew just keeps getting better. This is genuine music. I can't speak for everyone, but it just resonates with me. I am not sure I would recommend this as a starting point for his music, but you could do worse. It continues and builds upon the signature sound he has developed over the years. I would say Mysterious Production of Eggs, Armchair Apocrypha, or Noble Beast might be better starting points. This album ticks off all of those points though, and adds something new to his lexicon. Thoroughly enjoyable listening!~ Kort

Easy to use yoga straps in blue and black. Priced right and they feel like a quality product that will hold up over time. For me, using them to carry my yoga mat is secondary. Yeah, they work for that, but I love using them more as a stretching aid. Certain poses are rather hard to get at first and using a strap helps you limber up and work your way deeper in to poses. They come with a lifetime warranty but I don't think I'll ever have a problem with them wearing out or breaking. I've very happy with them.I received sample units for objective review purposes.~ Kort

I have wide, 45 year-old, size 11"+ feet with high arches and feet that ache and are sore if I am on my feet a lot and not properly supported. I've purchased custom shoes from the Walking Store in the past, and they are great. I sometimes wish some of my other (less pricy) shoes had similar support. Enter PROFOOT Dura-Sole Insoles. The feel quite sturdy for extended use, yet comfy and supportive as well. I especially like the cushioned heel and arch support. They're easy to trim to fit a pair of inexpensive 11.5" dress shoes I own. I can slide them into my sneakers as well, though the fit is much tighter. Support is greatly improved and I can wear them all day and be on my feet a lot without experiencing little if any of the end-of-the-day pain I would normally have if I just wore standard shoes alone. Dura-Soles are easy to trim - though I didn't have to trim much - so I question if they can be comfortable for size 14 feet. I would say the sweet spot is for sizes 9 through 12. There may be better insole support options out there, but this is the one OTC version I've tried and for the price they work well.~ Kort

Good stuff. Moroccan Treatment Premium Hair Serum from Simon $ Tom is a bit on the pricy side, but my wife and I like it. First off it smells good. An fresh, airy, yet earthy scent. A little hard to describe other than to say I like it and don't mind having my hair smell like it. The scent does fade after an hour or so. Most importantly, the oil is great for the hair and scalp. Essential a leave-in conditioner, be careful not to use too much. That said, it seems like absorbs rapidly does not leave much of an oily residue. My wife and I have used it right after the shower and towel drying our hair. 3 squirts from the bottle was good for her hair while my shorter crop only needed one. Once it has absorbed, the hair is very manageable without be laden down and flat looking. In other words, still soft and fluffy, but easier to style and it feels healthy. I look forward to seeing what long term use brings. It comes in a glass bottle and is quite full. Mine didn't overflow when I inserted the pump, but I've heard that others had that issue. Just be cautious. The top locks so that you don't accidentally dispense any product with an inadvertent press of the nozzle.I don't normally use any product after the shower, but I really like Z-Comforts product, think it is both good for my hair and scalp and helps me more easily style my hair.~ Kort

Monoprice offers quality cables at a great price point. A 6ft generic store brand version of this cable cost me $5 more and wasn't MFi certified. I've only used it for a short time, but it feels just as sturdy and the Apple version and the lightening connector fits easily past the cases on my family's iPads and iPhones. While some might prefer a shorter cable, I usually plug my cable into a wall socket or power strip using a USB adapter, so the extra length is welcome. 6ft probably would be enough but 10ft gives me even more flexibility. I just keep any extra rolled up with twist ties. Since my kids are extra tough on these cables, it is good to be able to get a strong one that stands up to heavy use but is inexpensive enough to replace if necessary.~ Kort

I'm an old school Star Wars fan and the Falcon is my favorite hunk-o-junk of all time. I'm a bit picky when it comes to reproductions of it. I was pleasantly surprised by Revell's Millennium Falcon kit done in the updated Episode 7 style. It is easy to snap together requiring no glue or painting, just 3 watch batteries to power the engine lights and three sound effects. I would purchase them if giving this as a gift since most people I know don't have 1.5v LR44 watch batteries laying around the house.I think this Revell model would be enjoyed by fans ages middle school and well into adult. Fit and finish is great, but it is handy to have an X-acto knife on hand to trim any excess plastic so that the fit is perfect. The retractible landing gear and moveable laser and radar are nice touches too. This is a model kids can play with and older fans can display proudly. It is not the most detailed Falcon out there, but for it's size I and at this price, I think it's just right. MTFBWY.~ Kort

I like the "look at me" appearance of Invicta watches. They are like the Lamborghinis and Ferrari's of the watch world (looks wise). I like many of their designs and the overall quality of the timepieces themselves. Fit and finish are not up to 'Rolex' level, but neither are the prices. This is my second Invicta and I've handled a number of others. As far as Invicta watches go, this one is still bold, yet rather understated in design and color scheme. The comfortable black leather band with white stitching is a plus too. It comes with Invicta's signature yellow box which makes it a great, showy, item for gift giving.Invicta (at this price point) is all about flash though. This is hardly a "Pro" diver's watch. The outer bezel doesn't turn and the 3 lower dials can be hard to read under the best lighting and circumstances. The I wouldn't use it with this band in the water either. My last watch's band was a heavy rubber and it broke. Twice. For $28 just to send it in for replacement and repair (before other costs), I didn't get a second band. I'm hoping this one is more durable. It also looks like I might be able to replace it with a non-Invicta band if it comes to that.The company puts the list price at just under $1K, but anyone familiar with Invicta knows how overinflated that is. What Amazon is selling it for is closer to the truth, though still a little pricey for what you get. It is a large, heavy, solid watch with an attractive leather band. As fashion accessory, it is great and I'd give it 4 stars. As a dive watch, 2 stars.~ Kort

I'm a graphic desinger and I've had Epson printers and scanners since the 90s. As a MAC user, I find they usually tended to cater to 1) the artistic side of things and 2) the Apple platform. Fast forward to late 2015 and I feel I finally have an EPSON printer that meets the needs of the Apple enthusiast and designer who made them popular. This compact wireless XP-960 is great for both the casual all-in-one user and those that want to create quality prints. The set-up was the easiest I've ever experienced. After the initial set-up and connecting (all very easy), I was printing wirelessly from both computer and mobile devices alike via my home network. Print quality is exemplary, but I recommend running the set-up print head alignment before using the printer.The 960 provides what you'd expect from a mid-level printer with all-in-on features. Scan quality is better than I had hoped for. Print quality is very good even on plain paper (though a bit muted), and overall usage of the printer is easier than any printer like this I've used in the past. For comparison purposes, my previous printer is and was an Epson 730. It still works and prints well, but the 960 integrates into our home system even better and print quality is better as well. My mobile devices find and can use the printer easily, though you don't get as many options as you do with the a dedicated desktop or laptop. The printer has a lot of features I've yet to explore, but I'd recommend it to anyone who wants a home printer that delivers on compatibility and print quality. It is may not be the best home printer for a graphic designer, but it certainly is better than most at meeting 90% of my needs and those of the more casual user.~ Kort

I never thought I'd be one of those Bluetooth wearing people. Then I got an iPhone. And then I got the GeekBok Bluetooth 4.1 Headset. It is easy to pair, comfortable to wear, quick to charge, and works well. A little quiet, but I've not had any problems making out conversations yet. For a device I never thought I'd use, the Geekbok Bluetooth headset (earpiece actually) had quickly become indispensable.I received a complimentary sample unit for review purposes.~ Kort

This is a medium weight T from Oxford NY that is comfortable and can be worn straight from the dryer. I know Oxford can run a bit tight so get a size larger than you are used to to be safe. The same held true for this shirt. Good quality at a great price, this is a casual t-shirt that can be worn every day.~ Kort

It is a slim fitting shirt with an unobtrusive knit design.  Understated yet classy. Aside from the other solid color shirts from Oxford, this one is probably the least busy. It pairs well with a pair of black slacks I also got from Oxford. It is good for work or dress casual. I no longer wear ties often so the collar is a bit "buttoned up" for me. The fabric is comfortable and resists wrinkling, which is a plus since I rarely iron my clothes. This is a quality product with excellent stitching which looks and feels like it will last, but it is not a shirt I'd wear daily given the choice.~ Kort

I'm very pleased. These Oxford's have a classic look with a slightly modern update. A very comfortable fit with the stretchable waistband. Easy maintenance with wrinkle free fabric. These dress pants make we look good, and will become a work week staple I am sure!~ Kort

I personally would not spend this kind of money on a playset like this, but my daughter is really into MLP and Equestria Girls, so having a fancy backdrop of the school makes playtime more fun. Aside from the 3 panel backdrop, you don't get a lot of extras. DJ Pon-3 is the only doll to come with the set. I'm not sure why the description says 2 dolls. Her DJ booth does light up and play "music" but I was really impressed with the lights or music, and the 3 AAA batteries are not included. The playset feels flimsy, but is holding together.I feel you are paying a lot for a little, and though it is being enjoyed right now, I can see it being relegated to the seldom-used toy heap in just a week or two. You need to ask yourself if your child will get a lot of playtime out of it to make the purchase worth it. I know I wore out my Death Star playset as a kid, but this Canterlot High is no Death Star. But that's me, the Dad. My daughter is loving it, ...for now. As with many toys these days, there is a digital/app tie-in that my girl has already figured out.It indicates adult assembly required, but my daughter was able to put it together herself -- and wanted to! She had it ready to go in about  an hour.~ Kort

This is my first flatscreen HDTV, so please realize this review is from someone who has used non-HD tvs at home up to this point. The company I work for sells commercial grade Samsung TVs to the hospitality industry, so I'm familiar with them and know they are a quality product. This is Samsung's base line series (5), though still a bit more advanced with the SMART features. I got mine locally on sale for less than last year's non-smart model, so am satisfied at the value.What I like:- Easy to set up. The process was fairly smooth, though I ran into some cable and Wi-Fi connectivity issues. My fault though.- Lovely clear picture and better audio than I expected for a thin unit.- Once Connected, The SMART hub offers a lot of web based content.- Controls fairly easy to understand and use.What's not so great. This may seem like a lot of negatives, but I feel most are relatively minor yet worth noting.- 2 HDMI inputs only. None have ARC.- Remote not very ergonomic- TV starts up quickly, yet the SMART menu takes about 2 minutes to become ready- Image quality varies. I suppose this is normal with HDTVs that don't have constant HD input, but it is noticeable over the older TV's uniform look.- Color balance in the reds tend towards a cooler magenta rather than a warmer red/yellow. I have not be able to find a way to adjust the colors appropriately even with a bunch of tweaking. Skin tones looked better on my analog TV.- I have a Bose Soundtouch 120 system hooked up to my TV. While it improves the sound quality, the TV didn't have HDMI ARC so I needed to get an optical audio cable to handle the added throughput.- Typing is a hunt and peck affair via the remote. Very time consuming.- My (Xfintity) cable box does not have an HDMI out so I use either the coaxial cable or AV cables to connect to the TV. AV cables provide a stronger audio signal, but coaxial provides a better picture. Upgrading my cable box will likely fix address this.It is a big change moving from an SD Plus TV to and HDTV. You lose the warmer analog look in favor of the more detailed digital HD look. Most of the time it is great. It can be a shock to those moving from one platform to the next though, especially if you don't have an HD infrastructure in place to support what the TV is capable of. I've seen what this TV is capable of and am impressed. I wish it were more seamless thing, but can't fault the TV. Overall, I'm happy with my purchase and this foothold in the next generation of TVs. Even with digital content I've yet to achieve the clarity I see on the TVs in the showrooms, but I know I'll get there.~ Kort

While taller than many non-charging cases, this one-piece design is slimmer and more affordable than most and I like the clean white look. I have a black iPhone 6, but it still looks attractive in this case and is well protected on the back and corners; and by the front by the bumper (I have a screen protector). As a case alone, it does a good job and all ports and controls are accessible, cameras are unobstructed and the speaker still sounds about the same, maybe even better now that it redirected to the front of the phone.As a MFI-Certified charging case, it gives more than a full recharge of my phone, more than doubling my battery life. This is fantastic. One minor drawback might be that while charge via a cord, you have to charge the phone fully first before the case battery begins charging. This will slightly more than double connected charging time so keep that in mind. However, you can charge the phone and the case while you're sending data through the iPhone -- something not all battery cases allow. It's a nice feature and shows how well this case integrates with the iPhone. The case charges the phone quickly.Perhaps it integrates too well. Once the phone is snapped in, it is a hassle to get off again. This is no big deal if you plan to leave the case on 24/7, but if plan on removing your phone for whatever reason, it isn't easy, and delicate component parts can bend and perhaps break. Other minor drawbacks are the added weight the somewhat slick battery case adds, the slight rounded back and the need to use their USB charger. Written instructions would have been nice too.This is a great charging case for the price and it does a lot of things well. There is a little room for improvement though. I was sent this product at a discount in exchange for an honest review.~ Kort

I can't speak to the rest of Native Construct's Quite World album other than to say I like the Amazon samples, but I heard this song and just had to have it. It is a quintessential orchestral progressive track with a variety of audio and thematic elements that they somehow manage to blend together into a cohesive whole. Queen and Muse influences stand out to me and even some Opeth-like death metal guitar and base.  It is a quite a ride and I have it on repeat for the time being.~ Kort

While I'm personally not a big fan of taking 3 large caplets a day, you do it if you need to and this one is effective. I've tried a number of joint supplements that contain Glucosamine and they all worked fairly well but required a few doses a day. At least this uses just one caplet at a time and I didn't find them hard to swallow. With daily use per the instructions, it should last about 5 months, so the high initial price point is worth it. If you want to take just one a day, then I recommend trying Schiff's Move Free Ultra Type II. It has a non-Glucosamine formulation but is still effective.This works for me. I'm in my mid-40s and when I stop taking supplements like this, I notice more aches and pains and joint issues, even though I am fairly active and get good nutrition otherwise. Old sports injuries make themselves felt. Joint Soother helps keep those aches away to a large degree.  They are still sometimes noticed, but I'm not thinking, "geez, my knees, feet, or hands are killing me today." In my experience, it takes about a month for Glucosamine (Chondroitin, MSM) supplements to start being effective, but I rolled from taking a competitive brand (Viva Labs TRIPLE STRENGTH) into this one and over a week later I'm still feeling fine. I should not I also supplement with Omega-3 fish oil and tumeric, so my aging joints should be getting all of the nutrients they require.~ Kort

This is a great set of modern yet cute wine glass markers. The bottle stopper is fun, effective, and completes the set nicely. I like simple design of the little figures and their colors make them easy to tell apart. My only complaint is that they brush off the stem of my glasses much more easily than hook and clasp wine glass markers, but otherwise are quite nice. They are easy to clean and would make a great gift for any progressive wine lover you may know.I received a sample from the manufacturer for objective review purposes.

This is a nice looking pepper/salt mill. The stainless finish and modern design look good and the battery powered grinding (4 AA's required) and LED light at the bottom work well. The clear storage area doesn't hold a lot of either salt or pepper, but mine looks like it will take a while to need refilling. This would make a great gift for a foodie who wants freshly ground spices at the push of a button.I was sent a sample from the manufacturer for review purposes. The first unit would not fit back together and did not work. They sent me a replacement unit that was free of such defects and works just fine.~ Kort
Good colors but pencil leads a bit hard. Not overly metallic looking so I'd go with standard colors instead.

I'm a 45-year old Star Wars fan. I've never had a Furby ...until now.While his Chewie voice impression isn't the greatest, it's good enough. Furbacca is also the only Furby that doesn't interact with other Furbies. That is not a big deal for me, but I would have liked to see him while he was still in the box. The digitized eyes are kinds neat and though there is a app you need to download to get full interactive play out of Furbacca, it isn't necessarily required.This is a cute little Wookie Furby appropriate for kids ages 4 and up, or for Star Wars fans of any age who appreciate the cute factor of a mini-Chewbaca. Time will tell if it captures the holiday market like the original Furby did a long time ago in a galaxy far, far away. 4 AA batteries required but not included.~ Kort

I was sent an evaluation unit by the Amazon Vine Program.I was actually expecting the X-Wing version of this toy, but was sent this model instead. If you have children who like Star Wars and are not that old yet, it would make a fun yet pricy gift. The idea behind the Mashers is that you can mix and match body parts to create custom figures. Other toys in this line range from $10 to $50, so if you want to mix parts, prepare to spend some money.The ship also reconfigures, though not a lot. It has a laser that shoots a projectile, so that along with the figure coming apart doesn't make it an appropriate toy for small children that like to put things in their mouths.While it looks kinda cool (and hey, it is Star Wars), it has an exaggerated Fisher-Price Hero World appearance I find off putting. So these toys may not be for older kids and adults and all but the most hardcore collectors. This 40-something old school fan is not overly impressed. Pre-school through middle school would seem to be the target audience. All parts are made from hard plastic, though the figures are minimally posable at the joints.~ Kort

The manufacturer recommend ages 3 and up. My 11-year old daughter loves My Little Pony though, and Pinkie Pie is her favorite character, so I had to pick this up. She loves it. Just unpack the parts, add AA batteries, turn on both the controller and the scooter, and Pinkie Pie is ready for action. The controller plays music clips and sound effects in addition to maneuvering the scooter. It is amazing how fast that thing can spin, but it has a 4th small wheel to help it make tight turns. The range is good for at least 50 feet, which is about as far as we can see it in our house. My daughter pops Pinkie Pie out of the scooter to play with her hair and generally have fun with her, but likes scooting her around to entertain our cats too. Overall a fun little toy appropriate for MLP fans of just about any age.~ Kort

This Moen faucet is a stunner simply from the form side of things. It's swooping shape and brushed metal finish just begs to be looked at.  Functionally, it works quite well also. The high arch and pull-out faucet with stream or spray selector is perfect for working with large dishes in a crowed sink.  The flow pause feature is a nice touch too. As seen in the photos, it fits well in an area with little backspace, but also looks good on open counter space. A bonus is that it is shaped like the filtered water dispenser installed to the right of our kitchen sink so we have a design theme going now.I've installed a number of faucets in our home, and this installation was the easiest by far.
