My sink is cut for 3 holes, and I had to contact Moen to get one, which they sent promptly with no fuss. Once I had that, installation when smoothly and I was done in about an hour. It was a bit tight and awkward maneuvering beneath the skink and around the garbage disposal, but I knew what to expect and all went well. Just makes sure you have all of the proper tools and that all parts are there and undamaged before beginning.The Moen Notch is a lovely example of kitchen hardware and it feel quite durable so should last a long time. I've very happy with it.~ Kort

No, I don't love this. My 11-yr old daughter does though. With a singular passion. When she isn't playing with figurines or watching MLP on TV or the web, she's drawing them.  MLP - Friendship is Magic Power Ponies, kick her playtime up a notch. She loves these figurines and I keep running into them all over the house when they aren't in some sort of action packed diorama. She loves these things, so I guess I have to as well. This is a pricy set, but it has made my girl VERY happy.~ Kort

You can research GC on your own and decide if it is right for you.  All I can say is that if you want to use this dietary supplement, then Jarrow's formula is a good one. It requires a lot of consumption of the supplement, but otherwise feels like it is effective when it comes to keeping you on track with your diet and curbing various hunger impulses.~ Kort

Thisis a great drying matt. Very absorbent for catching stray water from just washed items. The buttons to hold it closed are a nice touch, though not terribly useful . The grey design is cool, and fits our eclectic kitchen nicely.~ Kort

For those of you who don't take baths, these cleanser, double wonderfully at gel-washes in the show. Super-concentrated in fact, so I've found you only need less than half of what you might normally use. They smell wonderful and leave my skin feeling clean, refreshed and invigorated. This would make a great gift for someone you know (even yourself) who likes to paper themselves in the bath. I love using the lavender in the evening and the hibiscus in the morning. The M&H is great any time.~ Kort

I didn't know how my cats would react to this food since they normally prefer chicken, turkey and beef rather than fish foods. I was impressed that they scoff it down without hesitation and then look up at me with expectant stares. This thrills me because I know this is a healthy dry food I can use like treats rather than a last resort food. Pricey, but recommended! The bag design is neat 70s kitch as well.~ Kort

Tiny USB dongle, tons of memory. It works, and works fast and reliably. What's not to like? Perfect for back-up boot drive, for adding memory, or for storing lots of portable data. Not so great because the form factor is easy to miss or misplace, but otherwise spot-on.~ Kort

Not bad. Better than average, but not great though. I've had better mice from Logitech near this price point. Size of mouse and USB dongle are good -- small and good for use with a laptop for portability, but also as a daily user at a desk. Build quality is good, though a bit light, ant the buttons/scroll wheel work as expected. My main concern would be slight oversensitivity and lack of refinement in tracking and other functions. It is not as precise as pricier models I've used. Good, but not great. I would not want this as my only mouse, but it would do, and for the most part works well.~ Kort

A good more-than-basic wires mouse for a budget price. Batter life has been good thus far -- meaning I haven't had to change them after 3+ weeks of use like with some mice. The USB fob is tiny and works well with a laptop for a streamlined look and easy transport. The mouse itself feels a little cheap, but the buttons and the scroll wheel work, though perhaps not as finely as pricier models. It feel comfortable in the hand too. This might not be the mouse I'd choose as a daily user, but it could work as that and it is more than fine for mouse you'd bring with you on the road or use as a backup.~ Kort

How nice! This kit give you the essentials for mixing drinks; the metal shaker, glass cup, double jigger and strainer. All packaged in a classy box, this would make both a great gift to a starter mixologist or some nice added equipment for the seasoned barkeep. The stainless steel items are quality and show no signs of rust after weeks of use. They clean easily. The glass is nice and thick as well, and is a pleasure to drink directly from even though that is not it's intended purpose. I highly recommend it, especially for the price. I personally was sent a sample for objective review purposes.~ Kort

Easy to swallow No off taste or aftertaste Easy to assimilate vitamin D3 Fair priceViva labs delivers again with this Made in the USA Vitamin D3 supplement. I live in Florida (the sunshine state) but because I'm indoors most of the day, worry that I'm not producing enough of this essential hormone on my own. Studies have show a great percentage of Americans are vitamin D deficient, and it is key many healthful bodily functions. This is my added insurance and I feel great after taking it for a few days. Reported benefits include: Optimizing blood pressure Maintain the health of bones and teeth Improves mood and mental acuity Support the health of the immune system, brain and nervous system (fights colds/flu) Regulate insulin levels and aid diabetes management Support lung function and cardiovascular health May help limit cancer development Helps maintain healthy head of hair Leaner core area~ Kort

I installed a new bathroom faucet in our master bath about 3 years ago. It has worn okay for a sub-$100 Depot purchase, but there are little things I'm not super happy with. It is beginning to show wear after this short period of time, and I feel the water stream could be more powerful. Enter the Delta 564. This is more along the lines of a faucet you might find in a modern, upscale commercial bathroom, but it is classy and looks good in the home environment too, despite its industrial design. It is the fourth faucet I've installed, and it was the easiest (though still took a couple of hours to do right). Read all of the instructions first and make sure you have the proper tools and accessories handy. Get a plumber if you suspect this may not be something you can handle. The only slight hitch for me aside from maneuvering in the tight confines under my sink was the long length of the plumbing tubes, but I was able to curl and bind them to keep them out of the way of under-sink usage. The faucet mechanism is smooth and exact, the water flow good, and it feels solid. I used the 6" escutcheon to cover the 3 holes left in the sink from the original faucet, but it still looks good. I have a feeling this Delta is going to go the distance and perform well for years to come, but I will update here if that isn't the case.~ Kort

While I wouldn't say it is effective as an exercise ball, this rounded & knobbed cushion does make you sit up a bit straighter and reminds me to keep from slouching. Time will tell if it is really effective for the core, but is an interesting cushion even if you are not interested in a core workout as you sit at your work desk or at home. The little knobs can be hard to get used to at first, but I no find them stimulating. I wish it were a bit larger for my 6ft frame, but overall I am pleased. Comes with inflation needle, but you need your own pump.~ Kort

Not as flashy as they appear in the photos, and a tad smaller than I expected, but I really like these hoop earrings on my wife. She normally wears subtly styled earrings so these suit here nicely. Up to a couple of feet away, they indeed appear antique. There are no gems, but gold with rose gold accent and heart scrollwork along the bottom, they are very classy. They have a sparkle that makes a viewer think they MIGHT have gems from several feet away. My wife's sensitive ears suffered no irritation from these and the only really problem I can think of is that my 11 year old daughter likely wants to whisk them away. The click-top clasp I can see perhaps wearing over time, but for not it holds them shut nicely and is easy to open by feel. The gift box is understated yet of quality, so it makes for a lovely presentation.If the woman in your life likes this kind of style, why not spoil her a little? I'm not sure for the price that they are solid gold, and for a 10K mix, some might find them a little pricy.~ Kort

This is a perfect mask/snorkel set for my diving experience level. This set is an excellent advanced snorkel/mask combo. The curved tube keeps the breathing point in the sweet spot when surface swimming. Mouth fit and feel is excellent as is the clearing mechanism. The upper splash guard effectively keeps water from entering the breathing tube when splashed by waves and whatnot. The mask fits snugly and comfortably, keeps water out effectively and has a nice wide range of view. I recommend it as a good economy model for the more advanced diver/snorkeler just short of the expert level.~ Kort (South Florida coast swimmer)

I really like this Quill 66 pen. It writes smoothly and cleanly, feels comfortable in my hand, and looks great. I take a star off though because it feels a bit light and cheap. I'm not sure it will stand up to extended use and I wish it was a bit more hefty. Otherwise, I recommend it as a nicely designed entry-level fine writing instrument.~ Kort

The Ivation Dry Top Snorkel is an excellent advanced snorkel. It's sold alone in case you want to piece together your equipment. Mask sold separately. The curved tube keeps the breathing point in the sweet spot when surface swimming. Mouth fit and feel is excellent as is the clearing mechanism. The upper splash guard effectively keeps water from entering the breathing tube when splashed by waves and whatnot. I have other Ivation sets and this is pretty much the same snorkel that comes with the kit, though here you can choose your own color. Recommended for the more advanced diver/snorkeler.~ Kort (South Florida coast swimmer)

I have to agree with reviewer Cindy. Libert is pretty much the best yogurt I have ever had. It has a sour/sweet taste that is very hard to describe effectively. It is creamy and delicious, better than my standard Greek yogurt fare.  It is healthy stuff, though does have a high sugar content. Aside from that, this would be my desert island yogurt. Sensational stuff that I highly recommend!~ Kort

UAG cases have a utilitarian / military appearance that some users (like myself) find appealing. Others may want somethings a bit slicker and more classy. I personally like the look and functionality and like the UAG logo on the back. The Samsung Galaxy Note 5 snaps in easily and securely. It looses a point for not including a screen protector like the ones that come with the iPhone models, but it does have a protective bumper.It looks a bit bulky in the photos but really isn't, and is very light while still being quite strong. It slides easily into most of my pockets with the 6 model. I like the combination of white plastic and black bumpers/skid pads along the edges. I can see Storm Troopers really rocking this look with their smart phone. There are dimples along the surface that both provide added cushioning and help with air flow to keep your phone cool. Button openings and slots for camera, headphones and other things are correctly placed so there are no issues with fit and finish.I've yet to drop the 6 from any height above 1 foot, but feel confident that the UAG case would protect it within reason. It is a bit pricey when compared to some other cases, but it is a case you can count on.I was sent a sample unit for the Note 5 for objective review purposes.~ Kort

UAG cases have a utilitarian / military appearance that some users (like myself) find appealing. Others may want somethings a bit slicker and more classy. I personally like the look and functionality and like the metallic sheen of the UAG logo against the grey-blue back. iPhone 6 and 6 Plus models snap in easily and securely, and the case comes with a clear screen protector that is simple to apply. It appears a bit bulky in the photos but really isn't, and is very light while still being quite strong. It slides easily into my pockets with the 6 model, and my wife's 6 Plus fits into  I like the combination of clear plastic and black bumpers/skid pads along the edges. There are dimples along the surface that both provide added cushioning and help with air flow to keep your phone cool. Button openings and slots for camera, headphones and other things are correctly placed so there are no issues with fit and finish. If you want to protect your new iPad 6 Plus and like the functional look, then UAG's case should be at the top of your list.I've yet to drop the 6 from any height above 1 foot, but feel confident that the UAG case would protect it within reason.For the price, I would go with the case I originally got for my iPhone 6, the Maxboost HyperPro Series. Perhaps not quite as fancy as the UAG model but I like its tactile grip a bit more and it's understated looks. UAG is a bit more extreme in its looks, and while the contours enhance gripability, the overall case is slicker than the Maxboost model.I was sent sample units for both the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus for objective review purposes.~ Kort

Great for note taking. Thus the selection for meeting category. It looks professional and fills the part capably. The sheet layout is basic but does the job. The cover, binding and paper are of top quality. Anyone bringing this into a meeting will look professional, at least as far as this notebook goes. I have other "At-A-Glance" products and this one lives up to their quality reputation. Some may find the outer cover to be a little too flexible, but that is subjective. I know that when I slide it into my carry-all, I'm glad for the extra flexibility.~ Kort

This 5-drawer chest is a bit dark for my decor, but it is solid with quality materials once assembled. Assembly took longer than advertised. For someone of my intermediate level experience without motivation to get it done ASAP, it took just under 2 hours. My suggestion is to have it on the floor you plan to keep it on after assembly as it is a tad heavy and needs 2 people to maneuver it up stairs.That said, once put together, it is solid and looks good. A quality piece of furniture I hope to make use of for years to come. There is plenty of space in the drawers from everything to socks and underwear to shirts and shorts. Instructions were easy enough to follow and all of the parts were there. I am glad I had a drill though for the screwing part of things.~ Kort

This is an excellent probiotic supplement. I take this in addition to eating yogurt, keifer, cabbage, and other gut healthy foods. I've been a bit gassy since taking it, but otherwise my system has responded well to these tiny gutular reinforcements!  They're easy to swallow and seem to work well. I feel good, and that is what matters. Best taken before or with a meal. Eventually your system will adapt and gas will be less of an issue.I was sent a sample of this product for objective review purposes.~ Kort

While my recent elimination has been good, I have to say that I've been especially gassy since taking this probiotic. I don't question its efficacy, but my system has had trouble adjusting to it, and I am nearing the end of my first bottle. Thus, I question if it works for me. I am not sure I will get another.I received a sample for objective review purposes.~ Kort

What's the bottom line?  Poo-Pourri coats the water of the toilet bowl with a thin film of scented oil that helps keep less pleasant odors from rising from the water. The original scent put Poo-Pourri on the map and it delivers. The Juniper is more woodsy but just as effective. The strong scents of this spray overtake the other scents in the toilet bowl and waft throughout the bathroom and is noticable outside of it. This is powerful stuff! It is a great product for keeping unwanted odors in-check, but use sparingly.~ Kort

Like the Ubiquinol version, this form of CoQ10 is supposed to have better assimilation into your system thanks to the inclusion of black pepper extract (BioPerine). I'm in my mid forties and I started taking Co-Q10 a little while ago for heart health and to help lower blood pressure. I noticed it gives me a bit of extra energy too. Information on Co-Q10 is readily available on the internet, so you can do your own research to see if you think it may be valuable for your. Be sure to consult your physician as well. It is turns out to be a supplement you may benefit from taking, then I think this Viva Labs product is an excellent choice. These dark softgels are easy to swallow and have no aftertaste nor cause me any stomach upset.~ Kort

At almost 45 years old, I grew up thinking Bose products were the best because they are expensive, compact and supposedly innovative. I later learned this wasn't always the case. Still, the Bose name carries a certain panache and high expectations. For the most part, I am happy to say that this sound bar home theater system delivers to all but the most discriminating audiophiles and tech geeks. At this price point, you expect a lot. For the most part, the SoundTouch 120 delivers. It replaces a Sony HTCT260H in my home and is definitely and upgrade. Sound performance is comparable, but I'd give the edge to the new Bose system.When sitting in front of the sound bar, the Bose sounds sharper and fuller. The base woofer fills the room at the low end nicely. I would say 20x20 foot room is ideal for the 120, but can handle larger spaces as well. AdaptIQ helped the sound in our odd space sound great in the main room and the adjoining kitchen. Connectivity to television and in-home WiFi (and mobile device Bluetooth) is outstanding. I love being able to stream Pandora. I'm sure as I continue to use the system and explore more of it's ins and outs, I'll be able to update this review. Until then -- my initial usage impression is quite good and iTunes music is accessible and sounds amazing. The Bose SoundTouch 120 is a bit pricy, but I don't feel like it is overpriced for what you get. 4 HDMI inputs is a plus!The SoundTouch 120 came in a large box and was quite heavy. Be prepared to set up for at least an hour if you want to get it right. It took me a little over that.~ Kort

I'm old enough to have seen the original Star Wars in the theater. I was still under 10 at the time, but I remember it well. It was an amazing experience that transported me to far away worlds and sparked my playtime imagination for years to come. Aside from action figures and play sets, Star Wars merchandise has been hit or miss in the fun department. Especially with gaming. X-Wing and Tie-Fighter were big for me in the 90s but other video games didn't deliver. Fast forward to the present and now we have Disney's Infinity 3.0 Bundle.As a collector, I had to have this for the Boba Fett figure alone. As a fan of TOS, video games, and the latest animated Star Wars shows, this set really delivers. In the huge box you get lots of goodies - as has been laid out by other reviewers. The gameplay is amazing, as is the possibilities for creative fun with what is included. I could spend hours promoting what is provided here, the many pros and the few cons as well, but I'll try to be brief. If you are a Star Wars fan, or if you kids love the franchise -- get this. Get a PS4 if you have to. It might not totally supplant Minecraft, but it will put a big dent in the time kids spend on it. As an old school fan, I've found a lot to love here. Especially the "toy" integration aspect of the whole thing, and the options to create your own gaming fun. This is my first Disney Infinity experience, but I like it. Totally recommended!~ Kort

My cats enjoy Nutro canned cat food. Like any food I give them, it can depend on the day or if they've had a lot of it lately. But for the most part they appear to enjoy eating it. I like that because of the more healthy nature of the ingredients. They like the thicker gravy of some Friskies sliced foods a bit more (Nutro is more 'diced'), but the ingredients are not as wholesome from what I've read. I wish these cans were Friskies sized as well, but they are the 3 oz. Fancy Feast size. That may work for you if you have a single cat, but I like to feed multiple cats from a single can.~ Kort

This is a nice, quality set.The two units can be hung together or separately, but the spinner is definitely for cardinal lovers. The spin effect is pretty nice in a breezy situation no matter what your bird preference is, and the metal construction for both is excellent. The feeder lends itself to larger seeds like sunflower, but tight mesh can hold a variety of bird seeds. No assembly is required, so just fill it up, hang it and you are ready to go. Keep the squirrels away and the feeder will attract a variety of birds, at least here in South Florida. Finches and mocking birds seem to be the norm, though I've seen the occasional Jay. Still waiting for a Cardinal...~ Kort

Eggplant is (in my opinion) a cool, dark-purple color. It matches some oven mitts I've ordered from Amazon and DII in the past. For the price, you can't ask for more. It is a bit on the small side for my 6ft. frame, but it still covers what it needs too. The front pocket hold a standard tablet, or any other item you might need to shove in there. The fabric is comfortable, but sturdy. Perfect for something that will we an outer layer to your skin. Recommended for those who have similarly colored DII products or just want a good apront at an affordable price.~ Kort

Tessa Hadley's 'The Past' is not my usual literary fare. Gentle, meandering family dramas don't usually find their way into my hands for pleasure reading. Historical fiction, action and adventure, fantasy and sci-fi -- these are most often the staples of my reading diet. This lovely novel falls into none of those categories.I wasn't sure what to expect when I cracked open 'The Past', but from the first few pages I was hooked and wanted more. I don't mean hooked in the sense that I had to find out what happens next, because there are no real climactic scenes and overt plot twists to engage such thinking. Rather, I wanted to spend time with the characters. This is an exceptionally well written family drama about four siblings (sisters and a brother) and their families coming together in mid-life at the deteriorating family in the English countryside for a reunion of sorts and to decide what to do with their mother's (grandparents') home. The writing is unrushed and invites the reader to linger and ponder the motivations of the various characters, primarily the siblings but also the ancillary characters. We begin in the present, have a flashback to the past when the mother still lived in the home, and then come back to there here and now.I'm not sure who I would recommend 'The Past' to. Certainly fans of contemporary English literature and Ms. Hadley's other works. But even the hard-core Action/Adventure reader might find something to enjoy in this well-written interpersonal drama.~ Kort

I've been using Expo Low-Odor Dry Erase Markers markers at work and for my kids school needs for some time. They work great and priced fairly.  The AmazonBasics markers may seem more expensive at the outset, but they are larger and should last longer, especially considering their special DryGuard ink. For all intents and purposes though, they work much like Expo chisel-tip markers and while are considered low-odor, they still have a distinctive scent to them. They write easily, thin or thick, and are easy to wipe off in the first day or two. They WILL eventually dry and be harder to remove without a solvent though, so are best used for very temporary note taking or presentations.Aside from making lists at work, my kids use these at school and we have a fridge dry erase board for the daily diner menu or to leave messages for family members. This review is for the color assortment pack. The colors are vibrant and flow well on the whiteboard surface without patchiness or pooling.~ Kort

Finding and appropriately healthy AND good tasting protein bar can be hit or miss. Unfortunately, for me Manitoba Harvest Hemp Heart Protein Apple Cinnamon bars are in part a miss. Perusing the ingredient list, I won't dispute that they are a healthy snack. They're an excellent source of vegan, non-GMO protein and omegas. All in a handy bar form you can take with you wherever you go.  I personally just don't care for their taste and texture. The apple cinnamon flavored hemp has an odd tone and aftertaste, and the texture is a bit off-putting. I like hemp but perhaps this not the best flavor combination (maybe it is the rosemary?). This coming from a guy who eats a variety of healthy bars similar to this. Aside from a rather gritty texture, they also don't look overly appetizing. Not bit deal for the later, but there you go. They are worth trying if you want this kind of on-the-go dietary supplement, but I would not get a whole box to start with. Perhaps they will grow on me. Other options to consider are Health Warrior Chia Bars and/or Detour Smart Nutrition Bars.EDIT: 09/21 - The flavor has grown on me. Still not my favorite, but not bad. Good for an on-the-go healthy snack. 3.5 stars.EDIT: 11/12 - The flavor and texture continued to grow on me. I rather like them now. 4 stars.~ Kort

It can often be difficult to determine if an OTC supplement is working or not. I've no such issue with Jarro-Zymes. The night before these arrived I ate a garlicy bean and pasta dish and it caused some intestinal discomfort (gas, bloating). These capsules arrived the next day and I took one with the leftovers. No issues this time. They are priced fairly and are vegetarian based enzymes rather than ones derived from animal sources, so they actually have a broader appeal. The fact that they really work is icing on the proverbial cake. I don't take them with every meal, but when I eat something I know my system might be a bit sensitive to, Jarrow Formulas Veggie Caps are great insurance against possible later discomfort.~ Kort

Power strips have come a long way. Compared to those from just a few years ago, this one has a very compact size for 6 outlets, ensures 'clean' energy transmission, has built-in child-safe outlet protectors, and a terrific product usage warranty. The slim form is reason enough for me to want it. If I had to find one issue -- and this can be a big one -- is it may be too compact. It moves and twists easily if heavy cords are attached, and the strip is not affixed to anything. Also, with the "ground down" layout, many cords with even small power bricks will block the outlet below, cutting down on the Woods 041450's usefulness.~ Kort

This pricy Black & Decker PureOptics(tm) task lamp is quite impressive. It is well built. It has a USB charging port in the base. The magnifying glass has great optics for peering down at your work. The LED lights run cool and have 5 levels of brightness of what appears to be a fairly neutral light. Basically, I can see someone who needs this sort of light really liking it and getting a lot of use out of it. My wife is a watercolor artist and this is a great replacement for the current 2 bulb task lamp she currently uses on her oversized drafting table workspace.There are some aspects that are not so perfect. The base for this light is heavy. Perhaps too heavy at 12lbs.! it feels like it is stuck to the desktop and it is hard to lift or push it. It's great for lamp stability but bad for flexibility. Along those lines, the arm doesn't rotate in the base. The joints move vertically and the head of the lamp has a wide range of motion, but if you want to move the arm horizontally, then you need to shift the base. Lastly, the light controls are cool but not super easy to use. You press and hold down on one side of the top pad to reduce the light, and likewise for the increasing the light when pressing the other side. Sensitivity varies. A quick touch in the middle turns the light on and off. It isn't overly intuitive, but I got the hang of it fairly quickly.The Black & Decker PureOptics Summit Zoom desk lLamp is a great modern light and tool for those with the desk space and strength to take full advantage of it. The USB charging port is particularly useful for those who use a tablet or smartphone constantly throughout the day and don't want to deplete their battery.  I really like it but for those few caveats.~ Kort

Photography In The Digital Age: The Art of Image Capture (Volume 1) is a great book for the new or intermediate digital photographer who wants to learn everything they can about their new passion. It is a great mix of old school meets the modern age.  Think of it as a 101 type college course in photography. Readers such as myself who are more at the "graduate level" will appreciate the thorough information presented, and may enjoy reading it as a refresher with the occasional tidbit popping up that we may not have known. It explains photography, composition, and color theory in an easy to comprehend format that engages the reader. It is a fun to read book with good information and rewarding visuals, and will be a great resource for your reference library. Mr. Lawton's passion for and experience with photography shines through on every page. I look forward to future volumes that delve deeper into the more advanced aspects of photography in this digital age for producing more impactful images under specific circumstances.I received a copy of The Art Of Image Capture in exchange for an unbiased review.~ Kort

I don't often use stand-alone conditioners. But when I do, I want them to be much more effective than if I were simply using a 2in1 shampoo/conditioner. Nexxus has a reputation for producing affordable salon quality hair care products. The ones I've used thus far uphold that reputation. Emergencee is a luscious conditioner that leaves my hair soft, manageable and moisturized without being weighed down by excess oils. It has a noticeable but pleasant scent that mellows after rinsing. I don't fret overmuch about the abundance of mysterious ingredients in this most other hair care products. This one does what I expect from it and that is what matters. I had fairly dry hair just before using this, and after a single treatment it looked and felt much better, and was more manageable, even when taking into consideration that I have somewhat short hair to begin with.~ Kort

I've been using Ace bandages all my life. It has been a while since I needed one, but my daughter plays basketball and soccer so they are a staple again in my house. I like the new black look over the old flesh tone bandage, and think it wraps as well or easier as the older versions even though it appears to be the same elastic material. The clips, which have always been a weak link for Ace bandages, could still use improvement. It is better perhaps than the smaller, more simple clip that would stick to the bandage cloth by piercing it, but I think it is too big, and too obtrusive. Also it's not as simple to attach to a fresh bandage as the older version. And there is only one, so the side ends of the bandage will inevitably curl. I still prefer the smaller metal ones and some surgical tape strips to cover them so they hold on better. The bandage will still lose elasticity over time, but I've yet to encounter a bandage that doesn't. Thus it is still good to keep one or two of these in your first aid kit, or handy when you or your child is participating in a sporting event. For long-term conditions or injuries, a pre-made brace or compression sleeve (rather than a rap) like Breathable Neoprene Elbow Support or Copper Compression Recovery Knee Sleeves are what I'd recommend.3.5 stars, rounded up.~ Kort

I primarily use loose leaf teas and picked up a bag of this Irish Breakfast from Stash Tea. I prefer it to English Breakfast tea for the flavor which I find bolder and smoother at the same time. Stash's version is quite tasty and hits the right price point for everyday usability. It is comparable to Adagio's Irish Breakfast blend and I use their 16 oz. ingenuiTEA Bottom-Dispensing Teapot to brew mine for 2 minutes with hot water from the fresh water dispenser at work. I like mine without cream and sugar, but if you wanted to brew it a minute or two more, then cream and sugar would go well with it. This is the tea drinker's version of your basic cup of joe. It makes a good iced tea as well.~ Kort

I don't doubt that this a healthy cat treat for supporting a healthy immune system. I don't question that cats find them tasty. My two cats gobble them up. Unfortunately one of my cats can't seem to stomach Tasty Chews. She's thrown up twice after eating them, so I stopped offering them to her. My other cat has shown no signs of sensitivity however. I would recommend L Lysine for Cats chews, but with the caution that not all cats are able to easily eat them without possible regurgitation.~ Kort

For those looking for a step up in quality from VO5 or Suave, this Axe White label is a good, cost-effective option. I'm in my forties but still like many Axe products. Night seems a bit classier than some of their more overpowering scents. It is still strong, especially in the shower, but it soon mellows to a woody and slightly fruity scent. The menthol gives it a nice tingle and I use it was an all over body wash in a addition to a shampoo/conditioner in one. It lathers and cleans well, and leaves my hair and skin feeling and smelling good. The conditioning aspect isn't very strong, but it won't overly dry out your hair either. I feel it strikes a good balance. I was a bit surprised at first by the bright yellowish green color, but does the job and that's what matters.~ Kort

Whoever decided to print this book using such a small font size for the majority of the text should be fired. Seriously, it ruins the any enjoyment or accessibility there might be to this book. And the content, is fantastic. After the engaging introduction, it goes on to review the most currently held theories on the science of evolution, citing countless examples and exploring various time periods and life forms. The photos, drawings, 3D renderings and charts/table pull the view in, but unfortunately the size of the actual works pushes the reader out. There is obviously a wealth of information to be garnered here, surpassing the textbook range and going into reference book territory.I wear glasses. Without out them, much of what is written in this book is just a blur. Even with them on, a lot of it is difficult to read if conditions aren't perfect. This book is a great resource and a book that those with a interest in the subject matter might like to have on had both for reference and to pick up on occasion and read an excerpt from. I just wish the book was in a more over-sized, coffee table format.5 stars for the content brought down to 3 stars because of the overall presentation.~ Kort

This license plate frame now graces my wife's car. Construction and material quality is top-notch. The crystals sparkle nicely. There are some embedded finger prints from whoever glued on the crystals, but nothing you would notice from more than a few feet away. It was easy to install and replaced and old frame provided by the dealer. This one is much nicer, if a bit flashier. I like the Anti-theft caps both for safety and for how nicely they compliment the frame. This is a gaudy yet classy license plate frame, another win from The Friendly Swede!Tastes will vary when it comes to if this is for you or not, but the product itself is top-notch and it comes in a nice gift box. I received complimentary unit for objective review purposes.~ Kort

Viva Labs' Quinoa works great in my rice cooker. Use equal parts rice and quinoa and you have a very healthy starch based side dish. Did I mention that it tastes great too? No? Well, it does? It mixes well with rice or on it's own. This Viva Labs offering is a winner!I was sent a sample for objective review purposes.~ Kort

I've ordered CLA from Swanson in the past. This is my first shipment from Viva Labs. I'm quite happy with the quality, price point, and quantity, though some may find the gel-caps a bit large. No problem for me though. I've lost a few pounds since adding it to my supplement regime, so it appears to be effective. You can read all about it online, so all I have to impart is that Viva Labs is a great source for a quality version of this supplement.I was provided and sample by Viva Labs for objective reviewing purposes.~ Kort

The cat tree looks as if it has everything and then some. But it really doesn't. It has moving parts, and I don't know any cat who is a swinger...literally. There are a hammock and a swing, and they go unused. The multiple ledges are fine, the single cubby isn't bad (though perhaps a bit small for a Persian or Maine Coon), the stairs are a good addition, and the roped supporting bars are great. Otherwise, the material is the type of plush used on kids' toys and not suitable for vacuuming, though it's terrific for picking up shed fur. It is difficult to assemble, and I suggest having two people on hand. Another reviewer wound up assembling it from the top down, and that's a pretty good idea. The color is iffy - neutral enough to go with any dcor, but light enough to show stains from every hairball and shed fur from most cats. I think this is a case where less would have been much more.

The four flavors (2 bars each) have a wide range in the amount of salt and sugar. The dark chocolate with raspberries and sea salted almonds has 11 grams of sugar and 25 mg of sodium, while the milk chocolate with toasted coconut and macadamia nuts has 19 grams of sugar and 40 mg of sodium. The milk chocolate with sea salted almonds (no fruit) boasts 16 grams of sugar and 80 mg of sodium, and the dark chocolate with sea salted pistachios comes in at 11 grams of sugar and a whopping 120 mg of sodium. I found the sea salt to be very uneven; crunching into a chunk of it in the pistachio bar made my mouth shrivel up, and the bar itself didn't taste strongly enough of pistachios. The almond bar tasted better, but somewhat bland. I preferred the dark chocolate to the milk chocolate, though both had a nice, creamy texture. This assortment is intended for gift giving, but for the same price you can get a nice box of Godiva and I'd go for that instead.

This is like a milder form of the kind of book Lolah Burford was known for. Christian, the Duke of Mercia, is shown no mercy by his French captors during the Napoleonic Wars. He's tortured almost to death, and stays alive solely in the hopes of someday killing them all. Eventually, he's released, a gaunt, silent, scurvy-afflicted shadow of his former self, riddled with scars inside and out. Along comes the recently widowed cousin of his late wife, ready to take him - and his newly mute daughter - under her protection. She has her own problems, and the unlikely couple begin to heal together. However, the past is still present, and in an unexpected way it ensnares them both. Most of the book is written in the close third person from Christian's point of view, as is the author's style. Relatively little is revealed from Gilly, the heroine's, viewpoint. The villain is easily guessed early in the narrative, and the bulk of the book is spent dwelling upon the sexual development of the relationship. One point that annoyed me: "Christian" and "Mercia" point too deliberately at Christian mercy, a quality that is understandably lacking in the hero. The reader doesn't need to have this emphasis on every page.

In some ways, this author is starting to grow on me, but I'm still not convinced that one person has written dozens of books within three years or so, all of them lengthy novels with pretty decent editing. Also, I'm not sure the author is a woman, since all the books I've read so far, including this one, are told mostly in the close third person from the male point of view, and most of the sex scenes are written that way. It's almost as if they're written for gay men who want to read historical romance, and I have no problem with that. It's just a different angle for me as a female reader. There are touching scenes and humorous ones, but the reader must suspend a fair amount of disbelief. For example, Noah, the straight-arrow hero, is obsessed with privacy but blurts out marital details to all sorts of people, none of whom have the right to hear them. Thea, the slightly tarnished heroine, has no qualms about quarreling with her husband at every opportunity, yet doesn't force him to listen to her side of a most important story. I was wondering how one of the major obstacles to the happy-ever-after would be resolved, and was pleased with the way the author tied up the loose ends. It looks as if I'll continue reading her books, which she seems to be churning out once a month, making it even more unlikely that she's a one-writer show. I wouldn't be surprised if there was a whole group of men, a writer's club, working together under the name Grace Burrowes.

I rated this 3 stars because I am unable to use this product and have no idea whether it's a complete dud or the best thing since sliced bread. The only thing I can say is that the manufacturer has created it to work with an app, and that app doesn't work with anything I own. It works with many things, like iOS, Android and Bluetooth, but if you don't have a smart phone with those things, forget it. I put apps on my computer, which is an ordinary, 2011 version HP, so I am unable to set up the Nuyu. It looks great, the concept is fascinating, and if you have a smart phone that can download the app, go for it. The app is free, the product is not. If I ever get an iPhone or Bluetooth, I'll load this in a heartbeat.

If you ever wanted to be a hair specialist, here is your chance. This little gadget - which charges pretty fast and lasts long enough on a charge to do the job - has so many options that you can get your sideburns, whiskers, and other manscaping done to your exact specifications. As it happens, I am not a guy, but I found the Panasonic to work just fine on the sculptural aspects of my nape and those irritating wings of hair that fly out in front of my ears because I wear glasses. However, it doesn't work well around the ears, so I took off one star for that. The manufacturer would like you to oil it after every use, but that isn't necessary. The adaptor is an odd shape and uses up too much real estate on the power strip, but that's a minor consideration.

The good news: this is fairly light and easy to assemble, and likely to blend with neutral dcor. The bad news: it isn't really designed for cats. As any cat owner knows, cats scratch because their new claws grow inside the old ones, which become large, rounded, and loose. They need something to dig those claws into, to pull the shells of the old ones off. Any bristly material, like tree bark, or tough cloth, like canvas, or fibrous concoction, like sisal rope or the backing of carpet, are ideal for the purpose. This cat tree is covered with plush, one of the worst imaginable materials. Not only is it ineffective for scratching, it catches lint and shed fur like a magnet, can't be vacuumed without created droopy flops of cloth, isn't removable for washing, and I don't understand why it was used for a cat tree. There are some bits of sisal rope, but hardly enough. This would have been a million times better if the support posts were wood with the bark still on it, or solidly covered with rope or carpet backing. I've seen cat trees with removable, washable pads - that would have been a great idea for this as well. As for the configurations, the little containers are suitable for kittens and small-boned cats, like Siamese, but if you have multiple adult cats, or heavy felines like Persians or Maine Coons, this tree isn't going to be ideal for them. However, it is affordable, pretty, and if you don't mind plush...well, I can't get my mind around it. It's a deal breaker for me.

Disclaimer: I only read Wonderment in Death, by JD Robb, which is why I bought this book. The novella was so good, I only wish the author had chosen to make it a full-length entry in the In Death series. Based solidly on Alice in Wonderland, Lt. Eve Dallas - who doesn't believe in fantasy - and Det. Peabody - who does - find themselves up against a master manipulator. People are committing murder and/or suicide. Why? As a lifelong fan of Alice in Wonderland, I eagerly searched for every clue. This was a very satisfying read, with the author's trademark humor and some of the usual cast of characters involved.

Reader, be warned: this is a reprint of a Harlequin romance written in 1989, and has all the earmarks of that era. It's short. The hero's "secret" past is revealed in the space of a couple of paragraphs and dispensed with fast in favor of the warmth and charm of the heroine's present life (as an innkeeper on an island off the coast of Washington State). The heroine is unrelievedly good, with not a fault, flaw, vice or any physical imperfection. She has golden hair and blue eyes, is an organized bundle of energy, and is universally beloved by all who know her. Love occurs at first sight, which is necessary considering how short the book is. Love is expressed within the timeframe of a single day (I counted, out of curiosity). Within a week, marriage is proposed. Naturally, the heroine is in some peril, from which the hero must save her. However, in a nod to the author's future trademark self-reliant heroines, she has a hand in saving herself. As with any Harlequin, love conquers all and there is a happy-ever-after in store for Charity and Roman. It isn't a bad book, but if you compare it to more recent stand-alones, it has practically no substance.

After the previous book, which was profoundly entrenched in the supernatural, Charlie Parker is almost a shadow of his former self and the reader wonders how long he can keep going. After life threatening injuries, he's trying to recuperate in a small town where, it seems, everyone knows him by reputation and steers clear with a lively sense of self-preservation. His nearest neighbors, a single mother and her pre-teen daughter, are hoping to be similarly avoided - but why? After a body washes up on the beach, Parker finds himself involved in murder once again, but rather than ancient gods he's dealing with ancient people and their dark secrets. He's barely up to the task, but indomitable. The most interesting part of the book was about Samantha, his young daughter, who seems to have unusual powers. Did she inherit them from her father, who has the ability to interact with the Beyond, or is it something else? I was more focused on her than on the rest of the story, and I hope she comes into her own in later books.

As someone raised during the early days of the Women's Liberation movement, I struggled with the idea that women could have it all. It wasn't what I saw among my family, friends, neighbors and coworkers. In discussions, we all wondered what we might be doing wrong. Sooner or later, we all agreed that we were promised too much. In an ideal world, it would be possible to have a rewarding career, a loving relationship, a happy home, and well-raised children, and even some extra time to develop ourselves. This isn't an ideal world. Ms. Slaughter writes a clear and engaging account of the promises (kept and broken), the potential (and suggestions for achieving it) and the basic reality of the choices we face as individuals and couples. She particularly endorses early, frequent and candid communication between partners about their expectations and their willingness to compromise in the short and long term. She cites credible research as well as examples she has encountered. In short, this book is not simply "preaching to the choir" but an excellent overview of a subject that affects us all. Whether you're just starting out, or about to retire; whether you've always been single, or are in a long-term relationship; whether you're planning to have children, have already raised them, or are juggling elder care with babies, there are facts, reassurances, suggestions and a whole lot of fascinating and relevant information. I especially appreciate the lack of jargon and the warmth with which the author writes. She's been there, done that, and has a fine-tuned sense of what is needed next.

This is quite a thriller, and not quite over-the-top. The heroine's story is told in the first person, while alternating chapters are told in the close third person. Kaylee is living a stress-filled life in a small town. Her little brother is gravely ill, her mother doesn't seem to be doing anything about it, and Kaylee's efforts, to date, have all been well-meant but so misguided (even illegal) that she's up to her eyeballs in trouble. When a new social website appears, and everyone in her high school signs up, she finds herself on it as a last-ditch effort to help her brother. Instead, the website, called NEED, gradually seduces the teens into doing mischief, and the mischief has consequences no one could predict. Who is behind this? Why are people dying? And how is Kaylee getting caught in the net of mayhem and murder? I found my heart pounding as I read along. There are, of course, some YA tropes, such as the inability of adults to understand anything or take control. It's all up to the teens. Overall, I thought this was a truly scary book and well worth reading.

These are pretty decent gloves. I've never tried nitrile before, and I like the feel of it. Although the box says "textured", I didn't notice any texture. It's also strange that, on the front of the box, it states "industrial gloves", but on the back of the box it states that these aren't intended for "prolonged, direct exposure to harsh chemicals, where heavy duty or industrial gloves are required". After trying them out, my takeaway is that these are useful for short-term household use, such as cleaning a toilet with bleach or tiles with anti-mold cleanser. That's fine with me. I like to protect my hands from the chemicals in those disposable disinfecting wipes, and that turns out to be what I most often use these gloves for. They're thin, so if you need to protect your fingers while doing more delicate work, they should suit you. But...they're thin, so be careful if using any sharp objects.

Take a breath, you're going to need it. The pace in this, the 41st entry (not counting novellas) in the In Death series, is far faster than in any of its forerunners. Most of the action takes place within a couple of days, and the countdown is given frequently because someone's life is at stake. There's a fairly brief introduction to the villains, so the reader knows up front who they are and has a good sense of what they're doing and why. But Lt. Eve Dallas, in NYC, has yet to meet this lethal pair. There is one new character, Deputy Banner from out of state, and I hope we see more of him in the future. His experience of slower, small-town life makes a nice contrast to the headlong rush of Eve's NY. Since Eve and her husband, the fabulously wealthy Roarke, are now in a fairly smooth relationship, there's only one minor bump to lend interest. Other secondary characters of long standing are hardly mentioned. I can understand that something had to give; in a story based on top-speed police procedural, there's limited space for the extended crew, but I miss the interaction and character development. Baby Bella is turning a year old, Nadine is house-hunting, and Trueheart is taking his detective's exam, but there's very little about any of this. Despite this lack, the sizzling speed and urgency of the investigation keep the reader turning pages quickly. For the squeamish, be warned...there's a lot of torture detailed here. I think some of those details could have been omitted in favor of bringing secondary characters to the fore, but it obviously was not the author's intention to remove attention from the horror of the crimes.

This is a 1990 Harlequin (I now own the large print, hardcover Chivers version from 2004), so the reader knows right off the bat what she'll find: an incredibly rugged, handsome, alpha hero, and an incredibly beautiful, virginal, feisty heroine. In addition, the story's theme is Mail Order Bride,  contemporary version. Out West, where men are Men and women are Little Ladies, Reese Duncan is struggling to save the family ranch. His ex-wife, a beauty from the big city, took him to the cleaners in a nasty divorce, and his heart and soul are now encased in ice as far as women are concerned. But he wants children to inherit his ranch, he wants a warm body in his bed, and he wants a partner to keep house and home while he's out tending the land. So he puts an ad in the paper. Madelyn Patterson is a beautiful city girl who yearns for a more leisurely and meaningful life. She already has some family money, so it's her inner quest that has her responding to Duncan's ad. It's undoubtedly love at first sight, but Duncan resists with all his considerable strength. He tells Madelyn she's not up to the role of rancher's wife and sends her packing. But, after reviewing the few other candidates, he gives in. Madelyn, who is a lot more clear-sighted, understands she's in love and is facing an uphill battle to break through Duncan's reserve, but she's up for the challenge. As these two spirited characters face off and develop a relationship, a minimum of secondary characters leaven the tale. There's Madelyn's brother (who has his own book, "Loving Evangeline"), Floris, the man-hating caf owner, and that's about it. The weather also plays a part, from the scorching summer to the brutal winter, in which both hero and heroine face real danger. Will Madelyn overcome Duncan's distrust? Can the ranch be saved? Will true love win out? I give you one guess!

This is one of the author's best books in years, and certainly the best of the Survivors series (this is the sixth of seven planned books). The hero, Percy, who at first appears to be too good to be true, has endearing flaws and faults. He's afraid of heights and the sea, he's unbelievably rude, and he's rather aimless, having drifted on his good looks and fortune all his adult life. The heroine, who at first appears to be too damaged to heal, has strength and qualities that gradually endear her to the reader. The heroine's backstory, known in part from previous books, is that she was captured with her husband during the Peninsular Wars, watched him be tortured and die, and she has been an emotional wreck ever since, even though it is now eight years later and she's managing to endure life in a superficial way. These two unlikely people come together, and sparks fly. But they are not alone in the story. There are delightful secondary characters, such as Lady Lavinia, who collects stray humans and animals, and Cousin Adelaide, who hates men with a passion and has no hesitation about expressing her opinion in front of the foe. There is also something sinister going on, and it turns out to be as relevant to the past as to the present. The suspense holds up well, the confrontational dialogue between hero and heroine is often quite funny, the romance is believable, and the ending totally satisfying. After reading the last few books in this series, I was starting to think that the author had lost her luster, but this reassures me that she has a firm grasp of the reins!

The conclusion of the Sanctus trilogy is thrilling, but if anyone is strongly invested in Liv and Gabriel, the heroine and hero of the first two books, be prepared: this book focuses more on another hero. Agent Shepherd (all the names in all the books have strong significance, by the way) is a rookie with the FBI, yet somehow gets partnered with an experienced agent and the two are sent to investigate an extremely high-profile event: sabotage of the Hubble space telescope. They're hampered by a lot more than the usual villains. There is a religious conspiracy at play, with seemingly unlimited funds and other resources. The weather has turned on its head everywhere, and people are taking to the road in unprecedented and unstoppable hordes. Everyone is going home, whatever home means to them. Liv is out in the desert, pregnant and apparently in charge as a motley assortment of refugees make their way to her side. Gabriel is tied to a bed in the Citadel, the ominous home of an ancient order of monks. A seemingly incurable disease is wiping out people. And Shepherd has more at stake than tracking down bad guys. I was satisfied with this book, but I would have liked to have read more about Liv and Gabriel. Still, there was a thrilling and satisfying conclusion. The author has a new series on tap, and the first book of it was already terrific, so I'm going to stick with Mr. Toyne for future adventures.

The second installment of this thrilling trilogy does NOT suffer from the usual failings of the middle book. In many trilogies, they are often a weak link between an exciting start and climactic conclusion. But The Key is a strong novel, and essentially a long chase, from America to Turkey and back and into the desert. Liv Adamsen, a crime reporter from New Jersey, is investigating the apparent suicide of her brother, who had been a monk in a reclusive, sinister and all-but-unknown religious order in Turkey. Gabriel Mann, descendant of an ancient tribe (think 7,000 years ago or more) is doing his best to keep her alive while the monks and the Catholic Church are out to see her dead. All around them, the world is beginning to collapse; weather patterns are running amok, people and animals are migrating, and a horrific disease is taking hold. Is it the End of Days? There's a host of secondary characters, many of them quite well-drawn, considering the rapid pacing of the story. There are heart-rending scenes, enigmatic puzzles rooted in ancient times, and I loved this book as much as I loved Sanctus, the first one.

This is a terrific book, truly thrilling, with some surprises and lots of intriguing possibilities. It's the first of a trilogy and, although I think there are too many trilogies on the market, this is one time I approve. It starts off mysteriously enough, with a monk in an ancient and secretive order. It looks as if his brethren are going to kill him, but he escapes...sort of. This sets off a chain reaction that involves the entire planet. But the focus is on the monk's sister, a journalist who has been searching for him for years. As soon as she learns of his whereabouts, she heads to Ruin, Turkey, where there are those who seek to kill her at all costs, and others equally devoted to saving her life. In the meantime, the world is changing in astonishing ways, from unexpected weather events to the migration of people and animals. The characters are intriguing and most are well rounded. The writing is very good and keeps the reader turning pages as fast as possible. I wanted to read it in one sitting, but have to work for a living and was impatient for the workday to end so I could return to this enthralling adventure. By the way, the heroine's name is Liv Adamsen...her name is highly significant, so keep it in mind.

These are ordinary cordless phones made of cheap plastic, so I don't expect them to last more than a few years. Sometimes I dream about the Good Olde Days, when my Verizon corded phone lasted for decades. But that was then, and this is now. The answering machine can be wall-mounted, and a bracket is included. The Quick Start Guide is pretty comprehensive, but there are even more details available online. Instructions are clear, and in a readable font, and drawings are well done. I appreciate this very much, though many of the functions are bells and whistles I don't need. One thing that is handy, for people who tend to put down handsets and wander off, is a handset finder. Press a button, the handset rings, and you go right to it. The sound isn't perfect, but I'm not sure how much is due to the phone, how much is attributable to the fact that it's cordless and subject to interference, and how much can be blamed upon my service (Time Warner). Overall, I'm happy with these phones.

From 2007, this book features one of the author's kick-a$$ heroines who is also a damsel in distress on multiple occasions. It's a win-win for readers who like romantic suspense with a guaranteed happy ending after all sorts of mayhem. Phoebe is a hostage negotiator in Savannah. She has a lot to juggle in daily life, including an agoraphobic mother, an ex-husband who doesn't care about their child, and an insubordinate cop with a serious anger management problem. Then she meets Duncan. He's laid back where she's tightly wound. He's rich, having won a multi-million dollar lottery. And he's gorgeous and willing to fight for her. Then there's Carly, the 7-year-old daughter, Essie, the mother, Ava, the family friend (female), Dave, the family friend (male), Carter (the brother) and his wife Josie, Duncan's friend Phin and his wife and mother...lots of characters. And a fair amount of plot, as it becomes clear that someone's out to get Phoebe and possibly people around her. Is it Arnie Meeks, the bad cop with pull in the department? Is it someone else? Who and why? Set in Spring and Summer, the Georgia heat is almost a character as well. If you've never read a book by Nora Roberts, this is a pretty good place to start. It has some of her trademark witty banter between Phoebe and Duncan to offset the steadily increasing suspense if you don't like too much heart pounding, and it has passionate interludes if you do.

There are three things I really like about this stapler, and three that I don't.Pros:- it is balanced so that you can press anywhere and it will staple - you don't have to lean on the front alone- it staples flat, as advertised, so if you have piles of paper to file, this will save some space- it staples up to 30 sheets, which is far more than the average staplerCons:- it's heavy, about a pound. If you often staple in the air, by holding it in your hand and squeezing, your wrist will hurt- those flat staples are hard to remove; if you're filing something like taxes, that you plan to shred in a few years, this will annoy you or tangle your shredder- the top doesn't open up, so you can't staple anything to the wallAdditional notes: the staples themselves, because they lie flat instead of looping in the back, can scratch you. They're expensive compared to regular staples.Bottom line: if you staple on a desk, staple many pages, and don't plan to remove those staples, this is for you. If you generally hold a stapler in your hand to staple, are likely to pick out the staples at some point, or are on a budget when it comes to stationery supplies, skip this.

Once upon a time, four decades ago, Alice Cooper was a phenomenal sensation in the rock world. Their deliberately staged shock rock outraged parents, fascinated fans, and made headlines and filled performance arenas everywhere. The music was deliberately gritty, with lyrics designed to incite. Some of those songs hold up beautifully, especially the teen anthem School's Out. A fairly young reporter, Bob Greene from Chicago, pitched the idea of traveling with them on their Christmas tour, the Billion Dollar Babies tour, as a singer and performer (he couldn't sing worth a hill of beans, but that's another story). They let him in and this is the book he wrote about it. He covers all the bases: each of the band members (and their emotional baggage); their manager, the roadies, the groupies, the fans. He records with them and shows how marketing and hype were skillfully handled, as in a radio interview where Alice is presumably fishing on vacation, but the phone call is actually taken in the recording studio in NYC. A lot of scenes are clearly manipulated for effect, but that doesn't detract from the overview of life in a famous band as they tour. The book is now out of print, but you might find it in your library and it's worth reading. You can extrapolate a lot of it to other bands at other times.

This book is a quarter of a century old (1990) and reflects the style popular then: the fragile, virginal young heroine who yet survives every peril - and, believe me, there are plenty of perils on hand for Emma McAvoy, illegitimate daughter of a famous rock star and an unstable, low-life woman. We first meet Emma when she's a precocious toddler, subject to the physical and emotional abuse of her hard-drinking, drug-using mam. Jane thinks she can get back with Brian McAvoy, the poetic lead of the world-renowned band Devastation, but she'll be happy to take money instead. Brian, only 23 and about to marry his pregnant girlfriend, is unprepared for the addition of a brutalized little girl to his life, but he doesn't hesitate.We meet the members of the band, each with his own emotional baggage, and see how Emma grows into being their mascot. Then, tragedy strikes. Years pass, the band members are doing well or ill, and Emma is still their mascot. There's no flash forward; this is a fairly leisurely book, which is nice. Eventually, Emma is an adult. Falls in love, marries...then tragedy strikes again. Emma is like a lightning rod for this kind of thing. And, although it looks as if she's finally finding real love again, there is yet more tragedy in store before the happy ending we know will occur.This is the first Nora Roberts book I ever read, and I've reread it many times over the past 25 years. It holds up very well, so I recommend it, with the single caveat that if you weren't around back then, and are unfamiliar with the Perils of Pauline plotline that so many romance novels used to have, you may find it disconcerting.

I've read this several times. It's one of the best of the author's books in recent years, and it's like romantic suspense comfort food. You know in advance that all obstacles will be overcome, the heroine will be strong, the hero likewise, and there will be a happy-ever-after, complete with some witty dialogue and sizzling sex along the way. In some ways, the author is a careless writer. She telegraphs a lot of the plot, and an intelligent reader can tell what's going to happen and when. But it's a fun read - well, if you don't mind a couple of serial killers with their warped agendas.Fiona Bristow trains dogs, including Search and Rescue, and she's part of an S&R team. She lives on a remote island off the coast of Washington, and has loyal and devoted friends and family (I'm including her three dogs as part of that family). Simon Doyle has recently moved to the island and his mother has foisted an untrained puppy upon him. Naturally, he brings Jaws, as the voracious pup is named, to Fiona for training. Simon is one of those rough heroes. No tender words, a surly expression, a cranky attitude, and an unwillingness to fall for Fiona, even as he falls hard and fast.Along comes a serial killer, and the rest is the usual storyline. Since I've read this several times, I've long lost interest in that part of the book and skim it to get back to the banter and developing relationship between Fiona and Simon. This is a very enjoyable book, and if you haven't encountered the author before, I do recommend it.

The bright and cheerful patterns on these dividers will definitely appeal to schoolgirls (not sure about boys on this). The big tabs allow for longer titles, useful for today's more complex subjects in high school, particularly. Instead of Math, how about Advanced Placement Calculus? The 5 dividers come with a printer-friendly sheet of 18 tab inserts, so the dividers are good for three semesters...actually, they're sturdy enough that you can just make your own tab inserts and continue using them. The pocket part swoops up very high, the better to hold sheets without them leaping out, as papers tend to do with most such products. However, smaller bits of paper are likely to be harder to retrieve - index cards come to mind. So I took off one star for that, as I do have small scraps of paper to stow from time to time. More troublesome are those tabs, which is where the second star came off. They stick out of any normal binder. You really need an oversized binder, otherwise the tabs stick out and are prone to catch on things, be rubbed and, eventually, damaged. If you don't mind anything sticking out of a binder, and are careful with it, this won't bother you. I'm very careful with things, but this does bother me. I suppose the next step would be for Avery to create an oversized binder suitable for this product.

I've never tried an air purifier before, though I know people who have/had them. This one was not impressive. First, it has an odor. I don't know if it's because of impurities that emit a smell once trapped in the gadget and exposed to heat from the machine, but I'd rather be in a room that has impurities and no odor than vice versa. Second, I live in a large city, where the air has plenty of particulate matter. So the filters have to be changed more often than the manufacturer recommends, and that runs into a chunk of change over time. Third, notice the recommended room size for this. It is too small to handle a large room or an open floor plan. Fourth, it's pretty noisy. So if I use it in my bedroom, it is not comfortable because of the noise, but I can't use it in the living room/dining room because that is too large an area. I don't want to use it in the bathroom because of the high humidity, which leaves the kitchen. Unfortunately, past experience has shown that steam heat and greasy heat in the kitchen can gum up the works of machines, so I don't want to risk using it there. To sum it up: too expensive, thanks to the never-ending supply of filters, too noisy, too smelly, and not suitable for my needs.

Never mind the color on the computer. This is a much more attractive, darker red, and I liked it a lot more than I thought I would. It's made of some kind of pleather, so while it isn't soft at all, it can be scratched by a hard object. The back has a thin velveteen cover, and it can be used vertically or horizontally. The only thing I wasn't too keen about was the single rotating clip that holds the back in place, but the back opening is only a flap, open on three sides, so that is unlikely to fall off unexpectedly. Overall, I am very satisfied with this. I bought it to hold a little painting, and it looks great!

I happen to have both the monthly/weekly smaller planner, which fits into a tote bag, and this large monthly planner, which doesn't. Comparing the two, I've realized that it's more helpful to have both monthly and weekly pages in any size than simply monthly pages, even in a larger size. The best thing about this planner is the thick, flexible cover, which can be wiped down easily. In descending order, other good parts are the double-spiral binding, which prevents snags, a 2-pocket plastic page in the back for stray papers, a list of holidays (religious and secular, including Canada and Mexico, going out to 2018), and providing full boxes for Saturday and Sunday instead of combining them as many planners do. I received this free, but I did check the price. Unfortunately, I believe this planner is overpriced for the number of pages inside.

There are heroines who are too stupid to live. There are, more rarely, male characters who are too stupid to live. This book manages to have one of each, which makes it too stupid to read. I'm generally a fan of Ms. Mallery's Fool's Gold series, but this entry (#17) is more annoying than romantic. First we have Phoebe. Our heroine starts out as a do-good doormat. She performs a criminal act just to help out someone who doesn't deserve to be helped, then placidly accepts that her entire career may be lost due to her stupidity and makes excuses for the real bad guy (gal - her boss). Then we have Chase, a secondary character who commits fraud, theft, insider trading and who knows what else...but he has charm galore and just about everyone forgives him and makes excuses for him. What they ought to do is put him in juvie. Or send him to a psychiatrist. He doesn't seem to understand that he's actually committing illegal acts and we're not in Kansas anymore, Toto. Then there's Zane. In keeping with the author's usual technique, he's suffering from a past trauma that haunts him constantly. He could also do with some counseling, but never mind - Phoebe's on hand to distract him. What distracted me, as a reader, was the way she's a tiny woman and he's an unusually big man, so when the inevitable scenes of intimacy appear, some purely physical complications keep crossing my mind, though they don't cross the page. The way the Fool's Gold series is set up, each segment is comprised of a trilogy. This book is the second - always a weak link - in the sixth trilogy of the series. The book is stuffed to the brim with characters from the other 16 books, which creates unnecessary clutter. Since it's published by Harlequin, I am not giving you any spoilers when I say that there is attraction at first sight and a happy ending in store for the hapless heroine and the curmudgeonly cowboy. Why I keep reading the series is beyond me. But there have been some good books in it, and I'll probably continue to follow it, while secretly hoping it comes to an end before it jumps Sharknado.

This is a ghost story and a whodunit, and - having been written a long time ago - a charming period piece. There's no sex, no graphic violence, no profanity...just good writing, good manners, gentle humor, and many plot twists in a short novel, or novella. Mr. Brenton finds himself deceased on Christmas Eve, and disgruntled at being a witness to the world without being able to affect it in any way. He encounters various other people in the afterlife, most of whom are quite happy with their lot (and an ingenious explanation is offered for Hell). But his main concern is his wife, a beautiful young woman who is promptly charged with his murder. Despite being advised to stay out of earthly affairs, he decides to clear his wife's name and find his killer. It's a quick and delightful read, and I highly recommend it!

This is a pretty awful book with a poorly-blended mesh of genres, of which not one stands out to take charge. It starts out with a poor girl finding a humble job (cleaning toilets for a billionaire). Presumably, she's in college studying business, but there's never any indication that she learned a single thing. Her main feature is a bosom of amazing size, but nothing is done with that, either. There are bits about the billionaire's rocky childhood, more bits about a rocky coming-of-age, but in general, Dorian has all the personality of a flounder and he flops around for most of the book. There's a very feeble attempt to insinuate kinky sex, but it's so inadequate it should have been omitted. There's danger, which doesn't appear until the end of the book, and is dealt with so rapidly that it has little effect upon the reader. And there is no, I mean NO, sizzle between Tori and Dorian. Zilch. Zip. She should go back to cleaning toilets, at which she excels, and he should go back to standing around ineffectually in the vastness of his estate. The reader should go elsewhere for entertainment.

The white and off-white towels are attractive, but the brown is a muddy color and the greenish/bluish color is not pretty. These are thin cloths with very sparse raised loops. That sounds cheap, but actually it is a reasonable construction for its purpose as dish towel or bar mop. It is nowhere near as absorbent as terry or Turkish toweling, but if you just want to wipe down a table after a meal, or a counter after preparing that meal, or dry off a plate or glass, it is fine. I've sworn off paper towels (as much as possible) and have been collecting an assortment of dish cloths and towels. So far, I've been happy with DII products and I have plenty of them. They do shrink after washing, but the square footage isn't an issue when wiping down something. Really, the only thing I dislike about this set are those colors!

Mary Balogh has written so many books that she can probably pen one in her sleep that will still be better than most other historical romances. But she has a distressing tendency to write series that go on a bit too long and the result is a crowd of characters from previous books which distracts the reader from the hero and heroine of the present one. Not only that, she often pulls in characters from previous series or stand-alone novels, and those tales date back decades (of our time) though the novels may all be roughly contemporaneous. In this offering, Ralph is the heir to a dukedom and under considerable pressure to marry and keep the succession intact. Chloe is a woman  who is ineligible for marriage, through no fault of her own (and there's a nod to Pride and Prejudice in the situation, which I appreciated). Chloe proposes to Ralph and the two strike a bargain: a loveless match. She'll get children to love and a secure life; he'll avoid any possible entanglement while doing his duty to his rank. Naturally, things go wrong immediately, starting with the death of his grandfather within hours of the wedding. Chloe's dream of living in a modest manor turns into life as a Duchess. Ralph's constant depression and despair - the result of service in the Napoleonic Wars - must give way to membership in the House of Lords and taking up the reins from his late grandfather despite his real preference for a different life.  I found this book somewhat tiring. The constant dwelling upon Ralph's suicidal trauma and Chloe's woes was a drag. It was almost with relief that I encountered all those characters from other books and was able to reminisce about their stories as a change of pace. Although the modern rage for trilogies is swamping every genre from YA to romance, in this case I wish Ms. Balogh would stop writing extended series, cut back at least as far as trilogies, and keep some of those excess characters out of the way.

When I selected this book, I was impressed by the number of prestigious awards it had won. Then I learned that the original novel was only 40,000 words, not what we'd consider a novel at all. Further, it turned out that this book was originally published back in 2002, and the version I read was a rewrite to extend the story to a full-sized novel by American standards. Considered the Philippines' first crime novel, it's a fascinating yet grim tale of the truly downtrodden: forgotten people living in a trash dump, digging up tidbits to sell because there are no jobs to support them like human beings deserving of dignity. They are also deserving of justice, yet the author points out that justice takes a back seat to corruption in the Philippines. Apart from the politics, which are infuriating and fascinating, the book is engrossing. The villain is somewhat generic, a serial killer. The sleuths, however, are unique: a pair of Jesuit priests, one trained in psychology and the other as a forensic anthropologist. I liked this book on several levels. First, it's an excellent crime novel. Second, I cared about many of the characters. And third, arguably the best part, was the unique location of the story.
