I had been afraid that expanding the book would make it a great novelette with a lot of filler, but that is not the case. Ms. Batacan is a very talented writer and I look forward to reading more of her work.

There are many good things to say about this planner, and I'm about to say them. The only negative factors are very minor, so I'll say them first and get them out of the way. First, unless you write in pencil and are willing to erase, anything you enter here stays entered, even if your plans change. Second, it's a bit large and heavy to lug around in your handbag. BUT, the good far outweighs those trifling considerations. I like just about everything about this planner. The spiral binding is a double spiral, making it very strong. The covers are a thick, yet flexible "pleather", so I don't feel worried about damp-wiping them. There's a 3-year reference at the beginning, if you're interested in seeing what day of the week a date will fall (I like to know if my birthday will fall on a weekend!). There's a modest personal profile for your name, address, phone and email. Note: only room for one phone number and one email address is provided, but most people I know have home, cell and work phone numbers and several email addresses, so Acco ought to update this feature in subsequent planners. This is a planner for the Academic Year, meaning July through July. There's a tab for each month, opening to a 2-page spread of the entire month. The tabs are reinforced with plastic. Many holidays are already filled in. A small calendar inset of the previous and following months is provided, along with a small area for notes. I'm happy to report that both Saturday and Sunday get full squares instead of sharing one square. The monthly squares are not ruled. The following pages feature 2-page spreads for a week at a time, and those squares are ruled. Again, there's a section for notes. Although the last tab is for June 2016, all the pages (month and weeks) for July 2016 are present. Acco ought to add the July tab in subsequent planners. Following the last week, there are a couple of ruled pages for contacts, without specifying the type of contact. That's handy if you're less interested in addresses and more in websites, for example. Then there are several ruled pages for notes and an event calendar by month that doesn't state a year, which is handy for things like noting anniversaries. For reference, there's a list of holidays out to 2018. They include secular (and Canadian and Mexican holidays) as well as religious. There's also a map of time zones and area codes - personally, I found the area codes useless, as people tend to take their cell phones all over and their original area codes go with them. Finally, there's a plastic page with two pockets if you need to stuff in a few loose papers along the way. This may not be perfect - I'm very attached to my Excel spreadsheet, which can be altered and color-coded with ease. But if you don't have a smart phone, or your computer crashes, this planner is not likely to let you down.

These short stories, or essays, were the basis for a popular series of monologues given by the author. They are vignettes of life as a NYC cop over a span of 20 years. Starting in the 1980s, armed only with a high school diploma and a gung-ho attitude, he joined New York's Finest during a time when crime was so rampant that one borough was nicknamed Krooklyn, and a precinct in the Bronx was known as Fort Apache (the movie was loosely based on it). It is clear that the author has little technique or polish. But the stories speak for themselves, making this a worthwhile read. They are sometimes humorous, sometimes sad, and give a good feel for what things were like back in the days when the city had more than 2,000 murders a year and felons would sometimes commit their crimes right before a police officer or even inside the police precinct. You had to be there to believe it. I was, and I remember those days vividly. The city is very different now, and every citizen is armed with a cell phone to record what's happening. That is good, and I'm all for it. But, once upon a time, there was so much crime, and so little to fight it with, that strong measures were called for. This book describes some of them. You may not approve, but you'll be enlightened, and entertained.

Although I'm not too keen on the writing (it's a bit flat), the concept of the story is excellent and it held my interest. This is intended to be part of a series (yes, another trilogy - I'm really tired of the way EVERY book can't stand on its own any more), but I think it's enough to read this and imagine the rest, as the ending is not too much of a cliffhanger. It's somewhere between YA and adult science fiction. An experimental military spacecraft, Ananke has a top-secret mission. Dr. Althea Bastet is the computer expert who is in charge of the machinery. The first thing you notice is that a lot of the names evoke ancient gods, and this is done on purpose. Ananke is an amazingly intelligent computer, and Althea is more involved with it than with people. But there's a whole world outside the two of them, and that world is comprised of the System, which controls the people, and rebels who want to overturn the System. Some rebels wind up on board Ananke, and the next thing you know, they've tinkered with the computer. Now, Ananke is becoming sentient, and people aren't the only danger. Ananke, as a machine, doesn't have any empathy. It (she?) is like a baby turning into a toddler and thinking of herself as the center of the universe. Can Althea save her beloved ship? Or will Ananke take charge? Great concept + mediocre writing = well worth reading, but perhaps not worth buying. Check it out of the library.

The only reason I selected this book was because it supposedly featured interviews with celebrities about how gratitude impacted their lives, and it's pretty shallow of me to look for something that indicates depth in people I normally only see one-dimensionally on the movie screen. However, what I wound up with was a book that triggered me to begin my own gratitude diary. Unfortunately, I have to confess that it works. It helps. I HATE when New Age-y stuff works!The premise is simple, and it's been around a lot longer than the current trend. Look on the sunny side of the street. Pollyanna put a good spin on events a century ago (or longer?). Let a smile be your umbrella. Smile and the whole world smiles with you. Pay it forward. Or the Victorian mantra: Every day, in every way, I'm getting better and better. In this iteration, it's up to us to improve our physical and mental health, our relationships with others, and the world as a whole, by being grateful. We can be grateful for family, friends, a job, our homes, the weather, you name it. And that's where the diary comes in.It's easy to forget when you're grateful and what you were grateful for, so you keep a journal. As often as you can (I write daily), jot down at least one thing you're grateful for. You find yourself, during your normal daytime activities, thinking of ways to regard events positively. Sometimes you actively look for things to be grateful for. By the end of the day, you have some pleasant memories, and you've managed to overlook or soften any negatives you encountered.It works. I gave the book only 3 stars because it's a bit of overkill. This should have been a magazine article instead of a book. The author goes through a chapter being grateful for her husband (yes, comments from scientists and celebrities are tossed in), then a chapter being grateful for her kids, then...you get the picture. Every chapter, she's focusing her gratitude on another aspect of her life. I found her writing to be workman-like and well-meaning but not truly inspirational or engaging.

Originally written in 1983, this is a period piece. If you haven't read any of the Harlequin/Silhouette romances from that era, this is a decent example: there's practically no plot, and from page 1 on, the reader knows exactly what's coming (pun intended). It's as obvious as a neon sign that Rule Jackson, manager of the Texas ranch, is - and always has been, and always will be - passionately and obsessively in love with Cat. It's even more obvious, as the book focused on her, that Cat is, always has been, and always will be, passionately and obsessively in love with Rule. It's actually her ranch, but she fled it after having unprotected sex with Rule. She was a 17-year-old overcome with hormones. He was a 28-year-old Vietnam vet with lots of issues. Nowadays, that would raise red flags, but remember: 1983. Older, experienced man? Check. Young virgin? Check.Well, now Cat is home. She's 25, a widow, and Rule is ready to make a move on her. This begins in the ranch plane as soon as he picks her up from the main airport and doesn't stop until the last page. In between, he is jealous of her date with a perfectly nice guy, she is jealous of the way her stepsister throws herself at him, and to top it off, she wonders whether he truly loves her or just the ranch and will do anything to keep control of it.I can't tell you why I enjoy this book so much. I'm a big fan of Linda Howard, and when she writes well, she packs a punch. This is from early in her career, where she shows promise but honestly, this book is a piece of series fluff. Still, I reread it every decade or so. There's a lot of sensual kisses, virile masculinity, and melting surrender going on. If you want a pleasant way to spend a couple of hours and would like an alpha man getting what he wants while the feisty-yet-vulnerable heroine dithers, this is a great read. If you want a book with more depth, I recommend any of Howard's later books, like Mr. Perfect.

I don't normally read Christian fiction, and selected this book by accident. It's not a bad read, though neither is it especially good. I enjoyed the concept of it: a young woman who competes in Trivia tournaments finds herself somewhere between life and death, surrounded by dead celebrities. She has to come to terms with her emotional baggage, which is literally baggage - a pretty little trunk, which she's never seen before, is brought out of her car. Between memories and the type of flashbacks experienced by Ebenezer Scrooge, she reexamines her life and the choices the people in her life made, and the way she reacted to them and made her own choices. The biggest problem with the book is that a whole lifetime of memories is reviewed in a relatively slim volume. I think it would have worked much better if a small number of traumas had been dealt with and more time had been devoted to each. It also would have helped if her present life had been described better before plunging into the past.

While teenagers change clothing styles, hairdos, and dreams of what they'll be when they grow up, there's one thing that is immutable: the Best Friend. The real best friend, the one they've known since elementary school (if not from infancy). The one who knows every single detail about them, and loves them anyway. The teen years are filled with angst; I think half of it is propelled by hormones, but the other half is real enough. Life is about to change, they're going to launch into college and then out into the world, they're heading to the heady world of adulthood. In this YA novel, everything goes to pieces. Zoe and Olivia, inseparable, were going to be professional dancers. They've worked themselves to death, only to discover that the dance school is dropping them. They're good, but not good enough. While working for years on their now-unattainable goal, they gave up a lot...like other friends, and a social life. Awkwardly, they begin to pick up the reins and travel a new path, one including others. Then, just as it looks as if there are possibilities left for them, Olivia runs out of possibilities.Better have a box of tissues on hand while reading this. I found myself crying over it. My childhood best friend is still with me, half a century after we met, and the thought of losing her is devastating. I also remember a boy from middle school - not a friend, just a kid from class - and how shocking it was to all of us when he became ill and died. It seems impossible. It's wrong, it's against the laws of Nature, and how can anyone deal with it? This isn't what a teen (or an adult) signed up for when signing their friendship in blood.Some of the writing is a bit awkward, mixing metaphors, and some of it seems anachronistic. I've never heard a teenager say "snazzy", and even my contemporaries don't use the word. It's from my parents' generation. Some of it is written simply, which I think suits a topic that runs so deeply, but some is almost overwritten. I think it will appeal to teens who are heavily invested in their best friends, which means teenage girls. I can't envision a guy reading this. An increasing number of YA novels are being read by adults, but I don't think this will appeal to grown-ups.

The late Shirley Jackson, whose untimely death robbed us of endless reading pleasure, was an incredibly gifted master at conveying psychological horror. She understood that no description of mutant spiders with dripping fangs can ever compete with the fears in a person's mind and the evil in his heart. Using plain language and carefully crafted sentences, she could turn an ordinary commute home into an exercise in peril, and keep the reader guessing until the last sentence whether that peril is real or imagined. Sometimes, with a twist of genius, she even leaves the issue in doubt.At the same time, she had a deft touch with comedy, and mined her large family (four children and a husband, who is almost never named) for scenes that a reader can relate to completely. Most people have encountered her work already; her classic short story, The Lottery, is read in high school. Even if you haven't read one of her novels or many short stories, you have probably seen one of the movies made from them, such as The Haunting of Hill House.Decades after her death, her children have gone through her uncollected short stories, unpublished short stories, essays, letters, and some notes from speeches she gave, and put together this wonderful collection. If you're already a fan of Shirley Jackson, you won't want to miss this book. If you haven't encountered her yet, you can start here and get a sampling of her fiction, non-fiction, horror and humor, all in one place. And if you're a big fan of horror, you should try this to see how well it can be presented without the modern Stephen King-style trappings.

There are many suspense and mystery series which can be read out of order. This isn't one of them. There isn't sufficient backstory (though the author does try) to place a new reader in context and allow him to catch up with the regular characters. So, if you haven't read anything by Mr. Sears before, don't start here. After a promising, but not stellar, debut novel, and a much better sequel, this third book flounders a bit. It settles down in the second half, with clever chase scenes, thrills and a few chills. As for the Villain, there's more than one, and I guessed the identity at the first mention. There's a clever little bread crumb in the description of the character that the reader can detect right away. As for the convoluted plot, it includes insider trading, the rich and shameless, alternative energy sources, and computer hackers. There are any number of murders, endless Bad Guys willing to commit more, and the usual cast of characters: the almost-middle-aged hero, his autistic son, his girlfriend...who wants to become the mother of his next child...his father, his father's girlfriend, his employer, a buddy in the FBI, a friend who used to be his girlfriend's employer, the friend's new employee...as you can see, there are many characters. That's apart from a victim (or is he a villain), his wife, assorted lawyers and bankers...now you know why it isn't possible to convey sufficient details on the people, and you'll need to read the first two books to understand the third. In 340 pages, you have all the above characters, and plenty more, as well as the intricate plot and assorted secondary characters who appear for a few pages, and to top it off, there are chase scenes and fight scenes and scenes from Long Island to the Caribbean to New Mexico. I think the author needs to consider what he wants to tell the reader and pare down the rest. He's trying to cram an awful lot into too few pages. However, I'm willing to read the next book in the series to see if he improves.

I thought Outlander was nearly perfect as it was, but I was thrilled to find that the sequel was nearly as good. The setup is slightly different. Outlander was linear, and told the story in the first person all the way. Dragonfly in Amber tries another tack. The story alternates between the present and the past (mostly the past), with the past in the first person and the present in the third person. Set twenty years after the end of the first book, Claire Beauchamp Randall is now a doctor. Her daughter, Brianna, is a tall, red-headed young woman who accompanies her mother to Scotland on a little vacation after Frank Randall's death. Little does Brianna know that she's in for a shock: Claire, who promised Frank never to mention this during his lifetime, is about to reveal Brianna's true father: Jamie Fraser, the man she married back in 1744, just before Prince Charlie tried to regain the throne. There's another major character involved. He's Roger Mackenzie Wakefield (he made a brief appearance in Outlander, when he was a little boy). Roger is also in for a shock about his lineage. Once those shocks have been announced, the story reverts to the past. Claire and Jamie are expecting their first child, and they're stationed in Paris. Their goal is to thwart Prince Charlie's attempts to raise money and an army. Can they succeed? Old enemies and new ones appear onstage. Old friends and new ones are embraced or lost. Similar to Outlander, the author writes in a leisurely manner, crafting her sentences carefully and enjoying sidebars on everything from medicine to witchcraft to life on a farm. Although this is an excellent book, I found myself impatient to get through the chapters set in the present because the past was so compelling.

I've been a fan of John Sandford since Day 1 and have all his books in hardcover. So it's with regret that I have to report that his latest Prey novel, featuring Lucas Davenport, is sort of mediocre and predictable. The best part of it is the more-than-cameo appearance of Letty, his adopted daughter, whom I absolutely love. I'd be thrilled to see a spin-off series featuring her, though the author has indicated he has no plans for this. Since the author is somewhat up in years, churning out a yearly Davenport novel, a yearly Flowers novel and now a YA trilogy and his first sci-fi novel, I can see where his schedule may not permit any more series. There will be some changes in the Prey novels ahead, though, as indicated by Lucas' increasing disenchantment with the Bureau of Criminal Apprehension and a bit of a twist at the end. Otherwise, this story is not as good as it could have been. The bad guys, known to us from the first page, are uniformly bad. As the author well knows, even the worst character needs some relatable or redeemable quality to get the reader invested in the outcome of events. The usual interaction of Davenport's team is mostly offstage or missing, as he goes Lone Ranger, wandering out of state and taking the lead in hunting down the bad guys. Arguably the most interesting plot device, involving Juggalos, is handled weakly. More information on this subset of society would have improved the book immensely. The basic plot has Letty befriending some Juggalos, then becoming involved when it appears that one has been killed. Letty is removed from the story before the shootouts begin. Davenport's other children are barely mentioned; ditto for Weather, his wife. There is plenty of action, a fair amount of gore, and the usual high-speed travelling hither and yon. Though it doesn't equal the best books in the series, I'm hopeful the next one will be better and I'll continue to pre-order it in hardcover.

The author won the Nobel prize in Economics, but that wouldn't necessarily make him a good writer. I'm happy to say that this is a very readable, interesting, often humorous book. Whether Mr. Roth had a ghost writer assisting him or not, I enjoyed this a whole lot. This is definitely for fans of Malcolm Gladwell and the Freakonomics team. He dips into all sorts of transactions that don't directly involve money: the "matching markets", where a law student has to find a judge to clerk for, and vice versa, or something more urgent, like matching organ donors to those in need of transplants. For example, take those law students. Judges in desirable locations might not have any difficulty in recruiting a clerk, but judges in undesirable locations would. How do they compete? There's a rule about it, so they're not supposed to try to lure in clerks ahead of time and undercut the competition, but cheating - by judges, who set the rules! - is rampant. There are other factors at play, because the schools benefit when their students are taken by top judges, and then there is a whole subset of judges who are neither at the top of the heap nor the bottom of the barrel. The would-be clerks are also heavily invested, as their future career may depend upon a buff resume. And the professors who recommend them are also invested. Who follows the rules? Who breaks them and why? Can the process be fair? Anyone who thinks that economics is as boring as the drone of a housefly should try this book and get a new perspective. Economics affects us all, and not just in the wallet.

This is a crisply written book about several related topics, but the focus is on survivor's guilt. Shiv (that's a nickname) can't get over the loss of her brother Declan, and is rapidly becoming so self-destructive that it's clear she wants to join him in death. Her fractured family, trying to deal with their own grief, can no longer handle her. One last solution remains: a stay at an unusual clinic, where Shiv must face her feelings and memories. Over and over again, the things she can't escape are the things she must see and embrace. Can she learn to internalize her brother and make him a part of herself? Can she return to life, which is arguably a worse punishment than death? At least, once dead, she wouldn't have the constant burden of memory and her role in the events that ended so tragically. Shiv is far from alone. The other residents of the clinic are equally troubled. Can they, too, come to grips with their lives, or will they opt out? Although this is a very dark book, I found it interesting and moving. Having lost a loved one under horrific circumstances, I related well to Shiv's grief, but I don't think that's a prerequisite for reading this book.

I read an Advance Reader's Copy of this before it was published...nearly a quarter of a century ago. Since then, I've reread it many times, and although I'm no longer surprised by the plot twists, I still enjoy the characters, the story, and the quality of the writing. Nowadays, time travel is nearly overused, but back in 1991 this book was iconoclastic and original. There is a lot of sex and graphic violence; the first time I read it, I was a bit taken aback by it. But the world has changed a lot, and you can see (and hear) much more explicitness on TV, let alone read it in a book. Here are just a few of the many things I love about "Outlander":- the characters are not only well developed to begin with, but they continue to develop and grow as the novel progresses- the author takes the time to bring the reader fully into the settings- the story is not too linear; there are any number of sub plots and explorations of history, botany, medicine- the sentences are crafted well; it's a pleasure to read them- there is plenty of humor to leaven the darker aspects of the taleI first read it in one sitting, staying up until dawn to finish (and ruining my weekend!). It was worth every minute. I wasn't sure I'd want a follow up novel because this one seemed so perfect, but the following seven have kept up the pace and quality (plus an offshoot series based on a minor character)In short, I recommend this book to anyone who enjoys good writing, history (the Jacobite uprising of 1745), careful plotting, complex characters, plenty of humor, and a touch of the paranormal. The love story of Jamie Fraser and Claire Beauchamp Randall is very powerful, but this isn't a typical romance by any means. I consider it historical fiction from an extraordinarily talented writer.

I've been a fan of the author for decades, to the point where I normally pre-order her books in hardcover. It seems as if the time has come to rethink that habit and save my money. First, almost everything in the book is a rehash of a previous book. Red-headed heroine? The Search. Renovating an old house? Tribute. Small-town bully who goes too far? The Witness. Precocious toddler? Rising Tides. (There's even a scene with the toddler that appears to be lifted straight from that book). On and on. The "surprise" plot device can be guessed within the first chapter. The heroine is not too bright a bulb, and it's simply infuriating to accept her choice to pay off MILLIONS of dollars of debt that isn't hers. The book is amazingly slow for more than half, then sort of trundles along. Apparently, the author wanted to play with the idea of Southern relationships by listing lots of people with long names and convoluted connections to the heroine...but none of these characters appear again in the story. They are named. That's it. They don't further the plot. In fact, very little furthers this plot. I don't see a lot of heat between Shelby and Griff. He falls for her red hair at first sight. There's actually more warmth between Griff and Shelby's precocious toddler. I was terribly disappointed with this book. At least in other novels, there's something else to engage me, like details of training Search and Rescue dogs (The Search). There is no interesting sub plot here. If you've never read a book by Nora Roberts, don't start with this one! If you're a big fan, borrow it from the library if you must. But don't waste a dime on it.

It's no secret to anyone that knows me that I love my coffee. I can't function properly without a few cups of java in my system, especially when I wake up in the early morning hours trying to catch up on a few reviews on blog as well as on here.That being said, I was naturally interested in reviewing the Espresso Whole Bean Coffee (Sudamerica). I could smell the 2.2 lbs of coffee before I even opened the box it was shipped in. Despite already having a cup of coffee before I received the bag of coffee beans, I dragged out the coffee grinder and grounded some beans, just enough for a pot of coffee.I would like to point out that I like the fact that this brand doesn't use any chemical pesticides or fertilizers as it preserves the original flavor of the beans.How did the coffee taste? Well, it was toasty with a sweet, smooth and heavenly delightful taste. Overall, I have enjoyed trying out the Espresso Whole Bean Coffee and I recommend it to other coffee drinker!I received a complimentary bag in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

Not everybody can chop an onion like the chefs do on the cooking shows. Yes, they make it look easy, but for us regular folks, we can easily cut ourselves if we chop that fast. There are many different electronic choppers as well as the manual ones available to purchase that are easy and safe to use.About a week ago, I received the Kuuk Onion Chopper to test out and review. I already own a device that will cube an onion, but sometimes recipes calls for the onions to be smaller, so I wanted to test this chopper out. It's pretty simple to use. All you have to do is put a few small chunks of onions into the cap, slip the bottom of the chopper into the cap and press down on the handle to start chopping. The more you press the handle up & down, the finer the onions will be.The body of the chopper is made from heavy plastic, so it should last for a long time, if taken care of properly. It easily comes apart for cleaning.Overall, the Kuuk Onion is a cute little device that cuts an onion pretty well.I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

Reviewing a "bedroom companion" when you are single is a difficult thing to do, which is one of the reason why there was a delay in writing this review. Nevertheless, I wanted to get the product reviewed while it was still 2015! Now enough with my rambling, lets get on with the review.Indulge is made by Intimance and it's a pretty big bottle at 16 ounces! It's a water based lubricant that is made from glycerin, water, carboxymethylcellulose, pentylene glycol and potassium sorbate. The bottle sent to me was manufactured in June of this year and will expire in May 2018!What can I say? Indulge: Personal Lubricant is odorless, colorless and slippery. Trust me, you don't need very much, just a drop of it will get the job done. Overall, the Indulge is a pretty decent lubricant to have handy. (No pun intended!)I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I have a bad habit (well, it's not that bad) of saying 'yes' to reviewing any testosterone booster that comes my way and that's exactly what happened with the Mangatest, which I received a complimentary bottle in exchange for my honest thoughts. (All opinions are my own!)Each 60-cap bottle features mostly the same ingredients that are found in most testosterone boosters, such as Horny Goat Weed, L-Arginine, Ginseng, Ginko Biloba, etc.. According to the label the product is made right here in the USA. It's supposed to help increase strength, aid in building muscles, boosting hormones and it will aid in weight loss if you're eating a balanced diet & exercising regularly.While I've only been testing this out for a week or so, I've had no problems with the product so far. I take it (2 caps) in the middle the afternoon when I need an energy boost. There is no caffeine or anything like that in it. I've haven't exactly seen an energy boost while taking this, but my alertness is more clear and I'm able to push my body to finish a few activites (workouts, housecleaning, etc.). Overall, I do like the Mangatest. I recommend taking this along with a NO2 supplement.

After reading the first book in the Road to Kingdom series a few  years ago, I was an instant fan of Nancy Mehl's writings. Plus, I always like authors that live in my home-state of Missouri. While I had read book two (Deadly Echoes) in the Finding Sanctuary series earlier this year, I went ahead and reread it prior to reading book three, Rising Darkness, which was released earlier this month to bookstores.Once again, the setting is in Sanctuary, Missouri, but this time the story centers on an ex-Mennonite named Sophie Wittenbauer, who had left her strict community in Kingdom to start a new life. She takes a job working at newspaper office under a new identity. Sadly, she can no longer escape her previous life after she receives a tip that a criminal might be hiding somewhere in town. While this might seem like a great story for a newbie reporter, there is a slight problem - Sophie recognizes the criminal's name and she's worried that her past will be exposed.To make matters worse, she runs into an old crush from her childhood, Jonathon Wiese, who is a now a pastor in Sanctuary. There are threats and dangers around every corner, and while Sophie doesn't exactly trust Jonathon, she might not have any other choice, but to let him save her life.Like I already mentioned, I'm a fan of Nancy Mehl's works as she does an awesome job blending in romance and mystery to create an intriguing read. For this book, I was hooked into the story by the third chapter and I read it fairly quickly. (It was read in a couple of hours and a several cups of java!) The main heroine, Sophie, is a strong character that held her own through the entire novel. I like that that the author made some connections to the Road to Kingdom series. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed reading Rising Darkness and I do hope the author revisits Sanctuary in the near future. I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

In my continuing quest to review all the books that have been collecting dust on my desk for months, today I'm reviewing Deadly Echoes, book 2 in the Finding Sanctuary series, by Nancy Mehl. I stumbled upon her Road To Kingdom series a few years ago and I've been a fan of her writings ever since.Set in the same Mennonite community in Sanctuary, Missouri that had to deal with a horrible kidnapping in the first book, Gathering Storms, Deadly Echoes centers on Sarah Miller, who moved to the small town start a new life as a school teacher and to reconnected with her sister, Hannah. Their parents were murdered when they were young and they were separated after going into the foster care system.Out of nowhere, Hannah is also murdered, leaving Sarah to raise her niece by herself. While she could just let the local authorities try to solve the murder, Sarah believes there is a connection between Hannah's death and their parent's murders. With help from Sheriff Paul Gleason, she is determined to unravel a mystery that has been hidden for almost twenty years.Being from Missouri myself, I always appreciate a novel that is set in my home-state. While this is book two of the Finding Sanctuary series, it's a standalone novel, so you'll have no problems reading this if you haven't read the first novel. Nancy Mehl is definitely one of my favorite new authors as she likes to blend in romance and mystery, all of which is set in a small religious towns. Deadly Echoes has a really great mystery plot as well as an interesting heroine that kept me flipping through the pages. I originally read the book back in February, but since I was so late in writing my review for this, I reread the book a few weeks ago to refresh my memory. Overall, Deadly Echoes is a well-written mystery that I enjoyed reading from start to finish. I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I have way too many plastic food containers stored in the kitchen cabinets that need to be thrown in the trash as some of them have broken or cracked lids. That being said, I was happy to receive the Sunella Buddy Boxes.The 4-pack set is free of BPA, phthalate and lead. It meets all FDA standards. Each container measures 9.5 inches in length x  6.2 inches in width x 2.2 inches height and features three different compartments. The main compartment can hold up to 3 /12 cups, which is enough room for a sandwich, the second compartment measures 1/13 cups and the third compartment holds about 1 cup. The set comes with four sturdy lids (green, light blue, orange and red). The containers are microwave, dishwasher and freezer safe. Plus, you can easily stack the containers to save space.The Suneslla Buddy Boxes were delivered to my doorstep (the mail carrier literally left the box on the doorsteps) on Tuesday afternoon. Since they were new, I went ahead and washed the containers and lids in the dishwasher before I tested it out. As stated on the box, these aren't leak proof, so you might want to cover the containers with plastic wrap or foil before putting on the lids, just for extra precautions. Plus, you want to make sure not to always lay the containers on a flat surface, even when you put them into a lunch box. Overall, I do like the Sunsella Buddy Boxes. The containers (boxes) are big enough to store a sandwich, vegetables, fruit or whatever your heart (well, stomach) desires.I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I didn't realize how much junk I carry in my wallet until I received the Secret Felicity Men's Vintage Genuine Leather Money Clip Bifold Wallet in the mail a few days ago. This wallet has a cool vintage brown leather look to it. The actual leather is somewhat thin and soft, so it doesn't feel as bulky when carrying it my pocket. It has plenty of room in it with eight card slots, one ID window, one zipper coin pocket. There is a cloth divider in the dollar bills area as well as a long zipper pocket.Overall, this is a well-crafted wallet with plenty of room to carry all your stuff in it.I received a discount coupon for the wallet in exchange for my honest thoughts.

I hate to say this, but sometimes your neighbors should just mind their own business instead of stirring up trouble. While the premise of the novel isn't exactly new (Ever heard of Romeo and Juliet?), Lesile Gould unleashes her storytelling magic to create an intriguing story involving an English family and Amish family, whom must overcome their differences, so they can live in peace. I enjoyed all the characters, except for Charlie as his character and his romance with Eve seemed a little forced at times. Overall, for me, Amish Promises wasn't exactly a perfect read, but it wasn't a letdown either. The author's writing skills kept the story moving, therefore, I kept turning the pages.Note: I read this back in July, but I'm just now getting the review written. I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I had never even knew there was such a thing as Amish fiction until I read The Covenant (book one in the Abram's Daughter series) by Beverly Lewis, which was either in 2001 or 2002. I had joined one of the those book clubs where you get five or six books for $.99 and you have to buy three or four books during the next two years at full price. The Covenant was one of the books I got for joining the club. I recall I was short one book, so I just picked The Covenant as it looked an interesting read. Let's just say that I became a fan of Beverly Lewis's writings very quickly. I ended up purchasing her previous novels and I have continued to read each and every new release of hers.While many of the author's novels are part of a series featuring three to five books, she does occasionally write a stand alone novel, which just happens to be the case for The Love Letters. (No, this isn't the made-for-Hallmark movie from the late 90s.)  This story is set in 1966 and centers on Marlena Wenger, a young woman with a lot on her young shoulders. She was set to marry Nathaniel Zimmerman shortly after she finishes her classes prior to being baptized into the Old Amish Order, well, that is until she learns that her grandfather has passed away and someone needs to go to Brownstown, Pennsylvania and assist her grandmother, Mammi Janice, for the summer. Guess whose going?Yep, you guessed it - Marlena must put her life on hold to help out her grandmother. Not too long after arriving in Brownstown, Marlena learns that her estranged sister Luella has died in a car crash. Luell had left the Amish lifestyle to marry her sweetheart Gordon Munroe, who is currently serving his country in Vietnam. This leaves Marlena the guardian of her baby niece, Angela Rose.Her grandmother's neighbors are Ellie and Roman Bitner, who have a mentally-challenged son, Jake (known as Small Jay). Due to the Jake's problems, Roman has emotionally distant himself from the boy. All the boy wants is father figure, and eventually he finds one - Boston, a homeless man with signs of Alzheimers. Jake talks his parents into letting Boston stay in the small house on their land that once belonged to their late Dawdi, where Jake reads Boston's old letters to him.Meanwhile, Marlena must decide what is more important - marrying Nathaniel or taking care of her family.The Love Letters is a completely different novel for Beverly Lewis. While the majority of her novels is about the romance between an Amish girl and her beau, the novel is about faith, family and trust. For me, it starts out a little a slow for the first several chapters, but I eventually got swept into the story. Overall, The Love Letters is an emotional tale from beginning to end.I read the book back in April, but I'm just now getting around to writing the review. I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

It's almost hard to believe that there are only five more weeks until Christmas Day. Though I do have about 99% of my gift shopping finished already, I'm not exactly in the holiday mood this year. Every time I stumble upon a Christmas movie on the Hallmark channel, I avoid it all costs. I've also been skipping over the radio stations that are playing holiday tunes. No, I'm not a Scrooge. I just guess the Christmas magic hasn't exactly hit me yet. That being said, I had signed up to review a several holiday themed novels for a few book tours awhile back and I've delayed reading them as long as I could.One these books (well, a novella) happens to be An Endless Christmas by author Cynthia Ruchti, which centers on Wilson and Dodie Blinder hosting Christmas for their large family (children, grandchildren, etc.) at their cottage in Minnesota. They're excited that their grandson, Micah, is going to ask his girlfriend, Katie, to marry him. Micah asks her to marry him in front of his entire family and Katie's answer is - "No!"Unfortunately for Katie, she has no other place to go, so she's stuck at the Binder cottage for Christmas. Most of the family are upset with her for breaking Micah's heart, but Dodie sees this extra time as an opportunity for her grandson to win back Katie's heart.Typically, I have a good idea what a book is about by just looking at the cover at, but with a only a small cottage surrounded by snow on the cover, I had no idea what An Endless Christmas would be about. At only 232 pages, the author, Cynthia Ruchti, doesn't waste any time setting up the main plot. There is a proposal and an answer right on the first page, except the outcome is shockingly, "No." Overall, An Endless Christmas is a simple, fast-paced and sweet story that ignores all the cheesy holiday cliches that are found in books as well as movies. Speaking of films, I can easily see this novella being adapted into a movie for a Hallmark or Lifetime. I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

've test out several different brand of NO2 supplements over the last few years and for the most part all of them have basically the same ingredients (well, at least what's listed on the labels). The NO2 Booster has a few extra ingredients that I don't normally see in this type supplement, such as Beet Root Extract and Common Oat Extract. Just like any other supplement, I know that it will take awhile for it to get into system, if it even works for me to begin with.That being said, I've either taken the NO2 Booster (3 caps) right before I exercise or right before I'm going to do excess cleaning. (Hey, the holidays are coming up and the house needs to be spotless.) After the first day, it took about 90-minutes or so for me to notice a difference in my endurance. It wasn't a big boost, but it was enough for me to finish what I was doing. Slowly, I've seen an added increase in energy, even on the days that I don't exercise Overall, the NO2 Booster is a decent pre-workout supplement.I received a complimentary bottle in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

From the Start is a contemporary romance by author Melissa Tag that was released back in April by Bethany House. I have a bad habit of picking out books directly by their covers, but that wasn't the case with this book as I actually read the synopsis first. After being intrigued by the plot, I thought I would give it a try.The novel centers on screenplay writer Kate Walker, a young woman that writes made-for-TV romances, but her own love life is completely empty. Unfortunately, she has a series of bad luck starting with the lack of movie projects to work on. With no other choice, she packs her bags and returns home to Maple Valley, Iowa in the hope that she will find a new meaning (or career) for her life.This is a romantic tale, so of course there is a love interest for Kate, whom happens to be a NFL quarterback, Colton Green. Due to a recent injury that has sidelined him from playing football, Colton has been hiding out in his friend's (Logan) hometown, which as you have probably guessed, it's in Maple Valley. And guess who Logan's sister is?It's Kate! (How predictable!)After learning that Kate is writer, Logan gets her to help him write his autobiography. This means the two of them get to spend a lot of time together, so naturally some sparks fly and they learn that there is more to life than just football and writing sappy screenplays.The main character, Kate, in this book writes made-for-TV romantic movies, the one genre that I don't like watching as I find them corny and unbelievable. Ironically, I do like reading romance novels for some weird and unexplainable reason. Sadly, From the Start's plot feels more like a made-for-TV movie. (Yes, I've seen a few, well, a few scenes while flipping channel surfing.)The good news is that Melissa Tagg is a talented author and she works her magic to make the plot believable. Since I do dabble occasionally with my own writings, I instantly connected with Kate. I didnt care much for Logan. It probably has to do with the fact that I'm not the biggest football fan. (I'm a baseball fan!), so I couldn't connect with him. However, the two characters do have chemistry, which made the romantic parts more real. Overall, while From the Start isn't exactly a touchdown, it's not a fumble either. (Get it? I do know my football language.) I found the book to be a fun read.(Note: I read From the Start back in late April, but I'm just now getting around to writing the review for it.  I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

Between reading romance novels and horror books, I had a chance to read a new mystery-thriller, titled Vendetta, book one in the new Nikki Boyd Files by Lisa Harris.Vendetta centers Nikki Boyd, whom is part of the Tennessee Missing Persons Task Force. After her sister, Sarah, went missing nearly ten years ago, she decided to make it her life's mission in saving others, and hopefully one day she'll piece together the clues behind her sister's disappearance. Her hopes might finally come true when she discovers a link between Sarah and a recently missing teenager, Bridget.As she begins to investigate, she stumbles upon a bigger mystery than what she could ever imagined. To solve the case and rescue Bridget before it is too yet, Nikki must team up with her good friend, Tyler Grant, the widow of her best friend who died in accident a year ago, but standing in their way is the killer known as the Angel Abductor.While I had mixed thoughts on Lisa Harris's Hidden Agenda, I thoroughly enjoyed reading Vendetta, which I read in one afternoon. The plot is well put together; reminding somewhat of the early (and better) books by James Patterson. The characters are developed nicely and the descriptions are also nicely done. Overall, Vendetta is fast-paced, mystery-thriller than plays out more like a movie than a book. I was glued to the story after reading the first chapter and I couldn't put it down until I finished reading it.I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

Though I have read a few other books by the Robertson clan, I didn't know what to expect from Blessed, Blessed... BLESSED. It turns out that the title is part  autobiography of Missy and Jase's marriage and other other half is about their daughter's (Mia) fight against the cleft palate. Mia seems to be a strong kid as she has had several surgeries during her young life. You don't have to be a Duck Dynasty fan to enjoy reading about about the emotional journey that Mia and her family has went through over the years. Overall, I found Blessed, Blessed...BLESSED to be a wonderful read.I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I'm not much of a morning person without at least one cup of coffee in my system. Many of the breakfast blends are little too light for my taste. I do like the idea that you can purchase just a 3-pack of K-cups instead of having to buy a box of 12, so I won't have to be stuck with a bunch of coffee that I don't like.The Wakey Wakey Coffee has a smooth taste with just enough kick of caffeine to wake me up in the mornings. As of lately, I have had a bad habit of adding a bit of zero calorie sweetener to my coffee, but I didn't need any for Wakey Wakey Coffee as it already has a smokey flavor to it, so I didn't need to sweeten it up.And added plus for me is the fact that the cups are recyclable friendly!I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I don't recall reading the first book in there series, Home to Chicory Lane, but I did read the sequel, Two Roads Home, during the summer. While this book could be read as a stand-alone story, I do recommend reading the first two books as the plot centers around recurring characters. Typically, a Christian fiction is set around two characters that have never met each other and when they do, they fall in love. Here the main characters are already married, but their marriage and faith is being tested by the fact that they are having problems starting a family. Overall, Another Way Home is a fast-paced novel that I read in one sitting. The author did a marvelous job crafting a wonderful plot with likeable characters.I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

Christmas is less than two-months away and a few of the cable channels are already playing holiday themed movies. Many of these movies as well as countless books feature Santa Claus and elves. While I have nothing against Old Saint Nick, many kids can get confused about what the really meaning of Christmas is.Now available to own in bookstores is the picture book The Berenstain Bears: The Very First Christmas by the late Jan Berenstain and her son Mike Bernestain (whom has taken over the Berenstain Bears series).The book begins with the Bear cubs (Brother, Sister and Honey) asking  Papa to read them the story of Christmas from the storybook Bible. From there he tells them the about the birth of Jesus. The entire book is written in a similar style of the other Berenstain Bears' titles, so young readers can easily understand it. The story is accompanied by beautiful illustrations.Overall, The Berenstain Bears: The Very First Christmas is a cute picture book that tells the story of what Christmas is really about. However, I felt that it ended abruptly. There should have been another page or two with Papa and the Bear cubs at the very end. I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

Probably almost everyone has heard of the Italian Chef  Giada De Laurentiis who has had a cooking show on the Food Network since 2003. Happy Cooking is her 8th published cookbook. Why is it called Happy Cooking? Well, the author says she is happiest when she's in the kitchen.While Italian meals are always tasty, many of them come with a high calorie count, so Giada is compiled together the best recipes that healthy and delicious. She kicks off the book with "First Things First: #breakfast, featuring recipes ("Nutella" Milk; Greens Eggs, and Ham Wrap; Caprese Frittata; Carrot and Apple Muffins, etc.) that will give you just enough energy to start your day.Find the perfect snack in "Snacks & Small Plates,:" such as The Only Bean Dip That You'll Ever Need; Soy Citrus Turkey Jerky; New, Improved "Puppy Chow;" Warm and Spicy Popcorn; Pumpkin Spice Latte Popcorn; Italian Lemonade; Mediterranean Chile Chickens Wings; Goat Cheese Toast, etc..It's important to eat many greens each and every day, but it can get a little boring. In "Salads & Seasons," Giada puts several new spins on salads, eggplant and zucchini with recipes such as Better Wedge Salad, Hummus Salad and Herbed Cucumber Salad.With winter not too far away, it would be the perfect time to find new "Soups & Stews" recipes. Giada has come up with several unique recipes, like Child Watermelon-Basil Gazpacho and "House" Soup; Slow-Cooker Black Bean and Pork Stew.For those who do like their Italian meals, Giada features an entire chapter on "Pastas & Risottos." A few of the dishes are Brown Butter Tortellini, Pasta e Fagioli with Mussels; Parmesan Marinara; Short-Rib Lasagna; and Pasta Pizza.To all the health nuts, Giada has a whole chapter dedicated to eating healthy, titled "Eating Clean." A few of the recipes are Detox Soup; California Lettuce Cups; Tuna, White Bean, and Bitter Green Salad.Coming up with the perfect meal during the week can be difficult, but Giada is helping us out by creating many intriguing meals in "Weeknight Warriors." A few of the recipes are Yogurt-Marinated Chicken; Chicken Sausage and Mash; Stuffed Chicken Parmesan; Pan-Seared Salmon Burgers with Fennel Slaw; and Make It at Home Fried Rice.Every main dish needs something to with it. In "Vegetables & Sides," there are plenty of healthy delights, such as Corn Fritters with Cherry Tomato Salsita; Smoky Candied Carrots; Creamy Polenta; and Caesar-Roasted Broccoli.There is a small chapter called "Weekend & Holiday," featuring great recipes, such as Roasted Chicken and Potatoes and Leeks; Sunday Pot Roast; Fourth of July Pizza; Turkey Breast "Porchetta;" and Monte Cristo Sandwiches.Lastly is "Treats & Sweets," which should satisfy anyone's sweet tooth. A few of the recipes are Pumpkin Ginger Chocolate Muffins; Lemon Ricotta Cookies with Lemon Glaze; Orange Cream Butter Cookies; Espresso-Peanut Butter "Better" Cookies; and Cupcake Shake.While I've only watched a handful of Giada's cooking shows, my grandma is a big fan of her (and everything else on the Food Nework), so I thought I would give Happy Cooking a try. The cookbook is nicely put together with pictures that go along with the recipes as well as pictures of Giada and her daughter. There are also cooking tips and neat introductions to every chapter/section. I've only had time to try out a few of the recipes, but the ones that I did are simple to make, thanks to well-written directions. Overall, Happy Cooking would make a great addition to anyone's kitchen.I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I've never personally roasted coffee beans before, but after a quick internet search, I quickly learned how to. While I read about several different methods, I just covered a small amount of extra virgin olive oil in a frying pan and then scattered a handful of the coffee beans in the pan. On medium heat, I heated up the pan and placed a lid on it. Eventually, I started hearing crackling sounds, which means the beans were being roasted.Overall, the Adrano, Brazil Volcano Coffee has a nice, rich taste to it. While it does take a little time to roast a handful of beans, it's definitely worth it as it makes the coffee tastes so much fresher. I received a complimentary sample  in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

When I had signed up to review to Doctor Who: Royal Blood, I wasn't aware this was part of The Glamour Chronicles series, so I'm not for sure which part this is in the series. For me, it feels more like a stand-alone novel. I didn't like for the constant change from the third-person narrative to the point-of-view of Lord Bernhardt. While the author did a decent job with crating the chemistry between the Doctor and Clara, the plot is badly cliched. I mean how many times is the doctor going to go to a medievil world, where there just happens to be something weird going on. Now, I'm not saying that this is a complete waste of time to read, but Doctor Who: Royal Blood could have been better written.I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

Let me start out by stating that this is the first salad spinner that I've used, so I didn't know quite what to expect when I received it. The clear bowl is made out of clear, thin plastic, so you need to be careful to not to crack it. The white strainer is more durable. The lid seems to be well constructed and the handle can be easily locked when you don't want to use the spinner. I do like that I can store the vegetables in the spinner bowl, so I keep it in the fridge and save it for another meal. Overall, I'm impressed with the Brieftons Salad Spinner as it easily washes and dries salads.I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I never seen a tightening ring before until it was recommended on here when I was buying some other fishing gear. Since it was cheap, I went ahead and purchased the large size.Basically, this is just a plastic ring with a thin piece of rubber wrapped around it. The rings is used to help cinching, rigging and knot tying braided lines. If you've ever had to braid a line, then you would know how annoying it can be. If the line is already wet, it can take forever to tie a knot.Overall, I found the tightening ring simple to use and I can now easily tie a knot in a fishing line without worrying about cutting my fingers on the line.

While I always carry a pocket knife when I fish, I never bring along a pair of pliers, which can come in handy when a hook gets stuck in a fish's mouth. I saw that these fishing pliers were cheap, so I purchased it along with some other fishing gear.I was little thrown back when the packaging didn't have MadBite on it, but instead the packaging had Chinese writings. Nevertheless, I removed the pliers from the packaging and stuffed it in my tackle box. I finally used them last week to remove a stubborn hook from a fish and I easily removed the hook without breaking it.The fishing pliers are small, but well constructed. Overall, I do like the pliers.

I purchased this fish sale as well as a grip scale as my county's lake as a fishing limit as well as pound limit.This is more of a  traditional scale with an Aluminum body, a handle at the top and a hook at the bottom. There are markings on the body that measures both in kg & lb and goes up to 25 pounds. I wanted to check the accuracy of the scale, so I weighed some small weights and it gave the correct weight.Overall, I do like this fishing scale. It's very simple to use and it fits perfectly in the bottom of my tackle box.

Two things that I've never owned is a fishing gripper or scale. The county lake has a limit to the number of fish you can catch as well as a minimum pound limit per fish, so I thought it was about time that I buy a fish scale. I couldn't decide if I what kind of scale I wanted, so I purchased this one as well as a more traditional fish scale.The grip scale (yellow) is shaped like a gun. It has a small digital display screen with a on/off button that uses a CR2032 lithium cell battery (included). The description stated that I has an adjustable arm strap, but instead this one has a spiral-type key chain attached to the handle, which can be used as a strap. The actually grips are made from stainless steel.I tested it out with some small weights and the scale gives an accurate weight. Overall, I've been impressed with this grip scale. I especially like the sheath that comes with it.

Let me start out my stating that I have never quilted anything in my life. However, I have several quilters in my family, so I know a little too much about quilting. I've seen the original Wonderclips in the stores and they're a little expensive. Last year for Christmas, I gave my mother a set of a similar off-brand and she has loved using them to hold down the binding on her quilting projects.That being said, when I was offered a chance to review the Evergreen Craft Clips for free in exchange for my honest thoughts and I eagerly said yes as I can always give these to my mother for this year's Christmas.This set has 50 craft clips. Each clip features a clear side and a colored side of either red, orange, blue, purple or yellow. They're made out of hard plastic along with a metal strip. I've tested out each (Yes, all 50!) clip and every one seems to be pretty sturdy. There is a seam allowance line on the clear side of each clips. Overall, I do like the Evergreen Craft Clips and I recommend them to others.

Being a coffee lover, I was intrigued to try the Cappuccino flavor. Please take note that you really should read the directions as it calls to use a spoon to thoroughly mix it with water or milk before you shake or blend it, if you don't, the whey protein doesn't get blended quite right. I would like to point out that this does have Stevia Leaf Extract in it as I do know that some prefer not to use it as a sugar substitute, though it doesn't bother me at all. Overall, I do like the Zahler Whey Protein Meal Replacement Powder as it has a creamy cappuccino-like flavor. It especially tastes good mixed with skim milk.I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I've tried two other brands of CLA (Conjugated Linoleic Acid) in the past and for some reason I had heartburn from them, so I hesitated before I agreed to review a complimentary bottle of CLA  fromViva Labs in exchange for my thoughts on it.The good news that I haven't had any heartburn from taking it this time. I haven't been taking it long enough to notice any body fat loss, but I'm not going to comment on it or any of the other benefits. Overall, I do like the CLA softgels. I'm going to keep taking it until the bottle is empty. If I see any weight loss or other results from it, then I'll update this review.

I've been making it a daily goal this year to include some extra protein in my diet, which I normally add to my morning shake. During the summer, I was sent a complimentary sample of Organic Hemp Protein by Viva Labs to test out and review. While I have heard of Hemp, I've never tried it before receiving this bag.Let's just say that Hemp Protein (15 grams of protein per serving) by itself doesn't have the best taste, so I've been adding it to a chocolate protein shake and I can no longer taste the Hemp in it. Overall, I do like the Organic Hemp Protein.

Rocket Test is a dietary supplement, so it's never going to work like Viagra. It takes awhile to get the supplements into your system; a few weeks to a few months, depending on the individual. Always keep in mind that each person's body is different; just because a supplement works for one person doesn't mean it will work for someone else.It took me two weeks before I started feeling any results from taking it. I've seen a slight increase in my libido, stamina and energy. Overall, I'm impressed with the Rocket Test so far. I'm hoping to see more results by the time I'm done with the bottle.I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I'm normally not in the mood to read holiday theme novels until after Thanksgiving, but I'm a big fan of Amish fiction, so I jumped right into reading An Amish Christmas Gift when I received it last week. There are three different novellas in this title - Naomis Gift by Amy Clipston, An Unexpected Joy by Ruth Reid and A Christmas Visitor by Kelly Irvin.Naomis Gift centers on Caleb, a widower that is traveling with his young daughter, Susie, to Lancaster County, Pennsylvania to visit his sister's family for Christmas. Along the way, Susie spots a farmer's market. She begs Caleb to stop there and find a gift for Aeti Sadie, which he eventually agrees to. Being a kid, Susie gets distracted and walks away fro Caleb's sight at the market, but luckily she comes across a quilt booth where Naomi King happens to be. Naomi is a 24-year-old woman, who is lost all hope of finding love, well, that is until she meets Caleb and sparks fly between the two. Unfortunately, Caleb still isn't ready to let someone near his heart as he lost his wife on Christmas Eve two years ago.An Unexpected Gift is set in St. Joseph County, Michigan and centers on Abigail Kemp, a 22-year-old woman who decided just a year ago that she would never find love. With no future husband in sight, Abigail has been saving every cent that she earns from selling baked goods and quilted potholders, all so she can one day buy a horse. Despite being busy making sweets for the holiday season, Abigail agrees to help look after Micah Zook's grandmother, which the elderly woman makes it her mission to set the two up before Christmas comes around.A Christmas Visitor centers on Frannie Mast, a young woman that had fell in love an Englisch farm boy, Rocky, in Missouri, but her life is turned upside down when her parents sends her back to her hometown of Bee County, Texas to live with her aunt and her aunt's new husband. This is a Christmas story, so the unthinkable happens - Rocky follows Frannie to Texas to convince her family that he is the right man for her.There are gobs of authors that write Amish fiction now a days and I can't keep up with all the new names, but I did recognize authors Amy Clipston and Ruth Reid as I've read a few of their other titles. However, this is the first time I've read anything by Kelly Irvin and I'm an instant fan of her writing as A Christmas Visitor is a cute romantic story. The other two stories, Naomi's Gift and An Unexpected Joy, are both adorable romantic reads as well. Overall, it might not be December yet, but I enjoyed reading the three heartfelt novellas in An Amish Christmas Gift.I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I stumbled up on the first season of the Doctor Who reboot when it aired on the Scifi Channel (now known as Syfy) in 2006 and I quickly became a big fan. I later learned about the original the series that started in the 1960s to the 1980s and that the new seasons (well series in the Britain) are a continuation. Since then, I've watched a handful of episodes featuring the original incarnations of the Doctors on DVD.Now available in paperback is Doctor Who: The Dorsten's Curse by A.L. Kennedy, which is an adventure featuring the 4th Doctor (whom was played by Tom Baker from 1974 to 1981). Set at the Fetch Brothers Golf Spa Hotel, the plot involves golfers disappearing into thin air and of course the Doctor is there in the nick of time to investigate it.Once again the Doctor recruits two new companion, Bryony, a Fetch Brothers Junior Receptionist,  and alien named Putta Pattershaun, to help unravel the mystery behind why the golfers are vanishing. To make matters worse, the other people at the spa are acting weird, especially Mrs. Fetch and and the twin grandchildren; all of which seem to have the ability to read minds.As most Doctor Who stories go, there is something alien-like that is causing all the chaos and the Doctor Bryony and his companions must stop it.From my understanding by other readers, is that this book is based on a short story called The Death Pit, so if you've already read the short story, then there's no reason to read the full-version of it. I've only seen a few episodes that starred Tom Baker as the 4th Doctor and he seemed to be a fun Doctor, so I was slightly disappointed with The Dorsten's Curse as it doesn't have the wit that's in the Doctor Who seasons/series. Don't get me wrong, the book is well-written, but it has too many boring scenes. Overall, Doctor Who: The Drosten's Curse is written for diehard fans of the 4th Doctor. Other readers might not like it. I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I learned how to crochet from my mother when I was a young kid. On a rare occasion I do crochet an afghan to give away as a gift. My local Walmart only carries a few crochet hooks, so I've bought a few at a thrift store over the years; though I'm still missing several of the smaller size hooks.I recently received the Ohuhu 22pcs Aluminum Crochet Hooks, which also comes with a purple storage bag, to test out and review. The current price for the set is $6.99 on here, so my expectations where low for it.The good news is that my feelings for the set changed when I actually received it in the mail last week. The hooks are pretty sturdy and should last forever.I realize that the hook sizes are already listed in the description, but I going to list them anyway, but I've included a few conversion sizes. The set includes:0.6 mm0.75 mm0.85mm0.9 mm1.0 mm1.1 mm1.25 mm1.3 mm1.5 mm1.6 mm1.75 mm1.9 mm2.0mm2.5 mm3.0 mm3.5 mm (E/4)4.0mm (G/6)4.5 mm (7)5.0 mm (H/8)5.5 mm (I/9)6.0 mm (J/10)Overall, I do like the crochet kit and I do recommend it to others. However, I do wish the set included sizes 2.25 (B/1), 2.75 (C/2), 3.25 (D/3) and 3.75 (F/5).I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest thoughts.

What makes Jane Kirkpatrick different from other Christian writers is that she either features real-life people or events in books. In this novel, she tackles the massacure of 1847 and the life of the only survivor, Eliza Splading Warren. Honestly, I knew absoutely knowing about the event that took place in 1847 until I read The Memory Weaver. Kirkpatrick must have done alot of research while preparing to write this novel as she goes into details about aftermath of the massacure for Eliza and how it has always haunted her ever since. Overall, The Memory Weaver is a finely written novel that is part historical fiction and part biography.I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

Adding a few solar lights to your yard or flower bed is a fast and simple way to add a little spark to your property. I've been through several different brands and styles of solar lights over the years; a few of them have quit quickly and a few were even stolen right from my yard.This set comes with 8 solar LED garden lights (made from plastic), which all them come in pieces  the light head, the stem and the stake. The assembly only takes a few seconds. All the lights come with a solar battery. You'll have do disassemble the light head to get to the on/off switch.Yes, the lights in this set are made from cheap plastic, but are studier than some of the low-priced ones I've seen at my local Walmart. The lights aren't the brightest in the world, but they gives off a decent glow at night. Overall, I do like this set solar LED Garden Lights.I received a complimentary sample set in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

The coffee mug is made is made out of heavy glass and features the saying, "I love how we all know that I'm your favorite child" printed on it in white. It can be heated in a microwave and cleaned in a dishwasher. Overall, I think this is a cute coffee mug that would make a great birthday gift or a stocking stuffer for Christmas.I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

The coffee mug is made out of glass and is completely see-through with three different markings/sayings on it on two sides of the mug. The sayings are "Go Away," "Not Yet" and "How Can I Help You?," with markings next to each saying. It's a cute little mug that any coffee lover (including me) would love to own. It would also make a great a gift for a co-worker, teacher, friend, family member, etc.. Overall, I love the "Go Away" Glass Coffee Mug. I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I have a dishwasher and a garbage disposal in the kitchen. Between the two of them, the drain gets clogged up with grease and other junk, resulting in water backing up into the basement bathroom sink. There are countless brands of drain cleaners on the market and I've tried many of them with mostly bad results. Draino is worthless and Liquid Lightning just clogs it more.A few weeks ago, I was sent a complimentary bottle of Green Gobbler Drain Opener in exchange for my honest thoughts on it. Though I had never heard of the brand before, I thought I would give it a try. I mean I've already tried everything else, so why not try this as well!It's basically a bunch of white crystals that you pour down the drain (8oz to be exact) along with a small amount of hot water. Let it sit in the drain for about 15 to 30 minutes and then flush it with hot water. If the clog is really bad, let the crystals sit in the drain overnight.Currently the drain isn't clogged, but it has been gurgling (which is a sign that it will clog soon), so I tried out the Green Gobbler Drain Opener and the gurgling did stop. Overall, I think the product is pretty decent, though I'm not for sure how good it works on solid clogs. I would like to point out that you might want to cover up any drain openings as the drain odor has a strong odor.

I always find it a bit difficult to write a review for a cookbook as I've only had a short time to try out a few of the recipes, but in the case of this book, I have read all the stories, gone through all the recipes and even tried several of them out. There is a wide variety recipes here that will appeal to just about any cook. Some of my favorite are White Mountain Cake, Oatmeal Nut Sticky Buns, Coffee Ice Cream, Coffee Bars and Amish Macaroni Salad. Overall, the Gather Around the Amish Table is a well put together cookbook.I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I guess you can say that this is the Amish version of the Brady Bunch as both the main characters are widowers with three children each. I enjoyed reading the first books in the series (The Promise of Palm Groove and The Proposal of Siesta Key) and I wasn't disappointed with the third installment. Yes, there were a few cliched moments here and there, but nothing that bothered me from enjoying the novel. Overall, Shelly Shepard Gray once again spins her magic with the heartwarming A Wedding at Orange Blossom Inn'. I received a complimentary copy in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

At the end of August, I was sent a bottle of Nitro XL to test out and review. It's a dietary supplement with Nano-Diffusion Technology.You might have heard of people taking nitric oxide (NO) prior or after their workouts. It's a gas that is naturally biozynthesized in your body from oxygen and L-Arginine. Having healthy nitric oxide levels in your bloodstream is important to your overall health, especially for your heart and brain function as well as boosting your immune system.Increasing your NO will help boost your exercises by increasing the blood flow and oxygen to your muscles. This will expand your blood vessels and release a huge amounts of oxygen to your muscles, which will increase your strength and stamina during your workouts.Each serving (4 caps) has 3000 mg of a proprietary blend of:L-Arginine Alpha Ketoglutarate (AK-AKG) - an amino acid that helps the body make protein. It also increases the blood flow to your entire body.L-Ornithine AKG - an amino acid that reduces fatigue.Arginine Ketoisocaproate - an amino acid that increase your NO levels.L-Glutamine AKG - increases protein synthesis and reduces recovery time from your workouts.Nitric oxide supplements is a must have for anybody trying to lose weight and get into shape, especially if your past the age 30, like me. It recommends taking 4 caps twice a day, but I started out by taking two caps twice a day for two weeks, then I doubled the dose. I would like to point out that the supplement does have Gelatin, as some people are allergic to it. While taking this, I didn't have any sort of side effect.  I do recommend letting the supplement slowly build in your body before you'll see any results from taking it. Overall, I do like the Nitro XL as it's a strong nitric oxide that gave an extra boost during my workouts. I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I received a nice little package from Amazon about twenty minutes ago containing a 16 fl. oz. jar of Tropical Mango Salsa by SalsaCrazy. I was hungry, so I quickly opened the jar and dipped some of the salsa into a small bowl. Then I grabbed some chip, dipped it into the salsa and tested it out.I've had peach salsa before, but I've never tried a mango kind until today. Let me just say that you can't just eat one bite of this as it has an addicting taste. It has a sweet pineapple, mango taste with a hint of red pepper in it. Plus, it has corn in it as well. It's not hot hot, but it has a slight kick to it. Overall, I absolutely love the Tropical Mango Salsa. It would make a great afternoon snack on a rainy day or when you're watching a football game on Sunday afternoons.I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

I reviewed the Pink Tomameri MP4 Player last month and I have been enjoying it. I received the Purple MP4 Player at the end of last week and I was excited to try it out. While at first glance it does look cheaply made, it has a lot going for it. You can play videos and listen to your tunes on it. It has a FM radio and a voice recorder. It comes with earbud headphones and a 16 GB Micro SD card.Overall, this is a pretty good MP4 Player with decent sound. I received a complimentary sample in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are my own.

The Pretty Reckless is becoming one of my favorite bands. I stumbled across their videos on Youtube earlier this year and I ended up purchasing both their albums this month. Just like Light Me Up, there isn't a song on Going to Hell that I don't like. My favorites are House On A Hill, Heaven Knows, Follow Me Down and Waiting For A Friend. Overall, I'm more than satisfied with my purchase.

When I can't sleep at night (which is almost every night), I've been listening to music videos on Youtube. While I was watching a Halestorm video, I saw a recommendation for Make We Wanna Die by The Pretty Reckless, so I gave it a try and I quickly became a fan of the band. It took me awhile to finally realize that the lead singer is the girl from How The Grinch Stole Christmas movie.Well, I finally purchased the both the band's albums this month. There's not one song that I don't like from Light Me Up, though my two favorites are Zombie and You!

I would like to start out by stating that I'm not taking this for reproduction reasons, but for my overall health. I received a complimentary bottle along with a bundle of other supplements in exchange for my honest thoughts.As I said, I'm nor taking this for reproduction reasons, so I can't verify if it actually works in that way. Three of my favorite ingredients from this are Tongat All Ashwagandha and Panax Ginseng. I have no idea if it actually works. I've been taking it for twelve days now and I haven't had any side effects, but then again I haven't noticed any changes in my body from taking it.

Let me start out by stating that I don't have any spider veins or any inflammation that I know of. I received a complimentary bottle with a bunch of other supplements over the summer. Besides from Pine Bark Extract, I'm not familiar with the other ingredients. I tried it out for about a week and I didn't have any problems with it.
