There is a wonderful and revealing passage halfway through the book in which Babe Paley, restless because Truman is busy elsewhere (perhaps he doesnt care for her as much any more?) decides to throw caution to the winds and go out on the town with no prior preparation or warning to the parties involved in dealing with her once shes out there. She gathers up her friend Slim Keith, who is short on cash following an acrimonious divorce, and takes her to Bergdorfs to buy her some lingerie. Its her gift to her. But they leave the house in a chauffeured limousine, the CBS crest on its side, and get off right in front of Bergdorfs, leaving it to the driver to handle such messy details as where to park it. The stores manager greets them as soon as they come through the door, apologizes for the absence of Babes personal shopper, who has the day off, and hovers around them nervously, very visibly aware that if he displeases her he could lose his job, just like that. They sweep through the store to a private dressing room, where the clerks bring them merchandise to try on. When theyre done and ready6 to leave, their limousine is miraculously waiting by the door and their packages have been wrapped in Bergdorfs trademark pink paper. As they drive off, headed for another shopping mecca, Babe says to Slim that Its fun, sometimes, pretending. Pretending what? Theyre always protected, cossetted, but at the same time, never truly free. Husbands rule this world, not their wives, who devote their days to pleasing them, always groomed and coiffed to appear desirable, or if, as with Babes husband, if their husbands no longer desire them, still to appear a desirable acquisition to the world looking on.Marriage is for money in this world and husbands are necessary but inherently damaged, rutting goods.  Thats where Truman got his opening. He could talk to these ladies. He didnt lie to them. Yes, he was outrageously funny, always ready with a new scandal to relate or a naught bon mot that skewered not these ladies, but6 other s they knew. But what won them over to him was that he really looked at them and really listened to them, and his conversation might be artificial but it wasnt false. Dozens of people a day told Babe Paley how beautiful she was. But she really believed it only when Truman did. Then too, Trumans past resonated to these lost ladies especially to Babe- who didnt remember her father and had never felt truly valued for herself by her mother. Trumans hurt was hers too.So here we have it, a novel rich in incident and character, filled with glittering presences. It could have been a chatty Jacqueline Susan novel. It isnt. Its a novel about people and the felt cost of their upscale lives, and its a good one.

I saw Scott Coopers Black Mass yesterday. I wanted to see it for several reasons: my interest in the gangster movie genre and my interest in the actors, plus I had recently reviewed an account of Whitey Bulgers trial. I had read some of the reviews of the movie, which tended toward guardedly negative so I went wondering how the movie would hit me. My reaction? Guardedly negative.Lets get the elephant out of the room first. Its no Goodfellas but then neither are most movies, regardless of genre. The level of directing, acting and cinematography in that brilliant movie, its fizzing energy but also the coherence of its convoluted storyline and the interiority the feeling youre inside itof that groundbreaking movie its unfair to expect that every gangster movie coming out could replicate that. This one certainly doesnt but for interesting reasons.For all the violence that occurs in this movie (Whitey Bulger was a truly violent man and arguably psychopathic), everything in the movie the action, your take on the characters, even the story line as it unfolds in flashbacks from informant interviewsis distant: you feel removed, not involved, in it as it occurs. Thats especially true of the figure of Bulger himself: Depp is apparently being touted for an Oscar nomination but the only reason I can figure for that is that hes a star, and of course, hes copped out by playing one-dimensional freaks for so long now: Willy Wonka, Pirate Jack, even Sweeney Todd. Its a long time since he electrified the screen with a series of startlingly original but believable three-dimensionalcharacter roles in Gilbert Grape, Edward Scissorshand, Ed Wood, Donnie Brasco. In recent years, hes pretty much phoned it in on all his roles: kinks but nothing behind them. So the prospect of Depp investing himself in a role again was exciting. How does he do in this one? Hes adequate. But you never get inside him: hes an icon of crime, not a flesh and blood player. For all hes called on to do, or chose to do, they could have used his embalmed corpse with little difference to the effect on the movie.( Maybe he needs to do his next movie with no or minimal makeup.)By comparison, Benedict Cumberbach, as Bulgers politician brother, Billy, comes across as real and human, and so do some of the other characters: Joel Edgerton, as the FBI agent John Connolly, who becomes Bulgers dupe, and David Harbour, as John Morris, Connollys accomplice in protecting Bulger and deceiving the Bureau, are first rate. So too are many of the supporting actors, Julianne Nicholson as Connollys wife, Rory Cochrane, W. Earl Brown (always good in movies!), and Jesse Plemons as Bulgers loathsome crew members, Peter Sarsgaard in a cameo as a drugged out informant, soon dead at BUlgers hands. The one major actor who disappoints in a supporting role is Kevin Bacon, who plays Connollys skeptical supervisor in the Bureau: Bacon is too accomplished a movie actor to bomb in the role but he too pretty much phones it in its acting as coasting. (One player who does come across as vibrant and real is the city: south side Boston in the 70s and 80s. Its beautifully presented.)The story presents itself in flashbacks, seen between brief scenes of one or another of Bulgers accomplices turning States evidence against him in desperate attempts to keep their own necks on their heads.  Theres a lot of violence but little heart behind it I know I said its unfair to expect every big gangster movie to be another Goodfellas, but I cant ignore that as violent as that movie was, the violence was directly directlytied to emotions. It was player-driven rather than plot-imposed. Well, that doesnt come across in this movie.Im still waiting for Johnny Depps redemption as an actor because his best (= earlier) work was brilliant. But it hasnt happened yet. I hope he doesnt waste the rest of his career playing grotesque surfaces with no insides to them. Still, it isnt Depp that kills this movie. Its script and direction. You cant film this kind of story from the outside: you need to drag the movie viewer in.It didnt happen this time. At least not for me.

HdeH, mandolin, composer; ar. incl. Chucho Valdes, Mario Laginha, Omar Sosa, Andre Mehmari, Stefano Bollani, Andre Mehmari, p; Richard Galiiano, accord; Odette Ernest Dias, flt;  Carlos Malta, ten sx; Wynton Marsalis, tpt.Wikipedia tells us that Alfredo da Rocha Viana, Jr. (d. 1973), better known as Pixinguinha, was as Brazilian composer, arranger, flautist and saxophonist born in Rio de Janeiro. He was considered one of the greatest composers of Brazilian popular music, especially the genre of choro. Ive heard enough Brazilian music to know what choro sounds like but had never read a description of it: while it can range in tempo and mood, it is often a fast, happy music, full of syncopation and counterpoint, and leaves ample space for virtuosity, interplay and improvisation. Sounds a bit like jazz, doesnt it?This album of choro is mandolinist De Holandas homage to Pixinguinha and its difficult to imagine a better one. Most of the album is duets: de Holanda with jazz musicians: pianists Chucho Valdes, Stefano Bollani, accordionist Richard Galliano, trumpeter Wynton Marsalis; duets with pianists Id not heard before: Laginha, Sosa, Mehmari. The album starts with de Holanda solo; it ends with a delightful trio rendition flute, tenor sax and mandolinof Pixinguinhas Carinhoso. Throughout the playing is satisfying and rich, joyous and cooperative. Many of these players are heavy hitters in their own right but they submerge their egos in this gently and intellectually and musically satisfying collaboration. There are differences: Chucho Valdess playing brings a distinctly Cuban flavor to his two pieces where Stefano Bollanis contributions sound more classical: chamber music with Bollani providing backing and counterlines to the ever busy but always tasteful de Holanda on mandolin.This isnt jazz music but music into which elements of jazz fit well, adding zest and another kind of complexity to already zestful, intricately complex music. This album is the second to be issued this year that blend these two attractive musics so well. The other is guitarist Romero Lubambos solo outing, Setembro, on which I commented a week or two back. The listener who likes Brazilian popular music should get both.

TH, tpt, flglhrn; Mark Turner, ten sx; Ugonna Okegwo, b; Adam Cruz, dr.You expect a good ride from a Tom Harrell album. He knows his instruments trumpet mainly, but also flugelhorn-- backwards and forwards, in solo has a musical imagination as nimble as his exemplary technique, and, a creative composer and arranger, her spends serious effort crafting good song vehicles for his ensembles to play. And in his latest album, recorded toward the end of last year, what an ensemble it is! There is no saxophonist recording today who plays as consistently well as Mark Turner. His Warne Marsh-influenced tenor fits perfectly with Harrells smooth yet urgent trumpet playing: it is a particularly good pairing on those cuts in this album where Harrell plays flugelhorn, with its softer, fuzzier plangent sound. They fit together like hand and glove. The rhythm section bassist Okegwa and drummer Cruzare equally attuned to the music. This is a group that knows how to play together. Both bassist and drummer are superb in ensemble. If I am less enamored of their solo spots, its not because theyre bad, just not as well integrated into the song (Cruzs solo on Harrells tricky Cycle, for instance, is first rate but could fit into almost any up tempo piece it isnt integral to the tune being played) or clearly innovative (Okegwa). These are small potatoes reservations about a uniformly superior album, though. The twelve compositions are all by Harrell. Six of them form a suite about Don Quixote which is quite interesting. The other six are standalone compositions. The melodies are good, Harrell does interesting things with the arranging for the ensemble parts, and all the players not only understand the music, they groove to it.

Those We Left Behind is a crime novel, and a very good one, but it is equally a novel about the concatenating effects of abuse: parents abandoning children, the children bounced around foster homes, the younger one overly dependent on the elder, whose rage leads him to escalating acts of violence. It starts with biting he bites his brother, not himself moves to bullying another child, their latest foster parents son, and then inciting his younger brother to murder: the younger brother is convicted of killing the foster parent, bashing him to death, blood all over the place. But was that what happened? Its not at all clear it was. Yes, Ciaran, not twelve, confessed to the murder. He testified that he did it alone to protect his older brother, Thomas, from the mans abuse.  But if Thomas had done it, hed have been put away as an adult for a long, long sentence where as a minor, Ciarans sentence was shorter --and Thomass too as accomplice instead of killer.Ciarans out now with eight years served. Hes twenty years old now but still a child inside, and hes still utterly, helplessly dependent on his older brother for direction and support. The cop who put him away has doubts about Ciarans guilt. With him out again, she wants to question him: to find out what really happened that night. But she carries baggage too. She has just returned to the force after a hard battle with breast cancer. The scars it left on her arent only outside. She doesnt feel like a full woman yet and her husband isnt treating her like one. Theres a probation officer too. She too has problems in the past but theyre not fully stated or resolved in the course of the narration. All you know is that she likes her alcohol. Around these two women circle other cops, some keen to right wrongs, others putting in their time, reluctant to have their former judgment questioned.Ciarans released, Thomas is there, his dominance over his younger brother is back in place, seemingly unshaken. Ciaran will do whatever Thomas tells him to do. Terrible things follow as a consequence: there is a beating, then a murder, then much more blood and terror.  On the side, the detective confronts a second, completely separate mystery: the seeming suicide-murder of an elderly couple, both desperately ill in different ways. The pace quickens. Nemesis hovers nearby to claim her victims.Neville has been nominated for the Edgar award for at least one previous novel and has been a finalist for the Los Angeles Times Book Prize; he won two awards for best first crime novel and was finalist for three more. Its clear why on the basis of this fine novel. Its been interesting to me to watch the arrival of a spate of fine crime and detective novels from the nether parts of the United Kingdom: north Ireland and Scotland. They have common characteristics, which contrast in interesting ways with the many fine Scandinavian crime novels now on the market. I am obviously being over reductionist in what I am now going to say, but I think theres some truth in it:  like the Scandinavian crime stories (Larsen, Persson, Nesbo, and Mankell are examples), the novels feature policemen instead of private investigators, but unlike their Scandinavian peers, the police work that is done is much more a private, single individual affair (not police procedural in form) and though there is as much social commentary in these novels as in the better known Scandinavian ones, it is presented more as observed detail than as excursus digressions from the narrative.  The result is a prose that is gritty and nervy and propels you along the path to the inevitable confrontation, which is usually violent.

It seems like only yesterday when Finch (The Laws of Murder, 2014) brought forth his first Victorian era murder mystery, featuring amateur detective Charles Lenox and his sweet, elegant, formidably capable soon-to-be wife Lady Jane. And here he is now is the ninth book in this estimable series, in a tangled story that is as intriguing and delightful to read as the first one was. After a spell in Parliament, Charles has returned to full-time detecting, this time as a profession: hes partner in his own agency with his former protg, Lord Dallington, and a formidable lady detective, Polly Buchanan, who handles womens issues --stolen silver, vanished fiances, that sort of thing, under the pseudonym of Miss Strickland. After the defection of their former partner Lemaitre, the three are looking for ways to promote business. A success helping Scotland Yard would go a along way to keeping the ink in their ledger black instead of red. As usual in these books, Lenox juggles two very different cases in this installment. One is big. A German pianist goes missing after a concert: no one knows how he even got out of his dressing room, much less why he is gone. Thats the Scotland Yard case.  But more time is spent in the country, at brother Edmunds estate in Sussex, where he is approached by a local gentleman to solve the puzzling case of a strange woman or was it girl?spied in an upstairs window, a missing bottle of sherry. That case conflates with another odd happening: thefts at the village market where two missing chickens, four shillings in change, a half wheelbarrow of carrots, a springer spaniel, some blankets and a cloak, a box of candles, and another chicken have gone missing. Then theres an attack on the town mayor, who is left near death, and the stakes rise. Of course, Charles solves them all: the small potatoes thefts in Sussex, the woman in the window and the missing bottle of sherry, the attack on the mayor, but also the missing pianist in London. The search for answers is intriguing from start to finish, Charles and his family, friends and allies are easy to care about, and the local (and historical) color is lovingly depicted. This is a firstrate series and this installment, which shows no sign of flagging energy, is firstrate as well.

I dont like The Long Siesta as much as I did Sweets previous noir novel, Flowers at Midnight, (2012) but its a respectable effort. The setting is Seville, 1998. The protagonist, Inspector Jefe Velazquez, is lead inspector in the city homicide division. Hes also a junkie. Hes been addicted ever since a spooky pair of hoods, Bill and the Black Lady, abducted him and hooked him up. So along with trying to solve a mystery, a succession of killings starting with two priests, and dealing with a side concern, the Russian mobs abduction of his bullfighter girlfriend, he stops every once in a while to shoot up, alternating illegal heroin and legal methadone. The murders pile up, the mob boss wants him to find and deliver a mysterious LaserDisc, to get it he has to get a Russian prostitute away from her bosses and back to her homeland boyfriend, and behind it all he continues with his efforts to find out why the priests were killed and whats going on that is leading to a veritable crime epidemic in his normally sleepy bailiwick. The style is Raymond Chandler, and the dialogue abounds in touches of dialect, a slightly skewed mix of English English and Spanish slang. The action moves along crisply though not always convincingly. In the end, Velazquez solves the mystery, the killer is apprehended and the inspector is reunited with his girlfriend. But Velazquez is still a junkie and he hasnt yet learned who Bill and the Black Lady really are. Is it the hook for a sequel?

Minute zero is the moment of chaos that follows crisis: if you are ready to step in then, you have a brief opportunity to reshuffle the deck in your nations favor before the situation stabilizes and rigidifies anew. Theres an election pending in Zimbabwe: an aging dictator is being propped up by a vicious general but for the first time in decades he is vulnerable. A personable, able and honest woman lawyer is running against him. If all else were equal  --read that to mean if if the elections were being run fairly and the incumbent werent willing to declare the election results void and declare a state of emergency if the results go against himshed win handily. But things arent equal and if something isnt done, the country faces more years of corruption and oppression. This is the second novel featuring policy analyst Judd Ryker, who now heads a small free-wheeling unit within the State Department whose mission is to assist in dealing with crisis in countries that are destabilizing. In The Golden Hour, he headed off a crisis in Mali, assisted by his agronomist wife Jessica and a few other allies. They return in this installment to manage impending crisis in Zimbabwe. As Rykers mentor told him years before when he was headed towards a career as an academic rather than policy wonk: you dont manage crisis, you ride it. Its like whitewater rafting. You dont control the flow of events, you just try to ride them out, giving your vessel a nudge now and then to secure a favorable outcome. Minute Zero is a crisp, well written thriller. The author, formerly deputy assistant secretary of state under G. W, Bush, obviously knows the world he writes about: his charge at the State Department was the Bureau of African Affairs, where he was responsible for diplomatic relations with sixteen West African countries. Judd Ryker and his super-competent wife Jessica are attractive characters, as are many of the peripheral Good Guys. The Bad Guys? Well, theyre satisfyingly bad.

Supersymmetry is a welcome addition to the ranks of hard science science fiction, in this case, revolving around some of the newer hypotheses of subatomic physics Higgs particles, indeterminate reality, teleportation and a kind of time travel, and, oh yes, an extra-terrestrial intelligence extra-universal, actuallythat wants to replace weak humans maybe with something neater, maybe just with itself.The invader comes from one of the alternate universes that hover alongside our own. The Kelleys daughters Sandra and Kelley, physicist father Jasonhave fought the creature fifteen years before. They dubbed it the varcolac, a Romanian term for a demon that lives on the other side of the mirror. That battle was recorded in an earlier novel, Superposition, which was released earlier this year. One of the consequences of that struggle, not resolved until Jacob shut down the supercollider from which the creature was drawing power, was the splitting of his daughter Alessandra into separated twins, Sandra and Alex. Ever since they have been developing their own personalities, going their separate ways: Sandras a policewoman now and Alex is a physicist. Alex works on a below the radar project to develop superweapons for our armed forces. The scientist in charge of it is a neurotic, almost psychotic physics nerd named Ryan Oronzi. He has brought into existence a universe of his own, a bubble universe, which he monitors in his lab through computer simulation. The problem is that with the emergence of this alt-universe there also emerges, again, the varcolac and though Ryan doesnt know it, it is controlling him. From that point on, all sorts of increasingly dire things happen, including a baseball stadium exploding or did it implode?the varcolac invading a demonstration of the new military technology and taking over the Secretary of Defenses body, a second invasion at a funeral for Sandras and Alexs father, but is he dead?a mass assault on high security prison and the escape of a genius killer, and a shootout showdown between US military and varcolac-possessed Turks that segues to the systematic bombing of the major cities of the world in reverse order of their population. (If they get that far, New York will be thirty-fifth.) How do you reverse such destruction? And how do you stop a near-invulnerable super-intelligence that isnt hampered by the confines of physical flesh from taking over the world? And, lastly, will Sandra and Alex stay separate or lose their new found individuality through reunion in one body and mind a second time? Near the end, the math and physics get a bit hairy but theres enough adventure and even a bit of romance to carry it through in what is a successful return to days of high science but also high adventure science fiction.

Verve; orig. Impulse. 2007; orig. 1961.  ON, comp, arr, ten sx; Eric Dolphy, bss clari, alto sx; Freddie Hubbard, tpt; Bill Evans, p; Paul Chambers, b; Roy Haynes, dr.Composer-arranger-sax player Oliver Nelsons The Blues and the Abstract Truth is one of the gems of the mid-60s. Its not a great classic, though it comes close to it, but its one of those albums that is so well conceived and executed --the arrangements and the playingthat you keep coming back to it to listen.  Its fifty-four years now since the album was recorded. The only player still alive from it is drummer Roy Haynes, who still plays as hard and well at age 90 as at 20 or 30 or 40.The great player on the session was Dolphy: for this session, he left behind his most distinctive axe, the bass clarinet, but he was just as accomplished and distinctive on alto and flute. Fifty-four years later, his entrances to his solos on this album still astound. He may not have revolutionized the playing of his instruments as much as, say, had his confreres Ornette Coleman and John Coltrane, but the importance and stature of his achievement has become increasingly clear with the passage of time (and the 2014 release of two albums, Aki Takase and Alexander von Schlippenbachs So Long, Eric! and Russ Johnsons Still Out to Lunch: Dolphy deployed his technical mastery of his three horns to expand and solidify bop playing, still tied to the changes but freed from constraints  of rhythm and tonality. On flute, an instrument that usually bores me to death, only James Newton has come to close to matching him for technical artistry and forcefulness. Trumpet player Hubbard was on a roll back then: though nowhere as modernist as either of the group leaders, he played in the two great double quartet experiments of that age, Ornette Colemans Free Jazz in 1960 and Coltranes Ascension in 1965. Add to that sessions with countless other musicians, including Dolphy, Bill Evans, Herbie Hancock, Joe Henderson, Bobby Hutcherson and Andrew Hill, and his modernist credentials were well established. His sol work on this album is on a par with his work on other albums of the day: driving and fluid but not longer quite as new as it seemed back then. The weakest of the three horns is Nelson. Its common to say that Nelson played arrangers horn, and its true. Its also not an insult because though his solo work broke no new ground, it fit well into his own tunes and he was a good contrast to the fierier and definitely more innovative Dolphy. The other giants on this album were pianist Evans and Roy Haynes on drums. (Chambers was a more than competent bassist and especially good at propelling a group along.) This outing is one of Evanss less exciting ones: his solo passages are solid but never take off. Reading Peter Pettingers biography of Evans (Bill Evans: How My Heart Sings, 1988) it is evident that this was one of the down periods for Evans, whose addiction and physical woes were wearing him down.  Haynes is perfect for this group: his drumming is so right and so infectious and subtly driving that it could wake up a corpse.What of Nelsons compositions and his arrangements of them? The most familiar, and most haunting, is Stolen Moments, which was recorded by the Young Turk super group Roots  (Arthur Blythe, Chico Freeman, Sam Rivers, Don Pullen et al.) on its 2005 album Stablemates and by United Future Organization on the combined hip hop and jazz collection, Stolen Moments: Red Hot + Cool (1994). But Hoedown and Cascades are effective pieces which provoke the horns to exciting solo work, Yearnin and Teenies Blues are tricky blues takeoffs (listen to Dolphys left-field entrance on alto on Teenies Blues!) and Butch and Blue is a good boppish piece.I held off getting this album on CD for years because I already had it on vinyl.  Im glad I changed my mind. This album is too good to leave sitting in storage.

Twenty-four novels in and Sue Graftons chronicle of the adventures of private investigator Kinsey Milhone is still as fresh and engrossing as ever! What makes these novels work without reader fatigue? For one thing, theres Kinsey. She is a wonderful creation, one of the best fictional depictions of a P.I. in the business. Kinseys no Wonder Woman. She has no special talents exotic martial arts or whateverjust brains, common sense and doggedness, a super work ethic, and an appreciation of people which, if it doesnt help in solving cases, makes her appealing to the reader. Shes also very human: shes loyal to her friends, shes a bit stingy, definitely not fashion conscious, and her easting habits are atrocious (although who doesnt secretly love fatty, unhealthy food?). In this installment, Kinsey juggles three investigations. First, the widow of a former colleague asks her to look through her dead husbands extraordinarily messy files (he was a P.I. too but in Kinseys mind, a crooked one) to help her with an upcoming audit by the IRS. Kinsey discovers, hidden in a carton beneath a false bottom unexplained objects among them a sheet of paper with a string of four digit numbers on it. One of her friends loves ciphers he figures it out: its a cipher, a substitution code using the typewriter QWERTY keyboard as its base: 1 is for Q, 2 for W, 3 for E, and so on. Decoded, its a list of womens names, six of them. Kinsey investigates and the menace ratchets steadily up. Second, Kinsey takes a low budget job: find the address of a newly released con for his mother, who abandoned him at birth and now wants to make up for it. But matters soon go south in this case as well and soon Kinsey is pursuing a true puzzle: whats going on here and why? Lastly, new neighbors move next door to Kinsey and her octogenarian and friend landlord Henry and theyre the neighbors from Hell. Something is seriously amiss about them. Henrys too nice to do anything about it except be taken advantage of so its up to Kinsey to deal with this problem too.  It would be sinful to tell you what happens from this point on. Suffice it to say that this is one of the best installments in an exceptional series of detective novels. I dont know what Im going to do when Grafton runs out of letters to use.(I bought this novel for my wife, who loves the Kinsey Milhone stories. She had been going through a dry spell: no book she started kept her interest all the way through. I gave her this book and a day and a half later, she had finished it.)

Saul Black is the pseudonym for Glen Duncan, author of one of the best werewolf novel one of the few good ones --of recent years, 2012s The Last Werewolf. To all appearances this is his first published crime novel and its just as good as his werewolf book, which is to say, gripping. Pick it up and you wont want to put it down. A widow, still young, living alone with her two young children, finds two strange men in her house.  Soon blood is everywhere. Her ten-year-old daughter is pursued but escapes, but at a cost. She holes up with a neighbor nearby: he cant move because his sciatica has flared up and shes suffering from hypothermia and has a broken ankle, perhaps even more breaks in her bones elsewhere. The killers leave her behind and move on to more kills elsewhere. A San Francisco homicide detective is pursuing them but doesnt know who they are or where theyre based: the killings are all over the map. Whats common about them is the act. In each case, seven in all now, a young woman is abducted, tortured and mutilated before being killed, and in some cases raped. The DNA and fingerprints show that two men are involved, and theres always an extraneous object inserted somewhere into the victims body a candy apple, a balloon, a hammer, one time a large pottery goose is shoved into the eviscerated torso of a victim. The search for the killers is destroying the detectives life she drinks too much, has nightmares. Three years earlier, her obsession with a similar case had destroyed her romance with another detective. She still longs for him. Now, out of nowhere, he returns, another complication in her running-down life. Theres another killing, the eighth. But there are still no clues. The detective doubles down, watches surveillance tapes of the scene of one of the abductions. She finds something, possibly a photo one of the killers. Thats the first clue. Soon a second comes, then a third. Theres another abduction, but this one is reported early enough that the girl may still be alive. The manhunt is on. In alternating chapters, we follow the killers, the young girl hiding with a neighbor, the kidnapped woman, and the detectives, as events race toward the bloody climax. Along the way, we learn why the killers are killing stands for. I like thrillers and this one is a standout.

The list of stars who passed through Hollywood agent Sue Mengerss hands at one time or another in the 70s would knock your socks off: Streisand heads the list, but theres Christopher Walken and Gene Hackman, Ryan ONeal, Ali McGraw, Candice Bergen, Faye Dunaway, and Michael Caine. For a decade, she had the magical touch. She was even profiled on Sixty Minutes, the first time a theatrical agent had ever received such notice.She never lost her touch completely but from the 80s on, her career gradually subsided. Part of it was changes in the way movies were put together now bean counting had replaced talent scouting. Part of it was age to the powers that be who controlled so much of Hollywood film making, Sue was simply no longer young enough. Part of it, though, was the result of missteps as a talent manager.  Her premiere client, and she thought a friend, Barbra Streisand left in 1982 after the disastrous mishandling of the release of the movie All Night Long. (Barbra did okay in the film but the movie bombed and Sue wasnt sympathetic to Barbras issues any longer.)  Several other clients drifted away in the years to follow, some concerned about results, others alienated by her pushiness. Her career ended in disappointment: in 1988 she was brought back as senior vice president to revive a moribund William Morris agency but she could no longer able the goods. Increasingly an anachronism, she was pushed out of the agency within two years.  She was 58 and she would live to 79. . She spent the remaining years hosting high profile parties at her Hollywood home, hanging out with a coven of Hollywood female friends, the Dyke-ettes, traveling to Europe with her husband Jean-Claude Tramont (reluctantly, very reluctantly, for she never liked leaving L.A.), and proferring advice, sometimes asked for and sometimes not, to her show biz friends and colleagues. She outlived Jean-Claude by fifteen years.Kellow (Pauline Kael: A Life in the Dark, and biographies of Ethel Merman and Eileen Farrell) is a sympathetic and conscientious chronicler and the list of interviewees with whom he met to write this book is mindboggling. But however admirable Sue was, theres something cold and repellent about her climb to fame and the way she managed it after she arrived at the top. Her friends loved her but friends dropped off the table with almost clocklike regularity and once off, she was cold, cold, cold. Somewhere in this book, one of the people being interviewed captures it: Sue was a narcissist, with all the insecurity and capacity to manipulate people for her own ends that the diagnosis implies, but as long as you didnt rock her boat, she could be a charming and supportive friend just not one you could trust if you crossed her. She was loud, often lewd, and boy was she pushy, but for a decade at least, people felt they needed to be around her. Because she had the magical touch.On April 24, 2013, Bette Midler opened on Broadway in a one-woman play about Mengers: Ill Eat You Last: A Chat with Sue Mengers.

TS, tpt, flglhrn; Tim Warfield, sop, ten sx; Bruce Barth, p; Peter Washington, b; Dana Hall, dr.This album has everything going for it, first-rate musicians, pianist Barths simple but well crafted arrangements, and great, great songs from the pen of Duke Ellingtons alter ego, master songster Billy Strayhorn. Some of the songs are readily recognizable. Raincheck kicks off the album and Johnny Come lately (which starts with an intriguing rephrasing of the melody, fragmenting it into repeated blasts of notes from trumpeter Stafford and saxist Warfield) ends it. Between are the two lush emotive ballads, Lush Life and Daydream, done in quartet with the sax dropping out. Lush Life in particular is exceptionally well done. Having sung the song, I can testify how hard it is to negotiate the twists and turns in it without sounding false but Stafford does it: straight them statement by the horn, then a lightly swinging piano solo by Barth, then back to Staffords trumpet (or is it flugelhorn? I cant tell) for the chance to improvise. Its very tasty, without a single wrong step.  The next tune up is Multicolored Blue: Stafford plays it with mute, adding to the Ellingtonian quality, and the start of Warfields tenor solo evokes Ellington too not Ben Webster but perhaps one of the later players in the band, Harold Ashby? Paul Gonsalves? (Ashby more than Gonsalves.) The other tunes are equally enjoyable: Smada, My Little Brown Book, U.M.M.G (originally played by Dizzy on Ellingtons Jazz Party album),  Lana Turner. All in all, it is hard to conceive of a tastier, more enjoyable album. Its the type of timeless music you could play for a friend who doesnt like jazz and have him or her say, You know, thats really nice!

BENNETT, Tony.  Sings the Ultimate American Songbook, vol. I.  Columbia. 2007.  TB, voc, with. Ralph Sharon Orch and trio, Dave Brubeck quartet, Count Basie Orch.Songbook is a collection of cuts from various albums by Bennett, dating back to the tail end of the Fifties. Its mostly good stuff no, fine stuffwith a few exceptions. The best cuts are with Ralph Sharon, his musical director for who knows how many years, either his trio or an orchestra. The worst are (1) a duet on Moonglow with k. d. lang which doesnt ignite more importantly, it doesnt showcase langs unique talent as an interpreter of songs, and (2) a cut with the Mitch Miller Orchestra backing Tony up. The problem with the latter is that Miller was a hack who fit every song into the same cookie cutter mold.  Tonys voice is gorgeous and his ability to interpret songs so high that Miller doesnt ruin the cut, but a Ralph Sharon Mitch Miller certainly wasnt. There is one other hitch on the album, a cut labeled as performed with the Dave Brubeck Quartet, including Paul Desmond. It must be a mislabeling to the best of my knowledge Brubeck never recorded with a guitar player, and if he had, it would have been with someone like jim Hall, who wouldnt have produced such bland chording behind the piano, and there is no alto sax, and thus no Desmond on the cut either.  For that matter, the drummer doesnt match up with what I know of Joe Morello either. Its not a big deal, though, and this is basically a rewarding album, offering a historical retrospective of the classy singing of one of our national treasures.

I bought this album when it first came out, vinyl of course, and almost wore it out I played it so much. I cant take a turntable along with me in the car and I listen to music there, so Ive started to buy albums I loved years ago on CD this one, Willie Nelsons Stardust, Dinah Washingtons For Those in Love, with the Quincy jones band.This album is close to perfect, two in-tune artists performing unencumbered by anyone elses sounds and performing a repertoire of classic American ballads plus Evanss best known song, Waltz for Debbie. Intimate and sensitive are the words for it. Lyrical. Never above gentle up in tempo, muted dynamics. (Well, somewhat muted. Bennetts is a big, rich voice and he uses it as needed to make musical points.) The joining of these two artists wasnt an automatic thing: Bennetts musical sensitivities dont match totally with Evanss and Bennett sometimes slows down the release of phrases for dramatic effect where Evans would likely have pushed on with them. But they did what great artists should do: listened to each other and accommodated gloriously. No one could modulate background chords better than Evans. He could be and was here a consummate accompanist. The result is fifty-some minutes of flowing, lyric, magical song celebrating.

WN, voc, guit; Bobbie Nelson, p; Paul English, dr; Jody Payne, guit; Bee Spears, Chris Ethbridge, b; Mickey Raphael, harm; Booker T. Jones, org, p.In 1978, I had just left college teaching for my first administrative job, and we had moved a hundred miles, from Ithaca, NY, to Utica (New Hartford, actually). We moved into a temp apartment, three rooms plus bathroom, while we waited for a bigger place. And I bought this album. A jazz snob, I had never liked western music. But the year before, Id shared a house with a man who loved it, especially the outlaw trio, Willie Nelson, Waylon Jennings, Merle Haggard, plus outliers like Lyle Lovett and Nanci Griffith. Id left a convert. Stardust was still a surprise to me: not country music at all but American classic ballads sung straight by Willie and backed by his Class A band. I remember us lying on the bed listening to him sing  Moonlight in Vermont, Georgia on My Mind  So, yes, I love this album! The only thing I would change on it is to delete the two tracks that have been added: Scarlet Ribbons and I Can See Clearly Now.  Neither is up to the quality of the rest of the album but the rest is so good that Ill live with it.

RAVA, Enrico.  The Pilgrim and the Stars.  ECM. 1975; re-released 2008.  ER, tpt; John Abecrombie, guit; Palle Danielsson, b; Jon Christensen, dr.This was Ravas fourth album. He was 36 at the time.  The group is first-rate, as good as you could get at the time, which is saying a lot. Rava possesses a ravishing sound: his playing is reminiscent of Miles Davis before electronics, but stronger and much more fluent he rips through the 1 minute 52 second-long Surprise Hotel.  His playing throughout is fine, lyrical and moody with burst of savagery as change of pace. Guitarist Abercrombie the perfect partner for a trumpeter like Rava: hes a fine soloist but responsive and pliable in backing, where he produces a range of sounds up to and including guitar synthesizer. (There is some discrete overdubbing on some of the later cuts.) Danielsson and Christensen are among the finest modernists on their instruments in all of jazz, not just jazz in Europe. Its an ECM album with all the quality of sound you expect from that label, and the music played slotting in somewhere between lyrical-modern and film noir, with touches of post-bopis the type of music you expect from an ECM album of that decade. The compositions are all by Rava, good songs but you wont be humming them in the shower afterwards. One of them, Blancasnow, Rava recorded a second time in 2009, on his album New York Days, with Stefano Bollani, Larry Grenadier and Mark Turner.

With the release of Black Mass, starring Johnny Depp as Boston crime boss and sociopath Whitey Bulger, the time is good for another book on Bulger. And veteran crime writer T. J. English (The Westies, Whiteys Payback) is well situated to write it. Its his seventh true crime book and the third to deal directly with Irish-American criminals. This book is about the trial of Bulger for multiple murders (twenty in all) accomplished over many years. The trial lasted two months --June 12-August 12- and ended with Bulgers conviction for eleven out of the twenty murders. The verdict was hailed by the FBI and the Department of Justice as a triumph for the American justice system.  It had taken decades but one of Americas most ruthless and repugnant criminals had finally been taken down. But English asked at what cost? For, English claims with relatively convincing evidence, the government made its case at great cost, giving a pass to other monsters as heinous as Bulger in order to nail him. Even worse, the prosecution carefully limited the case to hide evidence of decades of corrupt practice in the handling of top echelon informers, Bulger included, which had led to the wrongful imprisonment of innocent men (the decades-long jailing of Joe Salvati), a free pass on murdering other hoods, and the exchange of information and money between cops and crooks. English argues that Bulger got what he deserved out of the trial but the American public did not: trial information was carefully cosmeticized to hide evidence of systematic, decades-long wrongdoing of government law officials.A strength of the book is Englishs personal contacts with the Boston crime figures involved with Bulger. He knows them, meets them for cookouts and dinners out, but doesnt try to romanticize them. He knows they lived still live in some casesin a violent world, but their testimony provides him insights into Bulgers world. Not surprisingly, Bulger, his lawyers and the prosecutors all declined to meet with Engiish. The result is a book that presents a pretty convincing case for Englishs thesis but relies of necessity on uncorroborated testimony, and English is the first to admit that the men he is talking to are masters at manipulating perception. There is much of interest in this book. It could have benefited from a rewrite: some assertions are made too often, the testimony presented in the order it appeared in the trialcould use a re-summation. But for the most part, this is a lively telling of a fascinating trial. As to Bulger, even in a world of slimy creatures like the ones depicted her, Bulger emerges as particularly repellent. And scary.

Sweet Caress is another in a long string of wholly engaging novels written by Boyd, who has won honors in the past for several of his books. The characteristics of a Boyd novel are that they are elegantly written and intricately plotted and the people who pass through the their pages are out of the ordinary, even, in the case of Amory Clay, strong willed and determined to lead her own life her own way, regardless of the many and sometimes painful pratfalls she takes en route through her long, rich life. Amory is the heroine of this book, and a very engaging one.  You could claim she doesthat her life started out wrong footed: the [London] Times announcement of her birth informed readers that Beverley and Wilfreda Clay had given birth to a son, Amory, on March 7, 1908. Amorys life played out that ambiguity. She turned down college to become a photographer, was on (or at least near) the front line during the Great War, took photographs on the sly of a den of extreme iniquity in Weimar Germany and when she displayed them in a photo exhibit, was hauled into court on charges of obscenity, and lost both her case and the photos and proof sheets. And on and on, though a life filled with drama, and backing and forwarding, through the between war years, on into WWII and much later Viet Nam, and includes passionate love, violent war, and trying to be a good mother to her two twins who have wills of their own.  It may seem like I am revealing too much of what happens in this fine novel but I havent. Amorys is a complicated life but once you start hearing her talk, you wont want to put this book down. And there will be surprises.Readers who have read others novels by Boyd may notice similarities between this novel and his The New Confessions (1988). That novel recounts the life and career of James Todd, a forgotten filmmaker, whose final project was a five-hour, three-screen version of Rousseaus Confessions. Unfortunately for Todd, his masterpiece appeared in the theaters just as talkies arrived and quickly sunk into obscurity. Amory Clay has the same passion for her art as did Todd, and again its a visual art, and though she has more success in her life than Todd did, Amorys projects also run up against the vagaries of history and they dont always make it through intact.Boyd is an elegant writer but hes an interesting one too. When I reviewed The New Cpnfessions years ago, I wrote that it was sparking with ideas. Sparking, not sparkling. The intensity of Amorys involvement with people and events fizzes with energy. And as are many of Boyds protagonists, Amory is strong, durable, human and admirable.

I think providing a sizing kit like this is very helpful, as I would have been hesitant to buy a full package of any particular size. The kit includes 2 each of each size, so you have a good chance of finding out what works best for you. In my case, I found they inserted easily enough and they stayed in place. However, they are very uncomfortable to me. My body is unique, as is yours, so you may not have the same experience. The sizing kit is a GREAT way to test a product like this in the privacy of your own home. It's worth a shot!

Solid Gold Furrever Young cat food is perfect for our older cat. He loves it, and he digests it well without any issues. His coat looks fantastic, too. He's older and getting slower, just like me. I'm a big fan of the Solid Gold brand, it's been a part of our lives for the last 10 years. Our vet said he thinks it's a good choice as well. I don't know if it matters to them or not, but they are healthy and happy cats. I'm very comfortable with the quality of ingredients in this brand, and in this flavor. It's produced in the United States from high quality ingredients, so it's going to cost more than imported foods that potentially carry more risks. It's a good food, the cats like it, and they are healthy.

This is a wonderful, high quality dog food for small breeds. The kibble is very small and easy for tiny mouths to eat. One of mine has a hard time eating most kibble, and this works perfectly. We used to buy Solid Gold Wee Bits when she was a puppy, then our local store stopped carrying it and we switched. I'd forgotten how small their food could be. She has no trouble digesting this dog food, although one of my other little dogs has a poultry allergy and this is off limits. Check the ingredient panel to make sure it's right for your dog. The company is known for using very high quality ingredients, and nothing is questionable or from China. That matters to me. We are very pleased with Solid Gold products for dogs and cats, and we recommend them to our friends along with similar brands. I believe that the quality of our pet food is important enough to pay a little more for, and I also feel better about how their ingredients are sourced. You can't have that kind of confidence with supermarket pet foods. Recommended.

This is a pretty amazing dog food! The quality is top notch and the ingredients are varied and nutritious. This dog food is miles ahead of anything you can buy in a supermarket or big box store. The label says the kibble is for all sizes of dogs. The pieces are about 1/2 inch diameter, flattened, so it's up to you whether it fits your dog. They do love it and it digests well. It contains poultry as the main ingredient, which is a problem for a lot of dogs, and one of mine can't have it. If your dog can tolerate it, this is an excellent food to feed him or her. It costs more, but it's not bad when quality matters. Definitely recommended!

I was very surprised by how well and how quickly this Honeywell heater works! It heats up very quickly and it's easy to control the heat level. I used this in a 12x16 room and it worked well. It heated smaller rooms quicker, of course. No matter where I put it, I was happy with the results. This heater also offers a lot of good features, with very little to complain about.My heater smelled bad at first, almost like burning plastic, but more chemical - if that makes sense. I inspected the unit and everything seemed fine, so I waited until the next day and turned it on while I could use a window fan to suck the air out. Once whatever it was burned off, it didn't emit anymore odors.It's not perfectly quiet, but I wouldn't call it noisy. The fan helps heat the room quickly, and the sound level is easy enough to tune out. I'm okay with that. You can turn the oscillator on or off as needed.I really, really like the timer. I feel safer knowing it's going to shut off after a set time. I tested it a few times and it really did shut off, no problems. The motion sensor is also a nice feature and would be helpful if you have children running around, or fearless dogs.This heater comes with a very small remote control. I can see where that would be handy under certain circumstances. Personally, I prefer to get up and move my body when I can, so I put the remote away. It's very small and would be easy to lose anyway. I wish they made small remotes in fluorescent colors!Overall, I'm very pleased with this heater. I haven't had a ceramic heater since the early 80s and it barely put out enough heat to warm a closet. I was pleasantly surprised at how well this heater works. It's packed with features, it doesn't take up much space, and it's efficient. Recommended.

This food is for Tank. He's big, he's bold, and he'll eat anything. He is getting older and his dietary needs are changing. He digests this food very well and he seems satisfied with it. I trust the brand, Solid Gold produces very high quality foods that are safer than imported pet foods. We've used various Solid Gold pet foods over the last 10 years, depending on our pets needs at the time, and our vet said he likes the brand as well. Overall, it's a high quality food. Their stools are more compact and less smelly, and that's always a plus and usually a good sign of diet quality. We would easily recommend this dog food.

Our cats love this cat food! They eat it as well as any other food they've tried. It digests well for them and they seem happy. I'm a big fan of the Solid Gold brand, it's been a part of our lives for the last 10 years. Our vet said he thinks it's a good choice as well. This particular variety is gluten free and grain free, and that's not something I ever thought about for cats. I don't know if it matters to them or not, but they are healthy and happy cats. I'm very comfortable with the quality of ingredients in this brand, and in this flavor. It's produced in the United States from high quality ingredients, so it's going to cost more than imported foods that potentially carry more risks. It's a good food, the cats like it, and they are healthy.

I've gone through a few retractable leads over the years. The cords shred and snap, or they cease to recoil properly. To be honest, I've always bought cheap leads and I had never compared them to higher quality models.  This lead is for my 8lb chihuahua, who recently broke her lead after spotting a squirrel.When I pulled this Amigo lead out of the package, I instantly noticed a difference. This lead feels more solid and well made than my old leads. The tape glides out very smoothly, and it retracts quickly and quietly. The stop button works perfectly and holds the tape at the correct length without any effort or slipping. The button even has a rubber tip so it's non-slip and easier to press. Before taking my dog outside with it, I pulled the tape all the way out and tugged hard to make sure it was secure, and I felt confident that it would hold Olive back.I have the small size lead and the tape is about 1/2 inch wide. It looks similar to satin ribbon, but it appears to be thicker and very tightly woven. It feels very strong. The swivel hook on the end spins easily, and it hooks into her harness and holds strong. Olive wears a Ruffwear Web Harness and I've had trouble finding a lead with the right size hook, they can be too large or too small. This one fits perfectly.The handle of the Amigo is easy to grip and it fits my hand well. I like the Mountain pattern, it makes her lead easy to spot in a pile of other pet supplies. It's not too bulky, so it can slide into my purse if necessary.Overall, I'm very pleased with this lead. I know I'll need more soon, for my other dogs, and I'd like to buy more Amigo leads. I have a feeling they will need replacing much less often.

I intended to write my review after 3 weeks of following the Brain Fog Fix plan, but as I read the book, I quickly realized that I already do everything in this book. I made these changes a few years ago, and they worked incredibly well for me. I'll explain that at the end of my review. I chose this book because my elderly mother saw it discussed on a daytime talk show, and she asked me to buy it and help her follow the plan. Mom has dementia and doesn't realize that she doesn't have the type of brain fog described in this book. The book does discuss dementia, and overcoming brain fog can be helpful in pushing back the onset of dementia for some people. However, my mother is not the target audience for this book. Of course, she doesn't realize that.I had this book in my cart for two weeks, as I was on the fence about it. I was not familiar with Dr Dow because I don't watch daytime TV or reality programming, which he is apparently known for. I wasn't sure if the book would be a wise investment. I accepted the book through Vine, and I'm glad I did. Overall, I believe this book can help many people, and I am living proof that the methods described can make a real difference in ridding brain fog and becoming more productive.This book was written for those of us who have ever fallen into the trap of eating processed foods while ignoring nutrient rich vegetables, and have forgone activity for lives of convenience, or lack of time or energy. The choices we make have a strong bearing on how our brains function, and brain fog is an all too common side effect of the Standard American Diet and lifestyle. These choices can also predetermine our future brain health, which is probably something most of us don't think about. We have more power and control than we realize.What's in the 3 week plan? The first week involves dietary changes. Take out everything that may cause brain fog, and replace it with foods that improve it. It's stringent, but also very flexible. Anyone can do it. You'll also work on improving your mood. You can loosen up a little on the diet the second week, but you will increase activity, improve sleeping habits, and learn new things to stimulate your brain. The third week is called a spirit revolution. There are many options, including religion, meditation, a connection with nature, or even political awareness.None of the advice in this book is ground-breaking, and it can all be found elsewhere from very reputable medical websites.  However, it is very helpful to have it consolidated in one place, especially to someone who hasn't taken the time to search through multiple resources. This book is also written in a manner that is very easy to follow and understand. The book includes many case studies that help explain how this information can help those that put it to use.  I know that this works, and that brain fog can be cleared up if we are willing to make changes to our diet and lifestyle.Brain fog caused me to float through my days in a near stupor, never really getting anything accomplished. I'd forget why I went into the next room. I had trouble concentrating. If you are considering this book, you already know how badly brain fog can affect your life. A few years ago, I started choosing food based on nutrients, not cravings. I chose the most colorful, nutrient dense vegetables and fruits available. I chose lean proteins, and high fiber foods. I cut way back on grains, and I gave up all added sugar as well as artificial ingredients. I cooked from scratch, giving up processed foods. I began exercising, working up to an hour a day on the treadmill. I discovered meditation, although it was difficult to master at first. Once I did, it made me feel incredibly relaxed. I became more social. I studied a second language. The result of these changes was a brain that was on fire!  My energy levels went through the roof, and I even felt more confident.By the way, I am in my 50s. I'm a grandmother, I work full time, and now I even help take care of my elderly mother.  I'm a very busy person, but I found the time to plan and make these changes. It DOES take time and effort to improve our lives, but it doesn't have to be difficult.  The quick results provide all the incentive you need to keep going. The Brain Fog Fix offers real advice for real people. It's do-able.Mom isn't going to get better, but we are going to walk her through the steps in this book. Maybe it will help slow down the progression of her dementia, maybe it won't. But it will give her hope, and that can greatly improve each day, one day at a time.I would definitely recommend this book to anyone who is struggling with brain fog, or who has a loved one that needs help.

I'm a big fan of Solid Gold pet food, so I was surprised to be disappointed in this variety. I found 3 issues with this dog food, although the quality is high and most dogs will benefit from eating it.Problems:1. Not just fish, it contains turkey2. Kibble size isn't really for all sizes as claimed3. Carnitine content useless for weight loss, as claimed on package.1. The front of the Fit and Fabulous package advertises 'fresh caught Alaskan pollock' while the back of the package lists a variety of healthy ingredients. It wasn't until I received the package and examined the side of the bag that I learned turkey meal is a prominent ingredient in this mixture. Like many dogs, one of my chihuahuas has a poultry allergy. I've come to depend on fish based dog food to help him feel normal and healthy. I think turkey should be included on the front and back of the label.2. The package says this variety is good for any size dog. Maybe it should say good for most sizes of dogs. My other chihuahua is very tiny and this kibble is too large for her to eat. Each piece is about 1/2 inch square. That's not a big issue, just a quibble.3. Package claims l-carnitine additive will help weight loss. However, the amount contained is negligible. According to Chow Hounds: Why Our Dogs Are Getting Fatter -A Vet's Plan to Save Their Lives- Small dogs (under 20lb) should be dosed at 250mg twice daily, and dogs 20-40 pounds 500mg twice daily..  This package contains 25mg per kg of food, and the bag weighs 1.81kg. Your dog could eat the entire bag in one sitting and still not get a day's dose of carnitine.All of that aside, I'm fostering a schnauzer who will eat anything. He LOVES this food. It digests well, but to be honest he doesn't have trouble digesting anything. So far, he's gobbling it up without any complaints. I feel good about giving it to him because the quality of Solid Gold is very high.If your dogs have a poultry allergy, avoid this food. If your dog has a tiny mouth, he may not be able to eat it comfortably. Otherwise, this may be the right food for your dog.

This humidifier is different from others I've owned in past years. It's evaporative, so it doesn't create a visible mist in the air. The unit is super quiet and it operates very simply. Setting it up was a breeze and the directions were on the box flap. The manual includes further information, such maintenance and safe usage. It requires a filter which must be replaced every now and then, so there will be an additional cost in using this model. The manual includes tips for making your filter last longer, such as turning it over and also drying it out when not in use.So far, I'm impressed with this model. It's very quiet and it's efficient, and it truly helped prevent dry mouth in the night for me. The filter is a great idea since it helps ensure the mist is clean and germ free. You can't put Vicks salve in the tank like Mom did when I was a kid, but the VapoPads seem convenient. However, they can get costly. The product description says the unit comes with two pads, one in each scent. Mine only came with one menthol pad, so I'll have to buy the lavender rosemary pads separately. I didn't try the menthol pad because my chihuahuas sleep in the same room with us. There seems to be conflicting information out there on whether menthol is safe for dogs to inhale, and one of my dogs is in poor health and it isn't worth the risk. I'll look forward to trying the lavender rosemary pads. I would love to see a reusable pad that can use essential oil for a more cost effective option.Like most people, I grew up with a Vicks humidifier and it got a lot of use every winter. Mom would spoon a small dollop of Vicks salve into the water and it would scent the room. Our humidifier lasted over a decade before it was lost in a move, it was very well made. I had one in my home when my son was growing up, and eventually gave it to him when he had his first child. I hope the new models are made as well. This particular model is lightweight and seems durable. If it bites the dust, I'll update my review accordingly.

These gloves are great! They are stretch without breaking and are stronger than we expected. The black color is a little odd for a glove, but it's easy to distinguish them from other gloves in our garage. We chose the XXL size because not everyone in our family has small hands. They fit well without being too tight. They go on and off easily and they can be reused, depending on what you do when you wear them. The nitrile material smells a little strange, but it's not overpowering and it airs out quickly. Overall, these are really good gloves.

This gate is short, light weight, designed very simply, and it looks nice. Even better, it works very well! Nothing has to be screwed into the wall, so it's totally portable.It arrived mostly assembled, and all I had to do was slip the four bumpers into each corner. I was initially concerned because I thought they screwed in, but they just slide into the holes. Then you simply turn the knobs to slightly increase the space and push them against the door jam to hold the gate in place.The gate size adjusts with knobs that screw into predrilled slots and it can fit a doorway up to 44 inches wide. It's very easy to loosen the bumpers to remove the gate and tuck it away when it isn't needed.If you want your pets to roam freely, but don't want to remove the gate, you can open the little door and let them go back and forth. It opens easily with a spring loaded knob. I have two chihuahuas and only one would walk through the gate. The other thought the bar across the bottom was still a barrier, so she wouldn't cross it. Your mileage may vary.I've tried several pet gates over the years, but always went back to a simple locking bar baby gate, even though it was a hassle to climb over at times. This little walk over gate is the solution I've been looking for. The size is perfect, it has a clean and simple appearance, and it works well. After examining the workmanship of the gate, I believe it will last a long time. I'm happy with it.

This beautifully written story details the sad and jarring lives of a few children whose lives took an unexpected turn at an early age. The author takes us through the many layers of their history which lead to their current situation in a mental hospital. This book is about more than the two sisters, there are other characters who also share their past, present, and future.I found myself absorbed into the pages of this book and looked forward to each chapter until it was finished. I enjoyed the author's style as she brought every detail to life, and I felt the emotions of each character. The book is filled with pain, but always tinged with hope. I thought I knew how their story would end, but I was taken by surprise. The ending didn't provide complete closure, but it ended on a note that was satisfactory.The book is recommended for ages 12 and up, but I would feel more comfortable recommending it for slightly older children. Fortunately, most children are not exposed to the experiences these characters lived through. Even I, as a grandmother, cringed through the painful parts. I would recommend it for young adults and older teens who are drawn towards this type of novel. For the right crowd, I would easily recommend this book.

I've been using an Epson XP-850 for over a year and am very happy with the performance. The XP-950 appealed to me primarily because it can print up to 11x17 prints. This is useful not only for photographs, but also signs and graphs for work. I also know that it will be very helpful for the grand-kids when they do their science projects, as we always either have to tape regular sheets together or get them printed at a local printer. The possibilities are endless, so I had to have it.Setup was super easy. My other model is connected to my Mac, so I decided to use this one with my PC. The software was easy to install and worked well with Windows 10. The touch screen display is easy to use and it walked me through the process. They make it all very simple, I think it would be hard to make a mistake.  Scanning is easy to use, and I like the folding top. It makes it easy to close and cover my documents without them slipping, so I get it right the first time.The photos that I printed came out very clear and gorgeous, with vivid colors or detailed black and white. I recently received a large box of old family photos, so I used this scanner to create high res scans. I used PaintShop Pro to correct and fine tune them, then I printed them with my new Epson. The detail was fantastic, and we were all impressed with the results. I now have a very large photo of my mother when she was a little girl in the 40s, and I'm going to frame it and give it to her for her 78th birthday this month. It was wonderful to be able to do this from home without sending it out and hoping for the best.

This weight bench is very solid and sturdy, and it offers a lot of features for a good workout. It was easy to put together, although it took some time and a partner is needed. The actual product varies slightly from the photo, which I'll describe below. Overall, assembling and using this bench has been a good experience. This is a substantial upgrade for me, because I've been using a small, portable bench. It takes up a decent amount of space, but it looks great, it's solid, and I can work every part of my body with it.The main photo for this model shows a smooth, solid black seat and back. The actual parts are gray and have a texture. If you scroll down to the 'design call outs' section, check the photo for the step in squat rack and zoom in. That's what this model looks like.The seat pad is ample and very comfortable. It measures 14 inches at the widest point, and it's 14 inches deep. It's approximately 2 inches thick. The seat consists of a wood base with padding, and vinyl cover. The top layer is stitched to the sides. The bottom is also stitched, and it also has a trim that goes around and has a metal piece that screws in to fasten it at the back of the seat. It's very well made.The backrest length is 29 inches. The width is 10 1/2 inches throughout most of the back, with it flaring out to 13 1/2 inches at the base. Also 2 inches thick with the same construction as the seat. It's comfortable and it offers support, and it feels very stable.The arm curl pad is large, measuring 20 inches at the widest point. It's about 11 1/2 inches deep, and shares the same construction as the back and seat.The rollers on the leg developer are dense foam with a vinyl cover. The cover is not sewn to the roller, each is made like a tube that is gathered on the ends. The foam core is visible at the center of each end.The frame is very heavy and sturdy. The metal is thick and the powder coating is high quality. The bench can fold up and back for more compact storage, which is helpful if you are limited on space.Total weight limit is 600 pounds which includes up to 300 pounds in weights and a person up to 300 pounds.You'll need to maintain this bench by occasionally lubricating all moving parts, and keep everything tightened.Overall, I am very happy with this weight bench. I go to a gym, but winter is coming and I've been considering setting up a more complete home gym. This is a great unit that beats my old bench, and it will offer a much more complete workout. Happy camper.

This cranberry hobnail glass hummingbird feeder is beautiful! It's much nicer in person, and we love it. The glass is thick and has an old-fashioned feel to it, but it's not terribly heavy. The base is lightweight, but it isn't dinky. The flower ports are all attached securely and in great condition, nothing is bent or out of shape.Measurements:* 8 1/2 inches tall without the wire hanger,* Base - 5 3/8 inch diameter* Glass is 3 3/4 inches diameter at widest pointTo fill the feeder, you turn it upside down and unscrew the base. The threads don't go all the way around, but they still hold it together without leaking. Just make sure you get it tightly back on. Unfortunately, the hummingbirds have migrated so I can't say how well they will like this feeder. We have good luck with hummingbirds in the summer, so I have no doubt that they will find it. I'm pleased with the quality of this feeder, and I love the appearance. I look forward to hanging it outside in the spring.

These gloves are very strong and comfortable. They go on easily and remove without tearing. I tried to puncture one by pushing my fingernail through but only ended up with a sore finger. The glove is tough! It feels a little bit thicker than the generic blue gloves I buy in 10-packs at the supermarket. The interior is smooth, and the exterior is slightly textured so I can grip items easily. Overall, I'm happy with these gloves.

Good quality faceplate, fits my Leviton switch perfectly. Mine had the screws with it, unlike some customers that seemed to be missing them. The faceplate fits snugly against the wall and is the right thickness for the switch, so it all lies as flush as possible. The finish is clean and smooth, and it looks great. I'm happy with it.

I really love these shoes, although they are not what I expected. Walking shoes are generally designed with support and shock absorption to help when walking for fitness or for extended walking. These shoes are very lightweight, they bend easily, and the fabric is soft and just stretchy enough for them to feel good on my feet. The only reason I gave them 4 stars instead of 5 is that they are marketed as walking shoes. I don't feel that they have enough support in the sole to wear while walking for fitness. The soles are so thin and flexible that I can feel every bump on the road, plus the arch support is not as full as I would have liked. They are great to wear to the supermarket or at work. When I go to the park to walk for exercise, I like more support on my feet. For general wearing, I'm very happy with them.  I'm probably going to buy another pair in another color.

This razor is lightweight and easy to use. The results are just average, it doesn't really provide a closer shave than similar razors - or disposables. It works well for a razor in this price range, especially on fine, straight hair. If you have curly or coarse hair, you might want a rotary razor. This model maneuvers easily, has a lightweight design, but it doesn't feel dinky.About this razor:* 6 1/2 inches long* 2 1/2 inches wide at the head* 6.6 ounces* Charger/cleaner, when extended, is 9 inches height, 3 3/4 inches wide, and 3 1/2 inches deep.This model has a 10,000 RPM motor. The more expensive models from Panasonic have up to 14,000 RPM while a couple of lower priced Panasonic models have 13,000 RPM. Not all of the models advertise their RPM. At the time I checked, there were 24 different models currently available from Panasonic. I'm not sure why there has to be so many, but it should be easy to find what you need.I honestly think this razor is easier to clean without the dedicated cleaner. It rinses of easily under running water. Plus the cleaner takes up quite a bit of space on the bathroom counter. We can tuck it under the vanity when not in use, but it will likely stay there unused.Overall, we like this razor, but we don't love it. It's better than some we've owned in the past, but it's not the highest quality. It's easy to use, does a good job, offers a close shave, it isn't too loud, and it feels like it will last a long time. We would both recommend it.

This little oven is a lot of fun to play with. The oven and the accessories have rounded edges, so there's nothing to hurt if your little one falls on anything. The size is just right, and I love how everything stores inside the oven. It's interactive, not too loud, the sounds are not annoying, and it's good and sturdy.It's designed to help teach a few numbers and simple equations to toddlers, and it makes learning fun and effortless. I see one missed opportunity - While pizza and cupcakes are a lot of fun, why not add in some roasted vegetables? Teaching kids that healthy food is also fun can help foster better eating habits.We've been playing with this with our granddaughter for about a month and it's still fun. She zooms right over to it when she comes to see us a few times a week. We have similar toys, but she seems to be fixated on this one. It's been a big hit in our house!

This little owl nightlight soother by Skip Hop is so cute! I love the clean, modern design, it can fit in with so many themes. The wings are the speakers, which is a creative idea that's also adorable. It works just as nicely as it looks! The buttons on the back of the owl are clearly marked and easy to figure out. They are a bright green color that is modern and fresh. There are also 4 green non-skid pads on the bottom of the owl, to help keep it in place. The light can be dimmed by pressing a button on the back, so you can choose how bright you want it. It's never very bright, but you can make it very dim if you prefer. There's also a volume control button. It has a timer that can let you run the sound for up to an hour, so you don't have to worry about turning it off later. The musical tunes are nice, but I really like the nature sounds better, especially the rainforest. I wouldn't mind having this in my own room!  I would definitely recommend this little nightlight. It's the perfect gift for a baby shower, or to treat your own little one to something special.

These cups are great for when everyone comes over to watch the game, or for other friendly gatherings. They hold a decent serving of beverages and they fit well in the hand. They feel about the same as similar Hefty disposable cups. Thin, but sturdy. You can crush it with one hand if you want, but they won't collapse easily unless you intend to break it. The design holds up under hand washing a few times, but it will eventually wear off. They are disposable, but not necessarily recyclable. My local recycling center won't take them, and polystyrene plastic isn't accepted at a lot of recycling centers. Call your local center to make sure they take this type of plastic before tossing them into your recycling bin, so you don't accidentally contaminate the batch. As a Hefty cup, these are great and the college sports design makes them unique and perfect for the right occasion. Recommended.

I am super impressed with this LeapPad! It's well made, offers a lot of features, and it's easy to use. She loves it, and even I am having fun with it! The colors are bright, and the graphics are clear. The LeapPad feels very durable in my hands, and I believe it will survive any accidents that may occur. The stylus is attached and easy to hold, even for smaller hands. It can be unlooped and removed if needed. It was easy to set up and we had it running in just a couple of moments after it was charged.Although the description says it's good for ages 3-9, there are games available for as young as 2. For the younger kids, this is an excellent tablet. You know exactly what is installed on it, so you can feel safe when they use it. I didn't test any games for older kids, so I don't know how they compare to the educational games you might find on a more robust tablet. It's not a Kindle or an iPad, but it's not supposed to be. It's a very dedicated little tablet that offers plenty of educational games and fun, and they are all fully supported by LeapFrog. I'm not comfy sharing my iPad or Kindle with the little ones because they can damage it - plus they are grown up toys and the distinction is important in our home. And again, it's safe because it can only accept LeapFrog apps.The games may seem a little pricey, but I think that's because we've become accustomed to so many apps that are free or cost 99 cents, and sometimes not even worth that. The LeapFrog games are designed specifically by the company and are fully supported.
